text: Oy. This place is pretty bad. The food I believe is all frozen. Nowhere to park. Not very unique. Not much more to say.
Yummy, but kind of expensive for what it is.

This is a cool, little restaurant in Harvard Square.  We popped in one night and were delightfully surprised by the joint.  The thin crust pizza is really good and well-priced.  We were happy that we ate and each had a beer for right around $25!  The atmosphere is nice and casual.

this review is only for the restaurant.

i'd been wanting to come here for a year! every time i drive by, i think, hmm, you look fun, middle east. let's hang.

but...from the very beginning, i felt like the waitress wasn't into me. i tried to lighten the mood with a josh or two... but she wasn't playin. she barely came around, and when she did, questions were barked and we timidly answered, "uh.. the fool and the chicken shawarma?" - she grabs the menus and walks away. it had the potential to be endearing- who doesn't like to fight for a brusque waitress's love?

the real issue of the evening was the pita bread. it came in a bag... and as i flipped it over, i was shocked to see that the bottom pieces were green. not just a spot of mold, but down right furrified. 

i call the waitress over and say, "is that mold?" ... she grabs it and walks away. no "whoops! my b, y'all!" or "dang!!!" just rips it out of my hands! 

she comes back several minutes later with more pita and says she's sorry... but by this point i kiiiiinda already internally vomited. plus, my friend's chicken was bland and stringy. he felt like it wasn't fresh meat.

i feel like most restaurants would comp my meal. they didn't even ask. sure, the prices are right ( $6-11) and the menu itself has fun items... but i won't ever eat there again... that furry pita will always be in my mind.

Where should I start....awesome food (Havarti Sandwich with a side of Bacon), drinks (fav place for Sangria) , coffee and its salute to old-school and underground music.  

I've been coming to SIP for over a year now and I am completely addicted to pretty much everything about it, while I kinda want to keep it to myself I also want to tell the word about it.  That being said stop by and enjoy one of the last NY gems.

Oh did i mention the bacon.  ;)

For some reason, I always get horrible service at this BWW,  much worse than the one in Novi or even the Ypsi one.  If you're going on a game day, be prepared to come early or wait for bit because it gets crowded...unfortunately i like their wings...the caribbean jerk and spicy garlic are tops on my list...the atmosphere's pretty normal for a bar...loud during sporting events and relatively tame on other nights...

If i was basing my review on service, i'd give it a 2/5 but just the wings i'd give it a 4/5 because of the variety and the cheaper prices on certain days.
Shitty atmosphere. The workers start putting up the chairs an hour before closing time. The food is absolutely nothing special and certainly overpriced.

Pixel Lounge is a great bar. 

Now, I often don't call things "great", because I believe compliments are unhealthy and encourage a mindset wherein people have to be given thorough dressing-downs and then proper de-corkings to get all the smoke out of all their asses. 

However, the Pixel does deserve the praise. The bartender, who I believe was named James Dean, was a rather spectacularly understanding chap when it came to me and one of my friends slightly inebriated antics, and the drink selection was a marvelous little stroll through sci-fi in-references.

I believe the highlight of my time at the Pixel Lounge was inciting a rather raucous laugh from everyone there when I became convinced of which Charlton Heston film was being projected onto one of the walls, only to see a starship and exclaim "I don't recall their being that many space-ships in Ben-Hur!". Quite the memory.  

Also, last place I hung out in Ithaca before I departed. I've still got one of their "next drink half-off" tokens on my wall, as a personal memento. 

So I'll recommend the Pixel lounge to any nerd who wants to get shitfaced and play Ms. Pac-Man for free.

Oh, I didn't mention that part?

We bought our "tickets" to the comedy club online with Groupon. (Two admittance for $10) 
I thought it would be a deal, but I also thought this was a legitimate comedy club. We get there to find the 10 o'clock show will be starting at about 10:30 and they don't have alcohol. Honestly? Is that not a huge requirement for a comedy club? Especially with a bunch of unknowns. 

But to make it worse, as others have said was the TWO ITEM minimum, and the prices of a soda $4 a bottle of tea $6 or the "deal" of three items for $10, so as the attendant put it "only $20 for two people" Sorry, not going to be raped. 
WE just left and came home to watch bad TV, certain we were still happier than if we stayed for the show.

NEW news, the main office called me back and offered us free admission to the Burbank facility. I appreciate their offer and look forward to trying again, even if it is a further drive. (I still would never return to the Claremont location)

I came to this best buy for one reason, and one reason only... I wanted the pink instinct mobile phone. I know they came out with the new bronze colour, but it's really not my thing. 

The staff is very friendly, and the girl that helped me Natasha made everything very easy when setting up my new mobile service. Which is always a bit of a headache, but we were out of there within 20 mins... NICE!

geez, how come this place has only 3 1/2 stars?? well, it's my fave Italian restaurant in pasadena. it's owned by the drago family and it is also their most economically priced restaurant. most entrees are $12-$16 dollars and most of the pasta's are made fresh daily. i've been there many times and everything i've ordered has tasted delish! my fave is the spaghetti with fresh sardines and fennel.

i usually try to cut my own hair or go to douglas j aveda because it's cheaper - but i decided to try new age salon after my friend recommended it.  the lady who cut my hair was chinese - she spoke mandarin to me.  she was very nice.  she immediately started wetting my hair with a spray bottle (no hair washing) and cutting my hair.  i've never had my haircut so fast - 10 minutes.  she gave me layers and nice bangs.  and the best part - it was only $16!

i'm not really picky  but i do think it is hard to cut asian hair.  but i think she did a pretty good job.  i'll go back!

Overrated. It's just an iceberg lettuce salad, which is fine if that is what you are looking for. The lettuce wasn't even that fresh. The other ingredients, though few, were tasty.  And the staff were super friendly, so they have that going for them.

I must say I was impressed by this place. Not so much the service - that was par, but the beers and foodstuff were great! My table ordere a few beers while we waited to be seated - each sampled one of the microbrews and they were all really good - I particularly enjoyed the Imperial Stout, though like most stouts I probably wouldn't be able to drink more than one of those without feeling full.

French Onion Soup - good cheese/bread/soup ratio, though the broth was super salty.
Hummus Plate - I liked that they had a spicey relish on top - gave it a good kick
Hangar Steak (subbed salad for shoestring fries) - steak cooked perfectly and the salad had figs and goat cheese. Delicious, but I bet those parmesean fries would have been fantastic too!

Overall a good time - good atmosphere too. Will probably make another trip back and order the beer sampler!

Awkward lesbian couples. People who have clearly never been to a real pool hall. EF employees who still desperately want to think they're hip and/or with "it" (or any once-hipster, now 9-5 corporate cheezeball who still has faith in their coolness, which is waning as fast as their hairline). And one dude who sat diagonal from me and wouldn't stop scratching his "junk". This seems to make up much of the clientele at Flat Top Johnny's. 

Not that this is a bad thing. In fact, these are very likely the type of people who want a pool hall that feels safe, friendly, and inclusive. And I include myself in that very broad category. 

I didn't play any pool when I came in, but the facilities appeared well maintained. I came in for dinner, the place was full but not crowded, and we quickly got a seat. I ordered a quesadilla and a Caesar salad, both of which were very tasty. I came in again the next night and ordered a burger, which was pretty lackluster. Bun was cold, cheese wasn't really melted. Offering chips seems like a lame cover for not having a deep fryer. 

However, I give this place 4 stars because the food and environment the first night was very good, I could see myself playing pool there at some point, and when I came in the second night, I was able to do exactly what I wanted--grab a table, order dinner and a few beers, and be left alone while I read Venus in Furs, a kinda boring, fairly weird novel about masochism in the late 19th century. I like a place where I can hang out and get my shiz done without interruption.

*Quesadilla Review* I eat a lot of quesadillas, so I think they need their own review. This quesadilla was an 7.5. Maybe an 8. It was made of very shredded chicken. I liked this though, because it allowed the meat to be evenly spread throughout the quesadilla (instead of in diced chicken chunks). It was even a bit spicy, which I appreciated because many are very bland. However, spicy is not necessarily flavorful. The platter came with sour cream, guacamole, and salsa, which are staples I hate to pay extra for. Would eat again.

For a quick-serve dining place, I thought it was pretty good. We went there on a Friday night with a couple of friends, and the place was just moderately filled with patrons. I remember having the Max's Grilled Chicken Sandwich with fries, and thinking the sandwich was huge! But it's one of those you think you can tackle but when you're 1/2 way through the second 1/2 of the sandwich, you realize you might've been better off saving the latter portion and taking it to go...but then you reluctantly go ahead and finish it but are incredibly stuffed after it, lol.

Would think about going back.

Perks:
-- Chill atmosphere
-- Outdoor seating
-- Decent price

This review comes from the heart. 
I have learned more about myself, my body, yoga, and the importance of breath as a student of Lee's in the past couple of months than I have in hundreds of hours of traditional group yoga classes over the years. (And those group classes were top notch!) Lee is highly intuitive and seems to always know exactly what I need when I need it yet he doesn't take himself too seriously. He has the unique skill of knowing when to push and when to be gentle... and always takes the time to learn about what's going on in my life and teaches accordingly. He is one of the most present individuals that I know and I'm amazed at how many breakthroughs I've experienced in my practice already. As an extra bonus Lee is always on time! Well worth the cost of private instruction.
A scoop of ice cream between two *warm* cookies for $1.50. Open until 2am on weekends. This place must be run by either God or Satan, and I don't think I care which one it is.

I get lunch here with friends fairly often.  The food is diner quality, so stick with sandwiches.  The coffee is bad.  The wait staff is very friendly, and it's a nice cozy spot to chat over lunch for an hour.

This place has my favorite sushi in ann arbor.  The menu is huge, so you can select from whatever you want. Also the first time I went here the amazing sushi chef gave us a roll on the house because I was new to the sushi world, and it was amazing. Great place go check it out, plus I hear they have sushi happy hour sundays, 20% off your bill, you can't pass it off.
This is the classic Telegraph Ave. head shop- this one- right here.  Stop at this one if you have some head shop requirements.

I have fond memories of Peet's in Pasadena.  I had a blogger date with one of my favorite people there.  Oh good times.

The coffee is always good.  Solid strong coffee.  I can drink it black without adding any modifiers.  

It's not just coffee that makes a good coffee shop.  It's got to be a place that you can study or just chillax with friends.  It's got to be a good chat and sip type of place.  This location has ample seating.  The baristas don't eye you once you've finished your cup of java.  I can sit in my chair and enjoy my caffeine high while jabbering with a friend.  I like that.  No rush. No pressure.

I think one commenter mentioned that it's a pretty white crowd.  Uhm, DUH... we're talking South Pasadena here.  I didn't mind.  Everyone was friendly.  A few people even started up a conversation with me.

I remember the last time I went in, I was unsure about the green tea limeade.  The barista gave me a sample.  Not some tiny flimsy cup but a full small size cup.  That made me feel all snugly inside.

It keeps getting better -- on site parking!!!!!!!!!!!!!

$0.30/ounce. 1lb of yogurt & toppings for $5: I'm there.

Way better than Pinkberry or Blush.

They have compostable spoons but not cups, which doesn't make much sense.

Disclaimer: I've done SAT prep for Kaplan since 2001.

Now that that's out of the way, let me tell you why this place rocks.  The office staff is friendly and they know what they're talking about.  The methods are sensible (not full of tricks/gimmicks) and based on things students have already encountered in school.  They offer a money-back guarantee on some programs.  They update their books every single year, if not more often.  There are online resources, video resources, and all kinds of classes for nearly every standardized test out there.

SAT-specific reasons: every tutor has to score in the 95th percentile or above to work at this location, undergo 16 hours of supervised training, and pass an extreme training gauntlet.  I've seen dramatic score increases from most of my students, which is the biggest reason I've continued to work here.

I rarely see any grumpy faces leaving the Kaplan center, so I figure they're doing something right.  The center is always full, too - I know some students just come here to study because they like the environment.
Ming's Cafe is the best place in Austin to get fresh and unique Chinese Cuisine.

I like Pinkberry. I don't like Red Mango.

Red Mango is too creamy and not tart enough. The fruit isn't fresh and the berries are always squished. And, I'd rather not eat yogurt in a place where everything's decorated in brown and red - those colors do not make fooding appealing to me.

Go to Pinkberry instead, in the land of Ikea products and neon colors!

Anytime the ex-bf wanted to purchase a unique piece of jewelry for me he used to buy it  from here for any occasions. So  when it was over (the relationship) I found myself still coming here looking for simple unique gift ideas for friends and my daughter.

The customer service here is ALWAYS impeccable they are attentive, creative and accommodating. It's located in downtown Claremont and it is a family owned and ran business. They send out cards for birthdays and reminders for any event they are having as well as if they have a new designer on staff. 

I recently purchased an item from them that was from an estate sale... it was a gift and in wonderful condition the piece was unique and the cost was well below what I expected.

Respectfully Reviewed

Paladora is the lounge at the Houston Marriott Medical Center.  In it I met a fellow soon-to-be Boston Marathon runner and another math teacher, and saw several rodeo attendees.  I liked the subtly classy decorations, the Lone Star beer, nice service, and Mini Mo sliders.  Chomp!
Grabbed a beef and chicken taco from the Calbi truck. Neither were particularly good. They didn't really taste like Korean tacos either - more like regular Mexican.
Nice little theater to see the latest Sundance selection. Tickets aren't too bad (7.50 - 9.50), and it's a nice walk from my apartment in Smith Hill over to Thayer.

It's hard not to give this place and extra star just for sentiment. Honestly Ritters is a favorite of mine. I love diner food. If you're looking for a late night, drunken fourth meal, this is your place. If you just want a no frills, greasy spoon, Saturday brunch, Ritters is there for you.

This place is blocks from where I live which makes it even better for me, and it is open 24 hours! One of the only places in town, or at least on the East End that holds that title. Perfect for those of us that frequent Bloomfield, Shadyside and Lawrenceville for late night fun. I can't tell you how many times in group of friends looking to satisfy their drunk munchies (or otherwise) in the wee hours that RITTERS!! is shouted. It's there, it's open and ready to serve you anything from it's extensive menu of diner food. 

It's also good anytime, to go in and watch the old yinzers on a Saturday morning, drink their coffee, read the paper and just being so Pittsburgh. Served by waitresses in their nurse scrubs that always call you 'hun.'

The food - I have never had a problem with the food. I love breakfast and I don't think I have gotten anything else here. I think maybe my sunnyside eggs were undercooked once - but that has happened to me at really nice restaurants too, and eggs just seem to be something that is done wrong fairly often. I think their hotcakes are pretty darn good and that is my go-to meal. A great hangover cure, always.

This place is awesome!  It's tucked away in the food court across the street from the DMV, right before you enter the 110 freeway.  I have heard so  many good things about it, I was excited to try it out.  

The owners are super friendly and will explain their entire menu to you.  i had the cochinita pibil, which came with delicious rice, bean, and hot homemade tortillas.  The pork was tender, and everyone was well-seasoned (not too salty or too bland).  I was most impressed with the cleanliness and simplicity of the food.  It wasn't heavy or greasy at all!  I would definitely come back.

It's hard to vote for what I hate most about Harvard Square: the parking (or lack there of), the clueless students who think they have the whole world figured out, the dirty restaurants (Charlie's Kitchen/The Greenhouse/Mr. Bartley's/Just about everything in the Garage), the permanent beggars parked directly across from the RICHEST school in the entire world, the independent intellectuals who drive Volvos but still think they're better than you because they buy their coffee at the local shop instead of Starbucks.  If you like dirty hypocrites, shitty food, blatant elitism, $40 parking tickets and "culture" then you'll love Harvard Square.

Not too impressed. It was my first time there and since I was clearly not familiar with the menu, I figured that the guy working the counter would be a little more patient and/or helpful especially since nobody else was ordering at that time, but he wasn't. Instead of staring at me while I tried to decide, what he could have done was tell me that they were out of chicken and that they don't serve roast beef anymore BEFORE I tried to order them. 

I ended up ordering the smoked salmon panini which was just ok...I'm still not sure how I feel about smoked salmon being pressed. My bf had the panini with prosciutto and some other cold cuts, also just ok. Please note that almost every single panini includes a lot of pesto so if pesto is your thing, this place may be for you.

Update: I added a star because the owner was nice enough to contact me to let me know that the person who waited on me usually doesn't work the counter but that they were short staffed that day. We all have off days I guess.

Great atmosphere, location, service and menu.  I recommend the key-lime martini.

The only issue is the music is too loud.  There is no reason to have the volume on the sound system turned to the max position.  The place is small enough that the performers really don't need a microphone.

I really didn't think this was a great place, cause even the Borders was more smiley than this, and they're going OUT OF BUSINESS! But I have to admit, there were pretty cool things about this place. There was a Starbucks on the second floor, and yes, it was a 2-story store. There was also some free Wi-Fi, and a mezzanine. But the employees kinda runied it for me. They weren't as perky or nice or friendly or social as other B&N stores or Borders. But overall, it was pretty okay. I liked it... my son got Diary of A Wimpy Kid and I got a subscription to Motor Trend magazine.

I'm so happy I finally found a place near me where I can get Sesame Balls everyday of the week. Thank you Yum Yum Cha Cafe!  Merci!

I've been meaning to stop by this place many times, but opportunity never allowed.  There was actually a large UYE (Unofficial Yelp Event) half a year ago, but I couldn't make it.  I vowed to go one day.  A few days ago, when Ken W got an ROTD (Review of the Day) for the restaurant, I couldn't get Dim Sum off my mind.  I was actually shopping in the Village that same day (completely by accident...that's a lie), and as I was driving home, noticed my car had parked itself a half-block away from Yum.  By the time I came out of my trance, I was sitting at a table near the register reading newspaper articles on the wall.

Apparently the thirty seat restaurant is owned and run by a daughter-father team.  How awesome is that?!  Also, there are no carts that are wheeled around; you order from a menu.  They cook what you want, then bring it to your table.  No food kept warm by Sterno.  Hot, not lukewarm Dim Sum.  But most importantly, this not cooking for the masses means I can get Dim Sum any day of the week.

Not to be snobbish, but disregard what most other negative reviewers say about this place because its greatness all boils down to a few simple points.  First let me just get one point out of the way, Houston's Dim Sum scene in "New Chinatown" is not stellar.  As Becky points out, no place I know has griddles in the carts.  Back to Yum, the Dim Sum is good; for the most part, it's made to order, so it takes a while for your order, but it tastes fresh.  If you live not so near "New Chinatown," this place is convenient.  If you want Dim Sum at any other time than for Sunday brunch (did you just hear a number of people rolling over in their graves, as well?), here is your place.  Oh, and most importantly, if you are feeling a little peaky after shopping in the Village all day, here's a great place to grab a rather inexpensive meal.

YUM!

I just got back from visiting my friends and this was one of the places they took me. They obviously are obsessed with this place, as their dog is named...Gordo. Fantastic, reasonably priced burritos. Everything tasted super fresh and I loved the selection of tortillas. After hiking around campus for a few hours, the burrito definitely hit the spot. I went with the carnitas, which the burrito maker chopped up fresh in front of me. 

If I'm in the area again, I will be stopping by!

Went here just to eat on valentines day. came out of the pocket 250 almost 300 for a 6 course dinner and on the table to the woman there was a $100 gift certificate to a jewelry store. the food was amazing, the atmosphere was romantic and we got to have a photo done in front of a fire place for free that you received at the end of the night in a nice little frame.. it was really a nice dinner.

I go here a lot as it's the closest grocery to my cribbbb.

It's an ok place... definitely has some pros and cons.  Lemme try and break em down for you.

PROS:
1. pre-seasoned chicken breasts and legs on the cheap.  For $1.50 I get a delicious cut of chiken that can feed 2 people!  I buy as many as possible whenever available.  Haven't seen these at any other Shaws/Star.
2. Validate yo parkin!  Spend over $10 here and you get free parking.  Dope!
3. Coke made with real sugar.  It really is better than wat you're used to.

That about does it for the pros.  

CONS:
1. Prices.  Noticeably higher than, for instance, Allston's Star Market.  I got a bag of chiken fingers here and then saw it in Allston the next day for 20% cheaper!  20 friggin percent!  omgwtf.
2. Selection.  SOMETIMES I WANT 72 slices of American cheese ine ONE box OK!?  Allston sells it!
3. A la carte stuff is suspect.  I haven't had lunch here, but their selection is weak.  The pizzas always look dry and/or burnt.  My roomie got a rotisserie chiken and said it was QUITE dry.  Shit.

So there are some key points for you.  Not bad, per se, but not good either.  Probably still cheaper than Whole Foods and TJ's tho.  I don't have the messenger bag, scruff, and fixed-gear bike required to shop at those places anyway.

Life would suck without Aladdin's. I often fantasize about taking a giant bite out of the rotating wad of gyro meat behind their counter. Their gyros are so huge and delicious that I could quite possibly eat myself to death from a platter of them. I really like their rice side too--it's a cup of rice with a blob of their magical gyro sauce on top (I wouldn't quite call it tzatziki since it tastes a bit different, but it's pretty close to tzatziki). 

In a nutshell, Aladdin's is cheap, ridiculously delicious, and an Ave essential. Go there and get your gyro on!

I love their combo boxes and sandwiches, very tasty and fresh.
And all those asian snacks are my favorites especially when I get homesick. You can also buy bubble tea powder, frozen dumplings, other asian materials and many different sauces to cook at home.

The atmosphere is so horrendous and smelly I find it kitchy.

It's a quirky little joint, Nasai Teriyaki, and it's well worth going. Excellent for take out, because you don't have to listen to 'Delilah' on Warm 106.9 while you eat and start at the stains in the carpet.
I find though, that's it's kind of fun to eat in this place. The sauce on their teriyaki is to die for. And he portions are gigantic. You could have two meals with amount they give you.
The ground beef in the tacos is gross. The chicken in their burritos is dry. The flavors just aren't good. Go to Chipotle!

Woah. This place is way nicer than the kitchen table I was tattooed on in New Hampshire 10 years ago. 

The staff is friendly, the pricing is fair and the location is perfect! 

Ellen is a great artist and totally provided one of the most relaxing experiences I've ever had under an electric needle.

;*)

This place is extremely overrated and I have no idea why it is such a Berkeley icon.

Three dollars for a decent hot dog?  You could get nachos right next door or a grilled burrito at Mario's for a similar price and be much more satisfied.

The service sucks.. the guy serving you is almost always rude, though I guess that fits the idea of a hot dog place.

The hot dogs here are not significantly better than what you would get at Costco, and they are a lot smaller.

You almost certainly could make a better hot dog yourself.

Seeing that there are like 500 five star reviews of this place blows my fucking mind.  People are saying its cheap?  I mean, I know most of the people reviewing this place are spoiled UC Berkeley kids buying stuff on their parents dime and used to paying way too much money for food and housing already.. but how can you say getting a pretty small hotdog and a fountain soda is a steal for 6 dollars?

That is insane.

I discovered Yelp back in late 2007. I had never heard of Yelp. I started using Yelp because I had just moved from Southwest Houston to North Houston and I had no clue what was out here other than the Woodlands mall and the new location of the company I work for. Ella and FM 1960? I had only heard of these places on the news usually because somebody was robbed, shot, or died from a gunshot wound because they were robbed. And now I lived out here. Where's a good sushi place? Where's a coffee shop (other than Starbuck's)? Where's Target? Where's Michael's? Where can I get banh mi? Boba tea? Where? 

Was Yelp helpful for this side of town? NOPE! Because all of the few Yelpers that existed in Houston only reviewed places either inside the loop or about a mile or 2 outside the loop. Damnit!!! Useless.  A few more months passed and I was getting a bit tiffed because there were still no reviews for the North side of town. So I finally wrote a review. 

And now today... I'm meeting other Yelpers for lunch bunches, Sunday brunches, and UYE's. I have yet been to an official Yelp event. Oh well. :( Someday. But at least I get to see them at other events. I met Gretchen, Shazia, Linh, and Eva L. for brunch here at Benjy's. I have yet to write a review of the places I've been for UYE's simply because it was the first time I had ever been to it. Or is it because others have already reviewed it and I need time to think about what I can possibly say that someone else hasn't already said? 

So my first impression of Benjy's? Wow... it's crowded. It was Sunday and also Father's Day. Good thing Gretchen and I decided to go early. The hostess looked like she was about to burst when we told her that we needed a table for 5. But since we were about an hour early, we were just going to sit at the bar and drink a cappuccino while we waited for our food or waited for a table for 5. Whichever came first. Surprisingly, after ordering the cappuccino, our table was ready. We were seated in the Lounge area upstairs. Nice. I liked that area the best. It wasn't as noisy. 

I ordered French toast. Tasty. It was crunchy because it had nuts. Interesting. I never had French toast with nuts. Pine nuts? Any who it worked. It came out pretty fast too. Cappuccino and French toast came out to $20. Ouch. But they included gratuity in the total, which in my opinion is the dumbest thing a restaurant can do because those who are in or who have been in the restaurant industry will tip more than your average Joe. Sometimes even at 20% or 25%. Knocked off a star for that alone. 

Service was good...enough. The waitresses were nice but very pretentious and they made me nervous. That's not a good thing either. I do understand that when restaurants are busy, they want people in and out. However, the larger the party, the longer they stay, the more they buy... hence, the more money they make so you need to pick on the smaller tables. Not the larger ones. 

I'll definitely come back here to try other things on the menu. I'll even come back with people from out of town who have never been here before. I think that's a bigger compliment to Benjy's than a 1-5 star rating system.

He gives a great haircut, spends a lot of time attending to your hair. He also frequently gives you a good back-of-neck shave.  He loves people and loves cutting hair. I highly recommend him. It is refreshing to go get your haircut in an old-school barbershop. He is also a joy to talk to because of his interesting life experiences in Europe and the U.S. Roadside parking on W. Peachtree St.

"Taste so good, make you want to slap yo mama"

John Witherspoon (Craig's Daddy) "Friday After Next" 2002
Only Vietnamese food around, so I guess that makes it the best around? Food is good, not great.

Here's a glimpse into my uninspiring youth on most Saturday afternoons:  Go to Telegraph, grab a veggie slice from Fat Slice, soak up as much grease as possible with napkins, and head out to the sidewalk to scarf it down while doing some people watching.

This is really as good as Shopper's gets at least in this area. It's like the Weggmans of Shoppers/ let me just start by saying I do not clip coupons. But to go into a Shoppers presumably because its already discounted. I can pickup produce that does'nt look like its been kicked around, the place is clean, good customer service--shout out to Ms. Mary and the crew, fresh seafood that you can put in your basket w/o a 5 second delay+ above average international foods section for a grocery store chain +Wine& Beer (Yes even in prohibition era Maryland). 

Bag it up honey, it's a one-stop shop for me.

every show I seem to hit at middle East is always overrun by bass coming from TT's - last night it was just the inverse.

cool venue, and I appreciate the bar is not overwhelmed by the music, just in case you want to chat during a band you ain't into.

Oh, Goody's. Named after late Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, this college dining joint/convenience market is one of the newest additions to UCSD's Never-ending Housing and Dining Extravaganza. I'm a second-year Marshall college apartment resident, so I depend on Goody's for many of my meals here on campus. I can say with confidence that the burritos and sandwiches are pretty satisfying and filling, too. The burrito station is a clear knock-off of Chipotle, but I have to say that, in options and size of average burrito (maybe even taste), it rivals the popular chain restaurant. They've even got vegetarian options and wheat tortillas upon request, which is nice.

As for the market downstairs (facing the small parking lot), they've pretty much got it down to a science. Everything from Oreos, loaves of bread, fruit, dish soap, cake mix, toenail clippers, and--wait--kombucha? Over the past year, UCSD H&D have made an effort (or were they pushed by environmental student orgs?) to bring organic, fair trade, all-natural, vegetarian 'health foods' into their cafeterias and convenience stores. This is great and all, but the one major problem I have with the market, especially, is the mark-up they put on their merchandise. Everything is severely overpriced. This is a gripe I have with the university in general, though. It's as if they use the perceived disconnect between dining dollars and 'real' dollars to their advantage. And, you know, the fact that on-campus residents are forced to get on a meal plan. 

Anyway, that's not to say I'm not grateful that I have a choice between Cheez-Its or Annie's Organic Bunny-shaped Snack Mix, or that I can now easily clean the kombucha spill in my double with Dr. Bronner's Pure-Castille Hemp Soap. Having a general idea of the student demographics here at UCSD though, you have to wonder--who are they marketing to?

Oh, and they've got a Starbucks.

I'm not even a coffee person but I work in the area and my coworkers told me about this place and I gave it a try.  It's pretty good ... it's your normal healthy soups, salads and sandwich kinda spot you'll find in  Claremont.  Everything is made fresh, great prices, healthy light meals and their vegan cookies are actually really good!  

I love the owner - he gets so excited when people come in ... although sometimes he gets a little sidetracked when a line forms he may forget some of your special requests while he's making them ... it's like he gets so giddy about all the people coming in he forgets you said no sprouts.  haha  but it's ok, the place is tiny, the staff is really friendly, he's charming and the food is good.  

For the summer he's doing cold soups - although I loved his hot soups I wish he would do one cold one hot!  And definitely give the vegan cookies a shot!  :)

Here is my take on Kabobs Express:

  \                /     give more than 3 stars. 
   \~~~~~~/      If you think this galss is half empty then you will probably

                        3 stars.

I tried:
--------
   1. Chicken:
                      Didn't really have any flavour. Their top secret marinade is lacking in flavours. 

   2. Minced beef:
                             Good, since beef is mixed with spices already. 
   
   3. Shrimp:
                     Not bad. 

Here is the ordering process:

If you're looking for a place to relax, have a good time and enjoy the great Mediterranean food Gypsy's can offer come here! First off, our server was super nice and attentive. She kept coming over to make sure we were okay and gave us plenty of refills. We ordered the peach flavored hookah which is one of my favorites there. We also ordered fries, hummus and kabobs and they were delish! They gave us cards to play too , I had a great time there!

A couple of my girls and I stopped by here after hanging at Mal's Bar on Saturday night so one of them could get her late-night pancake fix. 

The food is the same as every Denny's, but the service here is really good! The waiter we had was totally on point and brought out everything we could possibly need without us ever having to ask for anything. That's a plus, especially when you're a little too tipsy to remember to ask for ketchup and napkins. 

No one threw up gang signs at me like they do at Denny's in Carson so that's always nice. However, I don't know what it is with me and Denny's, but I always get hit on by the weirdest guys whenever I step foot inside one. No one ever spits game at me at IHOP or Norm's, but when I come here, there must be a sign over my head that says, "Hey you! Approach this girl in the most aggressive and creepiest manner ever!"

Just leave me and my chicken strips be!

This review is for Sharon. She took care of my eyebrows for 5 years while I lived in Pasadena. She is amazing and spends so much time making your brows look perfect with your facial features. She is such a sweetheart and fun to talk to also. Prices have gone up since they changed owners but she is worth it.

This place has great potential.  They were clearly unprepared for the Groupon onslaught.  We went the Saturday night after the Groupon was offered on the previous Thursday.  We made reservations for 8:45 pm but did not need them.

After we sat the apologetic server explained that they were out of quite a few things on the menu... like half the menu (no seriously half!).  Clearly management had no idea what they were in for with the groupon.

Everything is very reasonably priced, I was planning to have the seoul burger but they were out, my second choice (bahn mi) was also gone.  Ended up with the chicken, which had nice sides but was cooler than I like (my dining partner's fall flatbread was piping hot... a bit too sweet for my taste).  Chicken needed salt, none on the table which is fine if food is perfectly seasoned... but risky move if not.  Was a touch dry, wish I went for the steak instead, it looked good at the table next to us.

They totally forgot to bring us our appetizer (fried pickles) but came after the meal with appropriate mea culpa. A more experienced restaurant would comp the mistake.  The fried pickles were awesome, though!  especially the pickled cucumber, the carrot and onion did not pick up the vinegar flavor as well as the cucumber.

Dessert was "coffee and donuts" delicious fried dough, the chocolate/ coffee mousse had sea salt on top (a bit too much... wish I had it for my chicken!) but a nice end to the meal.

The ambiance was fun and eclectic, vintage video games, photo booth, we stuck around for the DJ and to dance a bit.  The DJ was a bit monotonous for our tastes but the varied crowd was enjoying.


Despite only 3 stars, I think they have a potential to be 4 or even 5, but will need to get the kinks ironed out. Definitely a welcome addition to Kendall square area.

Looking forward to returning to see if they improve!

We went here for the first time last Saturday (May 2009) with a group of 7 and had a wonderful time. The staff, atmosphere and food were fantastic.

For starters we ordered the mussels which were cooked perfectly. The flavors were delicious and the mussels were HUGE. We also ordered the boiled peanuts. I didn't know what to expect - they were soft (which I'm not used to) but I enjoyed them! A few people at the table claimed that that they "don't like cornbread" but really liked HM's cornbread. My husband and I love cornbread, but we were not that impressed with HM's - too greasy for me.

When I looked at the menu online, I have to admit that I was not all that impressed, but my mom wanted to try it (not to mention she was paying). While I do love places that offer a limited menu, nothing really jumped out to me.  Since I love fish, I decided to go with the cornmeal crusted catfish over rice w/ sausage and I was SO glad to have chosen that. The flavors worked really well together. I also tried a bite of my husband's roasted chicken and was pleasantly surprised. Normally I would NEVER order chicken on a night out, but I would order that chicken in a heartbeat. My husband and I also shared a side of grits since neither one of us had ever tried grits before. Once again, I was very pleasantly surprised - the cheesiness and the crispy bacon/ham on top had us fighting for that last few bites! 
For dessert we ordered a few plates of cookies that came with a bourbon milkshake which I am dying to recreate - it was fantastic!

I loved the atmosphere here! It looks like a house on the inside and the outside. They serve water in Ball jars and they've used glasses as sconces - very unique and cute!  I would definitely recommend this restaurant, but check the menu ahead of time as it is limited and definitely make reservations. Also, it's rather small inside so it can be tough to get a table for a larger party - for a party of 7 on Saturday we had to call a few weeks in advance and we had to eat early (6pm) or late (8pm).

Edit: Went here again this past weekend (12/26/09) & it is 1 of my top 3 restaurants in the area. Food, service & atmosphere are wonderful! Even if something sounds strange or interesting ORDER IT! You will not be disappointed. MUST MAKE RESERVATION.

First of all let me say that I think some of the previous reviewers have rated this establishment unfairly. China First does not pretend to be a five, four or even a three star restaurant. It is a cheap affordable Chinese food joint that caters to the college budget and does not have the pretension to claim otherwise.

While the food is most definately not the greatest culinary achievement in the realm of Chinese food, it is nonetheless -

1) Extremely affordable. The $4.35 lunch special serves eggdrop or hot and sour soup, a vegetarian egg roll, and a generous lunch portion sized entree. The dinner special is great too adding BBQ pork for only $5.99 total. All this and of course the tea is complimentary.

2) Lacking in MSG! The use of MSG is perhaps the cheapest most  uncreative way to enhance flavor where little or none exists. China First uses very little if any MSG. I would know as I'm allergic to the shite and too much of it will give me major headaches and dizzy spells.

3) Not nauseatingly greasy. Most cheap Chinese food places are so greasy you're arteries will be screaming at you soon after ingestion. China First's food has just the right amount of fat and grease to taste good but not make you sick. 

So come on folks, if you want the best that Chinese food has to offer than most certainly don't go to China First. But if you want a decent cheap meal of tasty Chinese food that's cheaper and actually healthier than most fast-food value meals, give China First a chance.

Sometimes dreams do come true, and sometimes, just sometimes, you discover a whole new world of tasty food closer than you previously imagined possible.

Just as our friend Aladdin from The Book of One Thousand and One (Arabian) Nights rises from his impoverished surroundings to become a hero, so does Aladdin Falafel Corner rise above the sea of mediocre and cheap food in the U-District to become singular in it's ability to stimulate my taste buds. 

It's TRUE.  Nothing compares, yes, nothing compares to you (the tasty goodness that is Aladdin's). For $5 bucks even (no credit cards and gold negotiable) I often find myself making the trip from Beacon Hill to the U-District to satisfy my craving.

It is said that to deny ones desires is to deny ones humanity... In that case I'll have one jumbo Gyro to go please.

Best pizza, period. Delicious thin crust. Best pepperoni. My personal favorite is the pepperoni and garlic combo--I always end up eating pretty much half a pie. Nothing compares. I want some now. 

Only problem is they have a very small wait staff, so when tables need to be cleared, drinks need to be refilled, or checks need to be given, that's when one experiences a lag. Sadly this can be problematic as the pizza is rather salty, so drinks need to be refilled quickly! Other than that (and the long lines, but if you know to be prepared, it's not that bad), it's 5 stars all the way.

It's cute how they greet everyone who comes in with the drum. 

I love their tempura! It kind of reminds me of Masa restaurant (on Colorado Blvd.) back in the 90s and early 2000's before they changed it all up.
And they have chawan mushi (my spelling is totally off) !! But it's $7 for a small sized one. =( But I love that stuff! It's hard to find that these days at a Japanese restaurant.

I don't have anything against Rite Aids in particular. But this one? She is not so good. Don't go if you enjoy activities like walking in unobstructed aisles or finding the very thing you went in there for. Close to the subway stop, though. But so is Duane Reade. And Chipotle. In fact, just say fuck it and go to Chipotle instead. Burrito always trumps shampoo.

My Own Fault!

I would totally go to Ecco for any Fri/Sat evening dinner.  My problem is that I was expecting an "experience".  

It was our anniversary and I made reservations through OpenTable 2 weeks in advance and called to re-confirm.  My request to have a patio table was fulfilled and our awesome waiter Christian made an ok  experience  better.  Christian was, by far, the best part of the meal!

However......the food came out really fast.  That tells me that the dishes were ready to go.  I was looking for a nice, quiet, enjoyable night and it went way too fast.   Our first wine order was great....LOVE the Albarino...and the fried goat cheese balls (our first order) was delicious.  Shortly thereafter I ordered the piquillo peppers with braised shortribs and those were really good.  

We had a table on the patio and were enjoying our mid-town experience.  One of the managers came by to check on us....I'm guessing it was a manger because she didn't introduce herself to us.  Nice of her to check on us, though.

Just saying, I was happy with the meal and wine, but it was just OK.  Will go back anytime, but it wasn't an anniversary experience, if you're willing to pay for something better.  

We had to ask for the dessert menu and decided to find somewhere close to home for desesrt. Sadly, our anniversary was not acknowledged in any way.  

Valet parking is great.....and I'll go back, but not for a special occasion.

I saw their sign, and was like, lunch for under 7 bucks? 

I was sold so I entered.  Ordered a generic chicken dish (basically breaded fried chicken chunks covered is brown gooey sauce).  It was bleh.  The meal also came with free soup, which tasted so nasty (I don't remember what is was called but it look like egg drop soup- the weird thing is I actually love egg drop soup, just not this one).  By nasty I mean, it tasted rotten - like expired soup, or they used some expired ingredient.  If that makes any sense!  The chicken wasn't any better, tastes old. 

Yes, it's cheap and you get a lot of food but the food is crap. 

Basically my whole experience here was less than wonderful, and because I was so scared the first time, I have never returned, and I don't plan on to.

The Middle East always has something going on.  

In one night alone, you can enjoy a meal at the restaurant, get stuck talking to an independent (unsigned) "musician" about how he can't ever work for the man again (even though he has a desk job downtown- "but I meant corporate!"), see great live music upstairs and then end up chatting with the bartenders until they kick you out.

To break it down:

Music: 4-5 Stars (every type of music passes through, usually good vibe)

Bar/Ambiance: 3-5 Stars (depends on the night, the crowd, the hipster to preppy ratio, how many boys' pants are tighter than my skinny jeans, how intoxicated the musicians are post show)

Food: 3-4 Stars (decent, good price)

I'd give it a go- especially if there's a show you'd like to check out.
I have eaten here a few times, and every time it is mint. My favorite meal is the porkbelly dish. It really is amazing. Wine list is great. I suggest it to anyone!

Lunch for under $5 bucks in the Udistrict?  Totally can be done. At Big Time Brewery I can get Pizza and Iced Tea and come back with a bill and change out of a fiver.  

The wifi works, unlike some other places on the ave, and this is my choice for places to hang out with a beer after work. Love them!

The main courses are delicious, tender and well seasoned meat with crisp grilled veggies. Also, I've never been a big fan of dolmas (grape leaves) as they've always been too bitter but that did not stop me from inhaling these--srsly a game-changer. The hummus and tabouleh and such are fine, not spectacular but good. If all yer looking for are those things and/or falafel you'd be better off at Tom's Tabooley.

Overall I think the food here is better than their Airport location and beats the hell out of Kismet or (yech) Milto's. 

One caveat: get it to go. The service was absolutely great but the space they were working in left something to be desired. The restaurant has an awkward ordering set-up, with a separate counter and cash register for ordering pizza (even though we were able to order pizza from the mediterranean counter). The queueing area was confusing and there were way, way, way too many tables for the small size of the space. It made for a loud, cramped and uncomfortable dining experience.

Great food, cheap price, weak dining room. 

Finally, try the greek pizza and order a side of tzatziki to slather on top. It is scientifically impossible for you to be disappointed with this choice.

When a customer asks for milk for the coffee they just purchased, you should not hem and haw over opening a new milk, the customer wanted 1 percent or 2 percent or whole. not fat free and not cream.  It was just a little request.. arguing with the customer and bringing our milk 7 minutes later makes the customer late for work, and it makes your store out about $70.00 a week that said customer used to spend there. 
 
Rude customer service is not something I need first thing int he morning after my almost two hour commute.

  its been fun. Thanks
Great stuff!

Dropped by this place intrigued by the "Eastern European Food" ad. Most foods seem Bulgarian or Greek.  I had the Tsatsiki salad, which was very yummy and served very nicely. Then I had the Chicken and Spinach Crepe, which was extremely good. The atmosphere was very nice, the service friendly and quick, the food yummy. I definitely recommend this place.

Great Customer Service! Helpful! Friendly! Very Clean! 
I went in three years ago for a nose piercing for my birthday. I was so nervous that it was going to hurt and was ready to hold my breath! 
I never felt a thing. I'm not even kidding when I say that I have had many papercuts that hurt way more! 
Have only gone back to Rockstar when I've needed adjustments to the stud or have needed to replace or add to my collection.

Love this place!!!  There is so much variety to chose from. Different veggies, lettuce, salad toppings, dressings......at first, its overwhelming!! The portions are enough for two. The decor is clean, bright and modern. Free wifi too. Its a fun place to go get a yummy salad and chill. 
The prices are moderate. If you start adding a lot of veggies or toppings, the price goes up quickly.

Probably my favorite Japanese restaurant in Pasadena.

And it's actually run by Japanese people... Yay!

The positives as a result of the above fact are:

1.  They offer more traditional-style bento boxes (like the one with the salted mackerel) in addition to the common teriyaki/tempura combo boxes that we see everywhere.  

2.  The details are there.  The panko-battered tempura is crisp and light (neither thick nor soggy).  The salad dressing is great.  The rice is perfectly cooked.  The teriyaki sauce is perfect (not too sweet or syrupy).  The daikon strings that come with the sashimi are perfectly fresh, etc.

3.  The sushi is fresh, well-prepared and down-right legit.  The only thing I'm not a huge fan of is their spicy-tuna, which tasted somewhat less fresh and too mayonaisy for me.  (FYI, Yoshida has the best spicy tuna).

The atmosphere is casual and the price/satisfaction index is high.

I'd never actually shopped at Lids before, until earlier this year when buying a gift for someone online. Since the hat I wanted wasn't in stock, they actually shipped it to this Lids location for me (for free) and called me when it arrived. The staff knew who I was when I got there and were surprisingly friendly, even offering to gift wrap it (not sure if that service was free, however). If I was more of a hat wearer, I'd definitely go back!

The food is incredibly tasty, the servers are hot, and the ambiance is nice.  It turns into a club (think bass drums and euro) after 10pm, so if you want your romantic night out to be quaint, come earlier.

I totally hate the place!@!

The peole here will NEVER ever listen to what you want, instead give u what they think u need!

the lady who cut my hair did not even understand what I wanted her to do to my hair I believe, she was simply 'scissor happy', and wanted to get going on my hair! She had absolutely NO technique and I hated what she did.

The worst part, I came home only to have my aunt point out to me, a whole big section of my hair trailing below my new short length! I mean that lady FORGOT/IGNORED a whole section of my hair, and left it un-cut! My aunt took a scissor to it though! 

well even after this experience, I decided to give them another chance (call it lack of option, maybe) and I ended up with another guy. It was like Deja vu again! He listened, nodded and then proceeded to cut up my hair with a frenzy. I still regret the results..sigh! I am so sure he too did not understand a word of what I said..sigh!

When I was done, the guy glared at me for leaving only 10% in the tip! beat that now! Also, they keep this shelf of discounted hair care products, most of which are out dated and old :/ God knows WHY!

Totally to be avoided!

Awesome awesome awesome.  Cool little place, great coffee, hot chocolate, cheap delicious food.  It is cramped, but its fun.  You'll hear lots of hilarious masshole convos, some genius, some pseudo-intellectuals.  Free wi-fi.  Great place to study or read with some headphones on.  Outdoor seating is great for the summertime!

Jen and Nate from B&G Photography are simply the best.  Not only is their photography fantastic (just check out their blog, their work speaks for itself!) they also made the process incredibly easy from start to finish.

Booking and Price - I contacted B&G about a week after we set a date for our wedding, about 9 months in advance (we got married in 2009).  Jen immediately got back to me, said that they were available and would love to shoot our destination wedding.  I then sent her a list of what I wanted included, she customized an existing package and got back to me with options in a day or two.  When I found that everything I wanted was a little over my budget, she worked with me to rearrange things and make sure that I could get what I wanted at a price I was comfortable with.  I thought that this would going to be the most stressful part of the process but Jen made it so easy.  We had them booked within the week.

Engagement Photo Shoot - My husband and I twiddled our thumbs a bit on this and had to rush to get our photos taken just two months before our wedding.  I was worried that we wouldn't have our photos in time to use at the reception but Jen and Nate reassured us that they would do their best to turn it around in time and they did!  We got to look at proofs just 2 weeks after shooting our photos. 

Wedding Day - Jen and Nate were prompt (as usual) at our hotel room the morning of the wedding.  They caught all the right moments and I don't feel like I missed a thing in the whirlwind craziness of that day.  When we did our first look in the lobby of THEHotel (in Vegas), they did a great job using the modern architecture as accents in our photos.  They pre-scouted the hotel and knew where to set-up us for the best light and photos.  As for the actual ceremony, they had all the angles covered.  Jen shot from the perimeter and Nate somehow got all of the close-ups without getting in any of Jen's shots.  They are such pros!  The photos from the reception also turned out great.  The lighting was very dim but they managed to get wonderful photos of our families interacting, our best-people giving speeches and us laughing and enjoying ourselves.  You'd think that they'd be pooped from all the running around but no, they were up for hitting the Strip after the reception to take more photos.

Day After Photo Shoot - Since we had a destination wedding, we thought it would be nice do get all dressed up and shoot some photos out in the desert (Red Rock Canyon) in a retro car.  We had the top down in the convertible and had a blast shooting photos in front of the car, on top of the car and even while we driving car (driving slowly and definitely not on the road).  When the sun started setting, they even whipped out their lights to make sure that we had enough light.  We were stoked, that they lugged them all the way from Los Angeles for us.  

Wedding Album - Jen did a fantastic job with this.  She knew that I was looking for something specific and she hit the nail right on the head!  The only revisions we had were swapping out photos (which we had chosen) and replacing them with ones we like better.  The album itself is so nice (love the black leather!) and especially looked great with all of the details Jen suggested.

To sum up, Jen and Nate are outstanding.  They're professional, knowledgeable and most of all, extremely talented.  I wouldn't hesitate to recommend them and will I'll definitely be booking them for future events.

I wish I could give the Co-Op 6 stars.  

Hands down the best place to buy school and office supplies anywhere.  I love school supplies.  Buy me dinner, buy me flowers, but buy me brightly colored hilighters and post-its & you've won my heart.  

Great deals on text book buy backs and awesome, awesome rebate program!

Perhaps my review will be adjusted upward or downward with future tastings or comparison to Sprinkles. On a side note about Sprinkles--there are clearly enough dumb people with money in this world to spend an hour in line for a cupcake by the looks of it.

I had one of each:
Fleur De Sel: chocolate cupcake with caramel filling, ganache frosting and fleur
de sel

Sweet Vanilla: vanilla cupcake with sweet madagascar bourbon vanilla frosting

I preferred the Fleur De Sel over the Sweet Vanilla. The Sweet Vanilla was painfully sweet. There was enough sugar in that frosting for diabetic to go into a coma. The cake part of the cupcakes seem to be moist as a dry cupcake is a dreadful one.

I'm not totally sold on this cupcake fad. All I can say is that the owner of thse cupcake joints must be sleeping on money with the high profit margins at $3.25+ a cupcake. 

Verdict: a cupcake for $3.25 or a gallon of gas? Calories for your hips or for your car?

Everyone is correct about the skirt steak! So delicious!

My meal included a beer that the waiter recommended and the cheese plate for dessert. Everything was top-notch: the food, the ambiance, the service, the cleanliness of the bathroom. Five stars. Well done, Malbec.

I am a pretty good customer because I work in retail...I always tip and say please and thank you. I don't spend two hours counting change out of my purse, and I don't make picky requests. Everyone who works behind the counter here always acts pissed, like you did something wrong by ordering an Americano. All I can say is screw you, and I hope someone nice eventually gets your job.

Pretty awesome bookstore when all is said and done. I think I would be in here a lot if I lived in the H Sq area. Their displays are always interesting (always end up buying something from them) and the used books are a deal, if you can stand sorting through them. 

One complaint-ish: I went here last week to try to sell some books back, and they were quite selective about what they took back. Ok that was fine with me (and I actually got more per book than I expected). But I did find it somewhat annoying that they don't have really any way for you to donate books for the greater good. I know they're snooty and all, but would it really hurt anyone to have a bin for donations? When I asked what they'd do with the 75% of my books they did not take, they replied "dunno. dollar rack I guess". I was like...wha? 

Prices are higher than Borders/BN on new books, and if you read my Borders review you'd know my view on this. I read alot therefore I need to save money on books.

This Nike reminded me of the one that was in Valley fair. Small clean store with a limited selection of shoes. Good casual/running shoes for older adults, runners and for those who like retail prices. If your a shoe head, you won't find much for your collection.  

I love Nike products but I'll rather go to Nike outlets and the one in SF.

i have been here once before due to an art class i was taking. i went here today, but this time just to go and check out the place without having any pressures of writing and taking pictures of things for a paper. that part was really nice!

i love museums of any sort! this museum is located right on the grounds of the stanford campus. if you come to visit on a weekday before 4pm, make sure you park in VISITOR PARKING. you will get a ticket! the machine where you buy parking day passes accept credit cards! so if you dont have any cash, use it!

inside the museum, they have everything from oil canvas paintings of everything you can think of. from landscapes, to portraits, to blown glass, to marble sculptures. they have a nice exhibit of the ohlone tribe woven baskets and figures.

i especially liked the first exhibit you see if you enter the galleries through the first floor. they display the entire stanford family and it narrates a story of how the Stanford family created their socalled "empire" here in palo alto.

my favorite exhibit is the Andy Warhol displays. color everywhere! very modern! it is truly a must see =)

I like how the bartender was the cleanest "dirty" guy in the world--kind of like Charlie from "Party of Five." He had well trimmed scruff on his face and delicate holes scattered throughout his shirt. It reminded me of when I was wee, and my mom would buy me cable-knit sweaters. I'd get my scissors out and place holes in spots that a sweater wouldn't normally get holes from wear and tear. But then whenever I wore said sweater in front of my mom, I'd have to fold my arms in front of the holes or stand awkwardly so she wouldn't yell at me.

ANYWAY, this is the kind of place that also practices cleanliness and modernity and minimalism (read: BARE, sparse, etc) but with those odd rolling benches. Their drink menu has some tasty cocktails (except the cucumber one. Yuk! What was I thinking !?)

The one time I was there, this girl either in her early twenties or with a fake ID who was wearing a sleeveless turquoise leotard with a pair of cut-off denim shorts over them and a pair of white high heels. Gasp! Her and her not-quite-as-fashiony friend were smoking butts outside when we were leaving and the conversation went as follows:

80s Chick 1: If you don't roll deep, don't roll at all.
80s Chick 2: We were the biggest crowd in there!

I was only rolling three deep that night by the way :( should have stayed home...

I LOVE this place! Its the only place in town I can go to work outside the office with a cup of latte and a hookah. This joint is great to get some serious work done during a weekday, or just chill with friends. Hookah prices are higher than normal, but I'll pay it because it's worth it. The folks here are very friendly, always refreshing the coals, always smiling and nice. Here's a tip - ask them for bubbles. You can blow bubbles with hookah smoke in them - it's a ton of fun and will get you buzzed really fast too :o)

-1 star because they are working on getting their liquor license (if they don't have it already) so they can be more of a wine bar/lounge. I love that idea - except that to accommodate this, they will no longer be able to serve hookah indoors. If you want hookah, you gotta sit out back in their patio - not cool! Sacrificing their main attraction (hookah lounge) to become another wine/bar/lounge is like if an Indian restaurant started serving TexMex because the TexMex joint next door does good business. There are plenty of bars and lounges in the area - so I'm not sure why this is a good idea.

In any case, I'll continue going here for my first points above - still great people and good hookah. But probably go there half as much because I don't feel like sitting outside in July so I can smoke hookah.

This was one of the first frozen yogurt shops before all the other ones opened. There are usually 4 flavours to choose from. There are plenty of toppings too. But minus 2 stars because it's dirty and looks kind of sketch when you walk in. My friend used to work here and he said that some food preparations aren't very sanitary. Nevertheless, I still ate here. 

The staff here are all very friendly! They try to strike up a conversation everytime you're weighing your cup and paying. The cost is about $0.38 an ounce now. It might have gone up a bit since the last time I've been here.

The other reviews have said it all---friendly, fast service and delicious food at a great price!

My favorite is the tofu banh mi: at only $3 including tax, it is a tasty, light and surprisingly filling sandwich that's perfect for eating on the go.  I ordered a few, thinking I'd save some for the next day, but one of Thanh Vi's strengths is its freshness, so you'll want to buy fresh.  

The veggie pho is also delicious and includes lots of veggies--carrot, broccoli, mushroom, sprouts, etc;

***UPDATE
My new favorite pho is the baby pho, which has thinner noodles and only green onions, basil, cilantro (no meat or veggies).  It pairs perfectly with a banh mi if you're like me and want to get simple, fresh flavors and drink the broth without excess flavor from toppings.

I have a love-hate relationship with this place. I really do think it has some of the better bar-style food in West LA, but it's the service that really takes it down a notch. They have a few flat screens that aren't well placed, but you can still follow whatever game is on at the time.

BJ's is a solid chain that I can rely on for cheesy, chewy, thick, deep dish pizzas. I've been ordering the BBQ chicken pizza since I was a kid and it's always been solid. The spinach and artichoke pizza is good as well, which can also be found in dip and calzone form. If you like doughy bread, the pizzas and calzones are for you.

The also have a good line of starters: nachos, spring rolls, chicken tenders, etc... 

For a sandwich, the turkey cobb is solid, again with the doughy, cheese bread, bacon and bleu cheese sauce.
 
Their list of microbrews has been the same for years and offers a great variety from a light blonde ale to the dark porter and stout. The Piranha Pale Ale is a past favorite.

They recently started brewing their own root beer which is made without high fructose corn syrup and actually tastes very good. Free refills on this too. 

The pizookie (deep dish cookie) desserts are easily the best item on the menu. Save room. They have many flavors available, but I always go with the classic chocolate chip cookie with scoops of ice cream on top. It's very very good.

They seem to have UCLA students staffing the place and the service is slow and many times I have had my food served incorrectly. However, if you make no substitutions or alterations you should be fine. 

BJ's is always a safe option when I am in unfamiliar territory, loooking for some bar food. Rarely will I go there if I find myself hungry in Westwood.

Roti Roll!!!!

This is the type of place I'd kill for near my work. What wonderful concoctions, and yet also a no brainer - why isn't there "portable Indian food" everywhere? Also agree with the reviewers who said you'll want to eat more than one - I had the Chicken Malai, and I don't know if it's the novel burrito-like presentation of Indian food or what, but it took me about half the roll of bites that were followed by "Hmm...interesting" before I devoured the rest of it in a flash and wanted more right away. Unfortunately I had to save room for food later, but on my next trip to Roti I will definitely be double-barrelling! Really want to try the eggplant!

last time i was in LA, i actually found this place on yelp. my boyfriend and i had 14 friends in town from hawaii who had never tried hookah before since it is nonexistent there. so we tried to find a place that was closest to where we were staying.  upon getting to habibi cafe, the atmosphere seemed pretty cool. the one thing i like about hookah cafes in so cal is that they can be outdoor and have lots of decor and music, which is very different from the indoor hookah cafes in nor cal.  

++ pros:
- even though we had a rather large group, the waiter gladly gave us a huge outdoor couch section. and he helped us open the section up, plug in the lights, etc. it was nice since we could give our tourists a great experience in a nicer setting than just getting tables along the sidewalk.
-- damn, the hookah here is strong, and i feel like i got my money's worth! and the flavors were good too. maybe it's the cap they keep over the hookah. or maybe hookah in socal is just better than in norcal. the flavors were yummy and the hookah even got me lightheaded and it was strong, like i like it.

++ cons:
-- they make you order one drink per person, which is ridiculous. we ordered 3 hookahs, which cost about $25 dollars, which is actually pretty good pricing. however, one drink per person at about $3 dollars each, made our tab come out to about $45 dollars more.
-- service was good when we got there. but when we tried to get help and get our check, it took about a day and a half.

Best pizza slice in Cambridge/Somerville. Thin, floppy, crispy, cheesy, fresh... just about every possible positive adjective that can be applied to pizza can be applied here. I just got a slice of the pepperoni because I was in the mood for something classic, but I couldn't help but check out the rest of the menu, and make mental notes of which funky flavors to order next time (the mango/pulled pork sounds awesome, as does the white bean/sausage/herb... there's definitely something for everyone!)

The minus one star here is simply for a few aspects of convenience that leave a tad to be desired in this place. This place is ultimately best if you're looking to 'grab a slice on the go,' which I rarely am - I wish they had a bit more in the way of seating, especially come wintertime. I love eating my pizza fresh, but don't exactly love sitting at a tiny stool awkwardly staring at tourists walking by on Mass Ave, which is really your only option here if you don't want to take your slice to-go. Ohh, and a delivery option would be AWESOME, and would allow them to compete even more strongly with places like Upper Crust.

Bottom line though - if you're looking for a seriously good slice of pizza, this is your place.

I LOVE THEIR HOME FRIES.

i came here for breakfast..finally after 3 years saying i would come....just never got around to it..and wow, what have i been missing!!! i ordered an ham and cheese omelet that comes with homefriends and toast.sooo good. the omelet tastes better than dc ones!! but homefries are soo good.

The down side? THEY DONT TAKE YCMP :( so i had to pay with a cc. succks....but i'll prob come randomly because its good and i'll prob run outta swipes later on. They have a large collection of drinks in their fridge too.

I wish they would open up near Philadelphia. This is the only semi fast food restaurant I have enjoyed in years. Great atmosphere. Fun decor that reminds you of a old time gas station. The food came in a cute cardboard racing car .  The wings are very good. Lots of condiments to chose from .Atomic to mild. Some locations have fried pickles.Yum ! Prices are reasonable and staff was pleasant.

Mmmmm Late Night Bliss!! Plenty of Grease to go around! Cheese steaks will fill you up and keep you smiling!

Date Rating: 10 (This is a little piece of History you can't miss it)
Pick up Scale: 10 (If you like Princetonians)

Strong Suggestions: Remember many have come before you, and many will come after you... Hoagie Haven is a Legend!

I go to UC Hair Salon to use their waxing services and let me tell you, its the best I've found around.  The owner, (I know her name, but I don't want to spell it wrong, so I'll call her "owner") is amazing.  She's super fast and efficient and I don't experience any pain during my wax. It only takes about 10 minutes (for Brazilian) and its worth it.  If you get Crystal, she's just as good as the owner (I believe the owner trained her).  Everyone is always extremely nice. So if you want a relatively pain free wax that's also reasonably priced, go to UC Hair Salon!

Came here for my best (male) friend's birthday celebration. 


Their Empanada's are the best I have ever had of its kind (Hey, I'm Filipino). The Chicken probably being the best.. or the Beef. I can't decide. The  service is awesome and the people are super nice and accommodating for a huge party. We had about 15 people and they were nice enough to spit the check into two separate tables. Easy for them, easy for us. 

Their Sangria (although I didnt have any) looked yummy and at only $5 a glass you really can't beat that--especially given where you're eating. 

The Chimichurri is addicting with their French Bread. And they're more than happy to refill your basket for you. 


I can't wait until my bank account allows me to go back ;)

O'Connell's, formerly Cannon's, almost lives two lives.  From Sunday nights to Wednesday nights it is a calm Irish pub/sports bar filled with TVs of sports games and other shows on their multiple TVs, there are everywhere!  

From Thursday through Saturday nights (normally after 10 PM) the bar is filled with young college students looking for a party.  The place becomes packed, and I mean packed, with people.  The bar turns into a huge party.  Some may like this atmosphere and some may not.  Be warned though it is very hard to walk around and get a drink but often times the bartenders try to help out with this and are normally good.

As for drinks, they're not bad at all.  Pitchers of Rolling Rock, Bud Light, and Coors Light are 9 bucks.  Others include Stella, Magners, Woodpecker, McSorley's, and Guinness all on tap, among others.  Great selection.  They also have a drink called a "B*tch Face" that is 9 bucks and is fruity but filled with about as much alcohol as a Long Island Iced Tea, it's not for the easily intoxicated!

Also- $20 minimum for credit cards

First & foremost.... turn in where the is a space in the bricks & an iron fence... you really can't see the sign for the place from the road unless you know where it is. I stayed here on my move across country & the BEST thing about this place is that it's animal friendly. I had to move my poor kitties cross country & this was a place that would let the little ones roam free inside for the night. The room was clean, although a little outdated.  The staff was friendly, there was a continental breakfast and they have a secure parking lot. You can walk to a lot of restaurants and bars. Plus it's close to the FED if you need to go there for work. No complaints other than the dated-ness and slower than molasses elevator. I would stay again.

This place is very small, boring and disappointing. I can't believe how much they charge people to get in. I love museums and expected a lot more from this place. We weren't the only ones expressing the same opinion. The cafe was a big disappointment as well. =\ We got in for free for some military special they had, and I know if I had paid to get in I would have tried to get my money back.
Went back to Hot Slices again to try their pizza...and it wasn't burnt! Their pizza was very good and their garlic knots are still deeeeeelish!!

Umm, delish. 

We had lunch here yesterday and rolled ourselves out the door after a wonderful meal. 

I started out the meal by sharing the Mista salad with the fiance. It had some nice greens, sliced dried apricots (oooh), candied walnuts and was finished with a delicate mustard / vinaigrette. 

On to the main course... 

The butternut squash ravioli in a Parmesan cream sauce. Fantastic and a perfect portion - I would have been alright for a fairly "light" lunch, but the bread and dipping sauce was too tasty - I couldn't contain myself!

The girls and I were in the mood for something on the light side and something that screamed Western Mass. since we were on a day trip in the area.  This definitely seemed like a hippie/left wing/college hangout kind of joint.  Check out the chalkboard by the bathroom if you don't believe me.  The owners/staff are not Republicans in any manner.  

I ordered a really delicious, yet very large spinach salad.  This was a tad on the expensive side for lunch but I was thankful for the day-old brioche, which I bought at half-price and it was still delicious. My friends ordered sandwiches and enjoyed them.  The seating area is kind of small so be sure to grab a table quickly after ordering.   I loved the acoustic swing band.  More restaurants should have live bands play.  

The desserts looked amazing but we didn't order anything.  I'd like to return  just for pastries.

I was lured into La Burrita because they have a massive TV screening the FIFA world cup... and I wanted a taco. 

The staff were quick and friendly. The taco was fine, fresh salad and salsa, the chicken meat was quality and had a very mild sweet sauce. The shell was very soggy, but the taste was overall satisfactory. 
It was ~$5 for 2 tacos and a bowl of chips with salsa.

Ok. Let me start this off by saying that I am not a big dessert guy. Sure cookies and ice cream are nice and all, but I'm more of a "save my money and appetite for REAL food like steaks and hamburger" type of guy. I mean, desserts cost more, are more unhealthy for you (usually), and don't even fill you up! So when all my friends were basically wetting themselves over how great this new Cream place was, I was wary.

Then I tried it, and consequences were never the same. This place is OUT OF CONTROL. I mean, a buck fifty (CASH ONLY!)? It was fast (1. scoop ice cream onto cookie  2. ready to eat) and delicious! They had warm cookies, and tons of flavors of both cookies and ice cream! Also, I'm pretty sure I picked the ultimate cookie/ice cream flavor combination on my first try. You HAVE to try peanut butter cookie with the cinnamon+caramel ice cream. My friend Ammar thinks it's better with Macedonia nuts, but he doesn't know anything and shouldn't be trusted.

In short: bring cash, eat Cream, leave happy.

Ohmigod. This is the best place to go for an ice cream sandwich!

Every time I go there, the line's always long, but it always move fast; I never spent more than 5 min on a line.
