As I arrive at the front of the line, you have the ease of choosing 2 cookies out of 10 different kind of cookies that's possibility of 100 combos! I know, it may seem hard to make a decision, but it's easy, You can choose in less than 30 seconds if not 10 seconds.

Then you move on to the ice cream. There you can choose one of 12 different flavors, so in addition (actually... multiplication if you're a mathematics freak) to the possibility of 100 different combo of cookies, now you have 1200 possible combo of ice cream and cookies! But don't worry, after choosing the cookies, your task becomes easier.

All 1200 possible combo cost only $1.50 each!

Not only the price is fabulous, but you can sit at one of the few chairs and watch the people go by behind the window. What a view if you like to people watch.

I so will go there everyday if I live close by!
I love this place, not for the food but for its upstair. Quite place with lots of light and midlle eastern decor!

Went twice. Once for dinner, once for lunch.

The food is good and plentiful, vegetarians will find quite a few choices and carnivores will delight as well. 

The service is, however, erratic. You can get lucky or have a completely rubbish experience. 

Give Massawa a pass if you have plans for the rest of the day / evening that stick to a schedule.

This was my first time here and I was not expressed with the food or the service.  They messed up my order twice, charged me an extra drink, and never apologized.  They made me feel stupid because I didn't know what syrups they had for the fruit shaved ice, which is not what it seems.  It's basically a fruit drink with two scoops of fruits.  If I'd ever go back, it would be for a frozen fruit bar.  Wouldn't want to ask the staff too many questions about their products.  Sorry but this is a rant.  Even after a few days...I'm still upset about it.

This is a very typical Jersey diner.  The food and service are decent, no complaints.  You get very large portions are very affordable prices.  The only problem is getting on and off Route 1 into the parking lot, especially if you're on the wrong side of Route 1.  ;)

This place is fun for a mellow sit-down meal with friends. Free peanuts are a perk and you can throw the shells on the floor. Their drinks are huge! Literally bigger than my face! I've had the California burger with a vegetarian patty (and no bacon) a few times now and it's consistently good. Their portions are huge! Their fries are really good too.. Curly or steak fries. Mmm :) Service has never been amazing but not horrible.

hands down my favorite place for lunch when I am at work. The food is fresh with a nice clean finish. I am completely addicted to the turkey club sandwich on wheat toast. Never ate inside but they are super fast for carry out. sooo good... wished they delivered (well, other than for catering orders)

We came last saturday afternoon (Oct 29th) right after visting the Samuel Adams Brewrey, it just finished snowing and it was really cold. Once we got in and it was nice and toasty our stomachs started growling. Bartley's satisfied that hunger in an instant. With their enormous burgers (The Viagra Burger is fabulous) and onions rings you won't complain about be hungry all day, and a great price. Another plus is that it's right near the T-Stop.

Eat lunch here for the first time today.  The garlic toast was excellent, the salad very good, the cheese tortellini fairly good and the pizza fairly good.  Cheerful place, service was ok.

I was hoping for better pizza, just not my style, I guess.  Too much cheese, not very crispy crust, even with the "thin" style.

I like this place best when no one else is there to talk to except the staff and a couple of locals.  On the weekends, this place is crazy busy but all other time's Spin provides a relaxing atmosphere where sophisticated locals have a drink while carrying on discussions about various topics. They also have a fantastic jazz night!

Jef is an old friend and a wondeful piercer and he did my nipples about 10 years ago now!  Wow.  I think it was back at Lunasea (rip), and well I always stop by when I am back in Providence and he seems to never be in.  I love you, Jef and hope you are well!!
I love Halo Pub chocolate shakes.  They're cheap, simple, chocolaty, and delicious.  It's not quite as "exciting" as the Bent Spoon, but it's (simply) great ice cream.

Old Dominion "Brewhouse" and sports bar. I went there and had a sampler of beers (I will review the beers at a later date) which consisted of four four ounce beer samples. I also had a 20 oz pale ale. The beer was average. It was not terrible but there was nothing special or interesting about any of the beers. They did not have the barely wine available, that might be worth a look. We only ordered appetizers (it was happy hour and everything was half off). The food was nice, but the waiter didn't know anything about the beer, including being able to correctly identify the beers in the samples. I will give it another chance, sometime soon. But as far as my first impression, not that good. Sorry OD.

I visited The Spicy Pickle for the first time today based on Yelp reviews, and I give it two pickle spears up!

Their specialty is fresh, yummy sandwiches made to order.  They also have salads, soups, and "pizzettis," which are thin-crust pizzas.  I got the "bronx" panini, which was corned beef, swiss, coleslaw and thousand island dressing, but substituted out the regular coleslaw for their horseradish version.  Very flavorful with a surprising amount of kick!  I have to say that I wasn't a huge fan of their panini bread - the mouth texture of it was weirdly crumbly, even though the bread itself was plenty sturdy and held up well to my drippy coleslaw concoction.  Next time I go, I'll try either their ciabatta or their focaccia.

I like that they have a "build your own" option; I love being able to choose *exactly* what goes into my meal.  And their toppings (of which you can choose unlimited amounts!) include more expensive options like avocado, sundried tomatoes, portobello mushrooms, artichoke hearts, and kalamata olives).  They also have nine kinds of cheese and fourteen different spreads (gimme the options, yo).

Unlike some of the other reviewers, I wasn't at all offended by the price.  Most sandwiches, including the "build your owns," were $6.45.  I don't think that's bad at all for a very good, high quality sandwich.

The Spicy Pickle serves beer (yes!) and the service is excellent and very cheerful.  The woman at the register waited very patiently for us while we perused their very large menu and painstakingly chose our lunch selections.  And at one point, one of the guys behind the counter was dancing around to the music (which was good, by the way).

They also have THE coolest restaurant t-shirts ever.  I love the one with the woman with the 60's haircut with the big pickle in her thought bubble.  I would totally have considered buying one if they had any in stock (they were out).

Biggest drawback:  they have world's tiniest parking lot - three spaces out front plus one handicapped space.  If you don't luck into one of those, you are left to fend for street parking in the heart of West Campus - no small feat (although easier in the summer months).

I just got a happy vibe from this place - and we can all use a little of that.  I'd definitely go back...assuming I could find parking.

Neat place. I didn't really have a good experience though. We were sat by ourselves and then forgotten about. Although I was impressed by the organic good and farm raised meat/eggs. I wasn't entirely impressed with the menu but a lot of people seemed to find just what they were looking for. I would give it another shot sometime.
While I was there, a woman next to us ordered blueberry pancakes, and they looked amazing.

I've had two experiences at this place and both were not what I expected. The pizza looked appetizing, but tasted horrendous.  I don't even think what I ate is allowed to be called pizza. The bottom was very doughy like it was uncooked.  On top of that the ratio of crust to sauce/toppings was like 6:1..and I felt like I was just eating a loaf of bread.  People, the pizza is misleading. It may look all CRAZY and awesome but it tastes like 10 day old pizza, even after being heated.  I don't think I'll be coming back here again.

1)
Radio commercials with the owner's thick European accent over butt rock music + slimy tanning beds = one bad tanning salon.

(I went twice thinking it was relaxing. Next time I'll go for a hot bath.)

2)
Tanning in general + white people = unnatural and cancerous.
The only place I go in Austin for a haircut!

We've never used the boarding services, but for grooming they're excellent.  The staff are friendly and kind to the animals.  We have a bichon frise who comes out looking fantastic every time.  They could stand to spend a little money on spiffing the place up a little, but if you can overlook the slightly run-down appearance of the place, your dog will get a great cut.

Cool laid back atmosphere. I had a ginger man cocktail which I enjoyed.
For Appetizers we had chicken tacos which were alright but nothing spectacular, and the chicken wings. They were very tasty, very meaty, and very spicy. 
Now, I odered pulled pork cus I had read so much about it and I loved pulled pork.
The beans and greens were pretty good, but the pulled pork was inedible due to the overpowering flavor of vinegar. I had one bite and couldn't taste anything else.
The service was attentive, if a little grouchy.

MOEUL IS HERE!!!

One of my most favorite massage therapists in town is here at my most favorite spa in town.  I win and from what Moeul tells me he wins, too!  Moeul has been working at another spa for 10+ years and has finally made the switch to a nicer, cleaner and friendlier spa!  If you love very deep, firm shiatsu-like work then this is the man for you! I recommend the Deep Tissue 105 to give him plenty of time to work his magic!
3 words: CHEAP. FAST. GRUBBY.

I've been to both the Pismo and SLO locations.  They were some of our favorite Italian restaurants.  However, our most recent visit to the SLO location was a disappointment.  It's way overprice for what you get.  I don't remember the portions being so tiny before.  My clam pasta was $17 and had sand/stone in the clams and too salty.

Self Serve! I love self serve! The sad thing is that they can have more flavors and the day we went they didn't have much options of fruit. I like how all the dry toppings are in covered boxes. Much cleaner! 

I am not too good at using their machines and got a bit much but o well. The price was still really good for what I got. I wouldn't mind coming back in the future to try more toppings.

The best place to pick up a CD when you can't find it anywhere else.  They carry many artists that are unknown to most people, and I believe they will special order CD's for you if you request them.  The staff knows their music if you have a question about anything.
I'm going out on a limb and say that for the money this place is awesome.  It's reasonable, food is great. Portions are awesoms. It's just pretty great for what it is and where it is. I love it.

They have a frequent rewards card system. If you order over $5, you get a stamp. When you get 10 stamps, you can get a free Big A burger or soup. If you get an A on any assignment, bring it here to get a free order of fries! You don't have to order anything with it.

The default Big A burger is vegetarian, so don't be upset if you did not specify beef. The vegetarian version is not the best burger I've had, but it's not bad. Veggie burgers just inherently cannot be as great tasting as beef burgers. The eggplant sandwich is super good. I absolutely love the garlic fries. They are air-baked and have real chucks of chopped garlic on them. The salads are huge, but not as huge as the ones at Cafe Intermezzo and comparable to the ones at Sufficient Grounds. Salad choices are little limited. Soup choices here include veggie soups, chowders, and chili. The soup comes with cornbread. The cornbread here is known to be the best in the area. It's nice and moist when you get it, but it will turn rock solid the next day.

There is a lot of seating, but... my favorite thing here is the bar seating by the huge open windows so you can people watch while you eat and make people jealous of your food.

Brett:  I thought the curry was delightfully sweet.  I liked the heartiness imparted by the chunky vegetables.  And the katsu just made everything more awesome.  
HannaH:  The pho was really tasty.  Brett's katsu was excellent - perfectly breaded and a great crunchy counterpart to the richness of the curry.  The udon dishes look like solid fare, and I'm excited to go back again when it's warmer to get some of the zaru soba.  Tomukun's a pretty busy place, so don't expect to be served right away, but the wait for the food is pretty much worth it.  I do wish and hope that their menu will someday be expanded to include a few other notable Asian noodle dishes, such as chashu ramen, shrimp wonton noodle soup, and naengmyeon.  But for right now, I like what they offer.

Ok. So I knew this place existed for a while, and it was in a convenient location, but I never really visited. However one lunch, I felt like eating a sandwich. And I heard they did sandwiches here right.

I ordered a pastrami sandwich on what I think was focaccia bread. It was awesome. The bread probably made it for me. Sure the pastrami was plentiful and cured right but the bread was a revelation. It was sweet and moist and delicious.

The next time I have an urge to eat a pastrami sandwich in Berkeley, I'm coming here first. No thinking needed.

There are several art museums here combined- Fogg and Sackler.  We took pretty much the entire day to get through all of it.  Harvard is the place to see some great museums.  I recall some renovations going on but you can still see exhibits here.  Totally worth the price of admission to see all of these great works of art.

It's open late, next to campus, is a classic institution, and they make a respectable pie. If you're a student  this is one of your meccas. It's more thick crust than thin crust, and the crust was always a draw for me.  If you live in Berkeley and have a car or are willing to walk past Southside, go to Pie in the Sky, Arinell, or Gioia's instead.

Even in the realm of awful postal clerks this place stands out. These employees are beyond terrible. Each day they build Jacob Marley-style chains for themselves, ensuring an afterlife of walking the Earth from post office to post office for eternity without any rest. And that is too good for them.
I stopped by for lunch today and got an uncooked chicken kabob and bread. Really nasty food and i would not go there again.

I'll start off with it comes with a lot of food. I ordered their chicken teriyaki and chicken katsu combo and it came with lettuce head salad. There's nothing special about it but it does surely fill you up. During lunch, there's a lot of people and it's hard to find a seat, but during off hours, it's pretty chill and you can go with a group of people. 

You take your order and they'll give you a number and they'll serve you, but you have to bus your own table. They also have a frozen yogurt there, but there's only fruit available. But during those hot summer days it's pretty clutch.

I'm sorry, but I just could not get over the smell in this place.  It stinks like dirty socks in here from what I'm guessing to be cheese fondues.  My friends and I did not get a fondue table which may have made a difference in how disturbing the odor is.  I couldn't concentrate on music, on conversation, or anything else.  Never thought myself to be so nose-sensitive until we came here.  That is all I remember about this place...

You know what?  I was really expecting this place to suck.  Everyone talks about it being "overrated" and the consensus is "the burgers are pretty good but nothing special."  But I think this is the foodie (or wanna be foodie) just trying to act too cool for school.

The burgers are great, for a few reasons.

1) great selection of toppings

2) choice of beef, turkey, or chicken (beef=obvious choice, duh).

3) THEY ALWAYS COOK IT THE WAY YOU ORDER IT!!  I can't say enough about this.  The most important thing to me is that my burger comes out mooing, and here this happens.

I've had the Santa Fe Burger, L.A. Burger, Crunchburger, Mulberry Street Burger.  All of them were solid.

The fries kick ass, too.

Bobby, your love for "dipping sauces" (for anyone that watched America's Next Great Restaurant) may piss me off, but you've made a great burger joint.

Had an appointment for both my daughters to get their hair cut. Had a 2:30 appointment and we still were not seen by 3pm. 

If I'm gonna drive 20 mins and pay $60 for my kids to get a nice hair cut, keep your dang appointments. 

My daughter is crying right now. Thanks Salon Lux-I will never go here again.

After hearing the boy speak so highly of Diddy Riese in LA, I was definitely excited when this place opened up. FINALLY, I get to enjoy my own ice cream sandwiches without jealousy for his.

CREAM's special is their ice cream sandwich, however they do sell cookies by themselves or scoops of ice cream too.  They change their flavors daily and bake their cookies fresh.

The ice cream sandwiches used to be $1.50, but it went up to $2.00 before summer started. :( On the bright side, lines go by really quickly, atmosphere is always great, and there's always a crowd of people outside...

This is going to make me sound painfully pathetic, but the U Bookstore is one of my favourite places EVER. I used to ask my dad to take me here after picking me up from AM Kindergarten at the age of 5. I am now perfectly capable of making the trek all on my own and believe me, I do it very often (probably way too often)!

They seriously carry everything: textbooks, every colour of Sharpie imaginable, UW gear, posters, lab supplies, the largest variety of pencils (both mechanical and non) that I've ever seen in one place, ugly dolls, quirky gifts like plush Gandhis and giant plush microbes (my personal favourite), Clinique makeup, greeting cards, and books (duh)!

I can spend hours at a time in this store and still not get bored. The unfortunate part is that I always come away with an assortment of things that I probably don't need (I bought a brontosaurus-shaped measuring tape and some dangly octopus earrings last Wednesday, for example). Thank god for my 10% customer rebate!

Even though my friends really like this place, I have several complaints.
If you go there after dark, believe me - take a flash light with you or you might end up eating the napkins. The lighting is really bad.
The food is good, finally something else than all the Chinese, Thai and what other places in Morningside Heights. 
You should take some nice friends with you or you might get bored when waiting for your food (it takes an hour, although I don't know how preparing some piles of mushy stuff could take so long).

All in all a good place, but it takes patience and nice friends, but then it's different.

Mmmm.  Haven't been here in a while, because I got turned off due to the prices.  It is just too expensive, especially for a college student in the college town of Westwood.

With that being said, the Matzoh ball/chicken noodle soup is just so darn delicious.  And Casey LOVED the triple decker sandwich, especially with the corned beef.

The pluses to this restaurant would be the HUGE menu - seriously, if you can't find something you like on this menu, you need to expand your food horizons and stop being so picky.  The downside, is they probably have too many items to ensure quality for all types of items (stir-fry?  what the heck?).  Stick with the traditional deli items, and maybe only go if you're not paying.  Just kidding.  Kinda.

So i was in love the moment i read the review. I made a reservation easily online for the sunday brunch. I did this the day before v-day. Anyways the line was out the door but moved quickly. 
It took a while to get the smoothies we ordered but i guess they didnt want to leave it on an unoccupied table lest someone slip a roofie.
The buffet had mesclun, a raw calamari salad, ribs, shrimp, eggs with spinach and feta....mostly everything on theur website. I didnt see the the chicken but eh? My favorite things were the moist, flavorful well cooked salmon, the plaintiakns with chipotle ketchup which goes great on everything and the eggs. I was not a fan of the bland penne or the tough ribs  and the shrimp was a hassle to peel at the table which means their backs arent cleaned. but the avocado quesadillas are you kidding me !!! Yum. The dessert table is nice and you can really taste the flavors in each thing. The lime and tequila cheesecake, pear tart and chocolate bread pudding. Nothing to sweet but instead full of lime, sublime pear flavor and then rich cocoa coated my mouth. The only thing i could really dream is the the line moved faster because people seemed to idle and that one day there will be a live jazz  show along with brunch. But honestly it was good and im glad i went.

This is an average mexican restaurant with somewhat upmarket ambience.  It looks like the good reviews are from people who basically went during happy hour for a margarita and nachos.  I am sure they can handle that.  In fact, if I had just wrapped up a day of shopping at University Village and wanted a margarita and chips, I could consider stopping in.  But if you're looking for outstanding Mexican food, you won't find it here.  A lot of odd touches.  The salsa -- at least the one i tried -- tasted a bit sweet actually, which is not good.  I'm from LA, where there is lots of good authentic Mexican food, and have been disappointed by Seattle's Mexican food options.  After Sonrisa, I am still disappointed.

This must be the slowest Jamba Juice location I have ever been to.  It doesn't matter whether there is a throng of people in line or you're the only one in the store, be prepared to wait!  Surely your stomach will start digesting itself as you stare at the busy (yet unproductive) workers only to receive what will become an unsatisfying fruit smoothie.  And what is up with the new "brrr charge"!?
Really a great place to hang out and have coffee but they don;t make the foam as rich and dense as they used to.

The store itself is okay. Customer service sucks at this location. There were 2 or 3 of us in the store and 5 employees hundled together talking. I had to ask twice for help to unsecure a jacket. I felt like I didn't exist. If it hadn't been pouring and I wasn't in desperate need for a jacket I would have walked out. Just plain rude.

The first time I went here there were a lot of people but not too crowded. It was a good atmosphere, friendly service, and good seating choices. They have bar seats, booths, and tables with stools. I always enjoy a bar with no smoking as well.

The second time I came was for the Yelp party. It was even more fun then. Even though it got pretty crowded and hot, it was not something taking off my jacket could not fix. The bartenders were friendly and pretty speedy even while mixing so many of the special Yelp drinks. They even have a good amount of bathrooms. They offer a decent selection of food too, with some good snacking foods.

Overall it was a great experience and a great location on West Peachtree right near Mac's in case you want to continue the party at home.

Wow, how bad can the service get? Once we were in there, without a server in sight, to the point that one customer stood up, took one of the pitchers of water, and started filling up everyone's glasses... I have been there about five times. Always very bad, slow service. The food is, well, mediochre. If you want really good and much cheaper Mexican food in NJ, drive 20 minutes to New Brunswick and eat with the Mexican locals! Much better food for 1/5th the price!!! Or if you want a nice and more expensive dining experience, go to Blue Tortilla in New Hope, PA, about 40 minutes form Princeton. Just don't bother with Tortugas's! I would rather go to Taste of Mexico at the Princeton Shopping Center (5 minute drive from downtown Princeton) which has some menu items that are great (chicken tacos) and some that are not so great (mole is inconsistent) but at least you pay a lot less! and they serve you when you sit down!

I've been here several times and it's mostly terrible. When I sit at the bar downstairs the service is above average. However, most people go here for the rooftop deck. They only have like 6 seats for people who just want drinks which is just crazy. SO, you have to order food if you come with a few friends and want to sit on the rooftop. The food just bad...dried up hot wings, a pile of crusty old nachos, and the shrimp quesadilla should be renamed to slimy onion quesadilla. The server was nice but she seemed to have been assigned ALL of the tables so the service was super slow. When we got our beers 20 minutes after arriving, they were lukewarm and my boyfriend noted something floating in my glass...ew.

Don't go here.

I'm a sucker for restaurants that are located off the beaten path.  I stumbled upon this cute, little restaurant about six months ago when it had been open for three months. It was the name of the restaurant that caught my attention, really. Cute and original! Now, this place is packed even during the week! BEWARE. Their dishes are quite unique and have interesting and DELICIOUS blends of spices. 
My favorite noodle dishes are the chicken and tofu Pad See Eww and the Daisy Noodles which are rice noodles with red currey, egg, bean sprouts and crushed peanuts. 
I usually get the Garlic String Beans because they are crispy and cooked in garlic and black bean sauce. The BEST dish there is this curry dish called the "Green Jungle." It's made with super tender egg plant, green beans, bell peppers, basil with chicken/beef. I personally love the beef option better because I am a piggy =)
 
The #1 reason why I go back to this place over and over is because of their vast selection of TEAS!!! Their Thai iced tea/coffee is the best I've ever experienced. They have a variety of green and white teas to choose from, most organic. However, the BEST, most fabulous, amazing drink that they serve is called the "Roasted Nuts Tea." It is semi-sweet and tastes like liquified peanut butter. SOOOOO GOOOOD.

Not really into it, but what's cool is sometimes I've gotten free rolls and butter to go. They put it in a paper bag. You don't even have to go inside the place.

I am really into rolls and butter.
You know it's not going to be good when they used sliced cheese instead of shredded.

My husband just returned from cataract surgery at Jules Stein.  I'm not going to review the specific doctor because he's rotated through several doctors who are on fellowship and each year he gets a new fellow.  I'm not thrilled with this arrangement, but that's what you get with his HMO.

This review is for the surgical staff and facility, which is just top notch.  The nurses where great at making him feel at ease. The staff is very helpful and knowledgable.  Very impressed all around.

I came in here the other night and was immediately overwhelmed by the decorative theme. First of all, I know this is supposed to be an Irish bar, but all the gigantic celtic knots and highbacked thrown- like chairs are a slight overkill.
Anyway, I sit down and decide to order the quesadilla. I know its an Irish bar, but I was in the mood for mexican. It was okay, but I couldn't help but notice that on the tab it came up as a "Celtic quesadilla". I can assure you there was nothing "Celtic" about it. My friend got the shepard's pie. First of all, who makes a shepard's pie with cheese? Second of all, it looked, and tasted, like it had been stuck in a microwave for five minutes. 
I went in on a busy Friday night, and the men's room was pretty disgusting, but i guess that might be expected.
I sat at the bar and the service was...decent. Near the end of my night, though, I heard the bartender make a slightly racist remark to a coworker about Cuba and a banana boat. Awkward much? Not to mention the crowd. I know it was a busy Friday night, but the MIT fratboys left me unamused. 
The beer was really good, if a bit overpriced, and as the food didn't make me ill, I'm giving the Asgard two stars.

One of the best places in westwood. It's a hole-in-the-wall place on Gayley that has amazingly fresh pita sandwiches. They'll give you the pita with the meat and you can add all the toppings and dressings you want in the little topping bar. It's way too hot in there all the time, and only seats 3, so you'll probably want to grab it to go. I crave this stuff all the time.

I'll just preface my review by saying that I'm sure Sasha is great for other aesthetic services, but as for me, I'll skip on their waxing services from here on out.

It's not that they do a bad job or anything - in fact the ladies here do a pretty adequate job, but, they certainly don't beat the skills of the gal I usually see who charges me $8, not $20, for my eyebrows.

I came into Sasha on a whim - I was in a bit of a crunch, running around trying to get ready for a big business trip. I knew I'd be on camera for a few tapings and needed my brows tamed. I had a few more errands to run in Cambridge and couldn't make it to my usual gal back in A rock so I popped in here. The staff were perfectly nice and kindly fit me in.

Truth be told, I was a little shocked when the aesthetician stepped away from  my brows at first - they were way too skinny - and - uneven! Happily, the woman working on me was really receptive to my input and evened things out for me. I was just slightly shocked that she was ready to let me walk out of the salon with an awkward line of hair coming off my right brow.

In the end everything worked out alright and I was in suitable shape for any press I had to do during my trip. Still, for $20, I kind of expected a little bit more for my money - I mean, for $12 in my hometown I can go to a spa and get hypoallergenic cool wax - I was shocked that it cost this much for standard old eyebrow waxing, no frills.

I'm giving them five stars just for the spinach salad.  I'm not even that big of a spinach fan or a gorgonzola cheese fan, and this salad is so delicious, I sometimes go just for the salad.  I've tried a few other things and based on other items, I'd give it a 3 or 4 star.  It's the salad, people.  Try the spinach salad.  It's a tad sweet, and it's got some turkey slices on it with walnuts and gorgonzola bits.  Ooh, and you get some Zucchini bread that comes with the salad, and that's the signature of Green Street Restaurant.  DO IT!

This place is good for grabbing lunch, but stands out as a date place. The cozy little booths make you feel more isolated than a normal table and the incredible tea list is a perfect conversation starter. 
The food is a little pricey, but the quality is usually quite good. Ordering appetizers to split is great fun. I recommend the sweet potato fries or gyoza. Also good on the menu is the Vietnamese hoagie.
The bubble tea itself is pretty standard. Sometimes the bubbles are not as squishy as they could be, but that is expected if you come near the end of the day. The help is usually attentive, although I have sometimes had to wait a while to order. 
The last time I went there were unexpectedly belly dancers roaming around, which was fun if not a bit surprising. Good art on the walls also.

Finally, after several attempts to beat a ridiculous line, I tried Bobby's Burger Place!  The wait was not that bad (if you want to be seated right away try coming during the week at off hours) but I would not recommend coming here with more than 3 people at a time because the seating availability is pretty much first come, first serve.  A little annoying, but the burgers are great!  I wanted to have a regular burger before I tried some of the more adventurous ones.  It was surprisingly very good and the milkshakes are great, too!  Fun and affordable, I will definitely come back for more :)
This place doesn't need any more reviews, but I have to say I loved their pulled pork or "pig sandwich" even though I'm not a big fan of meat.

Big Mouth's is a Chicago-Style hot dog joint. If you're not familiar, in Chicago you don't go to Gene and Jude's or even Portillo's for the "atmosphere." Big Mouth's delivers just what they advertise, Chicago style hot dogs and assorted other grilled animals. The hot dogs are 2 for $5 and come with fresh-cut fries, a good deal in my book.

The hot dogs are made correctly - Vienna Beef (complete with obligatory "snap"), poppy seed bun, sport pepper, celery salt, grilled onions (?), and THANKFULLY - the neon-green relish. A gripe of mine is that they will graciously put Ketchup on a "Chicago Style Hot Dog," but that's the only caveat. The fries are pretty decent, but if you get them delivered, they may need extra salt.

I guess if you have little creativity you could call this "drunk food," as it is greasy, but in reality it's a good place to get some comfort food for cheap, a good change from the 10,000 Asian restaurants on Green Street.

Once I went here and the guy dumped peppers and onions all over my food, which I didn't want. He saw how disappointed I was, but didn't offer to make me a new bowl, like everyone else does when they get my order wrong. I would have taken off a star, but that was just one person. Last time I visited, a girl dumped salsa all over my food and immediately offered to make me a new one, which was very nice and expected. The portions here are the best of any Chipotle I've been to (I've been to a lot.), and the food isn't too salty. They have the best and sweetest beans and rice and give a lot of guacamole, which isn't too salty, and cheese. The rice here has been mashed too much, however, and the grains are broken and mushy sometimes.
Also, to use the bathroom here, you have to get the staff to unlock it for you, which is not cool.
I am lowering my review from 4 stars to 2 because of an appalling thing that happened to me and about twelve others last time I was here. I was the next that they were SUPPOSED to serve, and had a perfect view of the disgusting lack of courtesy that happened. 
I have been to many Chipotles and have visited many of those many times. (In fact, my usual schedule involves the Northgate one every Wednesday and Friday.) I know that when an employee wants food, they get out of the kitchen and join the back of the line. That is fair.
The last time I was at this Chipotle, I was about to be served. However, I was cut by an employee who was in the kitchen, who leaned over the shoulder of the tortilla/beans/rice guy and ordered. That was extremely unacceptable behavior. He should have left the kitchen and gone to the back of the line like any other person. Instead, he cut over ten people from his spot in the kitchen.
(By the way, this location is ALWAYS jam-packed. This means a long line. However, other locations have long lines too, and they move their equally long lines was faster than this location's. This place's lines are by far the slowest-moving Chipotle lines that I have been in.)
This is an appalling lack of courtesy and so I am giving this Chipotle 2 stars. I know exactly who that rude employee is because of his peculiar order (for example, "5 helpings of tomatillo salsa" or "triple-wrapped"). I am disappointed, saddened and disgusted by my last experience at this location.

I'd do 3 1/2 if I could. It's a lovely little used bookstore but not quite 4 star material.

The store is rather deceptively large with a really good and varied selection of books to go through. However, being a librarians daughter & having the dewy decimal system beaten into my brain I had some issues finding the exact sections I was interested in. 

Prices seemed fairly standard for used books, and I left with about 4 under my arm.

Staff pretty much ignored me the whole time. Which at times is an ok thing but considering how much wandering I had to do I was a little irked that no help what-so-ever was offered.

Cute little kitties are also roaming the store, I certainly didn't mind but I know my allergic father would not have been able to be in this store for more than a couple of minutes.

Serious Health Violation by Manager - Read before patronizing this establishment

On Friday, May 1, at 11:35am, I noticed the manager of Noah's - his name is Albert - bringing a tray of muffins from the bakery in the back to the front counter for sale.  He was wearing a bandage on his left thumb.  The cut was deep, and blood and plasma had soaked through the bandage to the outside. He was handling the muffins with his bare hands, and prodding them forward into the display case with his bandaged thumb.

I couldn't believe my eyes - that a manager of a food establishment would so callously disregard obvious health standards and common sense.  So, to verify, I called him over to me and asked him what was on his hand.   He told me it was a cut, and I again saw a thumb-print sized ooze of blood and plasma on the exterior of the bandage.  I told him "I don't think you should be handling customer products with that cut", and he told me "oh - that's why I'm in the back doing paperwork", to which I replied "no, I just saw you place that tray of muffins on display.  I don't think you should be doing that".  He turned his back, and walked away.

I have contacted the Pasadena health office, and Noah's Bagels customer service about this matter.

This is the very last time I will ever patronize this establishment.  I highly advise that those seeking to protect their health and well-being avoid it too.

Huge improvement over Metro. The coffee is delicious, the remodeling, with the finished wood, makes for a much nicer space, and the staff is friendly and helpful, something that Metro lacked. The food is an improvement too. The morning glory muffin is amazing.

The furniture, however, is exactly the same. Strange metal chairs that kind of look like WALL-E. Plus, this place lacks power outlets, so you really can't use your laptop here for an extended period of time unless you get lucky and find a table near an outlet. 

But, on days with nice weather, this place opens up its entire front façade, making it a really nice place to sit. And I guess a place to be seen too.

Located in the midst of Rice Village, this is a great place to stop and shop for that Saturday night date or Wednesday wine time with the gals.  Prices range from quite affordable to a bit pricey and just vary by item.  They have a great stock of dresses, but they also have accessories so it's a complete outfit in here.

I went with my mom and sister and we all enjoyed a good 30 minutes picking up fun ideas.  I will definitely bring friends here in the future and keep it in mind for my fun outfit needs.

My husband's big 30 was coming up so I started planning his big shindig about five months before.  I contacted several hotels in the area to get quotes on hosting and catering the event and Hotel Palomar was by far the best quote I received.  I worked with Heather the catering manager to plan an exquisite event and the whole process was smooth and accommodating.  Once the day of the event arrived, Hotel Palomar took care of everything for us and our Banquet Manager, Etienne, was on top of all of the details!  The party was absolutely amazing; I couldn't have asked for a better experience for the event and Hotel Palomar really went above and beyond.  The food from Pacci was one of the many highlights of the evening; it definitely added that extra level of class to the party!  I cannot wait to use them in the future for another event.

We also stayed the night at the hotel and the hotel staff is just the epitome of excellence in Customer Service.  Karen, our front desk attendant, was so helpful, courteous, and fun.  Her personality really enhanced our experience!  The rooms were beautifully decorated and immaculate; I wish we would have stayed more than one night!  Can't wait to stay here again!  Definitely the best hotel experience I've ever had!!

Cool Cafe isn't the cheapest place to find lunch at Stanford, but it's the highest quality.  The food is all orgainic, sandwiches and soups and salads.  The smoked trout sandwich is tasty, and the burger is the best on campus. 

If you work on campus, it might behoove you to call your order in and pick it up, as they do attract a lengthy lunchtime line.  There's moderate seating, which fills up quickly.  This isn't a problem in the spring/summer, as you can always enjoy your meal outside amongst the sculptures.

This is a sweet little trail out and back (circular).  It was maybe 1/4 mile.  I took both my girls toddler and preschooler.  Super views of ocean, pier and La Jolla.  No eating on the trail.  So we snacked back at the front gate.  Need to relax with a friend or meditate?  Head here.

Had a mini-family gathering here and were pretty disappointed. The food here is overpriced for what you get...which is barely enough. We ordered a bunch of dishes for variety, but ended up getting small portions of salty food. There are other P.F. Chang's that came out better than this one.

What do the French know about burgers anyway? We're talking about the quintessential American food here, yet the SBK  and I are drawn to this charming Bistro on our weekly burger jaunt. It was an up and down experience the entire meal, good but not great burgers, very good but not excellent French Fries, and a more than awkward server than I was expecting. I guess I'm always baffled by up-selling outside of a movie theater, but if I'm in the mood for a Diet Coke with my meal, I will speak up. I was also surprised at how easily said waitress threw the kitchen staff under the bus, insisting that if we wanted to order dessert (this coming just after we ordered our entree's) we should do it quickly, since "our kitchen is very slow." There were other mishaps along the way, but whatever, let's get back to the burgers.

Sampling both the "Grilled French Burger" ($14) and the "Gourmand Sirloin Burger" ($13) yielded similar results. Cooked fairly close to the requested medium-rare, there just wasn't a ton of flavor from the beef. I suspect the leanness of Sirloin is the culprit here, as the cut of beef is generally a good indicator of the rest of the meal. We know Sirloin is not the best choice, correct? Fat is flavor, and I want my burgers fatty, dammit, is that too much to ask for? Bacon and melted brie do their best to bump up the flavor in the Grilled French Burger, despite the bacon not being completely crispy. (is it that hard to cook bacon?) The melted brie added a wonderful touch, oozing and creamy, with just the right amount of tang needed to offset the unpronounced flavor of the burger itself. The Gourmand Burger was less successful for me, topped with a duck truffle terrine, the flavors just never came through for me. Honestly I'm not a huge terrine fan anyway, and while this was well prepared, it just has no place on a burger in my opinion. Texture is important in a meal (yes, even on a burger) so the idea of a mushy terrine on top of a burger without a crust was a minor misstep, and fancy-pants ingredients such as a duck truffle terrine have no place on my ideal burger, but the attempt and the differentiation is duly noted.

The French Fries (excuse me, "pommes frites") are golden and crispy, but need just a touch more of salt and are a shade above room temperature. Not bad but not fantastic, kind of like the meal as a whole. I know the French can prepare food properly, and for the most part, they do at Sandrine's Bistro. The bun, a brioche no less, works well with the burger at hand, even if the burgers seem a little on the small side. The flaws aren't major, but for an overall experience, something is lacking, which I attribute to passion. Some may say you can't taste passion on the plate, but I know I can, and while they go through the motions to cook as spot-on as they can, without the love and the dedication behind the food, it will never be all that memorable.

At a certain age you must leave the crammed "underage" bars and turn to the "grad lounge" of uptown. 
a usually mellow crowd ABC is a good place to grab a beer and shoot pool. their house brews usually good i would suggest the patriot pils or honey pils. anything outside of their own brews is over priced. 
The FOOD....nothing to write home about dont be suckered in by the name, go for beer not food. head to antonios or bueno.

As much as I love this store, I have to say I rarely find anything worth buying there.  The newer men's stuff is mostly the same sort of selection you'd find at a Goodwill, while the vintage men's stuff is mostly costume-y period pieces that don't have much use outside of a themed cocktail party.  I have found some great ties there on occasion though.

The dollar-a-pound isn't worth the time spent digging.  It's more like "let's look at some shitty clothes that tons of people have walked on".

I miss the cats walking around.  

It's a landmark store and I hope it stays in business for a long time to come.  I wish, in addition to getting some new cats, that they'd spruce up their selection, at least in the men's.  Other vintage clothing stores in town seem to be able to get their hands on western shirts, cardigans, old track jackets, ironic t-shirts and other popular vintage items just fine.

I just got a craving for Mexican food, and I thought of this place! Sadly, I'm not in town so I can't satisfy my palate. =( However, I'm here to review.

I really believe this is the best and most consistent Mexican food I've had. The steak burritos are so good! The meat is yum. Everything is freshly made. However, what makes this place so good is the sauce "buffet" where you get can get the green sauce, onions / parsley, salsa (the best I've had), vinegar carrots...mmmmmmm. If you are downtown, try this place!

This place gets 4 stars for two reasons: it is cheaper and open later than every other Indian restaurant I've been to in Seattle.  
The food is better than everything I've yet had in Capitol Hill, but not as good as Taste of India or Cedar's.  Also, the disposable/styrofoam everything is off-putting.  But again, for the price and convenience, it's a pretty great place to go.

Awful experience, I brought in brand new tan boots to get rubber put on the leather soles.  The man who worked there was nice enough, and made me pay in advance and now I know why.  

When I picked the boots up, he had to dig around on the floor for them.  There were several black stains on the top of the boot shaft.  After I pointed the spot out, he reluctantly tried to fix it.  When he couldn't get the spots out, he told me that it wasn't his fault and he didn't do it, even though he admitted it wasn't there when i gave him the new boots.  I asked for a discount and he yelled at me to "shut up" and "get out".  

I stayed really calm during the whole encounter and was shocked at his response.  I will never go back to this place, he is completely unwilling to take responsibility, and honestly I would have been happy with an apology, and a $5 discount.  Ridiculous.

I don't really go there to drink, but I definitely go there to eat. Their burgers are AMAZING, and when I ask for medium-rare, they actually serve it to me medium-rare, which is something pretty... rare. :) They also have great specials throughout the week.

The place is big enough to have great dance parties, but since not that many people go there, it feels too big and empty and awkward.

But the food is SO FREAKING GOOD.

I must say I am really loving alternative 80's night here on Saturday evenings. Amazing fun time and what a low key non-pretentious crowd. I love the energy and everyone genuinely seems to be having a wonderful time. I really love getting my crazy groove on and sharing my enthusiasm for "MY" 80's music. Where else can you share a dance floor with straight frat boys, college co-eds, trannies, gay boys, lesbians and everyone in between?

I stumbled across this cool sneaker store after grabbing a bite at Top Dog and bought a couple of classic kicks from this new boutique in Berkeley. The store was cozy and inviting and the guys behind the counter were knowlegable about their product and pretty enthusiastic about making me a happy customer. They had shoes that I haven't seen since I was a kid. Great store and I'll definitely be back for more shoes when I throw out some older shoes from my closet.

How odd I have yet to write a review of the Middle East. Esp. Since it is one of my favorite places EVER!

I used to live around the corner so I am not there nearly as much as I used to be. The staff is great both during the day and at night. The food is always yummy (I get cravings for the chicken shwarma).

Then they also put on some kick ass rock shows. Drinks and entry are reasonably priced. 

Like I said LOVE THIS PLACE!

Growing up in the South, I have found that there are extreme differences between chinese food there versus New England.  You can order the exact same dish in each region and get a completely different experience.  For example, lobster sauce in the North is a brown sauce with ground beef also added.  In the South it is a lighter, white sauce with more veggies & no ground beef.  Also, what is it with serving rolls with chinese food?!?   

But I digress.  My point being that I have yet to find a chinese place that I love in the Boston area after almost 10 years of trying.  Yenching comes close, though.  

Like the other reviews note, the staff are ridiculously friendly, bordering on being uncomfortably so.  Don't get me wrong, I love good, friendly service, but when you literally end each sentence with  "sir", it is almost condescending.    

The food is pretty good, but won't bowl you over.  I am not gourmet when it comes to asian cuisine outside of sushi as I tend to stick to the americanized standards, but I enjoy it enough from here to make it my go-to when in the mood for chinese.  At the very least, it is worlds better than Hong Kong, which is on the same block.

A little more expensive that you would expect, but it is in the heart of Harvard Square, so it makes sense.

Overall, not the best, but far from the worst!

So I went to Tosci's for the first time last night. I ordered a scoop of burnt caramel off the bat since that seems to be the crowd favorite. How can I say this... it tasted TOO burnt. I don't mind some bitterness in my ice creams (e.g. I love the really bitter, gritty green tea ice creams), but this was a bit too much for me. I left about 1/5 of the cup because my taste buds couldn't handle it no' mo'.

However, it did have a great consistency (just the right texture/amount of creaminess) so maybe I just haven't found "MY" flavor yet.

years before i even know what kind of food meesha's was, i was told as a freshman to come here and say 3 words - "meesha's chicken plate".

for 10 years i've uttered the same 3 words every time i walk in.  only this past saturday did i branch out and order a beef gyro in addition.  

considering location and proximity of other options in this same genre, the awesomeness in terms of taste of the chicken plate (and gyro), and the usually short wait (unless it's post football game, then all bets are off).

I like this place and have come here on and off for the last decade. The place is just funky, but in a decent way. Their Gyros are well stacked and they have good hot sauce.  These guys are my number two Gryo place around.  If you take the price in to consideration these guys are probably 5 stars.  I don't so just a 4.  Still very good.

Summer in Champaign is ALL about outdoor seating. This great new restaurant has got it right. With plenty of space out and inside, and self-seating, the atmosphere is always semi-casual and always welcoming. After looking at the menu, we expected an average dining experience, based on the fact that the menu accentuates burgers (they call their mini-burgers SLIDERS) and salads...not our usual dining-out fare.
However...the wings are the BEST WINGS we have ever had in our lives. They are not your usual buffalo-drowned bits of suspiciously massive chook, these are fine specimens of realistically-sized, expertly-cooked bird, served crispy with your choice of two sauces, (there are lots to choose...from BBQ to Thai Peanut and beyond).
In ordering, we found that each ordering the Slider/Salad combo worked really well, although sharing sliders and tasting different flavors also works well. There is an extensive beer/wine selection, including some fashionable Spanish options, however we seriously question a wine list without a single New Zealand option, especially in the Sauvignon Blanc section. Our favorite sliders so far have included the Buffalo Chicken, the BlackJack, the California Turkey and the Salmon, although we highly recommend asking for NO BUTTER on the buns if you are interested in 'eating lightly'. Our two salads (Goat Cheese and Spinach/Fried Chicken Salad) were both surprisingly delicious, after so many below-average iceberg salads in the mid-west.
All in all, we think they have found a niche targeting people who appreciate casual dining prepared exceptionally well. This is the PERFECT OPTION for those diners who want a home-town up-scale alternative to Ruby Tuesday, Steak n Shake, Fridays, or perhaps even Guido's at the same price and not at the mall!
Expect to spend $30 on food for 2 courses for 2 people.

Came on a Tuesday night with a coworker.  She had two groupon coupons for wine and needed a drinking buddy. Lucky me =)

If you don't have a GPS, it might difficult to find this place because it's located on a small street/alley way.  It's also conveniently located right next to a cheese store. Talk about product placement 

anyways, this place is pretty nice.  It reminds me of the hole in the walls back in paris.  Rather comfortable low lighting, and simple rustic decor.  They keep most of their dishes simple and elegant.  I don't remember what we were eating, but I really liked the soft cheeses and the different tapas.  They all complement really well with what ever you're having and are also very light.  

Above all, I'd have to say the people there were all very nice and helpful.  They try to get an idea of what you like and try to accommodate the types of food for you.  They also know their wine, very informative.  I had a great conversation with one of them and learned more about wine.  Unfortunately, because it was a Tuesday night, it wasn't really booming and most of the red wines I tasted seemed to taste vinegary to me.  I don't know if my taste buds were off that day or maybe the wines were opened for a while.  I did enjoy the whites and dessert wines. Ever so delicious.  

Overall, this place was a treat because of their wonderful staff, but at $2/oz for the cheapest wine it's not economical to your wallet.  If you ever come here keep in mind you're here to sample a bunch of different things.  Enjoy!

This place is basically a big shoe box, but they put on a good show.

Electronica nights draw a VERY different crowd from the weekends. Hearthrob was amazing although the line was a b*tch and the bouncer was really mean about not letting people in even when the DJ says it's okay (*griping*)

Make sure to show up before 10 if you don't want to wait for a hour in the pouring rain!

Habibi Cafe is one of those so so places. Nothing to get excited about. DO NOT sit inside...ugh the smell of hookah when you sit inside gives me the worst headache. The outside seating is much better. Hookah wise its alright i guess.  What i would suggest doing is gatherng a bunch of friends...and getting a VIP table. This meanss they bring you hookahs and a bunch of food. Also you get to see the belly dancers perform and theres a dance floor. Also the service is 10x better. But be warned...it will cost you. I cant remember how many people we were...but every one ended up paying 40 dollars! I can't say it was worth it...but either way your going to atlest have to pay 20 per person for a regular table..might as well cough up 20 extra bucks. This place is not my cup of tea...I'd rather go to one of the hookah places in Burbank. But thats just me!

Good vegetarian offerings at extremely reasonable prices  in Harvard Square.

I like the chickpea fritters, but I ask for less pickled items than it normally comes with. It sort of overwhelms it for me. Rosemary fries are good too.

The ambience is stagnant - whitewashed walls. It's definitely not the cozy environment you feel at other Harvard Square cafes so don't go expecting a cozy cafe.

a cool little spot to spend time on your computer, reading a book or studying. for me, it provided as a resting place after walking through the South End, Back Bay, the Espanalde and over the bridge to Cambridge. the ice cream was nothing to rave about. the lemon butter straight up tasted like butter rather than just being buttery.

Small, helpful, fresh, eclectic, affordable. What more can you want?

If you have never tried their fresh pizza dough, it's time. I tried it for the first time last night. Where have I been? It was so good! A really easy and inexpensive way to go if you want pizza. Everything else needed for pizza making is there too. 

I needed a low cal meal the other day for lunch and picked up the reduced fat southwest salad. (this is how I found the pizza dough, it's in the same section.) The salad was excellent, and filling and only around 200 calories, including dressing. It looks small in the container, but it seems to double in size if you take it out...it's enough. 

I could go on about finds in every isle, but it would be more fun to discover your own.

I used to come here when I attended MIT five years ago.  I lived across the street from the restaurant.  Not the greatest food, but it satisfied my pad thai fix.  There was seriously a huge shortage of decent places to eat on the Mass Ave side of MIT campus.  My department even took a seminar speaker here for dinner and I wouldn't consider this place acceptable for that sort of purpose.

I'm speaking as a frequent visitor, not as a person who has ever rented out the space.

So apparently activism groups hold meetings here. Meh. I've just gone to a couple of shows here. I like that the kitchen is readily accessible so I can fill up on water. A night of skanking can get quite dehydrating.

No complaints. It's a clean, well-maintained space.

**Attention all poor college students**  A real sit down meal for under 10 bucks?!  holy shit!

Decent asian food.  from thai to chinese to korean.  kind of a random mix of popular asian foods.

I don't understand what it is about these ice cream sandwiches that is so irresistible. The ice cream is run-of-the-mill Dreyer's available at any grocery store, and the cookies by themselves are decent but really nothing out of the ordinary.

But put these two seemingly mediocre ingredients together, and BOOM! There's a party in my mouth! 

They let you combine cookie and ice cream flavors in each sandwich to your heart's content, meaning you can have two of the same cookie or two different cookies in each sandwich.  I wish I remembered what I had learned in my probability classes so that I could tell you how many possible combinations there are. Oh well - bottom line is, there are a lot, and one is sure to suit your fancy.

Watch out for long lines on weekend nights. But for only $1.25/sandwich, the wait is totally, totally worth it.

We went here tonight to see the Nutcracker and we weren't disappointed. We had walked past this theater before and just walking past it makes you want to go to a show there. The architecture is beautiful and I was really impressed by the acoustics, we arrived late and had to sit in the back until the intermission and the sound from the orchestra was excellent.

One of the things that I was most fascinated by was the ceiling above the orchestra,LOL. It was blue and had some clouds and as I looked up at it, it looked like the clouds were moving, I'm not sure if this was an optical illusion or something they were doing with the lighting or if they contrived some other way to make them move.

The only thing that happened that I didn't like is that they allowed people to eat things from the concession stand during the performance, which I thought was odd since I had never seen that in any other ballet that the wife and I had attended. There was this person next to us eating a giant bucket of popcorn and for a minute there, I wasn't sure if I was at the ballet or Regal Cinemas at Atlantic Station,LOL.

Excellent place overall, we are looking forward to going back.

Wow!  I've been an avid Mexican food fan my entire life and have tried pretty much everything in the area including Philly and this place blew them all way.  I haven't Mexican this good since my trip out to San Diego and Kaliente still beat them out.  I ordered a shredded steak burrito with tomato rice, lettuce, onion, tomatoes, jalapenos, refried rice and shredded cheese on a habanero wrap.  It was the size a small soccer ball and tasted amazing.  My friend ordered the chicken version on a regular wrap without jalapenos and raved about it.  This place completely tops the other two Mexican eateries in Princeton.  Two burritos and a soda was $16.44 and worth every penny.   I will be back again and again!

Yuck,  the pizza is too greasy and way overpriced.   Plus there is a snippy, rude female that was in there that just cannot be friendly to anyone it seems.  Maybe she is gone by now, who knows.   With all the pizza in ann arbor,  this is not even on the radar.

cute cafe, nice ppl, food is good, a bit expensive to me, but i guess its worth it
sometimes they have tapas, never been there when they do, but my friend said they are very yummy but quite expensive
the agua fresca, some strawberry drink, very good, try that for sure
the desserts are good too. i had a pumpkin cake and my friend had the carmel creme (flan looking thing) and it was delicious
the music is nice and the atmosphere is calming
good place to read, chat w/ ppl, grab lunch

Natasha brought me here last time I was in town, and it was a gastronomic feast of epic proportions. I was skeptical of the tavern in Harvard Square, but any concerns I may have had were quickly dispelled once I had a Southside in hand (and I'm not even a serious gin fan, so kudos) and some chicken pate in my mouth. Incredible! I have never had such a light and fluffy pate, delectable and almost sinful. My mouth is watering just writing about it!

We didn't have room for much more afterwards, and you'll definitely need a walk and/or a nap after such a feast, but it's well worth the effort. Russell House is definitely a must-eat in Cambridge, whether you live there or not.
Innovative coffee shop.  Brewing methods reach beyond drip and espresso to cold brew and aeropress.  Plenty of seating.  Excellent baked goods.

Food is really good. Pretty authentic. Didn't get more stars b/c it's a tiny place and it's a bit overpriced. Not too bad though. My chicken burrito was about $6.50 (was decent sized, but not huge) and then I went back for two $2 tacos (that were tiny, but good).

Ok. I very rarely write a negative review, but since this establishment has gotten so many great ones, I might as well do the buyer or eater beware. Or at least be one of those.

I have only eaten here once (and you will know why) and the food here was pretty good. I have had better from other diners before (namely in chicago) but it is a pretty decent place if you are around the neighborhood and you can't think of anywhere else to go and you are in the mood for diner food.

Now the bad part.

I came here on a pretty dead day and wandered in having read all the great reviews on facebook. People seem to have a thing for the Simpson's decor and loved to mention it. When I first walked in, I honestly looked around and raised a brow, honestly surprised. Ok. Its not exactly decorated fully in Simpson gear (it has a few things here and there) but when I think of a place filled to the brim with Simpson memorabilia, I think of it as toys crawling in every nook and cranny in the most obscene manner. So if you are a newcomer and are used to old school diner with a certain theme obsession, take the Simpson decor comments with a grain of salt. There is not that much. That honestly isn't what knocked down the stars hough and I forgive the establishment for the lack thereof (i'm not a big fan of the Simpson's anyway).

The biggest hit and the reason why I have given only two stars is a) the food was pretty good... but........

When closing the door of the shop since it was getting a bit chilly, a layer of black dust settled across my food and my coffee. At first I thought it was black pepper that somehow got blown all over (I like to give people the benefit of the doubt) but when I saw exactly where it was and it was EVERYWHERE (not just on my immediate spot, but on the register and etc...) I immediately felt sick to my stomach.

I've eaten at pretty greasy diners and this one definitely takes the cake. But not in a good way.

So sorry Sunny.. Greasy dirty diners are cool in my book.. But not when they are so dirty that a layer of dirt settles over my food and coffee when a slight breeze flutters in.....

Don't expect good service, don't expect clean surroundings, and don't order anything but the Protein 2000. 

If you bear these expectations in mind and follow my one simple rule (exceptions to rule: you may order the Lucky 7, the curry bun and the red bean paste bun) you will have an amazing meal at Veggie Heaven. If you disregard my advice, sorry.

And regarding the service: if you patronize the place for long enough, the waitstaff's usual hostility will transmute into a sort of adversarial respect. Think Gandalf and Saruman. It's a good feeling.

Everything I had from this bakery was really good. I tried to only eat half a blueberry muffin, but man, i couldn't resist. The raisin toast with sugar was really good too. I wanted more and more and more!!

and there was the chocolate chip cookie. and it was AWESOME as well. My coworkers loved the outmeal raisin. 

I'm leaning towards the conclusion that all their bakery goods are just so dang dong yummy!

Complete Clothing is a men's streetwear shop tucked away on 8th street between Chipotle and Anthony Nak. If you aren't looking for it, you'll probably miss it.

You'll find WESC, Standard, Freshjive, 10Deep and other similar brands. The clothing is mainly denim, T's, dunks, hoodies, caps and the like. They do have some cool limited edition gear. 

The setup inside is nice and if it's slow you can probably have a PS3 challenge with the staff on the huge flat panel TV.

The Bottom Line:

If streetwear is your thing, check 'em out. It's not a huge shop but it's worth visiting as there are so few quality streetwear shops in Austin.

I looooove this store. Rubber stamp stores are hard to find and this one is a gem. They still have the traditional wood-mounted stamps along with a nice selection of clear stamps to choose from. They have quite a few tools and accessories as well. If they dont have it, they will order it. I've special ordered a few times and they have come through every time. The staff is friendly and helpful. You won't be disappointed.

Stephen Hawking!

I was super excited to actually get a seat to see Dr. Hawking last night, as well as to actually attend an event inside this beautiful auditorium.  I've visited the CalTech campus several times and always ended up hanging out with friends near this building because the lighting here is so picturesque.  It's a good place to sit and talk and absorb some of the intellectual energy that permeates the grounds.  EIF?  Electro Intellectual Field?  In any case, this event was a big deal and the auditorium was full to capacity.  In spite of this, things were well organized & flowed smoothly - entrance & exit - bathrooms, etc.  

I will definately check out the Cal Tech calendar more often.  They have music here too & in the round auditorium, I bet the accoustics are great.
http://events.caltech.edu/calendar.html

Their food was quite good, but be warned- they are liberal with the spicing! We both ordered a medium spiciness level (figuring it's upstate NY and they'll probably underspice- I know, we are so biased...) and it was pretty hot. I've heard similar stories from other people who have eaten there.

So be warned- good food, but you might want to err on the side of caution.

Having grown up in the area and being the big lover of Italian food I am, I have driven by this place for YEARS always wondering how this place was and if it was any good.  It was not until recently did I start hearing things about this restaurant, that it was considered one of the better Italian restaurants in Pasadena.  Of course despite all that, I never found an excuse or the company to go with me to try this place.  Until last week.

Came here for a friend's birthday.  The birthday girl didn't want anything extravagant.  Just dinner with some folks.  I actually was running late, but so were they, so by the time I had gotten there (which was about an hour after the original time), they had just ordered so I wasn't too behind.

I actually had just read in Pasadena Magazine the day before in their cuisine section that this place had the best frutti di mare in Pasadena.  I like seafood, so why not?

The restaurant itself is a decent size.  They have their main dining area which can probably hold about 40 or so people, an outdoor patio that can hold maybe another 15-20, and then a smaller banquet room to the left (where we were) that could maybe hold 20-30 people, depending on the arrangement, and a couple of other rooms in the back.

The food came in a good time and everybody dug in.  My friend next to me got this one pasta (not sure what it was called) that was a mix of regular fettuccine and squid ink fettuccine that was tossed in a saffron cream sauce with bay scallops that just smelled divine when it was set down.  Despite my repeated objections, my friend let me have a bite and it was AWESOME.

The frutti di mare is served with spaghetti, but I'm not a huge fan of spaghetti, so I substituted linguine.  Our server set it down and it smelled fantastic.  Mussels, clams, shrimp, and bay scallops, all of the seafood was cooked just right, the pasta was al dente, and the sauce was just right.  Portion size was a little small for the price, but this place ain't so Bucca Di Beppo or Maggiano's.  But it was good and I couldn't complain.

Service was very good and despite passing on dessert, our server said he wanted to do something special when he found it it was my friend's birthday.  A few minutes later, he came back with a complimentary chocolate cake with 4 other servers in tow, singing "Happy Birthday" in Italian as they were walking in.  It was really cool, especially because all of the servers seemed to be Mexican.

as #399... this is what you would consider "foreplay"

Fin.

A long while back, I think when we were house hunting, we passed this place while trying to find Northside, where we were meeting some friends for breakfast.  I remember exclaiming, "Yes!  An Indian Grocer!" and yet we've never made our way back.

Until last night, that is.  UrbanSpoon kept suggesting this place while I was shaking it last night so I figured we should try.  After having a drink with friends we headed over, arriving around 8 p.m.  The place is stocked with a great selection of everything you need to cook indian food, and includes some home items, incense, candy and frozen/refrigerated options.

In the back, cut into the wall, is an area to place your order and above it is the menu, written in chalk and clearly deliniated between veg and non-veg options.  We ordered the Saag Paneer (or Palak Paneer), medium, with rice; Lamb Curry, mild, with naan; an extra order of naan and some vegetable samoosas (or samosas).  We were able to sit at the one table (two small tables pushed together) and were brought water immediately.  The place is incredibly low key, which we enoyed.

The saag was different from what I'm used to - less creamy and had a hint of mustard seed.  It was very good and not overladen with paneer.  I think it could have been a little spicier, but my husband insisted that it was incredibly spicy.  He greatly enjoyed his lamb and especially loved the samosas.

I found the samosas to be a little too sweet - the fried outer shell had taken on a sweetness much like a donut or fried dough that simply didn't work for me, although the filling was great.  The menu says it comes with both mint and tamarind chutney, they only served the tamarind (fine with me, I'm not a fan of mint!).  

The naan was perfect.  I'm glad we ordered extra.

All in all, this was a great dinner experience and I would recommend this place to anyone looking for something a little different from the Shalimar experience.  We get takeout from Shalimar a few times a month and love it, but there was something really fun about "Foods of India".

i love this place. I love that there are always new exhibits, but also they maintain some staples, like the dinosaur hall, welch chemistry hall, and the texas wildlife exhibit. 
The butterly center, imax, and planetarium are cool too. 
I recommend getting a membership, it's cheap, you save a lot, and you get discounts on parking, and gift shops stuff.

This place in my opinion is a bit over rated since it's departure from Buckhead to Midtown Atl, but I do hope that it stays open. Atleast longer than the other restaurants (how many 1, 2, 3, 4 in the past what? 5 years maybe?) that have graced this plot of land. I think this retail/ restaurant space is haunted with bad business ghosts. No business ever stays long. ......

I never stepped inside so until I do I can't say how the interior looked or what type of vibe was released, but the outside 2 story patio and deck is definitely a chill and relaxing place to go after a long day at work. 

I had the opportunity to join some friends for happy hour (minus the happy hour specials) here, and immediately found a table to seat 4 on the upstairs deck. The place wasn't technically busy but it was steady. 

Let's just get right to it shall we. My friends ordered the lobster bisque as did I, the tuna melt substituted with some type of fish other than tuna (I don't remember) and the peel and eat shrimp and raw oysters and also a catfish Po Boy. The prices aren't bad at all. Maybe $8, $10, and $20 here and there.  

The lobster bisque was tasty, and I heard from my company that the Po Boy, the shrimp, and the oysters hit the spot as well. Here are the complaints though and this is what does it for me. The service was unbelievably slow. We were sooooo thirsty. lol Out of 4 people everyone ordered the bisque and everyone ordered a meal. Only 3 people received their meal....whaaaat? Was the waiter trying to tell me something? lol I had just gotten off of work people. I was a bit hungry as well as thirsty. Once we were able to re order some drinks I politely asked when I could be expecting my food. He looked at me in a genuinely surprised way and said "You haven't gotten it yet." Nope, sure haven't. He delivered the drinks and retrurned 15 minutes later to ask me if I still wanted my sandwich. Are you kidding sir? I said nah, because I had already been sitting there for an hour waiting for it, my friends had finished their meals, and everyone was pretty much ready to go. Needless to say I left starving and highly disappointed, but atleast I had the lobster bisque to tie me over while my friends enjoyed their meals. lol 

I'll give you another try Steam house but i'm hoping you have added on to your staff and their skills have improved.

A tip for the ladies:

When you stumble into Hi-Fi at 2:07am on a Saturday, drunk and desperately needing to pee, and you ask the guy behind the counter if you can use the bathroom, and he asks you for a hug, DO NOT hug him.  He smells awful, and he's only looking for a cheap feel.  If you bitch enough they'll let you use their stank-ass bathroom without having to hug anyone.

We're new in AA, just moved from Northern California, and although I had been warned that we would be disappointed in the Mexican food here, we figured those "Best of Ann Arbor" plaques in the window wouldn't lie.  Oh but they did.

The only good thing I ate was their extra hot salsa.  But even that couldn't save the chicken enchilada plate.  I took one bite each of the rice and beans (I'd never seen beans that color before!), and ate exactly one of the three enchiladas, simply because I was hungry.  Those were the blandest, driest enchiladas I have ever tasted, and I grew up in Indiana, which isn't exactly known for Mexican cuisine!   Hubby had tacos, and both of us were quite queasy within an hour of our "meal".   

No way are we eating here again....

Before I started treatment with Dr. Dan, I would wake up several times a night having to crack my own back because I was sore, uncomfortable, and just fidgety. After starting treatment and learning better sleeping techniques from Terrapin Chiropractic I now sleep like a baby. I am grateful that I am a patient of Dr. Dan's and have referred several of my family and friends to go there and will conintue to do so. Dr Dan is the man!
 ~Brendan Spear

After posting my original review I was contacted by the manager and offered a complimentary meal to make up for my not so stellar experience. This time when I went back I decided to have my burger dry and add my own ketchup and mustard from the condiments by the fountain drinks. This was a much better idea. The burger turned out pretty good and the fries were much improved. But the thing that really turned my experience around was the chocolate shake. Holy cow it was delicious. I was so full by the end of my meal but that shake was so good I would have easily been able to get another one in my belly. 

Since trying the shake I've been back a couple more times and so far the experiences have been pretty good. I would still suggest that when you order your burger you ask them to go light on the condiments but other than that everything has improved from my first visit.

Unless you're really craving sushi and can't drive any farther, not the best place to go. 
The sushi is inauthentic and really expensive for what it is. I mean, I'm fine with eating some sub-par sushi if I'm getting it for a reasonable price, but not here, they'll charge you above average prices for below average sushi.
They don't use real sushi rice, instead they use some long grain rice. It's not properly seasoned sushi rice either.
Also, the staff was kind of pushy, they kept coming by every minute to ask if we were ready to order. We just sat down, give us a minute okay?

A Fish Fry is to Albany what a Cheese Steak is to Philly. I went to Ted's during my visit here and I just can't believe what kind of hoopla a piece of fried fish in a hot dog bun could create.
I mean it's not a big, hearty meal like a Cheese Steak can be. There's no controversy over slices of Beef vs chopped or what kind of roll is best, or Cheese Whiz vs regular cheese.
