None of that, just an elongated piece of Fish in a hot dog bun with Tartae saucwe. Cocktail sauce or whatever topping you choose.
But it works! Whenever I'm in All Bannie, the first thing and last thing I want is a Fish Fry. they are cheap and I probaply can eat 3 or 4 of them without blinking, but it's a simple pleasure I love. Ted'. s is located in a little town called Watervliet, a quaint, rustic upstate little town that provides a nice country vibe. 
Ted's also sells Hamburgers, Fish & Chips, Calamari, Onion Rings and other items for a reasonal price. So if you're ever in these neck of the woods, check them out.

Had the Spinach gnocchi & butternut squash rav, I've had better; but I can't say I didn't enjoy the food and experience. 
Service was great but seemed a little forced/ olive garden-esqe. Nervous maybe? 
I 'm sure I will be back again.

I am a big fan of this place for Sushi in MI.  (mind you it is the only sushi place i have been in MI).
 I went to Sadako on a tip from a friend of a friend.  And it was really good.  The sushi itself was really good and full of different flavor, we tried some of the house specialties (can't remember any right, to much Sapporo).  The staff was very friendly and easy to work with.  
We bought so much that the chef sent out a few rolls for free as apps.

I absolutely love this place.  The staff is wonderful. The food is delicious. But the BEST thing is... you can bring your own bottle of wine or run down the street to Il Capo Cafe & Deli and buy a bottle to drink at Cafe Verde and there is NO corkage fee! The place is absolutely adorable and feels like a cozy restaurant you would find in Manhattan. It is the perfect restaurant for a romantic date or a night out with the girls.

I'm Chinese, or if you'd like, I'm Taiwanese. I love the food of my culture, whether it's Shanghai style, Hong Kong's own, or Taiwan's ambrosia. It enrages me when Chinese people think they can run a Chinese restaurant in California just because they're Chinese.

This is one of those places. Honestly, it's like somebody slapped the panda from Panda Express, and out of sheer shock he threw up onto a plate. That's what they serve here.

One time, I assume they must have run out of beef because I ordered a beef chow mein for takeout and when I got home, there was absolutely no beef in it. Instead, there was a lot of soy sauce to make it appear darker as if there were some ground beef. There was no beef.

No matter what the price, I wouldn't spend my hard-earned cash here. It's not worth trying and definitely not worthy of the beautiful "Asian Ghetto" that is this plaza. Even broke college students must have their standards.

I found myself having a philosophical debate during zumba class at this studio.  The question was:  "what am I looking for in a zumba class?"

I had read the reviews about Twice Balanced before I attended class, and the 2 star review has valid points: if you are a regular zumba goer, you might be surprised by some of the instructor's moves and the pace can be...ummm...non-scientific, I'll say that.

But the 5 star reviews really focus on Christy - and she is the reason to go.  She has a great, infectious energy.  She is kind and fun.  I think she embodies zumba spirit because it's about fun - not perfection of moves - and I get annoyed when I go to classes where it becomes a (sorry to say it) "pissing contest" about who goes the hardest or the best.

I prefer dance-type zumba classes, with a good amount of challenge in the choreography, lots of hip movement, not too much high impact.  This class is pretty energetic, more energetic than finesse, and they have quite a bit of jumping - but you may modify as needed.

There were 12 people in the class today - I talked to a bunch of the regulars after class.  This is the right fit for them, and the atmosphere is one of acceptance and kindness...so, give it a try if you're new to zumba.  For $5, you really can't go wrong!!

Best pizza in boston.

And if the awesome pizza and friendly staff isn't enough- it's in a great hidden location that will impress any non-bostonian. (Although almost anyone who has been to Harvard Square knows about the garage) I'm a hands down margarita pizza fan- but a lot of my friends like the Cheeseburger.
Overpriced but definitely with some great fresh, pre-made items. It can be a bit of a squeeze when there are a lot of people in the store, making checkout maddening.

Pretty blah.

 I remember working around the corner from this place and being really excited when it opened because I used to work at an ice cream store for three years in hig school, so ice cream means a lot in my world. 
 Ive tired my three favorite flavors there: vanilla, cookie dough, and cookies and cream... and they were all just..bleh. Not so wonderful, and surely not worth your money.

 Oh, and the service sucked. No smiles, and no eye contcact. 

Stick to Ben and Jerry's in the Garage or that place that begins with an "H" thats in between John harvards and that sneaker store.  Or hell,buy a pint at CVS.

2 words for you: MORNING BUN.  Check it out team, its pretty delicious.  Strada has decent coffee, and I have been known to leave my apartment when its freezing out just for a cider.  The pastries are always awesome, although I would not necessarily recommend the apple cloud.  The main reason to go to strada is to people watch and listen.  Side story, last year my dad came to visit me and we were sitting and talking and watching all the people go by and he turns to me and informs me that I need a business suit - no prompting at all ha.  Strategic coffee decision on my part, sure but a wonderful place to meet up with friends or hunker down and study for days.

This places sucks, plain and simple.  Here's my story:
My mother ordered flowers through inter flora in a different country, inter flora then sadly they hooked up with Johnny's flowers here in Seattle - that's where the saga began.....First of all they didn't deliver the flowers on the day they were supposed to, then the following day they couldn't find our address and had to call for directions (ever heard of mapquest?)   Finally the flowers showed up wilted, vase full of green water and no apology.  

As if that wasn't bad enough, when I complained to Inter flora about it I got a call from Johnny's to tell me they were coming to PICKUP the flowers (this is three days after the delivery) so that they could refund my mother.  Outrageously bad customer service, the likes of which I haven't experienced....Who treats a customer this way?
Johnny's Flowers, that's who.

To top it all off they called today and asked me to return the flowers! I told them to come and get them and so far they have been sitting on the porch for over 24 hours.....

The spicy special is amaaazing.  The perfect late night food when koronets' pizza gets boring.  They've got a good selection of vitamin water and other beverages (cheap beer!) to wash the sandwich down and pepperidge farm cookies for dessert.

Sure it's incredibly sketchy, but that's part of the unique experience!

I once saw someone order the spicy special with 2 eggs and bacon..try it sometime for a change.

I used to be such a tremendous fan of Red Light that they offered me a job there.  Now that their pre-1960's stock seems to have significantly shrunk and their brand new, "now" selection gets flimsier (aesthetically and physically) with each season, I'm not such a frequent shopper.  However, this is still one of the best places to find Halloween and costume party items because Red Light continues to present unique vintage items. I'm still hoping that I'll walk through the door one of these days and find something that inspires my imagination as much as did my Red Light finds in college.

We really enjoyed this friendly French cafe in the little blue house.  I had the spiniach soup, which was rich and flavorful, and the black pepper duck, which was delightfully juicy.  The chocolate mousse was light and airy.  Aside from the extremely attentive service, it really does feel like Paris in there.  Will return.

Fondly called "The 2-9" by most people, this little cafe doesn't have too much special to offer besides its convenient location close to USC and typical American food (appetizers, sandwiches, and burgers) if you're craving it. I've been here a few times for happy hour, and even then with the discounts on appetizers, I didn't think the food was particularly worth it for the price since the portions aren't too generous. The beer was decent, but a bit on the pricey side as well.

The place is most often visited by the college crowd so I wouldn't recommend going with kids or as a middle-aged adult... unless you're a nostalgic Trojan alum perhaps. The atmosphere can be described as chill or laid-back and is more like that of a small bar. The outdoor patio is cute touch for those who would like to eat outdoors on a nice day. 

Be forewarned, though, that on late nights and often on weekends, this place can get fairly crowded with members of the party-loving USC Greek community if that's not your scene.

Not the best BBQ place.  Sauce was too sweet.  

Based in the hype I expected the meat to be more tender, but it was no better than the ribs you would get at Chili's.

The place with the blue awning! I finally know the real name of the restaurant...Pho Vietnam is my absolute favorite place not only to eat pho, but my favorite place to eat on the ave.  The broth is delicious, especially with a nice helping of plum sauce.  I always get chicken pho and the chicken is always clean (and white meat) which I prefer.   I also love that they aren't sparing with their helpings of cilantro and onions. This place is WAY better than any other pho place on the ave!

The place is pretty packed on Sunday mornings.  It's a nice place to have some breakfast, drink coffee and chat with friends and family.  The service is good and the wait for your order is not bad at all.

They have a good selection of bagels, but I only really come here during the fall and winter for the pumpkin bagels and pumpkin cream cheese.  I wait all year to get my fill and I haven't been disappointed with it yet.

This rating will go up, they just need to finish the place/add their fantastic beer.

Roof top view of Midtown is awesome!  I had a pizza with a funny name...it was great.

This past Saturday - we headed down to U-Village to get some brunch before the Huskies football game.  Surprise surprise....The Ram was packed.  We put our names down, it looked like we were about #10 down on the list...then we asked the hostess about an estimated wait time - she just looked at me and said 'honestly, there's no estimate - no one is moving".  Ok.  I was starving.  Next place please!  

It was a little before 10, so I wasn't sure what else would be open.  We called Sonrisa and they said they were...so we walked to the other side of U-village.  It was somewhat empty when we got there - a few football fans were already at the bar though.  Our waitress came by and let us know about a drink special they were running for the day - Husky-rita, basically a ton of alcohol mixed together then thrown into a bucket for our sipping pleasure.  Done, 2 please!

I had been here once before just for drinks - but was weary of all the bad reviews they got here on Yelp.  Didn't matter though cause like I said, I was huuuuuungry!  I got the breakfast burrito and the bf got steak/chicken combo fajitas.  

The Husky-ritas and chips/salsa were brought out first.  Both were good!  The chips and salsa were unlike any I had tried before - the chips were a little thicker and the salsa was really smoky, I liked it!  

My burrito was huge and I enjoyed every single bite of it.  Filled w/ eggs and potatoes - yum yum!  The fajitas were good too...but how can one really mess up on fajitas?  

I liked my experience at Sonrisa.  The service was good.  The food was good.  The drinks were good.  I'd go back!

Thank you Wow for being open late, having a ton of games such as jenga that I can play intensely and challenge others to, keeping a giant TV tuned in to the news, giving me that little bible verse on my cup, and providing a delicious product that is often elsewhere kind of messed up for me. 

A friend took me to Wow for my first bubble tea drinking experience in college, and the only thing I'd recommend is to skip the tapioca or ask for half the standard amount.  And bring cash, they CHARGE for using a credit card. wowww..

Beautiful Nude Beach
This is where I saw my first cock ring, very sexy.

I had the grilled cheese with bacon, tomatoes, and grilled onions, it was okay -2 points for that. I asked for no butter/oil on the bread and they listened- 5 points for that!!  I am not a fan thick fat french fries- minus points for that. My friend had the ruben sandwhich, she said it was good, but I think it looked nasty. The food is average. Prices are average. The drinks are weak. I had two jack and diets and my friend had  several seagram and diets and they were all weak. We just want a good drink! They did not know how to make a whiskey drink or they are just being cheap. If you go here just order beer. I will never go back here. I ordered whiskey because it was HALLOWEEN and I wanted a real drrrinnk, and their drinks were like Cola. Minus minus points for weak weak drinks on Halloween!! C'mon now.  If my fellow law students suggest going here, I will persuade all of them to go elsewhere. The end!

They deserve 6 stars. Tim and Hayley Townley are some of the best in the industry. They are honest,  real people dedicated to helping you find and secure the real estate you are looking for. I felt so comfortable with them as if we had been friends for years yet professional and dedicated to my needs. Thank you so much.

Michael Stout
EZ Storage Depot

Had dinner with some friends for a birthday. We got the DineLA "deal", so the dinner menu is kinda set.

All in all, the experience was good. The atmosphere was good and warm. I especially like the many small dinning "nooks" where there's just a few tables each ( less than 4). Very private and I really should take my wife there to experience it.

The dishes that we ordered were good - plating was excellent, items are fresh and they taste good. However, it wasn't exceptional, which was somewhat of a disappointment. The beef medallion that I ordered was good, but wasn't something that's comparable to Ruth's Chris -- a little on the salty and chewy side (trying to hide something?) However, I really liked their onion and olive tart. Pretty innovative and completely delicious. I have to try to experiment with making that at home!

In all, this is a good place for a small group to dine and enjoy the time and company. A little on the pricey side, but this is what it usually takes.

I don't know what kind of poopy pills Crystal was on when she wrote her review of Rice U. but damn woman, quite being such a pissy pot!  :P

Granted this is not the greatest running trail of all time as it can only accommodate so many people, but for us Houstonians we don't have many options.  I'll share my two cents of why i think this is a great running route and how you can make it into an even better loop than the original 2.9 miles.

This review is primarily about the 3 mile running loop around Rice U. campus but as most people know this is a world-class university with an absolutely beautiful campus.  If you haven't explored the campus I suggest taking an afternoon and walking through it. You'll be amazed at what you find.  I work closely with a number of professors at Rice and I even coached there for 4 years and all my student/athletes are awesome! 

The loop.  It's mostly shaded and consists of a nicely packed dirt trail along a 2.9 mile loop surrounding the campus and has 2 water stops.  It's narrow as I mentioned and you do have to be aware of cars that are coming in and out of the many entrances to the university.  But you're running!  You should always be conscientious of what's around you.

To extend my run I sometimes add an additional 2.2 mile loop of Hermann Park which is adjacent to the Rice campus.  Cut across Sunset over the light rail and you'll find a dirt trail that goes around the Houston Zoo and around Hermann Park and the golf course.  It's a nice little jaunt that can extend your run to a nice 5-6 miler.  Finally to add a little more variety, you can also opt to divert off the Rice loop and take a quick run up the Stadium Stairs.  I love this run and in fact used to have my teams do this as dry land training during our water polo season.  I make it challenging by running up and down each main stairline then run across the football field and up and down on the opposite side so you're literally running the entire stadium.  You can't do that anywhere else in Houston!

And finally, this is our weekly running route for our Brian O'Neill's Running Club so the next time you're out there on a Tuesday night and you get bombarbed by 100 people running at you all in the same direction, my apologies.  But we're having some serious fun so you should probably just join us anyways!

Run On!

In one word, Awesome! This is a smaller spot on the east side that from what it appears is like any other pizza joint. What it really is, is some of the best pizza I have ever tasted with great creations and cheap prices! Make sure to hit this spot! You wont be sorry!

Two words:

THE BEST.

This is awesome for a run of any length, and it provides a 5 star view of the river, which makes it perfect for those late evening runs because the heat earlier in the day were god awful and the sunset hours are the only hours where you can bear physical exertion outside. With Central Park several avenues over, Riverside Park is like the younger stepchild of runners' paths, but I'm not sure I understand why.

A) You don't risk running through gaggles of tourists and/or horse odors if you decide to run below 72nd street.

B) Along with the beautiful view of the river, you can also avoid the sauna-effect that sometimes happens in Central Park because of the nice breeze that comes directly off the river.

C) Whenever you've decided that you've had enough, Riverside Park offers an exit at nearly every street to head back over to Broadway. Central Park has exits and transverses at different streets, but they can be annoying to find sometimes. At Riverside Park, there's no guess work involved since you're running parallel to the street!

D) Taking an evening run near sunset + sunset view on the river? Need I say more?

I like it. I like it a lot.

"Cool" ambiance and free Wifi ain't enough; ya' gotta greet your customer and take their order at some point.  Well, the later seemed to be optional during my first visit to Octane.  I met a friend there and we both felt like the staff were enjoying the ambiance and Wifi instead of talking to customers to figure out what they're in for........go figure.

Yeah, just about everything other reviewers have said is true; but the laissez faire approach to service and loud atmosphere should make you think twice.

In all fairness, once we placed our order the staff were accommodating, the selection of beer was impressive, and the Wifi was free.  Just not sure that's enough reason to keep goin' back.

During the years that I was a student at UC San Diego, Dr. Lange was my general dentist.  For anyone on campus looking for a dentist (or anyone from the community in general looking for one), look no further!  Dr. Lange has such a great bedside manner, and he and his staff are very professional, friendly, and courteous.  During the last few years that I saw him (I've since moved back to Los Angeles), his office expanded in space, and it is now super comfortable for anyone getting a procedure done here.  Probably the highlight are the TV screens positioned at every chair, with satellite/cable TV access!!  Watch TV as you get your teeth cleaned or teeth filled!  Again, his staff is super super friendly.  I cannot speak highly enough of him and his staff, as well as his office.  Dr. Lange set the standard when I started searching for a new dentist upon moving back to Los Angeles after graduation from UC San Diego.  

Tip: For students who live on campus, there is a pedestrian bridge that leads from the Medical School parking lots to La Jolla Village Drive, and near Dr. Lange's office.  The pedestrian bridge crosses La Jolla Village Drive.  Perfect for riding your bike to the dentist!  The complex where his office is located has bike parking underneath.

UPDATE: I went back to KBP for eyebrow threading and underarm waxing. First of all, I got 20% of my services for a total of $14!!!!!!! NEVER, in Los Angeles, will you find eyebrow threading AND underarm waxing for such a price. Secondly, I was treated with such TLC knowing that I was a newbie to waxing. After the waxing, tweezers were used to remove any lingering stubborn hairs. Excellent service!

BEST place to go in the Berkeley area for lunch if you want a big, fresh, hearty, healthy salad! 

The servings at Cafe Intermezzo are HUGE! I usually get the $7.50 combo of veggie delight salad and sandwich or soup. Their Thai Chicken Noodle Soup is soo good! My favorite dressing is definitely their housemade poppyseed dressing.

This place always has a line, it's even crowded in the summer time when Cal isn't in session. But the line moves quickly and it's definitely worth the wait. Most people get it to go so it's not like a huge line of people waiting for a table to open up at a restaurant. 

Every friend I've taken to this place loved it!

Attitudes is a small hotel bar with a small performance area and dance floor. I've seen a couple of shows here and have had a pretty good time at both. 

The performance stage is small and low in front of a small dance floor and raised area surrounding it. It's a bit awkward to navigate - you can't get straight to the bathroom from the dance floor. The floor can get pretty crowded, and it can get fratty. There's a perfect space for those taping the shows, and the staff is friendly and accommodating - in general and to tapers. Beer is not too expensive. The food is a little more expensive, and passable but not fantastic. 

Both times I've been here, though, there's been some kind of preppy event at the conference room next door. It hasn't been a problem, I just thought I should note it.

I saw Donna Jean and the Tricksters here last summer and Railroad Earth here last night. Donna Jean was pretty good, though she played to a mostly empty house. Railroad Earth was fantastic, though. A small, intimate environment like this is the best place to see them.

Overall, a slightly inconvenient location but not a bad place.

Curious Tattoo is a 5 star spot! I'm not just saying that because I just got some work done there yesterday either (http://qik.ly/CgCKVEW5eTY8PzQDV714RxS).

The guys that run it are cool as hell & about their business at the same time. Their prices are pretty standard and if you're a faithful customer like me they'll even work with you more. Not a bad combination at all!

Parking sucks ass around there so walk with a lot of change & expect to have to go and feed the meter every hour and a half.  That could get annoying when you get big pieces done like me, but Curious has nothing to do with that so I guess it's a moot point!

Anyway, I get all my work done there (by Jon to be exact) so it would be an understatement to say I'm not pleased with his work. 

Normally I wouldn't write a review about something like this, but I had to this time!  Long story short, I was supposed to get this work done on Sat but Jon's car broke down. That's nothing he has control over but I was still pretty bummed about it! I booked this appointment weeks ago so I was looking forward to getting my tat ALL WEEK.  Anyway the reason this experience got them a review & I'll continue to be a faithful customer is because Jon came in on his day off to tat me! I'm still in awe about that.  I dunno too many people that would do that when they didn't do anything wrong to begin with.  That's what I call stellar customer service.

I'm already looking forward to my next appointment!

Soul food, just amazing. So good. I can't think about it. Oh my god. Fuck. After I write this review I am going to cook a pound of bacon eat some apple pie, which I just brought back from Upstate, and and when I'm done, I'll probably still want to go to Kitchenette. Nothing compares. 

Ok, Good Enough To Eat compares. And is better. But this place is really good. They're also different; Kitchenette is a little more austere. They're in different neighborhoods... whatever.

Anyway, everything here has a little delicious hint of grease in it. In a good way. I get a bacon omelette w/extra bacon and a side of bacon. No regrets. 

Oh and GUESS WHAT? This is really the awesome part: they deliver to the Columbia area. Pretty far south, actually. They used to get me on 111th, which is awesome given the relative lack of good food options immediately south of Columbia (Community being a notable exception), it was a godsend; I ordered from them dozens of times a year, and was always surprising people: 

Him: WAIT THEY DELIVER TO 113st? 
Me: No shit, you idiot! 
Him: Shit.
Me: Wait, have you been eating at Tom's? Hahhahahahahaha. Haha. Ha! You dunce! 

Note: I did have a terrible delivery experience with them once, however. This is just a funny story. You can stop reading here if you have shit to do, my review is over. Still here? Ok, so the Kitchenette delivery guy comes and he forgot my cookie (which was a few dollars) and my coffee (which was a few dollars) and I have been charged for both on the receipt. So I say, ok here's the bill plus another dollar, and have them knock off the balance of the cookie and coffee which you didn't send, and that's a great tip (maybe $5.50 on $11 principal). No big deal, anyway. The guy nodded as I explained in English, fluent Spanish, and pantomime. I also circled the missing items on the restaurant copy check. Well, he must have been Phillipe or Brazilian or deaf, because the next day I call, hey can I place an order. What's your address? _____ 111th street. The person starts cursing at me and yelling: you don't PAY FOR YOUR FOOD? I'm like wait a second, I paid. That's not what the delivery guy said. I definitely paid. He claimed I didn't pay again, and I explained that I did. Then he goes off: you tipped a QUARTER on a 3/4 mile walk in the snow? I tried to explain the deal with being billed for the coffee and undelivered cookie. But he basically continues with the indignant class warfare diatribe. ou rich boy. Bet you never worked delivery, he says. I explained that I delivered for Dominoes and in Texas, and I am totally sympathetic, and I really tipped $5 since I didn't get two (2) of my four (4) items, which is generous, considering it's nearly 50% of the value of delivered items and the order was done wrong. This doesn't calm him down at all. I've had enough. Can I talk to a manager? I AM THE MANAGER. AND YOU'RE BANNED FROM KITCHENNETE FOR LIFE. Yes, I was banned. The address was blacklisted from delivery. Of course, my roommates who I had gotten addicted to Kitchenette, were furious with me over this and blamed me. I tried calling back to talk it out, but it was just like an episode of Curb Your Enthusiasm or something.

This place pales in comparison to other places i've tried, but considering prices and milk-tea boba ratio, this place is pretty good. The boba is small, but sweet and chewy, so that sorta makes up for the watery milk tea. And its also a bit cheaper than quickly's. I've the the burgers here once...and it was very ordinary. so i guess you should stick w/ their boba.

thank goodness i have found my new haircut place in los angeles! i have been so skeptical of places in southern california (i dont like haircuts in the first place and trusting a stranger while paying them an arm and a leg doesn't really put me at ease, if you know what i mean).  i usually just grow my hair out and when i travel back home to the bay area, i fit in a quick hair cut.  however, due to way too much work and not enough time, i haven't been able to go back for a while and my hair was getting way too long for my liking.

I tried the aveda institute because it was so ridiculously close and the prices were so cheap that even if it turned out pretty horribly, i wouldn't have wasted a fortune on it.  the reviews you see here are totally correct...you really need to set aside a few hours to get your hair cut because they definitely take their sweet time cutting.  i think my hair grew in the time it took my hairdresser to cut it.  but that's not to say anything bad about them because I ended up with a great hairdresser who was very very nice, if not a little bit too gossipy for my taste.  but she was professional, sweet, and really cared about what i wanted.  i told her my concerns, kind of gave her an idea of what i wanted to accomplish in the session (intense, huh?) and i basically just put my faith in her.  she came through!  i loved my hair cut by the time i was out and she definitely addressed everything i mentioned.  for the price, it's a great deal because it comes with a wash, a small neck/head massage, consulting time, as well as the cut.  it also puts you more at ease when you know there are teachers who are ready to take over if something goes horribly wrong.  
everyone there is very nice and the customer service is great. no complaints and i'm definitely going back! the only negative i can think of is the obscene amount of time it takes.

The staff at elite body workers is the best in town, and then there is the talented therapist Jacklyn Hannibal! By far the best massage I have ever received, I will be referring my training clients and my friends to her for years to come. Thank you Jacklyn for being so in touch with your clients needs!

I have to say I'm a fan of Yummy.  I work across the street so it's a great place to grab a quick lunch on a weekday.  The girls who work there are sweet, and the lunch bento boxes are the best deal.

I usually order the bento with tempura shrimp (very tasty), or the sesame chicken (also good).  The box comes with your main choice, as well as salad, a wonton, edamame, rice, and 2 pieces of California roll.  I usually skip the CA roll and the edamame (not a huge fan of either) and I STILL leave full.  It's a lot of food for a great price - $7 - 9!

I did try some of their rolls once.  I thought they were good, and they do have a buy 3, get one free special.  Even still, the rolls are around $12, so with the promotion they even out to about $9 each.  For $9, I'd prefer the big hearty bento box, personally.

The place is small, the soda comes in cans, and they don't take Amex, but hey, I like it anyway!  :)  The service is always speedy yet very polite, and the food has never disappointed.

No! Really? Closed? Why? Is it my fault because I haven't been there in a few months? It's just that I live downtown now.. I'm sorry. Where am I going to go get yummy hand shaven noodles now? Really? International District? Fine. Sucky.

Warning: This is a little gross...

I actually went here a long time ago but just thought of writing a review.  I had never gotten a pedicure before (and only one manicure) and was a little squeamish about the idea of someone getting up close and personal with my toes but decided to see what all the fuss was about.  A friend of mine went there regularly.  

The place looked clean and the massaging chair was nice.  The technician talked me into getting a simultaneous manicure.  When I put my feet in the foot bath my skin nearly burned off!  It was REALLY hot which I guess is a good thing.  Still, I needed some convincing (OK, the technician held my feet down) to dip my feet in and keep them there.  

The manicure and pedicure were...OK, I guess.  Sorry, I don't have much to base it on since I don't get my nails done regularly.  I would've gone there again though.

Except...about a week later I noticed a cluster of 3 little dots on the bottom of my heel.  I thought it was a callous and ignored it.  But, it kept growing.  A plantar wart hurts and has little black dots inside so it couldn't be one, right? 

Finally, it got to the point where I thought someone was gonna call the CDC on me.  I saw a nurse who confirmed that it was a plantar wart.  A couple of months and two bottles of Dr's Scholl's wart remover later and it was finally gone.  

There is no way I could've gotten it from anywhere other than the nail salon.  I don't frequent any pools or locker rooms.  Sadly, this experience will probably prevent from getting a pedicure ever again.

As someone with several tattoos, all from different artists, I believe I'm fairly qualified to weigh in on the quality of a studio, an artist, and the finished product. I wanted to wait until my tattoo had full healed to write this review and I'm happy to say that it's a positive review.

I was greeted immediately upon entering the shop. The receptionist was pleasant and attentive. She listened to what I was interested in getting and handed me the portfolio of the artist she felt would be best for the art I wanted. Lucky for me, it was Kelly Barr. I looked through his portfolio and recognized some of the pieces. His style definitely meshed well with what I was looking to get. The receptionist went back and spoke to Kelly to see when he would be available to consult with me and it only took about five minutes. 

He was immediately into the design I wanted and knew exactly what I was talking about regarding the style I desired. He didn't take very long to draw up what I wanted and it turned out exactly as I had pictured in my head. We agreed on size, coloring, everything. We went back and he cleaned & set up his workspace. Everything was cleaned as it should be and the set-up of his gear was sanitary, which put me even more at ease.

Kelly let me pick the placement of the stencil and then got to work. My eyes wandered over the plethora of music memorabilia on his room's walls and some pieces piqued my interest. I've since read on a review here that Kelly isn't fond of talking while he works, but he seemed just fine to discuss music, Texas, his experience in Boston, and traveling. Now, I don't know if it's just because we had similar interests or if he was just in a talkative mood, but the conversation was fun.

He had me check the tattoo periodically as he was working, to make sure it was still to my liking. This was very appreciated. As he was doing the color, he checked to make sure I wanted certain colors in certain locations and the "shine" factor was acceptable (part of my request to give the object a metallic shine) and it more than met my expectations. 

The pain factor was nil. Kelly wasn't heavy-handed at any point, but did go over each line multiple times. The friends who accompanied me were both shocked that I wasn't reacting to the tattoo and was smiling & laughing during my conversation with Kelly. Admittedly, I do have a high pain tolerance, but this was the least painful tattoo I've had so far.

Kelly didn't go over aftercare, but I'm guessing it's because we had talked about my other tattoos and he assumed I knew what to do (I did). Prior to bandaging the tattoo, he asked if he could take pictures of it. I was very pleased with the work, so I agreed. He took pictures on his iPhone and with his SLR. 

Overall, the experience was very positive and as stated, the tattoo is exactly as I pictured it. The red coloring is extremely bright and the blues and white are very crisp. The linework is perfect and there has been no bleeding, despite the tattoo being on thinner skin (inner forearm, near the wrist). 

After seeing the finished product, I expressed to Kelly that I was so pleased with the tattoo that I would like to incorporate it into an entire sleeve design. Now that the tattoo is completely healed and it looks as perfect as it did when it was still fresh, I feel the exact same way. I won't go anywhere other than him for that sleeve. Since I live in San Diego, traveling to Boston for multiple sessions is going to add a pretty penny to the cost of the sleeve, overall, but with Kelly's artistry it will be well worth it.

[Note: The rating is for Kelly Barr only. I have not utilized Chameleon for piercing services, nor can I vouch for anyone working at Chameleon other than Kelly. I am pleased with the way the shop accommodated me, as a walk-in, and the nature of the receptionist... so for those instances, I will give a recommend. ]

Totally delicious food -- awesome selection of olive oils, balsamic vinegars, mustards, jams, baked goods, and CHOCOLATE!! Best of all, they want you to taste everything. I was in the shop for 15 minutes and walked out full of cheese and chocolate and brownies and delectable olive oil on bread.

I am sad that so many people disliked this place! Granted I have not physically been there, we only ordered in one lazy day, but I thought it was pretty good and not a bad deal wither! Got the thai sate chicken, yummy, lots of peanut!! How can you go wrong with peanut? The calamari was good too, yummy. Karen's sushi looked pretty decent. The bubble tea was sooooooo yummy!! The food came quickly. The delivery guy was nice. We had plasticware and chopsticks. Napkins too. I hope it stays good!!

Great prices on food and beer
I got theTri-Tip Salad,very tasty.
My husband got a burger,very good
the BBQ sauces they have there are very good.
Premium beer only $10.95 for a pitcher.

Attention POOR college students, this is a great place for drive-through Chinese!  I rave about this place and it gets 4 stars NOT because of taste, but the consistency their huge portions.  4 words:  Eat here, be full.  It has never failed me that way.  I don't ever go here to sit down (and don't plan on it), but the drive through is awesome for a quick boat-load of yummy carbs.  I get a box FULL of steaming rice and pick a 2-item combo from their daily menu, usually chicken with mushrooms or szechuan beef.  For around $5, it's the best bang for your buck.

The brown paper bag they hand over probably weighs several pounds and my hand buckles as I lift it through my window.  Their eggrolls and crab rangoon are good... everything is a version of "americanized" Chinese food.   I don't see a lot of asians frequenting this place because they don't offer much variety or quality of flavor but hey, I can't complain!  (From what I've encountered through the drive-through), the workers are smiley, pretty nice and very efficient.  It's not gourmet, but when I'm hungry and telling myself "not pizza again..." it will be Hot Wok Express.  Just slather on some sriracha hot sauce.

Cookie Noomber One... P. Diddy Tyrese's Pieces Peanut Booter Cups!

L.A's very own Tito at Power 106 would've deliciously devoured a dozen of these cookies in twenty-four seconds flat.  Yes, they have Peanut Butter Cookies, but I didn't try 'em.  Out of the ones I did, this is what Jose Ole's Top 4 at 4 would look like:

4.  Cinnamon Sugar (Snickerdoodle)
3.  White Chocolate Chip with Macadamia
2.  Chocolate Chip

... and Jose Ole's Noomber One Cookie es.....

1.  El Pollo Loco Chocolat Chip off the old block with a Walnuts, yes ma'am-sir

I like how the walnuts add a depth, heft and crunch.  Next time, I'll try their brownies.  If Diddy ran dis city, he wouldn't stop at Junior's for a Cheesecake, but at Diddy Riese for delectable treats worthy to Tweet.  How can you beat a $1.50 ice cream sandwich??  If only it wasn't Dreyer's, that's how.  It's still good though and you can't stop - WON'T stop..  *harlem shakes* eh EH.  eh EH eating dis 'wich.  You can always opt to pick up a dozen for under $4.

As my friend would say, it's utterly "joygasmic."  Or should I say, "yoyasmic"?

We prolly should have come in a lot earlier.  First available table was right by the door.  It was pretty cold the whole time we ate.  Food was great but since it was so busy our wait service wasn't that great. I'd definitely still come here again but this time was so-so.

Of all the Ted's locations, this is definitely my favorite. I ate there just the other day, and it was amazing. We ordered a few cheeseburgers, fries, onion rings, and calamari. Now I don't like fish fry much, but the rest of their offerings, I love. 
My favorite part of my dining experience there, is listening to them call back the order. Most of the time the person who takes your order will talk in what I call the "Ted's Lingo". For instance, a fish fry = a fry, a french fry = a french, onion rings = o ring, or sometimes just ring. It just makes it that much more fun when you are ordering, especially once you learn the lingo too!
Now keep in mind, it's a fish fry, so everything is greasy, so if grease scares you, don't bother coming here. But, if grease is ok with you, you'll be please, I'm sure. 
The fries are crisp, the onion rings are as well, and they are so golden. They have quite the variety for a fish fry, and I find the prices are great.

I don't care what anyone says.  Jimmy Johns is as awesome as  the day is long!  

I ordered the "Italian Night Club", which is a foot of delicious italian meats, provolone, mayo, oil and vinegar, onions lettuce tomato, etc.  The single sandwich was delivered to my door in under 15 minutes, and the entire thing only costs $5.75.  

It's like subway sandwiches on steroids.

I tend to workout before work at 7:00am, and it's not too bad. There are usually one or two cardio machines open at that time. If I were more motivated and got there half an hour earlier, I'd get my choice of machines, but THAT'S not gonna happen. When I get a day off and go mid-day it's a piece of cake also. Afternoons and evenings are a crap shoot. More than once I've given up and gone and lifted because I didn't want to stand and stare and wait for an elliptical to open up.

I never tried any of the rec classes and have heard mixed reviews. Debating if I want to get on board with one this semester or not.

The pool? Kind of useless, honestly. I'm not concerned about the depth as some have reported (For God's sake, I'm 6'6) but it's always used for practices and teams and there are so few hours for open swim that it's not worth the effort to coordinate that into my schedule. Maybe once the weather is nicer I'll redouble my efforts to work this into my routine, but not now.

Locker rooms are huge and generally well-maintained. Students who work here are mostly on top of things, though you of course get the occasional dingbat.

Price? Well, I'm on staff so it's reasonable. $35 deducted before taxes. Not the steal of the century, not a bad deal either for a big complex so close to work.

2 big, juicy dogs for $6? WORD.

Next time I am ordering everything on the menu and taking a bite of everything to see what I like best! =)

NOM, NOM, NOM

yeah, it's pricey for ice cream..
but damn people, ...Enjoy!
You could be going to 21 choices..lol

The best customer service I have had was at Santa Barbara
and Covina..yeah. I said Covina.
I used to live across the wall from there. Literally.
The Pasdena one is a bit bland in style and energy.
The one in Figueroa by USC has the worst service
and portions suck too!!

So..new flavor
Yellow cake with orea & almonds..
All these years I never new they had cake.
It's a bit sweet of a combo, but that's why you go
every once in a while, noy nightly rosy odonnel.
Yeah...I said it.
And, I like guns..haha

Park at barnes n noble, easiest places and you can walk to TJ's from the top parking lot too.
What's good is the out door seating at coffee bean next door.
Good summer hang

Working for a hospital out of state and recently moving over here, I had great expectations for UCLA. I was soo disappointed with the health care quality and there staff I have decided to NEVER come back here again for doctors visit unless it is down right necessary. 

The parking is ridiculously expensive first of all. $11 flat rate to much to just a visit. I can only imagine how much they make with people who have to routinely visit the doctor. In the maze of offices I finally landed to the OB/GYN department to see Dr. Kirsten Jensen. I came on time only to be pulled back and wait another hour to be finally placed in a room, when I kept asking the nurse how much longer it would be her English and understanding was so incompetent it just became annoying. The Dr. was OK, I could tell she was still new at her practice so I can't give her a hard time, she was OK. 
To get labs drawn, it's like deli, waiting for your number to be called and being pulled back in a maze of phlebotomists who draw and record and tell you that you can leave, I waited 20-25 min for that.

What gets me the MOST of this visit, that I can not get over, Was how the doctor told me it would be no more then 2 weeks to receive my lab results if not to call the office and if final resort to contact her at her email. I waited 2 weeks, NO call. I contacted the office which leads to voice mail and left a message, NO call. I finally emailed the Dr. and she responded fast thankfully, everything normal. But that's not the point, I'm paying 500ish for this visit I think I should at least get a call to let me know the results? very unprofessional.

Also, everything in insurance is almost all still pending after four months, Kind of crazy how I have to wait to see what will be the final bill this long. 
I'm now going to stick with private offices that seem to give a more friendly and warm approach to their patients for future appts.

I know several people who have gotten tattoos and piercings here and they were all totally pleased with their experiences. I've gotten pierced here twice and was also happy with the results, with one big exception.

First, the good:
The staff is pretty good at putting you at ease if you're nervous. Maybe there can be a little element of alterna-scorn, but really this is one of the more welcoming tattoo/piercing parlors I've been too. The staff is happy to answer questions, and they're serious business about what they do. The facilities are extremely clean and pleasant to be in.

Now the bad:
The second time I went there, I was determined to follow their instructions to a T since my skin is somewhat easily irritated. I stuck with their regimen, but lo, 2 days later my piercing was infected. REALLY infected. My entire ear was dark purple, swollen, and hot to the touch. I work in a hospital, and the doctors with whom I worked took one look at me and told me I needed to take some antibiotics immediately, or there could be serious health consequences. I decided to call Chameleon, since as piercing experts they probably knew what to do, right? Apparently not...
After I explained my situation they told me that my piercer wasn't available to talk, but he could call me in half an hour (apparently no one else at the store knows what to do when a piercing gets badly infected?). When he called me back, he dismissed my suggestion that my ear was infected, accused me of not following their advice and then told me not to take antibiotics, and just put a salt compress on my purple, seeping ear.
I was so intimidated that I tried to do what he said, but the infection just kept getting worse, to the point that I was pretty much ordered by the doctors at work to leave work and get a prescription for antibiotics.

I'm not implying that their facilities are unclean or that they caused the infection. My severe infection was an extremely rare complication of piercings (most often piercing infections are quite mild), but it's irresponsible for a store to provide a service that can have this complication and then give incorrect advice about what to do to deal with it. 
In summary: Get your piercings at chameleon, but do your research ahead of time, because their advice can be useless or even harmful.

I think Lemon Grass is pretty darn good.

Lunch special: Lemon Grass soup, Crispy Roll, and Royal Noodle combo is my fav. Though you can mix and match from a variety. 

Funny dish names... There's a dish called "Jungle Princess" You are what you eat, ya know....
Used to be a fan and then... I saw a rat!  EWWWWW

Small place, good burgers, terrible service.  I've been a few times and the service has been horrible every time.  I stood at the bar once for 10 minutes and was completely ignored so I walked out.  Another time I sat with a group at the high top tables and had a waitress who could have cared less.

The burgers are small but you get 2 of them.  The buns are soft and steamed and the burgers are juicy with a nice crunch on the outside.  The Crunch Burger is great with thinly sliced onion rings on it.  Delicious.  They have a decent beer selection as well as a full bar.

I want to like this place but will probably never go back.  After trying them a few times the lack of service does it for me.
Impressive vintage game selection. They didn't have what I was looking for, but if you're a gamer, you need to stop in here and look around.

Hands down my favorite restaurant in Providence.  I live in Boston now and I often find myself daydreaming about this place.  It is the total package.  Excellent food, great wine, superb service and pitch-perfect ambiance.  

Upon walking into this 40-seat beauty, I feel welcome and accommodated....as though I've just entered a close friend's house.  It's never stuffy or overzealous and always surpasses my expectations.  I lived in RI for 4 years and visited this place a fair amount and I never, never, never left feeling anything less than completely enamored (and no, I wasn't drunk).  Menus change daily.... always try the specials, they are the best.  And the Bistro meals offer a ridiculous value (3 courses for 23 bucks???) Oh New Rivers how you tantalize me,  Now see, in Boston, for the same quality bistro meal, you would pay 35-39$  and you have  to deal with the horror that is parking in Boston.  Not so in Rhody where the lot behind the restaurant welcomes you happily to the tune of 5$.  
Bruce, the owner, utilizes local food products, grown and harvested responsibly, which is not only ethical, but also yields fresher, better-tasting food. And I love that they have "half portions" of entrees.  So if you eat like a bird (as my BF claims I do- and I deny) you don't have that diner guilt of sitting in front of a too-huge portion of whatever and thinking about Sally Struthers and the withering children you should be sponsoring in developing countries.  

Also, it should be noted that  I'm not into eating at a "place to be seen".  I want to eat at an honest restaurant that does what a restaurant ought to do, which is nourish your body and act as a relaxing backdrop for great conversations.

I am struggling to match my experiences at New Rivers with a restaurant in Boston.  My favorites here, so far, are Oleana, Craigie St Bistro, and Ten Tables.... They are all great places...but each has a little something missing.  And I vow never to give 5-stars to any restaurant that can't knock my socks off and love me tender like this little gem always does. 

Mr. Tillenghast, you are my hero. For Real.

The one trip I have made thus far to Crook's Corner was enough to convince me that they are serving the greatest shrimp n' grits on this earth.  Succulent shrimp, tender mushrooms, perfectly cooked and seasoned cheddar grits, crispy bacon, fresh scallions.  Good lord I wish was I wasn't in DC for the sole reason that I can't eat there again today.  Furthermore, the jalapeno hushpuppies are a delicious addition to the meal.  Although, I can only attest to the tastiness of their shrimp n' grits, if their other food is one third as good it would still be super impressive.  My only complaint was the rather cramped dining space (I am 6'6), but for that food I would eat standing up in a small, cramped, out-of service elevator.  Go (Run...on second thought sprint!) there now..you will not be disappointed.

Smells like a stale, beer-soaked frat house and usually packed with a loud college crowd but man, the pizza is superb. Is it the hand tossed pizza dough or the sauce or fresh ingredients that makes it so delicious? No matter, a trip to SLO always includes a stop here.

This Taco Bell & A&W Express is located in the same food court as Quizno's and the La Famiglia Pizza place right next to UPenn's campus.  Pretty standard Taco Bell Express. They do a pretty good job at moving through the sometimes long lines.  The soda fountain seems to be screwed up 8 times out of 10.  Deductions for that.  Overall though, good spot if you're craving TB.

Oh Sandrine's! A great French restaurant just off the beaten path of Harvard Sq. Ask for Sherman as your waiter, he is amazing, funny, informative and friendly! 

I have eaten her many times and recommend the pan sired fois gras the best I have ever had. Chef Raymond Ost knows fois gras. The duck is always fantastic, as are the mussels. And the chocolate Kooglehoff is out of this world, with its salted caramel sauce and scoop of vanilla ice cream, I could eat this at every meal (and have tried!) 

Very friendly and knowledgeable staff, great wine list and delicious food!

Definitely..in my opinion there is a difference in this venue compared to the one in the Back Bay..from the service..the atmosphere..to the legendary molten chocolate....! The Finale @ Park Plaza is soooo much better....and almost just feels like a different spot all together...!

There was a party of like 20 cops in here? The stereotypes are REAL!

The girl behind the counter had PIGTAILS and made my coffee wrong.  She obviously didn't listen to one word I said.

Met my needs of coffee while waiting for my tire to get fixed at Car Zone across the street.

This store stocks a lot of tee shirts and jackets that would be the cream of the crop at a Goodwill.  The dude who owns it, Kerry, is cool.  He designs his own stuff under the arevolt label, and he plays good music.  

Last time I went I got two t-shirts. One says "Coors' Great Radkin River Raft Race" and another says "Union Made in the U.S.A. by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union ILGWU AFL-CIO."

They carry spray paint too, which is convenient.

I'm not too crazy about the whole frozen yogurt trend, since I've been eating the stuff for 15-20 years at TCBY, long before it suddenly became the cool food to eat. Perhaps that's why I like Yogurt Pump so much. It doesn't try to fit into the mold of the new yogurt places springing up everywhere across the country, with pretty colors on the walls and overpriced little bowls with few flavors to really choose from.

Yogurt Pump looks more like a storage room for a restaurant than an wanna-be trend-spot. Thankfully all I came for was yogurt, not pretty pictures, so they don't make me pay the extra cost for a nice environment. It's simple, delicious yogurt flavors, in huge portions with unpretentious service. They give you a large bowl for just a few dollars, much better than the skimpy sizes you get at Pink/Ice/JooJoo/whateverthehell-Berry you want to go to.

One of the true signs of good yogurt (to me anyway) is if they can make the flavors taste like their ice cream equivalents, since they don't get to use all the same yummy fatty ingredients. YP not only does that, they made their Cookies N Creme taste even better! The white chocolate & raspberry flavor was also very good, and they of course have all the mandatory toppings that come with any good yogurt shop.

If you want to taste REALLY good frozen yogurt, without all the snazzy decorating and down-the-nose cashiers be sure to check out Yogurt Pump.

Pizza is okay. It's very greasy and sometimes takes a long time to get order. The cheese falls apart right away and grease drips down into a puddle. So pat your pizza down first with a napkin. Lol 

The customer service is laughable. I've never received service worth mentioning. 

The house salads are a good deal. And I actually prefer that over the pizza now. 

The grinders or subs are actually the best items I've had here. Like butter.
Never eaten here...just met friends here for coffee.  A great place to meet when the weather isn't so nice!  Coffee was always good and pretty reasonable.  Nice and close to campus!

No longer Big O, the place is now called "tire pros". Funny, because there is hardly anything professional about them. I blew a tire up at Mt Baldy and limped it down the hill to the shop. After explaining that I was over 100 miles away from home and just needed to get a single tire replaced the man at the desk rudely told me that unless I could leave my car with him for at least a day he couldn't help me. At this time all the bays in the shop were empty, save for a single truck. Mounting and balancing a tire is not a complicated or lengthy process so I was quite appalled at their attitude toward not only a customer but someone having a bad day looking for help.

Luckily I found Carzar Automotive (used to be a discount tire co.) right around the corner and they not only were super helpful and understanding of my situation, but they even sent one of their staff to pick up a tire from a different location since they didn't have anything in stock. The experience is night and day. 

Think twice about taking your car to Tire Pros. They seem to be the type of shop that makes people dread mechanics.

Very good ambiance and service, this place is quite popular during happy hour on a Thursday night , but the mixed drinks are on the weak side,  both flavors and alcohol are lacking, beers would be the better choices.

SLO is a cute college town. and i think all of the college kids somehow end up at firestone - is it just me or does everyone look like they belong in an abercrombie catalogue? anyhoo, during dinner time, the plasmas are usually blaring with some sports game so that the locals can "hurrah" when their team scores. expect a long line when ordering, but with good reason, everyone's in line for their stellar sanwiches or sides - my fave so far: tri-tip & fries.

I have little experience with Greek food, so I can't really compare Kismet to any other Greek eatery.  However, it's hard to beat the $5.55 deal for a pita wrap, fries or chips, and a drink, especially when I work within walking distance.  I had a regular ol' gyro with chips and a drink and it was a good portion that filled me up for the rest of the day.  Now that I've found you, Kismet, I'm hoping we can hang out more often.

I was in the mood for fried food today and I got the new chicken nuggets and the chicken fries.  I went for lunch at 11:30am on a Friday and there was one person in front of me.  Got my food pretty quick.  The nugget was very good.  As advertised they were crispy and tender with just the right amount of seasoning.  The chicken fries on the other hand were a little more spicy than I would prefer.  The nuggets were are good deal at 4 for $1 but the chicken fries at 6 for $2.69 not so much.

I come here at least twice a week. The hamburgers are really good, especially with the pita bread, and the $6 meal deal with the gyro taco like thing is a great deal. The only downside is that sometimes the fries can be inconsistent. One day they might be perfectly cooked and seasoned, the next day they will be soggy and undercooked... But overall this place is a great escape from the crappy dining halls at USC.

I've dined here multiple times, and have yet to have a bad experience! I try something new every time I come and have honestly loved it all. The flavors are great and the pricing is beyond reasonable. The staff is friendly and the restaurant is newly renovated. The portion sizes are huge-- big enough for me to split it into two or even three meals. The servers are friendly enough, but the food is what will keep you coming back! If you want a fun night out, eat there for dinner on a Thursday night & stay for the karaoke! Always good times.
The Sunday Westwood Farmer's market SUCKS. It extends for the length of a single block and there can't be more than 15 stalls set up at any given time.

This is the first frozen yogurt place I ever went to back in the days.  This place opened sometime in 2007-2008 I believe after I graduated from Berkeley.  I thought the name was quite cute.

I never knew the hype of frozen yogurt really until all those famous places like Pinkberry and Yogurtland opened up a year later in NorCal.

From what I remember, the plain tart was pretty good and I always topped it off with strawberries and mangos.  The place is bright and clean.  Lately though, the place seems pretty dead.  I know there's a change in management and all those other bigger chain froyo places that have opened up in the Berkeley campus area.  

If you are lazy, and live right across the street in those university apartments, this is your place to go to!

I agree with Ken N. The Geffen does sell out more than seems necessary. I enjoyed the first Mamet play I happened to catch here. And the next. And then I looked to see what was on the slate that coming season, and lo and behold -- more Mamet! What's up with that? I. Am. Certain. That LA theatergoers are not solely interested in Mamet's work. 

The most recent play (Wishful Drinking -- Carrie Fisher's one woman show) was an embarrassment. I've liked her writing, but this was sort of a "greatest hits" collection of her well-circulated jokes and anecdotes. She put seemingly no effort into her performance. Despite having written the piece (and that it is based on the actual details of her life), she repeatedly went up on her lines (!!) -- mind you, this was halfway through the run! Even worse, towards the end of the show, we noticed that, off in the back of the house, hung nothing other than a ginormous teleprompter with her lines scroll scrolling away. Wow. The Geffen should be ashamed for pandering like this -- accepting Carrie's script, giving her a mainstage slot in its season, allowing something so poorly rehearsed to go up! Please, Geffen, give your audience some credit!

Spent my birthday here because the menu is huge and sure to please a group. I did enjoy the dolled up staff and the kooky decor. However, despite what the website says, it's more than just 5 minutes from the T and the menu has a $20 minimum per person at the tables, so plan on indulging. My disappointing drink was my own fault. [Word to the wise, don't try bourbon for the first time in a 10 dollar cocktail just because the name is Sugar Daddy from Miami]. Still, I appreciate their creativity and hope to come back for a simple fruity martini.

Went there twice and not going back unless I'm desperate. Sure, the price can't be beat. But they didn't give me what I asked for either time. My hair is on the short side, and the stylists actually seemed a bit intimidated by this. They needed major help from the instructors, and even then couldn't get it quite right. May be okay for "just a trim," but if you have an actual "style" that you're looking for, I wouldn't count on getting it here. (Also, one of the girls stabbed me with her scissors a few times.)

I seriously love this place. We've been twice and the food and space are completely fantastic. I am withholding the 5th star merely because I wish they had a bit of a wine program. The food deserves it. I understand that they buy wine in large barrels or something, which has environmental benefits, but I'd love to see them have a short, well curated bottle list as well, and actual stemware as opposed to flat bottom glasses. But anyway, I am going on too long about this one small problem. I love the way the menu is set up with smalls, mediums and larges. The bluefish salad we had there last night is to die for. Oh, and the olive oil chocolate cake is ungodly. Very very well composed with caramel and some sort of toffee crunchiness. Service is friendly and competent. I hope they are around for a long long time, as I plan to be back often.

Seriously I would give ZERO stars if that was an option.  I have never felt the need to write a yelp review, but this place is incredibly bad so I feel compelled to warn others. 

I dealt with two different asian women on two different occasions and they were extremely rude. The first time, I brought a thin paperback book that I needed to ship back to the sender, it was only worth $5. She put it in an envelope and sealed it AND THEN said it would be $13 to ship on ground service?! I was like WTF? $13 for ground service? I said nevermind then cause that is a total rip-off and she then proceeded to charge me $5 for the envelope she sealed the book in. This place is all about scamming people out of their money.

The second time was today, and I had a box all ready to go with a UPS shipping label and just needed one strip of tape to seal it. The lady said the charge for ONE STRIP OF TAPE across the box would be $2.00?! The guy next to me actually laughed, you can buy an entire roll for $2.00. I said to her, "That is rip off, I will go somewhere else." I think as I walked out she snickered too. 

These people should not be allowed to exploit students by overcharging for basic services. I will NEVER go here again and I suggest you don't either. There is absolutely no customer service and they charge nearly double the price of the post office. GO ELSEWHERE!! Seriously...

I opened an account with USC credit union and closed it three weeks later. I had nothing but problems trying to get my account open and working. The only thing I found worse than their customer service was their outdated website. I cringe at the thought that I was actually going to transfer my savings into this institution. I would advise anyone considering an account here to think twice.

You're better off getting cupcakes in NYC or DC or Palo Alto but this will do in a pinch.  But...the butter rum muffins are to die for.  Sooo rich and buttery.  And very generously sized, too.  All for under $2.50.  It's inexpensive happiness in a brown bag.

This place almost killed me with food poisoning.  I recently had their chicken and sushi combo platter (The # 1 to be exact.)  After a few hours of feeling okay, I began to get nauseous.  Then, I started having diarrhea and vomiting.  This lasted till 5 in the morning.  

The next day, I was blessed with severe dehydration, broken blood vessels underneath my eyelids (due to vomiting so hard), nausea, aches and pains, swelling in my stomach, loss of appetite, and a 102 degree fever.  Today (day 3), the fever is dissipating and I still have nausea and aches and pains.  I used to like this place, but now...it can go to hell.  

THANKS FOR RUINING MY LIFE M2M, THANKS A LOT.  I HOPE EVERYONE AT YOUR PLACE DIES OF FOOD POISONING LIKE 3 TIMES IN A ROW.

BONUS FUN GAME: Try eating here and not vomiting!

Abner's is everything a cheesesteak should be. Soft bread, tasty meat, perfectly cooked onions and gooey cheese. I have heard friends rave about other places but when I take them to Abner's, they all agree that they are good. I have been going to Abner's for over 10 years and have never been disappointed. The cheesesteaks are consistently good. I look forward to my next trip to Philly and introducing my son to Abner's.

So so so so good.  I had high expectations after a friend recommended Magic Carpet, but the Bella Donna was even better than I imagined it would be.  I had lunch here three days ago and I'm still thinking about it now.

I love Greek food, but I haven't found too many places that do it quite right. While in town for the weekend, Andreas himself saw us checking out the menu outside the restaurant door.  He introduced himself, ensured us we'd have an excellent meal, and promised us a glass of wine on the house should we chose to go inside and have dinner.  Well, as promised, we got the complimentary glass of wine as well as an excellent meal.  They're weren't a ton of veg options, so they went ahead and made me a small mezze plate for my entree.  Excellent.  My boyfriend had the Moussaka and I'm still curious how he managed to finish the whole thing.  He said it was rich, but very well prepared.  If I return to Providence, I'll probably go back as I enjoy fresh, thoughtfully prepared food as well as stellar service.  Thanks, Andreas.

I have a real love-hate relationship with this place.

Love:
First of all, it's fast. So fast that sometimes I think they microwave it.
It's tasty. So tasty that I've had dreams about their orange chicken. (OK it's not actually dream inducing good, but it really is not bad at all).
They have beef noodle soup, and you can ask them to make it even hotter/spicier.
And importantly it is cheap!

Hate:
The service is TERRIBLE. They will ignore you while you wait. Seriously. I hate dealing with the people who work there.
The boba is ridiculously sugary. I guess most probably are, but they just take giant scoops of sugar and put them in your tea right in front of you while you imagine the chemical processes that turn the sugar into fat :(

Overall I do come here at least once every couple of weeks, but I've made a conscious decision to NOT be a regular. Hopefully you guys have better experiences!

Free events: Checked 
Spacious: Checked 
Green: Checked! 

The Miller outdoor theatre is Great! I have to say I was surprised to find Houston has such a great outdoor theatre! The first time I went to Miller outdoor theatre it was to watch/listen to the Spanish Harlem Orchestra. It was Great! The sound is very good for an outdoor venue. I really love that you get to take a blanket and just sit on the grass while enjoying the show. I also went for a Cinco De Mayo festival and that too was great. They have some covered seating in case it rains, so don't be discouraged by a little rain. 

I've always wanted to go watch one of the movies they play there in the evenings . I promise I will do it as soon as I find out they are playing one. They also show plays there. Miller Outdoor Theatre is wonderful, and I am grateful for having it in Houston! =)

I give this place a higher rating not because it is a great gym (it is not), but because of the company there.  As a student, it is good to find a place where you can go work out with friends and other fellow students.  Being surrounded by young people makes you feel youthful and energetic; perfect for a workout environment.  Sometimes you will have to wait for equipment for quite a bit, but once you're a regular or know enough people in there, it isn't too much trouble working in with other people.

This is the second summer that I have taken a ceramics class at the UCSD Crafts Center.  The classes are mostly very good and they are very generous in their studio hours - basically 24/7 unless there is a class in progress.  The glaze selection is tops - I guess one of the instructors is a glaze guru!  The downsides, it seems that the management lets a handful of studio members run the show.  What that means - your stuff will sit on the bisque shelf for weeks because others are loading their work first.  Same thing with the glaze kiln - apparently non members can pay for a full or partial kiln load so again, more waiting.  You will spend hours trying to find your stuff - and maybe you never will.  You will be lucky to get one set of pieces through the entire process for the duration of your class. Also, there are a few people that are just downright unpleasant and critical to be around - scrutinizing how you are using the facility and the level to which said use meets with their approval.  The vibe was so unpleasant that I quit my class 2 weeks early. I probably will give it another shot next summer and hope that management deals with this - it is an Art Studio - it should be a pleasant place.

So it's 12:15 AM and I just got back to my apartment after studying at Biomed. 

I don't really like studying in libraries for the most part--I'd take a coffee shop or a nice place outdoors anytime over an overly quiet library...but Biomed is one of the best libraries to study in. Biomed is nice and quiet--but not obnoxiously quiet to the point where I feel bad turning the page in my book or unzipping my backpack.

Biomed is one of the best libraries to study on the UCSD campus, hands down. Unlike the dimly lit Geisel Library, Biomed has a ton natural light and lots of computers and desk space. I think most of my love for biomed is related to my HATRED for Geisel--I mean it looks relatively nice from the outside, but the inside it basically a shit hole. Granted it has most of the books you'll be needing if you need books for your studying and stuff, it sucks, a lot. 

Biomed also has great study space, there are circular type tables with a bunch of private computer terminal areas which are great if you need to work with a person or two. You can also study at regular computer desk, or desks without computer if you plan to bring your laptop. Biomed is open late on weeknights--try it you won't be disappointed.

I came here last night with a friend for dinner. Between the two of us we shared three rolls: Dragon, Baby Lobster, and Shrimp Tempura. The baby lobster was my favorite. I've had better dragon and shrimp tempura rolls though. The latter was a bit small compared to the size of shrimp tempura rolls at other sushi restaurants so that was a bit of a let down. Still, you can't complain much given the price (50% off during dinner!). I'll probably drop by again when I'm around the area.

Sansai's average. 

Everything is moderately priced and they even give you free refills. 

What they excel at is their customer service. Sansai is a Japanese sushi hybrid joint. They have teriyaki, and sushi. 

It can get expensive if you don't watch yourself. 

The decor is cool, and the place is clean. Try not to go during their peak hours or you'll be in a world of hurt. 

Average is as average does.

Absolutely amazing. The icecream/sorbet creation is incredible. Very true to whatever flavor the fruit tastes like. I got a 4-spoon cup and want to go back for more after that. I wish we have one in Nashville.

Two things I still don't get: flip flops and intentionally bad service.

First thing: I'm not going to walk around an urban area in shower shoes. Maybe in warmer climates they're "thongs" or "sandals," but in harsher climes they're more like something you wear when the bathroom is sketchy or you need to protect your feet between the hotel room and the hot tub. Podiatrists must have developed dollar-sign shaped pupils the moment this trend started. Every broken bottle or cracked sidewalk must be pure profit.

Second thing: how much hassle will people put up with to save a few bucks? Waste is one thing, but after having to stand in line for 90 minutes before a Southwest flight to save my boss $15 I realized it made more sense to pay the $15 out of pocket plus $12 for two beers at the airport bar and some free time to relax. Also, how much is the time, stress, and gas worth to hit the exurban mega store? A fair accounting probably suggests you buy from your neighbors even before you consider the contribution of local business to property values.

Which is why I go to Bill's first when I need shoes.

They stock a huge selection of sensible, stylish, sturdy, supportive and/or specialized shoes. Perhaps not everything in a Mega Mart sense, but more than you'll find in the bins at Shoe Pavilion. Everything from hipster to hiker to traditional dress styles. Many items are on sale frequently, so you're not paying full MSRP. But the selection reeks of quality, value, and healthy walking.

But what really counts is the service. When you walk in, you don't fear the "can I help you with anything?" It actually means something. Mellow, friendly guys help you try on shoes, recommending sizes and styles, passing on good information about each make and model, and never engaging in a hard sell. This is Nordstrom attention with Aldo prices and a pot dispensary attitude.
Great pizza - tons of cheese, and the veggie slices are loaded down with vegetables.

Ran into Coup de Taco on the street corner near Irish Pub in Center City on Friday night. They were partnered up with MyPHL marketing for Entourage.. Free Entourage themed tacos! I had the Ari-Os Taco which I think was pretty much the Sweet Thai Coconut Taco with Chicken and some Green Tea with Ginger. Overall the taco was amazing and the green tea was also delicious... exactly what I needed at 12:30 on a Friday night. Would definitely try other things on the menu and hunt them down for another delicious taco! I also suggested to the guy working there that they should have been on the Great Food Truck race on Food Network!

The BEST Thai Restaurant on the Ave!

Pros
- food is delicious!
- cheappppppp, I didn't cry because my wallet was significantly lighter 
- service is quick
- food is tasty
- YUMMY in MY TUMMY

Cons
- usually a 20 min wait
- small space, not for the claustrophobic
- like most restaurants on the ave... CASH ONLY, no checks, no cards, no hos, no gold.

My suggested meal:
- Appetizer: Fried Tofu Dish... you will love the peanut sauce and want to drink it from the dish
- Entree: Swimming Rama with Shrimp.... OMG my stomach is growling from thinking about how delicious it was.

One word: GOOOOOOOOO!

Came here for a brunch and enjoyed it thoroughly.

 The falafels are made after you order and are fresh and yummy. The falafel plate comes with fries, hummus, a dip and pita. Quite a stuffing and ideal for a heavy brunch.

Also had the eggplant wrap which was mildly spiced and flavorful.

This place is a stone's throw from campus, good value for money with quick service!

Get your Mediterranean fix here!

This is one of my favorite places in the entire world!  Hoagie Haven creates what I would argue are the best sandwiches in the world.  The combination of a Sanchez and an Arizona Ice Tea Arnold Palmer is a match made in haven.  My craving for Hoagie Haven will never be satiated.  This is hands down the best place to eat in Princeton.  The price is great, and make sure you take note of the grease underneath the benches outside.

Recommend to try... great for lunch. 

Very interesting flavors, everyone should give this place a shot at least once. Very reasonable prices! 

I'm not sure I'd visit back too often, but the atmosphere and food is definitely something everyone should try in the area.

3.5 stars.

Go for the ambience, go for fun, and drinks.  

I thought their salads and flatbreads were the best part of the meal. 

If you've never had real Mexican food, you will be blown away.  If you have, the tacos are pretty, but you can get better ones for pennies in South Philly.  

Guacamole is mediocre.  Mine is better than yours, Garces!
Great value.  Filling, tasty and always a nice place to sit down for not a lot of money.

The other day I decided to try Comet Coffee for the first time, and I boldly chose the most expensive coffee available that day, the Ethiopian. I also chose to have it made in a French press, bringing the total for my cup (I think it was 12 oz) to about $7. That's some pricey coffee. It said on the menu that this particular coffee had been flown in rather than driven, as most of their coffees are, to preserve its freshness (I mean, obviously you can't drive here from Ethiopia, but you know, part of the trip that they would normally drive). I assume this added to the price of my coffee. I appreciate freshness, but that's a super-unenvironmentally friendly way of doing business.
