I realize that I'm the one who chose to buy the Ethiopean coffee rather than, say, the closer Costa Rican, but what can I say, African coffees are my favorite. Well anyway...being made in a French press, these things take time, so we were in there for about 10 minutes altogether, with no waiting in line. I like that you can choose from three methods of brewing, and that each cup is hand-brewed. I like that they seem to know what they're doing. I like that they hand-stamp their eco-friendly cups. I don't like that they have no tables and don't accept credit cards, but those things will be fixed soon, they're brand-new right now. As far as would I go here frequently? Probably not. That's just wayyy too expensive. And the coffee was good, but not better than other places I've been that have good coffee for like $4 (I really mean "good coffee"-not talking about chains here). Plus I have my own French press if I'm really yearning for a cup made that way. I think this place will do great and is a great addition to the community, but I'm not sure if I'll go much. This was the longest review EVAR.

The veggie burger and salads are good but they need to work on the garlic fries. Cashiers are always meanies and that usually makes me stray away from this place. I'm smart enough to go somewhere else like Intermezzo or Fat Slice.

Good selection of burgers; which are above average. The drinks were very good, I think they have Raspberry Lime Rickey's, which always wins a place points in my book.  The names of all of the burgers are quite fun, and they are tasty. Sadly, the place is a bit of a tourist trap, is often overcrowded, and is a bit too pricey for what they serve.  I had to stop going there for lunch when I worked in Harvard, because the smell of the burgers would cling to your clothes all day.

Located in Mercado del Paloma just south of downtown LA, this little restaurant in more or less a food court was hopping, even while all else was either closed or had no customers to speak of.  This was my first time having Peruvian food, so I am not sure what makes it "Contemporary" Peruvian as they advertise.  What I do know is the Seco de Cordero, the lamb shank was hands down the best lamb I have ever had!  Sooo tender it was falling off the bone, served over delicious cannellini beans.  My buddy had the fish of the day, the sea bass over a pea quinoa.  Drop dead!!  We whet our palette with what seemed to be the Peruvian Aguas Frescas.  They had three to choose from:  a purple corn, a barley and a passion fruit.  All three were perfectly refreshing without being overly sugary sweet.  I had the barley one.  Perfect!  And the prices?  That lamb was $13 and could have easliy gone for double in some swanky over-priced white table clothed joint.  Forget that!  I'll take Mo-Chica's stained brown table cloths any day!!

Friendly service...

Not too pushy, very helpful, not too long of a wait on a Saturday afternoon.
They looking for ways to get me a discount.
I got lucky bc i got 1 of 2 spots up front that are reserved for Verizon only.

One negative - prices are highest compared to any other wireless service.

I can really do without the snarky college kid working the ticket counter who's sure he's the smartest guy on the block. And the place is getting a little old and dowdy, but it's one of the few repertory theatres in town. I'm more likely to wait for an obscure movie to show up on Netflix than to come here but every now and then it's worth the trip. 

I went to see The Chicago 10(good movie, check it out). The sound system is one of the better ones in town actually and the seats are relatively comfortable. The air conditioning was blasting on this cold March day which is odd. 

I prefer my rep house to be in an old theatre like the Neptune or the Egyptian but this place does okay in a pinch.

I've been to this place many times and I always get the same two things:
1) Curried Chutney Chicken Salad
2) Tomato Soup w/ gorgonzola cheese

Both are phenomenal. 

Last time we were here, my S.O. got the Tomato soup with grilled cheese which was good, but they forgot to give him the potato salad. The guy comes over with a little plate and a bill for $1.95. Wow. The potato salad was certainly sub par that day because even my S.O. wouldn't eat it and he is not one to leave food on the table.

If you don't like Kingpin, you clearly haven't waited, drunk, for a hot, fresh cinnamon roll at midnight.  The donut dude is an assassin with his sugar-laden donut treats and glazing ladler.  It is my personal mission to get this dude to custom-make me a cinnamon roll dipped in the chocolate frosting.  One day I shall convince him, I tell you.

I wouldn't really bother with the non-hot out the fryer donuts; they're good, but go at night for a mindblowing donut experience.
Holy crap it's so different after the re-open. Much better sports bar...but lost some of that great dive bar quality of the Tradi's of old.
Pretty cool place, but their bar food needs some improvement, it kinda blows.

Woulda been four stars if not for the fact that everyone knows about it and it's so damn crowded.  Woulda been five if they didn't periodically take away some of their most wonderful dishes.  I know, chef, that variety is the spice of life..but pretty please can we have the bouillabaisse back? how about that yummy coconut shrimpy soup with the radishes? what about the savory cupcakes? huh? can we, please? 

big ups to all the chill and wonderful peoples working the bar.  don't be a afraid to eat at the bar, you'll be in great company!

This is one of my favorite bars in University City. Yes, the crowd leans to the University crowd, but I have always had a good time here - whether during the Erin Express, or for a birthday party, or for most recently, Arrested Development Quizzo. 

They have great specials all the time and the food is cheap. The tacos are quite good and the Buffalo Fries! Plus, even when it's crowded, all the bathrooms are uni-sex AND there are about 10 of them. Reduces lines quite nicely.

I have never dealt with such a poorly managed apartment complex before. The rooms are nice -- small and overpriced-- but the real tragedy of the Quarters on Campus lies in the high school dropouts they hire as "managers." They cannot spell, add, or communicate on a level higher than that of a sixth grader. If you have a problem with something in your apartment, don't feel like you can rely on management to fix it. If you are locked out after hours, don't plan on spending the night in your own room. If you can, live ANYWHERE but the Quarters. You will regret it within the first day.

Much better than the Memorial location, as it's bigger, less crowded, and not really so much of a 'scene'. Plenty of good beers on draft and in bottle, plenty of choice liquor, and good food that's both unique and delicious. Pricey though, don't go for an appetizer unless you're really hungry, or just get an appetizer and skip the entree. Lots of sports playing all around in you're into sitting and watching the game, fairly good parking area with street parking too. I think they valet at night, so be prepared for it if you don't like to walk a block.

If you're a hot dog fan, you need to try this place.  They don't use hot dog buns, but rather french bread and their dogs are all beef and super tasty.  They have different types of dogs too, i recommend the buffalo dog.  

So friggin good.

If there was a way to rate this restaurant 0 stars, I would. My partner and I Yelped this restaurant because we were going to watch a movie nearby and wanted to stop in and get a quick bite. We arrived at the restaurant at 6:15pm and walked in to order. As we ordered the cashier told us that the order had to be to-go because they close up their seating area inside and outside 40 minutes before they close everyday. Really? 40 minutes? 

I explained to him that we would be done in 10-15 minutes and that we couldn't really take it to go. He didn't care. We walked out, went down the street and ate at another restaurant. As we walked back since our car was parked in front of the Mediterranean Cafe, we saw that others were still eating outside on the patio and this was around 6:50pm. This got me thinking, was it because my partner and I are an interracial couple? Was it due to the fact that this restaurant makes so much money that they didn't give a damn about customer service? Well regardless of what the reason is, they have permanently lost my business and anyone I ever talk to about this place. That's too bad because my partner and I are huge fans of Mediterranean food and this is actually pretty close to where we live.

I should have heeded to the advice of other trusty yelpers on this one. Blue Room is just "ok". Sure, it was easy enough to get a reservation on a Saturday night by calling two hours ahead of time. And yes, restaurant was clean and tidy and our waiter was completely awesome. He even allowed me to sample a few wines before I made my decision. 

The food was good, but not amazing and (call me crazy) but I really want something amazing when I'm paying up to $27-$35 for a dish. I ordered a whole fish which required some work navigating around the bones but overall it was good and definitely healthy. The grilled calamari was a huge disappointment though. They were too greasy and contained a ton of olives. I love olives, but not with calamari. 

Mixed drinks were okay and wine was fine but again, they didn't "wow" me. Not tempted to go back.

I've been coming to the Falafel King for years.  My Dad brought me here for lunch a couple times when we would visit UCLA before I started attending for basketball games and the book fair.

I've had the falafel (which are pretty good), the chicken (good), lamb (good but tough), and beef schwama (pretty good) over the years and they have remained pretty consistent.  They have lots of different sides you can add to your pita sandwich or plate such as avocado, tabbouleh, baba ganoush, salad, tomato and a white-ish grain rice, and lots of others that I can't define.  They also have different types of salsas on the side (I don't know that it's traditional Mediterranean to have salsa, but they add a lot of spice) and white tahini sauce with lots of flavor.

The prices are a bit high for a pita sandwich (they throw in some really unique potato chip things for extra filler), but for a full schwarma plate the price is pretty reasonable.  The quality, to me, has always been consistent and good.  I'm sure it's not the best quality in the world, but it's never been bad for me (that I can recall in my many trips), and they always pack in food that just tastes good.

There are also baklava dessert options that I'd recommend checking out.

Summary: Pretty cheap, very flavorful, lots of options, good quality.  Check it out.

The food here was ok.  The cheese curds were awesome.  The batter on them are light and the cheese itself is a big hunk.  I ordered the black and blue salad which was ok.  I was expecting a variety of greens but it was just lettuce.  The sweet potato fries were excellent. 

Service was good, fast and friendly.  I'd go back for the fries and cheese curds.

Hell for the lactose intolerant.

Hellish for the companions of the inconsiderate lactose intolerant.

mmm....

Wow, quick heads up on the homemade chips (all you can eat), if you get the bottom of the barrel (or wherever they store them), they will be -salty-.  

The service is swift, good for large groups of students wandering in, and the drinks are large and usually decent. Food is in good supply, and at decent prices, and the dessert of choice is the molten chocolate cake.

Mango iced tea here is a mix of sugar, tea, and flavoring, but at least the waitstaff is generally good about getting plenty of refills and is pretty helpful when it comes to boxing up leftovers.

Overall, food is not bad. If you get the queso, get the meat one, it makes it that much better with the chips.  Birthdays are celebrated with gusto here, too, nicely.

Only gripes are the wait time (not unusual near a university), and the inability to split checks for one-table parties (they tend to do more than one table okay, though, oddly enough, might just be the waitstaff on each day).

"This little shop restores my faith that man is not inherently evil. This is the bike shop inside the University Villiage by USC. It has free air to fill your tires outside, which is very convienent. My bike has been broken for months and I couldn't find a place in Hollywood to take care of it - I mean the bike only cost me $60 in the first place, so spending $30 on fixing it, well, I'm just not down with that. I decided to trek it down to the bike store by my old campus to see what they could do. Not only did they fix it, replaced some of the bolts, and give it a little wash down - they didn't charge me! They were really quiet that day and the guy said it wasn't a big deal. They were courteous, efficient, and just good guys in general. 

They have a variety of reasonably priced bikes and the services they offer follow suit. Fabulous bike shop!"

Welcome to River Oaks in the Rice Village. If you're going here you should be craving one thing only: it really seems that their menu is a combination of avocado, sun dried tomatoes, black beans, mushrooms, red peppers, and that's about it. The hamburgers are good, and the wraps are fine; it's just that for a white table cloth restaurant I'd expect something else.

Don't even bother trying to park in this lot; go another block and park somewhere else.

I've generally had decent service here; although on a 6 person ticket we did have someone not get the fries they substituted.

I do like the wedge salad too! Veggie friendly which is always a plus! Would be more enthusiastic about this place if the stuffy factor went down, the prices went down, or there was more variety on the menu...

I'm from the Bay Area (SF) and have complained that there are no good spots to gear up out here in Boston for some time. This place is different though. Not necessarily a great clothing store, but for kickz? Concepts comes correct.

They got some dope gear here, and it ain't all just Dunks and Air Force 1's. You can get some fly kicks for a little somethin more, like those nights on the town when your tryin to look all GQ.

Definitely recommend this joint, great selection, fair price, and coo duuds that can help you pick out your own style. Anyone visiting hit this spot up and you'll come out lookin fresh & clean.

I really enjoyed my experience at Just A Taste! They have a wide variety of dishes that change regularly (or "on the reg" if you will).  The focaccia was a great choice and came with a whole clove of garlic and a bowl to make a dipping sauce using the olive oil on the table. The New Potatoes were well flavored and one of my favorite dishes we ordered.  My favorite dish however was the spinach salad with feta cheese, black cherries and lemon dressing was out of this world! I was skeptical of ordering a salad initially, but wow (!!) it was so good.  We ordered two of the chicken dishes.  One was a sliced chicken breast with potatoes, onions and madiera which I preferred and the other was a chicken and rice dish with a tomato based sauce which my friend preferred.

Just A Taste was certainly one of (if not the) best tapas restaurant I have been to and I'd certainly recommend it to anyone in the Ithaca area.  I only took away one star because of the price.  This is a problem with all Tapas places because the system is set up to give you small amounts of food for relatively high prices.  Just A Taste is no different in this way, but definitely worth it!

L'Elizabeth is a very strange place.  Small, dark, and filled with cool old pieces of furniture, I found the atmosphere kind of interesting.  One of my other friends described it as "spooky."  It seems like the type of place you might meet for an illicit affair.

They have an extensive drink menu...including lots of fun coffee drinks that I haven't found anywhere else in Providence...but what the menu doesn't tell you is that these drinks cost $12 and up!  The desserts are similarly expensive and NOT at all worth the cost.  

To be honest, I'm not sure how this place stays in business.

I love small used book stores.  And Magus is really great.  They have a really good selection and the staff has always been super helpful.  The only complaint I have is that a lot of times there are books stacked on the floor and I feel like I'm going to knock over things half the time!  But, I always find a few treasures each time I go in, so that's a small price to pay for good books.

Impressive selection of microbrew beers. I have never seen anything like this in Canada (Ontario LCBO stores).
My aim was to find a wide variety of beers and I found it at FLBC.

Our waiter was spotty.  We were way in the back toward the exit so I guess it was easy to forget about us, but we did want to sit in a booth, so that's how we ended up there.  All around, I think everyone was satisfied with their food.  I had the scallops and grits, pretty tasty stuff.  Would've liked bit more of that crunchy fried stuff I was finding scattered around the sides.  It was a bit vinegary (I think it was balsamic) and cheesy and wasn't under or over salted.  I wouldn't have called it hearty, nor stand-out, but it was homey.

I think I've only actually set foot in this place one time, and as I recall, it's pretty cozy.

Whenever I come back home and stay with my family, we always order delivery from here and it's consistently good. The pasta is pretty well made and the sauces are simple, but delicious and hearty.

Get here early (9am), otherwise you'll be in line with a bunch of Brown kids looking for a weekend treat for brunch.

Food quality is well above-average here.  The menu sports a billion omelets, several breakfast burritos, and a few plates of normal breakfast fare.  I'm always happy with my orders, but I've never had a dish that really rocked my world.

Service is usually a bit slow.  Prices are reasonable.
This Ollie's has improved over the years.  I love the roast pork, the pork dumplings, and scallion pancakes.  It's a good place for take out, but is often packed during lunch and dinner.

I've only been to Eno twice, and both times I was in the bar area, so I can't speak to the full dining experience, but I've enjoyed the time I have spent there. 

The first time I just had a drink and tried a few bites of some small plates, including a gnocchi with abalone that was very good and unique, and last night I attended their Wednesday wine tasting from 6-8PM. For $10 I tried 8 wines, and near the end of the event I was able to taste a couple of them again. 

They also served a variety of free appetizers including lightly fried olives, polenta/cheese rounds, spare ribs, pine nut tapenade, and muscles. 

Parking can be a hassle, so I think the $3 valet (+ tip) is worth it to not have to deal. 

The chef Eli is very passionate and creative and I think will help elevate this restaurant.

The readings are rather mediocre. I have had four readings here just to be fair by 4 different psychics. I am an advanced teacher and was looking for startling information. Something I could really chew on. Although some of the readings are very general (ambika) others are informative if you are a novice & have never been exposed to these concepts. I am beyond novice level and apparently they were not strong enough to see that. I don't tend to trust anyone speaking of angels..they tend to give distorted readings. I was disappointed everytime I have had a reading. I never learned anything new. I need more powerful psychics. This isn't cutting it. Also if psychics are told too much in advance, their ego mind takes over & fills in cracks which makes the reading so much worse. One is only receiving regurgitation, pieced together answers from what you've told them. DONT influence them by giving them ANY information. Better to have a COLD reading by readers. Interpretation is everything & psychics are receivers like radios, they can't neccesarily decipher or totally understand what they're receiving.. they simply TELL YOU what they see. Its up to a gifted psychic artist to blend intelligence, a detached disinterest in being correct and a higher intelligence to understand the images they are seeing and information they are hearing and feeling and impart this upon the person receiving the reading. 

If I want biased info, I'll ask my mother or coworkers. They can't read anybody but depend on external clues and trigger words to hypothesize and create their belief systems. Many weak psychics do this and its of no use for me.

sometimes I feel like buying things a well traveled, learned, stylized, 8 year old would lust over. When you feel this way: go to black ink. 

Where else can my sister get a frog mug that reminds us of the mug with the ceramic frog glued to the bottom of it (a mug we would fight over at my grandma's house)? Where else can she also get a card that reads: 'hello friend' and nothing else? Where else can I obtain a huge deck of cards that I will never ever lose? There is also lots of other cool stuff to make you think for a blink of a minute- that a US shop can hold a candle to Japan.

LOVE this place! Its right across from the dental school at USC and is perfect when I am craving something a little healthier for lunch! All the salads and veggies are super fresh and they have a good variety. Their yogurt dressing is the BEST!!! 

The owners are super nice and always accomodate my request for two sides of dressing and they dont even charge me extra!

Amazing tri-tip sandwich, hands down. I'm not a fan of tri-tip but this is the only place I'll ever eat it at.

Tri-tip sandwich + bbq sauce on the roll is just perfect. The sandwich looks smaller in pictures than it does in person because they pile layers of tri tip on there. As I'm a small girl, I'm half of the sandwich and a side of fries is good enough for me.

Pig Sandwich: It comes with so much meat that I usually have to eat 
around it with a fork before I'm even able to pick up the sandwich.

ABC burger: avocado bacon and cheese. As with most places, it comes with the works but tastes great. Waiting for it is often discouraging but worth it.

Every time a friend comes to visit me in SLO, this is the first place I take them to. This place is almost always packed Thursdays-Sundays because of Farmer's Market and whatnot but the service is always surprisingly quick. If you're in hurry and want to order something quick, I would recommend the tri-tip sandwich since they're always making them as oppose to the other items on the menu.

The place has a sports bar set up with the tall tables with high chairs as well as out-door seating. During the cold seasons, it's difficult to enjoy your food while you're trying to beat the wind and cold weather. Overall, great atmosphere. 

Recommendations: Tri-tip sandwich, cob salad with tri-tip, pig sandwich, ABC burger

Come here for brunch!

Yes, their ice cream is seriously good, and yes, I enjoy coming here for a morning coffee or tea on my way to MIT's campus.  But I didn't truly love Tosci's until I started coming here for brunch.  

I used to live in the apartment building around the corner, and have been going here for brunch semi-regularly since they started offering it back in 2007.  Their menu is constantly in flux so it is hard to provide specific recommendations, but the grilled blueberry muffin and creamy egg sandwich are perennial favorites.  Their original fried-egg sandwich (fried egg, sriracha, a creamy/cheesy dressing and bibb lettuce) was one of my favorites ever, but alas, it is no longer on the menu.  Rumor has it that Mimi Rancatore is the brains behind the sandwich combinations, and no matter what's on the menu (bacon/tomato chutney/scallions) (bacon/apple/parmesan) they are always tasty.  

The service here is wonderful - the servers are friendly, happy and clearly love working there and with each other.  

I sometimes will round out my brunch with some breakfast dessert -  a small ice cream.  I love that they'll let you combine two flavors in a small (unlike Christina's!) and usually I go for the grapenut alongside anything I think it'll pair well with (which is everything, let's be honest).  I also really love the earl grey ice cream, but that's probably because I'm a fan of earl grey tea with a healthy dose of cream and sugar :)  Tosci's, I'll seriously miss you now that I've moved to Minnesota and I'm looking forward to visiting upon my returns to Boston/Cambridge!

The interior is woody, rustic, homey and exactly what I look for in a neighborhood bar. I would think I was in some Midwest blue-collar bar if I didn't know any better. I loved the eclectic decorations and the random table sizes and chairs.

The menu is very limited. You can get pizza, sandwiches, chili and baked potatoes. That's about it. And it's also expensive. A 8-inch personal pan pizza will run you about $9.00. If it were about two bucks cheaper, it'd be perfect. Because even though the pizza and chili is very good, it is still overpriced. Minus points for no dessert but pre-wrapped cookies.

Astoundingly good beer for such a small operation. There were 10 to choose from, and each was impressive. I could go on and on about seven of their beers which I found to be above average, but I'll focus on the coal porter, which was offered on cask. The smooth creamyness, slightly warm beer with a deep, complex taste profile knocked my socks off. If you like beer, this is the place to be. I can't believe a place with this good of homemade beer is on a college campus. 

But again, it's overpriced. A sampler of 4, 4-ounce beers ran $5, which is more than a pint. I'd rather smaller samplers of each beer for less per ounce than a pint, which is the way most places run it.

The bartender was on top of her game. Food orders are taken by the customer directly to the food window, which I'm fine with. The order comes out promptly. Not bad.

This seems to be the go-to bar here in Blacksburg. You can pretty much always expect it to be crowded. Their happy hour specials are ridiculous and their drinks are always pretty stiff. If you are looking for the epitome of college bar, this place is for you. Minus one shining star because the last time I went here, last call was at 1:15am and that was incredibly LAME.

So, I've heard a lot about Clover, since I'm a vegetarian and all, and word gets around.

Chickpea fritter sandwich: I love you so much. I loved the slaw that was in it that gave it a lot of crunch. The textures were great and it was huuuge. Extra U's to illustrate how big it was. I expected less for $5. 

Soy BLT: My roommate ordered this, and I tasted it. You were not as good... where is your T?    There was basically no tomato, there was a small shitty sliver of it. The sandwich was puny compared to my chickpea fritter and basically just looked sad next to it. The fakin' was great though, too bad the rest of the sandwich did not keep up.

Rosemary fries: omg tasty. I also really liked that malt vinegar was a condiment they had at the truck.  The rosemary sprigs in it tasted great, but kept getting caught in my teeth. My roommate really liked to eat the rosemary sprigs. So, to each their own.

Brown Sugar Lemonade: why the hell did this taste like iced tea?

Parsnip fritters: The woman at the counter gave us a free sample after we hung around looking indecisive for too long. These tasted like fried dough (the kind you get at fairs) and not at all like parsnips. This is not a complaint.

I wasn't sure which pizza to order for take-out, so the staff member I spoke with suggested a half-margherita, half-sausage.  The pizza was ready in less than 15 minutes, and I ate it after I got home, another 15 minutes later.  By then, the blobs of mozzarella on the margherita half were already congealed and kind of rubbery, and the middle of the pizza was kind of soggy.  This wasn't great, but the tomato sauce was extremely flavorful.  I thought the ratio of tomato sauce to cheese was too skewed in the sauce direction; it made it somewhat difficult to eat without sauce sliding everywhere.  The sausage and onion were really good - a little light on the sausage, but everything held together better than the margherita.  My pizza came to about $19, including tax.

I think Howie's pizza is best when eaten immediately, i.e. dining in, instead of take-out.  That said, if you're ordering take-out, I would recommend skipping the margherita in favor of the other pizzas, which have more substantial toppings.

I think everyone should figure out eventually that lunch and dinner at deluxe are overpriced, and not all that great. The salads are meh, but expensive. The burgers are hardly ever cooked right. The fries are almost always soggy. But it gets three stars because it is a perfect brunch place, good pancakes, french toast, and omelettes(though they're a bit on the greasy side). Bonus points for being able to run into friends there and catch up on thursday or saturday nights activities.

I really loved this place.  I love dim sum/yum cha.  They have a great selection of teas too (hence the name).
This is a smaller dim sum restaurant so you might have to wait for a table and the food takes longer to come.  There are no carts.  The upside to this is that the quality if much higher.

Recipe:
 
Toast 1 hot dog bun.
 
Add 1 Hot Link sausage or hot dog?  Call it what you will... it was juicy and spicy.
 
Squirt a straight line of Russian Mustard (good stuff) over the hot dog.
 
Pile on a mountain of delicious hot sauerkraut - my favorite.
 
Glare at the Ketchup, and say, "Ketchup is bad, ketchup is BAD."
 
 
Admire.
Sniff.
Devour.
 
Take what's left of Rob's and eat that, too.
 
Yummy to my tummy.
 
I can see now why this place is so well-known.  It's a good hot dog, for sure.  
Next time, I will try the other varieties.

Service was friendly.
Food is cheap.
What more do you want?


NOTE:  Cash only - there is an ATM at the end of the street.

Aimed squarely at the college crowd, which means good (not great) food and friendly ambiance at affordable prices.  There's nothing bad about the place but you can feel the invisible hand of cost control.  Best for coffee and desserts as others have said.  I'm still looking for the perfect breakfast place in the Waterloo / Kitchener area, which for me would consist of Eggs Benedict with real Hollandaise served with English Breakfast tea (fresh brewed, not from teabags).  Do I have to drive all the way to Toronto for this?

Great food, easy to find, but not enough seating so it's always crowded. Breakfast burritto is definitely my favorite though and their yummy sauce. My friend used to work there so we go there sometimes for lunch/brunch.
Their pepperoni rolls are great, and their ribs are surprisingly good.

Aww...why is everyone so mean to Thai Basil?

They make a great Pad Kee Mao here. All the spicy dishes here are great.

Good portions for a great price.

Yeh, so the food is semi-questionable here. I've definitely had better Chinese elsewhere (see my Great Wall in Bedford review). However, if you are in Central Square and want Chinese takeout, this is a very real option.

Ordering by phone is best, they really do arrive lickety-split. I have gone into their odd shop to get take out and the guy (owner?) taking the orders is all business. No smiles. No hugs. Nothing. He just takes your order and your money and then pretends you don't exist until your food is ready. I guess I wasn't looking for a best buddy, but...still. The "restaurant" itself kind of reminds me of a kitchen area in someones apartment. Strange. 

My man almost always gets the Pu Pu Platter and I always take his egg roll (good stuff). Chicken with broccoli is my constant pick. I'm not sure what sauce the chicken and broccoli actually come in... but the broccoli is always fresh, crispy and hot. 

As long as you don't think too deeply about what you're actually eating, you'll be just fine... besides isn't that the urban myth about Chinese food? I mean, no one REALLY knows what's in the egg rolls.

The Lantern might possibly be the best place to breakup with someone because they can' t possibly throw a fit here when eating deliciousness!  

Note: I have not done any breaking up with anyone at Lantern, nor do I plan to at this time. 

I have been going here since the place opened, and it is possibly the most reliably consistently good place around, especially considering their commitment to using as much local food sources as possible. For people that say they want to support local farms this is one of the best places to eat out (Panzanella and Crook's Corner being other places). Yes you pay a little more maybe, but the taste and quality is worth it and the power of your dollar spent is threefold which in turn is cheaper for you in the long run. 

I do have a few tips .. if you order a fish, it may come with a head.  The flesh on a fish's head is possibly one of the best bits so don't be a prude or complain about it.  Also this place isn't about being rushed, it's about having a pleasant experience and enjoying your food and drinks.  If you need food or drinks quickly, go somewhere else.  Lantern gets very busy on the weekends, so I advise going here during the week.   Finally, especially to newbies on a date,  there is no need to act pretentious or 'put on aires'.  Listen to your servers recommendations, they know what they are talking about and you cannot hope to 'one up them' or 'impress' without sounding like a douchebag.  Shut up, enjoy the experience, and let them take you on a lantern journey.  Oh I almost forgot - do not act condescending to the bar and waitstaff, of I might punch you in the face myself. 

Thank you Lantern for many years of happy memories and meals.
The only mom and pop bakery near Glendora! Love their pumpkin spice, mocha cookies. The strawberry cupcake is a little slice of heaven. Yummy!

I went here to get a replacement license. I went online to schedule and appointment - the earliest available was about week later. 

But I am really glad I made an appointment b/c I avoided the huge huge walk-in line. If you don't have an appointment it will probably take you over an hour to just check-in - bring a book, magazine, mp3 player, etc.   It took me about 10 minutes to check-in. If you have an appointment go right up to the door and enter on the left side. I was handed a form to fill out. Filled it out. Waited another 10 or so minutes to be called - they have a separate queue for appointment people. I was in and out of there in about 1/2 hour.  

PARKING: The have a lot right next to the DMV and a lot across the street from the DMV. Both these lots are small, crowded, etc.  I suggest arriving at least 10-15 minutes prior to your appointment to make sure you get parking. I ended up driving around a bit then just parking at USC and walking over. If you're a USC student, I suggest you do the same just to avoid the hassle. If not, there is some metered and street parking on South Grand Ave. It is a like a 4-5 minute walk.  

The part that irks me is that even though I filled out the form with my new weight (last time I filled one out was in like 2000 - I don't weigh 150 lbs anymore) they didn't update it on the license and they sent my license to my parents house!  I filled out the mailing address so it'd get sent to me instead of my parents. The lady even asked me which address I wanted it sent to, and I said my Los Angeles address... how do you screw up such a basic things? My new license arrived in about 5 weeks, but I had to drive 40 miles to pick it up.   

They started off with 4 stars because thanks to the appointment my DMV visit was quick and I was sent my license not too long after. -1 star for messing up something as basic as updating my information, lack of parking and sending my license to the wrong address.

We had purchased a gift certificate from restaurant.com and decided to use it to celebrate our anniversary here this past weekend. Made reservations for an earlier dinner (6pm) and when we arrived, we were just one of 3 tables they had at the time. 

The decor - beautiful and definitely formal feeling. There was a wedding going on in the courtyard outside which we walked out to peek in on after our dinner. 

The service - good! Our waiter was very nice. We never felt rushed, and he took good care of us. 

The drinks - Had a white cosmo which was really tasty. My husband ordered some time of gin drink and he liked it (it was crazy strong however!) 

The food - surprisingly not that expensive and good! It didn't totally blow us away, but large portion sizes, and definitely felt like a good value for the money. We both started with the Heirloom Tomato salad (which was tasty - an interesting take on a bread salad with grilled flatbread, tomatoes (yellow and red), balsamic, and some arugula with goat cheese.) Yum. I had the pecan crusted trout (HUGE piece, with a side of spinach and rice). And my husband had the Pork dish (it was served over some tasty grits/polenta/something delightful - big portion and he said definitely very filling!). For dessert we split a marscapone cheesecake (which was REALLY good). 

Overall - a good experience! I don't know that we otherwise would have tried it had we not had the gift certificate....but we enjoyed a nice, quiet, romantic dinner (until some people came in at the tail end with a bunch of kids - which confused me since there was nothing kid friendly on the menu? Maybe they were staying at the inn there...) We'd go back to try some more on the menu since I felt it was a good value and the service was good!

I am not quite as enamored with Milano Market as most. Granted, their sandwiches are pretty good, there's so often a long line and service is not really friendly. The $8 sandwich is fair, but many other items are pretty pricey. Also, I bought a cup of pasta salad that wasn't sealed properly. Without me noticing, it started running through the plastic bag onto my pants and shoes. I smelled like garlic all afternoon and just hope the dry cleaners will get the stains out.
My wife, I and a bunch of co-workers went here last Thanksgiving, the dinner was OK, I guess I just expected more, with it being in the Barn at Stanford...

#100

I heart fans... Thanks for making me feel like a superstar!

I heart opposing thumbs... Or it would take me a long time to type...

I heart when I slam the dishwashing soap on the counter and it releases happy little bubbles around me... Duh, Bubbles!

I heart gerbera daisies... Flowers make me smile!

I heart cream puffs...  Party in my mouth!

I heart stilettos... I have an obsession.

I also heart cookies... I have an addiction. Just call me Cookie Monster!

So it surprised me when I took that first bite and realized that I DO NOT heart Diddy Riese cookies. 

No nookie for this cookie!

Euro Cafe is nice because it's close to home.  I decided to come here for breakfast.  I ordered a croissant and let me tell you, this croissant is gianormous & great for a small breakfast.  The French cream coffee is very aromatic and gives me a nice perk in the morning!  I have a few friends that really enjoy the place.  One of them is obsessed!

From what I could observe, the environment was very homey, relaxing and I would say a nice place to just relax and have conversation with friends!
Excellent, five stars, healthy happy hippie food!!!! The mussels, the beets, the matzah ball soup were all great

If you are in the USC area go HERE. 


One reason, they actually list the price of their items so unlike 3Bros up the street or LA Bikes in the UV everyone gets the same price, and the color of your skin doesn't warrant a 20% mark up. Also knowledgeable and friendly service helps.

The true power of Pita Pit is how much it has ingrained itself into my psyche.  I FLIP OUT everytime I see a Pita Pit anywhere outside of Ithaca.  It brings me endless joy when that happens.

I love my pita punch card.  I used to covet it, saving it for a special occaision.  The workers are very liberal with the sauces, should you request it.  MMMMMMMMMMM tsazizkksiksiikikiki.  I have seriously written several pieces of prose, honouring Pita Pit.

But the best thing is?  The SMELL!!!!  I love how the smell can bring people together.  I love how you just know, after taking a whiff of someone, if they've frequented the Pita Pit in the past 72 hours.  And I love that everyone knows this smell.

I worked here for years (YEARS. Four of them, including summers) up in stacks, then down in Interlibrary Loans, then as an ILL student supervisor. I wasted the best vitriol of my life here; I will never be 18-21 again, and I will never reclaim the vile bitterness that laced my love for the library during those years.

It's probably a good thing that I've left it all behind.

If it could have been a little less ensconced in the North Campus boonies, that would have helped me out a lot during the Summer '02 Walks of Shame.

In case you haven't spent much time in libraries of any sort, I will make this very simple. YRL big. Powell not as big. Powell pretty. YRL ugly. Powell comfy. YRL less so, but more conducive to study session-induced nosebleeds. Powell filled with undergrads, usually first and second years. YRL infested with irate grad students clamoring for hard-to-find editions of publications from which they only need one paragraph. Their grumpiness was like a virus that spread through all five floors. I think they need a collective sabbatical.

I have big qualms with patrons who steal books, because when I look up a book in the Catalog and see that it's at YRL, I expect it to be at YRL. Many times, it was not. For shame, you thieves of public literature. When you steal a library book, it's not just the book you're taking. You're also robbing young girls of their dreams (of not having to buy it at Borders).

This is a great research library and has collections to suit. It has a Special Collections Room where you can read delicate, rare materials at a long wooden table with other seekers of Special Collections, a Reference Reading Room, Performing Arts Special Collections, Microform & Media Services, and it even houses the East Asian Library up on the second floor. The student employees don't care about you and will probably not be helpful, but the full-time staff are professional, knowledgeable and very nice.

There are computers stationed to your left upon entrance and study desks lining the walls of each floor, but I recommend checking out a laptop and taking it out to the lovely Sculpture Garden if you're looking to surf or kill time.

See you in the HQ's!

$1.50 Ice Cream cookies.  Win!

My favorite cookie flavors are the chocolate chip, and the cinnamon-sugar cookies.  One each, with some mint-chip ice cream in the middle.

Close your eyes, bite in, and grit your jaw so your sensitive teeth won't cause you some brain-freeze.  

Be full for $1.50.

This Is Good Stuff.

I started coming here because I was really hungry one late night and was pleasantly surprised.  The tacos are really fresh.  This is way above Del Taco or Taco Bell.  The food is cooked to order here.

The chicken tacos are great.  Grilled breast of chicken that is sliced up and filled in soft tortillas (I prefer flour).  A little fresh lettuce, cheese, guacamole, and pico de gallo.  That's it.  Very simple and very delicious.  No grease or anything.  Squeeze on a little lime and add some spicy hot sauce.

Tried the steak tacos tonight and they are also fresh and clean.  I hear people love their fish tacos and the Health Fresh Mahi Mahi.

I like this Lake Ave location because the employees work hard, are friendly, and keep a clean shop.

popular, so expect to wait and expect to be rushed. not the friendliest server for our table.  warm (almost) hot water served in our water glasses, which was pretty yucky.
delicious sounding brunch menu, but round the table all of our plates underwhelmed.
one slice of toast with a brunch eggs platter just makes me want to give the place 1 star.

Just came here for lunch and had a really awkward experience.  They are REALLY serious about the banh mi carry-out only thing (they introduced banh mi on their menu but it's carry-out only, or was when this was written).  Girlfriend and I came in and didn't know it was carry out only until we ordered, so we got out food and since the restaurant had literally 4 other people in it, we asked if it was okay to eat there.  The waiter said "Are you trying to get me in trouble" and wouldn't even ask the manager if it was okay for us to eat there.  He said the manager was "Being yelled at by some other customers about something else".  We were basically just told by the waiter  we should leave although he did eventually throw up his hands and say "Okay just do whatever you want,"  which made it too awkward to stay anyway.

While I understand it's a $5 item they don't want to let you have a table for an hour for (since the banh mi somehow took literally 30 minutes to get served to us, no exaggeration, with only 4 other customers in the restaurant), I think it's a really terrible business decision for a few reasons.

1) It's a new food item, you want it to be served so that its taste and texture are the best possible.  No food item is improved by sticking it in a bag where it will collect steam and the bread will lose its crispness.
2) It's a new food item, you want feedback.  You want to come around and ask people "How is it?  Could we improve it?" etc, instead of "Here's your lunch, now scram."
3) If you don't want to give a table away in a small restaurant so cheaply why not just offer a carry-out discount so that the sandwich is $5 carry-out or $7 to eat in?
4) Customer goodwill is pretty important.  I would have been really happy if I came away thinking "They said carryout only but they were flexible and let me eat here because it's 100 degrees outside and there's nobody here, that was nice of them," and I would have definitely come back.  Instead all I learned was that policy comes first and they don't really care what I think.

For the sake of objectivity, I will say the sandwich itself was good, and definitely a great deal for $5.  I think Jujube's is slightly better but it's also a good deal smaller and it's a little more expensive.  If you want a Banh Mi and you, for example, think it's reasonable to have to carry your lunch to Caribou Coffee to eat if you want to be out of the heat, then it's pretty good.

A late night staple for Columbia students, Koronet uses all the gimmicks it can get for customers to enjoy its somewhat mediocre pizza.  The size of the pizza - yes, it is mind boggling - can be daunting at first, but it's not too hard to eat a slice or two if you've got the appetite.  The only problem is whether or not you'd want to.

The pizza tastes a bit like cardboard at times, and doesn't have too much flavor.  For just a bit over $3, it's not a bad deal.  The place is open really late into the evening and is popular with students clearing out of the bars as it's one of the only places to eat nearby.  If there were other choices, Koronet just might not be so special.

So I have been craving that Combo A or Combo #2 ghetto Chinese food for the longest time. I actually even went to this restaurant three times around 8:45pm for quite some time, but they would always be closing and refuse to service me. I would argue with them that they close at 9, but they just apologized and sent me away.

I don't know why people like this place so much. Okay so let me talk about the food for starters. Maybe it's because I only go at night, but Chinese Express tastes like it was delivered by express mail or something because that chicken, rice, and chow mein is stale! It was disgusting. I did gobble it down because Chinese food is always pretty good, but mine was hot out of a frying pan and it still wasn't very tasty.

Another thing is that they only take cash. I had to go run to the ATM to get some cash and upon paying the cashier gave me the most janky, pink colored $5 bill that was ripping as my change. I asked to get another one, but he was super stingy and said he closed the register as he was actually closing it so he wouldn't be able to give me a different $5.

But if you're looking for cheap chinese food with pretty good portions eat at this place. It's not anything you MUST try, but its just that typical cheap chinese take out food so if you're broke and feel like eating paper. Go hit this place up.

the Great,
GumZ

you might think it's a bit far to go all the way to harlem for italian food...especially if you live in brooklyn.  but seriously, if you have the time to take that hike you will be SO glad you did.

this is a family-owned italian restaurant...i mean FROM italy, not like from bensonhurst and they're 3 generation new yorkers.  they're recently here from italy, from what i was told.  the food tastes like italy.  the decor feels like italy.  they have those amazing brick pizza ovens and some of the best pizza i've ever had.  the pasta dishes i tried, including my own seafood pasta dish were each better than the next.  and the prices are definitely reasonable...even cheap actually.  i'm definitely going back.

Leaving Blakes the other night I discovered this pizza by the slice place next door. At first I balked at the $3.79/slice price after tax, which seemed a little high. However, on closer inspection I realized that the slices were a pretty decent size and also nice and thick.

I bought a slice of vege pizza. It was excellent, and I wasn't fully inebriated (only slightly). Will be back. Will buy another vege. Will not try the meat topping pizzas, because they cost more and don't meat my cost-benefit analysis chart. And by chart I mean I'm cheap and the vege slice is bigger (thicker) for less money.

Going to telegraph i always enjoyed eating at 3 diff. spots and they were all on the same street.  Theres this joint, top dog across the street and this underground spot underneath the old tower records that served shitty pizza but u can play games and drink beers there.  

IB's is delicshshsh....always a hard decision on this and top dog since that pizza joint closed.  Bucket of cheese fries or garlic fries with your cheese steak and ur set to go..... i usually go next door to the liquor store and get a different drink while they are making the cheesesteak cus the thirst quenching options are limited....not much room for seating here...oh and the hot sauce make sure to get some of that ....try grabbing the bottle and hogging it until someone has to ask u for it....

(theres this other cheesesteak joint on E....1 ...FO..... in san leandro that would be good competition for IB's if they ever had an iron chef "hoogies/cheesesteak" edition, Bobby Flay would get his ass kicked)

I ate at East side pocket on the first night they opened their door, seriously...  I actually went to my favorite Cafe Paragon and they just closed the kichen after last call 1145pm.  My favorite server sent me out to East side pocket. I love it ever since.  They are family run business (seems like they all work there.  Their kaboob (wraps) are all great, low price and tasty.  It is clean, no fancy decor but solid popularity since they opened their door to public.
We love dining at this private club in Westwood. The service and food is the best LA has to offer. It is a very

This place is definitely budget oriented.  I don't know what kind of clientele they typically get, but next to the sink there was a sign asking guests not to use their hand towels for car cleaning, shoe shining or eating off of.

The manager was genuinely friendly and directed me to walk about a mile to the downtown where I could attend the weekly Farmer's Market.

Great pizza at a great price! Best in the wee hours of the morning when there's a line of drunk college students outside purchasing pizza as fast as Koronet can produce it. I came back the other afternoon and, be warned, 1 slice was too much pizza for me. However, you can ask them to cut it and make it into two meals. Good to go!

i enjoyed reading the other reviews. this place is a total crack up.

ah, the KONG.... this is the horrible place that no one admits to frequent... and all the no ones are sipping up scorpion bowls together in this place!  funny.  i've met some of my lifelong friends here.  have a soft spot for this place (and boston and cambridge sucks so to have a soft spot about anything here is a big deal).  oh the memories your closest friends in a scorpion bowl then fishing out the plastic figurines afterwards.

I wouldn't go anywhere else!

When I first moved to Michigan, I had several unfortunate hair experiences. One stylist, looked out the window AS she cut my hair, when I asked her if she was paying attention, she literally said "I check in every once in a while". Another supposedley 'hip' shop (turned out to be hippie shop), the stylist's dog was annoyingly running around and getting way more attention the I was, and I was paying the dog was not!

When I found Cookie, I knew I'd found my haircutting home for the duration of my stay. 

She's fun, knowledgeable, not afraid to tell you what she thinks, and keeps the joint jumpin' She's GREAT with curly hair, excellent with cut and color!

Don't expect a speedy in-and-out, AG is about the experience. Pamper yourself, relax, read some fashion mags, enjoy good music, and an eclectic thoughtfully hip interior an occasional 'beverage' and a professional FUN staff!

Also, if they do (rarely) screw up, or give you something you're not completely happy with, they will fix it, no questions asked! However, I have learned this is rare as my wife and I have gone hear for years.

I've attended 5 colleges, and I loved this school because of the location. I lived in Shell Beach, and commuted the 15 minutes to SLO, which wasn't too bad. The weather was fantastic, and the education wasn't bad either. The professors in the journalism and education departments were always willing to help, and they made students earn their grades. SLO is fairly small, which I like, and has limited nightlife-- for me that was okay, but there are those who crave crazy clubs and frat parties. This town is not the place for wild nights out, and most private parties are broken up by the cops. So, if you are looking for a solid education and limited nightlife, this is a fabulous college!

Nice ambience, nice drinks, decent fondue (though overpriced).  I suppose the band was okay, though they were more jazzy than jazz.  But the service was terrible.  I kept seeing our waiter flit from table to table right by us.  I think we had to tell him three times to bring desert.

His loss really - the tab would have been bigger because I would have drunk more if I knew it was going to take 4 hours to eat.

That said, it could be a nice night out with friends, if the service was better.  It didn't seem like a hipster hangout - really diverse crowd of all ages.

if you've ever been to the pacific northwest, you might long for coffee this strong and rich. i do.

why? the peetniks are true coffee geeks. when you want coffee, go to the peeps that know it. also, pastries aren't the mass preserved starbucks sort, but tasty and local instead.

yes, it gets crowded and it's not the best chill out spot, but, for me, the coffee is the basis of a coffee shop. 

is it the brewing machines?

Such a cute nail salon! 

Super nice and friendly. These ladies actually want to talk and make good conversation. I had Tammy and she seemed popular since every person that came in knew her! Bottom line.. I loved Tammy and her quality pedi! It was worth the $18. I won't go here every single time I need my nails done but I'd forsure go back again! =)

Some negative reviews here, but I always liked the place.

Nevertheless, as of mid Feb 2008, Pertutti's is closed.

Word on the street is that the place has been sold. Whether that means the new owners will renovate a little and re-open using the Pertutt name, or if it will turn into something else with a new name and a new genre of food, no word yet.

Hey Vegans, if you tell Petit Soleil ahead of time that you have a restricted diet they'll accommodate your needs for breakfast!  

2 years ago I spent a week in Paris by myself.  I was still an omnivore back then and I was staying at a small hotel in the Latin Quarter that provided breakfast every morning included in the cost of the stay.  Every morning I dined in the tiny dining room that also served as the lobby of the hotel.  I had my baguette with nutella, cafe au lait and orange juice before leaving to tackle the museums for the day.  I'd return to the hotel late at night and converse in english with the front desk before retiring to my room.  Traveling alone was liberating but also felt very isolating.  My little hotel felt like home and by the time my trip was over I was sad to leave the little family who worked there, who made my bed, who fed me breakfast, who tried to help me with simple french phrases.

While I made this trip to SLO with the dr. and I didn't need the B&B staff to serve as my mini-family, staying at Petit Soleil made me feel like I was back at Hotel Familia in Paris.  The quaint decor and the courtyard are nice.  You can rent the bikes they have in the bike racks near the front door.  Turn down service included a card with the weather for the next day plus truffles. L'Occitane (i know! the good stuff!) amenities in the bathroom were provided.  They provide wine and appetizers in the early evenings.  When I returned to the B&B and wanted to unwind after a yoga class, I went to the dining area and the girls hooked me up with some tea as they cleaned up after wine service and let me sit and write.  

There are so many nice little details about this place that made for a lovely stay.  Bonus points for being walking distance from Downtown SLO.  

I'm glad we ended up staying here and not at the Madonna Inn (which, from seeing from afar, I totally don't get).

Mon-Fri: 10am-1am, Sat-Sun: 10am-12am

Serves Mexican food, grill food, and sushi. Indoor and outdoor dining areas. Gourmet pizzas delivered to dorms nightly from 6pm-3am. In-house pizza slices served after 9pm.

Ate here tonight prior to seeing the 3rd and final staged reading of David Henry Hwang's new play, Yellowface, for the 2nd time (that's how much I liked it!). Anyways, I had the tiger taco (Steak), 1.25, the chicken taco, 1.25, and the Baja taco (fish), 1.75, $4.60 total. My order came with chips, and I liked the fiery red salsa and the salsa verde available. The place started out as El Pollo Rey in 1998, but that place sucked, and in 2000 became The Treehouse. Sometimes you'll find high school students here (there are only so many cheap places in Shallow Alto), and the rush is about 6:30 to 6:45PM on a Friday night, apparently.

Decided to take a day off work for some me-time and came here to get lunch with the bf. I've been here once for their pitcher margaritas, which was great, so this review is mainly focused on the food. Looked at the menu and didn't really see anything I really want. We sat at the bar section and the lady didn't notice us for a long time! Finally she came by and gave us our chips and salsa, which was very good, and I think that was the best part of the meal.

They don't have lunch specials, which kinda sucked since it was a weekday and I wanted something that was reasonable priced. I got the taquitos and enchiladas plate. It was alright, but I definitely had way better Mexican food before. 

Overall, there's no wow factor that makes me want to go back. I paid the bill and left unsatisfied and $20 bucks poorer.

Nice little neighborhood pub. I do not like beer and I even found a beer I liked.  It is nice during warm nights to sit outside but last time we were there we were a large party and the waiter was sort of rude about the sitting arrangement. Overall we have had great service. I have been to this place several times with friends and also met the owner, which is a really nice guy that shared with us his passion about beer and the reason he selected to offer the beers he has placed on the menu. I loved their grilled vegetable burger and their fries are really worth trying....the cheese plate is not bad either.

This is an ok spot to start off the night with drinks and maybe an appetizer or two, if and only if the good places around the corner are packed like a mofo..  

Beer selection here is ok, chips and salsa were good, guac tasted like it was defrosted, shredded beef nachos were good, and service was good.

I've usually have had great experience with Verizon stores.  After all, that's one of the reasons why you pay more on your monthly bill.  I came into today with my phone that is not even 45 days old that needed to be replaced.  I signed myself up on the check in and waited while there were employees simply standing around doing nothing.  Finally, this nice sales girl helped me and said I had to do it through their insurance company online or on the phone.  I don't understand why a store with 6 employees with nothing to do could not spend the 5 minutes to do that for me.  Then, they told me I would have to get a prepaid phone since I wouldn't receive my replacement for 2 days.  I asked them if I could buy a prepaid phone there and they said yes, but they would have to open up the package and activate it.  Thy recommended me to go to Radio Shack instead, which I did, and the guy had to activate it in store anyways!  What a disappointment!

Six flavors of some of best yogurt you'll ever have the pleasure to taste, mixed anyway you like. Chocolate, Vanilla and Oreo cookie seem to be the staples with guest flavors appearing daily. Go straight, go swirl. Go toppings if that's your bag. Not mine. Straight up vanilla is great there cuz it's a surprisingly good vanilla. Ghiradhelli chocolate fills the shop with college girls most days and especially at night. The vagrants and bored local high school kids loiter around the outside adding to the atmosphere. It's tucked between I (heart) New York Pizza and Caribou Coffee, like a dessert course.

They're cash only, because reporting accurate income for taxes is for losers. Keep receipts showing 10 items purchased and you get a free small yogurt. Parking is almost non-existent. Some people park illegally in front of Kinko's (me). Across the street at University Mall (park closer to Wachovia, the guard doesn't like to walk all the way down to shoo you away). Or just make a passenger jump out as you circle the block. There's also the pay parking lot that becomes free after 8 pm (only suckers pay at night).

Some people call it a Chapel Hill tradition. I don't know, it's a soft serve yogurt shop done well. If I have to call it a tradition to keep them from changing a thing except for the flavors, then it's a tradition.

The only time I was wronged by Yogurt Pump was an exceptionally bad batch of mint chocolate yogurt (mint to the extreme!). The girls who run the shop most days apparently can't do a free yogurt unless you bring them a receipt or a melted puddle of lactose free milk product. Meh it was $2, I was doing it for the principle of it anyways. I still go there and still take my friends. It's good, local and cheap.

This is one of my favorite gardens in the world! While it's part of the Cantor Arts Center, it's worth its own independent entry on Yelp since it stands alone from the Arts Center and can be visited at any hour of the day on any day of the year.

It is the most amazingly pleasant environment, it is impossible not to be caught up in the beauty of the place. The garden is very well kept. The sculptures and surrounding natural elements are in great harmony. At night, the garden is lit up and offers an experience quite unique from the one during the day.

Be sure to bring a camera when visiting as you will certainly want to take pictures of the sculptures. Depending on the time of day, the light plays off of the pieces in different ways. Every visit brings new experiences and revelations about the art and its surroundings. This is a must-see, an experience you are sure to enjoy and cherish.

I very rarely write updates because honestly -- when you have 100 more places to write reviews about, why bother writing a review about the same place twice? But I think Twist merits an update, because I reviewed it when it first opened, and it has definitely made plenty of improvements since then.

Without ever meeting the owners of Twist, I can tell that they care. They have suggestion boxes and almost everything I nitpicked on back in December has been improved or completely revamped. Fruit offerings are wide and varied, even more so than pinkberry. This is not to say that some of it isn't frozen -- some strawberries i've tried have been on the hard side -- but they offer canned longan, pineapple, blackberries, peaches, blueberries, pomegranate etc... more types of fruit than I can stuff in my little cup. They also now offer 2 cup sizes so you don't feel like an absolute glutton when you bring your $7 cup to the register; I can happily fill up on the small size and have it total under $5.

But more so than anything else, Twist has improved on the previously mundane decor by having paintings by a local artist all over the store. The art is cheery, eclectic and quite interesting to look at. It doesn't have the commercial hip, trendy feel of Pinkberry, but it is warm, inviting, and they actually WANT you to sit and stay! Pinkberry's decor for sure is very chic, but those wire chairs aren't exactly intended for comfort. There have been times when I've felt that the chairs are designed so you don't linger too long, so the next customers can sit too. It's not that way at Twist at all. People linger and hang out because the leather chairs are comfortable and no one will ever bother you. While I said in my first review that Twist lacks a lot of the charm of Pinkberry and Red Mango, I can safely say that this isn't true anymore. I find that there's something slightly boring now about the decor and feel of the millions of froyo places that dot the city. If anything, Twist brings a fresh perspective (or twist you could say) of what it means to be a small business reinterpreted on the back of a raging fad.

Kids, eat all the Mad Mushroom you can.  Seriously, it's good for the brain.  Why else would it be so cheap???

Cheesesticks + Ranch = Best days of my Life.

Viva la Mad Mushroom!

Now, I'm a pretty confident believer in Yelp reviews, so I must admit that I was let down, as I was led astray on this one. Truth be told, it was awful. I can sum up the experience pretty easily with just one simple equation: 

College kids + no taste + money to burn = Judie's

Rest assured, the next time I'm in Amherst (if that ever happens), you'll find me at the Route 9 Diner.

i've eaten at sushi.come (or sushi.com) several times in the past and n thought it was passable if I needed something quick around central campus that wasn't a sandwich or a hamburger. 

The food is do-able albeit at times a little overpriced. Throw some special sauce on the equivalent of bulgolgi (yes, i know it's a japanese restaurant, but its korean owned) and suddenly its 12.95?  honestly, its two ingredients away from beef terriyaki, 8.95.  and by ingredients, i mean hot sauce and maybe some sugar.

at any rate, my experience tonight sucked because our server forgot to punch in our order (we didn't know this) and we ended up waiting 35 minutes watching table after table get served within 5-10 minutes of placing their order. 

so, after asking another server, since my server was no where to be found, when our food was going to be ready, he went to the kiosk where they punch in their orders which i assume gets sent straight to the kitchen.  I notice him feverishly look down at the check and then back up at the screen and start punching in our order.  

my gf and i had to be somewhere in about 15 mins so i ask him "are you punching in our order? if you are, forget it because we actually have to leave."

the waiter responds: "uh. no. i'm not. am i your server?"

me: "no"

waiter: "lemme go get your server." (sprints off)

our original server comes back and apologizes, "im really sorry, i didn't punch it in."

at least she was honest.

at that point my partner and just get up and the server continues to apologize telling me to come back next wednesday and shell get it right next time.  

me: "nah its cool." 

pretty disappointing when a server forgets you.  worse yet, she didn't once come back to even check on us.  besides handing us our miso soup and salad, she was no where to be found besides seating other customers.  and the other server's attempt at salvaging the situation seemed even worse.

perhaps it was just a one time thing, but there is clearly something wrong when your server doesn't once check up on you or even bother filling up your water cup.

Petrune is definitely on the pricier side, which is both surprising and unsurprising (surprising because a lot of the clothes they sell are just modern pieces based on vintage styles, and unsurprising because... well, it's a vintage/consignment store, duh).

At any rate, you can find a ton of great modern 20's and 30's style pieces there. In particular, their coats and party dresses are divine (though way out of my budget!). 

Also, although it leaves much to be desired, Petrune has a small selection of clothes with thrift store prices. (Last spring, I managed to find a nice wool A-line skirt and a cheap flannel that I wear all the time when it gets cold.)

If you have money to spend, or if you're just looking for eye candy, Petrune is worth a visit for sure.
Great atmosphere, small and cozy. Great food, wonderful owner! It's an experience if you want it to be. Beer/wine not served, but you can byob.

This Capogiro has fewer flavors than the Center City locations, and that also translates into less counter space to accommodate the throngs of indecisive people who need to mill around and taste 18 different gelatos before they order.

On the other hand, this Capogiro has lots of seating and coffee, lunchtime foods and (hallelujah) a bar. I didn't try any of that, though - you can get a beer and a sandwich anywhere, but there's only one game in town for pineapple sage sorbetto. And god bless them for it!

Great store if you're looking for maps, guide books, and novels associated with traveling.  They have the best selection and it's so nice to be able to pick the guide that you want.

If you travel a great deal, then definitely get the frequent buyer card.  
After purchasing $100 worth of goods, you get 25% coupon on your next purchase! 

I love coming here, 'cause it means that I'm getting ready for my next adventure!

Carolina brewery great beer, good pub food, and slow but friendly service.

It is a great place for a burger type menu and the food is reasonable $8-$11 range. But go there for the beer!!! It is a tasty as it comes. Try the Bock beer 7.5% quiet the kick.

I know some have rated it 2 stars for the food it is better than that but think burger quality not fine dining.

To whom it may concern,

I've hired Carlos for years now for my parties. When my party is big enough, he's the guy I call. This was before he started Stanford's Bartender when he was a lone agent just delivering awesome bartending. When he told me he started a new company based on what he does so well, I was very happy for him.

Stanford's Bartender can be entrusted to deliver a phenomenal party. After years I've learned that he will deliver exactly what he said he will and excels at creating really fun professionally delivered bartending service to my guests. He has also helped me create themes, drink lists and grocery lists that have helped me be more efficient and save me thousands of $$, I have absolutely no problem giving him 5 stars and I am sure that you will feel the same way. After 16 years of entertaining at home and using dozens of other services and expensive big companies I'm very happy to have found Carlos and I highly recommend him and his new SB company. 

Don't try and use him on a night I need him. Carlos, remember who gets priority! 

Shawn Refoua
Director, Sf Mixology

Yes...it is over-priced and kinda ostentatious to shop in a place where the label "organic" is meant more for upcharging and to impart some pseudo-sense of health and enlightenment but the food is good.

Love to grab some of the prepped food at the counter, the sandwiches are made to order and the snacks in the front are always worth browsing.

I'm really disappointed to write this update, but after several months of denial about what has become of Paradiso, I'm finally admitting that it's time.

My experiences here have been getting progressively worse for awhile now.  Service is as bad as ever, which I used to be happy to overlook because the food and coffee were so great. Now the soups are being over-seasoned with heavy handed doses of curry powder, dill, and what tastes like artificial smoke flavoring, but ironically lack salt and pepper.  The vegetables and legumes are also usually undercooked (we're talking crunchy peas) while the pasta is overcooked and mushy. Their soups used to consistently wow me, but I can't remember the last time I had one that was even passable. Sandwich fixings are being poorly cut so you end up with things like half inch thick cucumber slices and bread of wildly different sizes on either side of the sandwich. Portion sizes are also shrinking to the point of ridiculousness, and the cup of soup for (i believe) $3.50 is becoming increasingly offensive.   Prices overall have gotten pretty nuts.  Today I spent over $12 on a half sandwich/soup combo with which I was given very little soup, a pastry, and a bottle of water that they didn't actually ever give me.  It was pretty much the nail in the coffin for my Paradiso lunch habit.

Paradiso, please take note! You were once my favorite place for lunch and had soup so good I was willing to wait forever to get it. Please get your act together so I can love you again!
I like the ambience here and the location sure is convenient.  Try the roast rabbit.  Order several tapas and share with your table.  The tequila bar is a gift in and of itself.

DA-Liciuos!
we love it there!

When you walk in the decor gives the vibe of an upscale restaurant.. but then you see the giant beer bongs and you remember you're right on a college campus.. the drinks were cheap I mean a 5$ margarita and 8$ long island is ok by me.. We sat at the bar .. so I don't know how the servers are but the bartender we had was nice.. however one of her coworkers worked my nerves .... but regardless of the nice service from the bartender who served me like the entire time.. it took FOREVER to get drinks.. I literally thought she forgot about us.. but then she showed up at the exact moment everytime when I thought " where the f#$@ is my drink " and all was... well I guess

I never got any food.. but were contemplating the nachos.. mainly because like EVERYONE was getting them and it's not like they were the cheapest thing on the menu which suggests to me that they must be good.. and for only 12$ that GIANT plate of nachos would totally be worth it.. ( if they are good  )  I work near penn so this is sort of on the other side HOWEVER I'd be down to go back to try out some food..

Since my initial review, I've been back twice to get other trophies made for karaoke league events and these guys always do a great job.  They also apparently have great memories--every single time I've walked through their door after my first visit they've been like "hey! karaoke league!".  

I think the best part about these guys though has to be the quick turnaround.  They can build you the most ridiculous trophy you've ever dreamed of in just a couple of days...and if you give them a vision (as I do with the karaoke trophies..."make it as hideously tacky as possible") they totally go with it.  

So if you ever find yourself in need of a trophy...go here.  They rock.

If you're looking for steak that is cooked well and not that pricey like other places..
Service was good, not great. Server was not as bright as would've originally thought. 
The atmosphere was friendly,

I didn't know my Reuben came with a side of Hepatitis A. 
Thanks!

Are you visiting the somewhat decent city of Boston when the weather is great and are you somewhat bored? Are you looking for something physically fun and exciting? Are you fearless of the water? If you said yes to all of my questions, this place may have your answer. Boating is probably one recreational activity I have started to appreciate recently, due to doing Dragon Boat racing on the Charles River about a year ago. 

I went with a group of friends with some excitement, since I was looking forward to getting back into the water and doing some boating when the weather was more than 28 degrees Celsius. 

By the time we finished filling out the waiver forms, passed the safety quiz, obtained our life vests, and got a brief overview about the kayak paddle we got onto our kayaks and headed out into the river for some fun. Within 1.5 hours, we got some great views of the city, paddled through a man made "lagoon", talked with some random people on sailboats, raced against each other, and went under the Longfellow Bridge and Mass Avenue Bridge. It was a lot of fun. Despite the really warm weather, I did not mind getting splashed by a few drops of water from the paddling. All of us thought we had a great time. 

Prices are reasonable. You definitely save some money if you are with someone and rent a two-person kayak.

Overall, if you are visitor or local, and looking for something fun and exciting to do in the somewhat decent city of Boston, with some physical activity, this is a great choice. If I had another chance to do this fun activity again with a group of people, I would definitely do it.

This joint totally gives out feeling of "A must hangout place on the weekends", well that is if you're still in College. It sure does, it reminds of the old joint I used to drop in for a quick bite or a beer. 

I was with a group of Southern Cali Audi Enthusiast, and we just caravaned from LA..SLO was our stop, a local reccomended this joint for easy bite and fast service for our big group. All I can think of at that point was just to get a quick bite, some beer and then head back to hotel for some rest. I was super tired, didnt have enough sleep from the night before, and the drove we had was crazy. Driving like maniacs and scared all the locals or others with our big groups. Thinking about it, it totally reminded me we're like in a movie or something on an ultimate race, but it sure was good times. Back to the story, they guarranteed us 30 mins wait, but wow, 30 mins became 90 mins. 

It was a complete torture seeing kids and grownups teasing us with the Chicken wings, Pizzas, breadsticks while us sitting in the corner still waiting. Eventually, we got to our seats and I got a small special pizza, which has Italian Sausage, Onion, Mushrooms, and Ham on them, and a drink. It came out to 18 bucks just for that with tips and taxes included. Yup, Trust me..I had your same reaction. Not only I was somewhat pissed, but I was too tired to think about it.

What a memory though..However, I like the little town, the locals are so friendly and everyone seem to know one another there.
