Like most native Houstonians, some of my fondest childhood memories took place at Miller Outdoor Theatre: rolling down its monstrous hill during field trips to the Zoo and nearby museums; Mom pulling us out of school to attend the Cinco de Mayo festivities - and one particular year circa '92 (I was in the 3rd grade) I ran up to Mayor Bob Lanier in a crowd of people and he kindly signed my copy of the Chronicle. 

Fast forward some 20+ years and the memories keep a happenin'. Catching "A Midsummer Night's Dream" during the summer's Shakespeare Festival, Houston Ballet, Houston Opera, The Fabulous Thunderbirds, and cultural performances like Bollywood musicals and Taiko drummers. And they have daytime performances on a weekly basis for the kiddies.

Tips:
*Bring the picnic baskets filled with goodies, bevs, blankets, BUG SPRAY, citronella candles
*Bring on the booze, but no glass.
*If you want reserved seating up by the stage, stop by MOT early and snag your free tickets. 
*Grass area: Lawn chairs MUST be seated stage left; blankets stage right.
*Please don't talk during the show. It's rude. 

***And as everyone else mentioned, all of these performance and festivities at MOT are FREE. If you want some good karma, make a monetary contribution to the non-profit online, via check or money order. And it's tax deductible.***

My one wish for MOT is to extend its season's schedule. How lovely would it be to sip on a cup of hot cocoa while bundled up in a Snuggie and catch a winter show? Sure beats the summer's heat!

The student population at Berkeley can be divided in half quite easily - patrons of Blondies or patrons of Fat Slice.  I was a Fat Slice boy, since well, the name is better.  It's FAT slice.  And Fat is the new orange.  In fact, Fat is so cool, I had to make a top ten list.

Ed M.'s Top Ten Reasons Why Fat is Cool. 
 
10. You can describe so many things as "fatty." (i.e. a fatty j, a fatty shit, a fatty burp) You can't describe many things as "thinny."  
 
9. Fat Albert exists. Skinny Albert does not.  
 
8. If you're really really really fat, you could probably hide something really cool between your fat rolls. Like a sandwich! Mmmmm, sammiches...  
 
7. Fat makes great soap (see Fight Club).  
 
6. Fat people get to have the arm flappies. How cool would it be to have HUGE ASS arm flappies! Like arm flappies down to the ground! Dude, you could probably cradle a baby in your own fat! Skinny people do not have that option.  
 
5. There are tons of "Yo mama so fat" jokes, but there are NO "Yo mama so skinny" jokes.  
 
4. Dude, how funny is a really excessively fat dog? Puahahahaha!  
 
3. Fat and fart have only one letter difference. And honestly, who doesn't love a good fart?  
 
2. Fat old people are way way nicer than skinny old people. And I bet you the fat old people could totally beat up the skinny old people too.  
 
1. I bet you God is fat.

It's not every hair salon that can handle a 50-something bride and her two daughters on the morning of the wedding. Karen and Catlin gave us three beautiful, individual styles while chatting us up and calming us down. A wonderful experience all around.
Come for the beer, and love it!

fast, friendly, reliable service. Great place for a quick bite anytime, the menu changes almost daily to provide consumers with fresh choices. Try the breakfast sandwiches as well, VERY good!! Also check out the refrigerated case with take home items.

Although not much space to sit and eat, there are tables outside, def an awesome place for a nice sunny day

Def a must stop if your in the University City Area..

my fav deli and not just because it's a block away from where I live.
They use Boar's head for their sandwiches, which is extremely important. A sandwich is not the same without quality cold cuts.
2nd, its made to order, cheap (3.50) for a sub and (3.00) if you want it on a roll.
Aside from the cheap delicious sandwiches, I get my coldcuts by the lbs here... 6.99/lbs for boars head, yes please@

I have visited the Hip Kitty several times and always leave a little disappointed.  It is a great idea, fondue and Jazz...but it is pricey and NEVER clean.  The outside tables are always sticky and dirty, the outside heaters are always out of propane (I don't think they even work because I have never seen them on), and the restroom cleanliness lives a lot to be desired.  I would visit more often and not even mind the cost if the Kitty was cleaner.

I love this place! My favorite meat is CHICKEN and Zankou is just the place to go to satisfy my chicken craving. I usually get the number 2 combo (half a chicken with hummus, pita, tomatoes and beets. The new addition to Zankou's side sauce is Tapato!! MMMMMmmmm it adds an extra spicy kick combined with the graclic sauce who could ask for more! :)

I read the review about them being able to break a six-pack, and that is a very beautiful thing especially considering I love beer.  I love beer and sampling good beers, and you just can't do that while being friendly to your wallet if you have to get 6 at a time.

The wine selection, however, is quite small.  Great stop for someone who wants to get in and out fairly quickly, but there will be no browsing it like a bookstore because the size of the store is about the size of my closet.  However, they have extremely nice, knowledgable people working here and a great selection of glassware to go with that bottle you just purchased.

As Duke of this establishment, I should write a review.  It's Krispy Kreme, which, while their donuts are not my favorite donuts (Dunkin Donuts make me happy), does also offer good drink-related goodness.  The Oreo drink, the hot chocolate drink, even the coffee drink are all a-ok.  They always have fresh donuts too, if the sign is to be believed. 

I don't really have any good allegories or stories or the like.  I mean, at least it's an actual establishment and not a Princeton Review.

The bread here is delicious. Sneak some out with you. Prices for entrees range around $15-$20. Ragu sauce is always a bit on the salty side. The food doesn't come with complex flavors, very straight forward food. It is good for poor college students for a nice night out and good for left overs to eat the next day.

I decided to try this place as i was sick of eating burgers at IBs all the time , and since it was new . 
They have really good grilled chicken burgers and their salads are pretty good too (especially the one with the salmon ) . 
Service was fast and friendly.  
Overall I would definitely come back and eat here again .

I get so excited when I enter ANY Ross.. just because I am already thinking about all the possibilities of merchandise, be it shoes, dress, a picture frame.. This Ross is conveniently located at Downtown SLO.. and It's nice because it has two entrances.. one in the front of the store on Higuera.. and the other on Monterey. 
Although I wish it is a bit cleaner.. cmon its Ross people.. It's not like it's SAKS 5th Ave.. you're not gonna get treated like royalties here. 
but nonetheles.. its a good place to shop at when you have a lot of time to browse~

I love this bar. This is definitely more of a lounge area, so it is a choice spot if you want to get away from the wilder old town strip. It is also a perfect place to meet up with friends and just have a couple of drinks. 

There is a beautiful atmosphere created by the decor and the famous tree everyone mentions in their review. It is a pretty well hidden and small bar, so it doesn't get crazy loud there. The few times I have been it wasn't terribly crowded (once on a Friday and once on a Saturday), but it took a little while for my friends and I to get a seat.

Their drinks are good, pretty strong, and of reasonable prices. You get what you pay for here. I love the "sour bitch" drink and "the nerd". They both taste like different flavors of jolly ranchers.

Too bad Diddy Riese isn't close by but then again, I could always make myself one of these bad boys. I gave 3.5 stars for Diddy only because it was too hyped up for me. A couple of friends tried this place out a while ago and suggested it so I was curious to try. It's $1.50 to make your own ice-cream sandwich.. a reasonable price but probably not worth the wait. Luckily, when I went.. there was hardly a line. I ended up getting the choco-chip w/ walnuts and peanut butter cookies with cookies and cream in between. Like a few other yelpers have said.. it's good but not great. If I'm in the area again and craving something cheap and good, I'll stop by here. If not, I surely have a bunch of other sweet spots to hit ;)

This place is like an orgasm for your eyes and our mouth and just oh so delicious. It is located right in the Stanford Mall so it is perfect to stop in and grab a quick bite to eat. I have noticed at prime time the lines can be EXTREMELY long and at least 20 or so people out the door and a lot of times there is no outdoor seating so you may have to find elsewhere to sit or walk around and eat your delectable treat you picked up. 

Although I have only had the pleasure of having their absolutely Divine Baguette sandwiches on my lunch breaks, the pastries look so lovely and luscious I have been tempted once or twice! I have had a couple of the Baguette sandwiches and the bread is perfectly crispy and then perfectly chewy inside. The bread i just amazing. Depending on what kind of sandwich you get they are all really good. My favorite is the one that has the feta cheese, spinach, sundried tomatoes, etc. IT IS SO YUMMY!

I also that day had a sample of some kind of divine bread cranberry something or other? I hope to come back and buy a couple of their breads as well as their pastries when the diet permits, which will be probably never ha ha but a girl can definitely dream!!! I noticed they also had macrons which looked good as well. Everything here really does look excellent. The only downside is that things are a little expensive. My sandwich was $8.50 and with a bottle of diet coke my bill came to $11 which is definitely expensive for lunch but okay to splurge once in a while!

Decent little lounge for the student community. It offers a decent prices on drinks. There is a lot more space here than the Enormous Room nearby.

This place gets rocking with the college crowd on the weekends. Come early to get your tables that is situated on the walls of a square room. The crowds make for some casual fun environment. Definitely not the shi-shi place that you will find elsewhere. Nearby late night foods make for a great, after club, supper.
The best food ever. Totally worth the wait.

Tang's is another Chinese food truck on Penn's campus. An alternative to Yue Kee's, it's a good substitute for someone who doesn't want to deal with the cantankerous Yue Kee lady or the Yue Kee wait.

Tang's is so much faster than Yue Kee's because they don't stir-fry the food fresh for you on the spot. Nonetheless, their food still comes out piping hot and is quite delicious and fast. My favorite is the "egglan & tofu"  followed closely by the "egglan and chicken". I love that purple vegetable! Get reacquainted with this delectable vegetable. Your mother would be proud.

I can't explain the personality difference.

They have an extensive menu and almost all of their options are under $4. Wait time during lunch hour is ~15-20 mins from the time you get in line to food in hand.

I like the philosophy of Clover and its food -- very eco-conscious, seasonal, and local. Also it's pretty healthy and a good cheap food option in Harvard Square. But, they don't always execute their food successfully; sometimes the fries are soggy or the sandwiches bland. (but my boyfriend just said "if I were vegetarian, I would come here all the time")

In general, their breakfast oatmeal/granola options are always tasty and the infused drinks and iced teas (that they make in house) are interesting and refreshing. The people behind the counter are also very friendly and fun, so it's a great atmosphere.

The main reason that I go to the Harvard square location is the great lighting, good study space, and excellent Harvard wifi signal. I don't mind loud, but if you need quiet then this place is probably not good for you (the minimalist interior design doesn't absorb any noise). The tables and benches are built nicely, not rickety, and big enough for laptops and books (a problem with many independent coffeeshops). Pretty good outlet coverage all around the walls.
The only thing good here is the lattes and the chowder. If you don't like either, then don't go here.

Coffee: I only get their Chai Lattes and they are good most of the times. When iced, I'd order a double shot since it tends to water down rather quickly. 

Salad: Cobb salad was amazing. The red-wine vinaigrette I believe, complimented the salad very well without being overwhelming. A light yet hearty salad for a long night studying on the patio.

I star docked for priciness.

Finale is the kind of place that my parents would always say ... "Ah, it's just expensive because they create a nice fancy environment... but the food isn't actually anything special." Well, I think yes, it is a nice fancy environment, but I do think the desserts are quite special. Sorry I don't remember particulars, I do remember that tastes seemed to be very chocolatey, I don't know if I have much more to add than the other reviews listed here, but I will say that for me Finale is a reason to get your dessert cookbook out of your closet (or go buy one at Harvard Book Store for cheap), buy some nice chocolate over at Whole Foods, get a few nice pots and pans, and make something you find interesting in that cookbook, and invite your friends over, turn on your fireplace (or fake fireplace, whichever you have), turn on whatever music you want, and then just chill. Besides it's good to get your hands dirty, something I think some patrons at Finale aren't fond of. Goes with the whole soul v. HBS thing another reviewer already alluded to.

Pro: Great location. Can't really get any better than that if you go to Cal and you spend most of your time southside.

Cons: 
-Limited selection (to their credit they put this disclaimer about not having all advertised items in the front of their store)
-A second entrance that is not for you. Walk around to the Telegraph side.
-By the time you get through the line, you could have taken the 51/1/7/52L/F down to the Walgreens on Shattuck, bought all your stuff and been back up again.

Bottom line: Go here when no one else is around.

Mhmmm sooooo good! I tried several other dishes lately on their cafeteria/mall style food.

Dishes Tried Recently:
Lemongrass Chicken
Beef Stew
Beef in Black Bean Sauce

Lemongrass Chicken:
Very standard taste. Good quality lemongrass chicken.

Beef Stew:
Very tasty! Lots of different spices, lots of tender beef. Wonderfully put together in this entrée.

Beef in Black Bean Sauce:
There could have been a little bit more beef. The taste was standard and quite satisfying. If you enjoy black bean sauce, you won't be disappointed.

How can it be that no one has reviewed Francesca's yet? Intimidated by tackling Troy's 'best politically connected luncheonette'?

I've been getting my morning coffee at Francesca's for years now. It's nice to get out of the office, stretch the ol' legs and wander a couple blocks down the way. Sometimes, when the spirit moves me, I grab some of the homemade muffins for me and my coworkers. There's all sorts of quick breakfast stuff, sometimes an 'everything' bagel hits the spot. Most of it though, except for some occasional fresh fruit, is not precisely healthy -- which of course means it's delicious.

At lunchtime (and you want to get there early or late -- go at 12 and you'll be waiting on a long line of Troy Record / gubment workers(?)) there's usually an interesting special sandwich, but regular sandwiches are good too. Ingredients are piled pretty high which makes for a filling sandwich. Personally, I usually go with roast beef on whole wheat with mayo and smoked mozzarella. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.

I would say one of the best thing about Francesca's is that all the ladies there will learn your name within 4 or 5 visits. I don't know how they do it, but it's just a small thing that makes me feel welcome every time I go there.

The Playhouse as a whole is absolutely amazing.  Every venue I've been to has been stunning in every detail, from the decorative lounges to unique silverware, everything has been thoughtfully placed.  

The latest show I've seen was Bonnie and Clyde, this last Sunday and it has been my favorite so far, it may be my favorite play I've seen actually.  The voices of the cast are unbelievable, I dare you to not get goosebumps when they hit some of their big notes.  When the show first began I had questioned myself if they were actually singing, it was that good.  
Their voices along with Frank Wildhorn's musicality is an unrivaled pair.  Go see this play while you still have the chance!

The crew behind the playhouse did a killer job turning the extra room in the back into a dancing party like atmosphere complete with themed decor and bar.  Props to them.  Food is always good, people are always great, not much more to ask for in a relaxing Sunday night out.

This Starbucks is ALWAYS crowded. If you plan on getting some work done here or utilizing the free wifi, good luck with finding a seat. Your best bet is to come in the morning. But the evening, forget about it!

As for the coffee and service. Its good and great. Love the staff, never had any issues with prolonged wait.

So surprised to find a bar like this in Pasadena! 
Very cozy, nice atmosphere, great waiter, good drinks, plus I had a very pleasant interaction with other customers here!

First of all, the waiter we had was great! The place was packed and busy but he often came by our table to make sure we were doing okay, always making sure our glasses were full. 
When he saw a very drunk guy sticking around our table, he came by and asked if the guy was bothering us and if it was necessary for him to ask the guy to leave us alone. (Wow, now that makes girls like us feel like we can have fun comfortably!)

Interestingly, that night we met 2 other girls here and hit it off!
 There were a good crowd of people with class, and every interaction we had with other customers were very pleasant. 
I've kept in touch with the girls that I've met here and I am so surprised to say that I've actually made great worthy friends at this bar!

Drinks - Looking at the menu it seemed like they were not cheap but not too expensive. I can't say much about their cocktail tastes because we ordered a bottle of wine. About $27-35 a bottle between 2 girls is not bad at all!
Came with a full stomach so I didn't get to order food but smelled extremely good. I Will have to try that next time!

One downside: they have the entrance open at all times, it gets kinda chilly when the weather is cold. Grab a seat near the heater or wear warm enough clothes!

I will definitely be coming back often!

I've become a semi-regular here. Each waffle type I've tried (buttermilk, hemp & buckwheat, etc) has been delicious. 

At the beginning there were some differences in portion sizes for the a la carte toppings, especially peanut butter. I've become a big fan of their savory waffles so I can't say whether that in particular has improved, but the savory waffles are very consistently made and a good value.
They charge you a dollar to use your credit card. This is illegal. Please call your credit card company and dispute the charge. This will put pressure on them to comply.

This is a great place. The food is terrific. Be sure to try the organic eggplant dish - it's outstanding. Even the pappadums are memorable, freshly prepared and studded with caraway seeds. This is our standing date night dinner place whenever we visit RI.

There is definitely better border food, but you have to travel across the continent to get it regularly. 

I was prepared to give the place a four star review, but I had to deduct a star because they ran out of Chimichurri steak. I was looking forward to having that and had to settle for a Cajun burger, which wasn't as spicy as I thought it was going to be. In fact, I thought it dry and bland. 

I had to add a ton of Tabasco sauce to make the burger somewhat reminiscent of what I'm more accustomed to eating. I was surprised that the entire Boston area doesn't do Mexican food that well. Though I know that this place bills itself as Tex-Mex, the "Mex" part is certainly lacking and can use some improvement. 

If anything, the only case I would vouch for protection of illegal immigrants would be if the chefs in the back room were indeed authentic illegal Mexicans straight up from Mexico City. Boston deserves a more authentic sort of Mexican food and the revolution may begin here at Harvard. 

I thought the inside was more like a glorified Rubio's Fish Taco restaurant (which is a chain of Baja California restaurants in California primarily) so it didn't stand out as totally original to me. I was surprised that there was even a 20 minute wait tonight. I did think that the service was pretty good, as the server kept checking with how we were doing. 

Overall, I've yet to find a decent Mexican restaurant in Boston, and I'm starting to lose hope. If you're from Boston and you find yourself in California, be sure to try any single establishment there for a dose of real Mexican food. It's usually so good, you'll be tempted to call "la migra" to double-check the place's legality.

I am a professed sandwich-hater and I think that sandwiches are generally cold, bland, life-less, and uninspired as a lunch option. However, Toscano & Sons has me rethinking my position. In fact, call me converted because  I'm regretting I didn't get another sandwich to go.

This cute Italian market and deli is located on Marietta Street in the same shopping center as Five Season's Brewing Company and Hop City. Bonus-- plenty of parking and no mobs. The store has about 4 small tables along with a bar-height counter that runs along the window looking out on Marietta. For a Monday, they were doing some brisk business both with take-out orders and some occasional groups eating-in. 

The panini are about $4.75 each if I remember correctly and sides like soup or salad are extra. I got the "Viola" (mortadella, speck, salami, provolone, tapenade) and my husband got the "Toscano" (soppressata, fontina, arugula).  

When I think of panini, I imagine sandwiches that are pressed into flattened road-kill. But oh no, not these. These were warm on a chewy crusty ciabatta, but not the kind of crusty that breaks your jaw. Full of flavor, these were not lackluster in any way. The side salad and the Tomato Basil soup were a tad small in portion but also equally delish in my belly. 

Like the sandwiches, the market and deli does not disappoint. They carry an assortment of high-end olive oils and dried goods in addition to fresh ravioli /pastas in the freezer, fresh ciabbata, deli cuts, and wines. You'll be sorely tempted to do some lunch-hour grocery shopping. I scored some of their fresh lobster ravioli and some butternut squash ravioli. I would have bought some pancetta too but I figured I needed  come back on a more serious shopping trip.

If you do stop in for lunch, don't forget to pick up a frequent diner's card --buy 9 get 1 free.

Sure its a chain.  Sure their beef may only be choice (not prime).  The beef is dry aged (unlike many other places) tender and delicious.  For a classic dinner of a wedge salad and a hunk of medium rare beef in a swanky steakhouse atmosphere I have never been disappointed... just don't stray too far from those options...

Exceptional customer service!

I visited this CVS on Thanksgiving Day.  I was in a jam -- didn't have the ingredients I needed for the pies I was bringing to a Thanksgiving dinner!

One of the employees there, Nancy, treated me like family in helping me find a solution.  She searched the store with me and when it became apparent CVS didn't have all the ingredients that I needed, she recommended other places in the area.  Best of all, she wrote down a recipe for handmade pie crusts -- and explained exactly how to make it -- that turned out very well.  Later on I ended up circling back to CVS to get some pecans and other ingredients that only they were carrying.

A superb experience on Thanksgiving Day!

I want to love this place. It reminds me of a bustling Jewish deli in New York; the space is cramped and loud, and the atmosphere is chintzy and fun.

Service is a bit brusque as the place gets very busy, and they need to move customers through quickly; however, despite a line, we were seated very in only a few minutes. We placed our order outside (as we were told to do), so it was already in by the time we were seated; however, we didn't have a lot of time to take in the menu, and there were things listed inside that I hadn't noticed on the menu they handed us (ex. certain 'special' frappes and simple cheeseburgers). People were packed in, and we had to move our chairs or get up entirely several times throughout the meal to let people pass.

During my first trip, I got The Hillary Clinton burger (grilled mushrooms and sour cream). I ordered my burger medium rare, and it was perfectly cooked. Although I enjoyed the burger immensely, I wished I had ordered something cheesier. The next trip, I ordered the Ted Kennedy (cheddar cheese and grilled mushrooms). This time, I found the burger to be a bit over-cooked, with the outside tasting a bit burnt and dry. For a $10+ burger, I was a bit disappointed. 

Both times I ordered a frappe (Elvis -- chocolate, banana, Reese's -- and chocolate, respectively), and while good, they weren't quite thick enough.

Overall, it's a fun place with good, interesting burgers. I would definitely go back, keeping in mind the service and atmosphere.

One of those situations where I wish there was an option for negative stars. Another yelper said it best already: "overstuffed flavorless piece of crap"

Workers were unfriendly too. Laaaaaame.

Well, its a nice hip jazzy joint. Fondue isn't my greatest fave, but it was nice and I suppose it's always fun. However, I felt Melted Pot has a better selection of fondue and dipping tidbits to immerse. 
However, maybe it's the jazz you really go for. And the jazz was nice, and the atmosphere was hip. Our server was quite attentive and helpful. We never had a problem in this area. The corkage fee for our bottles of wine was $15 and this was told to us when we made the reservations, which I appreciate. The cocktails were good. They had a variety of fun and creative cocktails to try. 

The Spanish Manchega fondue was excellent and you can request how spicy you want it. The meat fondue only  had a broth to dip in. Unilke Melting Pot where you  have a choice of broths or even oil to fry things up. The desert fondue seemed to be lacking in the dippy treats. Where's poundcake?  Marshmallows?  Brownies? graham crackers? Just fruit and rice crispy squares. And the twix bars peices were chocolate overkill. Yea, I know, is that possible?  Yes.  The fondues were about 22-$25 bucks. 

What we were NOT informed when we made reservations is that a $5 entertainment fee for each person is added to the bill. ??  We came long before the band even started. But okay.  

All in all, it IS a really nice place to take a date or hang out with a few friends. But I would recommend eating your meal elsewhere and just having a cheese snack there or a dessert fondue.
omg the chickpea fritters are amazing and the fries are insane!! very reasonable prices, nice people working there, incredible food...pretty much covers it for me!!

If you're in the mood to feel like a republican and grouse about your marginal tax rate then go to the Heights Cafe, where the food is rich and so are the customers; there's a real country club feel.  Although it is not a steakhouse, there is an emphasis on red meat with 4 printed menu choices (the tederloin, the signature steak, the rib eye and the short rib) and a quotidian special (last friday was veal).  Then again there's lots of fish - same deal as the beef with 4 printed choices (halibut, salmon, sea bass and a fish of the day) and a daily special (yes, in addition to the fish of the day).  What I'm trying to say is this:  lots of choices.  Because in addition to all this red meat and fish The Heights offers pork chops, laquered duck, rack of lamb, a vegetarian napoleon, even pizzas.  And the wine list includes well over 100 choices, $45 and up per bottle (up to an eye popping $250 for a meritage). 

So how is it?  The place is expensive by Ithaca's standards - about $35 per entree, which includes a prosaic salad (either caesar or greens).  The rest of my dinner, however, was superb.  I ordered the beef short ribs which played lead to a supporting cast of bacon, potato gnocchi and broccoli rabe.  Wow!  The ribs were cut in the flanken style and wonderful.  But the bacon stole the show.  It was not what I expected, but instead a thick slab of pork fat woven through with generous threads of what we (or at least I) think of as bacon.  In fact this bacon was like bacon in reverse.  Instead of a predominance of cured crispy pork belly with a trim of white fat this was a predominance of white fat with an interior trim of cured crispy pork belly.  But whatever (and how is pork belly not fat I can hear some of you say); it was delicious.  I can't believe I ate the whole thing.  So the food at least was five-star.

Less impressive was the flatware (boring and lacking heft), the glassware (a bit dusty) and the service (what? you can't memorize the specials).  Dessert, back to the actual food, was good (though not thrilling) as we split an appley bread pudding with a scoop of ordinary iced cream.  Although we were sharing we were each given our own plate, which was thoughtful, although somehow not as much as fun.  I also had espresso (well done) and drambuie (not so much), served as it was in a glass both ridiculous and impractical (how about a snifter?).

The excellence of the entree, however, made this an experience worth the price, which is saying quite a lot (at least here in our little town).

Love the way they design the restaurant and the plate color.
Fast and fresh, oh, and reasonable price.

There is NO PLACE like Thomas Sweet, and believe me, I've looked.

When I first came to the West Coast for graduate school, I lamented the fact that there was no place to get a blend in.  My housemates asked me what a blend-in was, and they suggested I visit Cold Stone.  Boy, was I disappointed.  It's a place where an employee with two spoons flattens the ice cream and adds in ingredients, usually candy or cookie bits.  THAT'S NOT EVEN CLOSE!

Nothing but a blend-in has the consistency and temperature of a blend-in.  Nothing else is worth standing in long lines on a hot, humid East Coast day.

I wish Thomas Sweet would expand to other parts of the country.  I think it could be successful.  I know they tried it in College Station, TX, around 1990, but the shop was not around the main drag, so I don't think word got around.

It was a bit unappetizing to see the cold pizzas in front of you as you're deciding.  However, it is cheap ($3-4+tax) for a huge slice of stuffed pizza, easily enough for ANYONE's lunch break.  Any more cheesey goodness and I would bet on an instant food coma.

Tried the veggie and the chicken cordon bleu.  Veggie definitely used frozen broccoli pieces, and was fairly plain.  The accompanying marinara made it better though.  The cordon bleu was really good, I'd definitely get it again if I went back; but the question is, will I be back?

I'm so glad I found Dr. Choy through Yelp. She got to the bottom of a persistent occasional allergy that had been bothering me for *years*.  She is whip-smart, thorough, and genuinely cares -- a real gem!
The best "four star" level restaurant in Cambridge.
I found Northview AutoSpa on Yelp and was super impressed! They were quick, inexpensive and professional. I highly recommend!

Perfect pre-dinner snack after a day at the beach.  I thought the chowder was good, but I've been to Boston and you really can't hold a candle to that.  A little too rich and creamy for me, I actually enjoyed mopping up the chowder with the $2 toasted and buttered sourdough loaf.

Skip the fish and chips, the fish is not very tasty and not the standard flaky flour coating I am used to on my fish.  I enjoyed the chili cheese fries, nice marriage of cheddar, chili and curly unseasoned fries.  

Don't be deterred by the line that wraps around the building, they get you in and out quick.
Great place to go for hot links. They are so spicy and the buns compliment them so well. Never a disappointment. I love the entertaining stuff on the walls, and the employees are kind. :)

Track was pretty busy around 9-10ish.  I prefer the track at USC better but this place isn't bad.  I got lost and a nice crosswalk-sign-holder-helper person directed me to the underground parking structure which I could park my scooter for free (big plus).

I love the seating/stairs - it's very epic, you almost feel like a gladiator.  

The track is somewhat cluttered, I'm a minimalist and can get easily distracted but it's all good.  Definitely a good place to run when you're getting bored with your typical routes.
best breakfast burritos! not sure about anything else on the menu though.

ORDER THEIR KIMCHI FRIED NOODLE WITH PORK! TRUST ME. If you don't like it, I'll buy you lunch somewhere else.

Berkeley has a very limited selection of Korean restaurants and please, STEVE'S KOREAN BBQ IS NOT KOREAN FOOD! Of all the dishes I've tried at Bear's, Steve, T-toust, and Koryo, Bear's has the best Korean dish. So save your time, money, and disappointment and go to Bear's Ramen House for their Kimchi Fried Noodle.

Good Food, Good Friends, ENJOY!
Good call on the peacocks.. Also they have Keith Harings last sculpture inside as well.. I love all the Chapels from around the world.. Really pretty inside and out..

My fav liquor store.  Hands down.  

It's super close to where I live, super clean, and cheaper if you use cash.

We went for lunch on Saturday and all had "the recession special".  It was awesome.  Waitstaff was a big slow and not overly friendly, but I was there with a couple friends and we weren't in a big hurry.  It wasn't so slow we got antsy, our water glasses just weren't attended to regularly.  Super delicious food, though.
Best Burger I have EVER had in a restaurant, EVER! Cooked to perfection. I like my burgers plain so it wasn't dressed up with any flavors other than the grill. I will definitely be back.

Food's pretty good, the coffee decent (however, a bit overpriced).  My main complaint is the upstairs area which feels like you're in a back alley of North Philadelphia.  The place is not super clean but the crowd is always interesting...if you can score one of the three tables in the front winidow you can just enjoy the world passing by and people watch to your heart's content.

If I had written this review after the first five times I've eaten there or ordered takeout, I would've given it 3 or 4 stars. However, the more I go to this restaurant, the more I'm convinced that the service is SO terrible that it's not worth it.
The price doesn't help it either. I usually order a pad thai, maybe some calamari, fried dumplings and fried rice. The food is pretty excellent but the prices are...Thayer St. prices. Essentially, everything costs about 30% more than you'd like to pay.
The service is really slow and while I've never been treated rudely, all the waitstaff seem devastatingly incompetent. How are they not able to get things rolling? They ruin the atmosphere because you get ushered into seats, perhaps ensuring you're a paying customer and then you wait forever for water, wait forever for your order to be taken and then forever for your food to arrive. If you're not hungry or in a rush and you have all day to wait around for these incompetents, it's an okay restaurant--the food is pretty decent. But look elsewhere if you're a busy person with classes, jobs, and responsibilities with deadlines.
Great location!

Was wed in the court yard and was very pleased with the the setting.  I was not impressed with the room and as others have mentioned charges for everything.  Paid less than half for much more impressive rooms in other large cities including Las Vegas during peak tourist time.  I also made the mistake of leaving my phone in the hotel bar and the staff seemed very unconcerned.  My wife finally found someone to help her look one last time as we were leaving but no luck.  Yet in the time it was lost to the following afternoon it was "found" and calls were made to local numbers in San Diego.  Never know if it was a staff member or what but the only other patrons in the bar were from a PALM conference going on, don't think they'd be making local calls or interested in stealing a phone.  Overall, I won't be returning to this hotel.  I guess any anniversary trips we'll be staying at another property.

Cookies, ice cream .  .  . ya want some cookie ice cream combo, eh?

My friend, Earl Barrington turned me onto this place and now the stuff has gone South to my hips and butt!  but, dude-how could I resist such sinful temptations when it's right there?

The cookie and ice cream prices went up a notch, but still, the line is out the door!  Ya gotta check out my pic!  I am not exaggerating either!
i had this absolutely disgusting chicken curry soup that had meat that looked like it was dog meat or something.  Absolutely disgusting!

If you don't like the Harvard Book Store, you must not like books.

This place is one of my fav places to find books, including used books. I've been able to walk away with mint condition books from the remainders/used section at half the original price and they don't just stick books there that no one likes. So make sure you go downstairs when you visit! 

Their staff is also uber helpful. This place has the knowledge, product  and customer service that you hope for in large chains, but never manage to get at large chain bookstores.

Decent pricing for large amount of food. 20% for Cal students and staff. Got a hot entree combo with chow mein and 2 dishes: orange chicken and broccoli beef. Sadly their hot food feels cold. No flavor in chow mein so you would have to borrow your dishes to add flavor. The orange chicken had more flour than chicken, I don't recall biting into a piece of chicken larger than my pinky. Broccoli was undercooked and too salty. Beef was overbooked, some were burnt. I must say that this is one of the few times where I have to throw my food away.
Makes you appreciate Nexus Cafe much more.

I went in for my first bikini wax ever. Yoww! It was fairly painful, but I survived. Kate was my aesthetician and she was really nice and helped me through it. Down there's still a little red and sore, but it hasn't been 12 hours since I got it waxed.

I got a same day appointment, so that was definitely a plus.

It was an expensive endeavor, however; the prices are listed on their website. As a student without a job I can't afford to do this on a monthly basis, with $60 + tip and all.

Update: I'm getting stubble in some parts just two days after. I'm very dissatisfied. I'm blonde, so my hair is thinner; perhaps that was a problem. However, I called the spa and the manager was very gracious. She offered to have me come in to be "cleaned up," a complimentary wax next time I come in, or to refund this service. Because I'm busy,and I don't know if or when I'll want another wax, I chose the refund. It seems the parts where hard wax was used, the hair was completely removed. If I go back, the manager said she's put in my file that I like the hard wax. I'm glad she was so understanding and helpful.

Hey Asians, how come you've managed to integrate so well into a Caucasian-dominated society but yet you still keep all your best foods segregated away in their own stores and supermarkets? Is this some sort of statement or a failure of large US supermarkets to notice a gap in the market, or is it some gang-controlled import/export thing?

Who knows? Who cares? Well I care! As awkward little me never feels very comfortable in some places like Lotte Market. The choices are bewildering and little help is on offer. I just want some Kim-chi.. oh, there is a bazillion types. I just want some Ma Po sauce.. oh there isn't any. I just want some good Japanese rice.. oh I have to buy a 20 kilo bag. I just want to browse around and come up with ideas.. oh I've tripped over some awkward pile of pots and electrical fans.

I think I like Super 88 a lot more. But maybe one day in the bright future, all the best things will be available in TJs, Shaws and Whole Foods too. I have a dream....

Cheese n' Stuff is a legendary sandwich shop in the middle of one of a weird subterranean mini-mall near the Berkeley campus.  If you have a break between classes or need to grab lunch on the way to a football game, this place is great.  The sandwiches are cheap and very reliable - the prices go up about 25 cents every three years or so.   I switched to the deluxe sandwich recently, and I feel that the sprouts and tomato are well worth the extra 30 cents to upgrade the standard version.  Plus, the counter staff will respect your healthier, high-class ways.

Roast-beef-and-swiss on a seeded roll is my personal favorite, and while it's a close contest, I have to say I prefer the Stuff to the Cheese. Signs forbid kissing, spitting, Stanfurd fans, and knife-chasing inside the shop, so be warned.

Party in my mouth (that's what she said!).

No, but seriously. Though they don't really have much along the lines of toppings, the yogurt here is deliiiiicioussssss.

I LOVE the press! I drive all the way from Garden Grove!! 

They almost always have a good or interesting musical performance of some sort. 

The fries for the boys are COVERED in garlic. I LOVE it. 

The food is always tasty! 

And the BAR... This place makes my favorite dirty martini so far. I've had more than a few and this one is the best, by far. Five stars for the martini alone, seriously.

Pretty decent pizza slices with some interesting toppings like pasta. They certainly don't skimp on the toppings either. It's also a welcome change from the ubiquitous thin-slice pies all over the city. I can't really recommend anything other than the pizza slices here however. Actually the milkshakes are pretty decent and cheaper than most places. Like nearly everyone else here has said though, the only reason most people come here is because there aren't a lot of alternatives in the area.

Been there once so far and it felt like an adventure.  Get to rummage through a huge pile of used clothing. Sure you  Get that grimy thrift store film on your hands, but hey, it's 1.50/pound, you can make it work for that....found a great guiness t there that i was able to cut up and make it more my style and, cowboy boots, which i thought i would never buy, but these were awesome, and for $28, eh, why not?

Almost 10 years after graduating, i still make it to buck fifty. it's not a buck fifty anymore, but its still good. And they give more meat than they used to. The combo choice of coke and seasoned fries are cool. Its still pretty cheap and with the additional meat, you cant beat it. I still havent had anything but the pastrami. This place still beats subway 2 for 1 deals with the student shopper.

I wasn't too impressed. My sandwich was dry and not that tasty. However, I may have just been going through a rough patch in my life since everyone on yelp seems to love this joint. The waitstaff was friendly, but I did feel a little rushed. I don't know; it wasn't great.

Dad had a dr's appt. this am. On his way home he stopped and bought 2 doughnuts. He bought the A-town cream and the smores doughnut. 
He said the A-town was pretty good.

I loved the smores doughnut. the marshmellow in the middle was very soft. OMG. I'd eat like 5 if i could....

This place is great!  And the herds of people waiting to get a table on a weekend evening proves its appeal.  The prices are great, the atmosphere is fun and the food is delicious.  I'll do a better job of remembering the names of the dishes in the future, but for now I'll just describe the foods my friends and I ordered.

Everything was from the regular tapas menu.

Artichoke: Amazing.  5 stars.
Chicken Croquette: pretty tasty.  4 stars.
Seafood Croquette: I enjoyed this more than the chicken croquettes.  5 stars.
Calamari: texture was tender and crispy, the aioli was a great compliment.  4 stars. 
Cheese and strawberry dessert: This is what I'll be coming back for!  5 STARS ++!

Wonderful place!  Give it a go!

So my girlfriend and I wanted to go to lunch and she was craving for a pazookie so we went to Bj's. When I got there it wasn't too crowded we got seated right away. We decided to order the make your own pizza with four or more toppings since it was the same price as one of their specialty pizza, and we also ordered a Clam Chowder Bowl. The pizza that the waiter brought out took quite a while to make and when they brought it out it had the wrong topping!! The put pepperoni on the pizza rather then pineapple, I don't know how you can mix up those two toppings but o well. when we told the waiter he just brought us a small bowl of cooked canned pineapples which did not taste good at all. Besides that the clam chowder was delicious and of course the pazooki was amazing.

"Go to Dog and Duck/Go to Dog and Duck/Go to Dog and Duck/Pub..."

More than just your standard college pub.

First of all-the beer is cold.  This is not only important, but a big MUST have.  Trust me when I say warm beer is not a cool trend to be starting in Austin (ahem...not naming names here). 

Second of all-the location is prime.  Far enough away from BOTH downtown and UT to get an eclectic mix of students, old frat dudes, professors and car club members.  Dog and Duck also has a fun and free Sunday evening Trivia contest with $6 pitchers of Lone Star.

Thirdly-the food is pretty decent.  I can't say they have the best fish and chips EVER.  It's tasty and fresh, but hit or miss in terms of being amazing or just 'good.'  

Overall, this is a pub that I frequent once or so a week.  The low key vibe coupled with a full food menu and a nice staff and inviting seating areas make the Dog and Duck pretty alright with me.

I just tried it tonight after the speaker from "How do you roll?" gave a talk on my MKT class.  I have to say that the sushi is pretty fresh and tasty, but the place is not sanitary enough.  
There was a spider crawling on the chopping board right after they packed my sushi.  Had it happen before they packed it, I would just leave right away.  Good thing is they got rid of it right way.  
one more thing, they left the rice cooker open on the floor, and a male worker just walked right pass it with a broom which was hanging right over the rice cooker (can't see if there was still rice in there); and he was sweeping the floor right next to the cooker.    

I think they need to train their employees better and provide a sanitary environment.   Anyway, I will give them one more try.

After years of having to drive to Pasadena for an indie film in a theatre, Laemmle's finally made its way east to Claremont and they picked the perfect place for it, i.e. The Packing House.  This is a new theatre with two large and three small theatres.  There is plenty of free parking though the some of the surrounding shops are still under construction.

I've been to Gus's three times.

1. A few people from my office decided to eat inside: a small counter, a few wobbly tables. The most striking thing was the horizontal lard and fat stalactites adhering to the exhaust fan. My clothes had to be washed that night to get rid of the diner's odor. Hot dogs were pretty good, though.

2. Feeling masochistic, my office again chose to eat at Gus's. Having learned our lesson, we decided to eat outside at one of the picnic tables. While waiting in the long line to place our order, one of Gus's hulking line cooks had a stroke. He was carried out by two of the others and seated on a bench. The two line cooks ran back inside, and we watched the guy's face droop further as customers unperturbedly placed their orders. A Watervliet firetruck and ambulance arrived, loaded the poor man into the ambulance and drove away.

Again, the hot dogs were pretty good.

3. I didn't feel like cooking one night, and managed to persuade Roxanne and Lukas that the best thing in the world to do was hit three mini-hot dog joints in one night. We went to Famous Lunch in Troy, Hot Dog Charlie's near Cohoes, and lastly, Gus's. Rox asked for sauerkraut on her dog. The order-taker snarled, "we don't do sauerkraut," with the surliness a French waiter would have if you'd ordered a hot dog at a good restaurant. Yet again, the hot dogs were pretty good.

This place is a little short on atmosphere, but long on tasty, tasty treats.

I had a veggie burger from here once.  

I have also had the tres leches, the bread pudding, the cookies, and the brownies numerous times, usually while drinking coffee on the patio with friends who shared my need to bemoan the fact that there was nothing decent to do near campus and we were tired of driving non-car-owning classmates around.

Expect lots of Rice students on dates, West U families, and a few other large groups.  Don't be fooled by the long dinner menu - just come for dessert.  (It's not world class by any means, but it is consistently able to fill the I-want-dessert-and-coffee needs of many savvy West U area diners).

Their bubble tea kicks ass! Don't get too adventurous with the food, as I heard it can be hit or miss. I just go in for the tasty tea and smoothies with pearls, but that alone is 5 stars.

I've had almost all of them, but what really stands out are the strawberry & banana, and the melon smoothies with pearls!

The drinks come with a giant pearl-width straw and cups that are sometimes very "kawaii." Very reminiscent of Taiwanese flair and pop-culture.

TO ALL 1 STAR READERS LISTEN UP:

The review goes like this.... My gf and I went to Melba's to use our Groupon $40 discount (thank god we didn't pay full price!).  The first go around, we didn't make reservations despite trying to call to make one... they, however, don't answer there phone after 6pm.  So on the first go around, we didn't get a table because the restaurant was PACKED... a good sign we thought, so we decided to come back for another try a week later... boy were we wrong!

Strike 1 On the second go around, despite making reservations for 7:15pm, we weren't seated until 7:30pm despite being early and arriving at 7pm... 

Strike 2 goes to the amount of time it took to even get served a drink and take our order (15 +15 more mins! = 30 mins of nothing but seating so far)

Strike 3 went to cooking time.  I had the most expensive plate on the menu (The Sea Bass for $23) and she had their "infamous" chicken and waffles.... (Caution... dark meat takes 5 mins more?)... took 40 mins to get my puny dish, and another 10 mins for my date to get her's... we've now been here for over a hour, and they didn't even ask if we wanted more wine on the 2nd go around... and what's up with serving in 2 tranches? FOOD SHOULD COME TOGETHER PEOPLE!

Strike 4 is THE FOOD:  Thinking the most expensive thing on the dish would be half good (THE SEA BASS) but nooo... it was tiny (compared to the people around me who ordered the sword fish, and other plates... mine had to be the smallest there... which prompted this review). It also was sub par... only warm not hot especially for the time we waited.  It also tasted like something I cooked at a university rez out of the frozen super market... DISAPPOINTED!

Her chicken and waffles were tasty I have to admit but SMALL! Seems like a soul food place with a minimalist dish... not impressed. I'd say go to KFC and save the extra money and time!

Strike 5 came in getting any service at all for the bill or clean up... with such a long wait line you'd think they'd be in a rush to seat as many as possible but noooo they take there time here too!

So all in all, if you can afford to waste 3 hrs waiting for 'OK' chicken and waffles (steer clear of all else) then MAYBE it's worth a look... but would I go back again?

NO~!

Simply amazing! What a great idea to make a sandwich from cookies and ice cream. And so cheap?? This place has to be the best ever!

One sandwich was $1.50 and it filled me up big time. Buying cookies and brownies are really cheap, I wish I bought them! For me, my sandwich was with a Chocolate Chip and an Oatmeal Raisin cookie with Cookies N' Cream ice cream. End result: HEAVEN! The cookies were really rich and delicious, and the ice cream added so much flavor as well. Such a cheap ice cream sandwich, and everything tastes so great, wow I wish there were more places like this in San Diego. This place is also right next to UCLA, lucky college students!! Parking can get tense, and there are parking lots everywhere, it's just some might be expensive. Luckily, my girlfriend and I found one for only $5 for as much time as we want! It was kind of shady because we just had to give them our keys and that's it because they stacked cars right behind and beside each other, but everything went smoothly. 

If I ever come up again, I am definitely coming back here. Excellent dessert, excellent pricing, just plain excellent.

Horrible, horrible bank.  Dishonest and unfriendly to their customers. Actually had a teller inform me that they purposely process debit transactions before deposits - any sort of deposits - so that they account may get overdrawn and cause overdraft fees.  Leaving them after 10 years because it has gotten so bad.  Had plenty of money in my checking account and even my own account online shows I was fine but they still charged be $200 in overdraft fees.  Spent 40 minutes on the phone with customer service and they just gave me the run around.  They deserve to go down in a ball of flames along with the rest of lying, cheating banks out there.

I don't understand what the hype is about.  One visit and I wanted to burn this place down I was so disappointed.  Pizza Napoletana is one of my favorite things to eat, and this place was supposed to be the best in town.  Our pie was still raw in the middle, and service was so scarce/rude that there was nothing we could do about it.  Gross.

Data point: 162 reviews, nearly all 4 or 5 stars.
Observation: Kudos well deserved.
Two words: Tasting Menu.  (*)
Of course: informed, professional servers, friendly staff, amazing cocktails.
Niggles hardly worth mentioning: reservation honored 30 minutes late, cocktail took a while to materialize from the bar.
On balance: what are you waiting for?

(*) The full tasting menu on the night of my visit:
1. Three Seafood Preparations (foie de lotte, dijon-miso vinaigrette; squid noodles, nuoc cham; rillettes of yellowfin tuna, paddlefish caviar).

2.  Salad of Hiramasu Sashimi, red onion-shiso salad, avacado, harissa-rose vinaigrette.

3.  Grilled Spanish Gray Mullet, cardoon puree, spicy yuzo kosho, crispy ginger salad.  

4.  House made farro sacchetti pasta, ragout of pork heart sausage, sea urchin and morel mushrooms, nocellara olive oil.

5.  Grilled Vermont organic pork belly, walnut miso puree, crispy garlic and shallots, burnt caramel vinaigrette.

6.  Elysian Fields lamb three ways: roasted loin, lamb heart sausage, braised belly.

7.  Tea infused panna cottas (Jasmine, toasted rice syrup and rooibos, candied citrus zest.

8.  Gingerbread pain perdu, pineapple puree, young ginger ice cream, poached cranberries.

9.  Peanut butter parfait, house made hobnob cookie, banana foam, cocoa nibs.

I wanted to like Chipotle - I really did. I work on Southside and am always excited when a new place opens up - food or otherwise. I had many of the same issues that others complain about namely that they cannot wrap a burrito! I had the burrito do-over that Warren G. describes and I also had an exciting 2 tortilla burrito that was constructed by half wrapping in one flour tortilla and then, when there was no more tortilla geography left, finishing the wrap in a second flour tortilla. I should have been grateful for that free tortilla because they sure do charge for everything else! Try walking out for less then $8 - for mexican food!

I'm torn about Podge's. On the one hand, their smoothies are made of real fruit, not mysterious pre-made pastes like the Jamba Juice around the corner. They're also very, uh, juice-like - you can actually drink these smoothies. On the other hand, Podge's service can be really terrible sometimes -- I've had literally 20 minutes go by between ordering and getting my juice with nobody else around because the person behind the counter was being as slow as humanly possible.

If you're not in the mood for juice, their sandwiches aren't bad. Not the best in the world, but pretty good for Claremont.

Was sooo looking forward to trying this place! Slow service, disinterested staff, talking to each other while we were trying to order, so busy talking totally messed up our order. Sraight from the can veggie's, no seasoning. Will never go back & tell everyone I know about the experience.

I am very sad to hear that Cerality is closed.  Yes, I realize that this place isn't that spectacular since all the stuff here you could basically do on your own if you really wanted to.  But, being on/near a college campus, I think it's a great idea.  

I've gone here about 2-3 times over the past 4 years and I had a good experience each time.  It's definitely overpriced, but, the experience was there (at least for me).  Rest in peace Cereality - Philadelphia, PA, you will be missed.

Went to JP's Java when visiting my kids in Austin.   The coffee?  Great.  Really good.  The atmosphere?  We could find NO table to sit at to enjoy our brew.  It looked like a field of cows and their cowbirds...  one person to each table, each with their laptops open and each table with 3 to 5 chairs empty.  No conversation in the place, just dead.  Really a depressing atmosphere.  There has to be some way to improve this...  maybe do more 2 person tables?  Or require folks to double up or something?  Or would that simply mean more cows... and so more birds. As for us, we'll have to find another place for our business.

The sesame chicken and general tso's chicken are horrible dishes (small pieces of chicken, not great sauce, soggy).  I have had a few other dishes that are just okay.  Chinese food in this area is really lacking.

NOTE: I have never consumed a treat prepared by Tiff. I have hovered over the box and looked lovingly at the cookies for an inappropriate length of time - just long enough to creep out my co-workers - but I have not partaken. Damn you, diabetes!

That said, Tiff's Treats are awesome for office functions or client meetings. We tend to forget about meetings and then at the last minute we need some food to offer and Tiff's has saved our collective booties on more than one occasion. The cookies are well-loved by co-workers and are especially delicious after ten seconds in the microwave.

Plus who doesn't love cookies?!?!

Defintely, not your average pizza slice joint. Whenever I'm in Berkeley, I always gotta pick up a slice of the FAT COMBO. How can all those toppings lay comfortably on top of the crispy crust without breaking it. The FAT COMBO Slice is literally almost a pound. Super cheesy and hits the spot everytime. 

Happy Grubbing!

I loooooooooooove me some Border.  For any occasion my first thought would be "It's a good time to eat at Border!".

The food & drinks are delicious, fast and cheap. The are able to sit large parties comfortably and the staff is always on top of everything and friendly.

The taco salad is what I always go for. It is what every taco salad should be. Don't get me started on the chip bowl it comes it. You could just eat that as a meal.

The chips and salsa always come out warm and fresh. They are so yummy that I always fill up on them before my food even arrives. 

The only thing holding me back from 5 stars is that fact they don't do reservations and they don't seat (usually) until you whole party has arrived. I understand why this is but it still kind of sucks. 

Good thing Border is worth the wait because on a Friday or Sat night you WILL be waiting.

I'm really sorry that all of the other reviewers have had bad experiences here.  My doctor is kind, communicative, responsive, and reasonable.  All of my doctor's visits here have been fast and easy- I usually spend about 10-15 minutes waiting TOTAL.  The staff is nice and I've also never had any issues reaching anyone over the phone or getting called back.  Perhaps they have made a ton of improvements in the past year.

This review is for the prepared food section.

I am a Whole Foods fan, and I usually adore their prepared food section. Today, during a study break, I decided to go and see what they had to offer today.  I was craving something good and healthy, so where else would I go?

I waited for twenty minutes before someone would help me.  Not because of long lines, not because there were a lot of people.

Nope.  One of two chefs wanted to flirt with a blonde girl that came way after me.  So I had to wait twenty minutes.  His back was turned, and the girl's boyfriend was right there, too -- probably hoping to score some free food or something.

I seriously had to wait twenty minutes to even ask for a sample, let alone get my food.  In the end, the guy in the burrito section took pity on me and came over, even while someone else was ordering.  Thank you, kind chef.  I get to eat my meal now.   An hour later than I had anticipated.

A trip to Whole Foods' prepared food section should not take an hour when I literally live down the street.

I would've given this a 1-star review, except that kind chef and the awesome food I'm eating right now (Spinach Empanada, Spicy Udon, and Pasta Marinara!) helped me give them a 2 instead. 

Oh, and their breakfast is amazing.  2.5 ... so 3.  I love Whole Foods too much to give it too low of a rating.

Stefani's House of Pizza is a pretty small place but it delivers and does take-out which I strongly suggest. There's always parking near it expect during peak lunch hours and they have some great subs and a wide variety of drinks available. Their pizzas are pretty good as well. The staff is friendly and the portions are generous considering their prices.

I usually get the vegeteriana pizza which is pretty good and simple although I enjoy their cheeseburger subs as well. They are opened every day and it's cheap.

The clothes there are actually pretty good. I've definitely had some really good finds there. HOWEVER, the indie-divas that work there need a serious attitude adjustment. Once an employee gave my packpack to some crazy who stole it & didn't even apologize, offer assistance, or seem to care at all. Everyone who works there is rude. Pretty expensive too.

The Fox is a perfect place to start a date... it's grand and theatrical, romantic and retro. Plus they serve beer. (SWEET.) Can't believe I waited this long to go to the fabulous Fox. We parked about 3 blocks away for $5, which is not too bad, and paid $8 for tickets to see "2001: A Space Odyssey." Attire for the movie crowd is pretty darn casual, which feels unnatural when you shuffle inside the fancy lobby in your dingy sneakers. I will definitely be going back for some fancier action chez Fox.

What's the one common theme we all talk about when reviewing a restaurant? It's usually consistency. I can definitely say that they consistently impress me with their food, service, and drinks.

Always. Without a question.

Sometimes it's busy and I'm not helped immediately. Those moments are few and far between. The servers, bartenders, and barbacks are on it.

Oh, and the kitchen is awesome! I'll be lame and say that my favorite thing to order are fries. The chili is a close second. Tonight Alexa G. recommended I try the chicken picatta with grilled chicken. Fantastic choice and the arugula mixed with caper vinaigrette was amazeballs.

I have been seeing her for years for all my medical dermatology needs.   She has helped me with every issue and impressed me with her knowledge.  I like that I can just call her about expired  prescriptions and she has called new ones in for me, without me having to go to see her.  She is very professional and nice in a no nonsense kind of way.  Her office at Palo Alto Medical Foundation is run the same as other offices at that facility. I have always been able to get an appointment fast and never had to wait for more than five minutes.

I love this place! They have a good selection of popular books and will order anything you request. They also carry Spanish-language books for the readers En SAP. You can get your Columbia para here... and some cute little trinkets, they also have really nice giftbags, cute mugs, Burt's Bee's products, Jelly Bellies and Ice Cream. And the manager is the GREATEST LADY IN THE WORLD! 

The security guard is also very knowledgeable about politics, he doesn't speak much English but the man knows what he's talking about.

Stayed in one of the King Suites with the Jacuzzi.  It was completely awesome.  Loved the stay.  The room was nice and big, cozy, very clean and just romantic with the fireplace.  It makes for a great get-a-way weekend.  You can head down the road a bit to this street fair they have, its fun.  I completely recommend this place.

I've been coming here for a while and think that the yogurt is very good. It's always been on the pricey side, but they recently SHRUNK their sizes. So, the last time I visited, I found that I paid the same amount for a significantly smaller portion. That was the last time I visited!

After I sat down on the patio, for lunch, my friend and I became the object of affection for a couple of flies. It proved to be a dangerous omen, indeed.

This place is awful. I came here for lunch, which is really, really easy to do. I mean, really easy. You have to try really hard to fuck up lunch. Sandwiches. C'mon.

I got a Cajun Chicken sandwich, I think I added cheese and bacon. Not sure what he got. Fries. Nothing impressive. Still tasted like Sysco packaging. They were Burger King style fries, which I have never been a fan of. The chicken tasted like it was boiled or par cooked then microwaved or something. Oh, and the food took forever. His was bad, and we didn't finish, despite still being hungry. It was on par with food from the DC on campus in terms of quality.

Now, the menu looks like this place should be great, but I think it's all done to be cheap and profitable and look nice so people bring their parents to eat here. Faux fine dining. Worse than Friendly's. Honestly. That Mahi Mahi has to be frozen. I guarantee it. Maybe it's like a nightclub/Red Lobster hybrid. I don't know. I don't understand.

As for the nightclub? Well, if you are looking to roofie / get roofied, I don't think you could pick a better spot than the basement of a frat (which, if nothing else, would be much cheaper). I just imagine people bumping lines in the bathroom, but maybe that's a good thing. They get away with running a shoddy place because they have a prime spot make plenty of money and people just wanna grind. Straight up. They let in underage girls (this is a fact). I feel bad for the people standing in line outside that place; they just don't know any better. As such, it's a LOCAL HOTSPOT. I just hope the drinks are boozy.

Hermann Park may be one of the best green spaces I have been to. The running trail is nice with some gorgeous panoramas of the med center, hotel zaza and the monuments visible for most of your run. The park is adorned by beautiful tall pines and it's a part of Houston that actually has some topographical variation (even though it's man made). 

Overall Hermann is a great place for a jog, walk or just to throw down a blanket and relax.
Apple cinnamon was amazing; #1 favorite. The french apple log is another & The jelly filled donut holes. Its a tasty place to have donuts. If you're ever in the area

Pool is great and is the reason I go.

Lockeroom (men's) often filthy, usually smells of BO, should be cleaned much more often.

There's was a dearth of servers here on a Saturday during Homecoming at the local university. Not sure how that happened, but they were a bit slower than normal because of it, but at least they noticed us.

Food here isn't anything remarkable, but the TBM and wasabi roast beef sandwiches are usually acceptable. Chai Tea Latte is decent, although the House Coffee has no refills.

I came in with some friends the other night and right away one of my them noticed a huge sign with a chinese symbol. Maybe this is chinese-owning? MAYBE i dont know but anyways this place is quite small and the servers are very attentive and polite. 

We decided to order something other than regular sushi rolls; so we ordered the sashimi boat, sushi super deluxe plate, chirashi and tempura (comes with miso and one bowl of rice) and green baked mussels. 

The mussels were $5, but only came in a plate of three. They were decent compared to other sushi places and definitely not worth it.  

The Sashimi Boat was around $32? This has to be the FRESHEST sashimi I have tasted in a japanese restaurant, particularly the Blue Fin. I can taste the natural sweetness of the fish (not a funky odor) and it melted in my mouth. I think there were 9 different types of fish, 3 pieces each. It included, from what i remember: blue fin, yellowtail, tuna, mackerel, salmon, ..... This dish was definitely high quality in terms of freshness and taste, but I would not order it again. It's more like a one-time-trying-experience.

Chirashi and Tempura - $17: Mediocre veggie and shrimp tempura as well as mediocre sashimi. When comparing the sashimi from this plate to the sashimi from the boat, there was a noticeable difference in the color, texture and taste of the two. The ones from the bowl were more vibrant in color, firm and easier to chew. I kinda wish i didn't order this one, but the rice and tempura did keep us full, i guess.

The Sushi Super plate was around 20 something? There was around 14 kinds of sushi, including uni, salmon roe, shrimp, tuna, salmon, eel, yellowtail, calamari,  and some other kinds of sushi i did not recognize. Very fresh. 

Well this is what i got out of my experience at Matsuri, I will be coming back to try some sushi rolls, instead of mainly sashimi. Total not including tips was arounf $87. Great quality, a little overpriced.

If it were humanly possible I would shove every single one of their cupcakes in my mouth in one bite. These cupcakes outshine their competitor Crave for 3 reasons: size, moistness, and presentation

Flavors tried: Fleur de Sel
                         Coconut
                         Vanilla Bean with Chocolate

Their chocolate cake/batter is the best I have ever had in any form--cake or cupcake. The Fleur de Sel is a must try--chocolate cupcake with a surprise caramel filling and chocolate ganache with sea salt sprinkled on top, however I must warn you to have a glass of milk handy with you. The only downside is that the cupcakes don't hold up very well the next day. These cupcakes are definitely worth a pretty penny!

Great sandwhiches, cooked to order, big variety and decent service.
It's not expensive, but not cheap either. A step up from ToGo's and Subway like places.

Lido serves up some great Italian fare in Harlem.  Much improved from the previous venue.  

The bar is now on the other side with a much improved seating area and fully stocked for making any type of potion.  Bartender was friendly and serves up a variety of interesting cocktails.  I ordered the El Tigre - Bourbon with a citrus mix.  Very tasty.  

Entrees hit the mark.  Fusilli pasta with sweet Italian sausage was the perfect meal for a rainy Sunday night.  

Service was friendly.  Waiter was quite knowledgable on the menu. It did take awhile for the second course to arrive.  Hopefully this improves the next time we go.
margarita tasted like it was made with crystal light mix and the cheapest tequila money can buy.  it covers up the taste of the food though...which is pretty tasteless.  service is good though!
Good authentic Italian food.  Good atmosphere.

I've been here so many times, the owner is now a friend. They are the sweetest people you can talk to, and if you've missed communicating in Hindi this is the place to be. Seriously, no degree of English adjectives expresses the level of spiciness compared to, "ekdam mazedaar" in Hindi.

They always bring out a complimentary "Kheer" for me and my friends every time we're there!

I think JP's interior is pretty nice for studying, it's spacious, most of it is well lit(not the back room), and there are outlets here and there. Barrista's are all quite nice.

However some things are suspect, every single time I go here there are multiple flies buzzing around, it's really dusty in some areas, and the beverages and food aren't exactly great. I usually have to opt for a mexican coke because I can't stand their iced tea or coffee, and that's a shame when I'm at a cafe. JP's is nice because of it's proximity to campus, but... that's about it.

Hungry and cold, my girls and I just happened upon this place looking for a quick bite.  I love this place.  The mojitos (with sugar cane stick and fun stirrer) are the best I've ever had.  The orange-glazed salmon and grilled vegetables are seasoned to perfection with the perfect texture.  This seems like a great happy hour spot.

I had my eyebrows waxed here and I can't believe I paid $25 for it. $25?!?! 

First of all, on their spa menu, they list "brow design" and "brow maintenance" as two separate things.  The former is $25 and the latter is $20.  Both prices, in my opinion, are ridiculously high for ripping a few hairs off my face, but it's the fact that they try to distinguish between "design" and "maintenance" that doesn't make sense to me.  I believe Pyara argues that your first visit is "design" and the visits thereafter are "maintenance." But, really, my brows are already "designed" and just need a touch-up.... charging a first-time customer an extra $5 is just stupid.

In addition to this, although the waxer was VERY nice, she used strip wax that was really, really thin and stung REALLY badly when she ripped it off. I've never had a pain problem with getting my eyebrows waxed...but this hurt quite a bit, and left me with a few raised red lines on above my eyes that lasted for a few days.

I wouldn't go back.

(One positive thing: The tea they serve is free and delicious.)

I wanted to like Harlem Tavern, I really did. But my burger and fries were microwaved to lukewarm, the beer was not cold enough, and the service is inexperienced (although our waitress was friendly and helpful) and overwhelmed. And I don't get the need for a bouncer. This isn't an after-hours spot or even a party hotspot. I'll wait until the fall to try again. Maybe by then the hiccups will be gone. But I'm not holding my breath.

So divine: Let me lay it on the line, they have two on the vine. Not only are Jon Fernandez's devastating good looks, political cunning, and long, luxurious hippie hair owed entirely to this fine establishment, but students have been known to spend thousands of dollars at "the haven" during their Princeton careers, settle bets with hoagies, and even push old women out of the way to get an order in before closing. I have personally enjoyed the haven (#24, hot pastrami) as a delicious dinner, lovely lunch, and part of a complete breakfast. Their selection of drinks is vast, their drink prices are competitive, and many students claim the haven is better after a few drinks anwyay. While students, eating clubs, administrators (you know who I mean...), and even entire prison camp-like residential colleges come and go, the haven is a beloved and time-tested Princeton establishment.

Oh Cinderella's... I've been putting off writing this review for a while. I am convinced that Cindy's success has mainly to do with being one of the three options for food past 10pm in Central Square, plus delivery. But their delivery charm is wasted on me since I live rather close. I had never actually had a bad calzone, until I came here. Mozzarella cheese or low-fat shredded tofu? It's a mystery! The pizza? No slices, pie only, and it's pretty lackluster. I noticed a few times my "chicken" parm tasting strangely like fried fish, which usually means someone hasn't been changing the oil in the deep fryer. Just barely a step above Central's claim to fame for complete and total pizza place failure- HiFi. I have given good ol' local Cinderella's more chances than I'm actually willing to admit. Fail, every time. 

I can think of only 2 situations in which my patronage of Cinderella's would be warranted. 
1) I have a car-less guest who absolutely MUST have pizza stat(!) at 1am and insists that the quality is NOT important. 
2) Zombies have taken over Cambridge, and our survivor group faces starvation. All other nearby establishments have already been raided for food. We must choose between horrible calzones, fishy chicken parm, or death...

This was one of my favorite places in the Village in college. Still is. It has addictive almond and chocolate shortbread cookies and good coffee. 

A favorite weekend ritual was to sit at one of the few small outside tables on an early Saturday morning, while the Village was still sleepy and the late, great hardware store hadn't opened yet, with a copy of the Los Angeles Times and a cuppa joe. Those were the days ....

However, it was nice to see that Some Crust expanded a few years ago to include more tables, and also augmented its menu to include lunch fare.

Who knew a conservatory/botanical gardens could warrant so many visits with its ever-changing scenery and themes. The rooms are constantly evolving throughout the season which draws you back regularly. All of the rooms are carefully arranged and maintained while having information provided about them and the plant life throughout your walk. Phipps also offers gardening workshops and classes, which I've heard are worth the price. 

At the lower level is a gift shop with plants of its own for purchase as well as visitor-oriented souvenirs. Not to mention you can also schedule an event there such as a Wedding in the Fleur de lis room which is an arrangement of flowers/plants in its namesake.

I also wanted to mention that if any children are present, there are a few interactive rooms offering manned stations for games or trivia and there's also a user-driven controlled fountain.

I want to like Legends more. I've been there a couple of times to watch various sporting events, and I love how the staff will obligingly change the channel for you if you want to see a different game. However, the hamburgers are a bit weak. My boyfriend and I went there after the depressing Illinois-Penn State game this past weekend and we were starving. Admittedly we were drunk too, but we were immediately hungry after we ate our burgers. Also I don't think the burgers come with fries. We were a bit disappointed to see bags of chips.
