I do like the way you can put your own stuff on the burgers and all, and the toppings are nice and fresh. Maybe next time I'll order something else! I am nothing if not magnanimous.

When I lived in NYC, went here a few times for the pernil. Living in Seattle now... had my dad bring me a few orders of the pernil :-) 
Yummy
ksdt is always too fresh

The food court that houses TB looks like it belongs in the Dallas Fort Worth airport.  I scouted it out and came to the same conclusion as Michael B.: TB is the only place that I considered walking up to.  The sushi rolls and platters looked good (in the photos), but I ended up with a "mixed udon" soup.  It was OK, and it was worth the $6.95 that I paid for it.
I like the place, but I can't figure out the crowd. It feels like the different groups don't belong together. Similar to the south lake shops, there is a lack of harmony.

No, no, no. Just no. 

This place, under no circumstances, qualifies under "superior Vietnamese taste." The pho is good if you're starving for just about anything, but it's certainly not the best if you're looking for quality. Don't even get me started on their vermicelli! Why are their noodles always shredded into meager, limp pieces? 

Perhaps my background keeps me from fully enjoying the Hai Ky experience because of my father's wonderful home-cooked meals, but that's never kept me from actually praising an epicurean experience outside of the home before. Even if you take authenticity out as a factor, Hai Ky is just very low key.

The chicken wings that Morty's sells are arguably the best in all of KW. They have a number of different flavours and the wings themselves are much larger than the average. On Mondays and Thursdays Morty's has wing night specials where wings are only $0.59 each.

The service can sometimes be slow, but this could be attributed to the amount of people in the restaurant. During nights, Morty's can get incredibly busy and you can end up waiting for some time for a table.

The only other thing to note is that Morty's does not accept debit cards. Instead, they have an ATM inside the restaurant where you can grab cash from.
My fave food here is the eggs sardu, though the pain perdu is pretty darn tasty also! delish food and fun atmosphere

Tako Sushi sells cheap sushi/food for berkeley students. little decor.  exists besides some music.

Sampling: '
-"Ghirashi (as it appears on menu) lunch 12.99
-miso soup: like any other j restaurant. not a lot of msg.
-salad: miso dressing over lettuce
-chirashi contained 1 ebi, 6 salmon, 5 maguro, 2 hamachi, 2 suzuki, a dap of seaweed
-white ginger and sliced daikon(radish)
-lots of nicely vinegared sushi rice provided..


temaki:
-service ok , biz slow
-quality ok, quantity a value.

Ecco is my favorite restaurant in Atlanta. The service is impeccable, the menu is great, and it is consistent like no one else i've ever experienced.

I often have the server just walk us through the menu and order a lot of small plates. so many great things to try.

Another frozen yogurt place. These have exploded over the past 2 years and each have a different name. If you don't know what these places are well then you are out of the loop, sorry. From Pink Berry, Berry Wild, Red Berry, Berripop, Go Berry, Berry R Us...so many. But one thing I liked from Swirl that I'm not sure other places do, they might I just haven't been to them, is do it yourself.

In other places the staff pours the yogurt and applies the number of toppings requested. Usually 3. Here though you can pick your favorite of yogurt and then add as many toppings as you like. You pay based on weight, which I think is a great idea.

They had 10 flavors that you could mix and a good number of toppings from fruit, candy, and of course gummy worms.

The only down side to this? I have no control and mix and add everything I see. In the end I go overboard and sometimes ruin my tasty treat.

About the only bookstore in NYC that is comparable to University of Chicago's Seminary Co-op, Labyrinth Books is right by Columbia University. 

A Columbia art history Ph.D student I knew told me that the Ph.D candidates were given a $400 scholarship by some wealthy lady to spend at Labyrinth Books.  And it might be the luckiest thing to happen during the grueling Ph.D. years for some of these people.  Labyrinth certainly has the wealth of art history and art criticism books to accomodate all these students.

Furthermore, their holdings in all academic categories are prodigious.  They boast their continuing support of poetry as a pallative to the horrors of living in U.S. post-9/11 (and rightly so).

But beyond the academic categories and poetry, they also keep their current events and fiction categories well stocked with good books.  

They've been expanding out to set up bookstores at Yale and Princeton.  This is important as chainstores such as B&N have monopolized most college bookstores and left college bookstores filled mostly with utter tripe and nonsense.

As their website quotes: 
A room without books is like a body without a soul --- Cicero

I couldn't agree more.

I rarely give a five star review but I legitimately believe that this deserves five stars for an Italian restaurant. Great authentic Italian food is such a rarity and La Parolaccia shocked me with how delicious it was. I visited on a Sunday afternoon for lunch and I was so impressed with the pasta...homemade and perfectly cooked to al dente. The Rigatoni alla Norcina (rigatoni, Porcini mushrooms, sausage, onions, cream sauce with truffle oil) was divine and the sausage was fresh and delicious. My friend got the Tagliatelle Trilussa (tagliatelle, Italian ham, peas, asparagus, pancetta, onions, garlic in a tomato sauce) and it was fantastic. I would go back in a heartbeat as I hear their pizza and sandwiches are really yummy. The lunch plates are all around $12-13 a plate...not cheap, but definitely worth it. I'm sure their dinner is a bit pricey but I think you won't be disappointed (haven't visited for dinner yet though). The server was really nice and you are greeted enthusiastically by the someone making fresh pasta. Two thumbs way up - yay for good eats in DT C-mont!

I think this is by far the cutest cafe in Providence. Very refreshing to not have to force myself to finish my dunkin donuts iced coffee( since it usually tastes like shittt)  

The color scheme is adorable, I love the green and brick... not to mention the array of live plants all over!

Latte was delicious. Iced coffee was perfect. And if you get a chance, check out the bathroom the owners husband did AWESOME robot drawings , looks amazinggg.

I really like Halo for having it's own identity.  Halo pits itself as having deconstructive and minimalist architecture.  Deconstructive architecture strives to stimulate unpredictability and simulate controlled chaos.  There was certainly a juxtaposition between the cold, clammy concrete walls to the warm, luminous bar.  The randomness of the concrete stairs to the plethora of glowing light fixtures made this place visually interesting. I am pretty sure the owners named the place in reference to the lighting and not the video game.  But, it certainly has the video game feel with the barren walls and futuristic furniture.  This lounge is certainly not conducive to dancing due to space layout, but more so for enjoying the conversation with intimate friends.  Also, it maybe a place of philosophy, where you question, why that beautiful woman is engrossed in the not so attractive man.  Which inevitably leads to introspection of why you're not engaging with that beautiful woman.  

Now I leave you with some quotes of Jacques Derrida, founder of deconstruction, the challenger of assumptions of metaphysics and the character of  text.  In some ways, I think these quotes relate to the art form of yelping.

"If this work seems so threatening, this is because it isn't simply eccentric or strange, but competent, rigorously argued, and carrying conviction."

"No one gets angry at a mathematician or a physicist whom he or she doesn't understand, or at someone who speaks a foreign language, but rather at someone who tampers with your own language."

"Certain readers resented me when they could no longer recognize their territory, their institution."

"Whatever precautions you take so the photograph will look like this or that, there comes a moment when the photograph surprises you. It is the other's gaze that wins out and decides." [Even if I turn my face at an angle or suck my gut in, I guess the photographer thinks I'm fat haha]

"I never give in to the temptation to be difficult just for the sake of being difficult. That would be too ridiculous." [ I wish some of my professors took heed of this.   I guess for some of you, you wish it was your significant other]

Having been at MIT for 4.5 years, never eating at a food truck, and avoiding vegetarian food most of the time, i was really timid about clover food lab. 

first time i went, i ordered the rosemary fries. they came out pipin hot with crunchy rosemary leaves mixed in with fresh fries. they didn't have ketchup, but i heard from previous yelpers you didn't need it. i tried it out. it was good. i left the food truck, sat down at a bench munching away on the fries and waiting for CT1 to come by.

second time i went, i got the fries again. (they also had ketchup this time) they were delicious once again! also tried the chickpea fritter (which turns out to be my fav). since then, its been a convenient place to go when you are in kendall square. its also pretty cheap compared to cosi and the food court behind the coop. 

i've tried the vegan BLT and the pesto sandwiches, but i think the chickpea surpasses both of them. 

sure the sandwiches aren't as big as other food truck items, but still fills me up and leaves me full but not in a food coma stage. :)

I'm half-Mexican and was raised by my loud Mexican mother who happens to be a great authentic cook and quite a snob when it comes to Mexican food, which unfortunately was passed on to me. I'm always on the quest to find the perfect bean, rice, and cheese burrito with a homemade tortilla. (There is nothing worse than a burrito with store-bought Mission tortillas) That being said, La Burrita's tortillas fall into the store-bought category but the burrito is still delicious. The small size is perfect and the chips are bomb.

This place is simply fantastic for delicious cheap food. I was born and raised in San Francisco, so I can't get enough Asian food, and I have very high standards. The Asian Ghetto meets those standards. The Vietnamese and Thai are my favorites, but it's all good in my opinion. 
    By the way, don't forget about what I call Asian Ghetto #2 on Hearst Ave. (across from North Gate next to Etcheverry). It's a food court that has Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Vietnamese, and Thai, with an American grill and a Top Dog for good measure. It's also worth checking out for sure.

~FROMAGE~
[fin]
 
If you're a cheese snob (like I could only dream to call myself), this is your Providence Destination-1.  Very small storefront located in the Art District; clean and simple with wood floors and high ceiling - my eye went STRAIGHT to ze chezzz.  ...and PRICEY little wheels of taste, they were!  Farmstead carried both domestic and imported cheeses, ranging in price between 15-35$.  Tthough, you can buy "cheese orphans" - tiny cheese wedge leftovers - for 2-5$.

GREAT service - the staff was incredibly well-versed in the langue de fromage (as well they should be, being Fromagiers!).  I tried a sheep milk cheese and then an ridiculously buttery cheese (I was too mesmerized that I didn't ask for the wheel name).  I hope to run into Matt Jennings (Executive Chef/Master Cheesemonger) just to bask in the glory of his cheese wisdom.  Maybe when I stop in for lunch between 11-4 (yum!) - - - I'll just have to be content with returning, day after day, until I've met the man behind the plan (or until I, myself, turn into a giant cheeseball).

Veggie Heaven is an old-faithful of mine, and I've really never had anything there I didn't like. I've never been a big fan of eggrolls / fried spring rolls since going veg, but I'll be damned if this isn't the most addicting and mouth pleasing eggroll - especially with the dipping sauce (which they give you more of if you ask!). If you're in the mood for something less greasy, the standard non-fried version of the spring roll is delightful, too. Speaking of addicting tasty stuff, their pot stickers are also awesome. Alternatively, a lot of people aren't used to steam buns, and the red bean bun or curry bun are a GREAT way to introduce yourself to a very tasy quick eat.

95% of the time, I order the Protein 2000. This is easily their most popular dish, but for a reason - it's certainly not ONLY for VH n00bs. This stuff is GOOD, and you always have the option of spicy or regular (even if they don't ask or mention it), and white or brown rice. I vote brown - who eats white when there is brown? Anyway, the Lucky 7, Curry City, Tangerine Mushroom (who's spicy sauce is available on the side, if you ask!), Path of Phoenix, Eggplant Tofu, Thunder Tofu, and all the quesadillas taste wonderful, and most have pretty spectacular names.

The food service is rapid, and the taste ALWAYS consistent. The staff is always compliant & friendly, regardless of any possible language barriers. Also, whether you're a bubble-tea-virgin or not - try theirs. The coconut-green-tea & almond-green-tea are reeeeeeeeeeally good chasers to food, and especially good for carrying with you as an after-snack in the general area :)

When in doubt of where to find some unique clothing (or accessory) item, no matter how obscure, turn to the Garment District. Be it a cowboy hat, magic wand, polyester frilly milkmaid dress, pleather thigh-high boot, maroon stockings, Hawaiian (fake) lei, faux-bauble encrusted ring, giant sparkling dollar-sign bling, wig-in-a-bag, fake tattoo or plain old American Apparel t-shirt, chances are they'll have it. 

This isn't a destination I turn to on a regular basis - the dust bunnies scare me, and I often leave feeling as musty as if I'd been stuck in an attic for several years. Particularly so if you enter the back, which not only feels and smells like I'm in a different decade, but also contains more of their 'eclectic' or seriously odd or old offerings. 

I've never had the heart to dig through their dollar-a-pound section despite the lure of a possible gem, since I've got other gem-hunting locations I prefer. I usually can't bring myself to buy some of the overpriced 'regular' things in here, like an American Apparel tank top that's just several dollars less than what it'd cost in the actual store. I do generally feel like this place, although separate from it's new Siamese-Twin Boston Costume downstairs, is still going to remain a costumey-oriented destination in my mind. But if I'm ever in need of a totally random item, this is the place I'm likely to find it. And occasionally, there's a treasure-find somewhere in there too.

It's kind of hard for me to write reviews for cupcake places due to the fact I don't like sweets as much as the next person, but I feel I could be fair and use my Yelptastic judgement (also, Teresa loves this places, so I have to do something about it).  So this review will be a co-written one for the most part.

The cupcakes were actually pretty good I thought.  From the reviews I've read on this place, it's a hit or miss on the moistness of the cupcake.  I got some chocolate cupcake w/ strawberry frosting, and Teresa go the Hummingbird. The chocolate cake was actually really moist and full of fluff.  You could stick a fork inside the cake and it would be clinging on for dear life.  The Hummingbird, however, was a little try (but I am told that's how that particular one is suppose to be).  The frosting is cream cheese heavy as Anna W. mentions in her wonderful review.  I think that is pretty spot on to how I felt.  But being a pig, I ate the whole thing and then regretted it later.  It wasn't too sweet, but not too dull.  Some cupcakes/cakes I've had hurt my teeth due to the frosting being overpowering.

I do like that this shop is off on it's on in a random corner.  With that said, I don't understand why the shop is so freakishly small.  It can barely fit 6 people at the counter (a family was behind us).  It also has a massive parking lot (for the size of the complex anyway).  There are also three ity-bity tables in front of the store.  Personally, I didn't think they were clean.  Come on now, three small tables and they can't be kept clean?  

That is my ownly gripe about this place.  I think I could easily say it'll satisfy the cupcake connoisseur (Teresa) to the "as long as it doesn't suck" (me) type.

I don't know maybe I ordered the wrong thing.  My hubby and I ordered their gelato as it came highly recommended by my brother-in-law and sister too.  I tried their lemon lychee gelato as well as their tiramisu gelato.  My husband ordered their strawberry gelato as well as the lemon lychee.  The lemon lychee had a nice flavor to it but a bit on the artificial side and the tiramisu was decent.  However, the consistency was a bit different than what I am use to.  I have to say, I have had better gelato and flavor choices at Pazzo Gelato in Silverlake (LA).  

But another thing about this place is that it does have a variety of desserts to choose from, not just gelato.  They have crepes, ice cream, shaved ice.  So maybe, in the future we will skip the gelato, and try the other items on their menu.  Yeah, I am willing to give them a second chance.

BTW, the lady working behind the counter was super nice and helpful and the place itself appears very clean and well kept. :)

I've never had a better dining experience. Ecco has the best wait staff in Atlanta, hands down! Every employee in the place owned a genuine smile. Our waiter knew the menu inside and out and his enthusiasm for Ecco's food was a wonderful surprise. Turns out, he was spot on about every item and from the first taste to the last, each bite was amazing! The fried goat cheese, oak grilled asparagus and San Marzano tomatoes pizza are just a few of the "must have" offerings. Oh, and the drinks ... let us not forget the drinks. Perfection ... each and every one.

This is a great place to party!  If your room is not big enough to entertain all your rowdy friends, just look for the lobby near the 400 block of rooms. The staff takes a hands off approach dealing with parties so you can get away with even leaving your trash in the halls.

For my first experience here, the delivery guy couldn't figure out how to get to my apartment. His English was poor and he seemed to not understand my explanation to go to the call box at the door to gain entry. I had to go down to the ground level, then go outside to *find him* -- he wasn't even near the door. *sigh* Building exteriors are generally not that complicated. But the pizza was good.

My second experience was nothing remarkable.

My third and probably last experience: I just called to place an order for a pizza, I was immediately asked to hold. I held for just over five minutes before hanging up and deciding on something else. If I have to wait that long to place an order... how long is it going to take to get my food? Surely they are not so bombarded with customers that someone can't at least come back to assure me they'll be able to take my order shortly.

I have been there a few times, different days of the week. It's nothing fancy, good location for the Pasadena 26-35yr old crowd. Parking is a nightmare... Happy Hour is decent, service is friendly. I would continue going for a after work cocktail.

I love this place, there pancake's are some of the best i've ever had!

all there food is great! 

it's a bit pricey, but man is it a lot of food!

Service can be slow at times, but it's still decent. 
the good food makes up for it. 

oh and they are no longer cash only.. they accept credit cards now!

really good corn beef hash, pancakes, hash browns, chocolate mlik.. it's all excellent!

What can I say?   The cookies are beyond belief good  While the chocolate chip are awesome, the sugar cookies just deliver a goodness that's hard to be topped even by homemade!

Combine this with an excellent delivery service that arrives when they say they will and this is a sure-fire winner of a gift/reward for co-workers and employees.  I've done this two years in a row for my legal assistant and she's always impressed.

The coupons and on-line specials are definitely worth using as they do lower the price a fair amount.
Great burgers and a great price. I think. I will give them that coveted 5th star after eating there a few times.

I love Hungry Mother! I read a lot of great reviews but really couldn't understand how neo-Southern cuisine could be so great? I had the catfish and it was PERFECT! The dirty rice that came with it was just as impressive...PERFECTION! Cornbread and collard greens were amazing.  MUST HAVE THE BEEF TONGUE CANAPE.
I will go back in a heartbeat, even if they don't have a table, the bar had a great vibe! Did I mention the immaculate service?

As Anna's got worse, this place sprung up.  My brother first found it for me after I had left Boston and this place was just beginning to sow its roots.  When we would go home to NY, he would freeze this delicious buffalo chicken burrito and bring one back for me.  One time I went to Boston for a visit, and got 4 of them, froze them, and when I landed back in DC and realized they were still in a freezer at my friend's place in Central Square, I swear my heart broke.  Last time I bought 9 of them and brought them back for my boyfriend and his housemates, and they were in love instantly.  Burrito wrapper stuffed with buffalo chicken, blue cheese, rice and ranchy goodness?  I ask you: What's not to love.  My only beef is that they ran out of bags and I had to carry 9 huge burritos in my 2 tiny arms.  People driving by on Mass Ave must have thought I was nuts.  I'll never come back from Boston without these again, and Bolocos are springing up everywhere there.

all rolls look the same
not that cheap for what you get
long wait, big pieces

top pick: island roll
Tried the double chocolate cookie...eh. Stick to the chocolate chip! At first bite, I enjoyed its chocolately goodness but then it just tasted uncooked and grainy. Eh!

Royal East-- the forgotten jewel of Kentral (that's the area between Kendall & Central, genius). This option always escapes me until it's too late. It's pretty cheap, always has seating-- even on a Friday night. Great lunch specials, and pretty satisfying Chinese food all around. Lame fortunes in the cookies, but hey folks- you can't win em all.

Non Smoking = Awesome (AGREED) As another local entertainment business owner I have to admit that the Cat's Cradle has been a role model for me for a long time. I can't wait for the day that DSI becomes the Cat's Cradle of Comedy, attracting groups from all over the country that want to play a set in North Carolina. 

I have seen so much music here. Its great that people can be all like "YO! I WANT TO SEE LIVE MUSIC" and there are  times when people can see a completely different genre of music every single night of the week. Can the bathrooms at a concert venue ever be awesome? If so, that's an area all local venues could investigate.

juicy patties + free toppings + double helping of fries = fuck that other burger... animal style!!!

Look, the debate always goes either way.  But in the truest form of a hamburger... five guys wins out (for a burger chain).

Toppings are fresh and free.  And it takes roughly 36 idaho potatos for one small order of fries... really it does, I did the research.

When your mom gets hunger pangs... this is where i take her.
Same old Panda but with extremely long lines. Good if you want to satisfy your fast food craving and don't want a burger.

I took a little motorcycle road trip to see a friend in SLO and got up before everyone else and needed to get some work done. My friend told me that this was his favorite coffee shop in SLO... after experiencing their iced americano and their free wifi for a couple hours this place is now my favorite place in SLO. This place had plenty of seating despite the fact that there was a big group of bikers who came through. BH had a big selection of pastries and other delicious coffee pairings that I could have tried, but was too full to get something. The staff was very courteous and you could tell they know how to do coffee right. I took a gander at a few people who got cappuccinos and they even did the cool foam art that you see in the high end places which tells me that they take pride in their work. I'm a big coffee person and this place I definitely gets two enthusiastic thumbs up. Worth stopping by if you are cruising down hwy 1 or 101 and need a little break.

"The Social Network".  

Very positive experience, as usual. Well-maintained facility - from the lobby to the restrooms to the theater itself. Always clean, without that usual movie theater stink (you know what I'm talking about...).  Comfortable seating, great sound, impressive screens...what's not to love?  Staff pleasant, despite having to run the requisite upsell script ad nauseum. 

Now that moviegoing is genuinely an "experience" or a treat for most folks these days, this Cinemark location consistently gets it right and makes it worthwhile.

I tried really hard to like this place, since this cafe is at such a convenient location for me.  It is cute and all, and I guess the food and drinks are alright (nothing too special though).  But it is the service that's been making me hesitate going here, and after the experience earlier today, I won't even consider them from now on.

The people here are just... unwelcoming.  Today was no exception.  When I sat down, they just left the menus on the table and walk away. No greetings, whatsoever. Not even an eye contact. Then I had to bother someone to take our order b/c no one was paying any attention to us.  My bf doesnt drink coffee and we weren't going to stay that long anyways, so it was just me who ordered a drink and the waitress gave us the dirtiest look, and then walked away again without a word.  At this point I was reminded that I shouldn't  even expect a smile... 
Then when we were trying to pay, the waitress, in the most rude way, informed us that we were supposed to order one drink per person minimum.  Umm... first of all, she has to learn how to say things in a non-b**chy way.  Secondly, what was the point of telling us that now? (perhaps for the "next time" which won't happen ever)  If that was the restaurant policy, they should have told me that when we were ordering, instead of scolding/embarrassing/treating us like ignorant fools when we were clearly unaware of how terribly we offended them with our wild behavior of ordering only one coffee...  I would have much preferred to just get another drink, than to be ignored and basically receiving zero service.

This might sound silly but I value myself too much to be treated like sh*t when I'm a paying customer.  Good bye Max Cafe.

This place is perfect! I used to frequent this location on a regular basis and never grew tired of the food.

The pick two for $6.99 is GREAT!  Half a sand which and hearty delicious soup are more than a girl can ask for for lunch.  I love their grilled sandwiches and their veggie soup. You really can't go wrong with those!

Date Rating: 2
Pick up Scale: 3

Strong Suggestions:  Bring a book, grab some coffee, eat lunch and relax.

With apologies to Keith Olbermann:

Worse: Goosebeary's, for your edible but tasteless "pan-Asian" (read:easy excuse for indeterminate flavor) slop. You will do in a pinch, but I really don't like being pinched.

Worser: Jose's. What kind of magic web of blandness do you weave, that you've convinced me that you are worse even than Anna's?

Worst: Jerusalem Cafe:  What kind of fuckery is this? This is not lamb, this is not falafel, not even falawful. Indeterminate and terrifying. Next time you send me to the hospital, I send you to the morgue (apologies now to Sean Connery in the Untouchables)

Cogratulations Jerusalem Cafe! You are today's 
WORST
PERSON
INTHEWORLD!!!!!

I attended USC for my Master's degree. (MFA in Interactive Media, School of Cinematic Arts.)  And I couldn't speak more highly of this institution or the value of my (many)dollars spent here.

The resources of USC that one can draw upon, especially as a graduate student, are just incredible. Doing a film project on parallel universes? We happen to have one of the word's leading experts on the 11th dimension here.  Want to know more about space travel? Neil Armstrong is an alum.

But I went to New York University as an undergrad - I know what it's like to have a prestigious list of alumni.  Why is USC different? Because of the whole "Trojan family" network.  USC has done an excellent job in creating a community of students and alumni who actively support and collaborate with each other.

After I graduated I started my own business, and this network has been invaluable. Not only did it make it easier to start my own business, but even now that I've graduated I feel no less supported by USC than I did when I was a paying student there.  They believe that the success of their university is measured by the successes of their students and alumni, and they put their money where their mouth is on that one.

While there, I will admit that the classes themselves won't spoon-feed you this kind of stuff, and you have to be willing to do extra work in order to really reap the benefits. But I promise if you do this work, you won't be disappointed.

Fight On.

My favorite store ever!! Puts any Whole Foods to shame because they make so much delicious vegan food that I don't know what to do with myself, except keep shoving it in my pie-hole! Whatever you do, don't miss the food counter. Everything I've ever had here was great!

Wow that milkshake was sweet...it was free after all. (I used a check-in offer)

I came in and was very nicely greeted by the host and quickly placed my order. The service is slow, but it was worth the wait since everything was fresh. They let you choose between wheat and white bread as well as the burger size and how well cooked it is. The price is well balanced, very reasonable considering its prime location on Thayer and the fact that it caters to mostly college students. The food was good but slightly too much on the sweet and salty side for my tastes. 

Thayer has been lacking a good burger joint and this place fills that need nicely.

I have been going to Kurama for about a year on and off now, and though it is definitely not the best sushi in the triangle, it is still pretty good, if you understand what you're getting.
I should mention I was friends with one of the sushi chefs for a while and this insured fresh cut sushi that was overfilled and yummy. Though honestly, the sushi I've had there is always overfilled and yummy. I always get the wizard roll and it always does the job of filling me with eel and avocado goodness.

There are definitely some drawbacks, only one of the waitstaff is any good (and I think he just left, grumble). You are charged for ginger and wasbi, which I find evil, and the owner kind of is a jerk.  I would also say that the bathrooms can be neglected, depending on the gender of the waitstaff (women's....)
But I can get lunch for 10 bucks and be easily full. I can drop in and be done in 20 minutes easy and, if I really am just craving a quick sushi bite, this is the place to go.

I'm not indian, and my indian palate cherry was popped by this place, so read my review with that in mind. I've come to this place probably 6 times, and I've been satisfied almost every time. 

Food: I'm a big eater, so the first thing I worry is quantity. Admittedly, the dishes aren't large for $8, but going to other indian restaurants, I would say they're about average size. The naan is usually my filler, and a pretty good filler at that. The potato, or garlic naan is pretty bomb-diggity, and ordering a couple of those bad boys usually does the trick for me. I've tried a bunch of items there, so my analysis of the menu would be would you read is what you get, which has ranged from a "not my cup of tea, but I guess not bad" to "weerd".

I'm a little hesitant to give 4 stars to a place that left a piece of hard plastic in my chicken marsala, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and call it a fluke. It's in berzerkeley-zone, so keep away from the shadies that walk around.

A serious upgrade to Claremont sushi.

Excellent food, great staff, very reasonable prices, and the place looks one million times better after the remodel.

Go here, give them your business. Make sure they do well and stick around.

Although it's probably been at least two years since I've been to Illium, I used to enjoy eating here when I lived in Troy. As a vegetarian at the time, they had plenty of sandwiches and delicious sides. Although I do believe their prices were a bit pricey for a college student, they certainly weren't bad.

Just stopped in here, the decor is nice, I didn't get any coffee so I can't speak on that. 

I did get a salad and a sandwich and probably won't be back for either. The salads are pre-packed and in a cold case at the front of the coffee bar. I grabbed one and ordered a sandwich. I went to sit down and opened the salad and the lettuce was all old and wilted. I asked to exchange and they obliged. I looked over the salads an grabbed one that I thought looked fresher, but the lettuce was again wilted, but not as much. I ate it because I didn't feel like complaining. 

On to the sandwich, it came out...veggie on wheat bread. Standard, nothing mind-blowing, as I got to the crust (sandwich was cut in half) the crust was pretty hard and stale. I didn't complain, but I think this place could do well as long as they rotated their salads and ingredients more frequently. Of course this comes with mor demand and volume of patrons, so we shall see. 

Pros: clean environment, nice decor, friendly service (helps that the girl behind the counter was cute), free wifi

Cons: ingredients that aren't fresh

Who could hate an ice cream sandwich? Warning: It can be overwhelmingly sweet. I can barely finish one cookie and the ice cream because of the sugar overload. 

Nonetheless, best white chocolate chip cookies I've ever had. Mmmmm.
Excellent service and quality polish. Gel nails lasted 4 weeks without chips!

The ONLY reason i'm rating this cafe so low is because of the absolutely awful service my party and I received at our last visit.  

The food was delicious and very attractive when it arrived.  I ordered the smoked salmon tartine which was very good.  The salmon was lightly coated with dill and tasted very fresh.  It was presented on a very simple dish containing about 5 triangular slices of bread upon which the salmon rested.  Cucumbers, avocado slices, & fresh greens were also on the dish.  The bread basket contained a variety of delicious breads, one that contained dried fruits was a little too sweet for my taste.

As far as service was concerned, this particular day they were SEVERELY understaffed.  We waited for almost 30 minutes to be seated when we were told it was only a 5 minute wait.  Multiple tables on the outdoor seating section (where we sat) had been left uncleaned and vacant the entire duration of our wait and one was only cleaned off when we inquired on the wait time.  Once we sat, it was another 15 minutes before the server took our drink order, and again, it  was only because we flagged him down to help us.  after about 10 more minutes, we received our drinks- which came after the 2 parties who were seated after us.  By the time our food arrived, we had been at the restaurant for 1.5 hours total.  We obviously complained to the manager and the response we received was an idiotic "well, you know it's parents' week at the colleges so there are just too many people here today".    I don't see how any of that was of my concern and feel that  since they obviously knew it was parents week, they should have planned accordingly and scheduled the appropriate number of staff to work that day so that the experience would have been a less sour one.

I'm not saying i'll never go back there, but if someone mentions it, i'll be more than reluctant to say yes.

I was walking down the ave one day with my stomach grumbling when I was enticed by a window display. A few items seemed decently priced due to the fact it was happy hour.  I entered the building and was affronted by atrocious mexican music.  I shouldve known something was amiss when the restaurant was devoid of peoples except for myself and the matre'd.  I ordered their nachos out of chance that they might resemble the picture by which the price was posted.  But alas, when the plate arrived, I was completely appalled by the portioning of my meal.  It seems as though this is just another place where things are too good to be true.  I left with nothing but disappointment to quell my hunger.

If you want to waste your money and you don't care to be served stale bread crumbs on poorly prepared baked scrod, go there.  Even the rolls were not their customarily reliable warm and fresh selves but instead tasted stale also.  We were pressed for time so we did not want to complain or return the food.  We had to ask for lemon for the scrod.  What a mistake!   We tipped 15% of the bill and the waitress had a look of shock.  Sorry!

UHHHHHHH sooooo very worth the trip if you like vintage! Ellie stocks a fine and ever changing selection of high quality pieces at very affordable prices....you just can't find this stuff anymore!!! And they do, at an affordable price. Set up is so sweet, a true must!!!!

It's a small ice cream place. They have some great flavors, like Pistachio, Chocolate Chestnut, and Mango. I shared a large (4 scoops) with my brother. The ice cream is super rich and creamy. I liked the christmas lighting. There's definitely a mom and pop feel to it, the servers are spunky and nice. The Pistachio flavor= gold! A bit pricey, but seriously worth every penny! Plus, this place was the Best Ice Cream place of the Year in 2007 in several magazines, I believe. YUMMMMMMMM!
I Love it here, I came here litterally every other weekend with my sister this past summer!

A few things about MC^2... There's no beer on tap. As in none. Bottles? Well, there's Sam and Sam Light...and then a bunch of your usual American Light water/beer. Seriously though, nothing on tap.

I was hoping the food would make up for it.

It didn't.

My "red, white and blue" onion soup was just meh. Also, it came out almost immediately after ordering, so I know it wasn't fresh baked. The menu boasted of caramelizing both white and red onions in Sam Adams beer. First, as they have no beer on tap, did they crack bottles for cooking?? Also, my thin slice of baguette had a layer of blue cheese coating it. Fine. However, the slice of bread was significantly smaller than the bowl of soup. As such, the bread and cheese were submerged in an attempted to eat it. This resulted in both disintegrating in the broth. Generally, the soup tasted okay, but was much less exciting than the menu led me to believe.

For my entre I got the "catch of the day". I put it in quotes as this catch was Tilapia. To my knowledge, Tilapia is native to Africa and parts of Asia...not New England...thus making me question it's "catch of the day" status. The dish was supposed to be served wrapped in bacon, topped with some kind of tomato salsa/sauce/chutney/thing with a side of cilantro rice and asparagus. That sauce stuff was disgusting and uninspired. There are more spices in the world than salt and chili paste. I don't eat bacon, so got my fish without. I can only imagine how salty the dish would have been if I hadn't requested it without bacon. The rice was just meh. Again, way too much salt. The asparagus was of the way too slender variety and many of the ends were tough. The only thing I finished on my plate was the asparagus....and that's because I really love asparagus.

The waitress was nice, but really just okay. When she recited the specials it seemed rehearsed and like she was straining to remember what they were. We were never asked if we wanted a dessert menu, simply just given them...one menu even being placed in my brother's hand.

Many hotels have stepped up their restaurants so as to compete with the plethora of options available in the city. Apparently not so much at MC^2. Actually, my stomach kind of hurts. I think I'm going to go lie down.
Hey, it's Starbucks, what can I say?  Decent location - not too big, not too small.  Friendly service in my experience.  I'm surprised this location was missing from yelp!

In theory, Zuzu is a good place for a late night weekend alternative dance party, because the cover is cheap and the DJ is good and the patrons are decent. But in practice, the place is tiny and gets way too crowded for people to be able to really enjoy themselves.  Especially if you're the type of socially introverted person that this place is inclined to attract. It would be a lot more fun if the place had 200 more square feet, or 25 fewer people.

I had a tough time picking what I wanted. The cheesey fries with provolone gorganzola and the haberno strawberry sauce was amazing. My sandwich was amazing. I was lucky enough to go with three lovely ladies who had been patrons at the original.

I LOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOVE this spot. Every time I come here I leave with something totally unique. Downstairs is the best place to get your shirts. 

The Oakland shirts are the best =)

My new mantra.  I will be calorie frugal.  I will maximize value and minimize unhealthy eating.  I will make good food choices.  

Thus, I did a price comparison between D'Yar and Cal Gyro.  Cal Gyro is more expensive.  For the wraps, the difference is less than 50c.  For the plates, the difference is much more noticeable.  A typical chicken plate here is $6.49.  That's with hummus, salad, rice (or fries) and meat.  At Cal Gyro, it's $9.99.  

I got the beef kebab plate.  When the lady asked whether I wanted fries or rice, I got all confused.  I'm so bad at making decisions.  Especially when it comes to horizontally bad food choices.  It was ready in a jiffy.  The weather was very hot outside so I enjoyed watching the inappropriately dressed young students walk, up and down, up and down to fetch their foods.  A young man sitting by the table chowing down on a rice bowl ($4.99 special of the day) asked for some pickled radishes.  I want pickles too!  These were the purple kind, the kind that is also served with the pita that has a pocket in the middle.  The other places that serve thick pita does not have purple pickled radishes and their hummus is rather gross.  

When I got home, I sat down in the little al fresco sun room my parents built.  As I opened my bounty, I heard the strangest noise, like a very small semi-tractor starting up.  Turns out it was a hummingbird fight!  Two hummingbirds put their dukes up and fought it out in the yard.  It was a good sign for the food.  The beef was not overly salty and still tender.  It had nice char marks on the outside.  The rice had those little toasted noodles that I've heard so much about.  And peas.  The salad had little grape tomatoes.  And the hummus was quite tasty.  Sometimes hummus can taste like mortar that is used to seal bricks.  But from here, it was savory and tasty.

Anthropologie South Lake has got to be one of my favorite places to window shop. (and occasionally blow a paycheck or two) The clothes, the accessories, the random cute little knick knacks.. all make my heart skip a beat.  The only reason why Anthro recieves 4 and not 5 stars is due to the slightly extravagent price tag.  It simply puts a halt on my shopping spree and a dent in my bank account. Thus, on a typical day, its only a window shop stop.  Once in a while though, its hard to resist.  When the quality is exceptional, the details unique, and the prints, always fun & feminine.. sometimes my bank account just has to take one for the team. 

Now, this particular store is also really well organized and well staffed, so I never feel unattended to nor ignored.. and I've learned to always check out the clearance section in the far back.  Cheap finds do exist! However, the absolute BEST time to pull out your wallet is right after xmas and at the very end of summer.  The markdowns are incredible and the amount of stuff on sale is breathtaking.  Too bad, I ALWAYS have to wait for the sales though!

This place has a huge selection of beer on tap. The beers are categorized, and it's easy to find something to enjoy. Considering the massive selection, I'd recommend sampling a few first; it's easy to get carried away.

It's spacious, clean, and trendy. The bar itself is very long, so there's plenty of seating; tables are spread out over the first and second floor. It has a bit of a modern, industrial feel.

The bartenders were incredibly friendly and helpful.

This place is awful.  I went yesterday and the service was spotty, so I thought I would try it for breakfast.  After we sat down, it took 30 minutes for the waitress to take our drink order.  I asked if we could order our food since we had been sitting there so long.

After placing the order, everyone else got their food except me.  Since they don't write down the order, they forgot about telling the kitchen that there was another person that needed to eat.  

Never going back.

Dr. Mason delivered me when I was born and now she's my gyno--22 years later. She's probably one of the most knowledgeable doctors I've ever had. And since I don't have a general doctor at the moment, I tend to ask her for general medical advice too, and she is always willing to help, even if it's not related to her specialization.

She's very nice, but also very no-nonsense. Don't expect her to be asking you about your life, job, etc. You'll get in and out as fast as possible, which, as all the ladies know, is just what you want when you have to go to this kind of doctor.

Not that great of food but ...

1 star - Great location to people watch on Sunday.  
1 star - Cool atmosphere.
1 star - Great soju drink!  Yes quite expensive but hey, I'm game!

I'd give it 4 stars if the food was just a wee bit better.

As for the $$ per person - I gave it 2 '$' signs because of the cost of food + drinks.  The food is pretty much hovering around $7 to $9 per person but with drinks, definitely over the $ price range.

It's funny how Boston gets so cold but has the highest per capita ice cream consumption.  

The flavors are a little more unique and fancy than at JP licks, and they may sound odd but are so good: goat cheese brownie, earl grey, olive oil, saffron.  It's pricier than some other ice cream places, but you get what you pay for.

Feel free to try whatever sounds good before you decide on your order (they're very patient and used to multiple samples, but be courteous if there's a long line behind you!)

One of the only places around USC with REAL high-quality low-cost YUMMY food.

My favorite is the the chorizo breakfast burrito (which has potatoes, cheese, chorizo and egg). And their home made hot sauce is the BEST in town. A close second is the bacon breakfast burrito.

On Tuesday's they have Albondigas (meatball soup) that kicks my ass.
On Wednesdays they have Pupusa's which KICK's everyone's ass.

I still keep coming back in the mornings for their excellent breakfast.

One of my favorite spots for a cocktail. I like the outdoor setting. It is located on south Lake across from Borders one block north of California. It's very small, and there's a huge tree in the middle of its courtyard where the bar is with firefly lights all over it. Reminds me of back east. I love the textured wallpaper, the cool lights, and the clear furniture.

After purposely avoiding DD for the first few months of living in Kendall Square I have now once again succumb to getting a weekly dose of DD.  I get free coffee at work so I usually only get 1 thing and 1 thing only - a multi-grain bagel with strawberry cream cheese - when these 2 breakfast items combine it's amazing - I don't even really like cream cheese there is just something about this combo.  I think there is crack or something in some aspect of this breakfast treat - because let's be honest anything that comes from dunkin donuts is a treat (more blunt - it will fatten you up).  This location is even a Baskin Robbins/DD combo!  

Now that you know way too much about my weekly breakfast indulgence, I'll fill you in on the details of the 4 stars.  I have now gotten my crack cream cheese/bagel combo 3 or 4 times and each time the bagel has been perfectly cooked - this does not happen at all DDs - I know I have been to several.  The fact I have not gotten a burned bagel and the guy has never given me the wrong kind of cream cheese is practically a miracle compared to some other DDs - this guy gets 5 stars.  Most of the other workers are nice albeit a bit slow (they get 3 stars) so slow the bagel guy has my bagel ready before I have gotten my change - again 5 stars for that guy. The location - close to the T is convenient - more convenient than I would like since I try and not go, but I digress.
Great bookstore for cultural/political studies and occasional discount and remainder sales.

Returning to this place 5 years later was a Deja Vu experience.

Great food and fast service all for a good deal.  I used to visit this establishment for lunch during my "good years" at PU.  What an experience to return here.  Not the best place for a first date, but a nice place to grab a quick bite alone or with the fam.  Highly recommended.

Dodgey meat with cheese mushrooms bacon and tons of hotsauce.  add a bucket of the chilli cheese fries and your mouth will love you while your heart gets pissed.   For two straight years every sunday afternoon I would go to IB's to recover from my hangover, and I was never disappointed.  The pastrami sandwich is also really tasty but it doesn't host a candle to the baconsteak+ mushrooms.  Just remember not to compare it to a philly cheesesteak, it's a different beast, you eat it without wiz, and you dress it differently.  Either way you'll have a hard time coming up with a better way to take the edge of a hungover rainy sunday afternoon

- great that its open late
- love the deli and soup/oatmeal (!) bar
- perfect location

- not a great produce selection
- inflated prices
- 10 dollar minimum on cards... isn't this illegal? 

I've started going to Met for my groceries but will occasionally run to Appletree for a hot cup of soup or a sandwich

I really like this place

As I read many of these other reviews, I notice many of them saying how you will get a heart attack if you eat there and that is the reason for their negative rating. Well I hate to tell you folks, this place doesn't claim to be healthy! Do you go to Burger King for salad and waist slimming food? No! So don't give the place a negative rating for being not being something that it doesn't claim to be!

That being said, I went on the 20th of April after seeing Anthony Jeselnik at Cap City Comedy Club and I had a great visit to Big Bite afterwards. I had never been there but I had heard good things. This place is based off a food cart in New Brunswick, New Jersey (Rutgers) . 

If I am not mistaken it was on an episode of Man v. Food. The premise was if you could eat 5 "phat sandwiches" then you get to create and name your own. This is an incredible feat as I could barely finish my phat sandwich. 

They had a huge selection of food but I saw what I wanted and went for it right away! I got the Phat Longhorn, it contained: double cheeseburger, chicken fingers, mozzarella sticks, fries, bacon, egg, ketchep and mayo. It was not only huge, but it was fantastic! The only thing I would change is I would switch out the normal fries on the sandwich for curly fries (which they offer). The best part is that all that food only cost $7.25! That/s not too shabby in the grand scheme of things.

The sandwich was awesome, albeit huge and heavily damaging to my arteries. I couldn't even finish. I brought it home and ate it the next morning for breakfast (reheat in the oven @ 475 for 5 min). and it was still amazing. 

This place is open late (4 AM I believe) and they deliver. My only wish is that they had a location close to where I live. So if the owner reads this, get a San Marcos location, you will make a boat load!

BEST EATEN WHEN DRUNK... the Hong Kong has almost become a routine for me on the weekends. They have a bar on the 2nd flr and the restaurant on the 1st flr. They have a good size menu and have generous portions but nothing special. However, what was special to me was the scorpion bowls its a Delicious drink to share with friends. The food may not be the greatest but I still check out the bar and restaurant.

I can only echo the positive reviews of their coffee, which is some of the best in Harvard Square, I think. But their WiFi is useless. So if you're coming here hoping to do some work over lunch and coffee, get your coffee to go and find another place. I don't understand why cafes will advertise free WiFi, and then think they can just buy a shitty Linksys router at Best Buy to handle everybody...

Update: Something has happened to Crema. As they've gotten more popular, the quality of their coffee has gone downhill for some reason. Given that the word is now out, and the place is now completely overrun with little Harvard Square hipsters loitering around in their aviator sunglasses, there's really not much left to like about it. Well, all good things must come to an end, and the end seems to come very quickly in Harvard Square...

I never buy here unless there is a sale going on.  When there are sale items, though, it's a fairly good steal.  And the sales rotate so if you're patient and/or plan ahead you can usually get a great work wardrobe.  

Parking in the Uptown shopping center is convenient (unless it's a Saturday afternoon).

Houston, thank you for having such a cool zoo and in keeping with the new zoo attitude of having enclosures, not cages.  Animals  appear to be well cared for, fit, healthy and the entire zoo is so well maintained and clean.  Landscaped beautifully too.

Along with my husband, we had 3 guys from Vera Cruz and another from San Diego with us.  My San Diego friend reluctantly admitted Houston has a nice zoo -  but staying loyal to his hometown, still had to put in a few comments or more about how much better "his" zoo was.  Hubby and I loved it as did the guys from Mexico.  We had a really nice time on a off and on drizzly day so luckily crowds were minimal  

Especially fun for us was seeing Tucker the 4 y/o elephant and his mom, Tess.  They came from elephant conservationists in SoCal who are friends of ours - we first met Tucker as a 500 pound baby in SoCal at his earlier home.  Many zoos wanted Tess and Tucker - it was because of the high standards of the Houston Zoo that they went here.  Otherwise our friends would have never ever given them up  unless they were positive they would be in good hands. 

We particularly liked the sea lion show - their grace their charm, the primate area, and the children's area.

 Gift store had fun stuff to buy -  mostly reasonable priced, decent and cool - not stupid souvenirs that break before you get home ( well, maybe some merchandize was like that)  but overall a nice little gift shop.  

We - obviously - didn't go to the zoo for food - hadn't plan to eat but ended up getting a few snacks and coffee. Prices were lower and better than what I expected.  Nice, that in addition to the ubiquitous burgers, fries and pizza  also have fruit cups, fresh fruit and yogurt.  

All in all we had a really nice day and I look forward to another zoo visit next year. 

Parking is free but recommend you take the train as parking fills up quickly.  Plus you get a buck off the already bargain adult admission of $10.00 if you take the metro.

I've visited these apartments before... and they are pretty bad.... I remember the quality of the apartments were horrible. They were dirty, had bugs every where, and it just doesn't seem like there's much upkeep going on here. As expected, this place gets really loud at night, especially since it's right next to campus. So if you need peace and quiet, this place is definitely not the place for you.

For anyone looking for housing, please consider a different location first. I also hear a lot of stories from my friends who live/lived here... and they're pretty bad. I just hope that, in the case you do move in, you get the apartment after people who clean up the place before moving out.

Let me just start off that my belly has expanded from this eating out experience. It is a great place for a reasonably priced Italian meal. A bunch of us from work were all in the mood for Italian and were told about this place. It was busy, yet it was a steady stream of people eating inside and out as well as take-out. The portions are  substantial and it does not hit the wallet too hard. I got the chicken pesto and it had the right mix of ingredients and yes the hidden secret of BUTTER! Each meal came with a piece of bread that had a little garlic piece on it for you to spread out...Yum! If you are in the mood, then go for it. The only down side is the guy who takes the order, he definitely does not get the Mr. Personality award! However, the service was quick!

This is a cute restaurant where if your feeling blue go into Distritos and see the color explosion in the decor that it will automatically make you feel happy. I wouldn't really consider this a real Mexican restaurant but its good for what it is. I think this place is good for a first date especially if you get seated in the car because that would be a good conversation piece. What I didnt like was the 45 minute wait to be seated with reservations. I realize it was a Saturday night but 45 minutes...oh my...get it together Distrito.

"I love Lamb" 

This place is tasty, I grew up in southeast VA so I had never had a Gyro prior to my college days. I was taken to this place by a frat bro and I thank him to this day for it. This place is awesome and the price is just right. 

Good food, good friends, great times (Save by the bell high five)

This place has a laid-back, old-school vibe. The interior is spare, with vinyl orange seats and formica tables. Oh, and it has pretty dang good doughnuts. I like the plain, sugar variety. If you go early in the morning, the doughnuts may still be warm from the oven. Mmmm. They are best eaten with a cold half-pint of milk or hot coffee.

It's also nice and quiet, so it's a perfect place to do a bit of studying, read the paper, or catch up on paperwork. And what better way to do it than with a fresh, light glazed or jelly doughnut?!

The ultimate movie experience, still with good student discounts. The place seats about 1300 people in one room, and it dates back to the 1930's...its a slice of history and is gorgeous.  A cant miss when youre in the area, and on Wednesday nights, youre sure to catch someone famous heading into a premiere.
It's disgustingly greasy, there's too much batter on the fish. I didn't enjoy it as much. It's clean in there however. But the food didn't appeal to me. the chips/fries they served me wasnt fresh.

This is a great new place that deserves the hype.   The owners seem to be aiming at making a comfortable, unpretentious place with great food.  The lack of pretension shows up in the prices - which are great considering this is the only place I've been to in the last six months that left me raving about the food.

Virginia is definitely the theme, reflected in the wall paper in the restroom and many items on the menu - so you'll find great corn bread, items coated with cornmeal and items made with ham and/or grits.  Everything I've sampled was exquisitely prepared.

Three stars awarded for what it is... the closest to main UW campus food alternative that's also affordable.  Plus, this offers the choice of two kinds of cuisine... neither of them to be recommended highly by your cardiologist or vegan neighbor.  

Service was always prompt and prices were fair for the product offered.

When I worked and attended classes at the UW a few years back, occasionally each quarter, I would stop by the used bookstore across the street from Orange King and browse for a unique new-to-me read and then grab a bacon burger or chicken katsu.  A nice combo to take your mind off of finals, class projects, or a rainy Tuesday afternoon.

I've eaten here probably three times, and been here for numerous work-related events. The food is a bit pricey, and frankly not that tasty. The bubble tea is okay though. Each day they have a discounted bubble tea special, which might be worth considering. As for atmosphere, this place tends to blast the music, which can make it difficult to talk. It seems to want to go for a dance atmosphere, but doesn't have a layout conducive to dancing.

The one redeeming quality of this place is that the restaurant has a nice greenhouse layout. There is a lot of exposure to natural light, so on a bright summer day, The Bubble House can be a pretty place to eat.

I've gone in and out of this place a couple of times & haven't been impressed.  Not only aren't they very veg-friendly, but they're just not very friendly in general.  

They have some unique packaged items, but nothing you couldn't pick up at Wegman's for at least 30% less.  I recently decided to give the salad bar a try...until I noticed that the sliced mushrooms were still visibly coated with dirt.  Not only hadn't they been washed, but no one had even taken the time to brush them off!  Since I can only assume the other veggies are equally unclean, I will not, personally, partake.

I'm new to Los Angeles and was pleased to find an independent little shop selling books!  My first time to the bookstore was on the night Rachel Caine, the author, came to talk and sign her books.  It was quite busy but held the crowd well enough.  I found the books I wanted, listened to the Rachel speek and even had a book signed.  I recommend this place if you like to support the independents and if you like those cozy bookstores that are so hard to find nowadays.

In consulting, you gotta have 2 out of 3 things at least:
1.) You like the work
2.) You like the clients
3.) You like the money

In fashion retail, you need 2 out of 3 things:
1.) You like the clothes
2.) You like the customers
3.) You don't care how much it costs

But in fashion in general, don't yield. Bat 3 for 3.
1.) Fashion
2.) Style
3.) Everlasting Mutability

So who's got the special sauce for your wardrobe? Louis Boston? No. Barney's New York? No. Saks Fifth Avenue? No.

The best threads are at Tess. Absolutement.

Back when they used to sell Men's, I was so entranced by everything in the store. I bought a lot of stuff there, way more than I should of. Somehow, all of those gorgeous things are missing from my wardrobe. Pretty much all horked by ex-girlfriends. The only thing left? A $950 Biella outerwear coat. Sure, extravagant, (I'm not made of money! At the same time, I have a rule of thumb, "Anything worth buying is at least a thousand bucks.") but I've had it for oh, 8 years now, I still wear it all the time, and if I had a dollar for every compliment I got for it, it would of paid for itself. Unfortunately, I work it off like everyone else. I still enjoy buying gifts here occasionally.

Make sure your choices are 3 for 3, and you'll never regret shopping here, no matter the cost.

Stumbled upon this on a short visit to Providence. This is a good place for coffee-you can drink up there or order it to go mocha was a-ok 3 stars but the 4 stars here are for food, service and a really nice place to enjoy a meal. 

The menu for lunch is not huge but is varied enough that anyone can find something tasty to eat and it all looked great and everything that came to the table was exceptional.

Starter was the small "pizza of the day" could have been a meal all by itself was pesto and chicken and bacon the day we were there and it was very tasty.

Soups all looked really good and it was hard to decide-went with the squash and was very happy yummy and delicious-added bonus for lunch you can get soup and half sandwich or salad and half sandwich-all the salads also looked great we saw lots of people ordering them-my half sandwich was the apple and brie and it was flavorful and filling.

The restaurant itself was nice, quiet, pleasant and the staff was friendly, well informed on menu items and could not have been more on top of their game!

If I am ever back in Providence for business or vacation I would go back to Tazza's in a heartbeat-added bonus great street they occupy lots of art galleries, shops etc.

The only Chinese food truck I frequent for multiple reasons. 
1) It's reasonably priced
2) It's fast
3) They're friendly
4) It's yum, yum tasty!
I always get the General Tso's Chicken (3.5/5stars), and I like it with fried rice on the side. 
It's not anything out of this world, but it is rather scrumptious on a sunny day. I'm not saying it's healthy food or anything, but it's yummy food.

Bambino's is my new favorite sandwich place! It has a great location..the drag across from the Villas. The service is great...it feels like a family when you go. The theme is really cool..New York/Gangster. The food is soooo fresh and great tasting. The bread is really soft and the Sammy Spread is great on anything! It's a little pricey for sandwiches but you can split one they're so huge.

Our visit to Madres was sincerely disappointing.  The service, while friendly,  was extremely slow.  The food was barely edible and the atmosphere was as romantic as Guns N' Roses concert.  

Although there is mandatory valet parking for the restaurant,  you can park for free at the lot adjacent to the Pier 1 Import off of Lake Ave.  My GF and I walked over to Madres and were promptly seated by the hostess (It was a Saturday night and we had reservations) right next to the bar.  Approximately 5 minutes passed before our waitress stopped by to take our drink order.  We also ordered an appetizer- the empanadas.  There are three empanadas with each order, 1 chicken, 1 beef and 1 stuffed with asparagus and cheese.   The Chicken was probably the best with the Asparagus and cheese taking last place.  

My GF ordered the Bistec Encebollado (sirloin steak) and I ordered the Bistec Empanizado (breaded sirloin steak).  The Encebollado was bland and not noteworthy.  My Empanizado tasted somewhat fishy and the breading was soggy.  The beans were quite tasteless and the only thing that was pretty cool was the pyramid form used to scoop the rice onto the plate.   The plantains were fairly well done, but by that time,  I was mainly depending on them for flavor.  

Our waitress was very friendly, but service was extremely slow.  Our busboy was at our table about three times as often as our waitress. Even after the busboy cleaned off our plates we waited closed to 20 minutes before the waitress came by to ask us if we wanted our checks.  

Another star was knocked off because my seat was located directly below the temperature controls and one of the staff reached uncomfortably close to my head to adjust the temperature without an "excuse me".  Couldn't the building contractor place the controls someplace more unobtrusive? 

A waste of time and hard-earned money in my opinion.  I will never go back.  The only reason I awarded a star was because I DIDN'T get food poisoning.

Oh. My. Goodness. 

Meeting Street is good. Really good. 

The menu is ridiculously huge. The quality of ingredients is great. And the portions. Well, I hope you go in there hungry. I've gotten a laundry list of different sandwiches, soups, and salads there and everything has been nothing short of fantastic. Though I've been there numerous times in the past few years, I've never made it to dessert. The portions are just so big! 
I also definitely recommend Meeting Street for takeout. The small dining area fills up really quickly!

I've been here a few times for dining: a couple times not by my own will because of a group event held here, the other times because I wanted to let loose and eat some unhealthy bar food! (Ergo, no comments from me on how the salads are here)

Sampler Plate - well-portioned for 3 people as they claim in the menu.  Good variety of appetizers to whet your appetite for your coming meal, or simply have it as a light snack and chat with your buddies with some drinks in hand.

Fries/Garlic Fries/Seasoned Fries/Onion Rings - pretty standard but a little greasy in my opinion.  When eaten with ranch, both don't sit too well in your stomach...

Blakes Burger - simple, but solid burger.  Get this if you're an indecisive eater and don't want to look at the menu

Chicken Sandwich - actually a healthy option but you run a high risk of getting a dry piece of chicken; I personally like my chicken very juicy so I typically don't like to order the chicken.

As for drinks, watch for their weekly specials: Margharita Monday, Taco Tues, Wing Wed, Thirsty thurs, Fish n Chip Fri, etc.

**** 4.5 stars ****

New Rivers has probably the best looking and most intriguing charcuterie and offal menu (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=hpw7UrWf51aaWKbaGGJ2hA&amp;amp;select=hY88KJ6A39-2iH5IO1C4kQ) of any restaurant I've been in. Where else can you get Cocks' Combs and Duck Fries on the same menu? Sadly, this was one of the few times on my trip that I passed up something I was curious about, as the idea of doing a cured meat degustation tasting on my own sounds great but I know I wouldn't even be able to tackle dinner after.

My only major complaint with New Rivers is something I encountered almost immediately upon entering and which continued throughout the whole dinner, and that is the piss poor attitude I received from my server. This was a rarity during my trip to Providence, which is partly what made this experience stand out even more. Not long after sitting down at the table the hostess put my at my waitress came by and informed me there were also seats available at the bar. I'm sorry, do you know WANT my money? Because I'll gladly just leave the restaurant and pay someone who wants to wait on me...

Fortunately the quality of the food far outweighed the service from those providing it, so I was able to see past the bitchy attitude and enjoy my meal. Apparently there was a Restaurant Week in Providence not long before my arrival, and the trend of prix-fixe menus was so popular in the fine dining restaurants that they decided to continue the option on a regular basis. I opted for the set menu on this night, primarily due to one of my favorite items (pork belly) being one of the offerings.

They start you here with a wonderful sampling of breads, and a really delicious spread made of chickpeas and white beans. Two of the breads in particular were very good, the rosemary covered loaf and the cheese covered bread stick. Rarely do I splurge on the bread in a restaurant prior to the meal coming, but I couldn't resist here.

For my first course of the night I selected the tomato water gazpacho. I'm normally not a fan of any type of gazpacho, mainly because cold soup just isn't appealing to me texturally, but this one was surprisingly good. The diced red pepper, cucumber, onion pair so well with the flavor of the tomato water, and it's a very refreshing flavor that I can imagine would be perfect on a hot sunny day on a patio. Accompanying the gazpacho is a pair of basil crostinis with melted cheese in the middle, great for dipping in the gazpacho to enjoy a whole medley of flavors. 

The main course was my entire reason for choosing the prix-fixe menu, the pork belly. It was slow cooked with shittake mushrooms, carmelized onions, zucchini and red peppers. The presentation was like something out of a child's book, bringing up memories of playing in the woods, surrounded by all the earthy ingredients. It really was something beautiful to behold.

Unfortunately, the desert I was really looking forward to, the rhubarb and strawberry tart, was no longer being served, which was really disappointing as I was looking forward to my first taste of rhubarb in the northeast. They ended up replacing it with a pecan-rum ice cream, topped with a bit of melted Belgian chocolate. The flavor of the ice cream was pretty nice, and I liked the texture of the bits of whole pecan that were left in, but the chocolate on top was just overkill, and a bit too dark in my opinion, often overpowering the ice cream.

I thought New Rivers offers many good culinary surprises, and has the potential to be a real star in the Providence dining scene, but they still have a way to go to in order to catch up with some of the bigger stars. One note, at the time of writing this the entire front of the building was covered by scaffolding from some construction, so it may not be obvious it actually exist, but trust me it's there!

The Berkeley alumnus in me still has cravings for cheap, good Korean food from Steve's. Get it to go if you're not super hungry because portions are huge. If you ask nicely, they'll sell you a little tray of japche too!

Cheap, cheap, cheap.  If you've got nickles and dimes left to your name and need a drink, come here.  They usually have 4 beers on tap, and seasonal casks as they come through.  The regular taps rotate on a pretty regular basis.  Don't come here expecting food, but if you need a beer you can do it cheap.  Did I mention how cheap it is?  So cheap in fact the bartenders are volunteers.  That's what I like to see, little over head and it keeps the prices low not paying employees.

So, I've been here twice now, both times as a result of a bad day or a day that just didn't go as planned.  In both cases, Diddy Riese has turned those bad days into GREAT days!  The first time was after a body-cramping and day-ruining experience at Tia Juana's in Irvine - unfortunately I had food poisioning but I still enjoyed the bite that I was able to try.  The second time was an attempt to see Amy Goodman in Pasadena but she was booked up full - so FAIL!  Shucks... but at least the night ended by waiting in the line ride at Diddy Riese for a DELICIOUS, day redeeming ice cream and cookie sammy.  

The cookies are so soft and tender.  It was just the right amount of chewiness to give you sufficient time to savor the flavor of lightly caramelized brown sugar and toasty aroma of the oatmeal with brief bursts of tart sweetness from the studding of warm raisins throughout the oatmeal cookie.  Imagine that cookie with decadent, milky, sweet cream folded with chunks of slightly frozen, tangy and smooth strawberry cheesecake.  The chocolate chip cookie was just as good as the oatmeal cookie.  The chips are small, but there are a lot in the cookie, so you're not missing out on gooey chocolate that will end up oozing all over your delicious mint chocolate chip ice cream.  The mint was so refreshing with slivers of dark chocolate veins throughout the pastel green cream.  Can you also believe a sammy is only $A BUCK FIDDY?  Love it.  

Just thinking about Diddy Riese makes me happy, and it helps me to think up new combinations of ice cream sammies for my next "bad day"!
Pretty good burritos and burrito bowls. It is a pretty convenient place to eat too. The only bad thing is that everyone goes here so the lines are always out the doors during lunch time.

Start with a Hendrick's basil Gimlet, move on to PEI oysters, munch on a healthy salad, and then gorge yourself on little necks and chorizo served in a gorgeous garlicky broth and perfectly grilled sourdough bread. What do you get? One glorious meal. 

I had an entirely pleasant experience at Mill's Tavern. The service was spot-on, the food was heavenly and the drinks went down very easily. I enjoyed every moment, bite and sip. The menu is impressive, and certainly has something for everyone. Be it beef, bivalves, salmon or salad, they have it all and present it very tastefully. 

Anyone who knows me (or merely reads my reviews) knows of my deep, unwavering love for oysters, little necks, chorizo, gimlets, and good service. Well, all of these things were excellent here - excellent. In fact, I can't wait to go back. I'm astounded it's taken me so long to go here. It was wonderful. Wonderful. 

Throw in the complementary valet parking (which pleases The Huz), and this gal's got a new restaurant to add to the list of The Regulars. Five stars!

Antica Osteria must be Italian for "slowest service EVER".

The BF and I had never had Italian together and I found Antica Osteria on Yelp. We called for a reservation but it was last minute and they told us there's no wait to sit on the patio. So we proceeded to drive there. FYI, you have to valet. Thank goodness my boyfriend drove because I would have been a little embarrassed rolling up to the valet in my non-European made car.

We were seated right away. The patio is very quaint and faces out to Bissonet. Most of the people dining there were an "old money" or "country club" type crowd. It sort of reminded me of Backstreet Cafe. I felt a little under dressed in jeans and a fitted tee. Maybe that would explain the mediocre service...

The waitress came and took our drink orders. We just asked for water since we were still looking at the wine menu. She said she would be back to give us the food menu. 10 minutes later, she comes back. She gives us our food menu. We ordered a glass of house wine. 10 minutes later, she comes back with the bottle of wine and lets us sample the house wine before pouring us a whole glass (very nice of her). The wine tasted like the bottle had been open for a few days though. She poured our glasses and then left for ANOTHER 10 minutes. By this time, we were really ready to order our food already. In total, we waited 40 minutes before we could even order our food. 

The only saving grace was that the food was pretty good and came out timely. I had a chicken breast stuffed with cheese in a wine sauce. My boyfriend had a veal with a tomato mushroom sauce. Both were served with mixed grilled veggies. The prices for the dishes were both very reasonable too (under $20). The food was very fresh and the meats were tender.

So maybe it was an off night? I don't know if the atmosphere is quite right for me. A lot of older rich people. So I'd recommend the place if you want a nice Italian meal in West U, but I think I'll continue my hunt for a better Italian place in Houston.

A++ Chung was very professional.  He has his poses down!! We shot both of our engagement and wedding photos with him.  I chose him because he has a great fashion eye and adds that extra flair into his photography.  He's very easy to work with and we're so excited about all 1400 images that he shot for us on our special day.  I have soo many to choose from that I'm having trouble narrowing it down to just 100.  Definitely, go check out his work and his final products.  They are to die for.  Thanks to Chung and his staff!!

PHOTOS posted to Yelp!!

Simply the best. 


Let me first say I have experienced Testmaters material and Powerscore material. Blueprint bitch slaps those around.  That's it and they keep getting better.
