I don't know what it is, but when you listen to their lectures they take you in a very well paced manner that makes clear sense. Well worth the investment.

Perhaps Mama Dip wasn't in the kitchen or this place is resting on its laurels. I ate a full  meal at 3, with nothing to eat all day so this state of appetite should have made the food taste amazing, even if it wasn't. And it wasn't. Chicken and dumplings forgot the chicken; one medium sized peice and the rest could have been from a can of Campbell's chunky soup. Everything was inadequately seasoned - the lima beans were neutral but had they been cooked the Old southern way, they should have been exquisite - no salt, backfat or hamhock flavor to be found. I've had better cornbread in a hospital cafeteria- Sweet pickle potato salad, again unseasoned, didn't even meet the take out standards of Harris Teeter. The fried green tomatoes also needed salt and were only made good by that terrific drippy ranch dressing that you seem only to be able to find in restaurants. 

For Southern food, cracker barrel - which is road side cafeteria fare at best - beat Mama Dips restaurant on taste and price. 

If you're a southern cook, as i am, this place will disappoint. Beats hospital food, beats Mcdonalds but not on a taste to price ratio, but otherwise, maybe nostalgia and people too tired to cook for themselves is what is keeping this place afloat. 
 My biggest fear is that this is, in fact, the best southern food the reviewers have had and they don't know any better - that would be tragic.

Just headed down to San Luis Obispo during a road trip.  Saw this place on Yelp and decided to check it out, considering my massive craving for meat and the lack of appetizing options in San Simeon.

Experienced complete and utter satisfaction.

Friendly cashier, fast speedy service; I was so happy to hear my number called out as my hunger was nearing epic proportions.

Began my path to absolute indulgence with an ABC burger (Avocado, bacon, cheese).

My girlfriend inhaled it whole.  Then, on to Round 2.

Tri-tip steak sandwich was the perfect harmony of succulent juicy medium rare steak slices, a hint of tender fat, and the optimum amount of BBQ sauce.

In a state of blissful contentment, my girlfriend moaned "evverrryyyttthiiinggg I could ask for in a mealll..."

This place is a must for anyone looking for delicious tofu-based dishes. The food is surprisingly delicious and very inexpensive.  I really do not know how they make the food taste so good! 

Even if you're not a vegan or vegetarian, you can find something to love here. I have dragged several of my fellow carnivorous compadres to this delightful little restaurant, and they too have been converted to Veggie Heaven fandom.

The restaurant doesn't have the best atmosphere but if you're looking for a place to get a quick bite to eat at a very affordable price then this is a good place to look.

DONUTS DONUTS DONUTSS.

Skip the cookies here ladies and gents, the donuts are where its at. 

I used to be huge fan of the glazed buttermilk, then moving onto the cinnamon sprinkles glazed buttermilk and the chocolate covered buttermilk but I now am firmly in the apple fritter camp. Only thing is they run out of apple fritters fast and make new ones at random times so be warned they may not have it when you come. 

They use no trans-fat too so you should use that to justify eating a dozen. 

Glazed maple bars are melt in your mouth goodness as are the swirled cinnamon and the cinnamon twist. 

However, I would absolutely advise NOT TO EAT ANY OF THOSE DELICIOUS LOOKING CAKES. They have been out there a very, VERY long time and will be stale and tough. Believe me. i have tried. Even the donut guy tried warning me not to buy it... 

Really good for a late night munchies craving since they close at 3AM. 

Bottom line: you love donuts? You love king pin.

I've been going to the Little Chef for months, but I want to chime in on the positive reviews.  Pouchon makes exquisite croissants.  The brioches are pretty good, too.  The almond croissant is my favorite, with the plain croissant a close second... simple, buttery, and the crust shatters in your mouth with every bite.  A weekly indulgence.  We like to be there just as Pouchon's taking them out of the oven.

We've also had a few cakes from here for special occasions, which were also lovely.  The chocolate mousse cake was well done -- so light and melt-in-your-mouth.

Anyway, to summarize: Pouchon = absolute legend.

the original review below still applies but i just wanted to add a little more food for thought:

i was watching top chef DC the other day.. and tom colicchio was talking about how the worst thing you could do to a salad is to serve it in a bowl bc when you put toppings like croutons, salad dressing, nuts, fruits, whatever on it in a bowl it gets weighed down and the leaves get wilted and oversaturated with gunk.  putting it on a plate allows you to refresh the salad, move it around, throughout the meal~

and that's when i thought.. i need to add an update to my dressed review.

I stopped in purely out of curiousity, because I can't even remember the last time I ate at a Bob's Big Boy.  It must be 15 years at least!  The remodel is actually quite nice, especially if you get a booth (see pic).  The covered patio also has heaters and ceiling fans, but not sure if those are holdovers from when this was a Baja Fresh.

At any rate, the food is unremarkable.  Salad & turkey sandwich on grilled sourdough are very standard, and competently prepared.  The menu reminds you a lot of Dennys, and whether that's good/bad/neutral, I'm gonna leave that up to you.  Breakfast food is served all day.

My server, however, was extremely polite and very on top of it, so that's the main reason this Bob's Big Boy pulls up to 3 stars.  Hey corporate and store manager - this guy spared you from getting the oh-so dreaded 2 stars.

Everyone is complaining about the kimchi...i'm more about the meat.

This place is getting expensive (and they're starting to skimp on the meat)!  I remember my freshman year it was at least two dollars cheaper, but I guess everything is going up now (looks down the street at the strikers).

I like the spicy pork and even the chicken over the veggies is good.  Also, i forgot what it's called something with meat, veggies, and the glass noodles...really good, you get rice and noodles!  I don't really like the short ribs and i only see korean people actually ordering the soup dishes.  If you smile really big and ask nicely, sometimes they'll put an egg on top for free = ) (haha i'm assuming it's only for the girls)  overally, good bbq for college students

Thanks to all you Yelpers for getting me psyched about this place -- I finally made it over there tonight.

Excellent pizza, and super-fast turn-around since the ovens are so incredibly hot.  Standing around and taking in the baking process for 10 minutes was worth it.  I didn't even think about trying to grab a seat given the crowd and all...

Not knowing the "ins and outs" of pizza and relying soley on taste + texture, I think Max's Coal Oven pizza is just as good.  That said, I'm giving it the same rating I gave Max's.  (note -- you can actually sit at Max's and it's less expensive)

One.  That is what this place would get if the service wasn't as friendly as it is.  This place tries to be something it isn't.  It's a great concept with very poor execution. I love the location so I was really hoping this would be good.

The thing is that I've been here more than once and even once for a wine tasting, thinking that my first experience was a fluke.  It was not. I really wonder what went into the making of this restaurant.  If the restaurant were a person, it would be THAT person who thinks he/she can sing (but can't) and goes to karaoke thinking everyone is enjoying the performance.

I wasn't that impressed with their wine tasting that I went to.  There wasn't a single wine that I was remotely interested in at the event.  The worst thing is their cheese selection in the specialty shop next door.  Unless they've changed things around (and maybe they have), it is a very limited cheese case, with poor selection.  It doesn't seem much thought goes into selecting the cheeses.  Many of them are very generic cheeses in the cheese world and not necessarily good cheeses.  You're much better off going to Alon's in the Highlands, Star Provisions, or even certain Whole Foods.  I may be overly critical, but I'm a bit of a cheese buff and was sorely disappointed with this place.

The only thing I do like about the place is that I've had decent service.

Primanti's is a Pittsburgh instituition and they make the single greatest sandwich in the world!  Whether it is late night after the bars are closed, in the middle of the day for lunch, or just for the heck of it for dinner there is nothing better than a pastrami and fries w/ slaw!

Dale is great. He is quick but efficient, funny, amusing, and one of the best hair stylists I have ever had! I left his salon feeling like a new woman, watch out boys. ;)

After having a horrible dye job at another salon in Berkeley, I decided to try Dale. First, I walked into the elegant former Hearst Castle designer's "Durant Hotel" where I found Dale's salon to be nestled in a clean and comfortable atmosphere. I came in without a picture but just told Dale, "I want no red influence in my blonde hair and need a touch up." Needless to say, when I walked out, I felt like a new woman. My hair was perfect, softer then I have ever felt, smooth, cut to my liking and the price was very reasonable. I had paid almost twice as much at the former salon I went to and only got a 1/2 highlight that was "to be blonde" but came out brown- I was not happy and it was before a hugh event- really not happy.

Dale is great. I will be back and will recommend all my friends to him! See for yourself why everyone who goes to him gives his salon a 5 star rating!!!!

University Gateway opened a Subway, CVS pharmacy, and Seattle's Best Coffee within a few blocks of my apartment. It is now even more convenient for me to grab supplies for my apartment, and I don't have to settle for Starbuck's anymore.

Good service from the older gentleman who is always taking the orders. Food is cooked fast and it all tastes pretty dang good without being too oily. The good is actually chinese for the most part (except the pho) and is amazingly cheap (6 total for many of the entrees). Only downside is that they are cash only. I can't even count the number of times I wanted to ready here only to find that I didn't have any paper money on me...

Just heard the news that Doc's is now Mario's!  After looking at the menu, I facebook begged my husband to go with me, and he took me up on the offer.  

I'm a fan.  It's a great improvement over Doc's.  There's nothing that overtly stands out, but it just as a classier feel, and the bar is pushed back further so it isn't taking up the whole front room.  It feels roomier, and has a better vibe than Doc's.  We were there for happy hour - $5 apps and 1/2 off drinks.  They seemed to offer other great specials throughout the week too.  We shared some pub fries (thin cut, slathered in cheese and bacon, and of course a side of ranch...they were delish), then I got spicy ranch wings (12 for a $5...good deal!), which were crispy, and also quite good.   Not the best I've ever had but I'd give them a 8.5 out of 10.  It was probably mostly my fault - I had been hoping for a saucy wing (like the hidden valley spicy ranch dressing) and it turned out to be more of a dry wing.  My husband got the Big Lou (or something like that) sandwich.  Mozarella sticks, chicken tenders, fries, and marinara sauce and he said it was amazing.  He really really liked the vibe of the place.

Service was fast, attentive, and pleasant.  

We will definitely be repeat customers.  

Great improvement over Doc's.

So as nice as Dave is, this place is overpriced and not worth the steep cost.  A haircut cost me twenty bucks and on top that, it was probably one of the worst haircuts I have ever gotten.  It was honestly my mistake as a freshman of going to this establishment not knowing that there are other places that have better prices and quality.

If these guys could fix their meat sauce, Hot Dog Charlie's would be incredible. 

Our little Capital District hot dog micro-region is defined by these diminutive dogs slathered with a line of mustard, a spoonful of raw onion, and topped with meat sauce.

If you were from Michigan, you would say it's like a Coney only smaller.

Anyhow, Hot Dog Charlie's does great things with their buns and dogs. The buns are steamed, and the dogs are gently warmed, keeping them plump and juicy with a nice snap to the casing. But they completely fall down on the raw spice graininess in the sauce. 

But of the holy trinity of these joints - Hot Dog Charlie's, Gus's and Famous Lunch - the sauce holds this long beloved establishment back to second place in the great regional hot dog war.

This is a great place to look for CDs and DVDs.

Used CDs and DVDs can literally be $2 (used).

They've got a great selection.

The downside?  Finding what you want in the Used sections.  They do a nice job of organizing by genres, but I wish they could do alphabetical organization too.

I just finished falafel over rice and it was pretty good. I think it would be a bit bland for people who prefer strong flavors and spices, but it worked just fine for me. It had 5 small falafel balls, rice, a few fries, and a bit of lettuce & tomato mix. My only complaint is that the falafel didn't seem super fresh - probably had been fried before and reheated. The halal cart at 116th and Broadway (NW corner) fries falafel as you wait, which takes about 2 minutes longer, but you know it's fresh and hasn't been sitting in oil for hours. That falafel is also a bit more spicy.

Overall a very good meal - will come back.

The thing that makes this place valuable is that it is dirt cheap and on Telegraph. Getting there is more trouble than it is worth though. I don't like driving/parking around Telegraph around dinner time and Berkeley has so many other places worth the drive. What IS awesome though is www.getnudesuhi.com. Getnude is the internet-based sushi delivery service that is run out of Tako until 4 am. Who needs to eat at nasty Denny's when they can have sushi delivered? (Berkeley only.) Oddly enough, the price is not horrible for delivery. Error rate is low because you never talk to anyone. It's very amazon.com--you add rolls to cart. Don't drive to this place; make them drive to you.

I've been known to have no other business in Berkeley, but have an urge  to hop on the BART, pick up some frozen yogurt and walk around before returning to the city.

It's good, it's cheap, and it's plentiful.  The large and medium sizes from a distance might fool you - it's bigger than it looks.

Yogurt Park, even your name has some sort of odd atheistic ring to it.

Don't let the name fool you, it's not Korean.

Had a very tasty brunch here. Wasn't super busy, as I was worried it would be, and we sat on the nice patio. I liked that my ice tea was served with a bottle of lemon simple syrup to sweeten it. My husband got the Pamlico Sound omelette, with crab, corn, and a Bearnaise sauce. It was light, herby, and tasty, although the sauce was so subtle it almost wasn't there. 

I felt compelled to get the shrimp and grits I'd been wanting to try for so long and they did not disappoint. Rich, salty, and creamy. Divine. Shrimp, bacon, and cheese grits are a culinary holy trinity. The only thing I would change about the dish is to have fewer scallions thrown in. 

We are definitely coming back for dinner sometime.

BEAT THE CLOCK (every Friday at 4pm) is where its at, its so fucking crowded though so you better come here early to get a seat.  The pitchers start at 5 bucks and they go up a dollar every hour.

The service gets pretty fucking bad, you get ignored a lot sometimes and sometimes you don't, but for 5 bucks for a fucking pitcher of hef it's pretty worth it.  

What sucks is that you get shit faced by 630 and the sun is still up and you're too tired to do shit the rest of the day.  But if you got the drunk munchies like I do order the food they have here or walk up the street to Desi Dog for some bomb and cheap ass hotdog/sausages.

I give it a three because it is across the street from my favorite site in NYC and because it reminds me of Cafe Roma in Isla Vista (the old one) at UCSB.  I suppose the only parallels are that it is a major Columbia co-ed hangout, they have coffee and yummy bakery items.

Be prepared to fight for a spot and to have the baristas look at you like you're an alien. Be prepared to be squeezed in like you've never been squeezed in before listening to the kid sitting next to you with his dad, chastise his dad while he stuffs his face with a plate full of sugar.

It is a great hang out to get some writing done and watch the college students prosylitize about their great knowledge and wisdom of the universe.  Ah...the Ivy League.

The atmosphere is sleek and trendy and is the first thing I noticed about this caf in Tech Square (the edge of Georgia Tech's campus on 5th street). Other than being incredibly out of place (no Tech students can afford these gourmet prices), it somehow fills up with business folks relaxing like they would in France sitting at rot iron tables under the lush green trees lining the courtyard. If you step inside you'll seen white shelves holding an array of crisp green glass bottles. Take a look closely and you'll notice they are San Pellegrino bottles, Italian mineral water.  There are a couple of smell settees (English word for sofas) with a selection of Vogues and GQs strategically placed on light wooden coffee tables. The bar is off to the right, fully stocked and with guests sitting on the swivel white stools.

The menu is a simply gourmet, and even the chef becomes an artists with his placement of garnishes on the sleek white plates.

The drinks menu continues the trend of sleek and upscale business class. I've tried the Momo Special, the Globe's twist on the mojito, and the Italian Job with a mix of fruit juices and campari.  Cocktails and glasses of wine range from $8 - $11. Reasonable if you appreciate well mixed drinks in a trendy atmosphere. However, I still think the location is odd.

A big YELP to Erin C. for tipping me off on this BYOB restaurant. I am glad she did. I now stop every time I am in Providence. Huge portions here! One tip: Order 1 thing each and share.
See my YELP list of other fine BYOB establishments all over New England.

Here I am, the food snob from Los Angeles trying to tackle all the food joints we have tried since moving here. Basmati is not good. And no offense to the other poster but authentic it is not! The food is watered down and they use small frozen shrimp for their seafood dishes. The salad at the buffet is always limp, telling me that the food has been sitting around....not something I want to enter my mouth! Anyways, if you know Indian this will not be the place for you. If you actually like good Indian go over to Bombays on campus, now this is great food!

Love Love Love this studio, spacious with ac in the lobby to welcome you back to a life of non self inflicted torture ahemmm, I mean health. 4 showers, more space in the studio as well so you can really spread your wings and lift up and go up... you will get that joke after taking your first class here witch I suggest you do! DRINK 120 oz h2o if you can, 3 liters minimum, you will pee a lot so plan water drinking carefully if you have a commute to class... I was dancing outside the studio door once pretty bad!
Nice park for the biotech working class and MIT kids

The food's greasy and really isn't a good combination with alcohol unless you have a really good book in the bathroom.

Nevertheless I still crave the chicken salad once in a while.  I would get it with all the fix'ns:  chihuahua cheese, peppers, sour cream, avocado (not guac... avocado :) ), extra hot sauce... (which they make fresh, btw) 

I never thought that I'd miss this place, but man I do.  I've had few dishes at any Mexican place that I've enjoyed as much as their chicken salad.

Oh and if you do get the chicken salad, get it to go.  You get waaaaay more.

Not only does this place have the best Ice cream sandwiches in the world, but it will always play dear to my heart. This was my spot with one of the true loves of my life. Every time I eat here I will always remember her. Thank for the good food and Memories.

I grabbed a quick steak quesadilla for $6 on special and it was loaded with steak, peppers and cheese. It basically hit the spot. It looks like they have a good beer selection and drink specials as well.

Although I think the best puerto rican food is found in my kitchen, Izzy's isn't a bad alternative if your not my friend and can't get free food from me.

When I lived in a kitchen-less dorm I would frequent Izzy's. It's very small Puerto Rican place in Cambridge between Central Sq and MIT. It serves fairly good Puerto Rican food...it truly is a Puerto Rican place...plastic table cloths...baseball memoriabilia on the walls...AND they close when the owners go on vacation to Puerto Rico. However it closes pretty early each night so I'd go before a movie and not after.

In all honesty, it's definitelly not the best Puerto Rican food I've ever had...but I live in Boston, not Puerto Rico, so considering the circumstances it'll do.

They were friendly and quickly printed up receipts for my prepaid sales returns. Not much more I could ask for. I didn't have to do anything complicated. 

Also, I kinda love this location. I can stop by on my way to U Village w/o dealing with the horrible U Village parking lot. :)

I LOVE Border Cafe. This place is the perfect spot to go with a bunch of friends of you're looking to have a great meal, good time, and not spend a lot of money.  
First off, they have unlimited tortilla chips and salsa- but like really legit housemade warm tortilla chips. But don't fill up on these because portions are huge! An entree per person is more than enough food and sometimes I even share with a girlfriend. Drinks are great too. BIG margaritas are delish and only $5-7. If you want to get real tipsy, real fast, order the Hurricane, its 3 types of rum and a bunch of juices. It tastes like a tropical vacation. 
My favorite dishes are chicken fajitas and the empanadas. You really cant go wrong though. All in all, you can get a meal and a drink for about $20 including tax and tip. You will leave totally full and probably even a bit tipsy. I'll be going back again and again!

Guess which was easier:

A) Getting a new passport, on a weekend (when Govt offices are closed), within 12 hours of discovering your old one expired and 12 hours before you're leaving the country,

                             or

B) Getting two passport photos from Kinko's
Delicious taro smoothies and tasty vegan cookies!

It wasn't amazing, nothing special.  Mediocre ice cream.

The guy at the counter was friendly though, we talked about which Berkeley (dance team?) girl we thought was the cutest looking on a poster.  Hahaha.  

We ordered a small cup of chocolate chip cookie dough for $2.25, and an Arizona tea.
The ice cream could of tasted better.  I wish there were more cookie dough chunks in there.  Didn't seem like there were much.  And the whole cup wasn't filled packed.  I guess I just expected it to maybe have been a slightly bigger scoop, to fill in the spaces of the cup more.

This place is awesome. The appetizer was a pureed black bean dip over warm, crispy tortilla chips that was accompanied by an orange salsa that was super-spicy (but delicious). I ordered the grilled white fish over a bed of rice and red sauce. It was seasoned perfectly, and the fish was not overcooked. The fried plantains were also yummy. The customer service was excellent too. Our waitress (I wish I remembered her name) was very attentive and sweet. I'd go back any day.

About a decade ago, my Thai boyfriend (now husband) took me here on a date. At the time I had little opinion about Thai food, but he obviously did...and this was one of his favorite Thai restaurants. All I remember from that night was that he had requested every dish to be ridiculously SPICY, yet it was all quite delicious.

We revisited Thai House recently, and we naturally had high expectations for the food. We ordered noodle soups (duck and seafood) and salad (yum neau) that tasted pitifully Americanized. Based on this one disappointing meal, we figured something must have happened over the past years. Moreover, the prices had increased; they are no longer so student-friendly.

The place looked more worn out, too. The service was slow. Maybe we went on the wrong day. Maybe not. 

SUM: We've definitely experienced better, and I'm sure there are newer and more authentic Thai restaurants in the city of Berkeley yet to be discovered.

Wow. This place is tricksy. They lured me in with the convenient location--the building right next to where I work--and the delicious DESCRIPTIONS of the food... and then something really horrible on a plate is served.

It kinda says something when the bread of a sandwich is harder than the croutons on the salad. And boy are the flavors off--all I tasted was stale bread and hot mustard. If that counts as "taste". Worst part is, it was really not worth the strain on my wallet. If you ask me, if you want something "light and healthy" in the area, you're better of going to Subway.

I was on the 2nd floor. Nice crowd size. Friendly staff. Didn't seem to dirty. Fun enough mix of booty shakin' music. 

Please add alcohol to your scorpion bowls. 

Cash only.

Relatively nice selection--bigger than Kuhli's, anyway, though I wish there were some Indian soft drinks like Limca and Thums Up!. Friendly staff, who reminded me about two deals that I was only taking advantage of half of a BOGO. 

And very clever in including an American aisle for the college students who have no other grocery stores in walking distance since Giant Eagle closed down a few years ago.

I injured my back earlier this year while running.  My back doctor recommended that I see Saxena to see if I need orthotics for my running shoes, since she thought not having them may have caused my injury or contributed to it.  

I saw Saxena last Friday.  He was late.  His nurse was rude and another one of his nurses kept knocking on the door and asking about another patient.  Throughout the whole exam, I got the impression that I wasn't important enough and that he really didn't want to treat me.  Towards the end of the visit, I asked him if he thought my feet may have contributed to my injury and out of nowhere he says, "You're a bit heavier than you need to be for running."

The funny thing is that if he had looked at my weight data (which PAMF has a pretty complete record of), he would have seen that I've lost about 70 pounds in the past few years.  And I lost a lot of that weight running.  And even if I hadn't lost any weight, I'm not sure that being overweight means that I'm not supposed to run.  It was almost like he said "You're too short to run" or "Your hair is too curly to run" or "You're too Arab to run."  His comment just felt really harsh and judgemental.

I realize that being thinner means that running is easier (I experienced that first hand - you know the whole losing 70 pounds thing).  But I didn't ask him for running advice.  And given that he's not my primary care doctor and that all I was seeing him for was orthotics, I really don't think my weight should have come up.

My friend and I were checking out Harvard square on one of our sightseeing stops of Boston when our stomachs indicated it was lunchtime.  We spotted a restaurant that looked pretty packed, which is usually a good sign of good food.  I felt somewhat apprehensive since I hadn't Yelp'd this place, but we went in anyways.  The place had character and yes it was rather crowded.  I loved the names of the burgers.  I had the Viagra :) my friend had the veggie burger with sweet potato fries.  The burgers were okay.  Apple Pan and Father's Office back home in LA had tastier burgers.  It was cool to try out, but I wouldn't go again.

If you love ice cream and cookies and you're on a tight budget, this is the place to go!

I got the ice cream sandwich with m&m cookies and cookies and cream ice cream for ONLY $1.50. ONLY. 

To be quite honest, it's not the MOST extraordinary ice cream sandwich I've tasted; however, it's definitely worth your money because it's so cheap yet still pretty delicious. Not to mention, that their portions are big too!!

This place deserves 5 stars because it's cheap yet the ice cream sandwich is big AND yummy!

I'm defintely looking forward to making another trip!

YUMMY! Mexican food is the bomb! Actually, I came here for breakfast and got the veggie omelet. At 6.95 with lots of veggies and not a whole lot of oil, this is great. I would love to come back and try their mexican dishes. YUM YUM.

I have still yet to find a better burger. With reasonable prices They cant be beat. 

Just be sure to get the burger the way the house cooks it.

First off I need to nail one pet peeve. IT'S STANFORD CARDINAL, not
STANFORD CARDINALS BRO-SKIMORONDOUCHBAGERBROSKI 

The "Patman" loves Basketball and the "Patman" was really looking forward to seeing a game here to complete "Patmans" tri-fecta of seeing Stanford CARDINAL play Cal in Football, Soccer and hoops since The "Patman" now lives on the Peninsula side of the Bay.

 Patman loves Basketball and the Patman followeds it often. the Patman also has allegiance to his College Basketball program, but follows the Bay Area sports scene pretty close. the Patman enjoyed the afternoon and saw Cal clinch the PAC-10 conference championship for the first time in fitty years so the Patman will always remember that. Overall the Patman was not impressed with the digs at Maples. The Patman felt it was cramped, and the seats that the Patman sat on, like the Football stadium were not at all comfortable. The building and the Stanford campus itself are all five stars and beyond, although the Patman felt the stadium was dated and for a 3PM game on a Saturday the Patman felt there was no ventilation and was very warm. 

OK, seriously, this is a great venue with allot of great History, but simply put, there is no ventilation. I loved it and look forward to coming back many more times in the future.

cool store with a lot of diverse products - not just house wares, they also had some very funky jewelry at pretty reasonable prices, some nice books and toys for kids, and more .. the girl working in the store was friendly and the only complaint i have is they have too much stuff i want to buy! had no idea such a cool little area existed downtown .. some other cool shops around here.

My partner and I were visiting Ithaca for a day, and, knowing Ithaca's reputation for used bookstores, spent a good portion of our day's wanderings perusing different "book barns." We stopped into Autumn Leaves while waiting to eat dinner, and easily spent a good hour browsing through the selection of political science, cultural studies, cultural criticism, and even the Youth Literature sections. We were impressed with the organization of this bookstore compared to some others we'd seen that day, and I also appreciated the bright lighting and ample comfy seating. The store manager was nice and amiable, and we felt comfortable hanging out and reading while we tried to kill time. We didn't even realize there was an upstairs until much later, because the first floor was so absorbing. 

My partner finally found the Angela Davis book he'd been trying to find all day. I dunno if that speaks to Autumn Leaves' selection or their organization, but either way, we liked it!
This place has great sandwiches, soups and pastries, with a cute and cozy setting. This and Starlife are my favorite U-District coffee shops. Try the biscotti!

To me and BF this is the best place on the ave to get pho.  Not only is it flavorful, but you get a lot of it.  Get the Xl pho and count on having this a few times.  The price you can't beat.  Only draw back for us is that they don't serve booze, oh well we get it to go.

Lines...lines...lines...that's what you will encounter here. BUT us SoHa (south Harlem ;) ) folks have no other pharma options. The couple of shinning points: a good selection of food/personal items and nice staff, though they do close early 9 or 10ish typically.

I'm a bit surprised by the other reviews, my experience here was quite memorable. We went here to celebrate a friend's birthday. I had the bouillabaisse and it was cooked impeccably- the stock they used was divine.

OH GOD, SO GOOD!! Everything I have ordered here has always been good. The prices are decent, the portions are good, and the pasta is QUALITY for what you are paying. I think my favorite would be the pollo gorgonzola (I LOVE CHEESE) and the pesto penne. I also like how they give you a piece of bread with garlic on it...delicious! If you need Italian close to the Berkeley campus, this is the place to go!

The Canopy was formerly the Thunderbird Theater and is a converted movie theater.  It is a live music venue for the most part.  The front bar area is used as a "small hall" for intimate shows.  The larger room has a sloped floor (old theater, remember) and has limited seating downstairs depending on the show.  There are movie seats in the balcony, but the balcony may be closed.  

A reasonable variety of shows come through the Canopy and tickets are usually reasonably priced.  Some pretty big names have passed there, both before and after they "hit it big".  

I've spent many a Tuesday night there drinking the tastiest $2 Long Island Iced Teas I've ever had.  They used to have open mics on Tuesday nights and it was a good time, but have changed the format in the last year or so.

As of this writing, you can get "delivery" from Manolo's Pizza right around the corner -- very yummy and creative take on the usually pizza and empanadas on campus.

Jay Goldberg Entertainment also puts on this festival in Chillicothe, Illinois each year.

www.summercampfestival.com

A great addition to the neighborhood! They will definitely take up the slack from the void left by the departure of McCray's to the suburbs.  This place has a cool, laid back vibe but yet remains quite stylish.  The fresh and simple bar food is surpisingly delicious.  They also pay attention to quality: no cheap sour mix for cocktails, they muddle fresh lemons and limes to concoct their drinks.  The patio is sure to be the bomb, as soon as the weather cooperates.

Great place, cool location, super friendly service, nice drive up/old school style restaurant with nice patio and seating area. But you may wonder why two stars? For the pita and hummus only. The prices are not that great, kinda expensive and the service is extremely slow. It took about 20 minutes each of the two times I have been there to get my food. Usually I only take a 30 minutes for lunch, but had to take a 45 minute the last time I went due to the food taking so long. And as much as I want this place to succeed and be good, the food is just not that good. The meat on my chicken shishkebob was blah. I think they tried to rely on the red onions too much and it just didn't work at all, and being allergic to red onions, it doesn't help everything is cooked with red onions. The beef plate I got the first time was ok, but not anywhere close to any of the other Mediterranean restaurants around here. I wish them well and want them to succeed, but this will probably be the last time going there.

Buck Fiddys is definitely best when you're piss drunk. I prefer the burritos over anything else. Here's the thing: there are two little stands directly next to each other. One is Roll In, which has sandwiches and stuff. The other place doesn't have a name. I've never eaten at Roll In. Just the other place, cause they have the delicious burritos for $3 and cheap burgers and fries as well. I get the chicken burrito with avocado, although I've had the chili burrito (yeah, a chili burrito, it's that kind of place) and that's good as well. If you're drunk.

I went to Buck Fiddys today and there was a homeless dude who was so incredibly annoying. He asked me to buy him food and I told him I'd give him the chips from my burrito. He replied, "I was trying to get a burger." Don't you sass me, homeless man! Later he stood uncomfortably close to me and started ranting about overpopulation and how we're all reptilian creatures. I finally got so fed up that I just went up to the counter and grabbed some food and left. As I walked up Gayley I opened the bag and realized the food wasn't mine. I wanted to bring it back. I really did. But I couldn't stand to be around that fucking homeless dude again. By the way, he had a cell phone. Homeless people don't have cell phones!!

Everything food (and drink and music) is fabulous here but try the goat cheese appetizer, the dates/bacon app, the fish and chips dinner, and the new wings especially! I also love the BLT@E sandwich (E stands for "egg"!)! The menu is not extensive, but everything on it is TOP-QUALITY and finely done! 

The background music is always new and great and unobtrusive, but easy enough to follow if you wish. We have frequently asked who/what something was, because it was especially of interest. The bartenders and servers are knowledgeable and friendly, unusual anymore. As time goes on, I find that a wider cross-section of the area is visiting the place...nice that we're not the "old folks" anymore! We never go there during weekend nights, though...INCREDIBLY popular, but not so much our speed as other times. We try to get there early, exploit them for their amazing food and drink, then duck out as the hipsters start amassing...lol Best place in town for checking out the latest fashions and fads- love people watching Great beer selections, which rotate and include hoppy AND not-hoppy choices, which is nice. Good wines and GREAT cocktails! Try the whiskey smash...amazing! Watch for seasonal food choices, too...they love trying new and interesting things and I love taking advantage of it!

i dont give out 5 stars lightly... but legal had the best oysters, surf & turf, and steamers ive ever had. maybe it was the freshness of everything, or the awesomeness of BJ the waiter, but the entire dining experience was delightful. the lobster was huge and meaty, and the chowder did not disappoint either. we came with a group of 9 in short notice and had no trouble getting seated quickly. 5 stars for Legal Sea Foods!!

Backroom Pizza is a little treasure that Freshmen will find as they drunkenly walk back to their dorms after a night of partying. Down the road, they will realize that it will become a staple of their post-partying adventures; and for this Senior, it most certainly has.

Everyone gets a bit hungry after trying to push through crowds of people at house parties, or making a trek to a hot spot, or even playing a tough game of beer pong. For those looking to get their munch on for less than $2 a slice, Backroom pizza is the place to be. 

The pizza is surprisingly good for such a cheap price; and that's while tasting it sober! So you know it seems like a culinary oasis when there's nothing but carbonation and hops in your liver. 

The employees are quick and there never seems to be a shortage of pizza. You might even tip them a little extra because their service, the pizza, and the satisfaction was spectacular.

The only downfall is that this place is tiny, which means the lines can become incredibly long. The good news is that the service is quick, and they always have pizza ready. So if you're patient, you'll get your pizza in no time.

Also, I'm not sure if they accept credit/debit cards. At a price so cheap though, I don't see who would offer. I've never tried to pay with anything else but cash. So just make sure to have cash handy. 

Cheap, quick, and delicious. After a night of fun, no matter where home is, stumble on down to Backroom for some surprisingly good pizza. Just make sure it doesn't come back up before the night is over you inexperienced Freshmen!

My roommate got a big box of Sweet cupcakes as part of a promotion, so I got to try a few (chocolate, vanilla, coconut, red velvet, and something else...).  The cakes are dense and super sweet, and the icing is buttercream style, way-saccharine, and over dosed.  I can't help but think that these taste just like every supermarket cupcake I've ever had: no intense flavor, mass-produced.  I'm a little disappointed. The reviews about the coconut cupcake are right, too.  It kinda tastes like cement.
The coffee sucks, the expensive drinks are good. Free refills on iced tea.

Great food, great music. I went to a 'sold out' show last weekend and it was pretty awesome. Awesome because there was so much space they easily could have let 50% more people in.  Also there is no 'back stage area' so the artist usually is in the crowd before they come on.  or selling their own swag at the tables in the back.

 Place serves beer, lines are super short because most college students are under age. I really wish this was here when I went to school. 

Parking does suck, but it is a cool little trek to walk around and feel all college-y. I went to school here and I still sort of get lost with all the new buildings.

The Magnolia Lounge is as good as it looks on Yelp. It is a cozy, romantic, and dark bar/lounge awesome for dates or to have a good time with your friends. You can sit at the small bar, a separate room with larger tables or on the sides with tables for two. The menu isn't too diverse, but what I ordered was good. Alcoholic beverages are expensive. The prices are not even mentioned on the menu card.Other than that come here if you want to have a more chill night with no dancing, or if you wanna warm up for a longer night out.
Same as sharkeys. Pretention and inane talk

I went here on a really nice Spring day with some friends. They dragged me there...I had no clue what to expect. I loved it! 

The location was really nice atop some steps about The Radian. The inside was really nice as well, boasting extremely high ceilings with really cool decor/accents. The layout was just really nice and relaxing. 

There were few people there so I did not experience any of the service issues that other reviewers mention. The waiting staff was pretty quick, courteous, and incredibly attractive O:).

I got a Stretch Chicken sandwich, fries, and sampled some of my friend's Belgian waffle. I never had Stretch Chicken before but it was amazing. Completely balanced price and portion and just so tender it melted right in my mouth basically. Just a really cool, textural experience you don't have every day with chicken. The roasted red pepper complimented the taste really well too. The fries were good as well: nothing exciting, but nothing bad at all. 

My friend's Belgian waffle was really good but at the price, I wouldn't really recommend it when you can get much hardier, "foodier" selections instead. Otherwise, if just looking for sweets though, it definitely does its job.

All in all, nice, QUIET place to go with some friends. I stress the quiet because I loathe places that are all about alcohol and completely anti-conversation. No loud music, a great view, good company and good food all makes for a great lunch :).

I got my first tattoo here after I turned 18. The tattoo itself isn't the bad part, I just felt it was way overpriced. 

It was black and grey and on the smaller side as far as tattoos go, but cost me $200 without tip. I just got another piece at another shop that was in color and a little more than 3 times the size for $350 without tip. 

Of course, the rest of the process was nice. Not too long of a wait, especially for a walk-in, and the people are nice.

P.S. I'm not saying that money is the deal breaker for a tattoo. Because it shouldn't be. But, for the amount of money I paid, I don't think the quality is as good as it could have been.

Some people have said that this is a great breakfast burrito.  I will disagree slightly it was of nice size and great fillings like Avacado and fresh eggs and ham yet I found the whole package a little on the bland side even with tons of salsa. The price is right though and unless u are starving u can split one with a friend. On Tuesdays bogo that's a nice feature. Nice little place.

This is probably the first place to open and last place to close at the LuValle Commons, which makes it super convenient with class schedules. They have a great breakfast menu; I believe they make custom omelets every morning. Their burgers are pretty good; I am a fan of the veggie burger and chicken burgers. They also have chicken strips but I haven't tried them. The service is really slow so be prepared to wait. Their sauce is good as are the onion rings. Burger, drink, and fries is about $4-$5 a person.

I came for some laughs and I left with vomit on my shoes!

Wow!  I mean, Wow!   I heard that Earl's was a dive/college bar and I heard correctly.   I met some friends there last night to celebrate being finished with a round of exams and at first I was kind of enjoying myself.  Even though I felt too old to be in Earl's, it was cool because it reminded me of every college bar I went to back in the day- dirt cheap drinks and dirt dirt floor. 

We were all hanging out and enjoying ourselves when a little sorority girl came over and ordered two shots of Jack.  She and her friend "downed" the biggest $4 shots I have ever seen.   They giggled and then they vomited on the floor, my shoes, and a friend's jacket.    

So, although they have great drink prices, pool tables, and dart boards, they do not have rain gear rentals to protect yourself from sorority vomit.

Love the food...very friendly and actually amazing.  3rd time there...BUT, the service is anything but friendly..c'mon people...lighten up and make this a positive experience to bring out of town friends.  Very willing to wait for a table but would then like at least  a friendly server!!  Please..just fake it if you have to!

I found this place today by accident, following a random funky looking chick to see where the hell she was headed and voila! Paper Heaven was found! A little like Aladdin's Cave it has everything that I never knew I needed in life! Blow up balls describing different fish, hilarious magnets, funny as f**k t-shirts, great cards for all occasions or just to amuse yourself, kitschy gag gifts, just plain fun! I ended up killing 45 minutes and $75 on gifts for other people that I know will make them smile. Left of center, this store has a little something for everyone that has a funny bone in their body!

I worked in marketfair for about 4-5 years and never went to sunny garden (the former hanami), however i knew how much it was beloved and enjoyed. So, when looking for somewhere to have a late-ish friday night dinner with the SO, we decided to drive over and see if Hanami was any good. 

It's Chinese food, but in a really beautiful environment. Perfect for groups, as many familes and girls-night-outs and groups of couples were enjoying. We were seated immediately and our server came around to take our drink order. 

Now, a big note- this place is BYOB. We totallly neglected this, and taht was the one downside of our experience, since SO likes to have a little wine or cocktail with his meal. However, they have fun tea drinks that they make. He got a fruity one that was good, a little too sweet for me. 

They feature Japanese and Chinese food and have a full sushi bar. Will have to check that our next time, but SO got a raw tuna dish served over seasoned rice and I got the spicy chicken, eggplant, shrimp, and squid plate, with brown rice. So good! And there were several pieces of jumbo shrimp in the dish. The serving was perfect- enough to fill me up, and enough to bring home to enjoy later. 

Will definitely check this place our again when we are looking for a place when we go out with friends for dinner date night. This time with some wine from Trader Joe's!

I found the staff to be attentive and helpful and the ambiance is nice. But I do not think I will be coming back here. 

This was my first time eating here, but from what I could tell, you can learn a lot about the performance of Eve's kitchen from watching the performance of the owner on Top Chef: food is inconsistent, over seasoned and sometimes is combined in ways that make little sense. 

CONS: 

Food is inconsistent: I ordered the soft shell crab (special for the night) and it arrived incredibly over-salted. I complained to the server and she admitted that other people had been complaining about this throughout the night. This is not the server's fault, but I do blame the kitchen for continuing to put out a dish that people had been complaining about. If it is no good, than don't do it. Cut your losses and walk away. 

The server worked really hard to make things up to us. She comped us gazpacho (which was delicious) and had my dish redone.  When it arrived the second time, it was much less salty (but still too salty), worse,  one of the crabs had a distinct "fishy" taste to it that suggested that it may have been off. I eat a lot of seafood and this is the first time this has ever happened to me. 

To their credit, they graciously offered to make me another dish (if this was my table, I would have wanted to murder a customer like me), and I had the macadamia encrusted salmon. This was much better - it was cooked just long enough and the texture was bang on (although I would have appreciated it if the macadamia nuts were a little more seared rather than warm and soft).  

The lesson: I would stay away from the daily specials until they have some time to get things right. 

Food is overseasoned: the crab, the rice and the salmon were way overseasoned, especially with salt. I like flavorful dishes with a lot of punch, but this meal just left me thirsty. Salt might be an easy way to make things taste good, but this was a consistent problem across dishes.

Combinations make little sense: the flavors in the butters served with the bread were all over the place, and clearly reflected an interest in novel tastes, rather than a thoughtful combination. For some reason, a pico de gaillo arrived with all my mains, even the salmon, where it clearly did not belong. 

PROS: 

Seasonal vegetables were awesome. I appreciated that they thought to include fiddleheads (very seasonal and underused) and they were cooked just right - warm, seared and crisp, a perfect al dente - all three times I tried them. 

Service was great: Wait staff worked really hard to fix the problems caused by the kitchen. Very patient and understanding. Very attentive

Ambiance is romantic: Good lighting, thoughtfully arraigned space, exposed brick etc. Nicest location in Ann Arbor

Drink selections are great: I'm a bit of a beer snob - their list is small but thoughtful. 

In short, this place might be worth going to for drinks and appetizers, but for the price of their entrees you could probably just buy a gigantic block of salt and call it a day. This is not worth the hype and fares poorly compared to Vinology or the Earle.

If  you want a indian meal that's authentic come here... because you'll get the runs as if you were getting a meal from a street cart from the streets of Delhi.

It's sad. Very sad. I like their curries. But when I eat here I flip a coin to see whether I'll be having the hershey squirts. 

I hate to talk bad about this place since I've heard such rave reviews about the SF N&C. The food is pretty decent too. I'm not even a light-weight when it comes to spicy food. Alas, my bunghole says no even though my appetite says yes. 

The meat is pretty low grade too. And I hate how you have to pay extra for rice / naan.

"Mia Za's"?  The hell?  I'm pretty sure that when I was in college ('03-'07), this place was just plain old "Za's."  But that was back in the DAY, back when shit was REAL.

It's true, this place has no personality, but the food is serviceable and I like building my own pizza/salad/sandwich/pasta dish.  The pizza crust is super-thin and crispy, and I like that the salads are ENORMOUS.  The pasta...I could live without.  I don't know why, but it kind of reminded me of pasta they might serve in the dorms.  GOOD dorm pasta, yes, but still dorm pasta.  Maybe that makes sense only in my head?

I looovveee Sunday brunch! :) This cute cafe had a very cozy atmosphere and yummy food. Thanks Kenneth F. for taking me! Being a Sunday, it was quite crowded and we had to wait about 15 minutes for a table to open up.

While I'm more of a sweet person and the boyfriend is more of savory, this place offered great choices in both. I was very impressed by the selection as well as their seasonal menu. We ended up ordering a french toast (half order) and an egg's benedict, and a side of rosemary potatoes to share. I thought the egg's benedict was good but the french toast was a little dry. The potatoes were well seasoned and made the perfect side. One of the coolest things I liked about this place was that you can order all their brunch entrees as a half order for half the price. That's freaking awesome and even more awesome for not overpricing you to do so. 

I definitely want to return and try some more dishes. :)  Also while you wait for your food, they give you crayons and paper table cloth so you can draw on the table like kids again. Fun!

I lived in the Wendover building for 5 years until the rent was raised beyond my limit. 

Mozart is a bit of a double-edged sword. No deposit, but they don't clean. (results from a discrimination lawsuit from the 90's) 


The office staff can be hyper-anal, but courtesy goes a long way with some of them. There was a round of random inspections to ensure there were no pest problems that might spread. 24-hour notice is a right in other states, but for the most part, they did not abuse the right in my building. Random inspections only happened once in my 5 years and only perhaps for new tenants or if it was triggered by a reported problem. It is easier to simply clean the place and ask.

People have had bad experiences with them before, but they are a profit-maximizing firm like all others. And they do a good job for the price (that I used to pay). Favors should not be expected (unless perhaps you are one of the residents who has rented from them for more than a decade). Reciprocity does smooth out some of the rough edges.

And they do weird things sometimes. 2 new window air conditioners were forced upon me. I prefer a whole window, but they have standards and they wouldn't budge. 

The original old fridge broke after 3 years. They replaced it in an afternoon and moved all of my food. New fridge broke and they replaced it in an hour.

Mozart is a bureaucracy with its own dysfunctions and quirks.  It is mostly efficient and well run (at least they have standards). You cannot take a customer service attitude with them. Bad experiences are possible. I have been there. But it balanced out in the long run.  (This may not apply to you if you are temporarily here for 1 or 2 years.)

I've had worse.

EDIT: rating bumped to 4, Mozart actually *prefers* that you call them for maintenance issues and not let problems fester.

Best doctors you can find! But some of the nurses were rather mean, I would say 1/3 rd of them. The good nurses were extremely good, and the bad ones, extremely bad

My husband was in the ICU, asked the nurse if he could have some more cold water sprayed into his mouth to relieve the pain, here is the response - "I cannot keep doing it continuously". 

After my husband was moved to a regular room, we had some more share of bitter experiences. Couple of nurses delayed his pain medication by 1.5 - 2 hours. By the time they showed up with the pain medication, it had already reached a point where the medication was ineffective.

If you need anything around the time when the nurses are changing shifts, you are screwed. Don't expect anything sooner than 2 hours.

Loveee Roma!!
This is seriously my favorite place to go on campus for coffee or a nice, hot drink or even a bagel. My usual order is the chai latte, sometimes with soy. I've also tried their blended mocha, which is pretty good too, but I definitely prefer the chai. 

As for eatery, I've tried their blueberry scone, but after eating half of it, it does get a bit too sugary for my palette. I prefer getting a toasted jalepeno cheddar bagel, no cream cheese. If not, then the sundried tomato and the spinach parmesan bagels are great choices, too, especially if you don't like eating spicy.

Their coffee is also pretty good too; I put half and half in mine. I've also had the zebra and the almond milk tea drinks, both of which are equally good as well. I really don't know why this place got bad ratings.. It's honestly not that bad.

I know Atlanta's not on the coast, but come on?  Why have a seafood joint if it's not fresh?  

Crab legs is what everyone loves from Steamhouse.  It's dry and steamed frozen before headed to the table.  The crab dip tastes like it came from a can and the hushpuppies were average.  However, I really did enjoy the lobster bisque!  With a friend's high recommendation, I'm finally on the cool list having tasted the awesome lobster bisque.  But I'm not going there for just the bisque.

This place really is a good spot for large groups.  You can converse while eating and if you're drinking, hell, who cares about the quality of food?!  Just make room for more food once you leave Steamhouse.
I only eat chicken. The chicken sandwiches are fine, good even, but certainly not great. The fries are OK, the onion rings are OK. This place is about the aura.

This is a well organized, clean, branch of the Crossroads resale chain.  I like the prices, the very clear focus and - when selling - their very clear buying policy.

Here is a detailed report on my experience selling.  I am providing this info for folks who are trying to decide if they should bring items in. 
 
Last week I sold five items to Crossroads: a pair of Marc Jacobs pumps, pr of Diesel jeans, pr of Luckys, an American Apparel polo dress and a dressy top by Laundry.  I received $35 cash or I could have had a $50 credit.  The jury is still out for me whether it was worth it.  (call me greedy) I intentionally brought very few items in to try to track their purchasing prices.  I brought 10 items in, so they rejected a couple pairs of jags, a pr of Sevens, and a tee.

The buyer was fast and pretty friendly, I felt the rejections were okay - if a little mystifying - and I will be selling more stuff next week to see how I fare.  I have to give kudos to the staff for being friendly & helpful - so many times you go into consignment/resale places and walk out feeling like dirt.

As far as buying, I've found some great stuff here.  My kids love Harajuku anything - and we found great prices on those items.  I got a fantastic Static-X tee for $6.  Things go half off after about a month. 

The star score sums it up, "Yay!  I'm a fan."

Crowded before 8 am on a Saturday. The parking is limited, take quarters for meters just in case. It's a very old school place with tons of students and alumni chattering about the upcoming Penn State game. Lots of people seem to be regulars and know each other. 

The food rocks though. 

We both got the special. Eggs are delicious, my husband added cheese to his but I got a side of Hollandaise and mmmm. We were both overwhelmed by the meats and ended up taking a bunch home. The ham was stellar, the bacon very nice, the sausage was thick but a bit too porky for me. Hashbrowns were just ok. The raisin toast OMG, happiness. James slathered his with jelly and I got some cream cheese (they gave me three containers wow). 

The waitress was a chatty hoot, service was efficient and everyone was very friendly.

We will be back but earlier in the morning or sometime on a weekday. Definitely swing by for your birthday, get a free one with a purchase of a second.
Gots muh learning their.  Sum good shit.  And, Obama rocked then too.

Like Yogurt Park needs another great review. I just think that getting their "small" on a hot evening is one of the best treats there can be.  Great selection AND they have a phone number hotline withe flavors of the day if you wanna see what you'll be waiting in line for!

I've eaten at a lot of american-mexican places and this is my favorite of ALL of them.  Sooo good. 

The burritos seem to have the freshest ingredients of any Mexican place I've ever had (this seemingly would apply to their other menu items but i always get the burrito). Very friendly staff.  

You have to try the chips....very good.

This came up on a random google search and I just had to write the review for the memories.
Still the same place, same food, probably same guys.

Half Triple Suicide.  
Made my night after many late night lab sessions.

Thanks for the memories, guys.

Why would you go here when Berryline is so much better and locally owned?

First of all, the wait was ridiculous. Ten people in front of us and four employees and it took like 20 minutes to get to the front of the line.

The yogurt isn't any tastier than Berryline but has more calories. The prices are ridiculous.

Once again, a place that suffers from a better rep than it deserves and is super over hyped. I've learned my lesson and it's back to Berryline for me.

After discovering the heaven that is gelato, and not wanting to walk one hour to whole foods every weekend, I decided to check out this gelato place with some friends as a suggestion from my roommate. I'm really into fruit flavors, and actually, those are the only flavors I've had here. The Raspberry was good, not exceptional, but the strawberry was truly horrible...just sour with no taste. The second time I went, I got the Lime WHICH WAS AMAZING! The consistency wasn't creamy, but that didn't bother me. It was like eating lime flavored snow. SO YUMMY. and the workers are super nice, the atmosphere is good, and they have free wifi so  I can download illegal music OFF campus! Win win situation...

First of all, parking sucks! One is forced to use the vallet parking = very expensive.
I went to the L&D for ECV (external cervical version) to try to turn my baby head down at 37 weeks of pregnancy. My appointment was at 10am (I arrived 10am sharp) and ...
first of all, the nurse could not get the HUGE IV needle into my vein and had to ask her friend to do it. I am still bruised almost a week later! The nurses are not capable of answering almost any questions and have to call the doctor which usually takes a lot of time. The doctor did not show up until little after 2pm (4 hours later, say whaaaaat???). The procedure lasted less than 5 minutes and I was forced to stay another 2 hours in the hospital. Considering the fact that I could not eat nor drink anything since the night before, at this point I was without food/drink for 20 hours!!!! 
Absolutely exhausted, I ran away from there. In general, I do not like hospitals but I guess there is a pretty good reason for it. Sorry, 6 hours or hospital stay, with an appointment, in order to get a 5 mins procedure? I do not recomment anybody to try ECV at UCLA Ronal Reagan Medical Center even if it was for free!

I just dont get it. $3.50 for a cupcake ?! Thats more than the price of a pint of beer at Bar Eleven on a Monday night or the $3 hooker that my buddy did while he was on his sex tour in Asia.

There were more people in this line than all of the idiots combined at all three of the Sushi Delis. Wtf. Conform ! Follow ! Run with the pack ! These cupcakes must be worth the wait in line because of the long lines right ?? Well the line for government cheese is pretty long also, and so is the line for unemployment.

I felt sorry for most of the guys in that line . I just know that their girlfriends or wives made them wait. Suckers.haha Im not hating on this business. Im just making fun of the people that would actually wait 3-5 hours for a small cupcake that costs as much as a gallon of gas.

Im going to my local supermarket when I want a cupcake and it will take me all of 5 minutes to get them and it will be less than $5 for a dozen or so. I bet if I blindfolded the people in line and pulled a pepsi challenge on their crazy asses, a lot of them wouldnt be able to taste the difference.

Or...you can check out Pubcakes ! http://pubcakes.com/where-can-i-find-pubcakes/ and http://www.yelp.com/biz/pubcakes-san-diego . A friend of mine makes them and they kick ass. Shes about to open her storefront and I would much rather support her business than support and stand in that line for a business that is obviously completely and utterly over hyped.

Ok so I finally tried it and because of the hype I was expecting to cream in my jeans the moment that I bit into it. I didnt cream in my jeans. Soooo freaking sweet. I couldnt eat all of it. Too much frosting for my taste.

Great place for breakfast.  Try the Belgian Waffles with the warm boysenberry preserves..KILLER!  Also, the omelets are good too, but beware, they're huge, so if you have someone to share it with be sure to do a split!

Eaten there at least a dozen times. The duk mandu guk is a favorite and rarely disappoints. If you like spicy food, their spicy soups are really good too. Love the banchan. Rarely manage to finish everything, especially with an appetizer.

Good Asian food around campus. Dishes I really liked were their Phos, dishes with  lemon grass or peaunut sauce, but their vegetarian dishes are not that great in my opinion. The portion size is big, so it's good for a big lunch.

The ambience inside is pretty artistic too. See you around...

The situation with Enzo's Pizzeria really reminds me of the Office episode where Michael orders pizza.

Michael: Good news.
Stanley: We get to go home?
Michael: Guess who just ordered from your favorite pizza place, Alfredo's?
Kevin: Wait. Alfredo's Pizza Cafe? Or Pizza By Alfredo?
Michael: Same thing.
Everyone: [grumbling] No. No it isn't.
Michael: Alright I don't understand when you all talk at the same time.
Kevin: Oscar, talk to him.
Oscar: Michael, there's a very big difference between these two pizza places, both in quality of ingredients and overall taste. Which one did you order from?
Michael: Pizza By Alfredo
[Everyone grumbles]
Michael: Alright. OK, OK. What is better: a medium amount of good pizza or all you can eat of pretty good pizza?
Everyone: Medium amount of good pizza.

In this case, Enzo's is "Pizza by Alfredo", the place that gives huge quantities of meh-tastic pizza which the office hates. On to the details!


The Good:

SUPER HUGE PIZZA TIEM NOW? Man that 23" pizza is something to look at. And it comes at a great price for the quantity you get. Good for feeding large groups of people that you don't really care about impressing becauuuuuse.....................


The Bad:

If you have any standards about pizza, that 23" pizza is bad. Soggy to the core. Weak sauce (quite literally). Skimpy on the toppings and the cheese is quite forgettable.


The verdict:

If you want great pizza for good prices, turn around and head to Lamonica's NY Pizza on Gayley Ave. If all you want is pizza and for CHEAP and don't give a care for what you shove in your mouth, Enzo's is your place. Harsh yes. Will I return for more Enzo's pizza? No.

So, I was in Seattle for 8 days this winter and I don't know where I would be without Aladdin's. I think I ate here 6 times during those visits - I mean what sounds better than a Lamb and Beef Gyro at 2 AM after a night out? Nothing. And for lunch the next morning? Nothing. And for breakfast? Well maybe not for breakfast. But I'm a huge fan of this place. 

The food is great, the price is low and the hours can't be beat.  I'm currently living around the corner from it and every two or three days me and my roommate are eating here.

Sub-par food, small portions and not that cheap.

If you can, go to Yoshinoya instead.
I like this place more than Pink Berry because the yogurt isn't as tart. But to be honest, they are both yummy.

Don't waste your time shopping anywhere else for a new bed! I was doing my due diligence making myself go to all the regular mattress spots in Pasadena. The last mattress store I'll ever check out that IS NOT Mattress City? Sit n' Sleep. Oh, don't worry SNS, you've received plenty of my money in the past for all your advertising.  

As I was already on Lake Avenue (see above), and happened upon Mattress City's new store, I forced myself to continue the drudgery of keeping yet another Bed Salesman at bay. I was convinced this was just another place I'd check off my list as a no go.

SO glad I dragged my butt in there! THESE GUYS... they elevated the mattress shopping experience to new heights. Bent over backwards to make sure I got an amazing bed at an amazing price. Serious bang for the buck--AND all the bells and whistles were thrown in. James even brought it to my attention I might want a shorter box spring in combination with my deep mattress so the two would fit my vintage frame better--THANK YOU! It would have really bugged me if it were taller and as predicted, my new set fits the frame perfectly. 

I love, love, love my bed and the sound sleep I'm getting--couldn't be happier with their product and service. I'm so enthused about them, I will dig a little deeper in conversation about one needing a new mattress just so I can recommend Mattress City!

Thanks again, guys!

i liked the space. big and open, and my group was DEFINITELY the only people there the night i went.  i'm always down for red decor, and it was nice to have lighting, that was different from a lot of places.  the jukebox was kinda crazy i think... like dichotic listening type shit, where somehow two songs would be playing on two different speakers.  interesting.  oh and hella cheap beers at happy hour.  

the one thing is, if you're GONNA have a full food menu, i don't really get why you gotta be all exasperated and shit when i order something. for real, so much attitude on that front.  i didn't realize that your food menu means you, the only bartender workin, are gonna have to order, then go across the street to some restaurant or whatever to pick it up, bring it back to us in to-go containers, and shout out the food orders. i mean, mention it on the menu or something. say "i hate going across the street, and this list of food is from a different place, so if you want something, how 'bout you just go get it yourself and bring it back, mmkaaaaay?" less grief all around.

Not the best Indian food I have ever had but not bad for Princeton.  They were able to seat the entire group (40+ members) upstairs and the service was very efficient, at least for the drinks.  We all had the lunch buffet, which was well-stocked and offered the typical standards like tandoori chicken, aloo gobi, chicken tikka masala, and chicken curry.  I was a fan of the tandoori chicken, which was nicely seasoned and quite juicy.  The chicken tikka masala was decent but not amazing; it was also quite mild although the sauce was flavorful.  The naan was nicely fluffy and went well with the curry sauce.  The gulab jamun was a bit soggy for my taste, and the rice pudding a tad bit too sweet, but overall the desserts were a nice touch.  They also had fresh fruit, mousse, and plain and chickpea salads.  The price was very good (less than $10/person for lunch) for the food quality and quantity.  Definitely recommend of you're looking for an inexpensive and quick lunch near the university.

Our party of six agreed, the food was great. On a Sunday night, with their live music, the atmosphere is lively, casual & hospitable. The crazy-good musicians drew out some amazing dancers to the floor. The only downside: Our table was near the fantastic but loud music. We literally had to scream across the table. But, from moment we walked in, soaked to the bone from down-pouring rain, the hostess made sure to create a festive tone for the night. In fact, on our way out, she danced with one of our fellows.

after visiting the Huntington Library and Gardens, we decided to stop here to get our grub on.  i've been to the sunset location before and LOVED it.  i was hoping for the same here.  all expectations were met, as well as the wacky decor inside and eclectic crowd.  we had a good time people watching while stuffing our faces with the chicken schwarma plate.  so delicious!  

i'll be backkkkkk....

I'm sorry but this place REALLY does not deserve to get all the hype it's getting! Lured by the "most booked" listing on opentable, I decided to wander off my tried and tested dining spots to make way for Distrito. I guess all this place has to offer is the decor. The food pales in comparison and what's even more infuriating is crappy food being exhorbitantly priced. My lunch alone cost me slightly below $50 and I was served a shrimp ceviche that really was just shrimp cocktail (bleah!) . At least the fish tacos fared better but at $14, it didn't come cheap. Since servings were tiny and taste truly mediocre, I decided to order on - although I should have gone with my instinct rather than my hunger pangs and gone somewhere else at that point. However, I spotted the fried plantains and tres leche dessert, both which I love and figured no one effs these dishes up.... after all one is a side dish. But OMG the fried plantains ended up being some crap served with weird sauce accompaniment and queso blanco. When the dish was set before me I was thinking WTF is that and what is the white stuff on the bananas.... whipped cream? The combination tasted awful. And the tres leche, was basically some lousy sponge cake with milk all over. VERY DISAPPOINTING MEAL. The only saving grace about this place was the decor - I don't usually go snapping pics in restos, but since I felt shortchanged by the food, I snapped away.
BASAS!  See you there!

Went here for takeout on a Saturday night. Was told it would take about 15 minutes.  30 minutes later we got our food.  Pad see you and pad thai.  It was fine - nothing to write home about or that I'd crave again.  Plus it wasn't such a great deal.  Still came to about $18 for the 2 dishes.  For a 30 minute wait for takeout, I'll pass.

I go back to So Cal for three reasons:

1. Family
2. Friends
3. The Hat

Need I say more?

I saw a couple get married underneath the statue in the fall of 2006, just the two of them and their officiant (who was wearing a fabulous, wide-rimmed hat, I might add). College kids regularly play frisbee here, and one of the Cambridge Adult Kickball leagues uses the Common's field for their games. It's a great little green space right in the heart of Harvard Square.

Several of my friends have instructions that, should I ever be involved in a freak accident involving a bus, they are to bring me Cocomero, specifically 1/2 cheesecake, 1/4 peanut butter, 1/4 banana with yogurt chips and 4 pieces of banana. I like Cocomero OK. It's a cool concept. Apparently, the same sort of stuff is popular out west. If I had more money and was paid more often, I'd definitely go more often.

I really don't get what people like to much about this store. Its dirty and disorganized, the staff is rude and as cheap as "$1 per pound" clothes might be, I just can't bring myself to sort through a 3 foot tall heap of used dirty clothes just to save some money. But anyways, I tried to sell some clothing to them. When I walked in I thought it was very weird because they said that they wanted "vintage items" yet none of the clothing could be older than three years old.... huh? That doesn't make sense. So after I waited for the girl to sort my clothing, for whatever reason (since she couldn't disclose why) she decided that my Gucci skirt, Guess shirts and Buffalo jeans were not good enough for the store. I certainly hope that the homeless person wearing them now really enjoys them.

Cheap large portions prepared quickly. I wish that there was even the slightest bit of quality, the hot and sour soup lacked the requsite flavors, all the other dishes from the Lo-Mein to the General Tso's and Szcehuan Chicken seem to have been a product of a lazy kitchen that just throws ingredients in a wok and tops it with a pre-made sauce. 

Eating here is also not a good idea, while I was here... The owner of the restaurant launched into a diatribe in Mandarin; screaming at the top of her lungs on the phone and to one of her cooks. It was absolutely nuts...

This place is, essentially the same, but now under new ownership and bears the name "Zada Kebab." The good news is that they've decided to give away the garlic sauce for free, you can pick up as much as you want. That said they've also cut back in spots. Meat plates have significantly less meat and that lovely green sauce and pita they used to give you while you waited for your food is no more. Just the overall quality seems to have dipped a bit. I still go though. 

Side note, I know it's a Mediterranean Place, but the fries here are pretty good. They're freshly made and well seasoned.

Today was our first experience at the Boatyard. Basically the food is decent, but this place had some other issues for me. First off, the clam chowder had too many small potatos in it and they were under done. Could not finish it. I ordered the stuffed shrimp for lunch today for $12.95. I only got two shrimp total on a small bed of rice and a small amount of spinach. TWO SHRIMP for $12.95, come on people. The waiter was so so. Probably won't go back.

This newly opened place near Pitt makes a third link to Pizza Sola's chainlet. It offers a comfortable, relaxed space with a friendly vibe -- the ceiling is a little low for the dough tossing though. A variety of pizzas are on display on the counter.  You buy by the slices and they will quickly re-bake your order. Their slices are very large (approx. two "normal" slices), but each slice costs ~$4 on average. I would have preferred smaller pieces at a lower price so that I can sample multiple flavors when I'm hungry or eat less when I'm not.

Pizza Sola makes NY-style pizzas; people who don't like doughy crusts will probably appreciate the thin crust. I like my crust more crispy so that it would hold its shape better, so I find Sola's a bit too floppy.  I like their sauce and cheese, and the topping proportion is reasonable. I find the vegetarian ones a bit on the bland side (they do offer a bunch of condiments like pepper flakes and garlic powder so you can doctor it up to your taste), but the meat pizza is satisfying.  

Good soda selection -- black cherry, orange cream, root beer, etc.

Overall, 3.5 stars for the entire venture, but an extra half star for opening in Oakland.

Can't remember what my dish was called, but it looked like a cow on a skewer and it tasted just as good (edit: looked it up and it's called "Gran Brochette Argentina").  Had a little bit of house Merlot to assist this bovine down the waterslide called my esophagus into a nice wading pool of HCl below also known as my stomach.  (I'll spare you the exit.)
