Some of the meats seemed a little tough, but it was well cooked and tasted good overall.  There were three sauces for your beefs to bathe in before they jumped into your mouth, but I preferred them straight up. 

My girlfriend appreciated the chimichurri sauce and bread, and she prayed to god that someone would make it into the next Jamba Juice drink, but to no avail.

Overall experience:  okay.  I don't know if the price-to-value-to-taste ratio was just there for me.

I agree with Hayden. THE BEST frozen screwdrivers. I'm from the NW side of town and drive all the way to Volcano just for the frozen screwdrivers. A few of those and you are feeling gooooood.   :-)

Last time I went there was a couple weekends ago. I think it is time for another trip.   :-)

I have not tried their munchies as of yet so can not comment on that.
The ice cream is really good. Pretty austere interior.
The food here is always outstanding. A great cross between comfort and and creative foods.  The service is also always friendly. I will say, this is a great place to go on an expense account.

Still holding to the 2 stars for this joint. Sat at the bar this time. Wow. It took an eternity for the bartender to notice us....so that instead of getting second rounds (b/c the beers were quite tasty), we left and went to Charlie's Kitchen instead! Whoo.

Lizz C. and I had been planning to check this place out for quite some time, so before a show across the street at Sparrow, we decided to give it a try.

She'd been regaled with tales of some awesome blueberry-containing mixed drink and some beef/lettuce cups that were supposedly awesome too.

We went in around 9:15 and were seated pretty instantly by a friendly (perhaps a little too effusive) server.  

We browsed the drink menu for a few minutes and she ordered the aforementioned blueberry drink and I ordered a coconut-rum-containing lemonade concoction.  Girly?  Eh, sure, maybe, but it sounded good.

From the appetizer menu, we decided to order the beef/lettuce cups we were told about, as well as some coconut shrimp.

The drinks were brought out crazy-fast and both were very good.  We always try each other's drinks/beers, and we both thought both drinks were good.  My lemonade/coco-rum drink was definitely well made - the coconut rum dominated, but the lemonade provided a nice contrast to it.  Overall, the drink wasn't super-sweet, which I like.

The food, too, came out VERY fast! (Kitchen is bored, the server said.)

The coconut shrimp were good, if a little "standard."  I mean, once you've had coconut shrimp, there's not a lot new or "wow" to experience.  The place either screws it up (overfrying, too much breading, wrong fryer temp leading to too much oil) or they don't.  Red Seven didn't screw it up, and the dish was good.

The beef/lettuce "cups" were not what I expected.  What you get is a serving dish of a beef, vegetable, and sauce concoction, with 4-5 leaves of romaine on the side.  You then spoon some of the beef mixture onto a leaf and eat it.  There is no "cup."  

That said, the dish wasn't bad.  A little too sweet for my tastes, but I prefer non-dessert food to be not sweet at all.  A little too saucy as well, but I figured with something being called "beef lettuce cups" it would be mostly beef and perhaps not even sauced at all.  Ah well - it's not "terrible" - just not what I expected and a little too sweet for me.

That was the extent of our food/drink ordering as this was just a pre-show nosh.  We often just split an appetizer or two - portions sizes being what they are these days, it's the best way to eat out and yet still maintain fitness/weight. :)

We will probably go back, either for drinks, or perhaps to try an entree.

Um, okay. Arguably, best espresso in San Diego, really. And I'm not just saying this because I am a UCSD student and without Art of Espresso I would wither away and die from the lack of on-campus independent brandage/general culture. A genuinely good espresso, every time. Employees are (apparently) really well trained and know their way around every (coffee) drink (I havent tried their chais, but their iced tea is good) such that you consistently get a quality drink.

Their pastries are really good too, AND they have chocolate chip oatmeal cookies! Swish! I mean, all of their cookies are fantastic (I am both a coffee snob and cookie monster bleh) but, to carry everyone's secret favorite flavor that apparently no one else has figured out is like, the best combination ever....! Bueno.

MMM...Greasy food late night.  Takes me back to my days at UT...cramming late at night, drinking late at night, munching late at night. I guess that's what happened to my metabolism...errk. This place def put a few pounds on me and I don't regret it one bit. 

I usually get the chicken tender dinner or a burger. The dinner has a salad, toast and fries with it. Plus they have a drive-thru! MONEY!! speaking of money, be sure to tip them! they yell, THANKS PRETTY LADY or something like that. Also, be sure to bring your appetite the burgers aren't small, and you'll want to finish it. While you're at it you should probably get a chocolate shake, just for good measure.  

I really dig the thin patty and they've never messed up my order. Their fries are always crisp and everything comes out screaming hot. The drinks are self-serve and pick up your food at the window when inside. Saves money and time in my opinion. I don't feel like a need a waiter to bring me a burger and fries, they get that. This place is a well oiled machine, don't expect more than a 5 minute wait here. I appreciate efficiency, as it saves us all time and money. They pass along the savings to their customers in their fair prices. In my opinion, this place is incredibly legit....it's also got that austin nostalgia I'm always raving about. 

So a recap:
*don't go anywhere near this place on a diet
*not frumpy or expensive
*fast, I mean turbo.
*open late--- 3am.
*great staff
*drive thru

sigh. 
I hate to say it, but Econ Tutor really saves my butt when midterms and finals come around. I always tell myself that this is the quarter where I am going to learn everything in class, and not go to Econ Tutor. Unfortunately, as 9th week comes along, I find myself logging onto the website to check out the session schedules.

Eric is nice and cares about his students. It would be better if sessions started on time though.

By the way, has anyone figured out what purpose those two huge plasmas in front of his office serve? I've never seen them turned on.

I think I order from here about once a week, so they keep my payment & delivery info on file, which is convenient.  I love the puttanesca pizza with pepperoni on whole wheat crust.  My boyfriend ordered it when he was in the recording studio with his band and they were pissed that he orderd whole wheat pizza, but they ended up loving it.

They seem to be quicker than alot of other delivery services, too.

Went here a few weeks ago and it was great. Missed the lunch buffet by an hour or so and the place was empty. The food was delicious. The only complaint I have was that the pork we got was extremely fatty - to the point of being left on the side of the plate, uneaten, but I'm going to hope that's a fluke.

Great spot! Great selection! Tasting is fun you walk up to machine stick your $25 card in and select the wine you want to taste. If you like the wine you can get a glass or the bottle. Staff is friendly and seem knowledgable. Once we sat down they forgot all about us though!

Bubble Island was around before all the newer places (yogobliss, momo tea) popped up, but it doesn't really make it any better. In fact before I moved here and was visiting the area, I tried Bubble Island's milk tea and was pretty disappointed by it. It was too creamy for a milk tea and didn't really resemble the actual thing at all. In fact, their Turtle Tea tastes more like the bubble milk tea I know from home. 

This place is still pretty decent though - A-OK is about as to the point about this place as you can get. I just get the turtle tea and nothing else when I'm around.
bling!

We waited about 10 minutes for our table but the wait was well worth it. The strawberry pancakes were awesome with whipped creme. I love my bacon crispy and that's how I got it so I was very satisfied with it. Get the loaded hash browns for $1.29 more its definitely worth it! Even though you can tell the staff is still learning, the service was very good. I will be back to try lunch/dinner and for breakfast for sure!

As others have already pointed out, the Harvard COOP is just a Barnes & Noble with HARVARD painted everywhere in crimson letters.  But why shouldn't it be?  Everything inside is decked out the same way.

This store has probably dressed and accessorized countless Asian tourists and Ivy League tools.  Who else wears HARVARD paraphernalia?  (I went to fancy schools too, but I keep the insignia limited to pajamas.)  The COOP had dozens of baseball caps, and I saw one that had a distinctly Ed Hardy aesthetic with paint splatter and thick HARVARD lettering.  Classy, that.  I'm being harsh, though - we did buy some HARVARD underwear for my teenaged brother (in the hopes that his ass gets aspirational?) and I have a few friends who occasionally bring out the Ivy gear to like, go to the market.

Anyway, the COOP is not just a store where you buy all things HARVARD - it's also a pretty decent bookstore.  I don't like that the fiction is tucked away on an upper floor, but the display tables are well curated and the selection of books is extensive.  The store is also clean and a little bit pretty.

I've been to the actual Harvard bookstore, and it's much better than the COOP, if what you're after is books.  If it's the HARVARD you're after, though, look no further.

This would normally be given 4 stars with room for improvement, but since is the only place in CU to get Indian food, it gets 5 stars.  The food itself is pretty damn phenomenal.  I had Lamb Saag, which knocked my socks off.  I've had better Lamb Saag, but that was at Taste of the Himalayas in San Francisco, and I don't see myself getting back there anytime soon.  The lamb was tender (but not totally melty-tender as at Taste of the Himalayas), and the saag was creamy and flavorful (with a hint of lemon!).  My fiance had Chicken Tikka Masala, which was definitely the best I've ever tasted.  The side order of naan was plentiful--definitely enough for our party of four.  The rice was not plain, but decorated with little vegetables, and most importantly, was not sticky with starch.  I didn't try the dishes my mother and stepfather tried, but they were extremely happy with their choices.

My only problem was the service.  They were overly attentive in the kind-of-intrusive way.  We'd be talking and a waiter would come up and start talking over us immediately--that sort of thing.  And they were constantly there in some capacity, whether it be filling up 3/4-full water glasses or asking if we wanted more popodums or naan or if they could take our dishes yet.  Cool it, folks.  We're trying to have a leisurely dinner here.  I know there are worse things than being served attentively, which is the other reason Bombay retains its 5 star rating from me.

AWFUL. Try Taste of Thai Express or Tamarind instead. Or Sticky Rice.

* I have gotten an upset stomach every time I ate here, which usually means (for me) that the food is not fresh. *
 
The food doesnt taste good for Thai food in the States. The duck curry is fine, as are the fried rice and pad thai dishes (though it's hard to mess up fried rice or pad thai). The other main dishes are gross. Flavorwise, my complaint is that they overdo it. Especially since Asian food already uses a lot of oil and salt--but also with the flavors generally--Taste of Thai's food is overwhelming in a bad way. I have been to Thailand a couple times and worked in a Thai restaurant in the US, plus I eat Thai food at every opportunity, so I'm familiar with authentic food as well as Americanized Thai food. Taste of Thai is just gross.

Service is hit or miss. The female server I had a number of times was good. I once had an obnoxious server who didn't know the difference between the various red curries try to correct me. Rude.

Atmosphere is good. It has a nice ambience, but you can wear jeans without feeling out of place.

I have been many times--when I first moved to Ithaca, I thought it was the only Thai restaurant--but I will never go back.

This Trader Joe's is located next to Buca di Beppo. They sell a variety of organic fruit and vegetables, packaged fresh vegetables, meats, and dairy. They also have some prepared foods like salads, sandwiches and wraps. I love trying all the trader joe's brand foods. They have a variety of frozen foods as well as snacks, spreads and even bread mixes. The store usually offers samples in the very far corner of the store. A week ago they were offering gingerbread with lemon curd.....weird combination, but it was sooo delish, we bought the mix and curd to make at home. I also like the variety of plants TJ sells. They usually have orchids year round, but switch out the other flowers and herbs. The staff is usually really friendly, but the lines can get a little long.
Not as good as when it first opened back in the day, but still love the many selections on the menu.

There are good dive bars and there are bad dive bars.

Cheap pitchers of PBR can almost make a bad dive bar into a good dive bar.

Almost.

This was a really enjoyable experience with a mix of fun, coolness, great margaritas and, most importantly, terrific food.

I haven't reviewed the choices à la carte but I can say that the chef's menu, a collection of tapas-like items, was truly memorable. Spiced just right, tasty as it can get, steak was cooked like it should be, just excellent and correctly priced ($55 for the full meal).

A must-go next time I'm in Philly.

Box and Box is the ideal personal jeweler because, well they're personal.  As in, they want to sit down with you and get your whole life story.  They want to be your friend.  They want to know what you like and why.  They want to take you out to dinner.  They want to go fishing with you.

This is all part of the experience at Box and Box.  The two boys (they're so much fun and have so much energy, it only makes sense to call them boys) work well together--Tony is all gab (and flirtation) while Wes is a bit calmer but with plenty of stories himself.  

They are the only authorized Ball watch dealer in Houston--affordable and attractive.  They also do custom jewelery--if you're talented you can design it or have Wes come up with something nifty on his fancy computer.  They can get in just about any type of stone you can imagine (we're making a custom ring for me soon!).  They have a decent collection of used watches (including a gorgeous Patek and a few Rolexes).  

But what really makes Box and Box stand out?  They don't know how to push a sale.  I mean, they're just having way too much fun with their job.  They'll let you try on anything and will compliment the hell outta you--the best place to go if you're having a low self-esteem day!

Inevitably we say that we're only going to go in for a few minutes and end up staying for hours on end.  Box is like the uncle (albeit a bit flirtation uncle) that you've never had--with all the charm and hilarious stories as you can imagine.  And on the weekends, they'll play college football on their tv and it always gets a bit interesting since one is an Aggie and the other a Longhorn.  It is definitely worth checking out, if only to get a refreshing difference from the monotony in Rice Village.
*************************************
Update:  I just got my ring from Box (almost a whole week early!) and it is gorgeous!  We were looking for a particular stone of a particular size and he brought in a few to look at.  After we chose the stone, we were given the option of designing our own band (which we had planned to do) or to look through their bands that were already made (all custom designs).  I found one that fit perfectly with what we were going for and they had the stone set in less than a week.  I've gotten so many compliments on my unique ring that I feel really captures "us" since we were so involved in the making.  If you're really looking to wow someone with a customized piece of jewelery, Tony is the man to see.

My mom and I went here for a nice post-valentine's day massage at the Town & Country location since our usual place closed down. I am not impressed in the least.

First of all, the decor is cheap. Everything, including the bed linens are straight from IKEA. Most spas have more class than to decorate with readily recognizable less-than-luxury materials and furniture. Also, my mom asked for a "couple's massage" when she set the appointment, but the receptionist booked two single massages, so we were stuck in separate rooms. This mistake didn't peeve me too much, I was just looking forward to a nice, stress relieving afternoon.

My masseuse asked me, before I even took off my robe, the pressure I liked best. I answered "medium," but of course this is a relative term. She started massaging me very hard, and didn't ask if the pressure was okay, so I had to tell her over and over again throughout the whole massage to lighten up because she would forget 5 minutes later and I would be wincing in pain. 

So today I am sitting here with big bruises on my butt, and between my shoulders because my masseuse didn't listen to me. So basically my mom paid for me to get beat up. 

She said that her massage with Helen, however was fabulous. So I guess if you must visit this place, she's the one to request.

The logo of the Russell House Tavern, a crow dangling three stars on strings, tells you everything you need to know. After you spend sometime there, you will understand how the crow feels with those stars dangling in front of her. The food and wine at the Russell are just as bright and just as glittering.

When you walk in, you have two options as to where you would like to sit. The downstairs area is more intimate, quieter and darker. The noise level stays at a low hum in the evening even with a full house. The decor is understated and classic.

There are black and white framed photographs that punctuate an elegant atmosphere of mostly taupe and coffee bean brown. Downstairs, there is a marble countertop at the bar. A few lamps with scarlet red lampshades sit on the bar. Look up and you will see little boathouses suspended from the ceiling with four bulbs as passengers.

Being so close to Harvard University, you can expect a mixed crowd. You may dress casually or dress up. The waitstaff is friendly and knowledgable about wine and which food goes well with which wine. Feel free to ask questions. You will find them to be attentive.

The wine selection is extensive, as one would expect from a tavern. There are several things to consider when choosing a wine. They offer one organic selection, ten sustainable ones and three biodynamic wines.

Additionally, there are sixteen different wines that you can have by the glass and twelve of these are under ten dollars. There are two wines offered on tap at only five dollars a glass and both of these are good values for the price.

At nine dollars a glass, the Motos Liberty Cabernet Sauvignon is a wonderful choice. Drink it slowly and savor each sip. It does down very smoothly and has a fruity taste. Both the body of the wine and the sweetness are medium. It has a hint of a pepper taste. Interestingly, the aftertaste is even better than the intial moment you experience with the wine in your mouth.

Another good choice at a somewhat higher price is the Benxziner Pinot Noir from the Sonoma Coast of California. This choice is one of the ten sustainable offerings at the Russell.

The Russell House Tavern also offers eleven different small plates for under ten dollars each. The Redondo Black Serrano Ham with House Pickled Pears and Honey Torched Manchego is a lovely choice with the Cabernet Sauvignon. Every bite was delicious and you will want to order another when you are done.

I'm a student at one of the Claremont Colleges and 21 Choices is my favorite place to take (delicious) study breaks. I love the atmosphere! The staff is quite friendly and are more than willing to give recommendations about choices/mix-ins. Plus, you can get samples of all the daily flavors if you want.  My favorite choices are "Reese's Chocolate Chips", "Twix Fix" and pretty much all of their fruit based yogurts. You have to check this place out if you're in the area. One of the best late night places in Claremont.

The portions are huge, while the damage on your wallet is minimal.  The food quality is not bad at all, and there seems to be quite a bit of history behind the place.  It's convenient and is definitely one of the better deals on the Ave. 

They focus on two things a college boy needs.  Teriyaki Chicken and Burgers.  Both are affordable, and they have so much fries, I couldn't finish.  You know you're a satisfied customer if you were content with the taste and you didn't finish your meal since there were large portions, and you still have cash in your wallet.  I definitely recommend this place.

100th REVIEW!! WOOHOOOOO!! :)

This place, often referred to as "The 2-9" is literally one street away from my apartment and I have always driven past it but have never had a chance to actually go. But tonight, I finally went for dinner with two of my friends. 

There was seating indoors as well as outdoors. There was plenty of seating available so we were seated right away. Service was just okay-- not really fast but not terribly slow either. They had a selection of wines and beers but I decided on a hibiscus lemonade because it sounded yummy. I asked the waitress what it was exactly and she said it was a fruity lemonade. When I asked her what kind of fruity, she replied with, "Red." Hmm..I didn't know "red" was a fruit! Either way, it tasted pretty good, kinda like a sweeter punch-like pink lemonade.

For food, I ordered the 2-9 turkey sandwich which came with avocados, lettuce, tomatoes, and cheese on a croissant with sweet potato fries on the side. The sandwich was overall okay and the sweet potato fries were pretty good but definitely not the best I've had. Portions were generous! I was really full at the end of the meal and couldn't finish the fries. 

Prices are pretty cheap and reasonable. Sandwiches were about $7-9. They also have burgers, salads, and soups. One good thing about this place is that there's a small parking lot right next to it and parking is free! :) Awesome because there's like NO street parking nearby!

Taste of Mexico offers good, unpretentious Mexican food prepared from scratch in front of you at decent prices. The ambiance sucks -- the restaurant is in a strip mall with four tables and bar seating, with a few outside tables when weather permits -- but the food is solid enough that we keep going back. Due to limited space, some things, like the chips and salsa, are clearly off-the-shelf, although the entrees are all freshly prepared. In particular, the tacos al pastor are really good, as are the enchiladas. Don't be afraid to ask if you want your food spicier as the default is somewhat mild.

I lived in Oakland for 4 years and possibly the thing I miss most about it is Johnny's Place. This is quite possibly the best food you'll find, at a reasonable price, in the city. 
The food is so good, it's one of those places that when you go in, you and your friends talk about the first time you went to such a great place. First of all the plates are huge, if your a true mountain of manliness, such as myself, you'll be able to finish your meal. Unless your dating a girl who really likes her food, your girl will probably be taking stuff home with her. In addition to quantity is the quality, the food is really indescribably good. 
This is the quintessential mom and pop shop, as Johnny and his wife are the only employees. They are really nice people and it's nice to support such an establishment on principle. 
The only bad part is that the hours are crappy, but from a place with literally 2 people, what do you expect?

They make my favorite bibimbop in town.  It's a mom and pop place for sure...but nothing wrong with that.  don't go in looking for a nice decor or lots of flair.  it's a small menu...but pretty much everything is pretty good.  service can be a lil slow if there's a couple tables in there but usually worth the wait.
Went to the Arizona game this weekend. Stadium is intimate. No bad seat in the house. Definitely will go back.

My friend took me here when I came to see her on vacation.

DEfuckingLICIOUS!

This place was ridiculous, all the shit on the walls, and crazy names of food was awesome, great atmosphere. 

I also had my very first Frappe here, and it was delicious and I approve.

I would come back to this place again and again and each time proceed to bust a fucking nut in my pants.

I have been here several times, and generally get the skender Kebab at the behest of my Turkish friend.  It is pretty delicious, and is great comfort food.

Today though I went with the Karsk Pide (Mixed pide) which is a cheese, eggs and meat pizza.  It is pretty much the best "breakfast" pizza I have ever had. I am not sure they consider it breakfast pizza, but I consider anything with scrambled eggs as an ingredient breakfast.  Also at about $10, it was enough for two at lunch.


Service was also very prompt, never was out of iced tea.

Also get the Turkish Coffee for some spring in your step on the way out.

Domino's Pizza doesn't give you any packets of condiments anymore--ie. crushed red peppers & parmesan cheese.  I had emailed and voiced my  two cents.  As a result, the franchisee send me a complimentary coupon for a free large one topping pizza!  After all, I am a loyal customer over ten years!  This was a while back; so, don't even think about doing the same thing!  As a result, I'm going to give them five stars!  And what's with the usc students?  I see no reviews from them.  Are they too busy doing their homework or are they too busy drinking at the bar across the street?

No thank you.

After reading glowing reviews on yelp, I was pretty much sold and decided to give them a phone call today to make a reservation -- and inquire about the 20% Yelp Discount. When a friendly sounding lady picked up, I said these exact words: "Hi! I discovered you guys through yelp and I would like to make..." I suddenly got interrupted and received an attitude. ?!?

The person went into some rant that they are not affiliated in any way with Yelp and would actually want their listing here to be taken out. She also stated that she specifically doesn't like it that people who use yelp would end up being disappointed etc. etc.

First of all, she could have had said all these things in a much nicer manner and with basic civility. I called because I was actually going to book them. In the whole conversation, she just sounded so irate and kept interrupting me. I just don't understand where the attitude is coming from, and why her being "upset" with yelp automatically translated to this uncalled-for unprofessionalism and attitude towards me -- a potential customer genuinely interested in booking a room.

Once again, even if its cheap at $79, it would pretty much become self-sabotage if I continue to book this hotel, knowing and experiencing firsthand that I would deal with type of unnecessary rudeness during my vacation.

I would not recommend this place.

Gia Pronto is a great lunch spot.  At first look, you think ti's just another hospital joint with crappy food.  But their salads are really good and freshly prepared as you wait. 

My recommendations:
House Rosemary Balsalmic Dressing
Balsalmic Chicken (in salads)
Multi-grain roll *love the seeds!  *also a great 4pm snack!
Pizza - super cheap and fast, and a very good crust.  My coworkers default to this for lunch
Tomato Cheddar Soup -mmm mmm good
Hope's Cookies sold here too!  Toffee cookie was yummy.

It'd be better if they had calorie information, but they seem committed to using quality ingredients - and you can taste it in the salad.  Also the people are pretty nice and have even let me have a free roll or cookie at the end of the day (otherwise they're wasted).

I will never go back to that Store! I wish I could give them zero for what they barely know as "customer service"! Shopping there is a ripp off! I knew that their stuffs are expensive but did not realize "how much" till I purchased an item for $190 and found the same thing on Amazon for $95! UNBELIEVABLE! it was double! I went to the shop and talked to the sale's person and she rudely told me "you can never get your money back"!!! I'm sure with such prices and that disgusting attitude, their business is not gonna work!

This is a great place for:

-Playful gifts, ranging from cheeky to mildly obscene
-Obscure candies
-Touristy gifts for your in-laws (sweet water taffy anyone?  No?  How about a mug with Boston on it?  Thanks for visiting!)
-Party gear like wrapping paper, cards, stickers, boxes, etc
-An astonishing assortment of mad libs (Mad Libs for...Estate Lawyers?)
-badly made tourist clothes that will tear your skin - to be found upstairs
-Killing time looking at the aforementioned
Good selection of shesha for a rural virginia college town.

"where the hell is this place??" is probably the typical question when your driving on Lake trying to find parking close to the entrance. the sign is practically covered by an untrimmed tree and the entrance is wedged between two seemingly large retail stores. i found out that the reason for its discreetness is that it use to be a speakeasy around the 1920's, hence the abstract layout once you walk inside.

very dark and very intimate. the decor is dark victorian crossed with the "modern lounge" look. it was very cute, but i found myself uncomfortable with how expensive it looked for such a small amount of space. if you walked over to the bar, you'd find yourself lookin up at the stars because half the lounge is open-air... it was still a bit toasty inside. 

they're happy hour is probably the only reason to visit this place. from 4:30 to 7 you can get drinks and select food half price! i wouldnt suggest the key lime martini because it tasted like tangy stank ass... or maybe it wasnt sweet enough, i couldnt really decide. try the pomegranate martini instead. but i highly recommend the mac and cheese ($8 full price) and the coconut shrimp ($10 full price), both which were absurdly delicious... fat has never tasted so expensively good. of course during happy hour theyre both half price, so you get more than your moneys worth. they have other items ranging from $5 to $12, as well as scrumptious desserts for your large sweet tooth.

if youre looking to meet new people, you'll have a had time as everybody usually minds their own business (which i actually love!). an intimate date with your significant other would work out pretty well here. or even a small party of 10 for a girls night out or relaxed birthday celebration. the waiters go at the pace that they can; naturally they pay more attention to larger parties, but on a busy night you can expect a little wait... better to get your drinks at the bar. 

their drinks are weak, in my opinion. but the more you pay the more liquor you get. theyre wine is decently priced and they have a relatively good selection to choose from, including champagnes. check their website for the slightly complicated drink specials they have on different days.

overall, thumbs up. not exciting enough to visit on a weekly or even monthly basis, but a good spot for an after-work drink.

Stumped and confused, I don't quite understand why most reviews of this place are so negative. I've had many trips over to the Windsor Street Health Center and none have been unpleasant in any shape or form.

My doctor there, Dr. Jeremy Keller ( http://www.yelp.com/biz/keller-jeremy-i-md-cambridge ) is excellent and I've seen him for check-ups and various other medical issues, including my shoulder which needed surgery on. He was able to assess it in detail and forward me to one of the best specialists in New England. 

The staff is friendly, they've never been late on their appointments and the facilities are clean. I have no complaints. My only minor issue was trying to reach my doctor there by phone; I had to leave a message and had to wait for one of the nurses to field my questions instead, a few hours later. It wasn't bad at all, far from it, but not the same as talking to him directly.

They have parking in the rear of the building, but it is very limited; Street parking on Main Street or in Central Square is easy to find though.

I want to make it REALLY REALLY CLEAR, I am not looking for sit down, napkin on the lap service. I know what heroes is, I used to go to the one in Fullerton all the time and it was a meeting place for old friends.  When you have 2 guys come in during the day time on an empty day and cant even get a menu or order a beer from an empty bar with two bartenders thats bad...On a friday night where the bartender blows off your order and pours himself a beer and gives you the cold shoulder, or when you sit down after waiting forever and the waitress stands you up and says these people have a bigger group after they just walked in...yeah that is INSULTING. 

I know what a "Cheers get-drunk and eat" place is. In fact i was at cheers in boston where i got drunk and ate...

The Fullerton Heroes is always packed at night and yet they always manage to get you a table and beer quickly. Why is it that an empty place cant even place a beer order at a bar with two bartenders?

Having seen a bunch of shows here and played a few myself, I can say TT's is one of my favorite clubs in all of Boston. Devoid of the Too Cool For You attitude that pervades a lot of places in this city, the staff is usually very cordial and down to earth. PBR's are cheep, there is a back room with a pool table in case the opening band happens to suck. Smaller than places like the Middle East, it's still a good enough size to put on a great rock show.

Passable. Better than the cheap chains, but not by much. Expensive too-- if you can, go with a friend and split the giant size, that'll knock a buck or two each off of your meal (vs. each ordering a regular) which gets the cost down from "kind of expensive" into "almost reasonable" territory.

The employees are a riot though, lots of fun. I just wish the food was better (ok, much better) and it was cheaper. Breaking the $10 barrier for lunch at a place like this just seems wrong.

Cool selection of gargoyles, fairys, mythical and religious statues/wall-hangings, lamps fountains, etc.
They also have tee-shirts, incense, and jewelery. 
I'm always happy when I have a chance to stop in, look around and chat.
I enjoy shopping here!

This review is for the IMAX only.  I have gone to the museum and IMAX several times before, but those were so long ago I can't even remember what show I watched there.  I did wind up at the Museum during one of the Music under the Stars on a Friday night.  A band plays as a crowd dances around in the grass. The alcohol there is priced like alcohol at the Toyota Center.  7 bucks for a beer??!?!  That's nuts.  I say get there already sloshed at those prices.  Other than that, it's pretty neat just to hang out, listen to music, and watch kids dance to Latin music.  

On Wednesday, I went to the IMAX with a fellow yelper, Chris M., to see the Dark Knight.  I secretly think that he just wanted to see me scared to death.  That's a common goal for many people come to think of it.

A few tips about the IMAX: *Lines for the Dark Knight are probably going to be incredibly long and crowded, even for the next month.  Get there early, cut in front of people, or get crappy seats.  

*The parking garage under the museum is free after 6 pm.  The sign is small, so now you know.  

*The only food and drinks allowed are candy and bottles with a screw top.  Sorry, no pop corn with the Joker.  Either eat first or hide food in your purse or manbag.  

The seats there are nice.  The bathrooms are clean.  The place is kept neat and tidy.  

I don't think I have to review the Dark Knight because if it raked in 158.3  million opening weekend, chances are you've already watched it.  Now I'm a chicken when it comes to scary movies.  I openly admit it.  I know as a phlebotomist (for my research) who engages in autocrossing, skydiving, regular visits to prisons (for work, CSI style), and other "dangerous" activities, I should not be scared of a movie.  I am scared though.  Even 4 days later, I'm still a little scared that the Joker might pop out and ask "Why so serious?"  

Unfortunately, since the movie was packed, the only seats that were not in the front row were on different rows.  Chris M. sat a few rows above me.  I sat next to two teenage boys.  During the one part (you know which part, I won't spoil it for the few who haven't watched the movie yet), I screamed and jumped.  The two boys next to me giggled and pointed at me.  They did that repeatedly during the movie.  I was terrified.  Oh, and yeah, Chris M. did confirm that I had indeed jumped 3 feet straight up during that one scene.  

After the movie, I turned on my phone as we were getting into the elevator.  The first thing that popped up was a text message that said "HELP" from a friend who was supposed to be on his way to Belize the next morning.  

This is a person that I've known for years that is just as much as an adrenaline junkie as I am.  He never freaks and always knows what to do in a tight situation.  The fact that I get a text that says "HELP" actually freaks me out.  He does drive some rare and sporty vehicles so the first thing that I think of is that someone is car jacking him.  Everyone else in the crowded elevator hears me panicking.  One woman leans over and says, "It's time to call the BATMAN!"  Everyone cracks up.  I'm still freaking out.  

I finally get out of the elevator and into cell service range.  I call him wondering if it's time to spring into action.  I do love one of the cars as much, if not more than he does.  He picks up.  "Hullo."  "Are you okay?" "Yeah, I'm just packing for my trip."  "Are the cars okay?"  "Yeah."  "How come you texted HELP?"  *Laughing*  "I texted HELO, but the iphone autocorrected it to HELP."  "That's not funny."  *Laughing*  "Dork, I'll talk to you later."

Tip for Iphone users: Wautch owT 4 de aouto-corRrekt.

The quality of their products is pretty good, but nothing else is. The prices are high (yes, I know, it's an organic grocery, prices are always high, but they rarely offer any of the cheaper organic brands), the selection is small and not great, the baked goods demonstrate all the negative features of bad hippie baking, the bulk section doesn't provide any sort of cheap reusable containers, only large and expensive glass ones (I understand their waste-cutting motivations there, but if you don't already have light-weight containers, the bulk section becomes prohibitively expensive-- and heavy for pedestrian customers!). Also, they don't take food stamps/EBT, which undercuts their progressive cred a lot. Don't poor people also deserve access to healthy food? Maybe I'm biased from all my time on the west coast, but I found this place to be a huge disappointment.

I used to like their baked goods a lot more. I'm not sure what it was that changed, me or them... But years ago, we used to get along well, me and ABP. 

Somewhere along the way, my tastebuds changed, or they started making things differently. For the last couple years this has been one of the "coffee break stop" locations that pulls in close to last place. 

I don't like that everybody can touch all the food. I like when only select few people, for whom it is LAW to have clean hands touch food stuffs. Not any old person between Harvard and Central squares...

They have decent soups, and I'll grab a banana or a croissant when we stop in. I don't like the coffee though- and that, I can't forgive. Weirdly watery taste, and their cups and lids have broken on me more times than I care to count.

Get ready for my longest review to date:

After Tony C. sent me his review, making me feel special and loved that someone thought of me, I made a mental note to check this out.  I finally got around to it, and my emotions are mixed.  First, I was super pumped by Tony's review.  Then I got there, and was a little disappointed.  

The store section:  Pretty much carries the necessities of Indian cooking; spices, rice, random selections of American based companies selling their stuff for an Indian market.  Their produce section was small, but what they did have was fresh and cheap, including peppers, onions, coconut and mango.  There is a $10 minimum to use your credit/debit card.

The Kitchen of India (the "take-out/restaurant" part): I wish they would put a "wholly owned subsidiary of Foods of India" sign underneath the window, but that would be silly.  Anyway, it's in the back of the store, with two tables, and a tiny "kitchen" that had four burners and what I think was a clay oven?  It's pretty hole in the wall, but that makes for good food, right? The menu is small, but there's a little bit of everything for everyone if you like chicken or you're a vegetarian, and the prices are decent ($7-10). There were two guys working, the guy at the register was brand spankin' new (as in first day) and was overwhelmed by the three people ordering/picking up food.  I had to help him with the credit card machine to charge me.  The other guy was cooking all of the orders fresh to go- so he was trying to juggle making food and helping the newbie.  

Which made what I thought would be a quick pop in, order, shop, then get food to go a lot longer than I had hoped.  It took awhile just to get my order, have me pay, and have the two people before me taken care of.  Maybe when newbie gets it together, things will be a lot quicker.  Point: call in your order, like half an hour before you want to pick it up.

But here is what made everything ok: The food was delicious, so yummy! And the portions are huge!  I got the veggie biryani and the chicken tikka, Andrew and I had dinner, and I think we have enough left over for at least another dinner.  You never get that much at a sit down place. Ever.  The naan was thick and cripsy, perfectly cooked.  The raita?  A little runny and bland, but you get a lot of it, so just use twice as much on your food.  The tikka had some nice heat, and the mix of veggies in the biryani was impressive.

Never been to a McAllister's deli before, from what I gather from the other reviewers it's a small local chain  and not on a national or even regional scale - I have to say I really enjoyed it. The chicken cesar wrap I ordered was well constructed and the chicken was moist and actually tasted like.....wait for it... chicken! Which you might be surprised seems to be the exception and not the rule anymore. 

I'm glad they offer a fruit cup (YEA!) as a side instead of the typical stuff you can usually get as a side in most places. Didn't get a chance to try their sweet tea - which seems to be a staple of theirs, well.. a staple of the south in general. But they do seem to have a great selection of fresh items. 

It took a lot of effort not to pig out and go to the BBQ place next door...but I can say, I'm glad I went here instead.

I love Revolution Books bookstore, they have all the classics in all areas of politics and even some literature classics.  It's a small store so they don't have piles of books but you can stay there reading for a while on one of the chairs.

Bookstores like this are what are keeping some people from slipping into complete complicity, stupidity complacently, and total subservience to "authority".

Spent my birthday here last Saturday afternoon with great friends. It was fairly quiet in the restaurant, which gave us time for plenty of great conversation--we were there over 2 hours. Service was impeccable: knowlegable and caring. We had wine and salads--the steak and shrimp- and they were absolutely delicious. They presented me with an ice cream dessert for my bday--also delectable.  It was my first time here and I will be back soon! Thank you!
Only one question: why paper napkins at lunch and cloth at dinner? We noticed the difference as they were setting up dinner and it seemed strange.

I don't really find the Wine Bar as intimidating or pretentious as some people seem to think it is. The atmosphere is casual and comfortable, with cushy couches and a great upstairs patio. They also have an awesome table-top Pac Man game that you can play, which is a nice playful touch. The staff has always been polite and helpful, and if you don't know anything about wine they can be a valuable resource. I've never had the cheese plate, but the wine selection is top notch, with many different tastes and price points. As some people have mentioned, the crowd does skew a bit older. That certainly doesn't mean that undergraduates would feel out of place, but it does mean that the drunken antics of East Franklin won't be well received here.

I went to the intensive outpatient  program for a while and it was the worse experience ever. Luckily I have insurance, because if I was paying for it out of my own pocket I would have quit after 1 week.

The worse part of it is not the fact that it's in a hospital or far from my job, but it's the facilitator, Tina. She has NO control over the group and people are able to rant for the whole hour. Other groups give people limits so everyone can share. But Tina sits back and does NOTHING. And she only knows 1 line "how does that make you feel". It is obvious that she only turns questions back to you, very basic, and nothing gets accomplished.

I am sharing this so people are forewarned, people usually quit that group after a month. And I haven't seen anyone actually stop their use. You re better off going to the realization center, it's a little more "real" and some people are mandated to be there, but that place actually helped me and gave me some time. I should have stayed there, but I thought I had a handle on my problem, so I left.

This review applies to the 1000 10th Ave location, at St Lukes. And it doesn't apply to all facilitators or groups. Only the intensive outpatient that's ran by Tina. Just don't do it.
I give this Nordstrom's cafe 5 stars because I can still get a cookie here.  If I don't eat at Max's, then this is where I like to lunch at Stanford.

The truffle /parm fries at the bar with some cold beers, good friends, and the game on any of the numerous tv screens= A+

I really wish I could give this place  a half a star. I hadn't been in a while, and went last night for a drink with friends, and the bartender was the rudest human being on the face of the earth. She snapped at us when we asked if we had to order at the bar. Then when we went up to order, she stood on the other end of the bar (where people were eating and it did not look like there was room for us to place our drink order) and then barked at us to come over there to order.  Then, when my friend gave her her license, she kept on questioning her license, since it was pretty beat up.   (my friend also carries her passport in case people don't believe that her license is legit- when presented with this, she snapped as well). 

I've never had such horrible service/attitude thrown my way. Definitely will avoid the place if that bartender happens to be working.

It is a shame that this place is such a disappointment. I waited for so long for a good Thai restaurant to come to Princeton.  Unfortunately, once again my dream will not come true.  I ate here when they first opened and ordered the Pad Thai. This is the classic dish, so i thought "they cant screw this up".  Well, I was wrong.  My dish tasted like someone just threw hot water on on the noodles, mixed in some sprouts and a few peanuts and called it Pad Thai.  My friends dish was not any better. I tried this place a second time to give it  one more shot ( I thought maybe they just opened, so they will get better).  The second time I ordered a dish that was watery, flavorless, and unsatisfying.  There were no aromatic or distinct flavors and nothing to awaken my taste buds. This is not how Thai food is supposed to taste.  The only thing positive I have to say is that they had fast service and decent decor.

ice cream sandwich cookies, what's not to like! used to be $1, now they're $1.50. back in the day they were $0.50 according to my friend who went there as a kid! they also have some non dessert foods like hot dogs. yum! if you're going to whine about the parking situation, that they take only cash, and that you have to wait in line, you're not their target market (or mine) :)

A Claremont landmark for decades, this is a great place to pick up a sandwich for lunch.  It's also a fully stocked grocery store, with butcher, deli, and bakery.  It's a small place, and more expensive for many types of items than a supermarket would be, but it's a nice place which only carries good quality food.

If you're a student at Harvey Mudd or Scripps, then this is a very useful place as it is within easy walking distance, unlike any of the supermarkets in town.

Go to Wolfe's for the foods prepared on-site (sandwiches, salads, etc.) and for the meat counter.  The dairy case and produce are worth checking out as well if you need to pick up a few things to complete a meal.

Packaged foods are not the focus here. The selection won't match any supermarket obviously, and some prices may seem high, but they're not outrageous.  You won't come here to buy cereal or canned soup, but if you need to pick up something to go along with the rest of a meal, they'll probably have it.

I had Pinkberry, Cefiore,  and Yogurtland. RED MANGO all the way.  I can taste the true flavor of the yogurt.  Although they don't have the mochi ball, the Ka-pow yogurt  flavor made me a loyal customer.  ^_^ I stopped going to Yogurtland.  I'll wait patiently until My Red Mango opens in Irvine. =) Open, open, open.

Stanford's Bartender is amazing!  From planning, shopping list, prep, event and clean-up - everything was top notch/outstanding!!  I can't say enough good things about Carlos and his operation!!  From the moment we spoke on the phone, I knew he was it - he knew his liquors and is not just a bartender but a true mixologist!!  His caiprinhas, mojitos and margaritas were the best I ever had - he introduced me to rum/margarita that will now be the standard here at our home =)  Not just great with drinks, but he's also good on gauging the crowd - it made for an energetic and fun party and all our guests loved him!!!  I highly recommend him!  Thanks Carlos, you are outstanding!!!

A couple friends and I had dinner on their famous patio recently.  The atmosphere was okay, food pretty good, but service was very poor and the manager rude.  It looked like they had two servers for the entire restaurant which wasn't packed but a little busy.  We waited about 20 minutes before our server came to take our drink orders.  She didn't appear to know much about the menu and was unable to make reccomendations other than the most expensive wine and saying "all the food is good."  Moreover we were virtually ignored the entire night with the exception when she brought the food.  At the end when a couple people wanted to pay with credit cards we were informed by the server they don't split checks, accept more than two cards and the manager literally told us if we didn't like it, tough, there's an ATM down the street.  There are other places with good food in Boston that treat customers well, I can do without the authentic portugese service.

For the $8 of bulgogi they ask for, you literally get $8 worth of bulgogi, teriyaki sauce, sriracha, rice and kimchi.  It's pretty much enough to leave you with a couple day's worth of leftovers, leaving your fridge and house smell like a korean shack.  

It's hard to find Korean places that's so low key that doesn't involve $20 buffet deals, sometimes a kid just wants their meat and rice yo.

I love love love this place.  I have never found so many awesome clothes in a store in my life.  I also have never paid for anything here over 10 dollars.  I bought all my clothes for work, the winter and everday life here basically and they are all AWESOME.  Best THRIFT STORE EVER.

Duck!

Ducky Duck!

Yummy Ducky Duck!

Hee hee, I've been to Casablanca a couple of times in the last couple of weeks, and right now there's an awesome duck dish that was unquestionably going to be my order on the second visit because it had delighted me so much on the first. My anticipatory savoring convinced someone else in our party, who'd only just met me, that duck was the way to go -- and we both practically licked our plates clean!

Actually I've been going to Casablanca for years.  Why haven't I reviewed it until now?  Oversight.  Four and a half stars if possible.  It's a bit pricey for dinner (duck two weeks in a row ... extravagant for my budget ... but so good in my mouth!).  But the ambiance is relaxed without being slovenly, there's a good wine list, including a French "biodynamic" syrah that is probably not the best tasting wine on their list but is fun to speculate about (our waitress sheepishly explained that biodynamic grapes are harvested according to the phases of the moon ... oh goody!).

The restaurant in the front (the Brattle Street entrance) is quieter.   I'm much more often in the back "café" area (accessible by either walking through the restaurant to the back, or via the second entrance behind the entrance to the Brattle theater).  Their staff are professional without being uptight.  And the place isn't crawling with inebriated young adults just a year or two into their legal drinking careers.  It's a classy joint.  

And then there's the duck ...

The repairs that were completed were done the same day, however I did have to make an appointment 3 business days in advance since they were backed up (this was the case for all the places I called so no negatives here, it'd be worth an extra star if they could get me in earlier). 

The original person I made the appointment with was very nice and straight forward on the phone. 

When I walked in I had a laundry list of problems. The person I spoke to inside was also straight forward but I think they got a wrong read on me. For one, I was dressed like I just rolled out of bed because I had dropped someone off at their work, planned on dropping my car off here and getting  a rental so I could go home and get ready myself. I think I looked like another poor college student, (I may be poor from college, but I'm no longer a college student :P). 

So when I read my list of items, several of the items were just side stepped entirely, including the main reason I was there, the A/C not working. 

Issue: A/C doesn't work when driving under 25 mph
Response: Air compressor sounds like it's failing, but that's going to cost a lot of money and it's already August so you should probably wait. 
(The A/C sputters and is therefore failing?)

Issue: Fuse for cooler fan blew out, this happened last summer more frequently but happened for the first time this summer a week ago
Response: It's probably fine now
(To me the bearing sounded bad on the fan)

Issue: Temp and Fuel gauges don't work, I have to use the trip and my MPG to estimate my fuel
Response: Just leave it how it is, it's going to cost a lot to fix, we don't have the part, and only the dealer can re-calibrate the gauges. 
(I found a do it yourself repair for this including the calibration online, but didn't want to do it myself)

Issue: I personally removed my fan blower motor since it was really easy to access, but the replacement unit I purchased did not use the same plastic pop-rivets, instead used the factory bolts (but did not come with the bolts). I asked if they had the bolts and could put it back on for me while it was in.
Response: We don't have the parts

Issue: Brakes sound like a dying goose when I backup, I believe the brake shop I took it to used the wrong pads or didn't calibrate it right, since it never did this before
Response: It's probably the material on the pad, sometimes that happens. 
(This sounds terribly loud though, like louder than when a bus stops and at teeth grinding levels)

Fixed issue: ABS, Traction and service lights all triggered, presumably my ABS was disabled too. They had to replace a sensor which cost in the low 200s. 

So in the end they fixed the issue that was the most noticeable and could have had serious repercussions in the winter. They fixed it the same day too and for not too much. 

But I wanted to go to a place to get everything taken care of in one fell swoop and hopefully save some money vs. what the dealer would charge since they are notoriously expensive. I will now have to take it to the dealer anyway (or another shop) to have these other issues addressed. 

I think they should take the  "Complete Auto Care" part off the sign, if it instead said "Partial Auto Care" I would have given them 3-4 stars.

You remember that time when you were young when your friend thought up the idea of milk and cereal bars and then that same year you saw them on store shelves, and then, not too long after you asked, "why don't they make chocolate whipped cream?" and sure enough it came out soon after?

Good.

Then you can understand, when I asked why there were no good Mediterranean restaurants in Austin I was not surprised to see one opening soon on the drag. what I was surprised to find was that they only serve vegetarian grapeleaves. now I didn't spend 15 million years evolving canine teeth to not be tearing through delicious flesh at every opportunity. besides,  Mediterranean cuisine has already far surpassed its duty to the vegetarian community by providing the falafel. thus should end the pandering to these weak-teethed hippies. despite this meaty setback, they have an excellent selection of wraps and skewers. at first I thought the skewers were a little pricey but after I saw the generous portion sizes I was no longer dismayed. the chicken schawarma (a steal at $5 for just the wrap), was hot, tender, well seasoned, and topped with fresh veggies. while this joint doesn't completely sate my desire for a good Austin Mediterranean establishment, it will certainly sate my lunch desires for weeks to come.

incidentally, the Turkish word for vegetarian grapeleaves translates as liar or fake.

Raffi is the man. I just moved to Pasadena and haven't had a cut in too long. He was the only Salon willing to take me on such short notice. 

His place is nice, quiet & in a great location. It was a relief to not have meaningless small talk with someone only mildly attentive..we talked important business only: pros and cons of leasing vs owning, lakers, and raffi's history (he's was a stylist in beverly hills for many years, etc.)

Cool ass dude.

Dr. Greene was my pediatrician and my sons....  Although we live in Sacramento and have many others since..... Dr. Greene is the best.  As a patient and as a mother.  Always made me feel my mothers intuition was to be trusted.

Came here today for dinner with my family! (:

Avocado Club Egg Rolls - Soo good!! Didn't think it'd be this delicious but it's an amazing combination avocado, chicken, tomato, cheese, and other stuff that tastes soo delicious! Nice and crispy!

Lettuce Wraps with Chicken - I always love their lettuce wraps! Usually get it with the shrimp, but the chicken tastes good too (: Lettuce was super fresh as well~

Wild Mushroom Pizza with Sausage - If you like mushrooms, you'll love this pizza! So good! (:

Asparagus + Spinach Spaghettini - Not very heavy in sauce, but it was still good! A bit dry, but otherwise very yummy! The asparagus was fresh and the spinach was actually good hahah 

Baby Clam Linguini with Lemon Cream Sauce - Very flavorful, with a tinge of lemony sourness! The baby clams were good! Delicious for the most part, but started to get tired of it after a while because of the overwhelming flavor.

Service was good, surprisingly, given that we ordered everything right when the waiter was only taking drink orders and he memorized EVERYTHING (including what type of sauces, what to add and what not) and delivered accordingly within a reasonable amount of time (:

After having read all the great reviews about this restaurant, I was super excited to try what everyone was talking about. It was just OK. Being an avid Peruvian cuisine fanatic, maybe I had really high expectations. 

first we ordered some chicha which was really sweet. Then we started with a couple of causas del dia which were actually quite good, though it was topped with huancaina sauce which I've never tried before in that combination.

We then had a sea bass ceviche - which was seared and therefore not really a ceviche. The sauce was more like a tiradito & had ginger and sea weed that really just threw my pallet off.

We also tried the lomito saltado (OK), and the seco de cordero - meat was kind of chewy.

Left much to desire.... :(

Poor, well-meaning thing.

The service is friendly. The decor is interesting and sorta, kinda, vintage-y (but not really). The music is great (classic rock--the only rock worth listening to). And the food? It has its moments. Unfortunately, everything except the service fell somewhat short of its full potential.

Pork belly and sriracha wings were awesome. But the chicken and ramen were....not. The chicken was juicy and tender, but bland with little seasoning. The ramen broth tasted like burnt vegetables (a result, I guess, of the slightly charred greens it came with), the noodles were strange instant-ramen kind and the salmon add-on was copious but extremely fatty.

Desserts: Coffee and donuts weren't bad but I personally thought the coffee mousse got a little overwhelming after a while. The s'mores were too rich for me but tailor-made for the boy, except he was not a fan of the dark chocolate. For cocky-tails, I got the Negroni for Xmas but all the orange and chocolate was overwhelmed by the campari. Not a fan.

Think Tank, keep on reaching for those rainbows!

For some strange reason, when most people see a skinny white guy with a flannel shirt they don't think, "Now there is a guy that can rip it up on the baseball field/basketball court."  Well, folks, I'm here to tell you that when those people encounter me, they are completely wrong.

I felt like channeling my inner bro and spending a night having a few beers and watching a game, so I decided to give the New Deck Tavern a try.  I really enjoyed the feel of this place.  The space is laid out nicely and there are numerous televisions for your viewing pleasure.  The beer list was alright and my veggie fajitas were very good.  Not a lot of options for vegetarians, but I don't expect much from an Irish Pub.  My friend says the fries are pretty great, but I can't confirm that statement.

While the layout and televisions were great for my desire to watch the game, I couldn't help but think how this bar would be rather annoying if you were hoping to have a few drinks and a conversation.  All of the televisions could easily become distracting and keep you from being able to have a real discussion.  Also, the TVs and close proximity to Penn probably makes for some rowdy nights.

All in all, New Deck Tavern is a pretty good choice if you're looking to meet up and watch the night's game.
The nice thing about not being a student anymore is not having to wait for happy hour to get a Crunch Crunch roll (or two). This place kicks the crap out of Crave and all other nearby sushi.

"A BIG step above the rest" is how I would describe what I consider to be the best gym in Southern California - Breakthru Fitness. I've belonged to about 5 gyms (does that qualify me to be an authentic critic?!) and Breakthru Fitness is the best in all categories. I go to the gym in the morning and I am always welcomed warmly by the receptionist.  The members are a wonderful mix of  individuals and we enjoy the fellowship of each other.  The classes are top notch, fun, and physically challenging. The instructors provide a great work out and continually "change it up" so our bodies are challenged. MIchelle and Phil, the owners, are caring people, who really know how to provide the best workout environment in southern California. Michelle and Phil and the entire staff are friendly and  professional and care deeply about making Breakthru Gym the best it can be for all of its members. You will never find a cleaner gym!!  Breakthru hosts many charity events on the premises, indicating their concern for the community it serves.  Hats off to Breakthru Gym!!     You have a member for life!!

The best, quality sushi in the town. Service was great. Although the place is pretty small, and not good for the young kids. I mean, 3 or 4 years old kids can easily bother the other customers who sit next to. 
Whenever I want to eat sushi I think about Ajihei, but I found myself in Whole Foods Market which is convenient for my children.

Best coffee in the area and nice, friendly staff. I wish it had a bigger seating area. If it did, I would definitely visit more often. Maybe one day I'll splurge and buy my coffee beans here instead of buying the cheapo $4.99 sludge beans from Westside Market.

I really like Joe The Art of Coffee and think it is a great addition to the Columbia campus. It is bright and airy, they take credit cards, they have good coffee and snacks and it has a nice ambiance.

However, there are many things to dislike about it. The lines are always dreadfully long, they do not carry a large selection of sandwiches and run out frequently, they do not have many outlets for laptops and they do not have enough seats.

Overall, I really like Joe but it's not conducive area for a good study session.

My boyfriend asked me out here!

this place is pretty classy and expensive. i think the bill was 80+  for two people. 

the appetizer- calamari was pretty good.
the sake marinated prawns-- omg the door to my heart, i tell you!
as for sushi, they had a pizza ROLL- but since i wanted to stick to the safe side and order something i like, i got the crunchy roll tempera. I really like but then again, i may be biased just cause it's my favorite!

Too bad this place was a bit too noisy, If my boyfriend didn't ask me out by asking the waiters to put a note saying will you go out with me on the assorted gelatos dessert we got, i would never be able to hear what he was saying lol.

I went to ecco for a first date and I could not have been more impressed with the food and atmosphere. Although we had a reservation we had to wait a few minutes, but the place was packed so I understood completely. The little table was cozy although I really hate being seated right on top of other diners. We asked our waiter for some wine suggestions. He seemed a little flustered but the wine list is very extensive and many are by the bottle only, so it is hard to have a good knowledge if you cannot taste the guest on it. In the end he selected a great pinot noir, Au Bon Climat. For appetizers we had the fried goat cheese (heavenly) the baby octopus (spicy and tangy) and some chorizo. The couple at the table next to us suggested the apps as they said they had dined at ecco many times. They were very friendly and it made me appreciate the close quarters more. For entrees my date had the lamb ribs which were fall off the bone tender and delicious, and I chose the roasted duck which was perfectly cooked to just the right temperature. The side dishes of lentils and brussel sprouts were incredible and I don't even like brussel sprouts! They were crispy and buttery and so flavorful. I was impressed that they did not have typical or boring sides such as mashed potatoes or asparagus. Everything was divine and I would give ecco 4.5 stars if I could only because I expected better wine knowledge.

I love this place! They have an A and the salads are made to order. I always get the avocado salad with blue cheese and a fresh carrot juice. My boss loves the "fresh complexion" juice they make. I am so glad there is something like this in this college area where everything else is just fast food with higher prices. Their smoothies are really good too. People are really nice.. Not too much else to say! I go here probably 3 times a week!
Great for academics. Well-priced.

Today I walked in here and it smelt like thanksgiving. I then spent the next few minutes debating how much longer this vegetarian thing will last (6 years going) But really, I love their veggie sandwiches, they are always made with the same eye for quality, and everything always tastes fresh (with the exception of one week of bad avocados... but we all know that happens). All in all, this is a good place to grab a quick, cheap and dependable sandwich.

Lunched today at "The Kong." I had a diet coke and chicken curry rice plate for $6.55 +tip. It was pretty good, rice a little dried out, but still for the price, a winner.  I decided to look at other yelpers thoughts. I do agree, the servers are questionable, well, yeah, pretty bad and slow. You have to remember, it's a weird place to begin with. The landmark Kip's Bar with burgers and pizza with a Chinese restaurant below and some type of ice cream stand (looks dirty, too). While I do have fond memories of the old SHKg on Shattuck Ave., this store is no where even close. I guess my fellow yelpers are right. $8 for lunch, still not bad.

I love pretty much everything about Pepper's. It was one of the first restaurants I ever visited on Franklin St., and I haven't found a better pizza place since.

It's hard for me to describe the decor - I would say it's vaguely punk-ish or grungey, but I've always thought the atmosphere was quite friendly. 

The calzones are delicious, but I almost always order a white slice with chicken and black olives. Their menu allows for much more creativity, but it works for me. 

Service is always polite, but sometimes kind of slow. The prices are probably a little higher than some of the other pizza restaurants in the area, but it's definitely worth it.

Excellent used bookstore. I've never been to Leon's but this one has a great collection and the prices are reasonable. We need at least one good used bookstore in every decent sized city so please support this place. Oh and no, I'm related to the owner. I just love books and these mom and pops are dropping like flies. Not good. Hey even the major bookstores are dropping like flies. Look what happened to Borders at the Santa Monica Promenade.  We also lost about five other smaller bookstores over the past few years.  

From now on, whenever I go on vacation I try and buy at least one book at each mom and pop. I know my one man crusade won't fix the problem of vanishing bookstores but I gotta do my part. 

Hollywood Howie

When I saw this place open, I was confused at the crazy line for it. I thought "hmm it must be something pretty amazing for there to be a line." So I went on 1/27/11 to try one of these cupcakes. The wait was maybe 20-30 mins. I finally got inside and noticed these cupcakes were small, usually gourmet cupcakes for 3.50 are big so you feel like you are getting your moneys worth. We tried the Red Velvet and the Chocolate PB. I would avoid the Chocolate PB if you go. The cake was very dry and did not taste that good, and the frosting was strange. The Red Velvet was much better, but almost too sweet for me and I love sugary frosting. 

To be fair I am comparing this place to Babycakes in Hillcrest. Babycakes is 50 times better! The cupcakes are twice the size and are moist and flavorful. Their frosting is creaming and delicious! Use that time you would have waited in line and drive down to hillcrest. You will be glad you did!

The name doesn't lie. I've only been to this location, and everytime I've eaten there I always wished I hadn't. It usually comes back to haunt me, if you know what I mean. I've got doubts about how fresh the seafood is. It's not hard to make a salad, but they managed to not even be able to accomplish that. The crab balls, all filler and for the price that isn't acceptable. The fruity cocktails almost always have flies in them. I won't complain about the service because it's just as bad as everywhere else in Blacksburg. I will never eat there again.

I went to school at Poly and still dream about firestones. The tri tip, of course, but I was always more of a Pig Sandwich (pulled pork) type of guy. 
I went to school in 2000-2002 during the awesome Lakers-Kings playoff matchups. Situated almost exactly half way between LA and the Bay Area, the town was amazing for the rivalry, and Firestones was ground zero. 

You would have to get there a couple hours and a few dozen beers before tip-off and the crowd, food, alcohol was simply amazing. Some of my fondest memories.

Any time I'm driving up 101, my wife makes me stop and get her a sandwich and a side of the baked beans. The garlic bread is amazing, the dipping sauces are all amazing.

Haven't had a bad item on the menu.

I've seriously considered a 'white castle' style day trip (3 hrs each way).

This place is my number one choice on The Ave and everytime I go there, the food is good, the portion is just right, and price affordably for us college students. I have tried almost all Teriyaki places on The Ave (south of 45th at least) and this place consistently satisfies my needs. Also, it is close to the campus, has a big dining area, and now serves yogurt! Yums! Makes me want to order some Chicken Yakisoba right now.

Also, they have a good menu for Korean food as well.

This was a fantastic experience.... and I call it an experience because it felt like a lot more than just dinner.  It was like a food theme park.  There were so many really good things that I tried, but I just wish I could have fit more in.  Plus, all of the staff in costume... if that doesn't have "theme park" written all over it, I don't know what does.

The drinks were fantastic and very creative, normally I would have wine with a nice dinner, but the cocktails were so good that I kept with those.  
Their "Salome's Potion" was incredible, definitely my favorite.  

The food was really interesting.  Not every dish was incredible, but they were all good and interesting.  Their seafood dishes were by far the best.  The "caspian heaven" was incredible and so were the cornets with tuna tartare.  

The setting and ambiance was nice.  This was a date, so the romantic feel was really nice.  We happened to come when it was a little busy, so it was a little loud at times, but to be expected.  

The one and only complaint that I have is that I wish that they took reservations.  I didn't wait for long, but it would have been nice to arrange it in advance.
Nice atmosphere, and right next to the beautiful Krannert center.  Also, they have $2 lattes on Wednesdays!

The pizza is not bad but nothing special. The service was okay and the eating areas are nice. There is an indoor dining room and a large fenced in outdoor patio. In the inside dining room, there is a small bar with a typical selection of beers on tap.

If I can give La Rez one bit of advice, it would be: Don't rest on your laurels. 

I too was there for the Triangle Restaurant Week. My food was excellent, though for the pricing, I expect local, non-chain restaurants to be incorporating (at least some) local ingredients listed on the menu for that price point. Not only that, but the service is not at $50+ a person standards. Memorize your specials, what's 86'd, be polite, don't order me around, and don't pour water all over my place at the table. 

I'm happy to pay the money for great food and a lovely evening, but don't take advantage of TRW to slack off or not put your best foot forward to support your waitstaff. I don't feel like making waitstaff generate a $25 pre-fix discount at the register from the normal menu is entirely appropriate. They didn't choose to take part in this, the restaurant did. We are were an 8 top. Sometimes that does take more than one person.

I'm there for the experience, not just the food on my plate or the drink in my glass. After the other reviews, this seems to just be the sprinkles on the whipped cream, on the already iced cake...but it's yelp, and there's my two cents.

I have had many good meals here. It's nice to have a little taste of Portugal so close to the city.  I usually get the Bife  Tasca com Ovo a Cavalo which is great (steak topped with egg, stir fried vegtables, and round cut fries on the side) The atmoshere is very cozy and I like how they hang all the decorative dishes on the walls. The portuguese wines are great too!

Two words: date spot. 

Cuchi Cuchi is an entirely different world inside. The waitresses and decor alike is a mix of retro/antique/couture/awesome. As Christian would say: they're pretty fierce. The ambiance, mixed crowd, low lighting, savory aromas and exciting menu make for a fun, inviting and romantic date spot.

Amazing selection among the tapas and drinks. I was there over a year ago but I still remember what I got: sizzling garlic shrimp and couscous with a strawberry basil martini. The shrimp were miniature and cooked to perfection- they sort of had that satisfying POP when I bit them. They came in a little plate with a delicious garlic sauce (strong... but not too strong.) I don't usually like seafood, but these were amazing. The couscous was simple (I mean, its couscous- how complicated could it get) but absolutely delicious. It clumped perfectly together on my fork, and it was light and fluffy on my tongue, seasoned just right. 

Then there was the drink. I generally like basil. I put it in food all the time. But my experience with the herb in drinks has been depressing, outside of Cuchi Cuchi. Whereas other bars will overpower the drink with strong, sweet and somehow bitter basil (*cough* Noir-ehem... excuse me.), the strawberry basil martini at Cuchi Cuchi was perfectly proportioned. 

It ended up being a little pricey, and you'll probably need to get a second dinner on the way home since the servings are small, for two of us our bill ended up being $100. But if you like him/her enough, its totally worth it to splurge.

Everyone should go here at least once.

Emma has been giving me facials for over 10 years!  She knows my skin and follows through on regular follow-ups.  Emma is Amazing! She is very sincere and provides constructive recommendations to help keep her clients looking their best!  She is very thorough and gives her clients the very best treatments.  She takes her time and doesn't push unnecessary, expensive products.  I recommend Emma  to all of my friends for their facials, hair treatments, etc.. She is very well located within walking distance from UCLA and just across the street from a Free Parking Structure.
Great genuine Mexican tacos. They have my favorite: lengua (beef tongue).  Do broaden your horizons and eat here.

Best slice in Princeton. If you like thin-crust pizza, you're going to love Old World. The crust is nicely floured and has the perfect balance between glutinous chewiness and that high-temperature sear. The sauce is understated with a bit of a lingering tang, which is the perfect compliment to their aromatic sausage.
