They were just closed a few days to fix their oven. Since they opened back up, I've had two of the best slices I've ever gotten here.

I love Armando's breakfast burritos. They are the perfect start to my day! You can pretty much ask him to make any variation of his breakfast burrito. The customer service is great and the truck is conveniently located on campus. The service is usually pretty quick, but if you're going during peak hours (around lunch time) you can always call in advance and place your order. Cheap and delicious food - highly recommended!

Many who have visited know the Cantor Arts Center (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/BOXMGHigA-fvRjwPRBCdGQ?select=BFKycr5oZjPMhMkgLlYriQ) at Stanford University as a fascinating place to visit with its beautiful mix of architectural style and seventeen galleries of art to enjoy entirely free of charge, and I can just as easily write about some of my favorite features (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/BOXMGHigA-fvRjwPRBCdGQ?select=4oPCmp5yuMQrV-FK19GLyw and http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/BOXMGHigA-fvRjwPRBCdGQ?select=UMUqf3wtyrfN9Cu2C5ycXg) and exhibits of the museum itself, but I've decided to base my review on one of the museum's more popular annual events.

The museum's annual Family Day was held this past Sunday in part through a generous donation from the Koret Foundation.  The theme of this year's event was something very meaningful to me, Chinese culture.  Chosen to coincide with its current special exhibition [Tracing the Past, Drawing the Future: Master Ink Painters in 20th-Century China], activities for the special Family Day focused on the art, music, dance and storytelling of the Chinese culture.

Several volunteer organizations including One Brick and Hands On Bay Area organized large groups of volunteers to come out to help staff the many activities scheduled.  Myself being the volunteer junkie that I am decided I wanted to be part of this event so I signed up through One Brick to be part of volunteer crew.  Once signed in we were told that our volunteers would be staffing children's art projects throughout the museum.

The art projects included building a Great Wall, creating opera masks, paper blossom trees, paper lanterns (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/BOXMGHigA-fvRjwPRBCdGQ?select=gf8inWTzFRxAp2hg29ITpw), coloring pre-printed dragon drawings and the project of my choosing, creating dragon puppets (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/BOXMGHigA-fvRjwPRBCdGQ?select=PYBY-Dpp3dCrvYGTtBor9Q).  

For our hand puppets we had a checklist and some pre-made puppets for display, and our job was to teach any child who wanted to create their own puppet how to do so.  Our involvement varied from child to child, and I found out the best way to determine how much we would help was to ask each individual child directly.  I was amazed by how many trusting parents just left their kids with us and walked away, but many parents stayed also to help their child and join in on the fun.  Working and teaching younger children isn't a task I'm very familiar with, but I actually enjoyed my duties for the day.  In the several hours of working side by side with many preschool children I was quite amazed with their artistic abilities even at their young age.  I can honestly say I did not encounter a single bad child throughout the day.

We were told the museum staff didn't anticipate the high attendance for this event.  They estimated some 2500 people arrived just in the first hour of the event, but despite the crunch of kids (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/BOXMGHigA-fvRjwPRBCdGQ?select=Nea50gG7OX0vYB6Eu73k1A) who showed up we handled the masses well, and judging from the smiles on the kids' faces they had a great time too.

What a rewarding way to spend a Sunday afternoon!  You can volunteer for future Family Days by contacting the Cantor Arts Center directly.

This Mexican style restaurant is set up in a house on Rosemary, a block over from Franklin.  The service here is great-- it's a great casual spot  for the college crowd pockets.  The food and service are good, try the beans & rice with a chimichanga-- it's awesome.

Ehhh. But let's do the math together.

My two lovely daughters and I had lunch here and sat outside at a table in the shade. One star!

We ordered chicken fingers and a club sandwich, both of which included honey mustard (a family favorite, plus I'm Southern, so the stuff runs through my veins). And the fries were crunchy and tasty. One more star!

The food was pretty good, and they had the new Flying Fish Summer Brew. What comes next, boys and girls? That's right: one additional star.

But the service...as I said earlier...ehhh. Dude was nice enough but he kept disappearing for extended stretches of time, drinks weren't refilled and he took a long time to bring the check. So long that I thought summer vacation might be over already.

So it's one, two, three stars for New Deck Tavern! Isn't math fun?

If you love local ingredients, supporting local businesses, and of course, ice cream, you will love this place!  But in the summer, watch out, because the lines often extend out the door and down the sidewalk.

I am always amazed at the flavors they come up with, and their flavors often reflect the time of year it is and ingredients that are in-season.  You can always expect a new interesting flavor each time you visit this place.  I was really grossed out that they came up with avocado ice cream, until I tried it, and it was amazing!  I highly recommend it.  Other favorites include mango, and Guiness and Baileys Irish Cream (for St. Patricks day of course!)

The only complaint I could possibly have about this place is the seating, or lack of.  In the winter, this definitely discourages me from coming in more; but in summer, its always nice to get some Bent Spoon and walk around Palmer Square, or sit in the library square.  If you only have a short time in Princeton, and are craving ice cream, go to this place!

I have a mixed review for this place. 

After reading great reviews on yelp, I decided to try this place. I am looking for a nail place to have a nail party for my birthday. Things started off well, since they immediately returned my call and scheduled an appointment. Two days before my scheduled appointment, I received a call saying that the appointment was double booked, and they needed to change my time. That would have been fine, except I travel 100% of the time out of town for work and have a limited amount of time in Atlanta. The appointment was rescheduled, but I was later called and informed that they arranged for an additional person to come in for my original appointment. Great! 

The facility itself is very nice, and I enjoyed my actual services. The problem occurred when the technician looked at my finger nails and realized I needed a gel manicure. She informed me that my appointment was only for a basic manicure and they didn't have enough time scheduled for a gel manicure. My choices were to get a polish change, have my gel removed to get a basic manicure, or pay a cancellation fee for not getting a manicure. WTH???

Alayna came over to explain that because I only asked for a manicure and pedicure, that was the service that I HAD to get or pay a cancellation charge. Really?? Just very matter of fact about it. I explained that my very first time getting gel nails happened 2 weeks prior, and I had no idea that I had to specify that I needed a gel manicure. At Sugarcoat, they specifically asked if I wanted gel nails when I called to schedule the appointment and also told me they would work with me since I wasn't sure what type of nails I wanted to get on that day. THANKS SUGARCOAT!!! 

I also did not appreciate that Alayna frequently called me "sweetie". I am a grown woman, please do not insult me by calling me "sweetie". 

An apology for the miscommunication would have been great, but that was not what I received. I received an explanation. It's so unfortunate, because I was looking forward to bringing a party of 10-15 people to the nail salon to celebrate my birthday. 

As I've seen with previous posts, I'm sure Alayna will offer an explanation in a kind of tongue-in-cheek way. Thanks, but no thanks. 

If anyone has recommendations for an upscale nail salon, please let me know. 

"Sweetie"

O-M-G.. I think I died and went to heaven after eating their clam chowder! I'm from San Jose and day dream about making a drive down there just for their food. Anyone wanna join me!? ;)

Of all the times i've been to Pismo, i've never tried this place and was bragged to about how good this place really is.. Well I couldn't go another Pismo trip without trying it. We went to the SLO location. It was clean and cute.. Just a little small for all the traffic that they get. I ordered the clam chowder in a bread bowl.. Upon my first bite, I wish I would have ordered 10! They toast the bread perfectly.. Take the inside out and toast it with a little butter for a nice golden crispy dipping side! The actual clam chowder was full or creamy, clam-y goodness! Don't forget the seafood topping!!!! For a dollar more you can get crab & shrimp on top!! Soooooooo good!!!! 

Someone.. Anyone... Let's go now!!

Oh, and they also have pastries! I didn't try any as I was just there for their clam chowder. Maybe next time!

Taking it to 3.5 

Their dim sum still rocks my socks. But the still after how long we haven't been here, there is still no one in the place (i.e. patrons). And we were told one of the buns we ordered would take to long when we were craving AKA "get the hell out, you're done". 

Good food, not so good service. Oh well, I'll keep coming back regardless! So yummy with the funny :D

I have occasionally found some clothes or records here, but this store pales in comparison to the Davis Square location.  The Davis store has better prices, better selection, and an awesome downstairs filled with housewares and electronics.

Edited 3/26/08:
You can forget what I said about the Davis Square Goodwill.  Due to a management change, expect higher prices and less stock.  Still worth checking out from time to time, but not what it used to be.

This, apparently, is a sister restaurant to the location on Wickenden Street. Nam Yaa Soup ($8.50) and Marinated Chicken with Rice ($8.50). The quantity of food is comically small for the money. We literally laughed when our food came. Unless they can get this dialed in, their fate will be the same as a few other in this spot - out of business,

So I've been here before for the ever-so-fun (and required) course packs for class. That is usually not something I want to rate a store on because it's a crazy busy line and it's never fun to have to fork over that money when you know you can't sell it back for anything. (Or at least, I don't think you can?)

The other day I came in to get some non-school copies done. The guy working was helpful, even though he seemed to automatically resort to them making my copies instead of letting me use the self-service machines (which would have been even cheaper for me). Oh well. I got my file uploaded, sent it to the printer, picked out the color paper (which is what cost depends on), and printed my project on 7-cent green paper.

It was a good experience and I was happy because the cost was cheaper than... the other place we've recently used for printing. Next time I'll have to remember to use the self-service, though, because I would have been able to use my Student Survival Kit coupon that would have lowered the per-page costs to 4 cents. (Both are cheap, but it adds up and I'd rather save some $ where I can!)

The lab was the answer to a clean hangout with great micro brews and now offers a full bar for all you Vodka lovers out there.  Its got some great comfort food options and the deserts are a lot of fun.

I went here for the first time today, and I was very impressed with this bookstore. It has a really great mix of used and new books, which I think is hard to find. It also has a library feel to it more than a bookstore I think. 

I always end up going to the COOP instead of here, but I think I will have to add this to my list. My only concern is that I didn't see much seating to sit around and read, but I'll have to look for that more the next time I go. 

I also enjoyed the cards throughout the store with suggested reading. That is something I really appreciate, and when they come from places like Barnes and Noble, you're kind of wondering if some 17 year old kid wrote the review and even knows what he's talking about. Since there were so many, and such a range, it's makes you feel like these people are really into all kinds of books. 

Going to be stopping by more in the future!

There are plenty of junky items to pick up, squint and blow dust off and put right back down but if you love grandmother dresses, you are in luck!

Plus you always end up chit chatting with the laid back helpful staff and some other funky customers who gasp in awe when you put on that perfect red leather jacket you've always wanted but was too pansy to really buy. They are the ultimate confidence boosters AND you walk out with only $10 spent. Not bad.

It's sort of sad that people go in here to look for "costumes" whereas I actually go in there looking for something to wear for the weekend. Oh well.

I also enjoy passing by when it's warm outside and seeing all kinds of "Oh boy I've always wanted one of those global studies classroom globes in my living room" pieces scattered in front. Nobody really comes outside to see if you steal either. You can look and not feel pressured.

It sure does it for me... for the rest of the day in Harvard Square at least.

Just to be clear, I give this place 4 stars for doing exactly what it is supposed to do.  HamDel provides me with the fastest, greasiest, most satisfying delivery in the entire neighborhood. Not only will they deliver with no minimum purchase, but they ALWAYS get the order right and they ALWAYS arrive in seemingly superhero-like speed.  I'm not sure how it is possible to cook a burger and have it at my door in the amount of time they do it, but I don't ask questions.  Seriously satisfying food + seriously cheap prices + seriously quick delivery = 4 stars

I've only ever ordered a burger and either fries or onion rings, so I don't know how their other stuff is, but this stuff is delish for my nights off from calorie counting.

I 've been here a few times now. Small family-run place in what appears to be an old filling station. Lots of people working inside. Fast friendly service.

Small menu of the taco, taquito and quesadilla type.  Good tasty tacos but they are on the small side. Besides the usual carne asada, they also have unusual fillings like vegetable, soyrizo with potato and conchinita pibil. 

The tortillas used for the tacos are hand made.

I never used to like going here but in the last few months I have made out like a bandit at this place.  You may have to visit a few times to find the perfect retro shirt for that show at TTs or finally decide to buy the paisley tie so you can wear once at a party and never again.  

Things usually don't jump out at this place because the staff and the inner circles of fashion whores take all the good stuff.  Yet with a little perseverence and a watchful eye, you can seriously hook yourself up and get all of those compliments in social settings to boost that deflated ego of yours.  

"Love your shirt, man?  Is that vintage?" 

Certain articles from the Garment District can be great conversation starters...especially for dudes that are striking out with the ladies as of late...

Bottom line:
God, this place is such a mixed bag. Food is pretty good but last time I was there I saw not one but TWO GIANT RATS ON THE DECK!!! 
Everyone, when there is smoke there is fire. You've been warned, and I'll add these were not mice we're talking about here. The food is fine, so I will bump up my review when they take care of this disgusting vermin problem. 

The atmosphere at night (and often in the day) tends to be LOUD. Don't come here if you're looking for a quiet date, unless it's warm out and you can sit outside - I highly recommend the deck, it's beautiful and won't lead you to wear out your vocal cords by the time dinner's over.

Waitresses are very sweet here, and I can say that they've never messed up the bill for us. They'll obsessively refill your water after you've taken one sip so if you're like me and find that annoying while you're trying to eat and converse with your comrades, hide your glass or something.

Food report card:
Dishes overall tend to be not so hot in temperature - Thai food is not the kind of cuisine to eat cold! Most veggie entrees run around $7.95, meat entrees $8.85, and seafood entrees around $11.95 or so. Note that they do NOT INCLUDE RICE usually - it's an extra $1 a person, and that is a royal pain. 

Pra Ram / Peanut Satay w/ Napa Cabbage - (C+) The peanut sauce here is missing some sort of spice, and I still can't quite figure out what it is. This dish has always been lukewarm (in temperature) when I've ordered it, and I've had it twice. Methinks this is just too much of the kind of thing you could make at home on the stove with the white-bread cultural experience even us Berkelians have foodwise. This is the kind of thing your uncle Joe might make for homecooked Asian night - you know, the guy who insists the only word he needs to know how to spell is "USA." Now, he's a good cook, but he's just too damn simple at it.
Green Curry - (A-) I have yet to find a Thai restaurant who has screwed up green curry. There's just something about it. Well done.
Pad Thai Tofu - (B) Average-sized portion; tofu was a little overcooked and noodles too chewy but the sauce was near perfect. Warning: They skimp on the green onion/leeks in here, at least to my taste.
Red Curry Vegetable - (A) Spicy but not blow-your-brains-out hot; this was cooked perfectly and there was a great curry-to-vegetable ratio which I've found a lot of other places have trouble with. Curry itself was perfect.
Fried Banana with Coconut Ice Cream - (B) Smaller portion of that excellent banana than one would like, but it was pretty good nevertheless. Ice cream was to die for.
Jasmine Rice - (B) Average-sized portion; I've always considered the rice quality to be synonymous with how good the restaurant is (usually). This stuff was a tiny bit dry but nevertheless did the trick.

IHOP is probably the closest 24-hour restaurant in campustown other than Perkin's which is on Springfield. The selections are pretty standard and the portions are huge. The service is good but not great. Well, it's IHOP, so I wouldn't expect anything more than average.

One of the first places I ate when I moved here and it for a second it made me think there was a resturant scene in this town (there isn't).  Excellent food, good veg choices.  I've yet to have a bad meal here.

Quick, cheap and really friggin' delicious! Great for a quick bite or even, a lunch date! 

During the busy times (lunch and early dinner), they have a dedicated person making fresh, hand-made tortillas. The barbacoa and pork are my favorite... very juicy and flavorful at only $1.50.
They also offer very good vegetarian options such as soy-chorizo and potatoes with avocado sauce, $2.00.

I used to hang out here all the time because one of my closest friends resided here and worked here.  Let me just say this:  Run as fast as you can.  It is in poor condition and most importantly the elevator is not up to code.  In fact, they had a problem with a serial pooper who would take poops in the elevator and leave it there.

I gave it an extra star because they have a flat screen in the lobby where the staff will sit and watch a movie and some of the tenants are invited to join.  That's about the only thing this place has going for it.

If it's between your place, or the place of the person who lives in this building, pick your place to hang out.  Trust me.

Fried Pickles: All I want for Christmas, my birthday, Valentine's, whatever holiday will make someone get me these...I want them NOW!

I have searched endlessly across the nation for a fried pickle spear that will top these...

If you haven't tried them...you haven't lived.

Even though Plucker's isn't a Diner/Drive-In/Dive...someone should get these pickles on TV...or maybe not...because then there won't be enough for me!!!

I'm another who ended up here because the Friendly Toast was too crowded.  I recommend the Irish Breakfast.  The coffee was excellent.  The service was excellent.  The "jazz" band I could have done without.

So I used to live in Westwood, and was there for about half a year after Pastagina opened. If what you're looking for is cheap Italian food to-go, this is the place to go. I came here a few times because they had free gelato to go with your pasta. I'm not ashamed to say it because the gelato was AMAZING. Yes, I would buy a bowl of pasta just for the gelato. I'll have to reconsider coming if the gelato isn't part of the deal though. 

But, I have to say, I love the modern decor of the restaurant! Note to self when decorating my future home, take a cue from Pastagina. Other than that, Pastagina is good for about two meals, which is great if you're a poor college student.

Usually I like to check out places at least twice before a review, but I honestly had such a good experience here I gotta throw out some props.

First off, the decor and ambiance pulls off a nice trifeCta of cozy, cute, and classy -- was here on like Monday afternoon I think, 3pm-ish. Atmosphere matters, ya know? Don't matter if it's Daniel or a dive -- if the aesthetics ain't chill the meal's gonna go down rough.

The lady and I started off with some sangria (unique fruit combo, pleasant) and caprese apps (usual, with some fantastic mozz). She had a vegetable rigatoni and I a grilled salmon entree with mashed potatoes and some greens. She seemed to dig hers (I concurred) and as for my salmon -- it was seemingly nothing extraordinary, but all the tastes on the plate really meshed well and after the meal I was full and completely satisfied. We chased the main course with some dessert whose name eludes me -- vanilla gelato (was ice cream, far as I could tell) mixed with espresso -- think root beer float style. It was a nice cap to the meal.

One of those outings where nothing really blew me away, nothing rang out as particularly de'lish -- but the nice space, our three courses, and chitchat with my wonderful company all blended together for a top notch late-lunch dining experience. I'll be back to update after Round #2!!

Food is OK, service was good, but the atmosphere is funky. The layout, furniture, etc. is pretty much identical to Baja Fresh, except with a pinkish coat of paint and a couple of pegboards with cat photos. The owner/manager walked around the whole time and hovered over the tables. I'm sure he is just trying to make sure everyone is happy, but I'd rather just talk with my friends and let them know if there's a problem.

The menu is an odd mix of diner and upscale: Breakfast all day, reasonable lunch prices and expensive dinners. I had a beer and burger with curly fries, which was great. My friend ordered a steak sandwich and hated it: tough and hard to chew, with lots of gristle and fat.

Overall not terrible, but with all the great restaurants around it, I probably won't be back.

I've known the owner of this t-shirt business since he was selling hemp jewelry and doing hair ties on the Avenue way back in the day.  Now he is hand-designing some super-cute t-shirts and selling them at his street booth and on the net.

Don't be fooled--these aren't your average tees.  Phil really takes pride in his work.  He prints his original designs on all American Apparel shirts, which means that all his products are 100% cotton, 100% American made, and 100% sweat-shop free.  The shirts and the designs last and last.

I am a real fan of Young Punks, which is his line of baby/kid's wear.  Love the Jimmy Hendrix tee (Jimmy in a cloud of purple haze), the purple Buddha, the silver Thai elephant, Holly Golightly.  A baby in a shirt that says "I'm WIth Stupid"?!  HAHAHA.   TOO CUTE!!!

Support a really great guy and his socially conscious local business.  Check out the website!  
www.catch23.com

I have a huge crush on Bobby Flay and def would bone him if I could, but BBP was pretty mediocre. Sorry!!!!!!!!!

I found the sauces heavy-handed and the bun unremarkable. The meat was delicious, but too many ingreds?

I had the Dallas Burger. 

But I guess I like LA hamburgers better.... they tend to have more upscale ingredients that are a bit more texturally variable and flavor-ally subtle.

awk!

What can I say about Wahoo's? I've never been to any other location besides this one so I can't really compare this one to any other. But I'm a fan. Why? Let's think..

They're cheap but good. It's hard to find that combo, but Wahoo's has it. You can get their tacos a la carte or in a combo (with rice and beans). The combo is pretty damn filling! I got the fish taco combo with avocado on the side (since I love love love avocado) and it was delish. Especially with the never-ending salsa. I think my friend and I ended up going through like six different sides of salsa. And we always made the staff get it for us.

Which brings me to another point. The staff. The service. They're all so nice and friendly! And quite helpful. They never complained about us asking for more salsa when they have a self-serve salsa bar. Hahaha, we are so lazy ^^#

I also like the way they decorated the place. Pretty much every inch is covered with skating/surfing stickers and/or posters. Although they do mix it up sometimes and stick on some other amusing sticker somewhere.

So while this place isn't WOW or amazing, it's still pretty good and it's worth visiting every now and then to get your fish taco fix for cheap.

I had a terrible experience at this store.  I had been the the store a couple of times, and it was always a decent haircut, if expensive for having 1-2 inches taken off a simple style.  

The last time (and I do mean last time) I was there they misread my haircut from their computer and buzzed a swath of 1/2" long stubble through my hair before I could tell them to stop.  I went to get an inch taken off and thinned, and left with a nearly shaved head on the day before Valentine's day that almost made my fiance cry.  What's worse, there was no manager there, so I had to pay for my ridiculous haircut at the time, even though a manager refunded my money later that day.  

Definitely not worth it, I will not be going back.

I'm a skeptic of expensive chocolate shops as hand made does not automatically equal good quality chocolate. However I've come to appreciate that Thomas Sweet chocolate is rather good.  The selection is large with everything from soft centres, bars, truffles, fudge, barks, and caramels. The sea salted dark chocolate caramels are amazing. My husband loved his milk chocolate cashew bark.  

This is a great place to buy yourself a treat or a little dessert chocolate after dinner somewhere in Princeton (i think they are open until at least 9pm maybe later on weekends).  Consider this 3.5 stars.

Haven't tried the food, but the iced chai was delicious.  More importantly, the atmosphere/decor was really neat, and it had lovely, outside seating.  Great location too.  Cool place for people watching, which is one of my favorite activities when sitting at a cafe / coffee shop.

My absolute favorite place for lattes and lunch in Claremont.  
The ham and cheese croissant melts in your moutha and is flaky goodness.  
The salads are delicious and very healthy. 
Sandwiches are generous size.  I had a hot dog once too- cheap and good.
I love the Iced Lattes too.  Actually quality coffee. 
And I forgot the cookies.  Always new variety and freshly made.
The owner, who is a very friendly guy, makes everything taste great.
Prices are also very low for everything and free wi-fi.  Also small but cozy.

I typically don't like eating at chains but this is an exception. Good soups and salads. My favorite: the chicken chipotle salad (I always ask for extra sauce which I later use when I cook or make sandwiches).

NOW CLOSED.  This is my staple for gifts.  The selection is huge, covers most tastes, and you rarely have to spend more than $10.  Choose carefully and your friend will never be able to tell how little you spent.
The childrens heart  center here is amazing! Thank you Dr. Daniel Murphy for all your help with my son and Marfan syndrom!

I miss this place. My office was in Cambridge Center and has now moved to a new building with a lake in Weston- we call it Gilligan's Island. I was lucky enough to be in Cambridge last night and pick up dinner. I ordered the Fried Rice and the Mushroom Chicken. Fried Rice was typical and yummy the chicken was not  too salty or mushy and the chicken was normal looking and tasting. (You know how you get Chinese food and look at the chicken and think: "What part of the chicken is THIS?"- not here) Bonus: I wanted an order of Crab Rangoons and they only had 3 ready (6 make an order) so they fried me up some fresh ones! Yum. The wonton to crabcreaminess ratio was a little off for me, but still, the filling was killer. 

I have had their sushi a ton, especially when dieting. The prices are great and the fish is always fresh and tasty. They have stuff in the case, but the sushi chef is always there and will gladly make you anything you want. 

Service is quick but still friendly.

My doctor tells me to drink more wine. So, okay. I like wine and I don't usually get stuck on my personal favorites either. So when I'm being a curious connoisseur, rather than by geography or varietal, the wines in the store are organized by "styles." By styles, it means crisp, fruity, mellow, bold, for example. So if you're into a particular bottle of wine and want to know what else is there similar to what you like, this store is a good place to browse.

Can't really complain too much about this place. It's close to where I live, and is surround by fast food places so to get a quality burger, waffle fries, and a drink for a reasonable price you can't beat this place.

Gets pretty crowded a lunch time, although what place doesn't. I got a bacon cheeseburger and let me tell you I'm itching to get my fix on soon. If you are in the area, or work in the Medical center, take a little walk or trip on over to Southwell's. You'll be glad you did.

Murphy's has the best atmosphere, patrons, employees, food, beer selection, space, price, drink specials, and Mortal Kombat II on campus.  If we haven't already met, then I'm sure we will at Murphy's.

Definitely as good as it gets on campus.

Best place to go for a remedial Manhattan pizza.
The pies are as big as the largest manhole cover you've ever seen.
And it's cheap!

So I'm just finishing up my leftovers of last night's Thalli and.... yep - still amazing. I'll be honest, I had absolutely no idea what I was ordering when I picked the first item on the large chalk board menu overhead. I'd had three glasses of sangria at the Yelp Elite event down the street and was coming down with a serious case of the drunchies. Everything sounded good. 

Fortunately for me, everything *was* good. Not just good, but phenomenal! This particular dish was served on a large compartmentalized tray with all kinds of goodies. I opted to add the tandori chicken (o.m.g.) and took them up on the gluten free option as well (the spongy GF flatbread rocks!). So many flavors, so little time (and room in my stomach... hence the leftovers). 

Can't wait to go back and try out some of the lassi and other interesting drink options. Although the night was warm, we sat in their gorgeous little courtyard (i'm such a sucker for Christmas lights). I also have to add that the staff is an outstanding bunch. They're consistently attentive, helpful and friendly. I don't get out to Chapel Hill often, but I'm already plotting a good excuse to return...

When we walked inside our hearts sank- we were expecting something a little nicer. We stayed, though, and were glad- the pizza was very tasty. We ordered whole pies so I can't speak to the quality of the slices.

Called "Noch's" for short by adoring, often-intoxicated Harvard students, this establishment is probably the first place new Harvard students visit once their parents leave.  The Sicilian pizza is heavenly and cheap.  Two thick, square, deep-dish pieces for under $5.  The owners and staff are fun, and if you make an effort to put away your cell phone while you order, they will smile and be nice to you.  If you ignore them, they'll basically ignore you.  Seems fair to me.  The owner once told me that the best selling pizzas are: Tomato-Basil, Pepperoni and Cheese.  Those three types add to 90% of the business.  Don't bother with the flat bread pizza, though I hear the subs are pretty good.  It's a hole-in-the-wall restaurant in the truest sense:  broken pavement on the road, uneven steps leading to the door, piles of cardboard boxes in the alley, but the Sicilian pizza is amazing.  More of a "I missed dinner" or "It's 1am and I'm famished" place than a first date or family place.

This is my favorite Thai restaurant in Atlanta!! The pad thai is my favorite dish but everything I have had here is fantastic!! The atmosphere is small but trendy and I have never had to wait for a table or had slow service! As long as Spoon continues to be this consistently impressive, I will be a loyal patron!

This place is cool. 

they redid the menu a little while ago, after realizing that they where referred to as the "ass-gaurd). and they did a good job. solid irish pub food. great wings.

STORYTIME!

One day, my sister (who was a UCI student at the time) decided to take a lad who missed his orientation to the school around campus. They get to talking and she finds out he's Lebanese. My sister gets excited and asks him if he likes Zankou Chicken (she loves.LOOOOOVES Zankou). He scoffed and shook his head and replied, "Asking me if I like Zankou Chicken is like asking a Mexican if he likes Taco Bell."

But that didn't break my sister's love for this place. And it didn't mine either. Yet another place that prevents me from becoming vegetarian; They do chicken right. I'm all about the white meat plate or the wrap, partnered up with my sister we get the half chicken or she gets the schwarma wrap and I the chicken and we share. I've never had their falafel, and I'm big on falafel but I just...can't...stay away...from chicken...

Next best thing: Garlic spread. I have to restrain myself from using it all on one bite. I can almost say that the chicken wouldn't be anything if not for the garlic spread. I'm surprised I haven't bought the 8oz. tub to take home and put on EVERYTHING. Lots of restraint on my part.

And Zankou has introduced two new and crazy things: Turkey (which is just as tasty but drier than chicken as turkey is) and they now accept credit card (a very dangerous thing indeed). Come for the Beck reference, stay for the everything else.

These people don't mess around. They do their jobs quickly, but they also do them right. I have gone to East Side Vision Care twice in the last two years, and each time have waited less than five minutes to see Dr. Gabriel. The good doctor has kindly listened to my confessions of rampant contact lens abuse, checked my eyes thoroughly to make sure that I haven't done any damage, answered my many questions, assuaged my fears, and offered sound advice. When I picked out new glasses from their wide selection of frames during my second visit, the staff patiently listened to my hemming and hawing, offered honest feedback, and helped me choose a great pair that didn't destroy my budget. As if all of this wasn't enough, they have always had my contact lenses and glasses ready within a day or two (I picked up my glasses mere hours after my appointment), they offer a student discount, and they're conveniently located right on the corner of Thayer and Waterman. Highly recommended.

Like Pinkberry and it's delicious. They too have the mochi balls that Pinkberry has as well (not on the menu).

The owner is really nice, they give 10% discounts to students and staff. 

The yogurt isn't as sour as Pinkberry, but it's better than any of Telegraph's other frozen yogurt places. Yogurt Park stinks!

I dig this place for its lunch specials.  I can spend 6-7 bucks for tea, soup, and an awesome dish.  I have had some only-ok dishes, and the occasional jackpot, but for 6 bucks I'm willing to hit and miss :)

My husband and I had sushi at Sadako for the first time and will not return.  The sushi here is just not good quality, in fact it is the worst we have ever had.  The fish, especially the tuna, did not taste fresh.  There was a definite fishiness about it.  Also the soft shell crab tasted bad, possibly the result of poor cleaning.  My husband had to spit it out into his napkin.  Tempura was like a heavy batter rather than the light, crunchy coating it should be.  Presentation was boring at best e.g. with tobiko spooned in a glop over part of the roll.   The sushi bar is very cramped.
There is much better sushi in Ann Arbor.

University Barber shop is a unique experience, almost all of the barbers are male (one female exception), and I believe all of them are over 50.  This probably isn't he place to go if you're looking at getting highlights done, but I get traditional male haircuts and the attention to detail is amazing.

A lot of times at supercuts, they almost rip your hair out with the buzzer, I suspect because most of the people working at supercuts have never had that thing used on them.  At the Barber Shop, they take appropriate care while brandishing a buzzer while still getting the job done quickly.

On top of that, they're much more laid back, and they often have ESPN on the tv while you're there, which is great.

The only weird/annoying thing about the place is they're closed on Tuesdays, but that's my biggest complaint.  They also only accept cash.

I visited the campus several times when I worked near the school.  Stanford is a place without a soul.  I've seen more life and met far more interesting people at community colleges.  A big disappointment.

Halo holds a record for having hosted more of my birthdays than any other establishment.  I've been coming here for years, and somehow this place always seems to be evolving to stay cooler than me.  I am going to get too old to be there before I ever catch up with this place in hipness factor.  Was just there last night for a Yelp Elite event, and it was nice to see such a down to earth crowd there.  Some nights it's club kids, others it's the sexy and swanky, but most of the time it's a decent blend of people.  Always good looking, rarely douchey.  Take your douchiness to Opera, thankyouverymuch.  

The place is hot, has a sexy vibe, and is always well maintained.  The staff are very chill, and not once in all my years have I had to flag a bartender for 15 minutes or stand there and be ignored.  They pour mean drinks, and while it's pretty easy to run up a big tab, never had to deal with anything watered down or sloppily made.  I think the great service is one of the big draws that makes me like this place more than typical clubs.  That, and ample places to park my ass when I want.  

Always love the music there, and they bring in some decent talent.  Typical names you'll see there are Kemit, Chris Grass, Dr. Katz, and the Turntables on the Hudson djs.  Very danceable stuff, which leads me to my one gripe with Halo... there is no real dance floor.  It's a lounge, not a club - I get it.  But when you play such fabulous music, you've gotta wanna dance.

I couldn't decide between 4 or 5 stars for this place. I love the atmosphere, the drinks, the food and the bartenders but the thing that makes me give it a 4 instead of a 5 is because of the prices. Their martinis range from $9-$12 and their appetizers were way too pricey for what you get. 
But that being said. I love going here for drinks on a chill night with friends. It's very quaint, quiet and classy. The area inside is rather small but they have a patio area that has lots of seating including benches along this beautiful glass fire pit.
The staff is always very nice and helpful. This last time we got the most awesome bartender EVER. Too bad I didn't get his name :(
An absolute gem.  Fresh ice cream cookie sandwiches.  Inexpensive.  The line gets long, but it is so worth it!  I ate one almost every day when I lived in Westwood.  I'm so naughty.

Good Chicken Kebabs. (9.99$)

They do not have LAMB.

Not tried their Beef.....

I visit the UCSD Bookstore at least 2-3 times per month, whether I want to or not.  Located in the Price Center, it's not even really a bookstore per se, since it carries computers, electronics, housewares, clothing, and various other items.  It's like a Target, but without the gnarly shopping-cart escalator.  Most of the time I end up here whenever we need something for the office, and our supervisor or admin assistant sends us on errands here.

The first level has the books and electronics.  The books are all priced at a premium.  The textbooks are especially guilty of being marked up and bundled with useless study guides and extras that nobody really needs.  But this is a common symptom of the textbook economy at all schools.  On the bright side, this is where I took advantage of Apple's education discount to snag myself a new Macbook (with a free iPod Touch and printer thrown in).  

Also, the first level has a massive selection of medical/science-oriented books.  And don't forget to check out the largest selection of plush novelty microbes that you'll ever see.  They're totally awesome.  (Both the books and the plush germs.)

The second floor has clothes, office supplies, and housewares.  Even though I've been at UCSD for several years, I can't bring myself to pay these exorbitant prices for a UCSD tee or hoodie.  I just can't do it.  I'm still waiting to win some campus raffle or something, because maybe then I can get my hands on a gift certificate.

On the other hand, when two buttons fell off my dress shirt an hour before I had to give a presentation, the UCSD Bookstore was the only place on walking distance where I could find a cheap sewing kit.  For saving my butt that one time, I will offer the UCSD Bookstore my grudging respect.

Moral of the story:  I feel safe and secure knowing that it's there, but I wouldn't actively recommend the UCSD Bookstore to the casual book-browser.

"Meh noodles."

With sub-standard service and par-food, I would say this place is "A-OK". Nothing really to write home about. I've been here a few times and overall, the place is average at best. The ramen both times didn't taste flavorful or special. The broth was oily as well and not as flavorful as I had expected.

Overall, for the price, I'd rather just pickup some ramen from a grocery store if I have a serious craving. There are tons of better noodle places on the ave (even across the street, like Pho) that I'd much rather  go to.

The VA in general sucks, they dont even let you talk to you doctor. Doctors dont even call back. You cant even talk to the secretary at the doctors desk. These people dont care about veterans all they care about is collecting a pay check. Ohhh and your doctors cahnges like every couple of months. all the people there have bad attitudes and treat us Veterans that fought for our country like shit. All these people that say that this place is helpfull and awesome are probably not even veterans. THIS PLACE SUCKS.

Firstly, love the name. I am also impressed with the southern style feel to the restaurant, even though we are sitting in Boston. I remember eating at local southern restaurants where they turned houses into restaurants. This restaurant did just that, and kudos to them. The food was pretty good over all, but I have to say the the south can make better authentic sweet tea. Oh, what's up with using drinking glasses as lamp shades. I heard that the owner paid some Italian decorator for that idea. Seriously..all that money and they came up with IKEA cost cutting style?  I should fire the owner for that :)  Nice.

I've been back many many times since my original review and I must finally upgrade this place to 5 stars!

I just love it so much.  Going over half a year now without a sip of beer I have learned to drink more cocktails.  This is and anvil are the specialists when it comes to cocktails.

What makes this place a standout 5 are the frozen drinks!  The frozen screwdrivers are sweet but still pack a powerful punch.  The rum and cokes are also the same way.  Who doesn't love a slushee? Who doesn't just melt over a slushee with alcohal?!?!

But my newest discovery is this place serves food!  On my recent outing for Heidi's birthday I had came straight from work and was in dire need for food.

They offer sandwiches.  I had the ham and cheese, with pesto mayo!!!  Some of the best tasting mayo's around.  I destroyed the sandwich and the side of potato salad. 

I can't spend all night here but it's a great pre drink place.

Have you ever played 7 minutes in heaven? How about 60 minutes in heaven? Well, you could play 60 minutes in heaven with Hyatt Regency's Spa within the Sporting Club. The full-body massage, scrub and facial will rejuvenate you no matter how tired, dilapitated or stressed out you are. They were open as early as 7 am, ready to take the most weary of individuals to get their day started off marvelously.

Using high-end products, calming expertise, and phenomenal service, The Sporting Club Spa attracts clientele such as the San Diego Chargers and other celebrities. Although the high price, I'm sure everybody deserves to spoil themselves every once in a while. Do yourself a favor and go get pampered for your birthday, anniversary, or just because it's Wednesday.

So much better than the chain game stores. It offers everything, card games, video games, and board games. Their huge tv is great, and John is always nice to talk to and great to customers.

Bought some of my favorite video games from this place. I'm sad I'm no longer walking distance from it.

the place itself is nice but they do NOT know how to do a shellac manicure. ive gotten them done before and although they took their time i dont think they are trained in shellac. my manicure started peeling right after i left the salon. i want a refund.
Najib is great. He still remembered me and wanted to help even if he had to direct me to out side of his business. He offered to help me find a strech  one time and another time a large van.

The *new* ABP (just opened at the end of January 2011) is fantastic. 

Changes:
Service has gone from being lousy to being quick and friendly.
Cleanliness has gone from grimy to spotless.
Food has gone from boring to new and attractive.
Decor has gone from depressing to cheerful.
Bathrooms have gone from dungeons to modern.
Layout has gone from crowded to sensible.
etc.

I overheard that they spent over a million dollars remodeling the store.  You can tell.  It looks great, it is far more attractive, and I very much hope they keep it up.  The management really needs to stay on top of the details, keep the menu fresh, and work hard to move people quickly through the store, especially during peak hours.  If they do this on a consistent basis going forward, Harvard Square will be much better off.

Well done, ABP!

I LOVE yogurt park and definitely have missed it since I graduated from Berkeley. 

First off, it's light and fat free (some are even fat AND sugar free), so you can eat a lot of it and not feel so bad :). They have new flavors everyday, but always have some type of vanilla flavor. They also have a great variety of toppings, and give you a LOT if you ask for toppings! I always get a mix of vanilla and something else, with toasted almonds. Delicious! 

This has always been my fav dessert place in Berkeley :).

$2 to rent any of the roughly 2387634987643bajillion random indie and mainstream movies/TV shows in the place?

Hell yes.

Suck it, Blockbuster - Rentertainment til I die.

Ithaca was one of my first stops on my cross country road trip last year, affectionately known as The Blaze of Glory 2007.  I knew if I was going to stop in Ithaca, I had to go to Moosewood.  Now, I didn't actually eat their supposedly scrumptious vegetarian food, because the kitchen wasn't open.  However, the bar was, so I'll just review the bar, and the general atmosphere.

The decor and overall ambiance are kind of bland.  It's not quite homey, and it's not really laid back and kitchy.  The bar/waiting area had those yellow wicker chairs.  However, their drinks were tasty.  They have a pretty impressive list of cocktails, and many were made with fresh fruit.  Also, the bar gave out free chips and salsa with drinks.  That's always a pleasant kick.

I have *extreme* jealousy for current Stanford students!  I graduated a couple years ago, but I would have loved to have a place like this on campus during school.

I've tried a lot of different fro-yo places on the peninsula, but I have to say that fraiche is my favorite. The soy frozen yogurt with strawberries and wildflower honey gets me every time.  The taste of the yogurt is very unique, and the texture feels "home-made".  Keep in mind that it's not as tart or as creamy as Red Mango or Pinkberry, if that's what you're into. 

Don't leave is place without putting wildflower honey on your yogurt!

Movie-goers should stay on the I. House's radar, as they're constantly screening new, old, and rare films, often for low or no money. The staff here is incredible, and for its diversity and planning, The I. House is nationally renowned. 

Just understand that you don't have to live here to benefit. Truth be told, I think my own college experience would've been exponentially better had I been living in conditions/environment like this.

This place is located right next ti UCLA in the Westwood area.  Very busy traffic but if you are able to find a parking spot and are in the area, you have to check Diddy Riese Cookies out.  I don't know of any other place that lets you pick 2 cookies and ice cream of your choice to make your very own ice cream sandwich!  And the best part of it is its only $1 !!!

I normally do the chocolate chip / white chocolate macadamia cookie with vanilla ice cream.  This is what you call good times.

EDIT:  The ice cream ice cream sandwich is now $1.50.  Still worth every penny!

I immediately disregard bad reviews given to Argentinian places when the reviewer says they ordered Italian-sounding dishes. 
Argentinians do meat really well. C'mon people! Don't order anything else.

The Chimichuri had a nice garlicky kick.
The beet salad very balanced flavor.
The skirt steak amazing and veggies grilled to perfection.
The service, my favorite part of all!

Granted, we had to wait quite a while between our bread/salad & the main course, but we were there on a Thursday night and it was PACKED! Thursday is the new Saturday apparently.  People who were waiting at the bar were given complimentary flutes of champagne or some other bubbly. Our waiter was absolutely outstanding and personable. 

When you think about it, we are the only culture that seems to pride ourselves on "quick quick quick" meals and have sort of lost that whole "this is a social event, it's not just about food consumption" thing. All that to say, I forgive the wait at Malbec's. 

Go forth and be carnivorous.

First and foremost, it is *not* a hot-pot restaurant.  I tried it, looking for Chinese hot pot, but such places are quite rare.  Other than that, right on with some other reviews:  not authentic, but cheap and tasty.

Appletree is located a few doors down from the social work school at Columbia, which means that I'm a regular. However, if I didn't go to school a stone's throw away, I wouldn't come here. 

For one, it's ridiculously crowded and hard to find anything. Add in the fact that it's overpriced ($5.99 for essentially a travel-sized deodorant--I forgot to put some on in the morning, no big deal), and I'm not a fan. 

However, I must say that their salads (toss-in variety) are pretty good, if overpriced, and they have quite a selection of prepared foods for a quick meal.

well chipotle, u really did it to me this time!...
two of us got the bowls, theyre huge btw!!! they come with rice, beans, meat, salsas, cheese, sour cream and lettuce. Its basically a burrito but without the tortilla......and lets just say, Food Won. we could not finish our bowls! i wanted to but just couldnt, thell do a number on u.

Food was good, but this particular Chipotle is really tiny and hot inside! Its best to sit outside if you come to this one. Also try avoiding Lunch Hours theres a long line since its right next to usc..line moves pretty fast, depending on how the staff is doing, there was a couple people infront of us and it took a little while, there was some confusion on who was making the burritos for another costumer. idk, it was all good though, that bowl was worth it.:)

btw, the burritos are huge too!! everything is fresh tasting, nothing too greasy.
What the hell was that crap they served me?

You know it's gonna happen... You know when you walk in that there will be a wait, and you will get shamelessly shitfaced at the bar, and completely joyously debauched when they finally seat you!  The drink list is too extensive and the cocktails too tasty, the restaurant is too quirky and the waitresses' outfits are too crazy - ours had a stuffed pigeon in her hair - not to get positively giddy.  For a fru fru drink, I like the Lemon Drop, the Black Dahlia, and the Happiness Cocktail.

Once you make it to a table, and if you're lucky, it'll be the glass topped anatomically correct mermaid coffee table, you will want everything on the menu, and your eyes will be bigger than your stomach.  It's tapas, so the illusion is, you can order tons of food because the amounts will be small.  But the dishes are actually decently sized; for 2 maybe 4-5 is enough.  I recommend the Brie en Croute (oh god oh god), Indian Lamb, Cous Cous, Mexican Deep Fried Tomato - and don't forget a big dish of marinated mushrooms, the best ever.  By the end, you'll be satiated, and likely frisky.  The mermaid knows.  That's why she looks so happy. (see photo)

Check out the loo, the ladies' has the most hilarious little table on stockinged legs.

It IS expensive, not for every weekend, but so fun.

I went here for lunch with a friend today. The place is clean and cute, has quick service, and the food was hot and good. They had burgers, chicken, salmon burgers, and a veggie option. You fill out the menu card yourself to let them know what toppings you want, and hand it to the counter person. 

If I were to compare this to other places on the Ave, I guess it would get 4 stars, and the 3 star rating shouldn't be interpreted as a negative . . . It's a safe bet for lunch if you are walking around the Ave feeling like you are surrounded by less than safe bets. (you kind of are) My chicken, fries and soda came to 9.25.

Now that I'm out of school and I can read whatever the hell I want, this has become one of my favorite places in the whole world.  There's just something about how the books here are lovingly chosen and organized that makes it a great place to learn about new books you didn't know you needed.  The used book selection and the Remainders area near the staircase are always full of surprises, and there's a seat on a windowsill next to the fiction and behind a rack of postcards where I like to look through my stack of books and figure out which ones I'm going to buy.  And when those frequent buyer discounts come up, the answer is: all of them.

It is what it is...  cheap, fast, greasy.  For me, the coffee and food (egg-white omlette with mushrooms, and hash browns) were not particularly good, but were filling, fast, and only $10.  I was in and out the door in less than 30 mins.  I felt the service was quite good, this morning.

I am at a conference at Columbia, and Tom's is two blocks away.  I will probably be a 7am regular, at least for the next 3 days.

I've been going to Charley's for four years now and will probably continue to go for as long as I am in Ann Arbor. Just went there this afternoon for the happy hour, and it would appear that all of the prices just went up by about a dollar. :( Boo. They used to take a dollar off all pub menu items during happy hour, but judging from today's tab, they've stopped doing that. Too bad.

At least they put the veggie plate back on the appetizers menu. Unfortunately, the ones I got today were in baaaad shape. They were dry and looked as though they had been sitting out on the counter all day, and all of the grape tomatoes were wrinkly.

The burgers are pretty tasty and so are the nachos. The pub fries are also really good. The sloppy joe's there is tasteless/bland, but it might have been taken off the menu. Their attempt at Vietnamese "bánh mì" (which they misspell every time it appears on the menu...) is pathetic and they shouldn't have bothered--the pickled vegetables they use range from either too salty to eat or too sweet.

If you plan on getting dessert, ask your server at the beginning of the meal if any are even available. It took me 3.5 years before I successfully ordered a milkshake because they never had ice cream on hand. A few visits ago, none of the desserts was available except for milkshakes.

3 stars because the waitstaff is friendly.

I might be shot walking on Spring Street by some Stan of this place, but...I don't see the big deal with The Varsity.  I understand the history and that's great.  Really it is.  I go there just for that.  But, the food?  Meh on a good day.  The chili is gross and dry to me.  The flat burgers are tasteless.  The frosted orange made me angry the first and last time I ordered it.  But, that's my fault.  I thought it was going to taste like something else and when it didn't, I was mad that I just didn't get an orange soda.

I have my own memories now: my stepdad picking me up late for work because he HAD to stop at "Tha Varsitys", stretching out my first meeting with my current beau over shared onion rings, and feeling like I'm back in DC with the swarms of tourists screaming "What'll ya have?" like the people across the counter.  But, do I ever have a craving for what they serve?  I don't think that will ever happen.

Hayes Gladstone is a liar and a crook.  He will make you come back for multiple visits while you see NO results.   Then you get  a huge bill in the mail.  When I disputed it he lied and made up these accusations against me, saying he only did what I asked him to, as if I'm an expert.

Plus, when you think you are seeing him, you are really seeing a Stanford student or intern for a majority of the visit.  He comes in for the final few minutes of your visit then charges you a ridiculous amount of money.

He is only out for your money!!! STAY AWAY!!!  There are much much better dermatologists in the area.

its always a clean and friendly environment. a worker was cleaning the glass door when I showed up and later she was using a tiny handheld mini vac to clean the crumbs and toppings from the counter. their green tea yogurt is pretty good but they don't have it often. service was moving pretty fast which was nice. this is one of my favorite froyo places because it's self serve :) if you go enough, you might even find a picture of yourself mounted on one of the many picture boards. there are artworks mounted throughout the place that are for sale.
HUGE selection.  Fun atmosphere.

Tommy D's in Kendall has a great outdoor patio and is an ideal spot for catching some rays and a buzz, good people watching here too. The bar also has good food and the bartenders are always friendly. The only thing I don't like is when it happens to be Kereoke night. Always too loud and never good singers.

I used to drive to Glendale and deal with the parking lot from hell for my Zankou fix until I found this location.  

I want to bathe in the garlic sauce.  Everything else is secondary.  Delicious but secondary.

You know you're a Columbia student when you can navigate the morning chaos in HamDel with ease. 

HamDel is there for you when you need it. With a coffee, a sandwich, a soda -- HamDel will get you through that afternoon lull when you're sitting in tax law seriously questioning your life decisions. The service is quick, efficient, and you get what you ask for. 

Personally, I find HamDel a little unnecessarily pricey. I can get the same turkey sandwich down the street a ways at Columbia Deli for about $2 less. But HamDel wins in proximity-to-school every time. AND they stayed open 24 hours during exams. Much respect.

I like Luna Red for the ambiance, great date setting... the cheese plates are AMAZING! Nice wine list. The only downfall is that every time we go there we have 2 dishes that are amazing and without fail one is just blah! I know they reconfigured their marketing plan and food style, hopefully over time they'll iron out all the kinks

Picnic is the perfect place to have lunch!  They have delicious homemade bread, which I like to pick up at least once every week and have around the house.  They have an amazing lunch special where you get a sandwich, cookie, chips, and a fruit salad all for $8.50!  I don't know any place in town where you can get that good of a deal.  The food is fresh and they have a cool atmosphere.  Also, their other restaurant Raven Grill is amazing as well...nice place to have a relaxing dinner!  Only downside is the parking.

I know I'm not the target demographic for Wet Seal. Fuck it, I'm writing the review anyway.

I judge women's clothing stores on three things: seating, music and whether or not I have to discourage my girlfriend from buying anything in there.

Seating: One cushioned bench near the dressing rooms. That's just not enough. And I hate sitting near the dressing rooms when my girl isn't trying anything on - I'm sure the girls who are trying something on think I'm creepy.

Music: Oh so very bad. Trite girl power songs for soccer moms, like that song "I'm a Bitch" and the one about feeling the rain on your skin. Female customers should feel insulted.

Clothes: Mostly pretty bad. A lot of shiny club clothes. But there were a few purchases that I approved of, plus a shirt that reads "SHAWTY WANNA THUG."  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/S_4KYDQj0IO6nx1IDxeUng?select=k4BEov4O7Ja6ZhFsA_5KwQ

I live in Cambridgeport and I order out a lot. For years I've had to withstand Pu Pu Hot Pot's randomly-quality-controlled food, but I've reluctantly stuck with them because they're the cheapest and fastest.

Needless to say, I was quite eager to try out Beijing Tokyo and see if I can break my Pu Pu Hot Pot habit. I had my doubts though because I always feel suspicious about "Chinese-imitating-Japanese" eating joints.  

I ordered some maki from the Chef's Special list, and just to be safe I also ordered salt-peppered pork chop. I also asked for hot sauce to go with the pork chop. To my pleasant surprise, the maki was quite fantastic! Well, not Oiishi quality or anything, but they're just tasty! I was impressed with the creativity displayed in composing the sushi menu. They seem to like using mango a lot. And the pork chop was good too! A bit bony, but tasty. Only Kantin's (at Super 88 Food Connection) and Chinatown's Hong Kong Eatery serve better pork chop. And being Indonesian, I was especially impressed with their chili sauce. It tasted home made, not one of those generic chili-cooked-in-oil sauce, and I thought I could even sniff a hint of mango in there too.

Bye bye Pu Pu Hot Pot!

I recommend Lafayette PC because the rates are reasonable, and I can trust Jason Rubsam and his team to do the job right.

Jason cleaned up my laptop after it picked up a virus, and he recovered data from a desktop computer that was hit by lightning. 

This is most important: I was using a MyBook device to back up my computer files. Then suddenly, the device stopped working. Jason signed me up for an online back up service. It's more reliable and safer than the DIY method I was using. I strongly recommend that you call Jason now to ask about back up options. Do it before the next tornado hits!

Call Lafayette PC for help with your computers. (800) 371-1781.

The health center itself is fine...I've had some obnoxious experiences there with one doctor in particular (read: worst bedside manner EVER), but for the most part things have been adequate.  

I write today about the pharmacy.  Because it was convenient, I went to them for four years (I'm a Ph.D. student, and thus stuck at school for 6-7).  After putting up with the lines, the fact that the pharmacy is closed all weekend, and the less than prompt refills, I got truly fed up from two incidents.  The first involved my request for summer meds.  Knowing that this can take awhile, I called in my prescription request 8 DAYS before I actually needed it.  I couldn't pick it up until the day before I went out of town, and I wasn't taking any chances.  I figured that they'd call me if there was a problem, right?  Nope.  I get there and they irritably tell me that one of the prescriptions doesn't exist, so they didn't fill it.  I told them that I knew it existed because the doctor had given it to them the day I called in the prescription.  Sure enough, when they thought to look in the "new prescriptions" file, it was there.  They then informed me that it would take two days.  I informed them that this was their fault (again, not so much as a call when they couldn't find one of the prescriptions on record...and they had more than a week to make it) and that I needed it that day.  Thankfully realizing this was their fault, they agreed to call me as soon as it was available.  They didn't call me, and I waited around on campus all day before finally going to the pharmacy right before it closed.  Yep, the meds had been ready for hours, but apparently the employees at the Ashe Center can't use a phone.

I won't describe the second incident in detail (since it would make for a long review), but it involved me trying to transfer a prescription to a pharmacy closer to where I lived.  It was only after I did so that the people at the Ashe Center mistakenly told me that the GSHIP insurance wouldn't transfer...because they couldn't look it up on the computer (they acted like this was my fault, which it wasn't, as I found out later).  It took me hours of arguing with people at the Ashe Center and CVS to discover that, yes!  GSHIP does cover prescriptions not filled at the Ashe Center!  The employee at the Ashe Center pharmacy was just too rude, vague, and uninformed to tell me that.   

So, the moral of this story is: have your prescriptions transferred to somewhere other than the Ashe Center pharmacy.  It costs the same.  The charges won't show up months later on your BAR account.  And, best of all, you won't have to deal with the lines, the lame hours, and the horrible customer service.

No more lunch specials, but a BRAND NEW lunch menu. Everything is still under $10 (and bowls of udon now come with 8 pcs of sushi--your choice: salmon, tuna or california roll).

The tempura udon now only comes with one piece of (still delectable) shrimp tempura. :(

Also: the wait staff were great, but there seems to be a high turnover because I have a new waitress every time I stop in.

I'm using my boyfriends account because I don't think it's worth it to create a new one just to leave this review but i feel like i MUST, especially after reading the last review before mine.

I went to Integrity with HIGH expectations.  I had an appointment scheduled with Tasha and even though I was a few minutes late she was still very welcoming and understanding.  She offered me a beverage or snack while I filled out the new client form, and I greatly accepted.  After I filled out the form, i thought we would head straight back to the room but instead Tasha sat down with me to go over everything and make sure she had a thorough understanding of what look I was going for.  She explained how to care for the lashes, asked about my past experience with having extensions and even went over a possibility of an allergic reaction; I mean, this girl was thorough and not only that she was cracking jokes and had such an amazing personality.

She took me back to her room and went through the whole set up, explaining everything she was doing from taping my lower lashes down so they wouldn't interfere with the top ones, to how she separates a single lash from all the rest to make sure my own natural lashes wouldn't be pulled out.  The entire procedure was so relaxing I fell asleep!  I woke up when I felt her removing the tape, and she told me to keep my eyes closed, then she would rinse my eyes.  I was a little nervous to see the final product because I was EXTREMELY specific about what I wanted.  Full and long but not unnatural looking and a teeny bit longer on the outside corner of my eyes.  After she rinsed my eyes she gave me a tissue, (she said the glue can be a little stingy at first), and i opened my eyes.  Dun DUN DUUUNNNNN!  I was AMAZED!!  My eyes have never looked more beautiful and it was the EXACT look I wanted.  That girl is super talented and she made sure I was happy with the results saying she had time to fix anything that I may not like, but that was not necessary.  She gave me a mascara brush to use to comb thru them and walked me out. 

I'm a bit perplexed as to how someone could have such a different experience with Tasha because she was so genuine with me, but I don't know the other situation I just wanted to share mine.  I made my next appointment, with Tasha of course, and I already know I'm addicted.  I've never gotten SO many compliments on my lashes before and people are shocked when I tell them that they are extensions!!!

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND Tasha.  She was so sweet, even with me being close to a half hour late, and not to mention she is stunning!  I don't think she was wearing a stitch of makeup and she looked like an exotic model.... no exageration.  

The place itself is so cute and pretty and the rest of the staff seemed pleasant.  I am officially a lash addict!!!

It's a bit expensive but soooo worth it!

Heart-attack Hoagies, at least that's what we call it. I don't think there's anything remotely healthy on this menu?? Nevertheless, when you have a craving, you have a craving, right?

Grilled, hot food toppings for a Hoagie served immediately is delicious. The sourdough rolls they use for their sandwiches/hoagies suck. They either put it in the oven for too long or they're using stale bread. Unfortunately, this has been a consistent deficiency for the items I've ordered here.

Curly fries and cheesy fries are soooo good though. You can taste the grease from the frier, that's how fast it's being brought out. 

Final Call:
For me, there are better alternatives for fried, greasy food elsewhere.

This has to be the best place in Cambridge/Boston to see live music. The sound quality has gotten much better lately, and the bar has the perfect rock club atmosphere.

This is the club that gets all the great bands before they become huge, and you generally can not go wrong going here on a thursday, friday or saturday night. The booking agent knows how to do her job, and she does it very well. 

The staff here are another reason to stop by, they are always talkative and friendly, even when it's a sold out show.

All in all, i love this place, and you will too.

Went here for lunch today. I ordered a tuna sandwich and fries. The sandwich was runny, way too much mayo and the tuna probably wasn't drained thoroughly.  The bread however, was delicious, thick and flavorful. 

The fries were decent. I wouldn't brag about them nor would I dis them. They were too salty, but its good to know that they aren't fried in oil. 

The whole meal was ready in like five minutes and the woman who took my order was pleasant. Definitly a step above fast food quality but still ready quick and very inexpensive.

Nice beer selection. Loud and collegiate. Decent for watching the game.

Wings were dry and terrible, even though their menu seems to suggest it as their specialty.

I'm not a vegetarian or vegan, so when this place was recommended to me, I was skeptical. I decided to try it, though, and it is so delicious! I have been here a bunch recently and I haven't had a bad dish.

To order here, you choose one of three: pizza dough, brown rice, or coconut rice and an entree to go on top. They have daily specials which are delicious and soups of the week. I just recently had tomato and lentil soup which was delicious.

Also, it is a small space and is part of a music club, Club Passim. You will be asked upon entering if you're there for the show or for dinner. You may have to wait for a table, especially if you have 4+ people, and take-out is always a fast, delicious option. Also, before 4 or 5PM, there are no waiters, so you just place your order through a window to the cook.

It is a little hard to find, take a look at the pictures on Yelp. It's a basement and connected to Club Passim, so if you're going here at night, you may hear music from the club. Just follow that and you'll figure it out.

They also have 2 beers on tap and desserts.
Food is marginal at best. But it is the staff that really earns the single star. You would think a pizza place on a college campus would be packed but it isn't.

Pinch me. A great swing venue 5 blocks from my apartment???? Surely I must be dreaming!!

I love everything about Dancer's Den! Lots of great dancers, great DJs, and I only pay $6 because I'm a student! 

But when I do pay the full $12 for the lesson Jean and Bromley make it well worth it! I like how they break up the lesson into intermediate and beginner so nobody gets lost or - on the flipside - bored. They teach at a great pace and have both a professional and encouraging demeanor when conducting lessons. 

Congrats to all the people who put in the hard work to make this venue a success! It was great to see tons of happy people swinging out on the dance floor tonight! I'll be back every Wednesday that I'm in Berkeley while my legs are functional!

This joint has been keeping me in frames for a few years now.  Being bespectacled is my calling card, so you know I've got to keep it tight in the glasses department.  This store has the best selection in town of the funky and fashionable in eyewear.  They let you browse for-everrrr with no presh.  Believe me, I tend to take about two hours to pick out a pair, bless their hearts!, and their salespeople are tactfully (if brutally) honest with you.  Both eye docs located there are highly affable, even to a neurotic such as myself who likes to know they've scored a 100% on the exam (A+ is  my middle name, no matter what the exam, dammit!).  Best of all?  They accept UT insurance (among other kinds), so I can get the height of specs fashion without having to drop a dime of my own money.

I've used this laundromat a few times, and while it gets the job done, it is nothing spectacular. The hours are decent, staying open until 10 PM every night, but it can get very crowded and sometimes a little messy. It's $2.50 per load to wash and $.25 per 15 minutes on the dryers, which is about average for the area. Other than that, it's a typical laundromat.

Okay, I know you are Wawa and you have a very limited selection of foods but I'd like to thank you for always being there for me. Even if we get hit by snow twice a week accumulating 65"+ of snow. Everything is shut down but you are still open!!

And have Wawa hoagies not been the best thing ever for like the past 10 years now? (Italian hoagie w/ lettuce, tomatoes, provolone, oregano, and a little bit of oil...with a pickle on the side!) 

Andddd...they stock Combos cheddar crackers (THE BEST!) and quite a selection of Ben & Jerry's ice cream! Wawa you are clearly a winner!
Great fresh aldente pasta, cooked to perfection.

This place is so cool. You can just imagine people seeing shows there back in the 30's. Kristin B. is right, the secret bathroom is a great hint. Although, the bathrooms in the basement of the Theater are so cool with their Ladie's Sitting Areas and what not. There is just so much to look at during intermission. The place is just impressive.

The mojitos were minty and sweet. Good burgers and skewers.
We went early while the sun was still out so it wasn't too busy. 
The second time around, the bar had a too-serious-for-Halloween sort of crowd. 
Walking in dressed as the Golden Girls was probably not a good idea.

Fabulous! If See served cocktails and finger foods, I'd never leave.

Katie seems to know everyone that comes in or walks by the shop, she was super friendly and just plain AWESOME!

I don't think I've ever been so happy to part with $800 in an afternoon (well, have Andy part with $800). Mind you, this $800 covered 2 eye exams, a contact exam, 2 pairs of glasses, a pair of prescription sunglasses, and a year's supply of contacts.

The optometrist had the best chairside manner of any optometrist I've ever had, he was so nice and congenial and actually interesting.

I think my new glasses are classy and nice and the frames were only $160 (before 20% discount).

I'm so happy I get to go back and pick them up (with dog in tow).

LOVE LOVE LOVE.

My office is a short walk to the Glass House, so I've been here about a half-dozen times (take out and sit down).   The last two times I went was because a coworker was buying, and because I got a $10 gift certificate from the boss.

The food is good, but the problem is there are a dozen other places within the same walking distance that are much better, and a better value.  Do I pay $6 for an awesome Griffin from Beanster's across the street, or $6+ for an awkward-tasting Turkey wrap?

I ordered the burger to-go one day; it took me five minutes to get back to my desk, and three seconds to realize my horrible mistake. The preparation was....not their strong suit.  The container was airy, so the burger was dry and cold.  Stingy on the condiments, and the fries were worse.

The interior is pleasant, there's a great view from most seats.  The staff is very nice, very friendly.  But I found that their kitchen closes at 2:00pm; I don't know if that's a regular occurrence or just something that's specific to the take out counter.

Overall, I won't be back, there's just too many choices on Central Campus that cost less or have better food.

I lived here a few months after the community was built and I had a great apartment on the top floor facing Midtown.  Once you got upstairs, it was great - it was a very large one bedroom and it didn't have any interior doors (except for the bathroom), which gave it an open feel that I haven't seen anywhere else.  I say "once you got upstairs" because the buildings are 3 and 4 stories and none of them have elevators.  That started to suck about 10 minutes after I started moving in.

The community is on Marietta Street at Northside Drive near GA Tech.  The neighborhood was in its early transition when I lived there, but lots of stuff has been built and it's now become known as "Midtown West".  From what I can tell it's a neat place.  There are several onsite businesses including a dry cleaners and a coffee shop.
