My only real complaints were the lack of elevators, crowded parking, and noise inside the apartments.  Between the train tracks and Marietta Street, you get noise on both sides.  Honestly, I could deal with the train, but you'd be surprised at how loud constant vehicles (including dump trucks and buses) can actually be...

The first movie I ever watched there was 'Requiem For A Dream' with my roommate back when we were in graduate school. I still remember like it was yesterday trying to find cinema for the very first time. We came via the T and for some strange reason had a lot of trouble finding it.... Oh well. In any event, I have no problems finding it now. Great place to watch Independent films!

delicious, and super affordable.
i know this place is known for their chicken...but the falafal are insane. crunchy on the outside, creamy and moist on the inside.

If you're into organic or mediterranean food, then this is a great place to go. However, besides that, there's not much else in terms of "food genre" to offer here. The calzone I had was OK; certainly different from others I've had, but it wasn't outstanding. It's a little expensive though.

It's good, but nothing I go out of my way for.  If I am in the area and need to kill time or am lacking in the caffeine department, then I stop in and grab an "amigo".  The white coffee is the only thing that really makes this place special (besides, arguably, the tabletop games like pacman and others I can't remember).  It is a milder taste, but I didn't notice a huge difference in all the things it claimed to be different in.  Worth a try though if you have never experienced it.  I still say El Diablo is better, but maybe that is because of my proximity to it.

4.5 stars if I could. I really enjoy this place. The employees are incredibly nice, coffee is great, and it's not a bad way to kill an afternoon with friends. I have lately found myself studying here too. They have free WIFI and plenty of seating. Uptown Espresso is a great way to start a day, and my favorite cafe in SLO.

I've been to this Ralphs almost every hour of the night, but daytime.. not really. lol. The beauty of a 24hr grocery store in a college town. It's really kind of fun to navigate the store while it's being restocked. And you'll always run into someone you know, except they're in their PJs! And so are you! 

At night there's less people working so you won't have access to the butcher or the folks working seafood, but everything else is up for grabs. I can't explain it, but there's a certain majesty in floating around the store after hunger strikes at 2am and you realize you have no ice cream in your fridge. 

Its gotten a lot more affordable in the last year, but my heart will forever be with my local Mexican markets and 99 Ranches.

i went here back in the year 2000 for two treatments of laser hair removal on my arms. the first time i went in i had consultation and the nurse or tech tested my arm a bit and i thought okay fine no big deal. she told me to buy some of the numbing cream for when i came  back in for the actual treatment, to put it on the area on hour before or whatever time she said, this was 9 years ago now. anyway, somehow i remember going back and getting a laser treatment without numbing cream! somewehre along the way the tech recommended or asked me if i wanted to try it without the cream and i said yes. i think that was my first treatment, yes. it was in the morning at 8am or the earliest appointment. i started getting sick to my stomach without any numbing cream, yes it hurt. she told me to lie down/back. i was sick i felt as though i could pass out. i told her i had to go to the bathroom and yes everything went through me, i was sick/in pain. i went back into the room and she gave me a funny look and said are you okay, i said yes....we rescheduled and i bought the cream to numb it....i remember her well because she made me feel bad, i was what 22 years old at the time and worked swing shift in high tech and studied fulltime in the morning and she told me "oh you have a hard life" i felt like shit..i guess she was used to rich people.

yeah i went back and had one treatment at least on my arms. god knows why my arms were fine just some brown hair, not thick at all.

on another visit i went to the actual doctor and he had me all ready in a room to biopsy my neck, a mole or something was on it and he was even ruder!! i walked toward the bathroom as he was coming in the room to do the surgery and he threw up his arms, like "wtf?" very rude....
he did the biopsy but a shaved one, he should have gotten at at root for the money my insurance paid him...

Went to Bluefin Bistro for lunch today and had three sushi rolls and miso soup.  The miso soup was unusual -- it seemed pre-made.  The miso didn't settle in the clear broth as it usually does.  It just kind of stayed muddy looking.  This was a disappointing beginning considering miso soup is about the easiest thing on Earth to make.

The rolls were on the small side with a high rice to filling ratio.  Pretty unremarkable.  They were also heavy on the spicy sauce and crunchy topping.  To me this signals a restaurant trying to mask the taste of less-than-stellar quality fish.  

The interior is kind of nice and the outside area has a good "loungey" feel to it.  So maybe this would be a good spot to have a few cocktails at night and hang out, but the sushi gets two stars.

We took our new hires out to dinner here as a "get to know each other" sort of event. Be careful with the wait though: we had a 20 minute wait and decided to go to the bar down the street and just get called when our table was ready, and it turns out we didn't have cell coverage! When we got back, they were able to put us in the conference room upstairs (which worked out great) but it's something to keep in mind.

Sangria margarita = win all over the place. The food was pretty good too. Since we had a private room, we were able to hook an iPod up to the docking station and rock out to some Lady Gaga. Well, some of us rocked out to her.

Since I was required to have jaw surgery, my orthodontist referred me to Dr. Taylor as my designated surgeon. According to my orthodontist, he had known Dr. Taylor for over 20 years or so. Dr. Taylor is one of the doctors that I love and trust. He is very funny, competent, sharp, honest, passionate and enthusiastic with his practice, etc. At the very beginning of our meeting, he made it very clear to me that both of my jaws would need surgery in order to correct my overbite issues. His daughter, Patti, is the one of the nurses also did an excellent job on explaining the procedures in details. Although my surgery was a very big deal and sounded scary and complicated, he had done a total outstanding and  amazing job with it (I came out of the surgery room safe and sound). The recovery time was much shorter than I expected. He definitely had made very sure that I was fine before releasing me from the hospital. For those know will go to him for jaw surgery, just keep in mind that you are in good hand. As long as you follow his words, you will do just fine without hassle and worries. FYI, I had my jaw surgery back in the middle of December 2008. Right now, I look much better, eat better, and feel better with the correct bite. My grinding habit is totally gone with Dr. Taylor's help. :)

This place is Exhibit A of "Why my parents only go out to eat either Chinese food or really good International Cuisine". Went with a good friend of mine for a late-night dinner. I ordered a BLT with chicken which ran at $11-$13. For a burger / sandwich? C'mon. Nothing more could inspire me to make my own burger. Rather dry / rubbery chicken, minimal lettuce. Perhaps I'm railing against bar food, perhaps I had just got of a plane from California, agricultural capital of the world, but I felt like a greaseball after the meal. Perhaps the highlight of the establishment was the bar / booze / loud music / waiters dancing to early Brit-pop. But bar food is bar food, and you'll definitely get that.

One more thing; if you want to have a quiet conversation, you won't be able to compete with the New Order in the background.

I came to woodstocks today and my friend got salad and a slice and it was mushroomy and delicious and the crust was bomby.
My other friend got a personal mediterranean pizza and it took them so long to get it to her we thought it got lost in the oven..just lost in the corner just burning to a crisp....in pizza hell. Jeez.

But its pretty good pizza, really
Cool atmosphere, cool room, cool service.

I just can't say enough good things about this truck!  It's about time a truck came to campus that wasn't all clapped up and diseased looking.  And to top it all off - they serve some awesome sandwiches!  If you haven't had a panini at Mojo - you just don't know what you're missing.  I highly recommend the Mojo Cuban or the Cajun.  They also offer vegetarian options like the Portabello - soooo good and they use a very yummy pesto sauce on some of their sandwiches.

I don't know why anyone would go anywhere else - Mojo has it all!  I tried their breakfast sandwiches too - you can now get a REAL sirloin steak & egg sandwich - not that minute steak junk everyone else serves.  The owner told me he buys a big piece of top sirloin and slices it himself!

Of course, this IS a coffee truck and if you actually care about what you're drinking, Mojo's coffee is top of the line - way better than Starfu*&'s or Wahwah's

A beautiful and romantic restaurant.  It's great for taking a date.

The restaurant is like a little maze.  Dinning areas in four or five different rooms, each with a different decor.

It's a bit pricey, but the quality is generally good.  Service is also good.  There's also a cute small wine bar on the other side of the building.

The Rodin scuplture garden is one of my absolute favorite places on Earth.  Love to go there at night and see sculpture come to life.  Love that you can touch it, feel every groove made by the artist's hand.  For a bonus, go to the Stanford courtyard and see the Burghers of Calais.  I can honestly say that I would not be the artist I am without the access to touch and experience these works by Rodin.  Thank you Stanford.

Food: pretty good. Service: awful. 

Took us about 15 minutes to get a table and sit -- for a popular brunch place (at brunch time) it's hard to complain.

But 40 minutes to get our food? 40 minutes? Nawwwwww. Not a word from our server or mgmt about why our stuff was taking so long. And indeed, it wasn't just us. Everyone had to wait.

Maybe if the service moved quicker there wouldn't be such a backlog. But maybe the wait makes for the intrigue. The food's good, but it's no better than Ball Sq. or Soundbites. And there, they race you through to get everyone in line fed. Not coming back to Kendall for Friendly Toast

Definitely overrated, but definitely fun and a great place to start a day walking around Princeton. If you show up at a busy time (breakfast before 9:30 or dinner time) you will wait. You will wait a long time. It's in a convenient location and the atmosphere is fun with the skribbled on tables. 

I would not recommend anything besides the pancakes.

I have so many fond memories of this place;

taking the mic and yelling stuff at the whole restaurant

going there multiple times in one night

the time there was an armed robbery in progress and we couldn't go in

ordering ridiculous quantities of tacos

when my friend twisted her ankle stepping down onto the sidewalk

unfortunately the food's not that great when you're sober

The look of this place just screams NY pizzeria, right down to the wood paneling and red-orange booths. Good pizza and I love their cheesesteak hoagies!

I really think that if this place was closer to the university on Franklin it would be unquestionably the most popular pizzeria in Chapel Hill.

The East Lansing location is a bit cozier, but the Ann Arbor Bubble Island will always have a special place in my heart. I LOVE the light turtle tea with honeydew and/or almond flavor and black bubbles. If you become a regular like me, definitely pick up a punch card and you can receive a free medium-sized drink for every 10 you purchase.
Simply Best burger in town.. and you gotta try the blue berry pie as well. They do have the zaggat award for something!!

One word: adorable. I love their sandwiches and the tea selection is incredible. I would highly recommend it for anyone who wants to catch up with old friends or if relatives are in town, and you actually like them. 

No matter what kind of tea you get, it's legit... I have a friend who works in a tea store, and she assured me that it's good to go.
RIP last arcade in like a 20 minute drive. :(

This place rules. We spend the entire day there. There's always cool new exhibits, for a small fee my kids can rock climb, ride the high wire bikes or we can check out the IMAX movie. It's busy-but doesn't seem too super crowded.
Best burgers ever, large size portions,excellent friendly staff, and again the best burgers ever! Mmm, now I'll need to go walk these extra calories off.

I love the Carolina Inn. This is my second time staying there in 2 years. Both times, I have received excellent service from everyone. 

When we checked in, they read my comments from my online hotel reservation and gave me some extra cookies. When I asked to move from a single bed room to a double bed room, they didn't bat an eye and kept the rate the same. My breakfast at Caroline Inn was delicious (try the grits) and the kids with our friends ate from the buffet for free.

The single bed rooms/bathrooms are on the smaller side, but it's worth it to stay in such a historic place. It's also an easy walk to campus/Franklin street.

If you sign up for their emails, you can get really good rates on the rooms.

When one of my guy friend's picked me up to go to "Blake's", I thought we were going to a house party. When we ended up at a bar, I was confused, but that's really not unusual for me.

I know they play live music downstairs, I know there is a bar upstairs, I know that their drinks are strong & I've never had to pay for them.

I also know that when a friend gets a slice of pizza while stumbling back to the car & they offer it to me & then change their mind & want it back, they end up shoved in a prickle bush.

Wow, this place just served me up one of the best meals I have ever eaten. I got the tampopo ramen with gyoza. It was a match made in lunch time heaven. The Pepsi also complimented the flavor. The pork is so soft, the flavored egg such a treat. Even the white and pink fish cakes are softer and juicer than any other place I have been to. I love this place!
Even though the service usually sucks, and the employees have kind of a bitchy, why do I have to work I have a trust fund attitude. It does not change the fact, that this place kicks my tongues ass!! My new weekly lunch spot.

excuse the language, but this place is a run-down, empty, worthless shit hole.

the last time i went here (to see a movie in the odd, but surprisingly good theater), almost all of the stores were closed for good, ostensibly due to not paying rent.

it's a shame someone hasn't torn this place down, or used it to open decent stores that don't just sell textbooks or random crap.

i think the positive reviews here are for the theater, which has a good selection of movies...
but the mall?

worthless.

I was recommended here by the dealership I bought my Chevy truck at after I got in a front and rear end collision. I figured that if the dealership recommended the place, it has to be good otherwise if it wasn't, the dealer would get a bad rap for recommending it as much as the collision center. I can say that Alpine has done an excellent job.

Brought my truck in here for some front and rear end damage, including the rear parking electronics and the tailgate. They coordinate with Enterprise (who is just down the street) for rentals and Enterprise will pick you up at Alpine to work out rentals with you. The Alpine office is clean and sharp, as well as the body shop itself.

The staff at Alpine are friendly and professional. They called several times to update me about my truck's status during the week that it was being repaired. At the end of the repair, they gave a copy of an itemized list of parts and labor with costs and did a walkthrough with me over my truck. They even thoroughly washed the truck with detailing both inside and out.

I haven't had any issues with my truck since and I'm completely satisfied with the work they've done.

I really hate writing a bad review about a local business, but after leaving in tears this afternoon I feel it is important.

About 11:00 AM, I spoke to a man at Jenn's over the phone and was quoted a price for copying and binding a report.  I emailed the document and was told it would be ready by 1:00.  When I arrived about 1:20, the employees (not the employee on the phone earlier) did not have the order ready or in process, though they did find my email.  As they started the order, I asked about the pricing because I was already concerned about the order not even being in queue.  I was told the total would be a price about 50% higher than what was quoted on the phone. 

At this point, I objected, stating exactly what I was quoted on the phone earlier.  Things turned way south.  I was rudely told they did not offer services at that price, that I had NOT been quoted the service at that price and I would not be receiving 'a discount'. It was in no uncertain terms implied that I was lying and trying to cheat the employees out of their services.  As I was in a serious hurry to get my reports turned in and had been expecting a finished product when I walked in the door, I paid (again, almost 50% more than quoted).  The reports were bound correctly and quickly, and I wish the customer service would match the quality of product they produced.

La Baguette reminded me of my trip to Paris a few years ago, they have the Baguette sandwiches ready to go just like the baguette stands in Paris. 

It was a rainy Sunday and I was in the mood for a vanilla latte and a croissant... I love croissants I just don't eat them in an effort to try and keep some pounds off, but come on lets face it... there is nothing better than pizza, a croissant and a latte on a rainy day =) 

La Baguette has plenty of deserts and breads. The croissant was good, soft and good. I have to admit a slice of cake cought my eye.  The latte actually was one of the best I have had in a long time. Now the cake.... I could not wait to try the cake! We went home and had dinner and then the cake. OMG lets talk about a good cake! This cake was just perfect not too sweet not too plain. Next time I go back I down to try another cake =) I think I have just found a place for my breads and deserts. Yes, it is a bit more than your regular Safeway and Albertson prices but the quality is better!

This isn't a bad stadium, people can get in and out easily enough and restroom lines aren't bad.

Oh, and as it's now BEAR TERRITORY is gets a full five stars!

The place is small and not much to look at, but if you're looking for good, affordable mediterranean food on the go, you can't beat here.  The meat is well marinated, juicy, and served hot.  Falafels are cooked in front of you.  Condiments are in the right proportions.  A great deal all around.

The salads here are huge and come with giant pieces of yummy focaccia bread that just couldn't be good for you.  The tomato soup felt more like minestrone but wasn't bad.  The place is full of students but there are plenty of tables.

This yogurt is bar-none the best in Austin.  It does NOT have the consistency of ice cream, which I find many of the "yogurt" shops have, which I don't like.  It isn't overly sweet and it has a hint of a tang to it which is addictive!  The toppings bar is always clean and stocked, you can have free samples of the flavors before you buy and they have a punch card for frequent customers.  The ONLY downsides to this place is that there is only one Austin location and it has a  shiesty parking situation....but it is worth it!

GRILLED CHEESE AND BEER TASTING REVIEW:

Great event!  5 courses w/ beer pairings for $35 (inclusive of tax & gratuity).  I felt satiated but not obese, drank some beers but not buzz worthy.  The sandwiches were creative and were more than just cheese (i.e. Brie with Duck Confit, Orange Spice Tea Gastrique).  Some were open faced, others were just 1/2 of a large sandwich. Beers were about a 6oz pour.  

An acoustic musician played on stage which was nice.  Twice during the evening, one of the WCL hosts spoke to the crowd about the details and attention that went into planning the menu which I thought was helpful.

The event was very well organized!  However, I think they should keep it within a 2 hour window (it ran about 2.5 hrs.).

I love this place! A bit pricey but worth it because everything is so fresh and definitely high quality! Try the lemon almond cookies ($1.60 ea).  A delicious butter cookie that is tangy and sweet with pieces of almond and white chocolate, topped with a lemon icing, oh god it is delicious.  Also a great place to grab breakfast and coffee after a trip to the farmer's market! $5 min for credit card purchases.

If you shop at Whole Foods, you might want to read some of the exchanges between WF CEO John Mackey and Berkeley writer Michael Pollan; I found http://michaelpollan.com/articles-archive/my-second-letter-to-whole-foods/ quite quickly.  It's striking to realize that this exchange is now 5 years old.  Possibly as a result of their correspondence, WF now touts its local sources.  Many of the items that I saw in the prepared food section trumpeted their locally sourced ingredients.

I came to buy the prepared food because I'm spending a few days at a local residence.  I really had my reservations, but their salads and rotisserie chicken are kind of on the excellent side.  I wouldn't hesitate to come back!

The personnel are very friendly (almost at Trader Joe's level) and the checkout lines that I saw were short or empty.  This is a good place!!

Parking: I walked, but I can see what the other yelpers were complaining about.  Come on foot or on bicycle if you can.

Ok, if you like old vinyl  the record exchange is a great resource for a vast variety of artists and genres. And they are an institution, so I can't give them less than three stars. But (begin the "kids these days" rants),  but the stacks are a total wreck.

When I was frequenting the Exchange, the stacks were orderly and tidy. The music was treated with reverence and respect. Yesterday, I was shocked at the state of the store. The stacks were completely neglected and were a total mess. I felt like I went to visit my old neighborhood and found it full of boarded up windows and crack dens.

In my memory the Exchange was like Championship Vinyl incarnate; it was a scared space, staffed by the high priests of music.  Seeing its current condition made me mad and sad and not likely to return.

I guess the times they are a changin'...

When I walked in, three employees were talking/laughing behind the counter, and that's fine. But then I waited in line for 8 minutes while they continued and no one came to help me. And when someone finally came, he was extremely rude.

Never going back there; I can't stand customer service like that.

Glamour nails does a good job with eyebrows.   As far as nails are concerned, I wouldn't know because every single time I've come to get my nails done, I had to wait indefinitely ("Yea, you next, you next!") and have always walked out without being served.  I stopped coming here because I got sick of the wait and because Technicolor Nails does a fine job and they're not too far down the mall.

This wine shop is so friendly. Me and my friend came here for a couple of bottles to enjoy Providence's BYOB experience. Two excellent reds were recommended to us by the staff. We intended to enjoy them at Guidos however they were closed on July 3rd so we went to Sawadee INSTEAD. Regardless they were still excellent and by one get one half off! Holla!

All I have to say is egg breakfast sandwich. They're amazing, good for me, and cheap. It's amazing what you can get when you combine real ingredients: a soft-boiled egg, cheese, tomato and a pita. The staff is always super friendly as well.

-1 for disorganization and slowness: despite the high-tech gadgets there's little communication between the people that work there, so sometimes orders get forgotten and order assembly isn't coordinated

Had dinner & drinks at Tory Row recently. The beer selection is great, and they seem to have a plentiful wine selection, although no hard liquor. The flatbread pizzas are fantastic, the chopped salad was adequate. The food was delivered very quickly after being ordered, despite it being a busy Saturday night. In fact, the waitstaff service in general was very speedy and attentive. The place was a bit drafty, though, which was noticeable form across the room on a cold winter night. Don't ditch your coat when you sit!

A great museum near downtown Los Angeles.  Lots of displays that explain what you're looking at. A large gem exhibit is on display. They don't have as many dinosaur bones as I remembered in my youth...perhaps I was thinking of the La Brea Tar Pits instead.  Great people watching at the Natural History Museum, as it is near USC's main campus.  Expect to pay $10 or so to park.  Have fun!

Aladdin has become my staple place when I try to get my friends with the most zenophobic eating habits to change their ways and embrace foods from beyond Jack in the Box and Red Robin.  And Aladdin has never failed.  Great food for good prices and very friendly staff.  Be prepared for having to take your food to-go, as there's as much seating as a Smart Car.

Opened ten minutes late today... we needed batteries and knocked a couple times in case an employee was just behind a shelf or something and ended up walking into Albertson's to kill time. 

The employees were bickering LOUDLY the ENTIRE 15 minutes that I was there... I was sooo close to letting them know that myself and the other five customers did not want to know their drama... soooo unprofessional. 

Very disappointing.

We went on a Saturday night and they only have meter parking. Luckily, the free parking started at 8pm so we got to park for free. The wait time wasn't long considering this is a college town. I haven't been to Applebee's in a very long time and my husband never went at all. I ordered the three appetizer meal which consisted of sliders, chips and spinach dip and hot wings. My husband order the ribs. As always, he liked his food...I don't think he ever says otherwise. My food must of been ready 20 minutes before his because it was obvious that it was sitting under the heat lamp. The buns on the sliders were hard as a brick! The hot wings were dry. The spinach dip was good. At least I don't ever waste food or money because my husband always eats his food and mine. And he thought the brick buns were good on the overcooked meat. The service wasn't great. Our waiter didn't ask us if we needed anything or refill our drinks. I won't be going there again.

Veggie Veggie surprised us!  From the window it seems like a modest little cafe, from the inexpensive prices and paper napkins, but the food itself was much better than we expected.  The waitress was also very attentive (she knew precisely what was vegan on the menu too, which was most things), and the chef (who has a front kitchen in the dining area) was really cheerful.  The curry parcel puffs were filled with a delicious variety of veggies, the faux-chicken tasted almost like chicken nuggets (in a good way), and the coconut-based curry sauce was outstanding.  Most dishes can be made spicy or less spicy to your preference.

If the very idea of spending more than $10 for a deli sandwich offends you, just keep moving. Other reviewers have accused Zingerman's of using "above-average" ingredients, but that is inaccurate, and misses the point entirely. They use the best ingredients that can be found--cost be damned--and pass these ingredients and their cost on to you.

The sandwiches are awesome. They all pack a huge flavor punch, and the flavor is good, real good. This is a foodie's paradise.  The only criticism I could level is that there are really no subtle sandwiches on the menu. All the one's I've tried come at you with in-your-face flavor, which you do have to be in the mood for.

For me, though, the sandwiches are less than half of the equation. The gourmet foodstuffs they sell here comprise the best curated stock I have ever seen, anywhere, period. There may be a food shop this good in New York, Chicago, or Boston, but I've spent a lot of time in those cities and I've never seen it. Dozens of jellies, jams, olive oils, vinegars (balsamic, white wine, sherry, etc.), honeys, mustards, hard to find herbs and spices, Spanish almonds, perfect peanuts, etc., etc., etc. I haven't even started on the meats and breads, which are just as good. And this is in Ann Arbor.

That said, you are going to pay and pay hard for this stuff. When you can find the same thing somewhere else, it's generally 10-20% less. The problem is finding it. And Zingerman's does make up for this little tariff of theirs by letting you sample almost anything in the shop. In fact they almost make you try their food. It's hard to leave without being offered something to eat.

Zingerman's combined with Monahan's Seafood, Sparrow Meat Market, and Bello Rosso (for wine, beer, and produce) make Ann Arbor the best food town I've ever lived in, which is all the more impressive since I've lived in cities 30 times its size.

When price is absolutely no object and you want the best food on the planet, head to Zingerman's.

Hmm, shocked I haven't yelped about this one yet.

One of my favorite bars around town. It def isn't for everyone but I always seem to find crowds of young and old inside. The place isn't very big but it still has two flat screens, juke box, buck hunter, and darts. My buddy and I would stop by after grabbing the unos snack hour across the street for some PBR and watch the bruins or c's.

If you are more of a fan of those div bar places then check this one out. Bar service is good too.

Oh and if you do go it is a cash only bar.

Don't like the lamb shawarma plate I got.  The lamb slices were really tough and old, like they've been on the spit for weeks.  The side hummus and tahini were mixed together in a watery pool that lacked flavor and texture.  It was a horrible experience and I will not be back.
Absolutely amazing food, and a cute concept.  I highly recommend the cochinita pibil tacos -- marinated pork topped with pickled onions.

Bottom line: the MAC smells like feet.

No exaggeration.  It's not that there's one room that smells like feet, or even one corridor.  The *whole* place smells like feet.

Harvard, PLEASE invest in ventilation. Or can someone crack a window? Especially in the cardio room. 

And it's beyond cramped. There are people doing calisthenics in dark hallways because there's no room anywhere else. Seriously. You will go downstairs to the locker room and find women practicing yoga on mats underneath a flight of stairs.

God help you if you get there between 4:40 and 6PM. It's a zoo.

Oh, and God help you if you want to swim after 5. You can't. The pool is closed.  And God help you if you want to swim after noon on a weekend. You can't. The pool is closed. And it turns out the only time time pool isn't crowded is between 10:30 and 11:45 AM on weekdays. Of course, it probably will be now, since I've told all of you my secret.

Yeah before I get into it, apologies to Tami H. 'cause I'm SO not making the $30 food budget this week.

Aaaand we're back!

I've frequented CSPP for the better part of 8 months or so and I've usually come away feeling rather satisfied. The food is well made, the beer is cold and the atmosphere is inviting. So tonight being Monday (yes I know I'm writing this early Tuesday AM) it's $.20 cent wing night. Figured I'd dine on the cheap with friends. Walk in and it is PACKED for a Monday, I had to ask if there was some event going on as it took a while to get a seat.

Manage to get a place, Kyle, Adam, Kit, Adam's roommate and I are talking about everything from the drunk people in the room to the economy. Definitely a happening place. I had 2 of the house ales, an order of wings and the meatball sliders. I was starving, so self control went out the window.

Not sure how to address the last part of the experience. Suffice it say that the bartenders need to find a better way to identify patrons. Kit and Adam, you guys can stop laughing anytime now. Ya freaks.

Wow lots of reviews so there probably isn't too much for me to say.... but here is the most important.

PROS: Huge selection of really great tasty (and often very unique) burgers, amazing milkshakes (I'm a big fan of the black & white), great fries (normal and sweet potato). 

CONS: You will leave smelling like your food... don't make the mistake I once did of wearing my fleece jacket in there - I had to get it dry cleaned to ge the smell out.

Do you like good micro-brews? Do you like an easy and tasty happy hour menu? Can you put up with going somewhere in La Jolla for happy hour on Friday that is going to be naturally busy? If you answered no to any of these, this place isn't for you. Try Gordon Biersch or some other crappy faux-brewery/restaurant. 

The La Jolla location has the much better brew master. The beer selections, especially seasonal ones are amazing. They've had a few award winners over the years, and I love their beers. Other things I like about the La Jolla RB is the pool tables that are out of the way of patrons who are eating or drinking. This is a good thing for the patrons and the people playing pool. The upstairs bar. This isn't always open, but when it is, it is a nice change of scenery. They also have a dart board upstairs, which instantly draws me in. 

If you're going here after work or during lunch, it's going to be busy. It's centrally located in La Jolla/UTC, has solid beer and food and seems understaffed at times. This happens, get over it. You'll get what you're after in a fairly timely manner. 

Also, don't forget to check the half kegs on the wall when you first walk into the bar. Keg on the far right, half way down on the right, you will see my lovely named engraved in this homage to San Diego's finest drunkards.
decent food. i have had better falafel and hummus tho. service is good, prices are good.

Just a short hike from Brown University, Coffee Exchange boasts excellent fair trade coffee, for sale in beverage form or by the pound. This is coffee for serious coffee drinkers: their blends tend to be on the rich, dark side and they never oversweeten their drinks. The shop itself, with its warm wood interior and bulletin boards covered in notices, is pleasantly messy but a bit crowded and noisy. Thankfully, there is also outdoor seating for the summer months.

I love ze Viet food. I am very grateful that I found a Viet place in Providence, except for the fact that their PHO tastes odd. There's something in it that doesn't belong, like Chinese five-spice, or black pepper. If you have ever eaten PHO before and liked the other version, don't get it here. 
I get around it by eating the very tasty Vermicelli instead. One excellent thing that this place lets me do is order fresh spring rolls instead of crispy with my vermicelli. The prices are about normal for what they charge at a sit-down restaurant in Providence, so I'm not going to do my usual thing of complaining about the value of the food. 
I'm gonna suggest not ordering non-Vietnamese food from this restaurant, because it usually goes horribly wrong. 
Read the descriptions on the menu before you order, and you won't be disappointed.

Note: ask for peanut sauce w/o chili if you don't like spicy stuff. I almost bled out of my nose, and eyes because I didn't check to see if it was in there the first time

The cafeteria gives me a cheap, quick, YET HEALTHY option for lunch during work.

An 8-oz. teriyaki salmon fillet with sides of brown rice and veggies and a bottle of water is $7. 

Shoot....clearly I'm impressed, even if you're not.

I look back on my college career and have fond memories of it. I don't think it could've been at a better place. Granted in the beginning I could not get used to the "SLO" life, the cows, and sometimes the prejudice. But as time went out things got better. I grew to love the place and it did provide me with the true "college experience." It's also a great school. It's not only good for engineering and computer science, but it's known to be a pretty good school all around. Another plus is the teacher to student ratios. You won't find many classes in big halls, and the teachers will actually learn your name. All in all, great school, great fun, great education, great experience.
Isn't it technically Yo-Pu?  Whatever it is, we love it.

A perfect Sunday afternoon hangover spot. Get an egg and cheese sandwich and a large coffee, all for under $5, and recover. There are also Odwalla smoothies and other snacks, so you're good to go. It's no-frills, but do you really need any fuss for a $5 breakfast?

Omg this piece of trash chai latte was so disgusting that I just kept it as a hand warmer on a freezing cold day even tho I was thirsty and craving a nice flavorful warm drink.. Will never come to this peets ever again!!!!!!!!!!!  It was like 3/4 full also!!! UGH!!!

Beer awesomeness!

Fresh Market is really cool.  They have lots of great foods, fresh meat, awesome chocolates, and a nice selection of fruits and other foods.

What I'd like to talk about today though is the Choose-Your-Own 6 pack for $8.99.  So for $9, I can choose among their loose beers and find a wide variety of interesting possibilities:  I can make a six pack of a German Octoberfest beer (particularly the crisp Beck-like ones... and you can get Beck's too!), a dark Chocolate Stout, and 4 other beers, and pay $9 for it.  I like this.  If I want both Tecate and Sierra Nevada, I'm going to get both Tecate and Sierra Nevada, and then buy a pear cider because that sounds really good at the time.   

So yes, I'm a fan.
This coffeehouse is a nice place to study near the UT campus. The prices on food are a little high but the clover coffee is good. The wifi is spotty, it is constantly going down.

Very surprised by the negativity this place gets but I  think its because they cater to a more healthy choice of Asian cuisine. Yes they might have less "flavor" but they also probably have way less lard and msg. They're called Long Life for a reason and it's not to clog your heart. I ordered the beef with wheat noodle and curry chicken and eggplant, the later definitely stole the show since it was extremely tasteful and blasting with flavors. The prices are the only thing that keeps it a 3 star but hell, you're in fucking Stanford where people got the top down screaming out inflation ain't a thang.

Can't find a beer here that I don't like. If you want a decent beverage in Claremont, go here. This place shines bright as a beacon of hope for all bars in this area. Much better than (de)press or the kitty. 

The pub food is good especially the fries. The only problem is that it's not open late enough when I want a beer after a long day at school but considering their target customer, quite understandable. Other than that, a big thank you to Back Abbey for not being lame.

5 STARS for the complimentary bread. I honestly dont remember eating a better tasting bread...it is SO flavorful, and perfectly baked so that its crisp on the outside but fluffy and soft in the inside. i didnt even need any balsamic vinegar to pair with it....it was truly divine on its own. and i would be lying if i said i didn't try this place out JUST for the bread (it really does meet up to the hype). 

3 stars for main entrees: granted, i ordered a boring dish that i was craving -- fettucine alfredo with chicken. unfortunately, i was so full from eating the bread (that our waiters thankfully kept refilling) and the starter salad that i had little room in my tummy for the pasta. it was, though, a gigantic portion (MUCH larger than some of the other dishes my friends tried). but the flavor wasn't all that. i ate some of it the next day, but it only tasted worse.

4 stars for service: lets be honest, this place is getting 4 stars for service because our bread was refilled. in terms of our waiter, though, he was incredibly unenthusiastic, and almost rude. unlike other tables, we didn't even get freshly grated parm cheese (he gave us some pre-grated in a bowl instead). 

our bill came out to about 30-35 per person, including wine. definitely a bit pricier than expected. If i were to come back (and surely i will, if only for the bread), i'd prolly split an entree and come with fewer ppl (4 or less).

Yo.  It's my first review, so props to me =]*  I reckon that since I've been using Yelp's services for so long, I might as well give a little bit back.

Have you heard about molecular gastronomy?  It's like the hottest 'new' thing in the culinary world, with chefs using scientific techniques to create new flavour experiences.

EVOO doesn't do that -- the food is pretty solid on its own.  7 of us went for Restaurant Week, when most restaurants are only OK.  But service was spectacular and nowhere was there any indication that our food was any worse than it would have been during a regular week..

First, the appetizer.  Four of us had the "Shy Brother's Cloumage-Filled Batter Fried Verrill Farm's Squash Blossom with Pesto Dressed Zucchini 'Noodles'".  Personally, it wasn't my favourite -- the zucchini noodles were not paricularly exciting, and parts of the squash were kind of bitter.  But the cloumage was delectable and the batter gave it a nice crunch.

Two of us had the "Pat's Wellfleet Littleneck Clams Steamed with Dick's Corn, Smoked Ham of Pete and Jen's Pig, Basil, Garlic, and White Wine".  And the last one had "Grilled 'n' Chilled Local Farmer's Summer Vegetable Gazpacho with Striped Bass Belly - Charred Corn Salad".  Apparently bass belly is rather tough and non-fatty.  Who knew?

If you thought the appetizers had long names, just wait till you see the entrees.

I had the "Turf in Surf: Crisp Fried Spciy Chicken Sausage Stuffed Chesapeake Bay Soft Shell Crab with Roasted Pepper - Potato Salad, Grilled Dick's Corn Salsa and Mustard Mayonnaise".  It was really clever -- a turf IN surf, where the breading enveloped both the chicken sausage and the soft-shell crab into a funny-looking thing that you would expect to find at the bottom of an aquarium.  The salad was also really good -- just the right amount of creaminess but with a lot of variety in the vegetables.  Succulence.  Five stars.

Pretty much all the entrees were successful.  Two of my friends got scallops -- but the star of that dish were actually the uber-fresh vegetables.  And one of them got the top sirloin (with zucchini), which was unfortunately way too tough.  He asked me how it was four minutes after I ate it.  I was still eating it.  That was the only sour note.

And the desserts!  OMG.  Cue Vanessa Williams' "Save the Best for Last".  I think I'll pull it up on YouTube right now.

Chocolate truffle cake with (seared?) marshmallow.  Thick and heavy, but full of chocolatey goodness.  Five stars.

Apple and blueberry crisp and almond ice cream.  There was something funny in there, not necessarily the tastiest but certainly not bad and definitely made the dish interesting.  Four and a half stars.

And I had the corn cake with blueberry compote.  Who makes a deconstructed dessert?  EVOO does!  It actually tasted like corn on the cob.  Yet it was flaky.  Like certain people who didn't show up for dinner (um ... first Yelp friend?  Please still accept my friend request, or whatever we do on this site.).  Four and a half stars.

And that very thing you're looking for -- the one thing you can't see?**  ZUCCHINI ICE CREAM.  A boy can dream.

There were at least six choices for each course, and all of them were presented and executed ABCD.  I'm giving it 5 stars because of the overall atmosphere -- and yeah, service was great.  The food was definitely above average, and while it's not like a 'sticks-in-your-memory-as-the-coolest-bestest-most-amazing-dinner-I've-ever-had-in-my-life" kind of place, I would consider coming back.  They gave us a lot of good food yo!

*And no, I'm not a conceited douchebag.  I hope.
**I'm also not a Vanessa Williams fanatic or anything.  Just so you all know.

I have to agree with Kat L on this one.  It's all just a little bit "eh" and a lot "hmph."

We stopped by yesterday to entertain an out of towner who wanted to do some lunch near UT.  We ascended on Pita Pit, and for $7.00 I got the falafel pita.   It was good, but only about $5.50 good.  I thought $7 was too steep for such a fair dish in a plastic basket.  

The people watching is not even that good at Pita Pit.   I think they all feel the same way about the food and experience there.  It's just "eh," and the vibe permeates throughout the room.

I felt it was a Subway with different bread.   They even have the exact same chips, dressings and bottle stickers as a Subway.   And that ain't so special.

Horrible service, mediocre food, this place is a mess, and yet always freaking packed?

Let's just start by saying I ordered a catering lunch order for delivery.  Nothing too big, and they're just down the street, so it shouldn't have been a problem.  Wrong.  10 minutes after the time they were supposed to be delivered, I called and was rudely told that the driver was on his way.  20 minutes later, the same rude lady told me that they were "busy, so you're just going to have to wait for him to get there."  A half hour, I called and demanded to talk to the manager after she gave me the runaround again.  

Then the manager gives me the great news:  there was NO DRIVER DELIVERING MY FOOD  - it was sitting in the restaurant the whole time.  He unapologetically tells me he can cancel my order for me, which doesn't help me AT ALL since I have an entire office waiting on their lunch right now.  I had to drive to the place myself to pick up my delivery order, wait in line, and deal with the incompetent manager.  I, and my office, will never order from them again.

This is a hard review to write. I really really want to like solstice, they have some really great things going for them.

1. Tasty homebaked goods
2. Nummy granola (though the yogurt they carry is icky)
3. Grilled Cheese sandwiches and they typically have tomato soup
4. Other handmade pannini
5. Tasty espresso drinks
6. Handsome staff always willing to help. 

This is *the* independent coffeshop. I should be stopping in every morning on my way to work. I even bought a small prepaid coffee card from them.  But here is the big problem preventing those two extra stars, and the problem that has me going to another coffee shop most every morning. 

There drip coffee has grounds in it. They actually do a french press instead of a typical drip. The coffee has a great flavor, but the little gritty bits at the bottom of  the cup drive me crazy. I should be able to savor every drop of my $ 2.00  brewed coffee. And going later in the day you'll run the risk of getting the dregs of the drip. A cup at 11 am reveled itself to be a murky soup of coffee grounds in greyish water. 
Yum.

Really now, why are you reading a review for in-n-out burger? you know you've been there, and if you haven't it doesn't matter what any of us say, you should go try it, it's simply that legendary.

why?

because it's awesome. it really is. I've been to tons of different in-n-outs and it tastes fresh everytime everywhere.

Get everything animal style though, that means hella thousand island with relish, onions, and cheese. Especially the fries, tasty plain, tastier with all that crap on them. In fact do yourself a favor and ask for a packet of extra sauce because you can never get too much. Well i guess you could but it's hard so better to be prepared.

One of the things I missed most about New York City when I was an undergrad at  Cornell was the independent films.  I mean, sure Cornell Cinema was awesome at bringing good films to campus, but none of them were movies that were out NOW.  Then I found Fall Creek!  Which was basically the answer to my prayers.

Fall Creek is small and a bit out of the way for most people, but I feel like that only works in its favor.  There is no glamour here, just the film (and knowing indie flicks, most of them probably wouldn't go with the concept of glamour anyway) and you in a chair that feels much older than you are.  Fall Creek always brings an awesome selection of films to Ithaca, and I've run into a lot of my professors here, who, too, must miss the cultural fulfillment of more metropolitan areas.  But the place makes you glad you're in Ithaca and not in a crowded city center - not only do you get to watch your indie movie in peace, you get room to think about it too.

The scene: Sunday morning. My friends and I are on a mission: To boldly go and get some freakin' brunch before hitting the science museum. The place: Friendly Toast. Well, I will admit my stomach was more like Angry Toast after the hour-long wait for a table. Which is really the only reason I didn't give five stars. But it was worth it! Oh, yes. Much toast was had, and it was very friendly.

Upon reading the menu, mine eyes doth lingered on the Ole Miss. Longing to be back home below the Mason-Dixon and devouring a plate of fine Southern soul food, I figured this might be a reasonable facsimile. Sausage... Eggs... Mango sour cream... Cayenne-cheddar toast... AND chipotle sweet potatoes?! Stop right there, and sign me up. If all those things sound amazing, it's because they are. Warm and happy in my tummy. 

My friend got one of the daily specials-- portobello mushroom caps filled with scrambled eggs, prosciutto, and goat cheese, with a balsamic glaze. What do y'all say in Boston...? Oh, it was "wicked good." 

I'd love to come back, but perhaps NOT on a weekend during prime brunch hours.
Have to agree with others, service is slow food is OK, kind of small.  Dare I say the one in fullerton is slightly better but still slow service.

The woman at the counter was nice and she was good about cleaning the tables right after customers left. I managed to grab the table next to the window, which provided me with great light for getting my class reading done. (A girl sitting deep in the restaurant was also reading, however, so I guess the light there was also enough.)

I was thinking fish & chips, but when I saw calamari & chips on the menu I decided to give it a go. The food and a vitamin water (jackfruit+guava- never seen that one before!) ended up costing me about $10. So... doesn't really fit into the "super wonderfully cheap eats in the U-district" list.

The fries were alright but nothing interesting. The calamari was okay, but I'm not a big fan of fried things (except the fried ice cream at some japanese joints!) so I wasn't super excited about it.

Over-all it was a decent experience and more of a 3.5, but I have no plans to return so I figure 3 stars is more accurate (than 4).

3.5 

The salsa was ok. Service was good. Loved the patio. Food was your average Americanized Mexican food. Personally i prefer the more authentic types of mexican food but i would return because of the patio seating available.

Since I don't know much about this place, but want to get it on record, I'm giving it a three until I try it again.

A bit out of the way for a girl from Queens, this pastry shop still packs a powerful punch as far as variety is concerned. Furthermore, considering I adore Hungarian and virtually all central European treats, this place hit the motherload. 

Points taken off, however, for bored, lazy service. 

I decided upon a napoleon, something which I think I might have had once in my life previously. It was $3.50, and made up almost entirely of a stiff, yellow and delicious custard. Sandwiching this delightful filling were two puff pastries covered in powdered sugar. Though they were tasty, I had to pick them up and bite into them, as a knife wouldn't suffice. Be sure to turn the pastries right side up when consuming, or else you'll be covered in a shower of baby powder.

When I get another hankering, I'll venture back over here and give you guys a more thorough review.

I love this bookstore. They may not always have what you need, but, if you don't know what you need this is the type of place where a book will jump off a shelf for you. (Not literally, of course; I don't think they have poltergeists) 

Once I was checking out a book on French verbs which I had been hunting for, when suddenly a book on drawing caught my eye. I flipped through it and immediately decided to purchase it instead of the verb book. Owning that book on drawing changed the course of things, and this is the kind of store where moments like that can happen. Plus, who wants to have moments of divine intervention in a big-box chain store, I ask you?

What kind of alum would I be if I didn't give a shout out to my alma mater?  Okay, sure after the generous geology department paid for my tuition, I only stayed in the field for 3 more years.  But the time I spent there was priceless.  I love the campus, the people, the programs.  I love how they took care of you as a grad student; there was a grad student union, can you believe it?  And grad student housing for $700 a semester!  Great public transportation, lively social scene (not that I partook, vis-a-vis the grad student part), excellent health center.  I loved everything about Ann Arbor and U. Mich. except the weather.  Constant winter or sweltering summer.  But I guess that's not the university's fault.

General Manager Andre' Hall and Chef Mark Pettyjohn make me happy.  Very happy.

I recently joined a few friends for a celebration dinner at California Cafe for the Friday Five Bites event.  It pairs five small courses with five tastes of regional wines.  

Shortly after we arrived, Andre' visited our table to ensure everyone was having a good time.  Being the honest man that I am, I said that I really wanted to try the food but as a Beer Snob I wasn't much of a wine fan.  I asked if he could possibly serve me the food on it's own.  Doing one step better he offered to personally pair the beer he had available with each course.  Very importantly, he offered this instantly and with a genuine smile.  It made me feel that my experience was important and that he would do whatever it took to make me happy.

And oooh how happy I was.

Each and every course was beautiful and inventively prepared.  From the Strawberry Rose' Gelatin, to the Pork Belly (PORK BELLY), to the Duck Confit ... I loved it all.  Andre's off the cuff beer pairings were spot on, and really added a fun surprise for each new course. 

Based on previous two visits (Beer Dinners for Devil's Canyon and Lagunitas) and this most recent visit, I strongly recommend that you make plans to visit California Cafe soon!

I'm only reviewing the customer service aspect, since I did not get to sample any actual food. I came in on Wednesday, lunch hour. The place was practically empty, only 2-3 table had people. There were 2 hosts, both of whom seem extremely unhappy about being there. When I asked them what is good for take out, they just handed me a take out menu. When I asked for the special, they said that they don't do their specials as take out. They did not have an answer for why. 

Summary: Shitty customer service and weird restrictions were an immediate turn off.

Visiting the Stanford campus, we ran across this little restaurant/cafe.  It reminde me of a hip version of a panera crossed with Starbucks, with a slightly better menu and more comfy seating.  There was also a piano in the corner that patrons took turns playing for other diners pleasure. It had a real community feel to it. All of our food was moderately priced to a little pricy, but very good. We had one unique pasta dish, one sandwich and one hummus plate in our group, all were done equally well. Coffee was fantastic and desert pastries were good enough to compete with a bakery vs a cafe. If I were a student here, this would be my hangout.

Sometimes all a foodie really needs is a quality salad fix. I certainly found that at The Spicy Pickle. Their Forest salad came complete with a winning mix of the crunchy and chewy. Representing Team Chewy were sun dried tomatoes and portobello mushrooms. The softness of the latter was really enjoyable as taste treats go. Allows for the hearty flavor to rush in unrestrained. The dominant member of Team Crunchy was the hazelnut. Considering how I'm used to honey-roasted walnuts as a salad nut this was a refreshing switch in both appearance and texture on the tooth. 
The presentation was inviting. Mounds of spinach with the stems still on. At least you could say you got your greens, right? The honey-balsamic vinaigrette it came with was robust. Not cloyingly sweet. That's a plus because you don't want the dressing overwhelming all the other components of the salad. A large dinner-sized salad runs you a hair over $9. Probably would've been worth it had I added roast chicken but that's not the fault of the purveyors. 
Why only 3 stars? Because it was only my first visit. Loads of room for a ranking hike upon future visits which seem plausible. From an atmosphere standpoint I have no quibble. Elevated seating for people watching purposes. You have the standard four to a table setup. There's also elevated seating in round table format. Don't know whether it was because I stopped in pre-dinner hour or if this restaurant feels this laid back all the time but I'd certainly say it's a comfy place to unwind with or without newspaper and with or without close buds. 
Possibilities can be very exciting and at this juncture in my relationship with The Spicy Pickle it has demonstrated it respects possibility. Next stop...the panini section.

The first time that I ate at Pinocciho's Pizza was on Sunday, July 26, 2009.  I went there twice that day, and that's how great this place is.  I actually ate there yesterday.  I am very familiar with other pizza places, like Pino's, Presto Pizzeria Restaurant , and Santarpia's.  I'm actually buddies with Pino's GM, named Mr. Osmani.  So anyways, Pinocchio's Pizza is excellent.  I've had their thick, Sicilian crust pizza, but never their thin crust.  Their sausage pizza is excellent, followed by their tomatoe/basil.  Their pepperoni is great, but I prefer the other two. 

This place is more crowded than Pino's, and it's smaller as well.  I'm so surprised that I've never been here before until now. 

Lastly, I wish that they sold thin crust pizza by the slice.

Props to Gastro N. Just got the porchetta panini.Thing was awesome. The meat is flavored so well and the cheese is nothing short of amazing. 

As for the grocery portion of the store, it's a bit pricey, but is to be expected of a speciality grocery.

I can't speak to the new management (I only get up to Ithaca once or twice a year), but I was very disappointed in Simeon's. I'd heard good things about it, it always appeared busy, so I was excited to try it. 

I had a pear and spinach salad and the pears were canned. CANNED. I mean, if you are going to prepare a fresh salad, how about using actually fresh ingredients? And it was not particuarly cheap.

Service was adequate, venue is attractive.

If you are picky about service, hygiene and ambience you probably won't like this place. I like it - the ladies do a good job on manicure for good price right at the square.

I normally use the Aveda accross the street for waxing etc but never for manicure/pedicure. Unique Nails offers what I perceive to be a better job for half of the price. You do need to direct them on how you want your manicure, and ask them to re-do it if you don't like it.
Fresh baked bread and amazing clam chowder served in a bread bowl. The ice tea is pretty good too.

I have finally discovered the ideal place to work away from the office.

The Frances C. Arrillaga Alumni Center is, as the name suggests, intended as a place for Stanford alums to call home when visiting campus. 

Right now I am sitting in a "living room" that Leland Stanford himself couldn't have helped being impressed by: it's filled with plush couches and chairs for 10+ separate groups, pristine tiled floors and floor-to-ceiling windows that look out onto the even-more-impressive terraced courtyard. The grand piano looks tiny just floating in one corner of the room.

Beyond the living room, there is also a business center with plentiful desks and some conference rooms, the courtyard itself with lots of tables for your afternoon meeting, and the Alumni Cafe with its decent lineup of food and beverages.

I believe the building's upstairs are filled with offices for both the Alumni Association and Office of Development. Not a bad place to come to work every day.

Overall, the Center is a better place to work than the lobby of a Four Seasons... and when you squint a little and get into your work (or book or lounging), you can drift into a dream of being back at home on Stanford campus, but with the beer smells of dorm life replaced with the lavender scent of an Atherton estate.

I wish there was a no star option. 

Last week I ordered from the Gap  and the item was suppose to be received today, however Gap uses FedEx Smartpost which means FedEx gives USPS their packages for delivery. 

USPS refused to deliver my package because they said my address was undeliverable and then lost the package when I called about. During my call the supervisor, Fran, left me on hold for 25 minutes and 3 seconds only to get back on the line and say she forgot about me because she went back to her desk and no she didn't find my package even though it has a tracking number and the number says it's there.

I called back this morning only to be told it's their busy and I have to call back. 

This is the worst post office and the laziest bunch of workers I have ever come across. 
 
I knew they were lazy when I kept getting sorry we missed you tags even though I was home..


Super frustrating

Yay! Useful stuff! I like it.

Radioshack isn't where I'd go for almost any electronic purchases, but when I need some small household thing like batteries... why the heck not? It was easy and convenient, and the staff seemed nice enough.

I can't for the life of me understand why the other customers in there were choosing to do their cell phone shopping at Radioshack, but... to each his own, I guess. Maybe it was a prepaid and it made sense to them somehow?

Anyway. Glad there's a Radioshack location on the Ave because it means I was able to get that errand done without having to go out of my way.

Finally! I've been waiting for a pole dancing studio like Boston Pole Fitness to open in this city for several years now. I took pole dancing classes several years ago, but had not had any instruction in over 2 years until Stacy opened her studio. This is EXACTLY what I have always wanted. It's the best pole dancing workout I've gotten in Boston and it focuses more on the athletic, the pole tricks, et al. 

Stacy and Wendy are great instructors. Unbelievably talented. They really know their stuff and you definitely get one-on-one instruction. They make sure you're warmed up, that you learn proper form and alignment, and that you do both sides. When I was doing pole dancing workouts before, I never learned my left side. Up until now, I did not think I had enough coordination to do it but guess what? I totally can! 

Another big plus is class and studio size. Located on the first floor of Gold's Gym on Landsdowne, the space is an excellent size and they make sure the number of poles = number of girls. When you have to share, you just don't learn as well. Also -- the class length. Classes are 1:15. I've always felt an hour is just too short. This might just be personal preference, but if you've ever take a pole class, you might agree. When I leave, my butt has been thoroughly whipped and it is awesome.

If you've ever been curious about pole dancing as a workout, you have to try a class at Boston Pole Fitness.

My review is for the restaurant-- I've eaten there twice.  And that's about all there is to say.  The food was good, but it wasn't that good.  Most recently I had the Asian chicken salad, and it was okay, but I felt like I had eaten a heavy meal afterwards because there are a lot of fried wontons on it, and it's loaded down with dressing.  The prices and size of their portions seem to run the full gamut, so at least you've got options.  The tables and decor are pretty cheesy, in my book-- basically a glorified diner.  But the garden area is really pretty, as is the watermill.  The service wasn't great, but we were there on Mother's Day, so I'm sure they were busy.  A smile from the hostess up front would have been great, but she was much more interested in saying hello to her friends behind us.

Ok, next time I come here, I pledge to get only a salad, which looks to be huge in portion.

Instead, today I ordered a Mexican special, the roasted poblano peppers stuffed with queso fresco, dipped in egg batter, and served with a spicy tomato salsa with jasmine rice and green peas, black beans, and two warm tortillas.

Translation: a tiny TINY bowl with ONE stuffed pepper and NO black beans.  The taste also wasn't extraordinary enough to make up for the absolute price gouge at $10 bucks.

In the end, I felt so unsatisfied I went next door (Espress Experience) to have shaved ice.

Who doesn't love a super awesome bartender?   Definitely grab a drink here and hang with the bartender.  He's really well informed, lets you sample before you commit, and will teach about all about Zirbenz. What's not to love.

I haven't tried much on the menu.... the chicken tenders leave quite a bit to be desired... 


HOWEVER... the fries are soooo good, and I seriously crave the fish sandwich at least once a week!

This is a cute lil cafe I've been to for breakfast.  It is indeed Frenchy.  Parking isn't so bad on Sunday mornings when not much else is open yet.  The space is small and feels cramped when busy.  They serve salads, quiche, soups, and sandwiches.  They also make pastries, cakes, and chocolate croissants.  You have to place your order at the counter, there's not really wait service.  Prices were reasonable and credit cards are accepted.  The food was quick and good.

I'm a fan of this place.  Cute idea, with the whole periodic table and lab table theme.  But this place has some solid food and a decent beer selections.

What really sets MOS apart from other spots in Central is their brunch.  Though I've never been thoroughly impressed by their steak and eggs, and the breakfast burrito my girlfriend ordered had a few beans that were undercooked, you can't beat entree, coffee, and fresh OJ for $13.  For both of us.  That's crackhouse prices right there, and it will keep me coming back. 

Don't get me wrong, there are major highlights on the menu.  Anytime I'm in there for lunch or dinner, I'll get the Roni burger.  And their homefries, which come with both breakfast and dinner foods, are amazing.

This place would be a great deal at half the price. But at $7 for a cup of soup, I expect something excellent. The descriptions of their soup all sound amazing, but really they all (including the famed lobster bisque) just taste like salt. Peering in there as I ordered once I saw them cooking godknowswhat in a microwave, so maybe that explains a bit of what goes wrong here. I'd prefer not paying double digits for microwavecookery.

I know people want to love the concept (hence 4.5 stars average), but it's just not that great.

This is a more traditional Mexican restaurant, with homemade salsa (fresca & verde) & guacamole, the burritos are delicious and the eggplant quesadilla is as well.  It's more of a cool dive to hang out and get a pretty inexpensive meal and leave quite satisfied.  There is typically mariachi playing in the background and smiling faces to greet you. During the semester, this place is open until 3am and sometimes later, in the summer they're open til 11pm during the week and 2am on Friday's and Saturday's.

I was here with my cousin who goes to Cal Berkeley. we were pretty hungry, and with thai being my favorite food, i decided to give this place a shot. i decided to try a foolproof dish: pad thai. The food itself was pretty good. there was a good amount, enough to fill a hungry teenager. but the flavor was lacking. by the time i was almost done, everything sorta tasted the same. the chicken was fine, as was the shrimp, but it could definitely use more sauce.

THE SERVICE IS ATROCIOUS. but i mean, thats typical of any asian owned restaurant. :P (im not being racist, im chinese myself). the price for the pad thai was 6.61, and so i thought 7 bucks would be enough. i ordered in a cherful voice, and then the lady stuck out her hand without telling me how much it was with tax. i gave her the 7 which she took, and then she stuck out her hand again and rudely gestured for the extra 25 cents that i was lacking. i was confused for a moment because she never even said how much the total was, but then i looked at the register and fumbled through my wallet for another dollar. she then took it, looking a bit annoyed, and then gave me my receipt. (side note: DO NOT LOSE YOUR RECEIPT. you need it to pick up your food.) so yeah, i got my receipt, and then waited something like 15 minutes for my food. that part was fine since i was with friends, but just a heads up on busy days.

overall, the food was pretty good, but the service was bad. if you have a thick skin, you'll have no issues getting some decent chow. and if you dont like it, there are 7 other types of food in the pavaliion ranging from italian to vietnamese.

Veggie Heaven is a perfect solution for herbivores and carnivores alike. With choices and serving sizes that can satisfy any meat lover (like myself) with a price perfect for the broke college student, it's really like being in heaven. 

Coming from an Asian background most of the flavors are familiar and remind me of home. My favorite dish is the eggplant tofu. Nice mushy eggplant with fried tofu all in a flavorful garlic blackbean sauce, delicious!

The only reason i don't give it 5 stars is because the restaurant itself is pretty sketchy. You may not want to question too much why there is only a little square cut out so the food can be passed from the kitchen. But if you can ignore that the tight space and slightly dingy dining area, then veggie heaven is definitely a place to go.

Visiting Blacksburg to watch Hokie's play against Tarheels and needed a place to eat before the men's basketball game.  So where do you go when Subway's and Hardee's crack the top 20 in restaurants in the area!?  You go 'local' and where the drinks are inexpensive!  After hearing about The Gobbler on yelp and checking out the menu I thought as a vegetarian worse case scenario would be having the baked ravioli. 

The place was not that busy when we arrived a little less than 2 hours before tipoff, but started picking up while we were dining.  Everyone coming in were college students enjoying some pool, beer and maybe a smoke (which coming from a non-smoking town forgot you were still able to do that).  The waitstaff was very nice.  The lady that sat us and started our order recommended I try the calzone which I am glad I did!  Not only was it delicious but also enough for three meals!  My friend also enjoyed her sub and chips.  

After the shift change we were also helped by a nice gentleman and a lady named Laura.  Now I have to give an extra shout-out to Laura for not only being an awesome server but also HAND DRAWING directions to Cassell Coliseum.  Sure I felt like a fool when I realized just how close we were BUT I wouldn't have made the correct turns to get there in a timely manner- AND she even gave us two options to get there! :)

If I make it back to Blacksburg I will plan on dropping in to The Gobbler knowing I'll be supporting a local hangout, eating a delicious calzone, treated to excellent service and maybe just another drawing from Laura!

We heart the Mother. After my husband's uberfoodie friend could not stop raving, he made a reservation to celebrate a special day. I admit I was a little worried because, as other reviewers have mentioned, restaurants like this can be pretentious-- both the staff and the clientele. However, every single thing about this restaurant is warm, comfortable, and approachable. You just want to cozy on up to the table and dine, even before the food arrives.

Our favorites: the boiled peanuts (combined with the sea salt, these are al dente and damply satisfying), the pulled pork (which set the bar for all other such dishes elsewhere as far as my husband is concerned) and I have never had better red velvet cake. Their menu changes constantly but all of it is made from local and/or sustainably grown ingredients. This honestly makes me feel better about trying something I would avoid in other restaurants, so the fish and seafood dishes have been consistently superb, and very fresh, as well.

The downsides: yes, it's slightly pricey, but two people can share a first course and a dessert and still feel satisfied (and you won't get eyeballed by the wait staff, either). Yes, if you drive you must park in the Kendall Square parking garage, but it's a very short walk and not outstandingly expensive for Cambridge. Yes, you do have to call ahead to get a table, and from the size of the place I would guess it's harder to get a reservation for 5 or more people. But none of these "negatives" make for a sincere dining hardship here in Boston proper, all things considered.

Yummy! Some friends and I wandered around Harvard Square area not knowing where to go, but letting our noses and stomachs dictate our footsteps. 

This place was perfect. It had some welcoming uplifiting music to draw our attention, some very very reasonable prices (especially for a broke grad student), and a mix of foods that are quite new to my palate (Cajun and Mexican??). 

They start you off with tortilla chips that seem to be made there. Taste fresh and I couldn't stop eating them! But had to, to save room for my meal.

I had the Catfish Mardi Gras and would strongly recommend it. Fried just right, tastes yummy and different, awesome cornbread and rice and beans on the side. My bf had the Catfish New Orleans. Almost similar to my dish save for the sauce which was lighter and creamier. My friend had the Fish Tacos which were a really good size. One thing she said was slightly off was the tortilla wrapper. A little too thick for her taste.

We topped off our meal with some frozen sangrias. First time I've ever had a frozen blended sangria. A little watered down (perhaps due to the nature of it being blended) but a good price. $4.75.

Letters, blankets, shorts, shirts, sweaters, robes, pillow cases, hats...let's just say if you can embroider it I've taken it here. Over the last three years I have made what feels like hundreds of trips here to personalize gifts for my sorority. 

They do great quality work and rarely make mistakes and if they do they fix it extremely quickly. They are also very kind to return customers like myself and go out of their way to help me with the designs and finishing my items when i need them (I've come in at 9am with 5 items and they would have it done for me the same day).  For most things they charge $5 per hit on an item.

Things to know: 

They are a bit tricky to find. They are on the northeast corner of 29th and Vermont. If you see the Trojan Cleaners they are just north of that. There is a glass door with a call box on the right. Just punch in their number from the directory and they will buzz you in. You can see their office from the door so sometimes you just have to wave and they'll let you inside the building. 

They are open Monday through Friday and they close a bit earlier on some days so just leave them your number and they will call you when your order is done and let you know when they are closing 

They are cash only so make a stop at the ATM before you go

I can only describe this experience at Rendezvous as surreal.  This was the third time I had been there, and each time I was less impressed with the food, but I'd say it is reasonable for the price, and the cocktails are tasty.  (The first time I had a bucatini with short rib that was DELICIOUS.) I've also eaten at the bar and had a good experience there.  On this particular night, my boyfriend and I had two friends who had just landed from London, and since it was MIT graduation weekend, this was one of the few close-by places we could get a reservation.  

We sat down and all when the server took our drink order, the other three in our party each ordered a cocktail and I asked her for a white wine recommendation, and she made one, and I said it sounded fine.  When she returned, she brought three drinks and opened a bottle of wine, poured me a glass and left the bottle. When I responded politely that I hadn't ordered a bottle, just a glass, she apologized for the confusion, poured me a bigger glass, and took the bottle away. I apologized as well for not being clear enough. 

A few minutes later, another server or manager, I'm not sure which, came over and reiterated that I had made them open a bottle of wine and then sent it back, and the bottle cost $48. I apologized again for the confusion.  She held the wine list right up to my face, pointing at the "$48" and said "Did this number just not REGISTER with you?" Those were her exact words, I am 100% serious. In stunned silence, I just apologized for the 12th time for the confusion, and said I wasn't sure what else I could say.  It was a misunderstanding. She walked off in a huff, clearly disappointed that I wasn't willing to pay for the whole bottle. 

The poor server came back about 15 minutes later and apologized profusely. I felt terrible for her.  We had an okay meal, spent $300, but if it weren't for the fact that our friends had just traveled across the Atlantic and were hungry, we definitely would have left.  

I took responsibility for contributing to what was an honest misunderstanding by both parties, and whoever this woman was must have had a terrible day and taken her frustration out on us.  It was definitely a buzzkill for the entire meal, although our server, once she recovered from her embarrassment, was great. The food was so-so, I had a pasta dish with peas and lamb that was okay but bland.  We won't return - Craigie on Main and Cuchi Cuchi are better choices.

there is over 2000 reviews for this 4.5 star place.  No one is going to read a review.  So you know its good.  But what to get?

White Chocolate Macadamia nut on espresso chip.

You get two cookies (mix and choose)

I thought this was ok nothing over the top its cookies and ice-cream its not innovative or anything just a good treat that will probably leave you in a diabetic coma.  

fun? of course!!

This is the best Chinese food you will find in the Champaign/Urbana/Savoy/Mahomet area.
