They used to be on campus, them moved out to Mahomet, now back on campus (note that the restaurant has changed names with each move). My friends and I always joke that they would make bank if they moved up to the Chicago suburb area. But they do very well already right now where they are. 

My family has known their family for about 6 years now, and they are the sweetest people on earth. If you're not sure what to order, you can always ask them (Tina is very helpful) what they recommend. Our staple dishes here are:

Steamed fish (i don't know the name, but it's some type of white fish steamed with green onions, ginger, sitting on top of bean sprouts. So fresh and delicious!)
Crab Rangoon - never had better
Orange Chicken
Basil Eggplant
soup of some kind, they're all pretty good
smoked chicken 
Crispy Tofu!!! People try to copy their recipe, but the original is still, after all these years, unbeatable!

Service in my opinion is always great. If you're going to gripe about cleaning your own table or writing down your order on a piece of paper (it just makes the ordering and cooking process faster - win for everyone), then don't eat here. More good food for the rest of us who don't need to be sucked up to and waited on for a good meal. This is your cozy mom and pop and daughter Chinese food shop. There's so much love in that food! :)

Sprinkles has become famous for a reason - a delicious reason :)

5 Stars comes easy for my review of this place.  All the things a cupcake should be becomes apparent upon first bite.  The look of the cupcake is even appealing.  You can see the chic modern spin on such an old fashioned treat.  The frosting is swirled around flatly creating an edged dome appearance.  And the little candied logo on top adds all the minimalist love one could ask for.

The ingredients used show off their potential over that of mass produced cupcakes found elsewhere.  The cake itself retains moisture (even over night) and fluffiness.  Yet, it isn't so moist that it seems raw or comes off as overly 'cakey' - instead its fresh, playfully spongy and packed with delicate sweetness that won't overpower your taste buds.  It compliments the frosting laying on top of it perfectly and creates of collage of taste and sweetness with subtle flavors through out, each unique to the flavor of cupcake you choose.

Yes, there will be a line, but it will be worth the wait.  Plus, as Sprinkles expands its wonders and opens more locations I am sure that the lines will slowly shorten.  It's still new in La Jolla and there are plenty of people that still haven't heard of it yet, so I'd predict long lines for at least another two to three months as word of mouth spreads like poppy.

Again, the wait is worth it.  In reality it moves quickly too.  Just be smart about and don't go when you know you need to be somewhere or have major obligations, and go with a buddy so you have something to do as you wait.  Have a chat, or grab a coffee somewhere as you waddle close to sweet success.  

What's great about this business is that they offer certain cupcakes on certain days which will appeal to most cupcake lovers as they'll come across that 'challenge' mentality - "I'm going to try them all!!" 

They also have staples within the menu which is a great way to start on your cupcake journey.

Enough words already, stop reading and start eating.  Just admit you're in a line for a cupcake, shell out the 3.50 (or more) and enjoy the goodness that is.

I have never encountered such terrible customer service in my life!  Stay away from thus place.  Rude, rude, rude!!!  This place should not be allowed to stay in business. There are so many other Jamaican restaurants with better food and MUCH better customer service.  Stay away!!!!  The woman at the counter with the ugly braids and nasty attitude made sure that I will never, ever enter the place again!!!

The back abbey is probably the best place to have a unique beer in the inland empire.   With a wide variety of foreign brews you get a cool euro feel to the already studious Claremont feel.  

But wait, there is more!   The fries (marinated in duck fat) are some of the best fries I have ever had, a MUST.  Additionally, the rest of the food is very nice.  

The service is friendly, but can be lacking because the place gets packed.  I hate to dock them for this because I like the service, but  waiting 30 minutes to order is ridiculous (in rare cases).  The crowd here varies from your beer lovers to hip College students to wealthy Claremont residents.
Ohhh Rhino.  This was my favorite spot in high school and still is a favorite of mine.  I can always find something that I really (don't) need here and it normally is a good and fair price.

this is a celebratory restaurant between me and my friends. the sushi is probably the best around here, which means its not cheap, though affordable.

special rolls/chef's specials are great. very flavourful, though a little pricier than your average order of nigiri.

This is probably one of the most consistently fun places to go out in Cambridge.  Every night I've gone, it's been a blast.  

Middlesex is a great spot for non-mainstream entertainment... both in terms of the music they have here and the patrons.  The crowd is pretty friendly overall and doesn't suffer from the usual boston frat-boy contingent.  The music is usually pretty unique too... so don't expect top 40's crap.  

Best night by far is Thursdays... which i'm proudly a regular of.  Every other tuesday is called "Hearthrob" which is pretty fun too.

PS - I can only comment on the late night aspect of this place, as i've never been here for the food.

You've got the Foundation in Raleigh...  and I've met her match in Chapel Thrill... she's called The Crunkleton.  And damn am I sad I never discovered her until now.  

It's got booths and tables, bar seating, and little cozy corners for you to tuck into depending on your visit purpose.  The drinks are incredible.  My husband had one of the best mojitos he's ever had and I had some pretty great bourbon.  Their liquor list is extensive... one of the best in the triangle.  I was impressed with the service and knowledge of the staff.  They have a pool table which is certainly a little one up on The Foundation.   A little entertainment.  They make their own tonic and it was great.  

You have to be a member to go in or at least go with one or something, I'm not really sure how it works.  I think the membership fee was 5$.

I have been here a couple of times and love it. The rooms are comfy and you get a great view. I love the decor. There is a different theme on each floor ( I think). 
I was surprised the first time here 2 years ago for my birthday. Ever since then, I was hooked. The pool area is so fun. The Sunday music is fun and relaxing. Being able to sit out and get some drinks at the same time is pretty relaxing to me. 
I like how there is complimentary coffee and tea on each floor in the morning. I know i need coffee first thing. The food is great too. 
At the Monarch Lounge, the service is quick and the people are fun. There are a couple of snooty people who think they run the place but all I do is ignore them because I am at the Lounge to have a great time. For the birthday treat they put sparklers on and it looks so nice when they come serve it to you. 

If you haven't been here yet, I don't know what you're waiting on. It is worth every dollar.

I eat here all the time.  Whether I'm in the mood for a quick Teriyaki on the run or a wonderful Korean fare, this place never disappoints.  The food comes fast.  It always tastes wonderful.  

And the frozen yogurt on a summers day?  A little overpriced but completely worth it for a guilt free treat.

I don't think I'll be doing business here again...I brought in a bag of books, the man took them out, stacked them on the table, and gave me a price. a very low price for a high stack of popular titles such as Anna Karenina, The Odyssey, Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, etc...all in almost brand new condition because most of them had not ever been read! I guess this is a good place to unload books you just wanna get rid of but if you are looking for a fair price for them you might as well sell them on Amazon. I knew that anyways, I have sold books at Magus and they put a price on each book individually and I walked out of there happy with how much $ I made....I guess I will go back there next time. I really felt ripped off here.

I really like this store. They have activity time for little ones and the sales people are super friendly and have great suggestions when you are looking for gifts. I went to this store looking for baby shower items and not only were they on par with online and big store prices, but they gift wrapped everything and were super nice. There were darling little baby bonnets and hand made items, bamboo, bpa free items. Food prep, reuseable diapers and strollers, lots of good gear!

This place is located in Sather Lane and reminded me of Korea as soon as I walked in. The decor is so Korean - and by that, I mean really bright colors and a fun feel.

My two friends from Korea took me here to thank me for helping them edit & proofread their resume and cover letters. It's gotta be good if the real Koreans like it, right? Everyone was speaking Korean in there...I really felt like I was in Korea again.

We got 3 dishes to share, including japchae and a rice cake dish (two of my favorite Korean foods), and I thought they were pretty good. But I refrain from giving 4 stars because I've had better - I'm getting to be pretty picky with my Korean foods...my Korean palate is developing now. ;)

I have no idea how much things cost since my it was their treat, but I'd probably go here again.

I stayed in a hotel right behind the plaza housing this lovely establishment and I was lucky it was there because even with cars we might not have found a better place for an easy breakfast.  I had a coffee and an everything bagel with cream cheese (it came with two orange slices, a nice touch) and my grand total was under $5.  Menu for lunch looks huge and interesting, so I might have to come back to sample some soup and sandwich.  The people who work here are friendly and there has been a constant stream of customers while I have been sitting here so it obviously meets the locals approval too.

Confession: Both my husband and I have been stalking the opening of this place for months. At first it was a general quest for what type of business would open, then when it was known to be a restaurant the excitement grew, once we heard it was a wine bar/small plates stalking went into overdrive (including google searches and daily walk bys). 

Ever since i've lived in this neighborhood, which is only about a year and a half, I have been complaining that there's just nothing exciting way up here to give my friends a reason to visit. Also, the only place to stop in and have some wine and apps/small plates is Sip, which is teensy weensy. 

Those days have changed, well maybe in one small instance. Vareli lives up to the hype aesthetically and size-wise. It's a fairly large restaurant, encompassing two floors: the downstairs a mix of the bar and hightops (around barrels) as well as seats for meals, the upstairs another bar and more dinner seating, plus a small outside area with standing room only. It's very pretty, definitely old-world Mediterranean style decor. This is a place you can come for date night meals or just for a glass of wine with the girls, and i'm looking forward to both. 

During grand opening night we had dinner, the menu while not completely generic was not out of the scope of  Mediterranean menu regulars. The chefs here aren't trying to reinvent the wheel or get a Michelin star, but still deliver on good upscale(ish?) food. There's a mix of cheese plates, meat plates, small plates, salads, burgers (which look amazing staring at the table next to us) and entrees. Something for every occasion while they figure out their niche. 

The two of us split the mussels, cauliflower, tuna tartar small plates, the mahi mahi entree and the chocolate mousse dessert. Nothing blew us away or was exceptional to speak of, but all were pleasant and certainly worth a recommendation to others. 

the wine list on the menu was fairly small and didn't have bottles, i'm wondering if there was a stronger list floating around. The draft and beer list was fine as well. I'd love to see this restaurant flesh out a nice strong beer list both in size and scope (as i'm told the owners come from the westside market at 110th and they themselves have a decent beer selection) and wine list. 

Perhaps if this was a different neighborhood the review would be more same old, same old, however in this neighborhood it's a different landscape and therefore a much stronger appreciation and star rating. I'm happy to welcome Vareli with open arms and looking forward to my return visit. probably next week...
My favorite teriyaki on the go.   This one is a walk up, with seating outside.  I love the mini bowls with chicken and beef, and there veggies are killer.   I wish they had one in Phoenix!

The price in unbeatable in the area and it's very convenient  if you are visiting someone in the UCLA medical center or college. The rooms are clean but pretty basic. for the price you get a lot of amenities such as free secured parking, wifi, computer center, work out room, play room with wii's, community kitchens, basic free continental breakfast, and a library.  The front desk people seemed very nice. coffee is available downstairs very late, maybe all night. it's Seattle's best and seemed pretty good to me.

... EDC... oh how i love thee... not many parties or events would I say is a perfect 5 but.. .this was just an amazing weekend of fun festive memories!! It was very well organized even with the chaotic crowds at time, it was well planned ... parking was a breeze ... the entrance to VIP I would say needs to improve... it's worst the TSA at LAX.. but still beats the general admission line.  The line up was superb... wouldnt have mind if it was louder! Just pay the fines if the neighbors complain I say.  My friends were spread out in Section 22 so it was good it was in one area! I would say this is one party worth flying into town for... words can't describe seeing the tens of thousands of people dancing to the beats of the night. The fireworks were killer and overall the whole event was just EPIC.  Definitely have to agree this has rekindle the thirst for raves!! ... i mean.. massive outdoor musical festivals :)

The best Starbucks in SLO. The barista's are so sweet here, and quickly learn your drink if you're a regular like myself! Depending on when you go determines how long the line will be, but a yummy latte is worth the wait.
Great music venue & the gentleman in the ticket booth was super friendly.

I am kind of freaking out. 

It appears as though someone was reading my mind without me knowing! 

I mean how else could anyone know that my 3 favorite things in life are GOOD coffee, french macarons and tart frozen yogurt??? 

Well whoever taped into my brain I thank you for creating Lab. 

Lab is my happy place. They have amazing fresh pour over drip coffee, fabulous cold brewed iced coffee and delicous Intelligentsia espresso. 

That not good enough for you? Ok...they also have self serve tart frozen yogurt available in rotating flavors. 

Still not happy? fine. To top everything else off they serve a ton of local pastries including the marvelous macarons from Cecilia's Pastries*. I have yet to have a good macaron in Michigan until I took a bite of one of these. The buttercream was perfection and the cookie portion had that small crunch that a macaron should have while still being chewy. ahhhhhh. finally a good macaron in Michigan!

Lab does coffee very well. I just had an iced coffee when I went. I get an iced coffee basically every day. I am going to be honest with you. This was probably the best iced coffee I have EVER had. I am pretty sure a HUGE smile sprung acorss my face the second I took a sip. I mean...I had the coffee 3 days ago and I still can't stop thinking about it!!

So why not 5 stars? First of all its kind of a sterile unwelcoming environment. I get that is what they are going for...but it is still not very welcoming or comfy. I wouldn't want to hang out there for any long stretch of time.

Secondly...I really wish the milk was sourced locally and was organic. I mean they have SOOOOO many local things there. Even their sweetener for the coffee was labeled as being bought locally. Why not take it one step further and serve local/organic milk. 

Even with those 2 small "problems" that does not deter from the fact that Lab is sheer bliss to me.

Bottom line...I live 45 minutes away from Lab and I am currently trying to formulate a reason why I have to drive back up there. I need some more Lab in my life and I need it now.

Oh happy place. I am so glad I found you. I shall see you again soon.
---------------------------------
*Cecilia's Pastries: http://www.yelp.com/biz/cecilias-pastries-ann-arbor

This place, wow. 

The food is extremely overpriced. And there is a bullshit gratuity for parties of two or more. WHAT THE FEEZY RIGHT????? This place is such bullshit. Stay away at all costs.

I have been trying for ages to get to this place, you'd think that it was in another state...but sadly, for us people with toddlers, it might as well be...I was FINALLY able to meet a friend for lunch after a business trip, and was so excited to be "a hipster", even if it was only for a couple hours (and only in my mouth, sadly my business attire gave me away). 

Started lunch with a Moscow Mule - now that's how you start a Friday Lunch! Super delicious and wickedly potent, it was exactly what I needed to bring myself down from my hectic traveling schedule...so much so that I had two - and then had to walk around Harvard Square for two hours before I was capable of driving home :) 

Had the egg salad sandwich special, with sardines. I know I lost half the crowd, but for the other half - it was yummy. Very comforting yet sophisticated all at the same time. 

We ended the meal with a shared gingerbread cake with butter cream frosting and it was the perfect way to end the meal, great flavor, not to sweet and left a nice taste in the mouth. 

Can't wait to try RHT for dinner, that is when my children are capable of watching themselves!
Cute little store with funky clothes, tights, and socks.  Seems reasonably priced.  Nice staff.  Kind of hard to find when you walk into the building, but it's to your right as you walk up the ramp.

Free Internet with wireless. Nice Pool, and Nice location.  Interior patio with Wall fountain good to sit and drink. Pool open 6 to 22. Fitness center open 24 hrs. Good location a mile east of Claremont downtown. Nice area with lost of old houses and trees. In hotel restaurant (2). But next door is a Bucca Di Beppo, and a Trader Joe's.  Flat TV. Refrigerator but no Microwave. GE discount US$98. Good for Family although rooms are not suites.
Mind blowing al pastor mulitas. Staff is super nice. If I'm in the area again and have a broham with me that hasn't been there, no doubt we will stop there and handle business.

I've used Dr Greenberg's services for  the past 6 years and couldn't be more pleased.  Her office staff is friendly and helpful, Dr. Greenberg herself is really great to work with.

She's very professional but personable.  She takes time to listen to what I want ask and answer questions and provides thoughtful advice on options that will best help me to achieve my desired outcomes.

She offers a few  products for sale in her office and even has her own skincare products for sale.  Her products are great and very reasonably priced!

I feel very comfortable recommending Dr. Greenberg to any of my friends who are interested in  the services she offers.

Wednesday night is karaoke night here, and it's a blast.  Bunches of tanked 20-30 somethings singing anything from Sonny & Cher to Whitesnake.  They have a great beer selection, but good luck getting one, the service leaves something to be desired.  The guy who runs karaoke is a riot.  He takes pictures of people looking ridiculous while they're singing then posts them on the big screen.

I agree with Shannon T. and James P. I took come from the northeast (CT originally, home to the great New Haven apizzas), and have lived a few years in NYC.  Moving to the Midwest was extremely disappointing in terms of the pizza.  Great deep dish, because that's the Midwest thing, but cannot seem to do a REAL thin crust to save their lives.  I have no idea   why.  I quested all summer all over Chicago to find good thin crust.  So many places advertise "NY style" pizza.  For whatever reason, though, they cannot seem to get the crust right, and really, it's all about the right crust, and not too much sauce.  Suffice to say, I have yet to find good thin crust in Chicago. So, then I moved to A2. I continued my quest.  Literally, the first place I tried was NYPD.  I just wanted to walk up to a joint and order a slice (something that is apparently also not done often in the Midwest... those damn deep dish pizzas take so long to make, and you can't even hold it with your hands!) Whenever I try new pizza I find you've got to start with the plain cheese to make the proper comparison to other pizza places.  So I ordered a slice of plain cheese.  It was delish! Good, thin crust (you're supposed to be able to fold it in half and eat it), great cheese, and not too much sauce.  The crust isn't completely perfect, but at least they got the idea, and it definitely would pass for good pizza back home.  

The other thing I like about the place are the people who run it.  I believe it's a family run business (at least it seems that way, right down to the little old Italian woman who takes orders on a busy Saturday after the football game).  According to the website the originators came from Italy and spent time working in the biz in NYC prior to the family expanding and spreading to A2.  It's no wonder they know how to actually do a NY style pizza, legitimately.  

I noticed several Yelpers claimed the place to be pricey.  Something I've found about a lot of reviews of places around here is that I can't trust native Midwesterners comments' about prices.  Coming from the Northeast my conception of what is "pricey" appears to be pretty different from Midwesterners' conception of what "pricey" is.  I do not think NYPD is pricey at all.  I think it's quite fairly priced, actually.  Right before moving to A2 I moved from Boston (another place that struggles with pizza) and what they charge for a large cheese I would consider pricey compared even to what you pay for a large cheese in CT or NY. 

So, bottom line. Good pizza. Good people. Good prices. Done.

Food, blah.  Pierogi with chipotle butter app was terrible- frozen Mrs. T's pierogi in PITTSBURGH is just lazy, and they were drowning in greasy, room temp aforementioned butter which carried heat with absolutely no flavor.  Everything else was of unremarkable to poor quality. Main courses were a cuban sandwich and something I don't recall (bad sign) and were extremely disappointing.

Service, argh.  It was late, but if you're open you're open, right?  Slow, inattentive, wrong sides (which we couldn't correct given the service) an they basically vacuumed around our feet.

The man and I stumbled upon this place while in SLO for work. With a name like Taco de Mexico, we figured it must be authentic.... and after seeing the look on the cashier's face when I insisted that yes, this gringa, wanted her salsa 'hot', I knew it must be very authentic... and it was. And yes the salsa was hot, but perfect!  We have been back to this place at least once on every SLO visit.
And don't let me forget to tell you that there is beer available for purchase, also.
Love, love, love this place!

Summed up: This is a modern mid-priced restaurant with a robust drink selection and trendy American cuisine. 

Overall, it is a pleasant place to grab a drink and snack. I went here with my husband and  a friend and had a flatbread pizza and grilled asparagus. The other two had bacon cheese burgers with grilled potatoes and a spicy ketchup. The food was tasty, not amazing, but very tasty.

If you're looking for a quiet or cozy restaurant, there are definitely better choices. The 'modern' in my initial sentence refers to the attractive clean lines and cushion-free, IKEA-like chairs. The lack of fabric made the acoustics fine for a night out with friends, but tough for an intimate date or gathering.

One big plus? They have several nice high-top tables in the center of the room, which would be good for groups.

I just got my haircut over the weekend by Kaytee.  She is super friendly and sweet.  But more importantly, she listened to what I wanted, clearly told me what she planned to do to my hair to address my needs and lastly did a great job on my hair.  In case you are curious, I had crazy split ends in uneven spots and asked Kaytee to fix the hot mess as well as give me a more contemporary cut that required little maintenance.  She not only was up for the challenge but also offered complimentary maintenance on my layers, if they got too heavy.  Also call me antisocial but I kind of dread the chatting when I'm getting a haircut...but Katyee was rather easy to talk to and there were times when we weren't talking and I didn't really feel uncomfortable.  Pretty awesome, right?

Agree with the reviewer that said the staff is very attractive but they do put you at ease, which is much appreciated.  I hate being uncomfortable in a place that is supposed to beautify me.  

The only reason it's 4 stars is because as much as I appreciate the ambiance, the convenient free parking and the comfort of knowing my hair was in good hands, I still have a hard time justifying spending *that* much on a haircut.  The cuts start at $75 for women.  I didn't ask but I also wasn't told how much a cut would be with Katyee...it ended up being $85.    And to be clear 4 stars is a great rating - it's "Yay! I'm a fan."  If I gave it 5 stars ("Woo hoo! As good as it gets!") then the cuts would be just a tad less....and actually, I bet you'd get more frequency at a little lower rate.  However, since Kaytee offered complimentary maintenance in between, I think she gets 5 stars...ack, I'm so indecisive tonight!!!

A lot of students from the Berkeley campus eat here since it's across the street. The curries are decent. I like the mushroom curry. The naan is made fresh and it's oh so good. The drinks are self served. Thus, you can have as many servings of milk tea as you want.

Tealuxe = Battle Wounds 

Lemme splain.

I was laughing all jolly-like sipping on my chocolate chai, when I tried to get up from my chair to grab a napkin. Bad idea. The incredibly lightweight chair (did mites eat its insides?) fell over with my coat, messenger bag, and me. Pretty much spread eagle. I jumped up Mary Catherine Gallagher style and made sure the whole store knew that  I fine. Although I know from the breeze I felt on my upper thigh that the people sitting in the front and probably a few passers-by got a glimpse of my ladybug underwear (good luck my ass.. err..). I glanced down at my legs and there was a huge gash starting at my knee and going to my upper thigh. Did I flail uncontrollably on the way down and Wolverine myself? WTF? Embarassed to tell my friend I had just been maimed by my chair.. or worse yet.. MYSELF... I concealed the wound and went home. Sometimes it hurts when it rains. 

Haven't been back. Not mainly because of that, but because the last few times I went, their chocolate chai wasn't right. It was having trouble getting married and melding with the ice. Boo. Otherwise, I'm not too much of a tea snob to truly judge this place. Pending a lesson, I'll give you my opinion on their choices.

I just got back from this place this morning and I'm stuffed in the best way possible!

So here's the lowdown...I got the Low fat omelette with fruit and wheat toast.  My friend got the breakfast trio with the Blntz, Potato Pancake, and the Challah French Toast.  Everything was awesome!

I've been trying to eat healthy and this was so delicious!! You couldn't even tell that it used egg whites only because it had so many awesome veggies on top, plus some crumbled feta cheese, which made the omlette!  Even for people who don't like egg white omelettes...try this!!
To stay on the healthy route, I got the fruit bowl, which the usual good blend of fruits.  The toast was good and the waitress was nice enough to bring me some peanut butter on the side so I can top my toast.  And even if you want to go the less healthier route, I've also tried their California Tex-Mex Omelette thing, and that is bomb as well!

As for my friends food...the cheese blings was AWESOME!!! Sooooo good and creamy and gooey!  And the French toast you can totally tell that they made the bread in house.  

It was the perfect place to come for an early morning breakfast with friends before you get your day started.  It's in a really convenient location and reasonably priced!  They even kind of have a breakfast happy hour thing I think...they had 2 pieces of the Challah French toast with something else (I forgot) for only $4.95.

Next time, we're gonna go back for the dessert case...it looked bomb!  So many good choices!  See you next time...
Wonderful selection, but was able to narrow it down ("these earrings are exactly what I've been looking for!") in about 5 minutes.  The salespeople were very nice too.

Dr. Hooghoogi yanked my wisdom teeth about a year ago, and he made the whole ordeal very pleasant. From day one he was very straight forward and very good with followup. And his staff is SUPERB. I love those girls! From what I remember they were all Fiipino and I got that first-class Filipino hospitality.

They knocked me out with the gas and it was the best thing since... well since a rave in the 90s. Then the drugs... oh bless thee who invented vicodin. The teeth were removed on a Thursday night. I was back to work on Monday morning, even able to present/speak at a meeting. 

Have you ever heard of anyone talk about their teeth getting pulled and enjoying it?

I eat here once and it burns down in a fire the very next day.  My hunt for good burgers in Waterloo/Kitchener/Guelph continues...  *sigh*

(Seriously, I hope they rebuild.  I want to go back.)

If you like your pizza made on matzoh, then this is the place for you.  If you don't like your pizza on a dry, dusty, yeastless cracker.... then I suggest you go somewhere else.

We tried one of each of their 5 pizzas and among the six of us, this was a unanimous conclusion.

For those who are wondering, The Spot replaced Robeks.  I think it was for the better.

I particularly enjoyed the Amazon Acai and my gf is fond of their Kiley Kuai smoothies.

Service is a hit or miss.  There is one girl who has a slight attitude problem.  She's the shorter one.  The rest are very laidback and helpful.

The owners recognize the importance of return business and will sometimes hand out coupons for B1G1 so keep an eye out for those. 

Unfortunately, I've had to deal with the shorter cashier for the majority of my experiences here, which has marred my experience.

Although I appreciate their community involvement--I've noticed lots of promotions for nearby schools--I'll be going to the Jamba on Indian Hill.

At least they greet me with a smile over there.

Great soups, good prices, fast and friendly service, and a location so close to campus - you can't go wrong. Lots of people have written about the lobster bisque, so I don't need to go into that - it's amazing. All the soups are tasty and filling, and pair very well with the Zingermans' bread that they sell in half-loaves along with the soups. I'm probably getting the names wrong, but the soups I've had and enjoyed in the past - since moving to A2 in September - were the chicken tortilla, the chicken noodle, the clam chowder, and most recently, the Bavarian potato. Not counting, of course, the times I've gotten lobster bisque on Thursdays and Fridays. Not a single bad soup. 

The owner and the staff are wonderfully friendly and serve up your orders quickly. I remember one instance when my girlfriend - who was visiting from out of town - and I came across Le Dog about 25 minutes after it had closed. She loves soups and was a little disappointed that we'd come too late to try out the place (she was about two hours away from getting on a flight back home). As we stood outside sadly reading over the signs, the window suddenly popped open. It was the owner (Jules?), and he'd heard us talking! After chatting us up and finding out it was my girlfriend's last day in Ann Arbor, he served up some soup - still every bit as fresh and tasty as those served at lunchtime - and gave us two cups of lemonade on the house! Now, I'm pretty sure this was a one-time deal (don't go wandering around Le Dog at 3PM hoping that Jules will magically appear), but it just goes to show how awesome this place is.

Dr. Bocian is AMAZING!  If only all doctors were like him.  It's such a relief to find a doctor so informative and able to provide immediate solutions to medical issues.  Ironically,  Dr.  Bocian helped me with endocrinology issues because I had an allergic reaction to my auto immune medication.  I'm extremely appreciative of everything he has done for me and only wish he could teach other doctors how to help/interact with their patient's.  A true gem!

This place makes massive burritos. Incredibly massive burritos, so if you're hungry you know where to go. In terms of how good they are, I would say they are "average" good. I wasn't blown away by anything that I've tasted here. The shredded beef and carnitas are both good, but thats it. 

btw .... I really feel you  might be wasting your money if you order the tacos. The burritos are just so much more food for the same price. 

They do have one great thing going for them, salsa. I am a big fan of good salsa, and every type I've had here have been great. I especially enjoy the habanero... quite spicy.

We have not visited Questan's in the later evening, when there is apparently a music and social scene. We often visit for dinner, in the early evening. 

The food at Questan's is terrific and the prices are reasonable. The seafood is absolutely fresh, something that is preserved in the preparation, and it is served with equally well-prepared and fresh vegetables. 

The service is polite and friendly - they have improved that in recent months. It is also attentive, surprising given that on several occasions, the restaurant was full and there was just one waitress. The owner is friendly, gracious, and often on hand. 

There is a full bar, and we would only hope for a more inventive wine selection.

The apple pie is delicious ...

I've lived in PIttsburgh most of my life and have gone to the Carnegie zillions of times. I had never been to this cafe though. When you go in on of the entrances of the Museum of Art it will be in front of the large glass window facing Forbes Ave and the fountain. You can pick up sandwiches and cold foods from the cases or order hot food at the register. Their menu very pretty diverse so its good for all ages. Its cafeteria style unless you order hot. If you order hot food they bring it to the table. Meals are under $10.

My favorite item is their salmon cake with asparagus and wild rice. It was amazing! The best I ever had.

I haven't been to a concert at World Cafe Live for a while, though that has nothing to do with the venue.  The two I have been to, Nouvelle Vague downstairs and KT Tunstall upstairs, were both good shows.  I think on the balance of it, I prefer the vibe of the upstairs venue especially when they have it as all seating downstairs.  That seems to just take away from any atmosphere.

I would love to go more but in all honesty, they just don't host that many artists that I want to go and see.  Maybe that says something about my taste (and its diversity) in music but I don't think so, I'm into some pretty varied stuff.

In terms of the place as a restaurant/bar, I am not really sold.  The happy hour drinks deals are good and there are often one or two interesting beers on tap.  The food just isn't anything to write home about.  On my visits, I haven't had any dish which made me go wow and I still fail to understand why people go mad about the eggplant fries, I thought they were pretty awful.  I have heard they have had problems keeping chefs, which may be making things difficult.

Still, it's a good place to see a show if something is on.

So, apparently, the HAG can be a great place for a UW student* to chill out in a dark room and watch a slide-show.... or in a big gym-like room and watch one of three movie-like things on screens.... but in either case, it's all FREE, and I like that price. (*It's also free for: Henry members; UW faculty, and staff with ID; High school & college students with ID; Children 13 years and under.... everyone on the first Thursday of the month.... otherwise it costs $10 for general public, $6 for seniors (62+).

I haven't really gone "oooh" or "aaah" about anything here, but they do have a variety of odd shows come through here and I'm guessing they might appeal to those who love modern art and projection screen art..... or are feeling very, very spacey. Me? I can enjoy that kind of art... but give me a choice and I'd MUCH rather look at well-done photographs, paintings, and most things that are 100+ years old.

One display that I recently enjoyed was a picture slide-show (of people/things in a city in Europe) in a dark room that only had the screen and a slightly lit-up bench. I ended up laying on the floor and enjoyed feeling like I had completely left the campus/U-District. The only disappointment was that I felt like this particular slide-show was made of just random point-and-shoot pictures that someone took without much thought while walking around the city. I don't know if it was supposed to be like that, but.... I couldn't really bring myself to be wowed by it.

From my very few experiences I don't think I would ever pay to go here, but I might come for special event nights and I'll definitely come back while it's still free.

Christina and the staff at 539 were fantastic. I met with Christina once to go over the details of my wedding. I brought our save the date and several other details with me so she could get a feel for our wedding vision.  I cannot say enough good things about her, she was incredibly helpful and her suggestions were spot on.  We had a few followup phone calls and e-mails to confirm the details. During every exchange she was professional and very fun to work with.
They did not disappoint the day of the wedding. There was beach traffic that day and the delivery driver called me twice to let me know where she was. She still arrived in plenty of time, but I thought it was a nice touch. 
The flowers were beautiful, my bouquet, the table arrangements and the flowers for the ceremony. I was blown away, they were even better than I imagined. In fact, my husbands grandfather who is an avid gardner and landscape professional, was thoroughly impressed.  The guests that were lucky enough to take the centerpieces home were thrilled and I received many compliments weeks after our wedding.
My bouquet lasted for two weeks. In fact, we took it on our mini honeymoon with us so we could enjoy it. 
To recap 539=awesome.

So now that I'm living off campus I have really begun to miss my New Deck happy hour specials! I used to come here like at least once or twice a week for happy hour and not only are the dicounts awesome but the food is great too! If you are a first timer at New Deck you have to try the loaded potato skins and buffalo wings becasue they are absolutely AMAZING! It is always crowded at happy hour but never uncomfortably so and there is almost never a wait. Living in Delco I don't get here very much any more so drink and eat plentifully and think of me while doing so!

Went there last week and again today and both times had a really delicious burger. One thing to note: last week I didn't enjoy the fries so much. Although they were hand-cut, which I really respect, they were on the soggy side. BUT! Today I went back and was happy to see that they had improved the fries considerably. They were delicious and could easily become addicting. An employee said they've been working on them to get them right and it looks like they did! They're perfect so now my "healthy" fast food meal is complete! Oh yeah...the tangy yogurt ROCKS.

I am writing an update in response to Caitlin W.'s review on 5/17 .... because the owner of Toscanini's is a man, not a woman. And the only times I've encountered him, he's been quite friendly, and offered to explain the inspiration behind newer flavors (such as the black bottom or ovaltine). And I will still go here because it's just too good to ignore after reading one person's bad experience. (And it sounds from Tony M. who reviewed on 5/19 that there's another side to Caitlin's story....)

I first tried Maoz in NYC two years ago when my vegetarian roommate encouraged us to go. I fell in love. And then when I was walking on Telegraph and noticed a sign that said Maoz was coming, I was so excited. I wonder what made them choose Berkeley for their West Coast debut. But whatever; it's here and people love it. I don't think the falafel is that particularly amazing (Sunrise Deli beats it by a long shot!) but I think the whole idea of a custom made pita with a bunch of toppings is appealing. 

Beware though - it sounds healthy at first but if you get the large pita with the eggplant and hummus combo (with a LOT of amazing Belgian fries), you will undoubtedly suffer from a food coma. I suggest the half pita with no eggplant and hummus and only fries if you're feeling in the mood to splurge. And if you really want to splurge - dip the fries in their mayonnaise (the true Belgian way). It doesn't taste like regular mayo; it has a slight kick to it and is not a gross texture like the mayo you buy from a grocery store. 

The salad bar is also really good - although if you are taking your falafel to go, you cant really add more toppings after you get through the first few bites. I really like the cole slaw topping, the cucumber and tomato mixture, and the roasted peppers. The tahini sauce is also a must!

Overall, this place is tasty, has good service, is very clean (the salad bar is wiped and replenished so often you feel like you are the first one to take from it), and is affordable. A good addition to the Telegraph slump.

This is a great cafe with delicious paninis and salads.  The funghi panini is an excellent vegetarian option, and the insalata with pollo and orzo is a filling and refreshing salad with tender orzo and nicely seasoned chicken in a sundried tomato dressing.  The margherita pizza is pretty good, as well, with a nice, crispy thin crust.  Stop by for a quick but gourmet-tasting lunch.  Service isn't all that wonderful and almost brusque but it's not like I usually have time to squander over lunch anyway.  Besides, the food compensates for that somewhat.

I came here for a late lunch. 

service:
Though, there were few people in the restaurant, I had to flag my server each time I wanted something after I was first seated. 

food:
They have no lunch buffet, which is a minus in my book for an Indian restaurant. They have a "cheap/student menu" which included decent size portions but is not nearly the value of a buffet.
I ordered the chicken tikki sandwich at the waitress's recommendation. 
The naan was excellent. tandoor chicken was also great. The sandwich is decent sized as well. Maybe its just me, but I thought the curry sauce was slightly odd in flavor and didn't mix too well with the lettuce and other veggies in the sandwich. I asked for some of their chutneys to finish the naan off with and was disappointed. The "green one" was too minty and lumpy with a slightly sour taste-I suspect it was going bad. I wasn't brought any others (most Indian places usually bring 2 or 3). I decided to try some kheer (rice pudding) to test an additional dish. This had a "lemony" flavor- evidence that it too had gone bad. I should have complained and asked for it to be taken off my bill but I was studying for a test and in a hurry so I chose not to finish it and just pay and leave. Again this is my own fault for paying full price, but I write this for future customs to be aware of. The waitress didn't seem to notice I had hardly eaten any of the rice pudding and didn't ask if there was a problem. I don't expect this from this type of restaurant, although considering she wasn't busy noticing this would have helped gain points for exceptional service. I'm not sure I would have even been able to have this conversation anyways, I had difficulty even asking her for the sauces (language barrier?)

overall: 
any time food has gone bad is a minus in my book. some of the other food was great, but without buffet or great deals I wont be going back, despite the fact that its a block from class. I'll make the trek north to any of the other better places on Roosevelt.

This place is not cool.  I went on a Sunday afternoon and here is the top 10 list:

1. Not cool for making me wait to park in this tiny little parking lot with no open spaces on 24th street.
2. Not cool for being over crowded with people waiting for their drinks.
3. Not cool for making me wade through the annoying three ring binder of funny drink names.
4. Not cool for asking me to pay $4.50 for a small sized drink and then having a tip jar on the counter.
5. Not cool for making me wait for over 15 minutes on a single milk tea drink.
6. Not cool for serving drinks to the four people who came in after me before serving me.
7. Not cool for having multiple security cameras pointed around the store as if someone would really want to steal this junk.
8. Not cool for having a sign saying "no pictures" as if someone would feel the need to take photos in this shop.
9. Not cool for trying too hard to be cool by stocking the shelves with a variety of trinkets.
10. Not cool (TOTALLY NOT COOL) for serving me a drink in a small cup with 75% of the volume consisting of ice.

Please avoid this place.  If you are looking for pearl tea, go to Coco's on the drag.  It is a much better drink and you won't have to deal with all of the pretentiousness.  If you are looking for fun toys, go to Toy Joy on the drag.  Don't say I didn't warn you.

I love this place! The fresh brewed coffee is always good, but the real reason to come here is for the cookies. They're the most delicious cookies ever and this is coming from someone who will travel far and wide for a good dessert. I've had the chance to try the chocolate chip, oatmeal, oatmeal applesauce, peanut butter, and vegan banana chocolate chip cookies and they are all delicious. They're slightly crisp on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside...just the way I like them.

B.K. is last place of all the fast food chains in my book. The only item I like is the well-spiced Chicken Fries. The chicken sandwich is very dry and smothered with mayo, and the fish burger has given me the wonderful gift of diarrhea the only 2 times i dared to try it in the last 15 yrs. Pity another eatery isn't in its place because it is the closest and most convenient place to walk to from the UCLA Medical Center.

great new remodel, wonderful equipment (though it's broken a fair amount). confusing staff loitering around for no apparent reason. some jagoff patrons, but what do you want. The price is excessive for Pittsburgh, but they do have sauna facilities that other places lack. The locker rooms are pretty clean but the steam room, showers and whirlpool need to be cleaned as they often smell bad.

I love this place and always go here when I am in SLO. 

I always get the shredded bbq sandwich :: can't beat it.

I have Top Dog cravings. 
I've been going to Top Dog since I was a kid--my parents introduced me to the one in montclair (which is no longer there) and I always look forward to going there for lunch when I'm in the area. There's nothing like their hot dogs :) 

I LOVE TOP DOG!

As a transferring Cal student, I like to check out the eateries in the area to prepare myself for school.  Me and my cousin came here since she was craving Thai food at the time.  This place is hidden in the back of Durant square.

We ordered some safe bets with Pad Thai and fried Gyoza.  Both of them were tasty but nothing really that sets it apart from the rest of the Thai places I've eaten at.  Perhaps I have to try something else to see if anything perks my taste buds.

#Pasadena. Sometimes you're so lazy on a Sunday afternoon that mediocre Mexican is what it's all about. Such was this rain-drenched Spring Sunday, and Wahoo pulled through, with overly salty rice and beans, and _chewy_ steak bits. Satisfied and full now. Looking forward to the next time I'm that hungry again (sort of).

I live in the area, and while I may not go here.. UCLA has a great impact on Los Angeles, so I'm a fan! I've met tons of students of all ages who go here, and they're all some of the most motivated, friendly people I've ever come into contact with. If there's one place I'd like to go for graduate school, this is it!

Their playhouse, student organizations, and medical facility all spread the school's impact out across Los Angeles, and I can comfortably say that this school is truly at the heart of Los Angeles! :)

Um. I'm not going to review this place at length because it's a second-hand store! Instead I'm going to tell you that I got a super cute, bouncy, flowing Free People skirt for $12, an almost new pair of William Rast jeans for $30 (love them), and a pair of Nick & Mo retro shorts for $15! I thought they were all wonderful pieces that I would have fallen in love with at any store, but was incredibly delighted that they were so cheap! I love, love, loved that there were so many premium brands and the selection for jeans was very exciting!! Already one of my favorite stores! :)
I have been eating at this place for a few years.  I love the mini chicken veggie bowl w/ white meat.  It is packed to the lid!  I come here because the food is pretty healthy.  The hot sauce rocks!

Breakfast is much better than lunch or dinner.  Thin pancakes are excellent. Burgers are as good as In&Out, but at twice the price.  Not what I would call a neighborhood gem, but good enough to grab some quick eats.

It's Ave Food. 

Standard Teriyaki. Don't order the Kim Chi Jjigae - it's disgusting. The rabokki is good although I don't believe it's on the menu so you have to ask for it.

Food overall is pretty standard and average. I'll eat there if I'm really busy so I don't care about what I'm eating, and I want two meals for the price of once. I also go when my gf bugs me because she loves the seafood kimchi fried rice, which is decent.

The interior of the place is a lot bigger than what I had imagined. I ordered the double double, disco fries, the onion straws, and shrimp blah blah and everything was deffffffinitey tasty. Pleasantly surprised and the beeeer!!! Def was absolutely delish and satisfying! All the five guys comments shouldnt throw you off one bit ... I'd say that in the area, Mel's has what it takes to hold its ground.

I don't know about cupcakes... I just don't know what the big deal is. Maybe I'm just not the cupcake type but thought I'd try Sprinkles since it's like the talk of the town right now and that maybe, just maybe, it would convert me from cupcake agnosticism. 
I will admit that it was pretty good, although a little sweet it was probably the best I've had, I do know it was definitely the cutest looking ones I ever had!
beautiful small desserts, reasonable prices, sufficient staff for the long line of people.  heard their coffee and croissants are heavenly, but haven't tried them yet.

I guess this program would get a better rating from me if ALL classes I was interested in taking were not canceled. I chose MIT's MEP over this.
Oh, the staff was helpful, but when they looked at me, they kept asking if I have a bachelor's degree from legitimate school. What the hell does legitimate school mean by the way? I may look like a teenage kid with jeans and t-shirt, but that's not the attitude they should bring out to someone. I can even teach most those classes I was going to take.

The food is very good and I liked that they put an interesting spin on traditional diner food. The best part is probably checking out all the crazy crap they have all over the place. Those are the positives. The reason this got only 3 stars is because the service stunk on ice. We were told it would be about a 20 minute wait, it ended up being about 30. Our coffee/juice order came pretty quick but good god did it take a long time to get our food. It was just two of us and it took about another 30 minutes to get our food. Eggs, toast, a pancake? 30 minutes? Sure they were busy but that just doesn't work for me when I want to eat! Plus I'm from NJ, the land of diners. We would have eaten, paid, and left by the time we got our food. That annoyed me. 

Overall, absolutely go for good food and an interesting take on the menu, just don't go starving during what I guess would be peak times?
So, this actually is the best place ever. The staff is so friendly and the product is worth the slightly-high price tag. This is one fad that I'm glad is actually quality.

When I first saw T-Shirt Orgy, I thought to myself t-shirt heaven, and that was what I saw when I first entered this store. The store is filled with all kind of t-shirts, but I think they would push more sales if they did a buy 2 get 1 free promotion of some sort. Paying $18+ for a t-shirt is pretty expensive if you buy a few, but this place is pretty awesome.

In order to see shows at Local 506, you have to be a member (it's less than $5 though). The venue hosts local bands from the Triangle area, and that's about it. The space is relatively small and the stage is hard to see, so I only come to see my friends' bands when they play here. Otherwise, I tend to stay away from Local 506.

Three questions:

1. Is this place sanitary???
2. Burger was borderline inedible. This isn't really a burger place is it?
3. What's with the awkward belly dancer on a sunday morning?

Hit or miss. I've eaten here 4 times and the food has either been fantastic or particularly amateurish and tasting as though it came out of a giant metal tray under a warmer. Once, my husband ordered a "pot pie" which was inexplicably served in a bowl, with a spoon and without any kind of crust (it wasn't a pie). The service is always friendly but usually poor. 

I do love the cookbooks though and have had some fantastic meals there. A great place to take your mother.

I love to read. I read  all the time. I am  a Reading Specialist!!I love cats.Why a 2? It is shoddy. The books are in disarray always! The carpet is ancient.. I have been coming there a long time - have they vaccuumed in 15 years?

I get along with the cats - sort of - crochety old things.. leave them alone! they want to sleep - not get petted.

One staff is really curt. I avoid asking questions or dialoguing any more. I am sad to see this degeneration.

I think I was being a little too hard on this b. good.  They seem to have all of their food together at this point.  It comes out quickly, so I can grab a bite and head off on my way to important meetings.  On top of that, it's as consistent as the other locations, in particular its two Boston brethren.   While the fries aren't the greatest fries, at least they're healthier than normal french fries, something I'm all for.

In comparison to other area eats, it's healthier, and at least somewhat compares on the taste scale.

For anyone who had Border Cafe as his or her first Mexican experience, I don't blame you for avoiding Latin food.  In a word, this place is disgusting.  Maybe Border Cafe suffices as Tex-Mex in the strip malls of Middle America, where no one has been outside their home state, but it has no place in a thriving collegetown with students from all over the world.  However, if you must serve plastic cheese and dog-food quality meat, can you at least make it taste okay?  Border Cafe pales in comparison to Taco Bell.

Anyone considering walking in should turn around and head straight to Felipe's, Chipotle, or even CVS for a frozen burrito.

Hands down, this was the best meal I've ever had.

I've been wanting to eat here since before I moved to NC. When I decided to move here and started researching the area, this place came up and has been on my list of places to try for the past 2 and a half years. It's a special occasion only place, but fiance and I decided to finally celebrate our engagement and went here for dinner.

The atmosphere is nice, service was friendly, if slightly over-attentive, but I'd prefer that to bad service any day. The atmosphere was somehow relaxed and romantic at the same time. I love the decor.

We had the okra and a scallop sashimi dish for appetizers. For entrees, I ordered the special Korean Fried Chicken with potato salad, Peter got the pork lettuce wraps. Dessert, I got the figs with creme fraiche ice cream, Peter got the hot chocolate cake with hazelnut ice cream. Finally, for drinks I got the Late Blossom and he got the Dark and Stormy. With the exception of my cocktail, I've order everything again. The fried chicken was especially delicious. I'm notoriously picky about chicken, I do pretty much boneless skinless breasts. I ate this off the bone, no problem. No weird bits, nothing gross, just amazingly tender and flavorful meat. The batter and spice were divine.I'll have dreams about this chicken. My cocktail was good enough, but nothing about it stood out to me. It was mildly sweet. I couldn't even say it tasted like anything in particular.

I'll be back and as soon as possible too. Maybe for my birthday in November...

After having sushi in Koreatown, this place just bombs. it's good when you're hungry and don't want to go too far from campus, and i will come here often. 
I do like the udon, it's sweet and slightly spicy. 
However, the staff just looks depressed. 
The sushi was infinitely better than the sushi on campus and that in the UV on jefferson. 
It's not the best, but for a broke college student, I appreciate it.

So having just started the new job yesterday I still havent gotten all my ducks in a row to start bringing my lunch.

So while I am doing that I intend to test the waters out in the Price Center. Its only a three to five minute walk from the workplace so its extremely convenient.

I tried this place today because the line for Subway was a million long and I couldnt decide whether or not I really wanted a quesadilla from Rubios.

Enter Tacone.

None of their custom wraps appealed to me because Im typically hesitant to try anything too weird so I ordered a chicken caesar wrap sans tomatoes.

It was good. i wish my chicken had been hot and had more dressing but hey, whatever. Im working towards being less food picky.

They had 'cafe chips' aka 'homemade chips' so I was pretty thrilled about that.

The cashier kept repeating some weird non-English phrase while I was there. I couldnt quite figure it out. POtentially because the only language I speak is English.

Maybe he was putting a hex on my lunch? Who knows. I guess we will find out if I wake up a chicken tomorrow.

Just say No!  I saw Dr. Rothman a few weeks back, she was very demeaning!  She just disregarded everything, laughed at my comments and concerns, TALKED DOWN TO ME and prescribed a prescription that had no positive effect whatsoever, in fact, it made it worse!  Very belittling!!!!  Do NOT see Dr. Rothman!

I've since been here a few times and the experiences just keep getting better. The 2nd floor is even nicer than the 1st - I don't often marvel at the interior design of restaurants but this is really tasteful and cool design. I've had a few different meals here, all top notch, especially the burgers and steaks - crazy juicy and flavorful. 

Without a doubt the best restaurant in Morningside Heights.

For the many negative reviews posted on this site about this place, it is understandable about how the people who work in this place behave towards their customers. Anyone who works in the restaurant industry needs to have this place investigated for how they cook their food and treat their cusomters, or be on the look out to stay away. The huge problem of course is dealing with making people tip. This is not something they understand very well because there is no law that requires tipping, but they seem to think that. The service with their attitude is horrible as well. 

I ate there a few times and always ordered the same dish, well as time went on they kept changing what went in the dish and when I would ask for the original items in the dish, they would deny ever having put them in there. I was surprised by that reaction. It was that only dish that kept me going back because it was so good, but it was the waitresses and owner that has kept me away, because they would always push about not tipping. The first times I did, but after they got sloppy on their service and food, I stopped, which turned into a shouting match of explaining that I don't have to tip. The lady kept hounding me about it and threated to add on a service charge of 15% for not tipping. I warned her if that if I saw it on my statement, she would be looking at a fine and that I would report them to the Texas Restaurant association, At which point the lady stopped talking and didn't say another word. If they give you hassle about removing a charge or reducing a price and ask for any personal IDs you should tell them no and that they should not be asking for that information in the first place. If you use a credit card, watch what amount they actually charge you because they like to add on little fees if they think you were a bad customer.

I truely believe this place needs to be investigated for their business practices. They are very rude and do not provide proper service, food, and cleanliness. If anything, get rid of the owners and bring in new people. I know that is not realistic but the food is good just not the people who run it. If there is rich business man out there who reads this, please buy up this place, get rid of the owners, shut it down, renovate the place, fix it up and then re-open so people can enjoy this place in peace, and not worrying about getting fined or taxed for asking for too much or looking at them wrong.

If nothing is done to stop how they run their place, then sooner or later it will turn into the soup naiz's place, where the owner can ban anyone at will and you can only order certain things and if you complain, you're kicked out, just like they sorta do now.

This place really needs to change. and as some people have already stated, this place doesn't even deservce one star. If this post helps keep people away from this place then it will have done its job and saved a life (lives). Besides, there are other great Thai places around austin without the attitude problem.

The salted caramels here will never be matched (the milk chocolate versions are my fave).

And I've tried.

I think it's the caramel--really smooth, buttery, and just sticky enough.  Not so much that you have a lump at the roof of your mouth, but also not so sugary that wish you hadn't popped it in your mouth.  In fact, it's a bit difficult not to pop several in a row.  

The girls who work here are super friendly, and always hand me a free chocolate to try.  Now that they're carrying Sweet Beauty items at the counter, I'm not sure that I have an interest in any other chocolate shop.

Hot Dog Charlies impressed the hell out of me. Maybe because I didn't expect much from this local chain. Or maybe because I didn't eat breakfast and was craving my first bite of food for the day. Yes, on the Tour de Hot Dog, these little suckers became my breakfast, lunch AND dinner.

Hot Dog Charlies serves up a mini wiener with its casing, yellow mustard, meat sauce and onions all on a mini bun from Bella Napoli. HD Charlies gets a few things right here. The steamed bun had some excellent chew, almost akin to some artisan loaf of bread. I also really enjoyed the dog. A light snap to the casing complete with the necessary juiciness. The dog starts to stumble as you get to the meat sauce. Much like Gus's, but nowhere near to the same extent, HD Charlies meat sauce tends to have a raw spice grit. I think this grit tends to be a common pitfall when tasting these local dogs, and any place avoiding it tends to receive high marks. 

If I was going for straight taste, I'd take Hot Dog Charlies over Gus's any day. Their fairly solid meat sauce and well prepared product are worth the extra mile or two needed to drive up rt 32.

This tops the list for when I have what I like to call the "Man Tourist" in town.

Man tourist likes engineery things, he likes ships and planes and this is just one extra feather in your cap if you bring him here.

Man Tourist could be your dad, or uncle or favorite step brother, but he will be excited by the simple grilled food if he happens to be hungry. If you did your job and took him to Man-Tourist restaurants, then he  might not be hungry yet. (I'll get to those later...)

If you are in this situation, walk him over to the tables and watch some people take off for about an hour, when he exclaims his glee in the most manly way, double intrigue him with the nude beach just over the edge.

He will be sure to follow you in a short walk as you point down to Black's Beach and the volleyball nets.
Good food.  Nice people.  Their spicy eggplant rocks my world.  Also they experiment like crazy with their food so there's always something new to try.

The Asgard is one of my favoriet pubs in Central Square. Their beer and drink selection is as diverse as it is wonderful, and the atmosphere makes me feel like I'm drinking in a spacious, medieval castle. It doesn't get much better than that, friends!

Some might describe it as an "Irish" pub, but I think it would be better described as a classy, themed pub. Also, it gets a bit of an older crowd in the evenings. I haven't had the food; I can only attest to the glories of their booze and my experiences there. One last thing that I'll add is that the bartender and hostesses were friendly and helpful.

My sentiments mirror those of the previous reviewers.  This museum is really a hidden jewel.  It's amazing more people don't know about this museum.  It's especially great because it's so darn cheap! You'll pay more for parking than you will for admission. I don't know why the city doesn't give this wonderful museum more attention.  My husband and I decided on a whim we needed some alone time and only had a few hours to do something.  We searched the web for museums in Philly and wanted to see something we had never been to before.  I'm so glad we ended up here.

Exhibits include an impressive mummy collection, Roman & Etruscan wing, and North and Meso American Indian wing, as well as smaller exhibits including Africa, the Maori and Polynesia, the Middle East, Asia, and everything in between.  

Be warned that parking is a bit of a hassle.  We had to park in Children's Hospital 3 blocks away and wind our way through the serpentine hospital to get to the museum. Stop at the hospital info desk for directions.

Salento is nowhere near my house or my job, yet I find myself driving 20 minutes out to the Village just to come here.  The BF practically lived here while attending Rice, and many a weekend was spent here working/studying/drinking... coffee for him, wine for me.  

I think their key to success is variety.  A variety of food, drink, and music draws a variety of clientele.  You'll find anyone from a soccer mom to a biker to a college student to your grandma here.  The wifi is free (technically with purchase, since the code is on the receipt, and you should buy something anyway!) and I have had no problems with Less Networks as mentioned in another review.  I am sitting in Salento as I type this, using the wifi, drinking the wine (if you can have mimosas for brunch, you can drink whenever you want), nibbling on some hummus and tapenade while the door is open to one of the few gorgeous days we get here in Houston.  

Things to note: wifi is turned off at night, there are only 2 areas where you can get an outlet, and they have live music and tango in the evenings on various days.

Fresh Side is a great place to go to get tasty food that is actually good for you.  Everyone raves about the tea rolls on review sites - and they are good, I like the spicy chicken.  They have a variety of asian salads, soups, rice and noodle dishes - all available in large and small sizes. I'd  recommend the Vietnamese salad.  Order a pot of tea, bring a book (or a friend), and you're all set.

Just got back from this place.  The only star is for the roof-deck, which is of course welcome in Cambridge.  The food all around was pretty awful, and neither of us ate more than half of our dishes.  That's not even taking into account the price ($20 entrees & $10 apps).  I didn't even particularly like the pita.  On top of that, my stomach didn't feel well after getting home.  Not sick, but ... unsettled

I know it's a chain but we were hungry and needed something still open at 10pm on Friday night. We got the pepperoni supremo and the original chopped salad and split it. With a glass of red wine, the bill still came out to like $45 which seemed pretty steep to me considering it was just CPK. The pizza wasn't the best in the world or anything, but again, it was close and open still Fri night so we ate there. The service was good and the food came out at a decent time.

Max Soha is a good joint.  I love that it is within my neighborhood.  

Positives:
- Love the sangria
- Nice warm bread with a delicious dipping sauce
- Delicious whole wheat pasta with vegetables, shredded ricotta, in an olive oil mix
- Yummy bruchetta

Negatives:
- $26 for a pitcher - should be a bit cheaper for sangria
- Cramped
- Can get crowded (after 7pm)
- Cash only

Will be visiting again since it is good on wallet and good in its taste!

Atrocious customer service! The cashier demonstrated no proper manners in communicating with me. I felt like the only thing she cared about was getting my order and moving on to the next customer. Moreover, their pricing system makes no sense. For example, I wanted to order a udon dish without seafood. The original price was $8, but even without seafood, that is, just udon, the price was still $8! To top it off, when she swung the plastic bag to me with my to-go box inside, the box tilted causing my switched order of cashew nut chicken sauce to leak. Situations like these make me reminiscent about customer service in Japan; where cashiers would delicately pass you your plastic bag of purchases and make the handle taut for you to easily grasp. Places like the Lotus House should learn about customer service from the Japanese.

This review lacks one very important ingredient: RECENT experience.

It's been several years since I have been so I cannot comment on the menu, pricing or recent service trends.

What I can comment on is the environment...which at the time I visited was most unique to any place I'd experienced in the Boston and/or Providence areas.  Cute little seating areas arranged in 2 cozy rooms on Main St.  I was attracted to the array of eclectic furnishings that created individual sitting spots where couples and small groups could cozy up with a sip of this or a pot of that and enjoy some conversation while hearing some Ella Fitzgerald.  AT THE TIME it was a great spot to enjoy an after dinner drink or late night cozy conversation.

AND it was pricey.  BUT lovely.
Cute little place with really friendly service and good Thai-ish food. Had the green curry with chicken and the salmon with creamy cilantro sauce - both tasty, fresh, and good quality. Will be back.
Your heaping stack of nachos saves you.  Ok, your burgers are good too.  I don't like your salads, and sometimes you get my order wrong, but you are the only thing open on campus late at night.

I just moved to Claremont a year ago, and had been going to Urban Renewal on Yale Ave to get my hair done, but after enough mediocre cuts and botched color jobs, I decided it was definitely time to move on.  I have really dark thick Asian hair and have a section of it bleached as light blond as it will go, and every time I went to UR to get my roots done, the stylist had to do it twice and ended up rushed toward the end because her next appointment would arrive. And I'd still be left with brassy roots on my platinum sections.

I made an appointment with April at Bliss after reading the glowing reviews on Yelp, and let's just say, the rumors are all true!  She was very professional, totally friendly, and gave me the best haircut ever.  (Sidenote: Don't you love when stylists give you a head massage when they wash your hair?  April does it, and does it well.)  I immediately made another appointment with her to get my color touched up, and again left extremely pleased.  No more brassy roots!

Best of all, the prices at Bliss are half of what they are at UR!  $50 for a cut (very long hair, layers, & bangs) and $80 for color retouching (it was only roots, but took at least a couple hours).  I'll still stop by UR for my B&b products, but I've found my salon-fo'-life at Bliss.
forget this place. don't come here
It's Ben & Jerry's.  In the Garage.  What are you really expecting?

Viva is the default dinner place for my household. When in doubt we go to Viva. The burritos are large, filling and delicious. The service is fast without skimping. Usually I take my food outside to the sidewalk tables.

Make no mistake, this is not Mexican food like you'll find in the southwest. Nothing compares to, say, Santa Fe. It's no San Francisco either. Given that, Viva is solid and fills the burrito craving.
Breakfast BUrrito is AWESOME! friendly service, but long wait on the weekends. Cash only is the only problem

Beware of the No Return policy at Cambridge Bicycle. I have joined Yelp to comment about this. 

About a year ago I saw a bike seat there that I was interested in. I told the salesman that if I bought it, I wanted to try it out briefly and if it was not comfortable, I would return it in its packaging, and there was no other candidate seat in the store of interest to me. The sales person assured me that I would be able to return it if necessary, so I bought it.  

When I found the seat was uncomfortable and went to return it, the manager said I could not get my money back, only get store credit. He pointed to a small sign that I recall being at about knee level on the front counter which indeed said there were no returns except for store credit. Only after I complained loudly did he finally agree to refund my money, and then said he hoped I never shopped there again. Indeed I have not.

I will say that once before I had gotten a brake cable changed quickly and properly there.

I have had pretty decent experiences picking up packages from here. Sending it has been a whole other experience. The staff that I worked with was very disinterested and not helpful at all with the questions I had about delivery. She basically just told me how much it would cost me, and would not answer any questions for my first time shipping internationally. 

I think I would have been happier with a self service kiosk, at least a computer won't give me stank attitude when I ask a question and it would probably give me more information on shipping options. This is one of the few experiences when I would not feel bad about the clerk getting "down-sized" and replaced by a kiosk. 

They get two stars, just because my pick up experiences have been decent and they have good hours.

I'm a tourist, OK, and had no clue about this place.  We three women had taken the T from Boston, and I need to find a place to pee, that was my entire motivation.  At first I thought the place was closed because I was actually in the back at the handicap entrance and it was dark.  But we discovered the door was open and walked down the hall and found the dark sort of basement area next to the bar.. and a BATHROOM, which was very clean.  My friend had hurt her foot and we were just exhausted, having spent the better part of the day wandering around Boston.  The weather was dreary and cold, and we wanted to try to just relax.  The Bartender, Brian, not only was friendly and helpful, but he brought my friend a bag of ice for her foot, and replaced a drink that I accidentally knocked over.  We hadn't really planned on eating, but we were feeling so welcomed there we ordered a Turkey Club and more drinks.  By the time we left we felt we'd found a real "Inn" in Boston.

The place decorated nice and clean. The girl who helped me was really nice. This is the first time I came to the store, only got a dozen donuts. It is 24-hour opened, I'll def come back and try their breads & pastries, those looks good too.

The donuts are tasty, the texture is a little bit different, not that puff, but in a good way, which I like it better.

Great service. Online reservations. Free parking.  Best haircut I have had in years.  
I have used Troy who is excellent.

Maison de Mode is a little bridal boutique tucked away in the middle of the Rice Village.  They sell unique European wedding dresses that you won't find anywhere else.  They are decently priced, as far as wedding dress go.  Expect to pay $800 - $2000 for a dress; they are a mid-range dress shop after all.  

The staff is amazing and some of the most helpful people I have ever met.  I got my wedding dress from them, they altered it there, were able to take it to a cleaner they do business with for me, and kept the dress in the shop until I was ready to take it home.  They even let me borrow a petty coat so I didn't have to buy it on top of everything else.  It was great to just go to one shop and not have to go anywhere else for cleaning and alterations.  

They only stock one of each dress, and while you can order one in your size if it is too small, I feel the best part is knowing that you have a dress that no one else is going to have.  No, you aren't going to show up at your wedding and see a woman wearing the same dress as you, you never are, but the benefit to this over someplace like David's Bridal is that you can get something that isn't your run of the mill, mass produced wedding dress that doesn't cost $5000+.  The fact that the staff starts to learn your name as you come in over the year before your wedding makes things very personal.

The owner of the shop also stocks and makes some of her own evening wear, mother of the bride dresses, and flower girl dresses.  If it weren't for the fact that I'm still a student and living off of student loans, I would totally be in there all the time buying dresses to wear on the town or on a cruise.  Expect the non-bridal dresses to cost about $300 - $600 dollars, and no, they aren't poofy.  I've seen a lot of girls go into the shop for a prom dress.
