I would much rather have a prom dress from here than the prom dress I had senior year that was a poof nightmare and set my mom back $500.  I still don't know why my mom bought me that dress....

I had high hopes for this place. They were not met.

While there was a long line the size of Pinks Hot Dog stand the line here actually moved. Just have fun standing in line with college students who live down the street in a one bedroom with six people.

The cookies were rock solid hard. I thought I was going to break a tooth! I prefer those Nestle Toll House Cookie sandwiches I get at my local 7-11. At least the cookies are softer.

I'm sad to report that I was hoping to go home after my delicious cookie and masturbate dreaming about Diddy Riese. Instead I went home and drank myself to sleep thinking about the 7-11 cookie I would masturbate to instead. It was a cold night.

Cheryl is a total professional. In trusting someone with a sale of a property requires confidence in an agent's abilities. When Cheryl is working for you, she focuses completely on your needs and best interests. She exudes confidence and competence. She is the very best in her profession.
Cute volleyball girls

I really like this place. Whenever I visit Providence, this place is high up on my food wishlist. Their homemade bread is great. Salads, soups, everything I've had here has been tasty. I'm also a huge fan of the dessert tray - lots to choose from and all delicious. I would describe the style of food as somewhere between rustic and gourmet. Give them a try!

Went back last night and loved seeing what had changed on the menu and what stayed the same.  I tried the beef tongue (I know, I'm brave, right??) and it was freakin' delicious.  Sooooooo damn good.  And the more I drank, the more tasty the boiled peanuts were.  Ned the bartender is totally the man, hooking us up with the best cocktails on the menu, telling us what's popular and what's new.  And you know the drinks are good when more than half your bill is for the booze.

The bar is small, but if you can snag a seat, it's a great place for a casual meal/boozefest.

the first time i've been to russell house was when i was visiting someone from harvard. we wanted to go out to eat and we came across russell house. the environment of the restaurant is very different from the restaurant in california (where i am from). there were a bunch of people crowded around the bar area and the restaurant was a bit noisy. the lighting is dim but the feel of the place is lively. great place for socializing.

all the food is tasty and the service is not bad. the one thing i suggest is the volcano lava dessert as it have drip of spice which gives an interesting flavor.

the only thing i wish for is that the restaurant is a little bit bigger so it can accommodate the amount of people there but i am from california so i'm used to open area/space.
Terrible customer service on togo orders...especially on a sunday when they open.  Rude and not worth the hassle.

Meh.  I've been here before. I tend to like the beverages pretty well, and the sandwiches aren't bad, but I've had better.  I'd favor any locale cafe over a chain.   I also feel weird when people ask me whether I want chips or apple slices. Apple slices in bags just seem a bit strange at a restaurant. Why not just give out a real apple?

I think you're better off going here to meet someone for a coffee or smoothie, rather than a full meal.
An awesome space despite recent construction. Beautiful architecture and it shines as a beacon from below and above the Morningside Heights area.
Came here while exploring princeton with my family. Loved the corned beef hash & the "mashed browns"!!! Ordered blueberry pancakes; very fluffy & delicious.

Note: Not really writing a review about this place but think of it more like an FYI kinda thing... So ignore the Starts. Cool? Here we go... 

First of all this is not a restaurant or anything like that!!! I think this is like a by-product of some cooking class or experiment in UCSD where students sell the food under a big canopy once a week. The food tastes Awesome (don't get me wrong), but it's really not a "restaurant" kind of food. 

Of course the meal is very cheap, but there is only 2/3 dishes with rice and dessert and that's all. But the biggest problem you will face is to find the location. After you park your car (which is also very hard to find... remember, this is a campus area), you will be all lost and browsing for this place unless you are with some one who already knows where it is (I'm not kidding!!!) 

I also have doubt about the hygienic part of their food (both preparation and serving). I mean, I don't think they really have any certificates from the food inspectors or something (but again, I could be wrong). 

It's cheap food and tastes awesome. But careful about your expectation about this place!!! Thanks.

Okay, I really like this place.  BAM!  I really like the decor.  Those wrestling masks on the wall is pretty cool.  I always go with friends, so that makes it even more enjoyable.  I said that because the wait staff are okay I guess, I have never had to wait long to place my order, they bring your drinks promptly and check on you from time to time.  That's it, but they don't stand out.

I am a sucker for "the same thing"  I love, love, love, love, did I say love? Their nachos!  They are great and yummy! I had a burrito and I didn't like the flavor too much.  For dessert, I get the churros.  That caramel sauce is good!  

I say, give it a try. Nice atmosphere, good food, bring some people with you and you've got good company!

One reason and one reason only this bar gets my props - Wednesday nights. They have 10 cent wings that are amazing, and dollar high life bottles. (they also have a goof fishbowl deal too).... weekdays in general at brothers are great, its easy to get a table and there are TVs all over for watching sports.

On the weekend it is a different story. This is a very narrow (but long) bar.... so it can be very hard to move around the place.... but once you find an open spot usually towards the back or upstairs its a pretty fun time. It can take a bit to get drinks because of this too...

I have never had a credit card issue like stated in the other review... and I go here all the time, but I do know a couple friends that did (this was over a year and a half ago) before they changed their credit card policy.

I was really excited about JP Licks the first few times I visited this location. The ice cream is good, the line moves fast, it's conveniently located.

After several visits, though, my favorite ice cream place is still Christina's. Although Christina's is out of the way for me, their flavors are wide in variety and high in quality. 

After a few visits to JP Licks, once Peach was no longer the flavor of the month, I found myself missing Christina's Burnt Sugar ice cream, and unable to get excited about any of the flavors here. They have significantly fewer flavors than Christina's, lots of them have nuts in them (I hate nuts), and the one that had the most promise, Cake Batter, was grainy from the grains of cake batter that hadn't dissolved. 

Alas. I will definitely still stop in here, but I wish they had more variety. Or that they had a flavor that I just couldn't do without.

I would crave for hot dogs randomly at timess...

I like all of them... chicken apple, kielbasa, hot link, calabrese, and etc.... Pretty quick service, friendly people, quick food to go...

I mostly had these wonderful hot dogs after going out though around Berkeley... or a study break if i am sick of Peet's or the DC or the Asian Ghetto..

One of the few places that are opened late!

I can never eat just one though to get full.. i need TWO :) what a pig i am!

I haven't been on yelp in probably months because i've been working on my website a lot lately and travelling...

but i felt the need to update this review
my friend, Missy told me to go here for a salad, and me, being hungover worse than I've ever been, today, thought I needed a salad to cure me.  I came here with her recommendation in mind.  It's actually pretty good and delicious for a $7 salad plus another $2 for grilled chicken.  Make sure to add salt and pepper because it definitely needs them.  I'd come back here for salads again.  I give them credit, I gave them another chance.

Went here last night for Restaurant Week with a friend.  Some thoughts:

Wines by the glass were EXTREMELY overpriced, and small for the $$.
Pate was great!  Woo hoo pate!
Choucroute was okay.  The sauerkraut lacked acidity, and the sausages looked....boiled.  Tasted pretty good, but the presentation was lacking.  Nothing stellar.  The potato was a simple red bliss - no bacon-wrapped, smoked anything.  And if the little piece of ham they gave us was a pork chop, I'm a prima ballerina.
Desserts were fine - our server recommended the praline souffle dessert, but the pear-almond option was much simpler, cleaner, and had better flavor.

Overall, it was disappointing.  I found myself walking out thinking about the price tag, rather than the meal, which is never a good sign.

After spending most of the day with my French brother in law shopping for some Texas/US made boots at all the big boot stores in Austin and finding very little that was not made in China or India, we found ourselves hungry and stopped into EL Mercado. 

I had to offer My French pal something authentic as he was pretty disappointed. I had to assure him that our meal here would not be made in China or India and would be authentic Aus/Mex fare. He enjoyed the colorful interior and casual feel of EL Mercado although the HD TV in the middle of the dining room seemed outta place. 

I had the lunch Chicken Enchiladas with Verde sauce and my bro-in-law had the 3 Beef Enchilada meal. Our server was nice and prompt with the drinks, salsa and food. Marcel enjoyed the salsa and his enchilada very much. I was really pretty impressed at how much i enjoyed the chicken enchiladas. 

So although we had to give the boot expedition the boot...the darn good lunch we had here perhaps redeemed our day in some small way.

Doesn't have to be fancy to be good. 

You order at the bar, your food comes in a plastic basket and on paper, but it is oh-so-good, cheap, and well-portioned.

I love the chicken tacos. You'd be suprised at how many places can mess up chicken tacos. The chili dog is good too. The people are chill and real, the music is underground rap or indie rock or classics, the beers available rock my face off.

I truly love frozen yogurt in all it's creamy and delicious glory. Unfortunately, Red Mango (in Austin) just did not meet my standards. The yogurt was icy, and while the flavors were creative...they did not tickle my taste buds like I expected.

Overall I was pretty disappointed. I'd more likely go to Swirll or Juicy Tart (both very close by) next time. 

I did appreciate the great customer service though and the eclectic choice of music ;) "Toot it and boot it," anyone?

I went to Elude for laser hair removal, and I had a wonderful experience. This is the nicest salon in the cutest part of Pasadena. They have friendliest staff, I felt safe and well taken care of. They'll answer any of your questions, and the nurse practitioner who performs the procedure is so sweet and gentle. 

The best part is that I saw results right away, and it was definitely worth my money. Their technology is the newest out there, I would recommend this spa to anyone.

LIVE NUDES!

No just kidding. Of course this is a nude beach, but don't let the nakedness detest you from coming. This is an absolutely serene beach. Situated off the La Jolla cliffs, it is beautiful in every way.

The coolest thing happened yesterday when my sister and I visited, was when we discovered tiny baby sand crabs burying themselves in the sand. It made certain parts of the beach look pretty awesome: a darker shade with little tiny holes in it.

When you brushed your feet across that part of the sand, you can see the tiny crabs burying themselves deeper. I guess spring time has come and its crab mating season. Later on we saw seagulls picking some of these crabs from the ground. What douches!

If you're craving thai food, but don't want to try something too terrifyingly new, Thai Basil is perfect. The food is unchallenging but tasty, and the portions are generous. The major problems are the lack of seating and a cashier that doesn't have a sense of urgency even when there are 20 hungry students waiting in line.

When I was going to UW, Solstice was pretty much a part of my daily routine.  Really good coffee, good selection of fun teas, BEER, and the best grilled cheese and tomato soup in town.  There's always interesting art on the walls and good music playing.  It's a noisy place to be for real hardcore studying, but good for socializing.  I really like most of the staff there, but must admit there have been a couple employees there in the past couple years that seem unfriendly and give out the "holier than though" vibe.  With that said, I hold nothing against them, I still love Solstice.

Sigh.  Just thinking about this place and everything it has going for it makes me sigh.  Nestled away in a world-class metropolitan region.  Pristine campus.  (People say it looks like a giant taco bell.  I see nothing wrong with a giant taco bell.)  Perfect weather.  Fun, smart, laid-back people.  When I visited, I just knew that this was going to be the perfect setting for the best four years of my life.

So if everything was so perfect (except for the quarter system, but I'd be willing to over look that), then why only one star?

Bitter grapes, you say?

OH YOU'D BETTER BELIEVE IT!!!!!!!!

*sniff sniff*  This was the only school I really wanted to go to and the only one that I got rejected from.  So instead of spending four years as a happy Stanford student in the sunshine, being the yuppie that I've always dreamed of being by going to downtown Palo Alto and hanging out at trendy coffee shops, I froze my ass off at a middle of nowhere B-rate Ivy League school which sucked every ounce of pride and ambition out of me that I ever had.  And for what?  NOTHING!!!!!  Nobody in California takes Dartmouth seriously because it's not 'local,' so now I'm working for Starbucks!!!  AAARGH!!!  I have every right to be bitter, goddamnit!!!!  Screw you Stanford!!!

:'-(
Very friendly and prompt service.  Great big portions.  Food tastier than Pittsburgh's average but not very exciting.

Very cute bustling cafe in Berkeley. It's at the edge of campus so you will always find students studyig on the tables with laptops. It's a great stop before class or a great place to hang out between classes

Mmmmmm... fried goat cheese. Seriously one of my favorite things to eat, anywhere. I'm also a big fan of the piquillo stuffed peppers. Deliciously delicate and full of meat. They're awesome.

Speaking of meat, the steak is really good. It's served medium rare, but I would suggest ordering it medium. Not bad. Just a little too raw for my taste. It comes with some sort of herb sauce that is divine. That plus the homemade mayo that comes with the fries was enough to make me want to dip everything (including the roasted Brussels sprouts).

Oh, and David K. says that GiGi Says is the best cocktail in Atlanta. Fab-yoo-luss!

I'm a fan of any restaurant that can take all my loves of bad for you food like hamburgers, pizzas and decadent desserts and combine them in one large menu. BJ's of course is that place with tons of things to order and a different take on each.

With a full drink menu, including quite an impressive list of wines given that BJ's is kind of like an Applebee's or Cheesecake factory (aka. Chains), a concoction of liquor filled drinks and of course beers (to compliment the sports playing on the flat screen TVs) you'll never go thirsty here. Add to this their extensive menu of pages upon pages of different appetizers, salads, soups, pizza's and of course hamburgers.

Their pizzas are classic Chicago deep dish style and while I'm not sure I can speak with any authority on classic Chicago deep dish pizzas I found these to be rich and yummy. The crust and dough almost melted in my mouth along with the cheese (which was a little too salty for my taste and where they lost that desired last star) and tomato sauce. Their wedge french fries are large, in charge and perfectly seasoned to make you want to keep eating even when your stomach may scream to stop.

And speaking of stomach's talking, yours should most certainly ask for the pizookie dessert, a trademark of the BJ's franchise. With a huge recently cooked cookie (of the chocolate chip, oatmeal raisin, oreo or peanut butter variety--your choice) ice cream and flavorful adds on on the very top you'll be in sweet heaven, literally. So save room because this dessert is huge, meant to be shared but definitely fulfilling after only a few bites.

Go with friends after a night out, as they stay open late and enjoy what drunk eating or merely late munchies can be satisfied here.

The only time I've ever been to Cain and Abel's, it was to go get cheap beer on Tuesday nights with all the other college crowd looking for something more exciting to do then study Literature of American History.

Surprisingly for a college hangout, the place is ridiculously tame and well spirited.  The pool table rotates players without argument, the bartenders get to every one quickly and in turn, folks will always scoot over to make room if you want to sit down.  Come to think of it, my experience at C&A's is that it has all good stuff about a college bar and hangout and very little of the bad.

If this place had existed  when I was a USC student, I'm sure I would have become a beer lover much sooner.  They take their beer education mission seriously and offer a great selection of craft beers, alongside some standard lagers/ales if you're not feeling adventurous.  The Trojan Blonde and the Smoked Stone Porter were both tasty.  So was the caprese salad with heirloom tomatoes and burrata.  The burrata was creamy and fresh and paired well with buttery toasted baguette.  The best, and most surprising, addition was fig jam mixed in with the balsamic-- a great twist on the classic caprese.  

I loved that the decor really felt more like a classroom than a bar, with wide wooden tables, perfect for beer experimentation, lining the room.  Also a good spot for catching a game-- plenty of TVs gave us a great view of the Phillies/Giants NLCS champion series opener.

For years I've been a fan of the Friendly Toast in Portsmouth, NH and have visited whenever in the general area.  In fact, I have driven up to Portsmouth specifically for the Friendly Toast.  SO, I was happily surprised when I learned from a friend that a Cambridge version of an old favorite had recently opened.  

The first reviews I read of the Cambridge Friendly Toast referenced the restaurant size (small) and cost (high).  This gave me some early skepticism.  Additionally, I often find that the charm of any restaurant is a combination of the menu, atmosphere (inner and outer), and other factors that are challenging to duplicate.  With those reservations in mind, we headed to Kendall Square on a sunny Saturday afternoon.   

When we entered the restaurant I noticed the decor was definitely striving for a similar feel to the Portsmouth location, though in a forced sort of way.  Not painfully so, however.  The bar and "lounge" seating area are nice touches as we definitely had a wait when we got there.  With the timing (saturday) and perfect spring weather, we ended up waiting a good 30+ minutes for a table.  It didn't necessarily feel long, though as there was plenty of space to sit it out.  There were larger groups that seemed to have waited longer and were enjoying some interesting mixed drinks from the bar.  

Once we were finally seated, I did find the restaurant to be more spacious than I initially expected.  Others complained about the hipster servers, though you would sort of expect it with the decor.  As everyone there was polite and friendly, the hipster factor didn't bother me so much.  As far as the food, I ordered Kate's Tofu Scramble with home fries.  It was essentially a tofu omelette with corn, mushroom and fake sausage.  It was delicious.  Seriously.  The bread was thick and tasty too.  Overall it was more than enough food that was too much to finish.  

My final analysis is that the Friendly Toast is a great addition to Cambridge, and especially Kendall Square, a place I rarely have reason to visit.  The downsides are a possible wait and some challenges with parking, though those are pretty minor and expected inconveniences for good food.........

A little Thai place tucked into that plaza of Asian places on Durant near Telegraph. 

Food: Pretty much your standard issue Thai food. Nothing life changing or out there, but tasty, and the portions are large. A great place to come if you're hungry and you want something flavorful. 

Their lunch special is also a great deal, where you get to choose two dishes from a rotating set of three (say, pad thai, pineapple chicken curry and cashew tofu) for about five dollars. 

Service: Pretty standard. They take your order, the food comes, you eat it. It does tend to get a bit crowded during the lunch rush hour from about 11:30 to 1 though. 

Overall: There's nothing particularly memorable about this place (I had to think a little before I remembered the actual name... normally I just refer to it as "that Thai place in the Asian place"), but you always need those places you can drop in and have a quick, cheap, satisfying lunch.  Gets extra credit for being a hop, skip and a jump from South Hall.

this place is so strange to me.. the venue is huge... which makes it an awesome place to throw a giant party... Also I always seem to go here and get something free.. or REALLY discounted.. hmmm anyway when certain songs come on they give out like free mini shots.. AKA one of the girls stands on the bar and will pour liquor into your mouth.... the food selection seems okay.. though I've never tried anything and the prices are definitely more in line with the prices of other U city bars as opposed to it's CC and OC counterparts... I will be here again drinkers.. on one of those random nights I end up in west to lazy to drive to CC and needing a def break from Joes

Refreshingly addictive frozen yougurt.  I alway sample the other flavors but end up ordering the plain.  In theory there are lots of toppings to choose from, but they often "run out" of things [see side note].  I think it's way too expensive ($3 something with a student discount) for the amount that you get.  Their swirl technique creates a big air hole in the middle of the yogurt, and that just ain't right.  


*sidenote:  multiple times I've gone in, ordered, and been told that they are "out" of a certain topping, so I'm forced to chose another.  The last time I went in, my friend Zoey wanted banana and she was told they were "out", even though there was a banana sitting on the counter in plain view.  Zoey called the girl out and she begrudgingly peeled and sliced it, as if it were some huge inconvinience.  I just don't like to be played like that...

Best Coffee in town!!  Nice atmosphere.  They do their own roasting so they get it right, no burnt beans.  It is more expensive than Starbucks, but their coffee is worth it.  You know that they are true connoisseurs because in addition to sugar, sugar in the raw and pink blue and yellow packets, they have simple syrup.  Homemade simple syrup!

This place is pretty awesome.  A giant ice cream sandwich for $1.50?  Win.  The first time I went here was after spending the day at UCLA for the annual LA Times Festival of Books.  It's not a far walk from UCLA actually - in the Westwood area, down the street from CPK and near other restaurants.  

They offer about 10 different types of cookies, a bunch of different Dreyer's ice cream flavors, brownies, Hawaiian shaved ice, and their famous ice cream sandwiches.  Everything on their menu is under $5.  

When I went, I got the ice cream sandwich.  You can pick from any available ice cream flavor and the same goes with the cookies.  You can mix the different type of cookies you want too.  I picked mint chocolate chip ice cream with a white chocolate macadamia nut cookie and a chocolate with white chocolate chip cookie.  It was delicious!  They give you a huge scoop of ice cream stuffed between two huge cookies.

The only downside to this place that I can think of is that the line is ridiculously long.  Maybe it was because it was a Saturday, but my friend and I waited for about an hour before we even got into the store and even after that we waited about another 10 minutes.

I'm definitely down to go again,  but only if I'm in the area and if there's not a huge line to wait in.

You must try this place (pick up, not delivery) at least once if you're in San Diego, if not for the cheap sushi, then for the experience of feeling like you're walking off to go get kidnapped. 

The kitchen (literally, only a kitchen) is located in the plaza right across from UCSD in THE MOST HIDDEN and RANDOM little shack. A friend tricked us and told us it was a normal restaurant but when we went there I thought we were going to be kidnapped and sold into slavery because of the secluded location. Not to mention they only open after 7pm.

That all being said, the sushi tastes great. Slightly better quality than what you would find at one of those super cheap sushi restaurants in the area but around the same price. Never tried delivery, but from what I hear, they're pretty fast. I also got to meet the chefs in person. They're very nice.

Bottom line: Unique sushi experience with slightly above average sushi.

Cookies Rules Everything Around Me..."dolla dolla bills yall"...
What more can I say best fresh cookies ever. Especially if you make an ice cream sandwich. Extremely reasonable as far as pricing. 

BEWARE: The line might be overflowing outside of the door. But TRUST ME it is worth the wait!!!! And they're pretty fast....

I'm just not a fan of Spurlock's.  The food isn't that good, or at least what I've tried has been pretty mediocre.  There's not much of a vibe there either.  It's not a bad place, just not for me I think.

Not exactly student budget-friendly, but great food. The falafel is worth checking out, the po'boys are great, and the service is pretty fast n' friendly. 

Delicious fries too. I would definitely check it out when you're in the area. It's probably about 2 years old by now so it's safe to say that their game is on-point.

I had the spa manicure and pedicure, because I had bought the HomeRun voucher (50% off). Was it worth what I paid for it? Definitely. Was it worth the full price? *shrug* Eh, maybe. Suong is very nice and she did a very good job, but the experience wasn't anything to truly swoon over.

Wasn't all that impressed with the color selection - decent array of your traditional pinks, reds, burgundies, etc., but I was in the mood for something a little different and there wasn't much in greens and blues.

I did like the multi-tasking - I started in the pedi chair. After Suong put on the paraffin treatment, she moved me to the mani table. Again, went as far as the paraffin, then back to the pedi chair to finish that, then back to the mani table. I had no issues with moving around; I'm guessing some people might. 

Going back is not an absolute must for me, but nor do I have any reason to swear the place off forever.

I've had quite a time finding a good local restaurant but am pleased that Girasole has finally filled that need for me. It is tucked away in Shadyside, under, I might add, one of the best places to get ice cream in the city. 

We went for lunch, on a weekday, and the place was packed but we were given a table quickly and the service, overall, was fast and friendly. Their lunch menu did not have a lot of options - but I would rather see a place focus on a few items and do them really well than spread themselves over several mediocre offerings. I opted for the potato gnocchi in a marinara with fresh mozzarella and my husband ordered the penne in marinara with roasted chicken... bot of us were really happy with our entrees. For me, the star was the salad. I am never a real fan of salads in restaurants but this one was excellent. The lettuce was fresh and perfectly balanced - garbanzo beans, Gorgonzola, sunflower seeds, shaved red onion, and nicoise olives (the only thing that I left on the plate) dressed with a house sunflower vinaigrette dressing. 

I'd certainly recommend this for a casual lunch/dinner -- I really want to head back if only just for the salad! In warmer months they also offer seating outside.... for dessert, head upstairs for some amazing gelatto.
Terrible service, flies everywhere.

I had never heard of a "pizzookie" until I came to Los Angeles. I don't know if they really have them in northern California. Anyway, the pizzookie was good. Nice sugar load at 11 PM. I love the sensation of cold ice cream with hot things!!!!! Especially big cookies! Still, apple pie a la mode beats pizzookie.

EDIT
I actually ate at BJ's for the first time. The pizza was decent; really really deep-dish, which is not really my thing, but the crust was nice as it had crispy cheese on it. We tried the blackened chicken and the barbeque chicken. Talk about RICH. And then, everyone got a personal pizzookie. I had the half Oreo, half peanut butter. It's cool because you can order everything in halves so you can try a bunch of different flavors. The nice thing about the Oreo pizzookie is that it comes with oreo mousse on top (a sort of glorified whip cream). That was pretty darn tasty. I love the soft, half-baked texture of the cookie too... now if only it came with a magic calorie eraser! Guess I'll have to go run tomorrow. That's what exercise is for, so you can eat at restaurants like BJ's and not feel TOO guilty.

A few things you should know about Mr. Bartley's Burger Cottage: 

1. It's crowded. Not only did we wait for a table, but once you're in there, you're packed like sardines. I didn't want to get up and use the restroom because you feel like you're disturbing everyone around you, pushing chairs and squeezing by tables. 

2. Cash only. This was definitely an inconvenience. My friend left and went to the ATM because we didn't know if we'd have enough cash to cover our whole meal. For this being such a tourist trap kind of restaurant, I was surprised that they were cash only. 

3. Expect to wait. We waited forever. We waited to ask for water, to get our water, to order, to get our order, to ask for the check, to get our check....it was a whole lotta waiting. 

4. Food is good. Not great. Good. I ordered the Facebook. It was a burger with BBQ sauce and coleslaw, served with fries. The fries aren't anything special. The burger was good, but not even close to some of the best burgers I've ever had. Also, for $10 (and I think another $1 for me because I added cheese), I was disappointed with the portion. 

5. The burgers all have cute, clever names. This is their hook. That, and all the crap all over the walls, like funny signs and bumper stickers. 

So, overall, if you're in the area and have some time to kill, this may be a good spot to grab a burger. If I could go back to my vacation and choose somewhere else to have lunch in the Harvard area, I probably would.

Found this through the livingsocial.com deal they were having. My biggest suggestion is dont go hungry as they only serve appetizers and they are very small and a lil pricey.  If you are in the neighborhood I think its a great place to go but possibly not worth the trek. I made 4 of my friends venture there with me because I really didn't know how far it was. Lesson learned. 

(side note: even though it was a wine bar, several times our waitress spilled the wine while pouring all over the table)

The best sandwich place near campus. Free WiFi and great food - I get the mozzarella sandwich whenever I go and it's damn tasty, if a bit small and definitely not the healthiest thing in the world. 

At night, it turns into a hipster hangout. Think the near-polar opposite of Players just down the street. If that's your thing, great.

Gushi could very well be the best place to get Asian food in Westwood. After trying to find a decent Asian food place, I came across Gushi. I either get their Combo Plate that comes with beef, chicken, rice, salad, kimchi and soda or just the Kalbi Bowl which comes with Korean BBQ ribs and rice. They top their food off with some great sauce, and then adding some Sriracha sauce just makes their food even more amazing.

Although there's a lack of parking available in the streets of Westwood, don't let that turn your away from this place. It's very well worth the walk and the wait in line. Also, since there's a limited amount of seating, I like to make my orders to-go and just eat at home. With this place being quite popular, don't expect to be able to just order your food and go. You'll probably have to wait at least 10 minutes before you get your food.

All things considered, I will continue to come to this place. The appearance of this eatery may not lure you in, but until you try their food you will definitely be missing out.

I can't believe people actually gave this place 4 stars..  I have never paid so much for so little at an Indian restaurant, and had mediocre food to boot.  If you're looking for South Indian food, there are better and cheaper alternatives in the east side (Udupi Palace), if you're willing to drive out there.  If you're looking for North Indian food, pretty much anywhere else is a better value.  

In summary, the food was alright, but the price was not.

Oh, one note about spiciness:  if you want mild, this is not the place for you.  We witnessed one guest send back her meal several times, only to finally leave without eating just because they did not understand the meaning of the word "mild".  We were fine with the spiciness, however, my husband (who is Indian) found it spicy.

maybe not fair to read other reviews and then comment, but here goes. i went after the lunch rush on a sunday for after-lunch snacks and beer with a friend. i had the calamari and the honey wheat brew. the beer was clean and sweet with a pleasant woodsy aftertaste. it reminded me a little of the victory lager. i enjoyed it well enough. the calamari was good, but nothing notable. the service was ok. it wasn't too crowded, though there was an echo, and i definately felt an overwhelming sense of "you are in the presence of rich kids and their parents out at school" type of thing. all in all it was a pleasant experience. i would love to try more of their beers, and the swill comment (see below of venue page) should be thrown out.

Okay folks,
heres my first review. I went with the wife just to get a hot chocolate and the reason why I am giving this place 2 stars is because the hot chocolate cost me nearly $5.00. Now, I am the first one to admit that I love a good cup of cafe or hot chocolate, or tea for that matter. This place does not  deserve the praise that it is getting as a result. I can name numerous coffee houses in the boston area that give the same quality for a lot less money.

I really, really hate to do this, but it must be said. The food at Bocado is quite good, but the service was deplorable to the point of making me feel uncomfortable and unwelcome. 

Yes, I was a party of one, but that doesn't make me a leper. I entered through one door, made my way to the host stand, got the shaft for a few minutes until a guy came and asked if I needed help. I was ushered over to a crappy table along the wall with the fire alarm right in my face. Charming. They don't have wifi, which was a bummer, but no matter. The waiter arrived, took my order without offering recommendations or assistance, and then brought out my sandwich about 10 minutes later. The whole exchange was painfully cut and dry.

My sandwich (chicken with fennel and other goodies) was quite lovely with fresh crunchy bread and flavorful toppings. I hate sandwich spots like this that make you order sides a la carte, as the servings are typically much too large for one person. The same is true here, so if I ever come back solo I'll just go with a sandwich without anything in addition, which is kind of a bummer. 

I paid my check and left without so much of a thank you from any of the staff and made my way across the street to Octane where I was greeted with open arms and friendly smiles.

Mas Amigos, I owe you an apology for not upgrading your rating sooner.  I've been back several times since my first review, and you are now one of my favorite restaurants in C-U.

I have to reiterate that the chips and salsa are INCREDIBLE.  And that green sauce (a mixture of avocados, tomatillos, and jalapeños) should really just be poured straight into my mouth from now on.  I want it on everything.  Their lunch specials are cheap and delicious, and for God's sake, order their tacos with onion and cilantro.  Soooo good.

Dos is dead.  Viva Mas Amigos!

This update is only to comment on an entree that i had here that wasn't my favorite and I think is bit misleading, (didn't taste bad enough to affect my rating however). Basil chicken off the Thai menu. Doesn't taste Thai at all, not a lot of basil flavors either for that matter and super sweet. This dish doesn't taste yucky or anything - it just isn't at all reminiscent of the usual Thai basil chicken. Still go here, just skip this if authentic flavors matter

Although it is next door to campus this crowd seemed a little older during the early evening. They have plenty of beers on tap and the night we went (Sat) they had them all on special for $3.25. They have pool tables, shuffle board (wahoo!!) a few video games and steel tip dart boards. Out back they have a trailer with plenty of choices for food, but it is the usual bar food pickings. Big patio is great for large groups. 

Friendly staff and plenty of TVs. The one thing is they have an Internet jukebox which is great, but the keyboard is always messed up. So you are left with their selections which is a mixture of Texas country and top 40 rap. Why those two together I don't know. Like they say, the lesser of two evils is still evil. Great for early evening but head on out when the night gets going.

**I first reviewed this as the Little Woodrows on Guadalupe, because they still have the signs in the parking lot. I called asking about their happy hour special and then they answered by this name. So I moved it here.

I remember driving to Champaign from Kankakee to go to "C street". It was worth the drive. 

They have a large dance floor and 3 levels you can observe the dancefloor from. When it is warm, you can hang out on the patio as well. 

C street is where the boys are in Champaign.

The best of the worst on campus, I guess.  It's expensive but it could definitely be worse.  The main trouble with this place is inventory - they had the recalled Clif bars here long after the recall. I just went to buy a box of cookies and they were covered in dust and long expired.  Last week I bought some expired inari rolls, which was unpleasant enough to bite into, and on top of that I had to deal with a manager who had no comment at all - let alone an apology.  I've encountered a few other expired things too - drinks mostly.  Basically they buy a bunch of shit at the start of the quarter and let everything run down until the quarter ends, so if you see something you like early in the quarter you'd have to just buy them up and keep your own little inventory at your place.  Better yet, just buy in bulk from Amazon and save yourself some money.  FYI, Wholefoods gives a 10% case discount and if you get one of those UCSD Green Cards, you get $5 off of a $25 order.

Manas is a great little restaurant close to USC.  My co-workers and I often come here for lunch.  the buffet is always great - filled with many delicious options and is quite reasonable.  Ordering off the menu is a good option too, but is a bit more pricey.  
The folks running the restaurant seem genuine, they always greet us kindly and are for the most part, efficient.
Oh, and the Naan (esp the GARLIC naan) is really really good!

I gave it an "A-OK" because I come back here.  If you know and enjoy great beer, you can't go wrong here.  The rotating taps always are great--even if you know all beer, you can always experience something you have never tried before.  I once had a beer called Bananas and Blow, that truly tasted like bananas (as far as the latter goes, my experiences discredit me).  

As Leanna G. said, don't come here if you are expecting to get drunk, the waitstaff don't allow it because they are so slow to respond to you that it will be impossible to do so.  Beyond that, the food leaves little to be commended.  Being a vegetarian, I enjoy eating somewhere that offers an herbivore selection which goes beyond  a salad, soup, bean burger, and a veggie wrap.  Here you can't find a salad that does not include a meat option, they do not offer a bean burger at all, but they do boast a vegetarian soup each day.  The last few times I have eaten here I opted for the Georgia Reuben minus turkey, plus tomato (a customized go-to veggie option of mine), and each time the wait staff have given me an odd look before walking away--you're in Ann Arbor, what can you expect?  

On another note, I will preface this by saying I am fairly tolerant when it comes to a smokey environment.  In fact, when it comes to a good bar/pub, I think this to be an important component.  However, I find the smokiness to be a bit intolerable, even when I sit in the non-smoking section.

If you are looking for a great beer, loud music, and a good flavor of emphysema...enjoy!

Giovanni,

Grazie, Grazie and more Grazie!!!!!! Need I say more.

Zoe was a great waitress.  Food was good
Atmosphere great!

One of my favorite restaurants in Ithaca! They have a variety of curry. All are very tasty! The texture is delicate and the ingredients are fresh. I don't like curry that only has the flavor of curry (I don't know if this sentence makes any sense^^), but my taste buds tell me that Thai Cuisine curry are made from many fresh ingredients in a very good proportion being mixed together very well that makes its taste complicated yet harmonious. 

I like their specials: crab leg curry, fish with three curry sauce, and crispy duck. My friends and I ordered these three dishes every time when we went there. They have some dishes in their "Rice" section which is served or baked in hot clay pot. They are worth trying. Cooking rice in this way by using the hot clay pot makes the texture and taste of the rice and its companions so different from steaming and stir-frying.

Having lunch there is really a good deal. The price is a lot cheaper, but the food is still in the same high quality.

If you are a big fan of classical music and coffee, then the Music Offering is the place for you. The coffee, coffee cake, desserts and iced tea is good. You can also order wine, which could be a plus. Classical music wafting around you was soothing and calming. 

The  ambience was collegiate, with professors, teachers, students and wanderers like me dropping by from UCB (I'm lucky that UCB's blue and gold colors are just about the same as the colors of my UBC's thunderbird baseball cap). The music and the vicinity around the People's Republic of UC Berekeley was what differentiated this nice place. The strong 802.11 wifi signal from across the street can be good enough to use your laptop. The negatives could be: the parking, and bathroom (must go next door and use the book shop's); but twas a great find.

I have mixed feelings giving Budget higher than a three.  Why, you ask?  It's f-ing expensive.  For five days, including insurance, it was around $365.  That's a lot.  A LOT.  Granted, I don't often rent cars, but I felt a little price gouged at that rate.  I set up the reservation on priceline.com, and thought I was getting a good deal, but alas, that drive didn't include any insurance or the hidden fees, which almost double the cost.  The car was nice, the service was okay (nicer upon return; the guy who gave me the car seemed annoyed that I didn't like the hidden costs), but I don't think I'd use them again.  

At the price I paid at Budget, it actually factors out to be cheaper to use zipcar.com, because the gas is included, and honestly, that's what I will do for future car needs.

I'm still hungover so I'll make this short.

Over-rated. I ordered a "margarita pizza" expecting a topping of cheese, tomatoes, and basil. What do I get? A soggy, oily $6 mess of a  cheese pizza (mozzarella and CHEDDAR no less). 

Calzones are huge, but a light on the filling and again with the soggyness. 

The pasta's look promising, but didn't get to try one. 

There's tons of great places right next door so I suggest hitting those up if you want to get your money's worth. Blondie's down the street for pizza, falafel / gyros next door, cheap Thai around the corner, Top Dog.... Go anywhere else but here unless you have a raging hard-on for Americanized-Italian fast food.

Still love this place!  Just wanted to add that you can order your Kendall movie tickets at the restaurant and they will go and buy them for you while you eat.  And the price of the tickets is discounted (they are $7, I think).  So, excellent food and a great deal on your movie as well.

I've been to this Aveda salon a few times, and I've always been happy with the results. My first time was the best hair experience of my life. The stylist was very attentive, but offered good suggestions about which cut would work best for me. The cut was great, but my hair is not complicated to style, and I was just looking for layers.

The second time I went for a haircut, it was fine. The stylist I had this time wasn't that great. She didn't listen to how I wanted my hair, but the cut wasn't terrible. It looked fine, it was just not what I wanted and for almost $50 I wanted the exact thing I asked for. I would do research on which stylist to choose for your hair appointment. I've always had appointments with junior stylists, but I imagine senior stylists will work wonders on your hair. It is pricey, but compared to other salons in NYC they are ok, and they have a student discount (10-15%). 

It's worth giving it a try, especially since aveda products are great!

This place was good, the food was tasty (try the Vietnamese spring rolls - delicious!), and fairly reasonably priced.  Their brews & sampler left us a little unenthused but it was a great location for checking out WaterFire after, and could also be a nice alternative to eating in the mall if you wanted to do some shopping or hit up Dave & Buster's.

The original Affection boutique is still open!

Owner Paula has opened up another Affection Boutique- this time, right smack dab in the middle of Rice Village! It's located right across the street from Salento Coffee and to the right of Fleet Feet Express. 

If you've been to the original location - this is a "bigger, badder" version of the Washington venue.  Expect to see a continuation of sexy cocktail dresses, trendy jackets for the fall, some casual staples, and tons of fabulous jewelry/accessories.  Paula only buys about 3 of each style (S, M, and L), so if you see something you like- grab it before it's gone!

As always - complimentary wine while you shop.

This is the TJs on top of parking structure @Lake & Del Mar. Given that, it is usually quite easy to park unlike most TJs. This store has slightly wider aisles and a bigger wine selection. Otherwise the usual merch & friendly staff.

They put American cheese on my French onion soup.

Food was not great. Not awful, but still, you'd expect something tasty (or at least not a crime, as evidenced by my first sentence of this review) to come out of that kitchen.

Decent outdoor seating area. Service was not as bad as some reviewed, I thought it was fine. Unlike the chow.

Over-priced and under-flavored, Judy's food is not worth the wait (usually taking the form of both a table queue and cook time).  For some reason, this restaurant is now expanding in 5 directions, taking over valuable downtown space in Amherst and making Judy's larger than some grocery stores in the area.  I guess if you're a student off campus, interested in the cafeteria experience, you'll be quite satisfied by Judy's spaciousness and food.

This is the best comic book store I have ever been to and I love comics. The owners are very helpful, really nice, and have excellent taste. There is something for everyone here, and they even host cool events at their store like art shows and 24-hour write a comic day. They update their website regularly, so check them out.

It's been written here on Yelp that Pie 'n' Burger doesn't serve breakfast any more. This is not true.
Pie 'n' Burger still serves breakfast - I just checked with them today 10/21/08. They serve breakfast till 11:00 on weekdays and till 1:00 on weekends.

It is a shame that in such a great location there is such a bad restaurant. First of all they DO NOT have bathrooms!  Also they don't take credit cards. The owners are angry all the time and even when paying the bill they treat you badly. The food is terrible. The salads are disgustingly full of cheese. I am not super fan of cheese but even my friends who are, were not very excited about it. Plus with a name like Greenhouse you would think they would have great salads with a wide variety of vegetables. Salads for them are basically lettuce and tomato. I am never going back.

I'm not sure why I like Jimmy John's, but I do.
The meat isn't extra tasty, the cheese is provolone and white bread is the only option. Maybe its the simplicity that makes it good.

I stopped at this CVS to fill a prescription for a friend that just got out of the hospital.  This crew was very good at their job.  I was asked lots of questions to make sure I had no questions. Great location with ample parking garage as well

The chilaquiles and machaca are a reliable breakfast and for a good price.  It is nice to sit on the patio and watch the passers by on their way to school while enjoying a breakfast that would be considered brunch if I hadn't just gotten up.

I love that place! 
I am NOT a big pizza fan, but Cambridge 1 knows where it's at. Service was lacking, but the pizza delicious! Particularly dish 12 with the artichokes. 

My friend and I ordered 3 halfs, the artichoke, the arugula (7) and the onions (3). All good, but number 12 was the best

Also good news: wine selection. I got the chardonnay and it was so good that I ordered another glass. 

it was a lot of YUM!

I saw the North Face sign peeking out of a store that looked like a defunct, closed down store from Starbucks on San Antonio street.  

Returning at a later time to investigate, I found out that this store was Whole Earth Provision company. The store looks great, the wooden columns and exposed brick.  The staff were very nice.  I went straight up to the 2nd floor in search for climbing equipment and found a nice amount in the corner.  There was a guy behind the counter I engaged in conversation who was quite knowledgeable and very helpful.  Although I had no intent on buying gear quite yet, the prices were comparable to REI.  But it's hard to compare large-scale places such as REI to something only as big as Whole Earth(even though I know it's got multiple stores in multiple cities). 

Long live local, and the mom and pop shops!
A student lunch joint serving great middle eastern and mediterranean food in the heart of the University area.  Great kefta kabobs, basmati rice, dolmatas and tzatziki sauce.

First impression: Subtle sophistication tucked away from the busier Higuera Street.  Conveniently situated next to the movie theater.  Its a perfect place for quick cocktails and tapas before you catch a movie.  The drinks are well made, and tapas are tasty and delicious.   Service is friendly and good.
Best Thai Ice Tea EVER!!  The food is good for lunch when you work a few blocks away!  For dinner, Noodle Planet is a lot better!

I would absolutely recommend the Franklin Plaza to anyone looking to make their special occasion PERFECT. When my husband and I were looking for wedding venues in the Capital District, we were referred to The Franklin Plaza by a relative who had recently been to someone else's wedding there. He boasted about the food and how pretty the reception room was, so we decided to check it out (knowing that we had basically decided on another venue already). 

Since we live in NYC, we made a quick call to see if there was a way we would be able to come see the space that weekend. We spoke with Joe, who came in for a special appointment on a Sunday morning with us. We were floored the second we walked into the space. An old federal savings bank, this place has the rich history and grandeur you would imagine, but with a charm and beauty that look my breath away. Joe was incredible - walking us through every detail of the way the ceremony would be set up, the HOUR-AND-A-HALF cocktail hour upstairs with 15 passed hors d'oeuvres, 4 stationary tables, and open bar, and then the reception downstairs with a four-course dinner, including dessert course and more open bar. And, their hotel is right across the street - none of our guests would have to drive anywhere. We were sold. Especially when we found out that they were actually cheaper than some of the other places we had been looking at previously. 

Our wedding day was PERFECTION. I work as an event planner, so I am used to managing every detail of event days myself. The folks at the Franklin Plaza took care of absolutely everything. There was never a question in my mind that our wedding would be anything less than exquisite. The head waiters and site managers were incredible, and we had everything we needed taken care of for us all night. I didn't have to lift a finger. The food was incredible. You could really tell that Michael's catering (through the Franklin Plaza) was truly a chef and caterer, not just your run-of-the-mill event venue cranking out the typical steak, chicken, fish. They did every single meal to order, served every one of my 180 guests in record time, and kept everyone happy - and FULL - all night long. 

There is honestly not a bad thing I could possibly say about this venue. I would suggest that anyone looking for a terrific venue for their wedding, bar Mitzi, anniversary party, ANYTHING visit the Franklin Plaza. If you ever get an invitation for an event at the Franklin Plaza, go! Even if you don't even like the person inviting you. Go anyway to check out this incredible place and have an amazing experience like I had. It's that good.

I bought a MacBook Pro here during the "sales tax-free" promotion a while back. The service was alright but we did not receive the free printer even though it was part of the package. As a customer service representative, it would be wise to give some sort of voucher to redeem the printer when it comes back in stock. The printer didn't get discontinued so that is my complaint. It's pretty quiet here since it's not a everyday where students purchase a personal computer, notebook, or accessories. I'm glad that the UCB campus has this retail resource since the nearest Apple Store is at Bay Street in Emeryville but the prices are pretty much the same if not a few cents or dollars less.

If you're going to a costume party and or just looking to revamp your style in the vein of Bishop Don Magic Juan (Google him if you think I made that up!), then Red Light will definitely help you out.  In the day-to-day clothing area, you may have more of a task in front of you.  If you want to use a fitting room, beware; you can almost hear the grinding teeth of the staff as you oh-so-rudely interrupted their conversation about how that Pitchfork interview with Devendra Banhart was (insert hip, ironic slang meaning "good" here).

good hummus & pita, great kafka sandwich, awesome fries!!

we were a little crowded seated in the middle of the restaurant, and the chairs felt like they were about to fall apart, but it's almost part of the place's charm.

UPDATE: i just went to the middle east again for a late lunch and fell in love a bit more. my girlfriend and i were seated in the tiny little booths that are perfect for a date. we split an order of fries, i got the baba ganooj sandwich (would definitely get again!) and she got the chicken schwarama, which she also recommended

topped it off with a sam adams seasonal (summer). a refreshing and tasty lunch after walking from downtown, over the charles river bridge, into cambridge!

The cookies are absolutely amazing if you get the right one. I always get the creamy brown sugar dough with some combination of dark chocolate. It is a little piece of heaven when it comes out all warm and gooey. I've tried bites of other combinations but they don't do much for me. 

It is kind of overpriced and it does take a long time for your cookie to come out, but they do have some games and coffee table books to look at while you wait. 

Go with a chatty friend or with someone whom you have a lot of catching up to do.

Went with my guy friends for happy hour but i didn't eat because i had just ate... and they were really bummed about the happy hour menu. but then we were talking to the server and they said they were going to be updating their happy hour menu. i really can't comment on anything else...

Although cramped and boasting the staircase from hell (a million people trying to go up and down one tiny stairway,) the Harvard Bookstore is your go-to place for knowledgeable book service.  Just ask the staff, they can tell you anything about books.  Especially the older guy... ask him a question, I guarantee he'll know what you're looking for.

The collections are a little cluttered, and they're hard to manuever, but overall this place is a good experience.

Much more personable than the "Coop," Harvard Book Store is your place to go if you're looking for a book in Harvard Square.

SOMETIMES A LONG REVIEW IS NOT NEEDED FOR SOMETHING THAT IS SO DELICIOUS. 
My two Favorites here are:
Butter Chicken- smothered in a rich Indian butter sauce almost like a gravy texture which I love compared to the watery texture of most places.

Mango Curry with Chicken- The sweetness of the mango goes nicely with the spiciness of the curry! 

The portions are quite large compared to most Indian Restaurants and the prices are the same.
The only disappointment is that this joint does not offer a lunch buffet (assuming cause they know they are pretty damn good!)

By far my favorite Indian Joint! Does anyone have a place that outdoes this one? let me know! In the mean time I'm sticking with Cedars.

PS THIS PLACE WILL TOP OFF YOUR CHAI TEA FOR FREE! THEY WALK AROUND AND FILL IT UP LIKE COFFEE! WHAT INDIAN PLACE DOES THAT?? THIS ONE DOES!

Wow. So incredibly good. We tried a few different kinds and my favorite was the white. It had gobs of delicious gooey ricotta. Yummy. I found the experience and pizza much better than Varasanos, for what it's worth. 

And the best part? It's quite affordable. Bring a little vino and $20 and you've got your self a little party!

I always go for the vegetarian burger. It's some kind of spicy chickpea mash burger - tastes great! Simple, spicy goodness. Fries are always spot-on as well. Just can't go wrong with this place, consistently yummy!

Great spot for wedding photography! The courtyard is beautiful, and the "Round Room" is nice for those last minute "getting ready" shots, especially with portraits outside with the doors closed. This is very old architecture and adds a timeless look.

I have photographed several weddings here, and a note to fellow photogs... Get access permission to the balcony for photos AHEAD OF TIME. Meaning, you MUST coordinate with the couple you are working with, and the University, to make sure you have access upstairs during the ceremony.
I learned this the hard way many years ago... If the couple marrying has not hired a organist, then this can actually LOCK you out of the balcony.

The idea of photographing a wedding here, without access to the balcony, is a bad one. It's one of the better angles from above that I have seen in over 400 weddings.

Lighting is low, tripod is required for interior full room shots... handheld of ceremony is do-able, but a mono-pod with anything over 100mm, under 400iso, is recommended.

GOOD LUCK!

I gave the place 3 stars only because I love their red wine sangria. I had a bad experience the last time I came here with two of my girlfriends. I had been raving about their delicious sangria so we came here after lunch. We were seated, ordered our sangria, and told the waitress we weren't going to order any food. She said that was fine and brought us our drinks. About 10 minutes later another waitress came up to us and told us that we either had to order food or move to the bar. We decided to move to the bar since we were too full to eat. While sitting at the bar a woman who appeared to be the manager/owner kept giving us dirty looks as if she were waiting for us to leave! We all felt really uncomfortable and decided to go to another bar instead. It'll be a very long time before I go back to this place, that is if I ever do go back.

I agree with Sparkely K. that this location has great service; last minute bday cake for my dtr who is into princesses, and they were able to get it from another location and have it ready for me before their store opened the next day.  The blue frosting doesn't really melt (ever) which makes me wonder what it is made of, but the cake tasted great, was not overly frozen, and made exactly as I requested (cookie dough and choc cake, yum)

Bottom line: excellent service, great bday cake

it's funny how you go into a store for one specific thing that you want... and there's always that one salesman that just doesn't understand that when you tell them no, it means NO. I am a regular customer at the Harvard square store. I come in, grab my maca root shaving cream and face protector, and the women who work there understand that I like to be in and out. I'm a guy, I don't want all this body stuff and cards, I just like what I like. The last time I went it to get a face protector, the man working just kept bashing it into my head that I needed to buy more than one product. He even tried to guilt trip me into it. I shouldn't have to feel guilty while shopping because I only want one item. All he wanted to talk about was what he thinks I should buy. I don't go to other retail stores because these are the type of salespeople that I try to avoid. I've never had to deal with this type of aggressive, money-hungry employee at the body shop until now. If this is how I'm going to be treated every time I come in now, then I might as well just go deal with the pushy jackasses at Macys.

This place is legit. It isn't the best mediterranean I've had, but it gets the job done. I tried to go here at least once a week, if I was forced to eat out while cramming for exams or the like at Haas... The quality can't be beat for the price. While Smart Alec's is decent for salads, I'll take lamb kabob all day...

I'm a huge believer in not judging a book by it's cover. For some reason, some people think the term "microbrewery" automatically means that it's of a high quality. I went with friends and an open mind and ordered a pint of the Guinness type dark beer. I got my nose over the glass and was punched in the face with smokey, beef jerky-like aromas. When I took a sip, I was karate chopped in the neck with some serious off-bitter smokey, meaty mid-palate and finish. I had to struggle to finish it. I then tried an Irish Red - I would probably of liked it if they used about 1/10th the hops.

This is some of the best food you will eat in Harlem.  The pasta is fresh, and there is a decent amount of variety with daily specials and their usual menu.  

Try the pear gorgonzola salad or the bruschetta for appies, and for a main dish, the lamb ragu, gnocchi, lasagna, or pasta with vodka sauce are awesome.  I also love the bread and sauce with olives they put on the table after you order, mmm!  For dessert, try the chocolate mousse cake.  I don't know where they get this stuff, but it is heavenly!

Cash only, but well worth the trip to the ATM.

Libertarian strong hold of Berkeley. The cook isn't nice cause he's not here to baby you, he's here to take your money and give you a top dog so don't expect patience. The food is great and what you want for food that's prepared quickly but isn't from a fast food chain. Does not take plastic so beware.

Wow what great pizza!!! Fresh basil, delicious melted cheese (fresh tasting) and the toppings are stupendous.  I tried two slices (pepporoni and sausage w/mushroom) that was YUMMY!

The crust was perfect crunchy, light, crisp and perfect consistency for toppings.  

If you see this truck make sure you grab a slice.  They are the best slices in LA!!!!

With the salad, get the poppy seed dressing. 

For a sandwich, get the BLTA. 

For the bloated and full feeling that inevitably follows, get TUMS. 

God I love this place.

I'm always suspicious of restaurants that serve both Chinese AND Japanese food.  Completely different countries with very different cuisines.

But Panda East manages it pretty well.  I usually order from their Japanese menu, and have never had a bad sushi experience.  I like their Unagi Don (mmmm, eel....).

On their Chinese menu, I like the Ma-La Lamb.

I've had crepes before, but never like this.  First of all I was surprised how expensive the crepe menu was and then they handed me my crepe and I took my thought back.  It was huge and delicious!!!  I had a nutella, fresh strawberries, bananas, and topped it off with whip cream.  It was perfect!  I am literally wiping the drool from my mouth as I think about my delicious crepe.  Until my next trip to Berkeley I'll have my delicious memories to think about.

I never bought a PC from here but I bought other software.  As a Penn student you get great discounts, financing, and (I've been told) better service.  

If you're a Penn student, you don't need to read this revie,w though, as I'm certian you've alreadu been there to buy something.  When the first 4th gen iPod came out, kids were lined out into the street to get them.  They have all of the new Mac stuff.

Held a party at the uptown Pourhouse.  I don't think there is anything particularly unique about this beer joint/sports bar, but it is worth a visit if in the neighborhood.  And, I am guessing it is a good place to catch a sporting event as it is spacious.

Music was good!
Our party was 30+, and I must say the service was excellent.  Our waitress hustled like you would not believe.
Drinks, tasty and strong.
Plenty of TV's if you need to watch the games.
Attractive, outgoing, friendly staff.
Manager was responsive to our large group needs!

We did the usual platter of wings and nachos, which seemed to please the group.

Then the shots came out,...

All around a fun place and a fun night.

The neighborhood bustled on a Friday night.  Afterward, I went out to a small french place called Cafe du Soleil (review pending).  I really got a positive vibe from the whole area.  Made me want to explore more in this dynamic neighborhood.

I would definitely stop by again on a tour around Columbia U.

The low rating for this branch of Whole Foods is for the following reasons:

1. Many of the pantry items here are shockingly overpriced.  I don't just mean that they're overpriced compared to other grocery stores, I mean they're overpriced compared to other branches of Whole Foods.  The stores I go to in the Bay Area and the LA area all carry the same exact products I tend to watch the prices for at a rough average of two to three dollars less.  I get that location/climate/distribution affects produce prices but for pantry items there's no justification for such a price difference.

2. Rude service at the food counters.

3. Because there's not much in the way of eating/shopping around UCSD except for the retail complex in which this Whole Foods is located, the parking situation here is ridiculously crowded/stressful/dangerous.

4. This is the first Whole Foods where I've seen flyers for a pseudoscientific seminar/class on "the link between gluten and autism."  Never mind that a large review of the major studies on the very issue have debunked the idea of a link between gluten (or casein) and autism; this Whole Foods seems to be actively promoting the idea anyway.  There's nothing in it for Whole Foods, right?  They're just doing it because they care about the consumer and not because they're trying to sell their insanely priced gluten-free baked goods and rice breads, right?  Hmm.  Hmmmmmm.

The reason you're not seeing a one-star rating is because there's really no other place in the general UCSD area for healthy, affordable prepared meals as all the restaurants are either of the crappy chain/mall variety or just overpriced, hotel-adjacent wastes of time.  Pretty much the only place in the area to get quality food at a reasonable price is at the salad bar and hot food/deli counters at this Whole Foods.  The salad bar is impressively fresh and clean, and there are some great sandwiches, roasted brussel sprouts, and sautéed kale with garlic to be had here.

I can't believe I didn't know about this for a while.  

Portions a big plus.  I asked for bucket size.  They had it!!!!  and they gave it to me without the wide-eyed "really?  you're going to put all this in your face in one go?" face.  Yep.  They had their game-face on.

The person who made my serving even slammed it down on the counter twice to make sure it settled to the bottom, so she could put even MORE in it.  After my own heart...  and reminded me of the days of making slushies at 7-11, after coming out of a club known for it's questionable ethics, and even more questionable clientele.

Big line. Big.  Looked like a BIG mistake.  There were at least 30 people in line in front of us.  And a few fire fighters on the side.  (huh?  I guess if cops can hang around doughnut places, fire-fighters can hang out at frozen yogurt places, right?)

This odd reality is that it took us less than 5 minutes to sift through such a considerably big line.  And this was just a little before 10pm.  I thought the crowd would have thinned out by now.  The thing is, they don't thin out.  Maybe students don't have lives.  Duh.

Their yogurt is yummy.  It is very ice-cream like.  It tasted great.  and when it melts...it reminds me of Asian yogurt drinks.  The tiny kind that are as tall as my finger, with the peel-off metal top.  lol.  Good times.

Did I mention a good choice of toppings?  I got a lot of gummy bears too.  he heh heh.

The person that helped us?  She was awesome.  Everything was answered with a polite and enthusiastic YES.  Where can you find that nowadays?  And from someone young?  hmmmm.  Maybe we should send all of our chitlins there, so they can learn something.  (cuz you know, the bay area isn't known for it's politeness or for being agreeable people.)

What an unexpected find.  Normally, I refer to Yelp for assistance in finding good places to eat or drink when I'm on the road.  But on my recent trip to Seattle, I found myself needing coffee after arrival from my 6 am departure flight.  Just a ways across the street from the hotel I was staying in was Trabant.  The concierge of the hotel suggested I get my needed dose of legalized stimulant from Trabant and proclaimed in a school girl way how much she loved their chai.

Not being a fan of chai, of any sort, I did not have high expectations.  I resigned myself to an average cup of coffee and figured I could look for truly good coffee places online, when I had the time.  This was Seattle, after all.  What I didn't expect, but what I did in fact receive, was one of the best cups of coffee I've ever had.  Those super-duper Clover machines really do brew good coffee.  Ethiopian sidamo was good and, for a sweeter drink, I liked the Mexican mocha.  

I wound up dropping in every morning that I was in Seattle.  Nice place for a cup of coffee, armed with the morning paper or if you want to look over your emails for the day.
Affordable, close to USC and a good Mexican place. Room was clean, beds were comfy. Not super frilly, but it was all that we needed. Fun times!

I liked Maxie's Supper club.  I liked the name, I like the comfortableness and somewhat hip feel of the place.  The waiters, waitress's are all young, attractive and pleasant.  Food is acceptable.  I thought the prices were a little high for mediocre food.

I had one issue here.  We came in at 6:01-6:02...and I told the waiter that we would have the 2 for 1 Oysters as appetizers ONLY if we could get the 2 for 1 price (which ended at 6PM).  He said..."Ummmm...I'll have to check, because it ends at 6PM."  Well, cuz you know oysters are expensive

Being only a few minutes past 6...I figured he could work it out.  And if he COULD make it happen, then we would like a big plate of Oysters......if not, then we would not want any oysters.

I figured if it was a question of giving us the order for half price...or not ordering them at all, the manager would rather see us run up our bill....than skip the appetizers altogether.

He brought the big plate of oysters and I figured he came thru for us.  Yay!

Well, the bill came, and I realized that he had charged me full price.  When I questioned this, he said "I checked and was told that we couldn't offer the half-price since it was a couple of minutes past 6".  Which is fine, but I wouldn't have ordered them otherwise.  I asked my tablemates if I was clear when I spoke to him, and they all remember me saying to skip it if we could get the 1/2 price offer.

Not wanting to get into a to-do over it with a group of people....I simply deducted the amount of the discount I was expecting from his tip.  (And I usually tip well.)  I figured I wasn't going to pay for this...and since it was his fault, he was.

I can't tell if this was a simple misunderstanding...or a waiter trying to "pull something".

I would go there again, but again, go over the bill item by item.

This is a good casual dining place, and the food is great - not pretentious at all. The menu is simple, and I have pretty much tried everything on it, with very little dissapointment. Nice ambience in the evening.

Good Pizza, nothing spectacular. I miss Cafe Aventura ! Anyone who say's this is the best pizza in Boston apparently first of all doesn't realize that Cambridge is NOT Boston, and has also apparently only eaten at one pizza place in the Boston area. The pizza here doesn't even begin to compair to Pizzaira Regina, or the Upper Crust. Take a trip to the North End! This place is a blast late night if you like mowing your way through drunken Harvard kids.

Decent Mexican fare with good service.  Also one of the few attempts at authentic Mexican food on this side of the city.

Personally have been to Zocalo a few times, with mixed experiences each time.  The food is on the upper end of decent, with my personal favorite being the chile relleno.  They seem to consistently pick good peppers and the spiced cheese is of a very nice quality, although the same cannot be said about the sides.  The beans routinely seem to be overcooked and the rice way too hard and undercooked.  Very unfortunate, but I guess that the main dish is where they put the most effort.  Students can avail of a 10$ lunch special, which is very very reasonable for a UC eatery with above-average food, and there is also a 25$ prix fixe menu which is a good option for those who aren't too financially constrained.

The story of the restaurant is nice, with a husband and wife who worked in the food industry for over 30 years outside the city coming together to open their own eatery and serve traditional food.

Unfortunately, the staff seems like they are forced to work there, and this is very evident with the service.  A few are nice, and actually help out with the food selection, but the majority just don't make the cut.

The bar selection seems to be decent, although I cannot personally comment.

All in all, decent pricing and above-average food make this place a good visit, and honestly, ymmv, depending on the staff and which chef is there for that day.

Good eats!

Decaying and yet still a-building.  See the Biblical garden!

And is that great pizza place (called V & T?) still across the street?

Ambiance: This place is very loud, and you get the feeling that's there a few too many tables in the space available. Six of us sat at a table that should have really held four. It's definitely a place to go with friends, not a date or the like. For what its worth, the walls are a pleasing eggplant colour. If you like eggplants, anyway. 

Food: For the amount we paid (none of my friends got anything over 9 bucks, and I don't remember seeing anything over 15 even on the menu) I guess you could say it was worth it. I got the spicy calamari because I'm a seafood maniac. It wasn't spicy at all, although it was cut and cooked in such a way as to resemble flower shapes, which was a nice detail until I bit into a piece and realized that no real flavour made up for the pleasing visual. It was served with a sweet chilli sauce that I distinctly recognized from a bottle I bought at 99 Ranch once, which bothered me especially since it really didn't go with the calamari at all. My friends got Pad Thai, which looked gloppy but serviceable; a vegetable dish that came with rice and actually looked the best out of the bunch, with fresh vegetables (!); pan fried noodles, something involving pork, and some other noodle thing. Yeah, it's a noodle place and if you want your fix of basic thai noodles for around 7 bucks you'll get what you're looking for. 

Service: This is what REALLY brought it down for me. Not only did it take forever for our order to be taken and for the server to realize four waters wouldn't be enough for six people, when the check arrived it was about 60 something... which we quickly realized is impossible when no one ordered anything above 9 dollars, even with tax and the 15% service charge already added. Somehow they added ten dollars to our bill. When my friend took it up to ask them about it, they just took the receipt and retyped it out without an apology. I get that you're all quite busy, but ten extra dollars on a bill that was only 50 dollars to begin with? Really? 

It was a Friday night dinner with friends, but I wouldn't recommend this place for a relaxing evening, really. Maybe if you're heading home from classes and really need a pad thai takeaway fix, it's good, but... the noise and slow, inattentive service really made it a place I was happy to leave.

Normally, I love Tealuxe, but lately I gotta say that I just haven't been able to deal with being there. Aside from no bathrooms and not enough seating, every time I've gone in for the last six months I've had to wait upwards of 15 minutes for a half-dozen college girls in front of me to get their froofy tea drinks. With a staff of 2-3 at most, usually moving at the speed of sea turtles, even with 4 people in front of me it's been an insane wait, and frankly, I'm a straight-up tea of the day girl.
