I do give them major points for the coconut green tea.

Small cozy space...great wall paper in the bathrooms.
Wonderful service. Say hi to John the owner.
Vibrant environments along with humble tasty food.
Late night menu as well.
Awesome bar...
Come here with a small group, or with 1 other friend...or just hit up the bar..
Always good food, and desserts with drinks! if anything a very humble environment and southern menu.//awesome corn bread and rice pudding... chicken dishes are great too!
I really don't know much about all of Espiau's plates...all I know is that the Espiau's salad with blue cheese dressing is amazing!!!!!! Yummmm.

I've had Hanami basically every other week for the past 5 years I've lived in College Park. They have the best rolls in the city of College Park, by far. However, I am giving them a 1 star review because they messed up my pick up order yesterday and the manager was extremely rude. They forgot one of the entrees in my order, yet she is the one acting like the victim. They offered me soup for my inconvenience (which already comes with the meal anyway. What the hell am I going to do with 2 miso soups?). Sorry, but a bowl of soup does not make up the fact that I had to spend 20 minutes on the phone and an extra 30 minutes for the delivery, after I had already waited and picked up my order. I have spent a lot of money at Hanami in the past, but will not be giving them any more of my business. Worst customer service I have experienced.

My husband and I were out shopping in SLO and decided to have a nice meal at Guiseppe's.  We had been to the one in Pismo Beach several times and had nice meals there.  This was the first trip to this restaurant. Ambiance was pleasant.  We don't get to go out to nice restaurants very often and we decided to splurge.

We were the first ones there for dinner at 5 pm.  We were seated at a booth and the server took our order.  I ordered butternut squash ravioli with shrimp and my husband ordered a pizza. The restaurant filled up quickly.  We sat and watched while everyone got their dinners while we sat there.  We had to ask for more bread, which was not very good.

We had to ask the water person twice what happened to our meals and our server.  Apparently he was helping a banquet in the other room.  When he finally showed up, he had to check with the chef where our meals were.  After everyone who sat around us had finished their meals, we finally got ours.  There were only three ravioli and the shrimp tasted like it had sat around and then was reheated in the microwave--overcooked.  The pizza was cold (apparently it was supposed to be but it did not say it on the menu) and was not very good.

We asked to talk to the manager and after a while, he appeared.  We told him how disappointed we were with the meal and the service.  He did not offer to do anything, he just wanted us to come back to give them another try.  When we got the bill, they subtracted one of our glasses of wine off the total.

We will NOT EVER be back and have told all our friends not to go there.  Extremely bad experience and the food was very disappointing. The whole experience lasted two and a half hours!  Do not go to this place--it has bad service and is overpriced for what you get!

Janice B.
A slice is bigger than your head!! Very tasty pizza and good prices.  3.25 for cheese and 5 and change to add a topping!! One slice is a feast, trust me!!! My favorite NY greasy yummy cheesy pizza!!

Store is a bit small, but mostly has all the fun tj things that I love. Wine, bread, great snacks, great prices, free samples... need I say more? Oh yeah, free parking and I'm quickly learning that in LA, this is a huge plus!

Some of the best deals: frozen green beans, mangoliscous frozen fruit, tapenade, wine, blister peanuts, prunes, cilantro salad dressing, hummus, bath/body products. 

And I love the cheese selection.  Stretches me a bit to pay $10lb. but I suppose compared to other stores, it's still a deal for high quality, fresh cheese.  

And did I say? Friendly staff!

This hole-in-the-wall place in the middle of a strip mall serves up some outstanding Mediterranean fare. It's a small family owned restaurant serving delicious food with a friendly smile. The place is packed during lunch, but come at night and there's no wait. I show up just before they close at 7PM.

I usually get the chicken shawerma plate. It's really moist dark and white meat cooked/marinated in some magical spice mixture. There's a very generous portion and it comes with rice, salad, hummus and pita. I've played with my food since childhood and like stuffing everything in the pita for a makeshift pita-wich.

Today I finally decided to try something different, the chicken kebab. I thought it might be on the dry side since it's white meat, but it's moist and tender! You get two large kebabs with their usual sides of rice, salad, hummus and pita bread. Eating this makes me feel healthier than the dark meat shawerma.

Ask for extra garlic sauce. I'm always too busy slathering it over everything to bother with the hot sauce. I'm sure that's good too though. Whatever you get, you'll leave satisfied and stuffed for less than $10. Excellent food, excellent value, excellent service.

Great independent movie theatre with a wide selection of non-blockbuster fims.  They do get packed, so make sure you get your tickets early.  It's a no-frills place, but does it's job in providing a good, clean environment to hang out in.  They have a parking lot with validation, but it can be a pain to get out of after the show; don't think you will just speed out of the lot after a show. I would tack on another 1/2 hour. Street parking is much better if you can find it.

I seem to be handing out the five stars today!

I stopped in here with a friend on the way back from lunch at the Earthen Jar- and was really surprised. I'd never been up here in my time in Ann Arbor- regretfully! I could definitely spend hours here going through the used CDs and the records. They seem to do a lot of re-selling. I also picked up a copy of the Kenna CD I was looking for.


Definitely drop by- very calm, very nice. I think they also specifically look for things for people if you ask, given the phone calls being made while I was there.

Wow, very nice.  The building itself looks like a historic mansion, and the facilities are beautiful.  When my taxi pulled up, a bellhop ran over and opened the door for me and took my bags.

The checkin staff was also very polite and helpful.  You get a chocolate chip cookie when you check in, which was cute, and the rooms were clean and well-maintained.  The decor was a bit more old-fashioned and quaint than your typical hotel, which fit with the whole mansion theme.

I was here for a conference, so I got to have some of the restaurant's catered food.  Very good, excellent all around.

I enjoyed my experience here, and would love to come back.  My only caveat is that I probably wouldn't stay someplace this nice (read, expensive) if it hadn't been for business.

Went in for a quick dinner last night.

This place is great.  Good food and super fast service.  I got the carnitas (pork) burrito bowl (a burrito with no tortilla made in a bowl).  It was delicious and satisfying.

The only thing I had a problem with was $.  It was $13 for food and a water.  Come on man.
I really like Bruno's. The pizza is great, the atmosphere is wonderful and the staff is always friendly.

First off, don't go to Blake's just for drinks or food.  If you sit at a table, you'll be waiting fifteen minutes before one of their clueless wait staff (hmmm, maybe there's a reason they call them a "wait" staff?) returns with your pitcher, and the food ain't all that either.  Additionally, many of the people you'll encounter there will be lame, just like Berkeley's night life scene in general.  The middle and top floors are just a mis-mash of college bar, Irish pub and TGI Fridays, minus any redeemable sense of excitement or flavor.

No sir, the only reason to ever come through Blake's is to see a show downstairs.  And basically, while their cover charges are steep ($10+), it's a pretty good time if you hit it on the right night.  The basement is divey in the extreme, the sound not-so-great and the drink specials non-existant, but at least there is a sense of some excitement and fun, which the upper levels lack completely.

I don't know if they still have the blonde rocker chick tending bar downstairs anymore or not, but she is just incredibly hot, and therefore singlehandedly raises my rating of Blake's by one star to a respectable 3.

I started going here back in high school, and even though its not a monthly trip like it was then, its still pretty much my favorite record store around.

The selection (in terms of diversity) is amazing...sure, I've been to better "rock" record stores, or "jazz" record stores, but PREX has it all. Any format you could want, and unless things have changed they used to have some laserdiscs tucked away somewhere. If you are a music fan (a REAL fan), I dare you to not spend at least $100. Can't be done. Even if you stick to the "budget" wall (around $2 a pop) you'll still spend the money.

The staff has changed a lot over the years, obviously, and its been up and down. Sure, you get the token uber-ironic, thick-rimmed glasses wearing Judge Of All Music (judgment = what you like sucks), but there have also been some really cool people there with great suggestions. It has been a while since I've gotten back here, and I've heard things have moved around and maybe the vinyl ain't what it used to be...sad if true, but I can't comment until I see it for myself.

The negatives aren't really the fault of the store...parking can be a royal bitch, and if you hang out in town at all you have to suffer some Princeton students, but all the obstacles make the destination just that much better, I suppose.
Really nice selection of fun jewelry at great prices. Highly recommend!

I wanted to be blown away by Salts but was a little underwhelmed. Perhaps it was the addition of beets to the entire Winter menu that threw me off. The food was wonderfully prepared and the service was incredible I just didn't leave thinking that Salts was the French inspired restaurant I was waiting for. 

It was also filled with Boomers. So that hurt its ratings a little.

Kip's is a part of my pre-game ritual I do before the Golden Bears take the field in Memorial Stadium.  I've been coming here with some regularity since I turned 21.  But what the hell happened to the cheap-ass pitchers?  I used to buy two pitchers for about ten bucks (including tip? I don't remember) and double fist them.  Now the pitchers are ordinary priced.

I give this place two more stars if the cheap pitchers would make a comeback.

Is there a secret room with handjobs & unicorns? If so, directions please...if not, damn, I must be missing something.

Everything's in good shape and appears new, but that's why it's whack. When I think independent bookstore, I think old, hard to find books, not standalone B&N or Borders. Book Culture is small yet wastes space, much like Columbia, bless its soul. Most importantly, this joint lacks charm (and adds creepy, leering employees) and is as pretentious as it sounds.

I had a late breakfast here with co-workers on Friday.  We looked at the menu outside and thought it was decently priced so we went in.  Now at this place you pay right before you leave, not when you order.  I was a little shocked when my order tallied up to almost $11.  All I had was pancakes, sausage, and orange juice.  The pancakes alone would have been about $4.  Pancakes with sausage was about $7.  So that means I was charged about $4 for the orange juice.  WTF?  Granted it came in a bottle (I was expecting a glass) but seriously?  $4?  There is no way that this meal should have totaled up to what it did.
one word: EW!

Great food, friendly, comfortable and nicely decorated dining room and gracious service! My "Book Club" had a "meeting" at Henry's this week and every dish we ordered was delicious and perfectly executed from a simple salad to an exquisite fruit "granita" to a rich and delicious cassoulet. One of our number is an exacting chef herself and she was impressed with each dish! Lovely to find such tasty food near campus! The server was attentive and helpful with good recommendations. And when there was an ordering mix-up the dish in question was "on the house"!

Kams, HQ of Bros and Slags. This place sucks it smells like vomit and alcohol. Literally, I saw someone puke on the floor and rather the employees cleaning it up everyone stepped on it and smeared it around, I guess that's called teamwork. Also, I truly believe they only sell one type of beer, Kam's special ale, which is disguised as other taps. Worst of all bros flock to this place like it's their own personal lek. So if your looking for place to get hammered, drink on the street its cleaner.

I will preface this by saying I was here on a Wednesday night in the summer with no college kids, so my opinion would probably change if I were to visit while college was in and there were a lot of students.  That said, this is a really cool dive bar with a surprisingly great beer selection.  Several NC beers on draft and a good mix of bottles too.  Prices are good too, got a Lonerider Sweet Josie for $3.75.

If I lived in Chapel Hill/Carrboro this is the kind of place I'd like to hang out at more often.  Also, as far as I could tell there's no restrictions on the use of credit cards.  My tab was under $10 and I was allowed to use a card. There's a whole bunch of signs hanging up about how they take credit cards now too.

Definitely a cool spot, but I'd be a little more hesitant when all the UNC kids are running around.

Gypsy's Trattoria Italiano is located within Asian Ghetto by UC Berkeley, so it's very convenient if you're looking for a quick bite. This place is constantly full of customers (mainly college students), so there might be a short wait during rushes.

I recommend the calzones and pasta plates. However, beware of their sauces! They're pretty rich, so be ready to food coma after eating here.

They also offer any entree, salad, and soda for $7.99. Good deal!!

I LOVE korean food so this place was a little disappointing. I had the bi bim bop and there was nothing bi or bim or bop about it. The ingredients didn't seem fresh and the service wasn't great either. 

It was CHEAP, i'll give it that much. But if it's just cheap korean food you want, then steve's korean bbq is just as good, just as cheap and closer to campus.
There is always people walking in and out of here. It's a hit or miss with the service. Once my sandwich was drenched is dressing which was gross and really messy, and other times it was perfect.

Surprisingly good menu. You'll have a hard time picking a burger cause they all sound great and most of them are. 
Their tacos are the dark horse of their menu. All of the tacos are fantastic and are guaranteed to fill you up. 
You'll hate yourself for eating it but love it while you're there.

I love this Ralphs for their Coffee Bean/free wi-fi seating area -- I haven't found a better place in the Westwood area to use my laptop than here (not being a UCLA student, I don't know the on-campus options y'all have). The lighting is great, there's convenient outlets for your laptop at the bar seating, and if you feel ill while writing your dissertation (my usual state of being), you can walk over into the pharmacy section and self-medicate. Now granted, you might begin to go crazy because it's right by the self check-out so you constantly hear an automated voice saying "please place the item in the bag" and "do you have any coupons?" over and over again while you're there -- but I love it.
How do they get away with it?

It's hard to go wrong with Jason's Deli.  I've been a fan of this restaurant even back in Dallas (it's one of the few mass franchises I that I'd willingly patron).  It's AYCE salad bar is $7.59 and includes fresh-cut vegetables, select organics, homemade potato and pasta salads, gingerbread muffins, garlic toast.  For $7.59 that's cheaper than most pay-by-the-pound hot food & salad bars in downtown DC.  Personally, I always get an extra serving of the egg salad as well as the pasta salad.  Like Jeffrey D. said, "no matter what you order, you get free soft-serve ice cream."  That's right, even if you got the cup of soup for $2.79 you can stuff yourself with complimentary muffins and soft serve.  And this is no ordinary soft-serve ... it's thick and creamy yet light and airy.  As far as salad bars, it's second only to the Sweet Tomato franchise (assuming you have the buy-one-get-one-free coupon).  [Original Visit: August 16, 2009]

this place is good until you realize that it's not the only italian restaurant in the world.

that changes things.

sometimes salty and often bland.

Wow, you guys are HARSH! How in the world can the ultra mediocre Bombay Coast in the Price Center get 4 stars when Hi Thai has only two? I wonder if it's because UCSD students are more familiar with Southeast Asian cuisine and therefore are more critical of it?

I'm not saying Hi Thai is brilliant -- keep in mind that they're an on campus eatery, and expectations are automatically lower -- but I think they're worth three stars ("A-OK" in Yelp-speak) for food, eating space, and convenience to my classes. And I'm adding an extra star to make up for all the haters.

I honestly think the food is rather tasty. I come here when I want a break or am craving some Asian food (Panda Express doesn't count...). I get more meat in my sandwiches here than I do at K Sandwiches, and I gotta say I prefer Hi Thai's (I'm going to get some haters for that comment). It's one of the cheapest meals you can get on campus, with a sandwich for approximately $4.08, including tax. 

Plus, their other dishes (say, curry chicken) provides a lot of food and are a great value -- more than most on-campus outlets. They've got a big variety of food -- sandwiches, rice dishes, fried noodles, noodle soups -- and I hear they're now serving breakfast (from 8am onwards). 

I'm not going to lie, I don't love everything on the menu. I dislike their bright-orange pad thai, their iced tea isn't great either. But the BBQ pork noodles are great. When I'm having a bad day I go for beef curry over rice, which comes with a small fried wonton (eh) and a green salad. Their coconut soup with tofu is an appetizer that works great as a light meal. Their meat isn't the highest quality, but I wouldn't say it's as atrocious as others put it out to be -- I've never had problems with the food quality here. 

They're open lateish -- till 9pm, and have ample space for studying and eating, including a study lounge complete with comfy chairs and a fireplace.

So there ya go. Hi Thai isn't high-class, it isn't going to knock your socks off, but it will feed ya and feed ya better than most places on campus.  You could do much, much worse at UCSD and it's the best Asian food choice - although Shogun does have beer...

I'm sad that this place is gone.  Jessica always did a great job and I never had a bad experience here.  No one ever reused water on me or made me feel the least bit uncomfortable.  Instruments were always taken right out of the sterile liquid holder.  The only thing I found annoying was when they would all speak in Vietnamese and I couldn't understand anything.  The girls here were always nice and would always fix something I was unhappy with.

I have to openly admit in this public forum that I LOVE this store and actually buy a lot of crap here, from clothing and accessories to home decor items, I love it all.

Urban Outfitters has some of the coolest stuff in the world, even their books are cool!  Whether you are looking for some cool home decor stuff to spice up that lame dorm room or a cool t-shirt to wear to the show tonight, you can find what you need at Urban Outfitters.

I have bought sheets, wall art, rugs, bedspreads, books, clothing and so much more here.  I have spent a ridiculous amount of time and money here and it has all been worth it.  The prices are fair, the selection is fun and unique and the service is responsive without being annoying. 

Overall, this is a great store to get cool gifts, stay up on the latest trends and to outfit your life and your home with the coolest and neatest stuff around.  Oh, and you can do all that without breaking the proverbial bank.

We took my sister here for her birthday and it was perfect. 
About a year ago, my husband and I heard bad things about the service at Hungry Mother so we hesitated. Word must have gotten back to the restaurant because every person we interacted with at the restaurant was genuinely friendly. 

I'm not a mixed drink person by habit but the ones here are delicious and not so heavy on the alcohol that I would wake up in a strange city. 

The food, very tasty and good portions: not annoyingly tiny and not over-the-top huge. 

Reservations are hard to get. You need to call a week or more in advance in most cases, but we were seeing a movie at the Kendall afterwards so got a table for 4 at 5:45 without any trouble. And making the meal even better, we told the host what movie we were seeing and they picked up the tickets for us while we ate, at a discount. 

The movie? Not so great but at least we had a great meal.
The Winery is a great shop -- reasonable prices, great selection.  I wish they'd open a wine bar!

This is a terrific music store that really fits in with the rest of SLO. It's survived through some chain records stores that are no longer in business, and can hold its own alongside chains like Best Buy and Wal-Mart. 

It's all about the service and selection, and its customers can be finicky about a wide variety of music. Especially in a college town like SLO, Boo Boo Records fills an important vacuum of catering to people with tastes beyond mainstream music like me. 

And records...plenty of records, both new and used, and several different turntables! Not to mention, CD's, music magazine, t-shirts, and much more.

Also, the store has always had a friendly and knowledgeable staff who really are passionate about music. If the store doesn't have what you're looking for, just ask; the music may be ordered for you.

Again, great and vital independent record store.

I will always remember Earls and it has earned a special place in my liver. I knew about Earl's when my older brother told me about this place called Earl's that had this crazy lady bartender who poured them stiffer than Tiger's golf chub. 

Hmm I thought, he really means what he is saying about that place. Then years later, when I was home for break, my UW friend said Im gunna take you out uw style. I mean I showed the place who is boss, and got wasted. I then did it any other time I was home for break.

I semi-recently went to Earl's on a Sunday when it wasn't so busy. I sat alone in the corner and marveled in the thought of the partying souls it embraces without judging.

This is the second time I've eaten at this place. I don't know why... it's close, I guess.
It's called "Chicago Pizza." Lets discuss why this is a dumb title.

Frist of all, its in Cambridge, not the windy city. If anyone has ever had Chicago pizza... it is nothing like this. Chicago pizza is almost always deep dish, and can get to be more like a stew or a pie. Third of all, I'm not even sure this stuff is pizza... the dough/crust is more like a croissant. Fourth, this place has a huge menu, and pizza takes up TWO ITEMS: Cheese and 'specialty'... the rest of the menu is stricly non-pizza. And the LAST reason this is a dumb name, the folks who own and run "Not Chicago Not Pizza" are, as far as I can tell, not Chicagoans. There are pictures of the mediterranean, and they all speak with heavy accents. Not "da bearz" accents, either.

Now that we've established that Eastern-European Schmorgesboard is not Chicago or Pizza, lets highlight the other features of this dump: flourescent lighting gives me a headache, withered and dead plants in ugly vases make me depressed, the counter-area is littered with random pieces of paper with items and prices on them, walls are plain with fake wood paneling along the bottom, seating is hard and yellow...

That being said the pizza was not all that bad, the flaky crust made it interesting, and the flavors were pretty good. Also, the pieces are huge, so you get a lot of bizzang for your bizzuck.


This is no Presto's... don't go out of your way to get here.

I stayed here for 2 nights with my family to help my sister move out from her dorm at UCSD to her apartment which happened to be a 10-15 minute walk from the hotel. The hotel seems to be quite small from the outside but that wasn't a problem at all. One of the front desk staff, Molly, who help my family (my parents can understand some English, but not advanced levels) and I check into the hotel was very courteous and enthusiastic which really helped me translate some information to my parents.

Did not have much problems with the hotel. However some advices to help those who might want to stay at this hotel. Location is extremely convenient to UCSD and if you are worried about the price, there's always priceline. Refrigerators (since my family bought refrigerated food) and coffee pot are complimentary, but you have to ask (well, that's what they offered when we asked).

I read some reviews about the fees for parking in their lot. You know, there is FREE parking outside and around the hotel. At one point, we managed to park our car across the hotel that from our room on the 12th floor, we could see and monitor it. 

O yes, there's an outdoor swimming pool and jacuzzi. The swimming pool temperature was appropriate. One thing worth swimming is if the weather was really nice and warm. But when it's cold, imagine trying to get out of the pool without shivering down to your bones.

Finally, we had access to the Hyatt Regency Club up on the 16th floor. Complimentary continental breakfast, afternoon snacks, and evening hor d'oeuvres, not a bad idea for my family who decided to eat the hor d'oeuvres as dinner. Selection was alright. Too bad, alcohol isn't free.

Not much I can say that hasn't already been said, but oh my, the rack of lamb was delicious. It really was amazing to me how much I loved it. Highly recommended. My friend really loves the foie gras there as well.

To me, this place is more about the experience and decore than the food. The unique burger names and posters make it a Cambridge "to do." 
As for the food, I don't find it to be anything special. The burgers are made in a variety of ways, and the food I've had there is fairly above average. However, the burgers are small and somewhat lacking. It's a place to show people, but not a go-to.

A-OK

I mean what more can you expect? This is Indiana.

I am from California where there are way way way better Vietnamese food, however, my Purdue friend suggested to have a Vietnamese dinner, so we walked here from her house. She is Korean. but she loves Pho.

I think Vietnamese customers would not likely to like this place, especially my parents, well, the restaurant seems to have lots of non-Asian customers.

Overall, the pho does not taste so bad at all.

cuchi cuchi is super cool. i am sad this was my first time there out of the couple years i've been in boston! the art nouveau theme inside is amazing, with stained glass windows, art nouveau paraphernalia, a gorgeous bar and costumed flapper waitresses.

so the night begins - randomly see 2 of my friends who ended up there too! we all wait 2.5 hours for a table annnnd ask the very stressed out waitress and hostess if our table is ready yet. the bar was SUPER packed, so i was afraid to get a martini beverage so i wouldn't spill it everywhere by someone knocking into me. (the drink menu was very interesting by the way, yummy fruity cocktails).

i've learned that you can't get drunk while waiting for a table at cuchi cuchi, because you need to stay sober-ish to keep following up about your table...everyone is hawking for a table. chaos. crankyness.
that's what happens when you have a restaurant that doesn't take reservations! huge pet peeve of mine. c'mon, don't be lazy! just space out dining at 1.5 hrs and go for it. not too hard!!!

waiting for a table was stressful and annoying, and even though the ambiance was so cool, there were too many people waiting for a table by the bar and not enough waitstaff...which sucks! 

once we were sat much later FINALLY, our waitress was super nice and funky and the delicious tapa-style food, unlike the wait, came out pretty fast! impressive.

so, overall sum up is that cuchi cuchi is awesome. i was majorly pissed about the long table wait i practically ate the napkin out of starvation when i sat down. i realllly wish they fixed this, and then i will give them 5 stars!

Two days ago, I was seeking shelter from the heat over by Georgia Tech. I needed somewhere to sit, cool down, and feed my hunger. 

After pish-poshing this sandwich place in comparison to f2O, I sat down here by myself. I ate my words, and my sandwich in shame. 

It was cheap and great. The service is good, and I might just choose it over a Subway. Their minimum delivery is ONE sandwich, which is awesome. 

I'm a huge fan that they will serve any sandwich in a lettuce wrap (Unwich). I never go to sub places because I can't get over the carbs. Sad but true concerns, folks. 

Anyway, They only serve their own brand of kettle-style chips, and even the reduced fat taste really great. I'm telling you, it's the little things that make these places different from their competitors. 

I kind of wish this place were more "original", but I'll settle with their sammaches for a while.

I think this is a fantastic place, as does the entire population of Cal and their mothers apparently. The place is always packed and if you can stomach the long line (it once went to American Apparel when I was there), it is a sure bet!

I find self-serve to be great given that I am really inconsistent in my sweet tooth cravings. Sometimes I just want a truck full of frozen yogurt and other times I just want a few spoon-fulls, okay? I love that it can accommodate both whenever I want to! 

Tart and cheesecake are the best, seriously. The frozen yogurt does melt a bit quickly by the way!

Desserts, freaking huge!  Dang good price for the size.  My date and I ordered a Tres Leches that we split.  It was so very rich, that we each had about 3 bites and took the rest to go.  He took a 1/3 while I took 2/3 to give each of my girls a taste.  They could barely eat more than 2 or 3 bites themselves.

I also had a cappuccino.  The cappuccino came with a soft gingerbread cookie (if I would have known that, I probably would have skipped ordering the cake).  The cookie was to die for.  I don't like the hard, crunchy ginger snap cookies.  This one was perfect with the cuppa.  

My date had a mocha latte.  He said it was ok.  I personally do not like any flavorings in my coffee, so I didn't even bother to taste, as I would not have liked it, no matter how good it was.

Shrimp tacos were fantastic.  We had fruit salad with the tacos.  The fruit was nice and fresh, not mushy at all.

The Black bean, goat cheese, and bacon soup was pretty tasty.  A little too pureed for our taste, but the flavor was there.  

We also had an order of the Warm Baked Texas Goat Cheese Salad with shrimp.  This was very good.

The food and service are very mediocre. My friend and I split an Irish panhandle skillet and chicken avocado club. The killer was excessively greasy and bland, but the sandwich was okay. Nothing amazing but edible enough. Portions are pretty big though. It came to about $20 before tip. The French toast that my friend ordered and I stole a few bites of was nicely crispy yet soft simultaneously. I haven't tried the homemade veggie burger yet but have heard good things about it. A decent enough option for a diner in the area I suppose. Oh wait...it's the only option. But nevertheless, come here if you are looking for brisk service and greasy diner food. Me?  I'm driving to cracker barrel or skylark for my brunch fix.

I just went to this place for the 1st time & can't wait to go back again.  It is delicious.  I got the chickpea fritter pita and the rosemary french fries with a lavendar lemonade all for just $10.  Amazing!!!

Lived here for six months.  Great concierge staff.  Very friendly  rental office.  Maintenance crew is very responsive.  They get a five-star for the people.  Also excellent location for attending school at MIT or work near Kendall Square.  

However, razor thin walls and front doors makes the place almost unbearable..  You will hear the banging of medicine cabinets and closets all day long and the vents on the roof during the summer, not to mention the conversations of your neighbors.  Inefficient bathroom vent systems so hope not to get a smoker as your neighbor (up, down or sideways).  They are also charging a premium for being close to MIT so prepare for the steep rental prices.  No grocery store, drug store, or any other convenience shops anywhere nearby.  Very inconvenient.  However, there's always the T nearby to get you back to civilization.  Finally, there are no storage units.  For these reasons, I give a 2-star.  If I see improvements I will be happy to up my rating.

I had the most horrible experience at this restaurant yesterday when our family went for their all-you-can-eat sunday sushi buffet. After I finished two plates, the owner lady came to our table and literally said "didn't you have enough already?" My jaw dropped and I became speechless. I totally lost my appetite and was very upset. We stopped our meal, expressed our anger, and left the place quickly. During that process, she apologized for the remark once, but still had the nerve to charge a full 15% tip on our bill. Thank you, sushi.come, for completely ruining our Sunday family lunch. You will never see a penny from me and my friends in the future.

Cambridge 1 is a super sleek, bordering on cold, fancy schmany pizza joint, without the fancy attitude. The pizza is delicious but don't ocme here expecting NY/Chicago/Italian-style pizza. The pies are inventive and borderline strange. I love the potato-fontina-rosemary and the pepperoni. Do yourself a favor and get two half-pizzas (no extra charge for ordering halves, from what I recall) to split between two people. Feeling like you need a healthy meal? Order a delicious salad to go with the pie. Don't expect a circular pizza; they arrive at the table as unsliced squares. It takes some getting used to.

The beer selection is small but thoughtful; same goes for the wine. Service can be a little abrupt but the restaurant gets damn busy and the waitstaff keeps up the pace. Don't be surprised if two (or three) different waiters come around to your table; they all seem to run around helping each other out. 

Parking sucks but it's Harvard Square, what do you expect? Prices are reasonable. My only complaint is that you can get stuck seated with another couple at one of the large booths. That really kills a date.

DO NOT USE the self check out machines here. They're always broken AND even though the machines accept cash, they don't give you change back. You have to wait FOREVER for a person to slowly wobble over and fumble with the key.

Great service, good margaritas - wait staff is great.  Manager is an ass, and the chips and rice and beans follow in his personality.  We sampled the chips and rice and beans before deciding if we "should stay or we should go".  Some of the worst chips I've had the displeasure of tasting in a very long time... but given how bad Daisy Bakers turned out to be, we probably should've stayed here and enjoyed some good margaritas with maybe bread?  Food did not look appealing, and really, the rice and beans were terrible.  Nice staff.  but they wanted $30.00 for a shot of Don Julio 1942 - you don't pay that much at the Intercontinental in Boston... Nice try guys, but you are over priced, the manager behind the bar was very unpleasant and the food is terrible.  Not returning either...

Dibi, dibi and only dibi.
This a regular haunt of mine, and all I ever eat is dibi - delightfully smoky flavored grilled lamb with a mildly spicy sauce. Its wonderful. The service is terrible, it could use a renovation and what the hell is updtairs in this building? However, I love it. I've traveled throughout  Africa and it feels and tastes authentic. Get over yourselves and try it!

Good for groups and everyone was raving about the $2.99 margs during the week, but the food was pretty bland. 

I would never go back for the food, but it probably wouldn't be a bad place to happy hour it up!

this is by far the best restaurant I've been to in San Diego!  the interior is dimly lit and busy on Saturday nights.  it's best to make a reservation ahead.  first off,  you get a complimentary basket of bread with two spreads.  the bread was soft, warm, and fresh out of the oven.  it was so good I was trying so hard to stop eating it, since I was starting to feel full.  but thankfully, the main course arrived.  the filet mignon I ordered was melt in your mouth orgasmic way better than sex any day :) cooked to perfection.  the cut was thick and juicy, and presented delightfully on the plate.  I can't stop thinking about this place.   oh and the creamed spinach was a perfect pairing!  our waiter was good looking and charming.  he provided excellent service to match the expectations i had of the place.  I definitely will be back for the happy hour menu: 5 appetizers for $6 until 7pm.

I get a severe case of wanderlust every time I merely look at this store. It's torture to even walk by during the times when I'm entrenched in my worklife with no holidays on the horizon. Yesterday I allowed myself to enter, beckoned by the coffee table sized atlases and whispers from Lonely Planets. Great historical books, maps of all sorts and travel books for even the most exotic of locations. The staff was helpful and knew the products well though I didn't find the detailed neighborhood map that I sought. So I left empty handed, with a head full of Cambodia dreams. I'm hoping it will be #26 on my 30 countries by my 30th birthday list.

With Houston weather you never know what to expect but on those nice sunny days, this park is awesome! i enjoy the enviorment and the atmosphere of everyone there.

alot of friendly people, very clean park :)

high recomend on those nice beautiful houston days :-)

I am a fan of CPK and have been for a while seeing as how I grew up on it. Im writing this review because of the service not the food. Infact, we basically got no service. I called at 3 pm for an after lunch rush pickup order. Me and a buddy ordered a sandwich, salad, and two appetizers. Some guy took our order, but seemed either clueless or new to the job. He re-read our order to me, took down my phone number and everything, told us to pick it up at 3:30...so I thought it'd be legit...little did I know!
We get there, go to the back where take out orders are...wait 5 min for someone to come and ask us about our order...said she didnt have it in the computer and went to go check on it in the office or something.  10 minutes later she comes back and reconfirms that there is no order....ridiculous. Never ever should a restaurant be so clueless to something like that. She asked if we wanted to wait for it...definitely not. 
Walked a block to whole foods and got a sandwich instead. saved 20 bucks tho! thanks for at least that cpk!

These three stars are for the Pumpkin beer.  It is very tasty and it is my favorite part of the season.  A few friends and I shared a tower of it (100 ounces) and were shocked to find it was only $28bucks. I was pleasantly surprised to find that the tower stayed relatively cool for the entire time. Delightful!

The food it okay.  It's not mind-blowing and it's not all that terrible.... Okay. Except for the mussels. The mussels were questionable - like they'd been sitting there for quite some time and bland as all get out.

The service wasn't bad.  It was pretty busy - but our server was around, inconsistently so.  She popped up before we were ready to order and didn't come back around for at least twenty minutes.  It's okay...we weren't in a rush.

For my future visits to the CBC, I'll eat elsewhere and have a nice big tower of beer.

I really wanted to love Louis, because, well, everyone else seems to....but ugh, sick city.
I literally felt like I had just stepped out of the Twilight Zone when left Louis, but I don't think the sick feeling I had for 2 days after was from time travel. I think it was from the memories of the mayonaise caked burger or some fallen residue off the 50 year old blackish-brown (once white) apron worn by a strange staff member. 
Loved the outside and inside Art work, appreciate the old school quirky vibe, but when someone is at your table every 45 seconds removing a straw wrapper or the plate you are eating your sandwich over (while still eating said sandwich), its time to accept the fact that you just can't hop on this bandwagon. Not to mention, the food, unfortunately, just wasn't good.
All I kept thinking after leaving was,damn, I should have and wish I would have, gotten totally sh!* faced before going to Louis. Maybe then, and only then, I could like it too...

Ugh.  I regret eating here.  Being a Japanese-American, I should be ashamed to even admit that I ate here.  This place sucks.  If you want ramen, head over to Little Tokyo, or just go to 7-11 and pick up a Cup o'Noodles.  I would have rather ate across the street at Yoshinoya.

Worst. Ramen. Ever.

At least I ate and didn't get sick.  I usually don't write about places I don't like, but people need to know that this isn't Japanese food.  Why are there so many crappy places to eat around USC?  It costs like $5 million just to attend that school.

The only dish I've tried a number of times is the chicken bowl with either white or brown rice.  The prices listed on the menu do not include taxes.  For a bowl it's about 5.36 + tax.  A plate is about 7.56 + taxes.  To be honest, I think that Gushi, which is located around the corner, has plates that are better priced. A BBQ chicken at Gushi includes a bed of rice, salad, kimchi and a beverage for $8 dollars.  I think that the best deals at Flame Broiler are the bowls.  Flame Broiler happens to also be conveniently located juxtaposed to Stan's donuts to satisfy anyone with a sweet tooth.

Earls Tuesdays & Thirsty Thursdays on the Ave, if you're looking for a college atmosphere, this is the spot to go!  From pool tables, good music, stiff and cheap drinks this place covers it. Whether you're looking for a chill night or to let loose come to Earls on the Ave!

Compared to Chipotle, this place is mediocre. You seem to receive more ingredients at Chipotle than Freebirds. You also get better portions. I will say, however, that the food is relatively inexpensive.

I could care less about the free, fun vibe of this place too. I suppose that it's a good place if you want a quick bite, but I would always go to Chipotle over this joint.

Specializes in child and adolescents. My daughter saw her for a year that cost us $20,000. She was unable to make a diagnosis and the situation dramatically worsened. She claimed that, "she was the best and that if she couldn't make a diagnosis, no one could". It was a very unpleasant experience.
Since then she has seen someone else who has been able to make a treatable diagnosis. 
Her laughable claim of "being the best" is just shameless self promotion.

Ever since we moved into our new apartment right down the street from this place, my roommates and I have been dying to try it. So we decided that we should go for my birthday dinner a few nights ago, and absolutely fell in love with it!

The food was really unique and flavorful; the portions were so large, we took home three boxes of leftovers. We ordered the queso, stuffed jalapenos, Strogonoff, and El Burro Grande. The Strogonoff was by far the table favorite, although everything else was really delicious.... they even have their own house fried chips for the queso. We ended the meal with a free (and enormous) slice of Tres Leches cake for the occasion. Yum.

A word of warning to the weak of tounge- the stuffed jalapenos were a bit too spicy for me, but my roommates both enjoyed them. 

Our waiter was super friendly and helpful, not even thinking twice about bringing three extra plates and forks for our family style dinner, and was very attentive and polite.

The atmosphere is very warm and dark, and would probably make a good place to take a date.

Overall, we had a very good experience here, it was a little pricey, but definitely worth it if you're looking for a treat!

Awesome inventory of not-so useful stuff. It's expensive because it's in Harvard Sq and it's a boutique gift store. I always find unique and cool gifts there and it's a great compliment to the Harvard retail culture. The staff have consistently been kind and helpful.

Nothing like getting your weight in lettuce and bread for just about $5.oo.
Typical Berkeley student feeding ground- super fresh, super good and dirt cheap.

This church is absolutely breathtaking. The stained glass throughout is enough to move you to tears. 

You can walk in for free (or give a donation) to see the main floor of the cathedral. You can also pay for a tour and get to see a lot more than you'd otherwise be able to.

Its a wonderful place to go visit even if it is just to enjoy the beauty and art of it. Plus there is a park right nearby so its a lovely way to spend a day. I've already told a bunch of my friends that they have to come visit it with me to see it.

A half soup/salad/panini lunch special combo is $6.50 at Y2E2.
Coupa-Green Library has the same thing for $5.00.

Granted you do have the amenities of indoor seating and "waiter service" consisting of people delivering your food in exchange for your tag number.

Always a huge line/wait during peak lunch hours so either get their early or be prepared to hold off on chomping in. Their sandwiches are always solid and the tomato bisque (when they have it) is great! Their small coffee is usually more than enough to give me a caffeine kick for the afternoon.

This place has the best breakfast potatoes I have ever ever tasted and for this they get 5 stars!!! I had a bacon, egg and potato burrito and it is soooo good!!!

I should give them 4 stars since they messed up my to-go order and generally i would not care, but I got it for breakfast before work and noticed when I was already on the clock in. So that kinda sucked!

L'Elizabeth is the perfect place to impress a date or charm friends from out of town.  The high-backed leather chairs and antique settees bring you back to another era, and even mundane conversation becomes magical over flickering candlelight.

The first time I went to L'Elizabeth I had a similar experience to the previous reviewer.  We had a couple of drinks and a piece of apple pie, and were shocked by our $80 bill!  However, I've since gone back and had great experiences - you just have to order something with a predictable price and not get carried away.

I recommend trying their alcohol-enhanced coffees or sipping an aperitif. If this is your first time and you're on a low budget, they have a few beers as well.  If you're there at a quiet time of day, I do not recommend getting wine by the glass - when I have done so it's tasted a bit old. Nor do I recommend the desserts, which were saran-wrapped and pricey.  However, neither of these shakes my belief that everyone in Providence should give this lovely place a try!

It's usually moderately empty (which is great for a romantic date) but fills up after theater and other events. Street parking is usually easy to find around here.

rated 4.5 stars

the first time i came here... i was with some friends and then girlfriend (now wife). we didn't know how to order so we were standing around the doorway looking at the menu. the only worker there (who was doing the grill) yelled out  "if you're not going to order... get the f out of my doorway." we jus looked at each other confused and shocked. we continued to look at the menu trying to see what we wanted.  he then shouted "are you guys deaf!... get the F out of my doorway!!" so we finally ordered and then asked for 2 drinks (didn't specify what kind). he was like.. "are you going to tell me which kind or do i have to be a f-ing mind reader." WHAT A FREAKIN JERK! 

but you know what... SCREW YOU MR. TOP DOG DUDE!... I LOVE the links here. The original top dog, hot link and kielbasa were my favorites. my least favorite was the lemon chicken. I can't wait to go back and try some others.
I'm not a vegetarian and I love this place! The flavors are flavored just like meat dishes so the veggie dishes taste great. I love the eggplant and tofu dish.

So I first got this food when I lived in the dorms and needed something to eat at night.  This place delivers til very late, I don't really know the times but I believe they deliver til 1:30AM on Fri and Sat, and 12:30AM on the other days.

I've been to Jose Bernstein about 10 times, and I've almost ALWAYS got the Monster JB burrito.=.  It's a 6-7 dollars burrito that is MASSSSSIVE.  Imagine the Chipotle burger, and now resize it to 150%.  That's what you get.  In it comes with chicken, carne asada, sour cream, beans, rice, a lot of other stuff, and in the end, BBQ sauce.  I know, it seems kind of weird, but it's a good addition!

So it's not the most authentic Mexican food, BBQ sauce on burrito? Kalbi Burritos? But does it matter for a cheap college students looking for a delicious large bite?

I've heard good things about all the other stuff, but if you're a big eater, the Monster JB is the way to go.

When I was a student at a nearby university, Koreana was probably my favorite cheap-eats place on campus. Pretty much everything on the menu is under $10, and I really enjoyed the food served. The restaurant isn't very big, and the set-up is such that you order and pay for your food at the register, grab a table, and wait for your food to be brought out. 

Since I generally prefer rice dishes over noodles, I usually ordered bi bim bap and some of the other stone pot-based rice dishes served at Koreana. I was particular fond of the Dol Sot Bulgogi, which is rice, bulgogi, kimchi vegetables, and a fried egg, all served in a hot stone pot. The rice that makes contact with the stone pot becomes really nicely charred, especially if you let it sit in the pot for a minute or two after it's served. 

I guess the one downside to Koreana is that, unlike larger Korean restaurants, there is no full complement of banchan (little side dishes), which is one of my favorite aspects of dining at Korean establishments. Instead, each meal comes with a small container of kimchi. 

Koreana serves good food at reasonable prices. These qualities make it an appealing dining option for the local college crowd, particularly because there are so many Korean students and so few nearby Korean restaurants. While not life-changing, Koreana's food will certainly satisfy a Korean craving, so if you're looking for a quick, cheap, and, most importantly, good meal, than you should check out Koreana.

This is one of the best haircuts I've ever had, if not the best- which doesn't usually say much since 99% of my lifetime haircuts have been homemade, over the bathroom sink mishaps, but this haircut is so nice I don't want to hide it up in my usual rat's nest of a ponytail. 

The price was definitely friendly ($15!! That means you have room to leave a great tip if they do ya right), but the services offered seem as though they would vary from visit to visit. Example: The woman to my left got the most gorgeous shampoo/style that everyone stopped momentarily out of awe, I some cute layers that made me no longer look homeless, and the girl to my right got some haircut she was dissatisfied with, but the instructor fixed it to her liking. We had different hair types (curly, thick-and-hobo-ish, fine) so you never know which student might respond best to your hair needs. Also, I didn't get any lip touchup or tea (the gorgeous hair lady was offered some tea) but I did get the mini-facial along with my cut and style, and I was in and out of there without any extra waiting.

If you're as awkward as I am at making conversation with your hairdresser, take advantage of the magazine rack next to the check-in area, because you'll likely be in there for a while.

I was this close to a moving, growling, feathery baby t-rex. Yes, feathery. They have this dinosaur encounter thing, and it was a big puppet roving around and looking at us like we were lunch. And yes, I was definitely entertained for the whole five minute show. 

Anyway, I've been to the science center so many times, but never thought to come here! Well, so I went, and then came back. It wasn't nearly as interesting as the science museum.

BUT, it was a good way to kill two hours or so. Looking at all those skeletons of animals, some that still exist, and some that don't anymore, and looking at stuffed animals, of some that still exist, and some that don't exist, is fun, but only for so long. Plus you have to walk the whole time. AND it was really cold in some of the rooms (and now, I knew this, so I took a sweater, but my fingers were still cold)

I don't foresee myself going back for another year or five, but I think it is definitely worth a visit. 

I feel like I've rambled enough now.

Famous Lunch has been a Downtown Troy institution since the 1920s serving those tiny hot dogs with the zippy sauce. Two bites each, pop, and done! I enjoy getting 6 with the works to go! 

My old man used stop here during his high school years back in the 1950s when the hot dogs at Famous Lunch were only a nickel. The Hot Dog Charlie's aka "the hairy arm" nearby charged double, a dime for their mini dogs.

Recently, I had to pick up my "semi-famous" sister from the train station and the first thing she said was, "I'm starving! Drive me to Famous Lunch." We picked up a dozen tiny hot dogs with the works and some fries, dinner served to go! Delish!

For a chinese restaurant they really have a uniquely WRONG recipes. Most of their recipes either give you too little for the price or overload it nasty nasty crap.
Pad Thai - Noodles are bad and recipe is messed up.
Lo Mein - Comes out to varied had it only once where it was good
Kung Pow - Was ok not bad but not enough meet overloaded with veggies
Sushi (Rainbow Roll) used only 3 of the 6 parts of a rainbow roll tuna, salmon and ____(forgot) also the 3 they used were bland and the recipe for the rice mixture was all wrong. 
AND WHAT KIND OF ASIAN RESTAURANT MESSES UP FRIED RICE 99.99% OF THE TIME!
ETC........

Not recommended unless your drunk and desperate.

I recently went to Nine Irish Brothers to watch a World Cup game...and ended up being pleasantly surprised.  Inside the pub is welcoming and clean, the food was fantastic, and the service great and not over the top like some places.  Even my vegetarian friends love to eat here!

I have been to a few other places in this little downtown area of Clairemont, and I've always left feeling kinda MEH, you know? But a friend and I walked into Back Abbey, and I felt like I departed Clairemont and entered a little hole-in-the-wall, Sicily.

We took a couple stools at a table made for 8, sharing it with 6 other diners, and hooked our purses under the bar.  Yes, there are little hooks under the bar for one to hang one's purse--automatic 5 stars!  I had a tall glass of Paulaner [mmm] and ordered a Turkey burger.

After half of my GINOURMOUS turkey burger and my 1 tall glass of ale, I was giggling and giddy.  I went to the restroom and was madly in love with the design.  When they created The Back Abbey you can tell they had one thing in mind: intimacy. Lots of intimacy.  You'll see what I mean when you dine here.

Loved the community sinks--an opportunity to rub elbows with some cute guy who believes in hygiene.

I have much affection for you, Back Abbey.  Thou doth rockith my socksith.

I don't live in Champaign, but whenever I come to visit my boyfriend, I HAVE to come here (usually more than once). They keep a variety of flavors (my favorites are red velvet cake and original tart), and you can mix and match as many as you like (as it's all pay-by-the-weight). The topping bar includes everything from cereal to fresh fruit, cheesecake bits to mochi balls. 

The decour is wacky and fun, and the staff is friendly enough....but the yogurt would make it worth it no matter what!!!

OMG. I discovered this rather late in my UW career, but late is better than never!

In the beginning, you could get a burger (huge burger) and fries (lots of fries) for about $5. The prices have raised very slightly, considering I've been going here 10yrs, it's not bad at all.

Question: Does anyone remember how they used to have this oil at the pick-up counter that you can use to sprinkle on your fries? They took that away years ago, and I suppose you don't need more oil on your fries, but this oil(!) it was really good. I should probably ask them this but I feel like it was a myth because it was sooooo long ago.

You're here for the burgers, I've had their chicken burger (which was a breaded patty, fakey thing..back in my no red meat phase) but have pretty much stuck with bacon cheese burgers...or "bacon cheeeeeee" like how they say it. It's adorable. It's a bacon chee and "eff eff" (for FF = french fry).

Then you seat yourself until they call your order, which can be either your number or order item..then it gets confusing but you will get served quickly. There are water cups that still have a slight taste of soap on them but I don't mind it...it means it's clean right? There is also hot tea, but I won't go near the stuff until it's 60degrees.

It can be busy during prime lunch, so I aim for a little before or after. If I'm with someone I'll moochy mooch a few fries from them to put in my burger. Yes, I put fries in my burgers!

I've tried their chicken and pork katsu and teriyaki too, they've been tasty, but you're reeeeeeeally here for a burger, so get to it.

PS: There is a minimum charge if using card. I think it's $5-6.

The softest most comfortable pieces in my closet ; pants , house hoodie and hoodie ! Thank you UNCL ! 
Girls , wear the black house hoodie or t shirt with pearls ; tres chic !

This used to be my favorite Thai place. Sure, the food was inconsistent: sometimes the peanut sauce was too sweet, sometimes the 4 star wasn't even spicy, but nothing too horrible. Last night changed my mind. I ordered 2 of my favorite dishes: Shrimp Pad Thai and Drunken Noodles. It was the worst Thai food I've ever had. Worst than Thai food at a mall in the Midwest. The Pad Thai was dry- the shrimp was way overcooked and the noodles were flavorless. The drunken noodle was worse. It was weirdly sticky, appeared to lack sauce, and was frankly, inedible. I ended up throwing them out, because I didn't feel like driving the 12 miles round trip back to the U-District to complain. I guess I am going to have to find a new Thai place.

I can't believe I'm the first to review Dr. Adams and his team. Dr. Adams has been in business for over two decades and has treated our son's teachers' children here in Palo Alto. As a coincidence I was talking to one today who  had her daughter go to Dr. Adams over 20 years ago and still swears by him.  His office is completely set up to be for pediatric dentistry like no other.

When our son was 2 he hadn't been to the dentist yet and his pediatrician recommended Dr. Adams and his associates. They are so patient, gentle, and understanding. The office is set up with children in mind: sinks are at their level, they have TV's embedded in the ceiling and your kid has a choice of videos to watch during treatment. Each room has a large fish tank with colorful tropical fish.

For the first exam, they take their time and don't force anything with your child. Exams and cleanings are done with a toothbrush and fingers; not the scary equipment you might expect. They spent a good deal of time making it a positive experience for your child and developing a relationship with your child as the patient.

I only wish that other pediatric health care specialists were as good as Dr. Adams and his team. Even my husband doesn't want to miss my son's dentist appointments because it is a fun adventure for parents and child.

Oh, and getting an appointment is easy too. We were able to get it within 2 days of calling, which is great.

I've been waiting to write a sober review of this place but I don't think that's ever going to happen. So! if you are drunk and on your way home, go here. You can even go by yourself if have skinny friends who don't eat pizza at 2 am. Hi Fi is a good sport.  They are selfless giver's of delicious pizza at all hours of the night. And I agree that their slices magically deter really terrible hangover's.

So remember, this is a time sensitive review- please don't go there at say- noon and write a review about how they suck and then refer to my review in your review (and then perchance misquote me by declaring to quote me- but never really "quoting" me). All hypothetical of course.

I went to Veggie Plant for Sunday brunch. We chose this restaurant because I'm vegan, and brunch can be one of the more challenging meals to have out- usually everything has egg or cheese somewhere! I was really impressed by the number of choices I had on the menu. In addition to all of the regular vegan options, they can modify almost everything on the menu to be vegan!

I had the waffle of the week (ginger), and it was glorious. I can't remember the last time I had a waffle. The homefries were pretty cold, but they were tasty none the less. 

The place was just about full- it was pretty crowded and tough to get around, but I don't think it detracted from our meal. I kinda liked the hustle and bustle. The waitstaff were really friendly, and food came out fast, and they had some nice live music.

Back Abbey Burger + Fries + 750 mL Dark Beer = Happy Marlon

I love coming here alone after work just to chill and have dinner...

Outdoor seating is the best!

maybe it's just nostalgia, i've been coming to this place my whole life, but i really can't think of a better burger.  juicy, messy as hell damn tasty.  the berry pies are my favorite.

the real surprise here are the breakfasts.  you can get a pretty good cup of coffee, some amazing home made jams and your choice of regular, or extra thin pancakes.  (go for the thin!)  throw in some bacon or sausage and you're ready to conquer the world!

why only 4 stars?  this place ain't cheap.

I love this place.  The drinks are cheap and have plenty of booze; a Cointreau margarita for 6 bucks?  Gimme gimme.  The food is also well priced, with good sized portions and loads of flavor to boot.  The service is always good despite the sheer business volume that this place cranks out.  I always show excitement when one of my friend's suggest this place.  Honestly, getting a good meal and a good buzz for 20 bucks can be a rarity in Cambridge.  Highly recommended.

It's scary how much I love this joint. I don't usually like ice cream but I go out of my way to get some and never regret it. The service is fast and the bounty of flavors is enough to please even the pickiest of ice cream eaters.

My top brunch place!

I've been 3 times and all times were excellent.

When you walk in, there is an IKEA flavor to the place. There are a lot of tables in the main room so you do feel a little squeezed. There is a second area upstairs w/ a bar and patio. There's a different feel with brick walls and darker furniture.

Start off with a carafe of mimosas--peach or orange, both are good.

We've had the french toast, sausage and scrambled eggs. We've had an omelette before too. 

It is on the pricier side for brunches. Average $14 a plate. But I think the ambiance and quality of food help.

The portion size is big too so that's a plus.

The location is great--right in Rice Village where everything is happenin'.

I have lived right above this place for about 6 months, and had never gone, but I had buy one get one free coupon, and it always smells great when I walk by so decided to try it. Very mediocre sandwich. I mean, it gets the job done, but I was not overly impressed. I may have enjoyed it more if I had not packed it at 10:30 for a lunch at 12 (very soggy by that point) or if I were an adventurous orderer- Tyson G.'s Roast Beef and Provolone, and Amber B.'s original Italian do sound delicious, but I can never bring myself to order more than Turkey, lettuce, tomato, pickles. The turkey was good, but the condiments were lackluster, and like I said, just not super impressive.I think I will probably continue venture a little further for my subs...sorry Mike!

John Harvard's is a respectable brew house if you know how to work it: do not go when it's busy and always sit at the bar. If you don't follow these basic guidelines, you can read the reviews here to commiserate with all those people with good intentions, but bad timing.

In the off-hours, notably between lunch and dinner (2-4:30 PM), this place rocks. Some people are turned off by the dark interior. Yes, it looks kinda like a dungeon, but any place with a stain-glassed window depicting  Jerry Garcia and JFK dressed as saints I think is pretty funny.

The beer is good, but I wouldn't write home about it. The food can be good. I generally like their burgers and fries and the chicken pot pie. The service...well...this is why you go during off hours. The waitstaff generally seems to think its more your pleasure to be there than theirs to serve you. But during the between lunch-and-dinner hours, who cares? You'll be one of three people sitting at the bar and the bartender is almost always there.

Jonny H's: great for a late lunch or early dinner but the standard hours imbiber beware.

I am a fan of this because hey, I like my pizza cheesy, big and oily. That combination alone makes it more than ok. It's not NY style, but if you're looking to get a bang for your buck and love to use 10 napkins in one sitting, go grab a fat slice.  I had two, in one sitting and I gotta say, the basic pepperoni is a definite winner. Not a clean place, but i'm not picky like that. The food's good, I don't care.

pretty good ice cream with odd an interesting flavors. I like the hydrox cookie (sort of an oreo-alike ice cream) and the kulfi. ice cream could be sweeter, though, and portions could be bigger. herrell's is an overall better harvard square experience, though

This place totally caught me off guard. It's not my typical scene - I tend to prefer holes in the wall, but I got to give credit where credit is due: RHT is an awesome spot. 

My friend and I ended up here simply because it was freezing out, and this place was the closest to the T stop. The top floor seemed tiny, but then we meandered downstairs, and the place really opens up. We sat at the bar, and were pleased to discover that they were still serving food (it was after 11). We got dollar oysters, and were going to be content with that, until someone next to us ordered a burger and fries, which looked and smelled too good to pass on. Even better, our bartender, Lou (who just laughed like a good sport when we told him that was an old man's name), was really patient with us ordering our girly frou-frou drinks. He was really knowledgeable, asking us what we liked and didn't like, then just made us some yummy cocktails. 

This place is just a hair more expensive than I would like to add it to my regular rotation, but if your budget isn't as pathetic as mine, it should be on yours!

This was my first taste of Mexican food when I moved up to the Bay Area in '01.  I was disappointed then and I'm disappointed now.  I'm aware that this food is designed for undergrads with undiscerning palates but is cheap street food and they manage to put some deliciousness in their food somehow.

The highlight is that it's open to til 1 or 2am which when you're stumbling home from a frat party makes it alright.  Don't call it Mexican food whatever you do.  It's cheap drunken Berkeley food made for cheap drunken Berkeley students.  Enough said.

Dr. Deanna is always super friendly and always makes time for me! She has offered to make appointments for me on a Sunday and even at 8pm! She started as a massage therapist then became a chiropractor. I have referred 2 coworkers there and she offered a free massage with each referral. She honestly cares about her patients and her rates are really reasonable.  You can also get a discount if you pre-pay for a couple sessions at once. 

Same parking lot as Walgreens, Blockbuster, Baja Fresh. She is located on the second floor of Burlington Arcade. The entrace to her stairs is across from a Japanese kimono shop, next to Heavely Yogurt.

UT is a catchphrase in Husky Jargon (closely related to Chinook Jargon, often used to confuse Cougars, and mildly disorient WWU students). What does it mean? Well, it means: "Starving, broke, studying too long, and need nourishment other than instant noodles".

UT serves straight up half-decent teriyaki (meat with some teriyaki sauce on it) with some rice and a half-decent iceberg salad that probably came right out of the "iceberg salad mix" bag. Throw some Kikkoman on it, and there you go. A perfectly acceptable meal for 7-8 bucks, depending on what you ordered.

While the food is. Well, alright. The portions are nice and huge, and will last for both lunch and dinner if you've had an energy bar for breakfast. Which is good, because of its excessively convenient location at 41st & The Ave. Sometimes I just stop in just to get some food that'll last me the day because I'm already there. And that's probably good business for them.

They just added a whole Korean menu, but I haven't yet been convinced that it would last me for the two meals rather than just for one meal, so I haven't partaken yet. Besides, there are plenty of Korean places around.
Not bad.  Curry was flavorful with lots of bamboo.   I didn't enjoy the bbq chicken though nothing special.  Appetizers are expensive; they cost as much as a meal!

Unless you can eat a lot, like more than a chipotle burrito, go for the small.

I had the carne asada burrito, and it was delicious. The flavors aren't too overpowering, so that's a plus. It doesn't get sickening like Chipotle does after a while. The meat's nice and soft, and the guacamole and sour cream they add is great. The salsa they have goes great with the chips they provide with each order. I usually only get a little bit, but I couldn't keep myself from getting up and refilling my cup of salsa.

And the burrito looks skinny, but it's very, very filling. And a good price too!

These pleasant easy-going folks are veterans in the veggie world. It's very casual and laid back, somewhat reminiscent of a small college cafeteria, with its brick lined, subterranean space lined with posters for upcoming concerts. The members of the staff are helpful and if you go at lunch time, it's not too crowded. 

You can order a pizza or some rice and then select from a selection of earthy, healthy topping combinations, some of which are vegan. Others can be made vegan. There are also various add-ins available to make your meal more unique. Free ice water that you get out of a large cooler using a washable glass is a nice change from having to order an expensive plastic bottle of water. 

I just wish the food was better. Peanut curry, served over coconut rice, was dry and lackluster. The broccoli that was served in this dish was clearly old and very, very tired. The puffy fried tofu, tasteless.  

Roasted vegetables and rice fare somewhat better, but remain boring and bland. Where are the fresh local vegetables? I don't want old imported broccoli when my local farmers are selling fresh onions, kale or parsnips. When so much freshness comes from local farms and gardens, Veggie Planet still delivers the old broccoli. (Note that I do like broccoli, really, I do.) 

There's a kids' menu with pizza, p,b and j and mac and cheese. This environment is a very welcoming one for young families. 

Portions are substantial and affordable. You get a hefty lunch for seven or eight dollars. It's also a very welcoming place, but I'd love to see some creative innovation coming out of the veggie kitchen.

This is a review based almost entirely on the congee. Some of the other food, especially the American style Chinese food looks not so great. Why people order lemon chicken is beyond my comprehension.

I like congee a lot. I never know where to find congee in Berkeley, and then Lotus House opened and answered my congee prayers. The congee here is cheap, huge, made fresh and hot and is a really satisfying lunch. I wish they had more fixings like peanuts and green onions and fish sauce and those little dried anchovies, but they do have hot sauce and soy and they have several meats and things you can add to the plain congee, so I don't really need all the extra stuff.

I will be a Haven devotee until the day I die. 

Rest assured that, unless you are 6'6 or a professional athlete, you'll be fine getting the "half" sized sub as opposed to the "whole". I normally order a half cheese sub with LTO, mayo, oil/ vinegar, hot peppers, and extra pickles. The pickles here are the BEST: they're thick-cut and just add so much to the sandwich. One day they were out of them and it literally ruined my day. True story. 

They also make killer cheese fries. Be sure to ask for extra ketchup on them, and if you want them to layer the cheese throughout the fries, ask for it "Eleonore style". 

Mentally prepared your order while you're in line (or before approaching the counter if there's no line), since you'll be expected to machine-gun it out once they're ready for you. This place gets VERY crowded around mealtime, but the staff are very efficient and speedy so you probably won't wait a terribly long time. 

Be aware that Hoagies takes cash only- they used to take checks but I don't think they do anymore. There's an ATM near the door, and if it's broken there are a few nearby banks and a health food store across the road that have them.

Great Food, Large Portions--Share a Sandwich 

Great Food, Large Portions--Share a Sandwich
Located within walking distance of UCLA and in the heart of Westwood, Jerry's serves up some of the largest sandwiches on the West Coast. The Reuben is one of the best and thickest sandwiches that I have ever had. The fries are always crispy, the coleslaw is sweet, the sauerkraut has just the right flavor, and the Russian sauce is delectable with just the right consistency. Be sure to try the Snickers cake, which is very rich with wonderful texture. 

For those with a tight billfold or want budget dining, this place can be tough. With that said, remember that you are eating in one of the wealthier suburbs in the and pretty much everything is pricey. Go to In-N-Out down the street for a good meal on the cheap. People who bemoan the prices to the point of giving the diner a poor review do not have the experience with real delis; instead, they believe that Subway or similar purveyors of mediocre bread and processed meats are real sandwich shops. Delis have the choicest cuts of meat stacked high between two slices of bread that complement all the components of the sandwich appropriately. At Jerry's because the servings are so large, whether you are on a budget or not, I suggest taking a friend or date and splitting a sandwich ($15) and a dessert ($5); you will be very satisfied.

I always come here whenever I come to slo. Their clam chowder is really good especially with their crab toppings.  I like their fish tacos as well, but sometimes they are kind of dry.  They also have delicious desserts, such as black forest cake and banana cream pie.  I love their black forest cake, but it's way too big for one person.  I heard their breakfast are good, but I didn't have a chance to try it. Maybe I'll when I head to slo again. :]

I like surprises. And Judge's Hill surprised me last night.

First, the maitre d: he was so nice and friendly! Now, that is a rarity!

Then, the shrimp tacos. I re-lived my Nobu experience (http://www.yelp.com/biz/nobu-57-new-york#hrid:6Ni4suhrgw548Aq9CbQSKw), but this time, at least the tacos weren't $24. 

And finally, the pork belly. I snuck a bite of my friend's entree, and it was the bombbbbb!!! The meat was extremely flavorful and tender. 

The only non-pleasant surprise was my entree's name: the ultimate chicken. It kinda made me feel like I was at TGIFs. But, thankfully, I wasn't, and the chicken didn't taste anything like a TGIFs Jack Daniel's platter.

i was hesitant to try this place after so many people had suggested crepes-a-go go but after trying their crepe, which was practically a thick ass pancake, i decided to try ryno's. no lie! after having the banana sundae crepe, i have been going everyday since. im hooked. get over your hesitation & try this place out. it's worth every penny.

Eh. Seriously. I'm originally from a super Asian area where there are bajillion top-notch pearl milk tea places, and this just doesn't compare to home. The boba gets really chewy and hard after a couple of minutes for the smoothies, and even in the milk tea, it's just not like an actual tapioca ball - more like a lump of tapioca. The smoothies are alright - the kiwi one is pretty good though - but same thing. The boba pretty much ruins it. I'm pretty sure the milk tea is made out of powder, too. It just doesn't taste the same. 

Overall, this place is good for a quick boba fix, but not for much else.

This review is a little delayed but this is really the most inefficient Dr's office I've ever been to in my life. I located them on Zoc Doc and was under the impression that having the convenience of booking my appointment online would be a big win - NOT! 

On my first visit, the nurse took my height wrong - she was literally 3 inches off *blank stare." I should have taken that as a sign but decided to stick it out.  I attempted to have a simple procedure taken care of and it did not come to pass because I was given the runaround for weeks. First, I was given wrong information and then they kept telling me that they were "waiting on my insurance to push it through." I had already gotten clearance from my insurance but needed a certain prescription filled by the doctor. They were supposed fill it and never did. I called for weeks hoping for an update and kept getting the runaround (Oh, the Dr. hasn't called you yet?? Um, no.) The communication is utterly horrendous and I really don't understand how they are still in business.

Please do not waste your time by going to this practice - if you want to call it that.

Rhode Runner came highly recommended (thanks Rhody Yelpers!), and it did not disappoint. I am not generous with my five-star ratings, but this establishment earned one. 

The store is small, but it is a treasure chest of running riches. They carry the good stuff and only the good stuff. 

When I walked in, I was promptly greeted by a staff member, and we got right down to business: I desperately needed a new pair of sneakers.
