She instructed me to take off my shoes, roll up my pants and walk in a straight line. Not a DUI test, but rather a quick pronation test. I overpronate, which I suspected. She asked if I had any problems, and I mentioned getting chronic shin splints. Yup, my feet are screaming for a stable shoe, she told me. 

She measured my foot and brought out a pair of Brooks and a pair of Sauconys. She was spot on with the first pair, especially after she taught me the "runner's knot" to remedy my narrow heels slipping in the shoe. Never satisfied though, I wanted to try one more to be sure, so she brought a pair of New Balance. They fit like a sock (or a glove as people sometimes say), and I thought I had found the ones. 

She suggested putting the New Balance on one foot and the Brooks on the other for a jog on the treadmill. She video-taped me running to see which shoe performed better. 

The award-winning (Runner's World "Best Update") Brooks Adrenaline GTS 11 won. They kept my foot straight while my ankle clearly wobbled in the New Balance . 

At $100, I am totally happy with the value of my purchase (which is why I am scoring them in the moderate price range -- even though the prices are high, so is the quality, and they are what you would expect), and I'm overjoyed with my experience at Rhode Runner. I will definately be back in 500-600 miles for my next pair!

I have been going to the owner of salon for years Lawanda is extremely knowledgeable about hair and how to maintain healthy hair.I have very coarse hair and she introduced me to there product organic hair softer no chemicals and transformed my hair to soft and defined my curls I love it.I highly recommend it if you have thick coarse hair that is hard to style.they cater to your specific hair type and teach you how to care for your hair.Rochelle is excellent hair stylist that you can walk out happy with your hair.

I've had maybe one or two deliveries from here. The food there is okay, nothing remarkable.   However, this is more for their MIT Truck, as that has given me a food option that allows a quick and easy way to buy some cheap food.

For $4, you can get a falafel, or a kebab, or something else with a pita, and a sodie pop.  Think about this.  A wrap filled with decent ingredients plus a soda for about half of what you will pay elsewhere in the Kendall area (and, with about a quarter of the line that Gooseberry's has, so when you need to get food quickly, it's usually quick and easy). 

Again, the food isn't the greatest, but it's definitely serviceable, and easy to get, in the Kendall/MIT area, and a much better deal than most.

I want to like this place because it's convenient (e.g., local, quick and decently priced), but have been 3 times and have been disappointed.  The nigiri is flat out bad (although fair enough I shouldn't expect super high quality fish in a place like this, but I tried it).  But even the rice was always a bit old (dried out).  My last trip I thought I'd try a California roll in hopes that it would do in a pinch (as it is close to both my hose and office), but even that was a disappointment. So even as a SanSai level fast food sushi place, I have a hard time with it.

This is where I go for Tuesday lunches. The same waitress knew my drink order, and that of all my friends, by the third week. The sushi is decent and not outrageously expensive. Other than that... it's a rotary sushi bar.

This was really my first time trying Lebanese food and it wasn't really my favorite. My friend suggested it and goes there often. They just started a new lunch buffet apparently so I figured that would be a good place to start. I didn't ask the price beforehand, which i later regretted. It was about $16 and there was not very much selection. The owner/chef was very friendly and came out asking everyone personally if they wanted Falafel as it wasn't on the buffet. This was excellent and would have made the buffet a little more worthwhile. The hummus was excellent also, as well as this garlic paste they make and some sort goat cheese pita like pizza. I didn't really catch the name because of the buffet. Overall I hate to leave a bad review because it seems like a nice place with some good dishes but the buffet was a fail. I would like to come back again and order off the menu.

Post Scottish Rite Children's Theater.  Two big people, two small people.  One kids cheese pizza, one kids ham n cheese, a turkey original, a turkey guacamole.  Meh.  Fountain diet coke, meh.  It was good enough for a Sunday afternoon.

Sooooooo good.

Soooooo cheap.

It looks and feels like a chain, and it's not "Jose's" authentic.  Hence...4 not 5 stars.  Also, I'd avoid the fajitas.  Everything on the menu is better.  

Good Margerita's, nothing crazy on the beer list, but the low cost great tasting food (along with the complete lack of convenient low cost good tasting Mexican in the Boston area) means we're there at least 5-6 times a year.

Was in Pittsburgh for 2 nights and came here both nights for giant, cheap ice cream loaded with sprinkles for the kids. Didn't like the chocolate ice cream, but the vanilla and confetti cake were great. If I had been there another night, would have gone for the handrolled cones, which smelled great.

We were here in summer, so the lines were short and students scarce.

A beautifully decorated and well-stocked wine store specializing in little-known and budget-friendly priced wines, in my neighbourhood? Yes, please!
They have great hours and a nice location. Coming out of the 116th subway stop, I find myself directly in front of their door, so it can't really be any more convenient to stop their on my way home when I need a bottle of wine.
The staff is generally very friendly and helpful. They are especially talented at food pairings and are willing to listen to my "menu" and then recommend a few wines that would pair well to whatever I might be cooking.
Upon a recent visit, however, I accidentally took a bottle from their refrigerator and was chastised by the lady working for going against their "system". Then the bottle was more than I have paid for it in the past and when I tried to ask her about it, she snapped "We've never sold this wine for that price". OK... I'm sure that in her opinion she knew what she was talking about on both points. I don't work there so I can't pretend to be an expert. But as far as customer service goes, it was a bit surprising to be criticized for my actions as I'm handing over my credit card. This is an isolated incident in my experience and I will keep visiting the Winery. Though, I sincerely hope that this level of "customer service" remains an isolated incident, and does not become a rule.

I love Newbury Comics.  It's full of strange and funny items that I want to buy, but I usually don't because I am afraid the novelty may wear off soon after a purchase.  That said, I did buy two magnets in here.  I can get lost in this store.

I'm full. And pleased with what's inside me. (Yes, that's what she said)

I can't believe I walked past this place so many times without trying it! Met a friend here for dinner. Yes, the beverage area is a tad sketchy, but it's a nice place for a meal and conversation (if you find a non-wobbly table).

They have some interesting tea that comes with the meal. Try it! It's good.

2 things that set House of Curries apart:

1. Ample indoor and outdoor seating, yet you order at the counter, so you don't have to pay a tip!

2. It's raised above street level, but not quite on a second story. It looks like you're dining in a more expensive place, but you're paying the same as any other indian place (hah).

I had the Chana Masala, which is garbanzo beans in a really yummy sauce. It was tasty by itself, and killer with naan. And I'm even happier now that I looked up the nutritional value of garbanzo beans: http://www.whfoods.com/genpage.php?tname=foodspice&dbid=58 Apparently they're really good for you!

My friend recommends the Chicken Tikka Masala, because it's his usual, but he warns that sometimes they chince out on the chicken.

Even the guy at the counter was really friendly! I was fully satisfied by all aspects of my experience here, and I think it deserves a higher average rating than 3.5.

(Addendum after I saw someone's review complaining about the music: I love the music!!! It sounds like indian techo/dance music or something. I wanna know where I can find some of that music.)

Overpriced? How could anyone call these overpriced? I GOT TWO OF THEM FOR FREE!

While strolling through Farmer's Market and down the main drag in Solana Beach the Sprinkles Cupcake Car drove down the street. As a native of Nor Cal, I had never had a Sprinkles Cupcake, but So Cal friends assured me these were one of the many things that made So Cal cooler than Nor Cal.

A friend of mine got a text saying they were handing out cupcakes FOR FREE. Naturally, the group of us ran over to grab one...or two.

I tried the Black & White as well as the Vanilla. I wasn't a huge fan of the Vanilla cupcake, but I loved the Black & White. THe cake was moist and dense and the ratio of frosting to cake was perfect! Sometimes I feel they're overly frosted with zero cake- but Sprinkles has this all right! 

I am now on a mission to find the "Sprinkles" of San Francisco!

Fuck you Chipotle for the 10 lbs I've gained the past couple of months. Damn my chicken fajita burrito with extra corn, sour cream, fresh salsa with hot sauce, and a side of guacamole. It's OK if no one in Berkeley wants to eat you, I'll do it. The whole damn thing. 

On the plus side, they sell beer. I love sitting on the patio with my huge-ass burrito and corona watching the Cal madness from afar. 

One star off for absolutely no parking, and when it's lunch time, there's not a single table or seat available. And also because of the McDonald's deal. Past or present, it doesn't matter.

Taste: 3
Value: 3
Service: 4

I came here with a few people from my lab for lunch about 3-4 months ago. The place was completely empty inside, save maybe 1-2 other tables. Since they were still relatively new, they had a special with all of their specialty rolls being $8-10.

I decided to go with the Super Crunch roll, and it was okay. Overall, the food wasn't bad, but it wasn't memorable enough to warrant 4 stars. The decor is nice inside, and it's a bit of a shame it's so empty.
best fruit cart in the city !  the fruit is usually ripe, you get a ton of fruit for your money, and the husband and wife team who run the cart are very friendly.  free banana with every order !

Amazing food, amazing service!!  My fiance and I went to Russell House Tavern last night to celebrate my getting into nursing school.  We told the waitress why we were there and when we recieved our food the chef sent out extra portions of the menu specials to congratulate us.  As if that wasn't enough Michael Scelfo (the chef) came to the table to personally congratulate us!  When we left the host congratulated us as well!
   The raw bar was the freshest I've ever had, our cocktails were made with ginger beer that was made in-house.  Our charcuterie was delicious (and fit for four rather than two).  The arctic char was perfectly cooked and flavored.  Prices were very reasonable, especially for such fresh ingredients and Michael Scelfo's expertise! Very happy that we chose Russell House as a place to celebrate, our experience was as good as it gets!

I can't remember what I had here, so basically the food isn't too memorable. Fajitas are the dead giveaway that this is an attempt at Tex-Mex and since I don't live in the South, I'd really rather prefer my Mexican left alone the way it is--good.

The wait wasn't too bad considering it was a weekend. The (loud/lively) atmosphere makes me think it might be better in a group setting. Preferably with enough cocktail drinking to make you forget why you came here instead of some other better restaurant.

Really mediocre. $8.25 for an omelet and homefries. Good blueberry pancakes, but very small and only 4 served. Indifferent staff, almost asleep on the morning were there. Good for the college crowd, but otherwise do avoid.
this is probably my second favorite pizza ever. so big, so many choices!

Age: 31 & Sex: Male
Why am I reviewing Anthropologie? 
I go to this store quite often than any mens clothing stores.  Why???  Why??

No... I am not a cross-dresser. 

My girlfriend loves this store and we live within walking distance. 
She can shop here for hours, I usually follow her around for few minutes but eventually will pick one of  their cookbooks and head to a couch. In those few minutes I would have heard "this is what Giada wore when she cooked..." a few times. 

"Do you come here to shop for yourself or to check out Giada's closet?" I always wanted to ask, but never did. 

I do like the cookbooks they carry and they constantly change their selections to keep me busy. 

I almost forgot to buy a gift for her birthday this year and how a quick stop at Anthropologie and a gift card saved the day for me!  I can't fall back on Anthro for a gift again can I? But wait I think I got  a hint last time when we went to Anthro.

Location: Anthropologie
Scene: I am on the couch with Foods of Asia on page 365 of 380  and 
             she is empty handed and we are ready to leave.
Me: How come you didn't buy anything?
She:  I can't afford anything.
Me: Nothing from the sales rack? 
She: No, I am saving up for the $500 GUCCI bag that we saw when
         we went to San Diego.

Great, I am putting my kidney up for sale. Any buyers???

We used to go to Burger Continental for breakfast on Saturday mornings about 10 years back.  We just went back for dinner 2 Sundays ago and the quality of food is just not as good as it used to be.  I ordered the beef and chicken kabab plate, my husband ordered the lamb plate, and our friend ordered the fish (don't remember what kind).  When the plates came, they all looked the same and were very sloppily piled on with some very overcooked vegetables and mashed potatoes (???).  There was plenty of food but they don't look appetizing and don't taste that good either .  Towards the end of the meal, the band started playing and that sort of saved the dinner.

If you enjoy eating colored cardboard you might enjoy this place. None of the pizza had any flavor, to the point where the hawaiian tasted just like the buffalo chicken. I'm still trying to figure out how that is even possible. Needless to say I won't be returning.

Been living in the neighborhood for over 2 years and have neglected the nearby restaurants, firstly because there aren't very many and secondly, since I tend to meet friends in Hell's Kitchen all the time.  But, finally, I made my way around the corner for dinner with a friend/coworker (Amy) at this cozy little uptown eatery.  Got there early so the place was quite empty leaving table choice up to us.  We grabbed the corner and our super friendly waiter got our drink orders and shared the specials.  A DJ was setting up near the windows and soon started spinning plenty of Luther's Christmas Album, setting the perfect mood for a chilly winter's night meal.  The bar was full of the afterwork crowd, quietly enjoying the atmosphere and their cocktails.

We shared a Mango Martini which was deliciously refreshing.  

For dinner, Amy thoroughly enjoyed Pecan Encrusted Tilapia with Garlic Mashed Potatoes and the Country Yams (see below for description).  By the way she cleaned her plate, I'd say this was a fantastic choice!

I had the BBQ Meatloaf.  Two huge slices of perfectly cooked Turkey Meatloaf with just the right amount of slightly spicy, slightly sweet BBQ sauce.  I couldn't eat it fast enough.  On the side, I had the sauteed spinach with garlic and like Amy, the Country Yams.  Oh those yams!!!  Every bite melted in my mouth, sweet as can be, YUM!

Needless to say, we were far too full to even attempt dessert, but I know I have to make a return trip just to savor their Sweet Potatoe Pie.  

You should too!

To start, I went on a Tuesday night, and it was just for food.   So the place was empty, so I can't comment on the crowd.  They did play some awesome tunes, stuff I hadn't heard in years.. Swallow-Bush, some old Offspring.  It was great. 

The food, well.. not so much.  I had the BBQ Salad which was pretty good, but the guy I was with ordered a Bacon Cheeseburger medium well.  You would think that with us being really the only 'eaters' there they would be able to get the order right... right?   Well, his burger was missing the bacon, and it was rare.  He took a couple of bites and it was still mooing.  Not good.  So he had to send it back and they just threw it right back on the grill, cheese and all and brought it back to him, still with no bacon.  Needless to say, he wasn't really happy.  

There is an awesome patio, so I'm sure this will be a pretty popular place in the summer.. Just eat somewhere else first.. 

It's SO close to where I live, I feel like I have to try it again.. I will give it a second chance, but him.. not so much.

THEY'VE STARTED ACCEPTING CREDIT CARDS!  I was going to have to give them a 4-star rating, but now that they're accepting more than just cash or check, they've made the 5-star list.  I am addicted to their Vanilla Custard pastry.  Their fruit tarts are always fresh, and they have chocolate mousse in a lot of their desserts, which is huge.  The only drawback is that this place is almost always crowded.  But it's not so bad to walk around beautiful Stanford mall, window shopping and eating a delicious pastry.

Piano Piano is, well, a piano bar. Full bar, two pianos, very interesting.  I don't know if it's the kind of place I'd want to be a regular at, but I've always had a fabulous time there.  I've also always gotten pretty hammed before I got there.  
Biggest surprise?  Piano versions of club favorites and classics like The Thong Song.  Seriously.  And the fact that a wide variety of people come here, so it's not just stuffy piano lovers, of skinny kids sipping beer and appreciating the kitsch value, or menopausal woman mooning over Elton John favorites and a glass of chardonnay.  It's a good time, and you can grab a good table and have a fun, unique time with your buddies.  

As long as no one punches you for suggesting a piano bar.. :)
I really love Walter's.  My family and I eat here all the time.  I love having breakfast on the patio and on cold nights it is fun to eat in the cottage with all the twinkle lights!

3.5 stars! I ordered a cheeseburger combo which included a fountain drink and fries for $10. Other than feeling good about eating organically and locally grown, the burger itself wasn't too special. The beef was lean (perhaps due to the cows being grass fed, as suggested by a friend). It was enough to satisfy my meat craving. 

The real deal at this place were the fries, I had the mixed potato and sweet potato fries. They were mouth watering delicious! Generous portions that are cut to perfection, crispy on the out side and meaty on the inside. I also have to give a shout out to the sodas sweetened with cane sugar. One sip and you can tell the difference between these and its' distant high fructose cousins. On a side note, they're breakfast tacos are very flavorful, especially eaten with corn tortillas. 

I'll probably go back for my fries fix and try their shakes (which I heard are very tasty too).

HOLY  TOLEDO.

Where have you been all my life?? You are the prince charming of cookies, the sultan of sweets, the...

Too cheesy? OK OK OK I'm done.

So first off, this spot is damn near haunted. Once a shitty Ms. Fields, then a Beard Papa, the chain sweeteries are just not cutting it on this corner. So what did Berkeley need? A brand new, open late, incredibly cheap, good quality snack spot.  

And CREAM delivers.

Standing for "Cookies Rule Everything Around Me" (excuse me while I nerd out really hard), CREAM just opened recently and BOY is it booming.  I have yet to go in where the line ISN'T around the block.

Small, hip, and bright. It bumps top 40 shit (eh) but the fun corny shit so it doesn't feel too Miley Cyrus but more what you hear bumping out of cars.  The concept is that the store is strictly ice cream and homemade cookies (in addition to a small cooler of sodas and soy milks).  One cookie is fifty cents (HOLY TOLEDO!), and ice cream is not all that much more. You can do a cup or cone, single cookies to a dozen, OR what you can do (if you're wild) is get an ice cream sandwich. They are big. They are messy. They are effing delicious.

I got a half dozen cookies for UNDER $3 and my fat ass can ASSURE you that it was worth WAY more than $3, and I am more than pleased.

I would absolutely love to see CREAM succeed. Keep it up.

This store has been in the area for as long as I can remember.  Even though this market is physically smaller than most of the traditional markets in the area, it makes up for it by carrying top-drawer products.  They have restaurant-quality cuts of meat, which is perfect if you are looking to prepare that special occasion meal.  They also have a great deli section if you are looking for prepared entrees to heat-and-eat at home.  Best of all, they also carry Dr. Bob's ice cream.  If I won the lottery, this is where I would do all of my shopping.
Really friendly staff and great brews!

Without a doubt, this is the worst place I've eaten at in Berkeley. It's been a while since I've visited Indian Flavors Express, so I can't recall exactly what I ordered on the menu, but I do know this:
- the portions are tiny
- everything you order is in a puddle of oil
- they don't know the first thing about spicy as nothing is actually spicy
- spicy to these people actually means extremely sour
- the amount of rice you get is enough to feed a small bird. 
- the price is about $6-$9 for the dishes and then $1 or $2 for the nann or rice.
- this place is empty most of the time. i should've taken this as a clue of how terrible this place is
- to the reviewer who said you walk in and are greeted with the smell of *hand ground* spices... how in the world do you get this? if anything, there's a reek of vomit from the place

I would highly not recommend going here. i ended up eating 1/4 of my order, and then getting some la burrita after.

Place is alright, but the cannoli shells were defiantly store bought.  But i mean hey, I guess every place cant be perfect.  For the price though, I feel like they sold be homemade.  

The filling in the cannolis were kind of strange.  The fact that neither my mother nor I wanted to eat the second one showed that there was a problem.

My mom did enjoy her other pasty.  I, however, did not like the biscotti very much.  I mean I would go back if I was walking by, but I defiantly would not go out of my way to get pastries here.  

I would walk to La Gourmandine Bakery in Lawrenceville before going here again.

All the smoothies were $4.00 and were a reasonable size. Too bad I had to try out boba for the first time here with a perfectly good smoothie. I don't know if boba usually tastes like "bla," but it did here. I just kept trying to stop from getting any of those balls in my damn straw because the smoothie was delicious. 

Very small hometown feel. Quiet, so it would be a good place to study, but apparently a lot of people already know that... as 5 people were studying when I did go there. 

I would go back, but only for the smoothies.

The menu here is really nice - good pancakes, decent eggs, my mom liked the middle eastern breakfast with hummus and falafel. I think the eggs are a little dry, but there is something in the homey feel that I really enjoy. They also left the stems on the spinach for the eggs florentine. The coffee and OJ are really good. Avoid the bathroom! 
All in all, the food isn't incredible, but this is a great little hole in the wall to enjoy Sunday morning, the paper, and conversation. Extra points if you were across the street at the Middle East the night before.

This is probably the absolute worst food I have ever eaten.  A group of us stopped here on a road trip.  We ordered burgers, fries, hotdogs, and onion rings.  ALL of the food was cold, a chicken sandwich smelled like formaldehyde, and the fries were completely limp and greasy.  The only edible thing were the onion rings which were decent.  The place was packed so with that much turnaround I don't understand why the food was cold.  If I could give it zero stars, I would.
So large couldn't even fit the whole facade in my picture! So ornate and lovely. Surely visit. The adjacent Children's Garden was a sweet surprise too.

I love this place! Their gyros are cheap, authentic and delicious!

I don't know what to say except that they're so good... there are long lines at times. but it's sooo worth it! 

you always get your fast good and you know it's authentic!
I hear they're open late too :)

I used to live in Coolidge Corner and I remember when Anna's Taqueria first opened.  My earlier experience with mexican food or tex mex was Taco bell and Chi Chi's.  I didnt really like it.  Anna's changed that for me, and for the better.  It opened my eyes to fresh foods a la mexican.  I also went to San Diego and got some really good Mexican food there.  Now, I am not a mexican food expert, so forgive me if I am misclassifying things.  But, their stuff is fresh and it is good.  The cambridge location at MIT is just as good as the Brookline location.  Give it a try, and maybe you will agree that this place is a keeper.  Eat!

I'm glad i went to this place before I became balkanized, as this place is right in enemy USC territory. I went here back in elementary school and passing through and it is a great place. The high wire bicycle course looks scary as hell but scientifically it is quite hard to fall. The rose garden outside is pretty cool also.

There's more than just milk and cereal to this place. As a bistro, they serve an array of cereal based foods. They make sandwiches with cereal (I know, sounds odd, but I had a sandwich with Apple Jacks, apple pie filling, yogurt and nuts and it was GOOD-the bread was like crust on a yummy yummy pie). They have cereal infused ice cream that they're just introducing (different from placing toppings of cereal on top of ice cream, but the ice cream mixture itself is composed of cereal-I sampled the chocolate which had a mix of several chocolate cereals and I can totally say it's something that I've never experienced before-good stuff).
The owner said they should be coming out with cereal-based soup by mid-August, so be on the lookout.
The owner and other staff were really nice and the price is definitely right (under $5 for just about everything).
I'll be back for the soup, true that.

I have been Chairman Spike's Junkyard Dog for 13 years now. This branch is the first and original Spike's before they expand it all the way to Boston and soon Portland.  My sister love this place so much that I have to pick up Spike's postcard and send her everytime I eat there.  My sister got really mad seeing the postcard since she is living oversea. She love it that much! and want to bring Spike's franchise to her hometown.  They didn't franchise it at that time.   I love their pizza dog, their dog roll (texture like small version of french baquett), not lousy bun, choices of dogs, and my curly fries.  Now, I go to all 3 branches in Boston instead of driving down to Providence like before. I am happy:) they expanded to Boston...  Best dog on earth, seriously... Pinks in LA has to bow to our Chairman Spike....

decent yogurts and their flavors change every so often.  really go for the pumpkin pie yogurt they have around thanksgiving time....sooo good.  bailey's irish cream was good too.  their fruit flavored yogurts are just okay. 

i got the vanilla yogurt with oreos once.... but the oreo tasted kinda stale.  oddly enough i prefer mcdonald's mcflurry to this.  so now if i go to yogurt park i just get the chocolate.

they give you a lot of mix ins...but it's also kinda pricey...but portions are big.  

you can call in ahead for their recorded message for the flavors of the day.  also, the ppl who work here are rude and think they're too good for the job so i never tip :P

They have a tasty vegetarian hoagie.. Not eating neat usually limits your options in conventional chains but I'm okay with ordering that here because it's tasty goodness .. And you get 5 stars from me when on multiple times you've delivered food at 2am to me and friends at the bar!! Gotta love that!!

I was here with my mom and we ate fairly well, but it wasn't stellar. 
Bubble House is an overpriced restaurant/tea house that's good for  a bite of lunch if you're willing to overpay for your meal. You know your food will be edible, but be prepared to feel disappointed. 
I ordered the crab cake sandwich (3/5 stars) and found that the crabmeat wasn't very fresh, and the mixture that they used to form the patties really overpowered any potential crab flavor. The sweat potato fries (5/5) on the side were spectacular. I didn't really care for the sauce they came with, I'm more of a honey person for my sweet potato fries, and the one they give you is a little to tangy. My bubble tea (can't have bubble house without bubble tea!) was good, but overpriced and a little watered down (4/5)- I had a green tea latte.

I have to concur with Mark. I have only seen Dr. Rubinstein once but was very impressed. I found him to be engaging, responsive, bright and not condescending.  He answered all my questions (I had a lot) and even took the time to make sure I didn't have any more.  I highly recommend.

shhhhh, don't tell my family I went to Cream without them.  

this place is AWESOME- many vegan cookie options (4-6 daily!) & 2 Double rainbow soy ice creams (one is always mint chip).  nothing like a scoop of ice cream smooshed between two warm cookies.  and all for $3. 

everything is very very very sweet-- nothing subtle about it.  

I no longer have to complain about the lack of vegan dessert options near campus. YAY!

Home of the Big Five and the University of Pennsylvania Basketball, Wrestling, and Volleyball teams, I can't think of a cozier place to spend a winter's night with 8,700 screaming fans.

If you haven't been, just go.  Its a building that is likely older than your parents, and it is like a trip back in time.  An arena without an laser show or diamond vision, this place actually depends on cheerleaders to lead cheers.  What a concept.  Not that its necessary.  The noise starts at the opening tip and continues until after the end of the game.

I was there for the Penn Temple game last night.  Penn fell behind by 19 in the first half but continued pecking away to take a lead in the second half.  The game wasn't decided until Penn hit three free throws with under two seconds to take a two point lead.

Five stars for history and vitality.  Its nice to go back in time and look ahead all at once.

The fabulous thing about La Piccoletta is that they serve the best pasta sauces, the best pasta and loveliest bread I have ever tasted.  I have never been to Italy, but I have friends who are natives of Italy and I brought them to La Piccoletta just as an experiment - to see what they would say. Their verdict was that both the ambiance and the food makes you feel as though you are at a small lodge/restaurant that makes scrumptious food in the Italian countryside. La Piccoletta is an incredibly delightful place!! 

The warning I shall give anyone visiting this charming restaurant is that you may find it quite hard to appreciate food at other Italian/American-Italian restaurants after enjoying La Piccoletta's fare. 

Being a small restaurant that is open only in the evenings, they limit their menu to dishes that they decide upon every week. Their menu focuses on quality rather than quantity. The options (recently expanded) include dishes like Filet Mignon, Cioppino, Meatballs, servings of antipasto platter, insalata, and their featured pasta and sauces of the week (together with salad and bread). 

They feature a pasta and four or five sauces every week, available all through the week. If you order pasta, you get a plate of pasta and as much and as many sauces as you would like. My favorite sauces are the White Sauce with Peas and the Aromi sauce. Simply Delicious!! 

Tuesday nights are half-price on a pasta dinner for two ($11 per person with salad, bread and non-alcoholic drink). The same type of dinner is available for college students on Thursday nights for $9.50. Ever since we discovered this place hidden in the parking lot between Indian Hill and Yale Ave last year, my friends and I dine here at least once in two weeks. Needless to say, Tuesday and Thursday nights are our favorite La Piccoletta nights. I believe they also have family specials on Saturdays.

I think they have a neat selection of wines, and they are all reasonably priced per glass or bottle. Their house wines are good quality as well, and you can enjoy a fresh, fine-tasting red or white wine for as low as $3 or $4. I like that they don't empty stale wine into the glasses of those who order their house wine. 

We always order their Tiramisu when we are at La Piccoletta to celebrate an occasion.  I like their other desserts, but their Tiramisu definitely rocks the house!!!  

Finally, always make reservations as the seating area is small and intimate and this place is really popular. I want to give a bonus star to their friendly and considerate staff.  :-) I will move from Claremont next year and will probably really miss this place!

I'm a fan of Oishii! It's quick and easy on the wallet, great for a quick dinner or lunch. The place itself is small and it looks like there's nowhere to sit but they have a whole upstairs area with tables and cushion-seat counter. 

I got a bulgogi bento box here that came with a miso soup and sides of kimchi, pickled radish and glass noodles - all for under $10! We also got a spicy tuna roll, it still wasn't spicy and the rice wasn't very packed but for being $4 or so, I wasn't complaining.

This place is OK, not amazing. Does the trick if you're in the mood for some super greasy and bad for you Thai food, but I wouldn't go here on a regular basis if you're concerned about health in any way.

I might come here for Teriyaki because that is pretty hard to screw up...but I will never get sushi here again. It just didn't seem fresh at all and not up to par with what I get at every other sushi place.

i used to eat here often, mainly because i didn't know what else was available within a 3 block radius of my home. anyway, the meat here is god-awful, it baaaaaarely surpases the meat they serve in the dorms, which is Grade D (aka: Prison grade.) the food is always oily, and they skimp on ingredients - a good summary of the dishes is: rice, chili oil, soy sauce, msg.
the pad thai is really awful too - pad thai is supposed to be refreshing, sweet and sour, with a little kick. it tasted more like a katsudon than pad thai, in an gross way.

but they are open after 11, and always reliable. so. yeah.  -____-

A hopeful visit to Sfoof's turned sour the second I looked in and saw the menu.

Not only are almost all of the featured "woofles" disgusting sounding, but they don't even serve their only decent looking item-- a corndog in waffle batter-- until noon! I'm completely baffled as to their reasoning, because I'm sure the $5 I would be giving them for my Corn Dog would more than cover the extra 90 minutes of corn-dog-maker time costs they think they're "losing".

I got the Darin's Special Waffle which is a Chocolate "Woofle" with really sour raspberry puree, a nice surprise of straight up butter in the middle *barf*, and razor-sharp coffee beans wedged inside.

I really *wanted* to like my "Woofle", but for $8 plus the sourest Lemonade type drink I've ever tasted for $3 a stomachache and four bites of a terrible waffle were NOT WORTH IT.

Save yourself $10 and the time and eat your breakfast elsewhere.

I'm visiting from outta town; lucky for Cafe on the Ave for the  followng reasons - 

1. I went for a 2-hr run and was hungry...

2. I originally wanted to go to Portage Bay Cafe, however, they were closed. I then walked up Roosevelt and down University, and nothing caught my eye until gettin' to this corner. I actually glanced in the window, walked by and crossed the street, then realized that if I didn't find anything fast, I'd pass out!

3. I'm a Yelper, and hadn't read these reviews yet. Had I done so, I would never have gone in.,.

It's actually a cool space. It's got some bar-height tables; regular tables and chairs; and couches w/coffee tables. The decor is kind of bohemian. Though there is a lot of natural light filtering through the many windows, they also leave the space dark.

Granted, I am still skeptical for the following reasons - 

I checked out the case of desserts, and the cakes looked ginormous, sugary, and possibly dense and dry - at least, that is how they looked. I made a mental note to stay away from them,

Most of the hired helped look totally disenchanted, disengaged, and grumpy, which made my skepticism shoot through the roof. It left me wondering whether or not they looked like coffee-shop-material.

I was hungry for a burger and took the risk, cuz the only way someone could screw up a burger is to not cook it fresh, and/or overcook it. I also ordered it with extra cheddar, and extra avocado (it was called the Cali Burger).

The hamburger came, and it looked to be more than a quarter pound, yet less than a third. It also was just barely cooked, and this is exactly how burgers should be cooked - not well, yet still juicy.

Fortunately, they met both of my criterium, except that the avocado equated to be about a teaspoon worth! ...and they chose the wrong person from which to scrimp the avocado cuz I'm an avocado whore! 
I wondered whether or not they were paying attention to the food ticket, or whether or not it's normal to serve such a tiny morsel! I asked someone to add more of it, and she was pretty nice about it.

I ordered an iced tea; and when I was finished with my first glass, and sauntered over to the ice tea canister on promonent display, and it was water. They should've really labeled it properly!

The fries were standard. Actually, they were hot and freshly made, though I probably would've cooked 'em a tad bit longer if I were them. They were kind of pasty white.

The meal came with quarter of a pickle, which was a nice touch.

Actually, the chocolate chip cookies looked like the homemade kind (rather than the commercial pre-made ones) and I took the risk and bought one to-go. I just finished eating it, and it was pretty good.

I used the restroom, and it was almost spotless! I made mental note...

I'm *not* surprised that everyone else here had such choice things to say, cuz I sensed that they'd just be OK. Luckily, the gods were with me today, and my meal turned out decent. The burger with iced tea came out to about $12, which I expected.

It's not the best falafel in the bay area, but it's the best falafel I've had in Berkeley.  

I seriously have random cravings for falafel at least once a week, and with their cheap prices: about $4 for a dozen (if I remember correctly), I can get my falafel fix any time I want!  

I got their Falafel sandwich with avocado.  I don't think it's worth it to pay more than a dollar extra for some damn avocado because you're not eating a falafel sandwich for avocado, you're eating it because of the falafel and pita!  

Their veggie platter was pretty gross and pretty small.  WTH I swear the plate was only a little bigger than my hand with my fingers stretched out.  This place is so close to campus that it doesn't make sense for it to have such small portions for the veggie platters.  College students are HUNGRY and poor!  

Yeah, just go for the falafel.  The staff kind of creeps me out though...  They stare at you while you eat, but I suppose they don't have much else to look at since the counter is two feet away from the tables.

Walked in on a very cold day Thanksgiving weekend with a friend. The place was dead, but it was happy hour. E sat in the little "private" area at the end of the bar (room for about 6 in this pseudo-room) and were greeted by a very friendly bartender. She kept the drinks flowing while we waited for my friends wife and mother-in-law. I would love to see how this place is when school (meaning Cornell and Ithaca College) is not on holiday. Will go back on my next trip to Ithaca.

How can you NOT give a 5 star rating for Gypsy's on Durant?!

REMEMBER, this is a fast food italian "joint" but with great taste.  It's cheap, filling (typically take some home), and very good.  You will typically wait for about 5-10 mins for the food and many of the items on the menu are very good.

I always get the Godfather and the Bronx Tale and the Calzone's are pretty darn good as well.  The only bad thing is after years of going here (pre-college through post), I cannot find a bathroom to wash my hands!  Oh, ask for an extra slice of garlic bread, it's worth it.

I had not been under this roof since it was BW3's... and as my first foray into this Irish pub was at four o'clock on St. Patrick's Day, well... that's timing for you!
I was really pleased with the effort that went into properly pouring each pint of Guinness.  I don't think I'm being overly sensitive here... some things just have to be done right, and they did it each time.  
The volume inside - from all of the revelers, the televisions tuned to March Madness, the bagpiper (remember, it WAS St. Patrick's Day) was a bit much in which to carry on a conversation, so we opted for their outdoor seating.  Bar or no bar (excuse me - pub or no pub), I was disappointed with the amount of second-hand smoke we had to endure while sitting out there.
We had only appetizers there, and they were...okay.  While the calamari was really good, I have to agree with Lauren B.'s take on potato-chip nachos.  They were... nachos on potatoes.  Oh, well.
I've heard that Kildare's has trivia games on Monday nights.  That may just be worth fighting the traffic and hassling for a parking space.

Has to be the most beautiful Garden I've ever seen. It's so amazing. Every time I walk by it I take at least 10 photos of the various plants. 

I'm happy there is a gate surrounding it. It shocks me how many want to step all over. Also shocks me when someone picks a flower (seen it with my own eyes). Not cool people. It looses it's aura when you do that. 

I love the smell. Oh the smell of the flowers is amazing. This is a great date spot. A great first kiss spot. A "will you marry me" spot. It's perfect.

I have worked with Danielle on a couple of different occasions. She first photographed my family for our holiday cards and the pictures were just amazing. She captured everyone from my mother in law to my 2 year old twin girls. Her colors are amazing and she really gets the shot. 

She also has been photographing my 3rd daughter since she was 6 weeks old and every picture she takes is fabulous. 

Not only is Danielle a wonderful photographer but she is easy to work with and fun. She makes the shoot comfortable for everyone! Highly recommend.
Mixed up burger with egg, onion rings, and an extra large orange bang......the end (really, you'll have a heart attack after this combo but very worth it)..still hungry carne asada fries

In Philly, we ate out of food trucks. Crepes, fruit, hogies, you name it, you can get it from a truck.  

Magic Carpet is the best food truck around. It's been 4 years since I moved out of Philly and I still crave Magic Carpet's veggie chili. This chili was amazing and powered me through some really long nights of.. studying!  MC is completely vegetarian and everything is delicious.  Super cheap, fast and friendly staff! 

There is another location on 34th & Walnut where all the food trucks (and engineers!) live. 

Go for my sake if you are in the area.  I miss you Magic Carpet and your delicious vegetarian food.

Really like this place! The burritos are night are awesome because they are open late. They have a great selection of beverages like Jaritos and I noticed they have a bottled water called Nika Water that donates ALL its profits to alleviating poverty in Africa. It's nice to see them care about incorporating helping others in their business model

For women's shoes...I will give this Seattle based company 5 stars!  The clothing leaves something to be desired at times.  Maybe that's because most of it I can't afford and I would rather shop at small boutiques.
It's kind of average as far as indian food, and there are definetly places aroudn cal that are alot better, but it has saved my hangoverness mornings more than a few times, it gets and extra star

I'm usually not too picky when it comes to campus apartments, mainly because it's almost expected that they'll be a little dirty. So when I heard people talk about how bad CPM was, I just brushed it aside. Now I know better. Our apartment is not only disgusting, but it is unhealthy to live in. When we moved in back in August, there was mold all over the ceiling, walls, and growing in the toilet in our bathroom. We called them to take care of it, but all they did was spray paint over it. A few months later, the mold grew back. Big surprise! We called them again to take care of it. Their response to the situation: "Well, last time we used our special mold spray, which is supposed to permanently get rid of mold. It looks like it lasted a few months, so that's pretty good." I'm sorry, since when are permanently and four months the same thing?! Anyway, it took them over a week to come and take care of something that should be taken care of immediately!!! Now all of our clothes smell like mold and even when we wash them, it's hard to get rid of the smell.

Not only that, but recently we've had problems with a leaky shower. They had someone come in to cut out a huge chunk from the ceiling above our shower to fix the pipe. Now little pieces of drywall are falling into our bathtub and all the moldy pipes are exposed! As he was leaving, he told us that he fixed the pipe, but someone else was going to come to patch up the two feet by one foot hole in our ceiling. Yeah...it's been a week and still no one has come to fix it! I wouldn't mind so much, but now the mold smell in our bathroom is even stronger!!! I'll definitely be contacting the tenant union and health department about this. They've been screwing over students for far too long!

Just finished devouring Molly's super fresh sandwiches. The salmon lox sandwich had the perfect amount of salmon and cream cheese. I also loved their balsamic dressing served with my salad. The menu is short and simple, which makes its easy for an indecisive eater like myself. I don't have to put too much brain power into selecting what to eat. I feel like I am doing my part to help the environment since everything is organic and compostable. Molly's is a great healthy, fast lunch and makes me feel better too. :) I am sure I will order again and again!

Horrendous in every way.

Service was non-existent. Food was by far the worst middle eastern food I'd ever had in my life--eggplant hummus that looked that dog vomit, slapped on a plate like dog vomit, and tasted akin to sour cream of wheat. 

Pita bread was cold and came in a plastic baggy. I examined mine for mold it was so bad.

Burger tasted like cafeteria food; beef shwarma sandwich was tough and lacking.

Quality of food is like 1960s. Not that I existed in this world then, but their brunch is actually just like how I would cook myself, hearty and tasty, although you will see some disagreements as to how they make the pancake and french toast. Also, they don't use real maple syrup.

Well, their eggs benedict is pretty good. Actually, I shouldn't talk about anything else served there, because every time I go there, I order different kinds of eggs benedict.

The worst part is their coffee. It's about the same level as the donuts chains and convenience store quality. Well, I might be a coffee snob, btu they should at least get the quality matched to Andala, Mariposa or C3 (when the sloppy staff is not working there). Well, coffee at these  three places is only passable anyway.

Oh I had such high hopes for a good veggie pizza: bursts of flavor while getting my essentials vitamins and minerals.  But I just got a veggie pizza.  Word of warning: try not to go to this place at night when there's a concert at Club Passim. There are about 4 tables for dining and you have to be quiet. Also, if you'd rather sit an adult table with an adult chair with a back (we sat on stools which is uncomfortable and gives you no place to put your coat), don't come here or get takeout. I found the place generally too dingy for my liking. On to the food.

I ordered the Portobello Redhead: portobello  mushrooms, caramelized onion and feta with red pepper-almond sauce. Sounds great right? Except for the fact that this pizza had precisely 50% less flavor than you think it would have.  Other things ordered (and reactions from friends):
- Special (some black bean and guacamole concoction: lack of flavor like that tofu burrito tried at Purple Cactus (I tried that burrito too and never has the Mexican delicacy made me want to gag so much)
- Open Faced Grilled Cheese: "Well it's something to eat, so whatever" and "Not good enough to make me want to come back."

Redeeming feature: The crust is AWESOME - thin and crispy. And it's cheap!

Time-Out Survival Guide

As Mari J. said - review it in it's class.  For restaurants between the hours of 2:01am and 6:00am, you will not find better.  Between 10-2am, you have a few other options.  In order to maximize your 'visit' its important to know what to expect. 

Pros: 
Independently owned, Unique offerings, 24 hour breakfast, History, Tolerates your drunkass, General safety (police on hand). 

Cons: 
Like the person you might be with when you go here, you might regret your indulgence in the morning. Calorie Busters! Tolerates other drunk asses, police on hand might not appreciate your demeanor.

Menu Breakdown:
*Safe choices - Most Biscuits, Sweet Tea, BBQ sandwich (I know but its not bad!), french fries
*Good, but worse for you - Fried Chicken, Macaroni and Cheese, Breakfast biscuits with cheese/bacon, fried okra, possibly a few other things. 
*Possible gut bombs, that taste good at the time - brunswich stew, pancakes, chicken liver, country fried steak, anything mashed, anything with gravy

Other things of note, sit the farthest away from the bathroom as possible, use cash, and NEVER talk back to the staff.  They are very courteous, but as I witnessed one time, will come over the counter with pots and knives at you if you get out of line. If you are drunk, walk home or call a cab, if you aren't - say hello to the police so they know you are cool and leave you alone when you leave.  Don't talk to offwork strippers, bouncers, police, posterguys, or coeds between the hours of 3-6 unless you are prepared to have a ridiculous converstation.

There are very few restaurants that I can rave about lately. This is either due to poor service, lacking food quality, deterioration of originality. This is one of the reasons I only review independently owned restaurants. Whenever people ask me to reccomend somewhere to dine, it takes less than 3 seconds for "Jose Malone's on River Street in Troy" to come out of my mouth. You cannot deny the food quality. My favorite menu items? Pineapple goat cheese quesadilla, BBQ pulled pork nachos, and the strawberry chipotle glazed ribs. I wish they would season their guacamole more and consider adding the tequila infused carrots back on the menu, but I can deal. White chocolate banana flan is now one of my favorite desserts. The premium margaritas are the best I have had in the area. The only negative thing I have to comment on is sometimes the service can be slow, but still is always friendly. It's difficult for me to go longer than a few weeks without stopping in. I hope to make a visit this week.

Not much more I can say here that hasn't be covered


Patron Margaritas ****

Best Burrito in NC (BBNC)

Hands down my favorite salsa place. Get chips and ALL of the salsa - don't cheap out on them. Sit outside if the weather permits. I have almost always got the fish burrito

One of my favorite places

We were here at lunchtime and I was amazed that the lines were not long at all, especially in a place where they will build your own sandwich. Perhaps the fact that this is tucked away in the back of the Medical Tower at St. Luke's is why it seemed so empty. My sandwich was OK but I felt the wheat roll was a bit insubstantial and not dense enough somehow. I did however like the huge range of food available and would go back if in the area.

TWO ROWS CLOSED! 

So sad. Granted that everyone I know didn't go there except on wednesdays!  (it is important to note that everyone I know is pretty lame.)But still, it was an important place in Rice. My brother had his 21st birthday celebration here. It was pretty cool seeing him get hammered for the first time in public. Also, he tried out fried pickles for the first time which is not so spectacular. But still a first is a first. I'm sure when the topic of fried pickles comes up when he's on a date with a disinterested girl who will give him mixed signals and reject him eventually, he will say, 'I know fried pickles. I tried them once at Two Rows at Rice. That was a fun place. We should go there on our second date'. To which the girl will respond, 'Oh that place closed down and I'm not going on a second date with you.' That will be doubly painful for him. TWO BLOWS if you will. Lets have a moment of silence for Two Rows and my brothers love life. 

(Shhh...cellphones off people)

Okay. Well. All that remains to be said is. Thank you Two Rows! You were wonderful!

It's hella convenient, it's open 24/7, it houses a Caribou Coffee with free wi-fi, it has its own free parking lot, items are reasonably priced, there are always sales and coupons, they have a big liquor section... really now... what more could a college student ask for???

With the opening of a County Market at Stoughton, there really is no need for me to bum rides from friends to Market Place anymore, and I never need to worry about running out of milk or toilet paper.  Plus, clubs and other organizations are always advertising/promoting here, so there's always someone giving away free food or random goodies =P

Oh Dog and Duck... when we last dated I just loved you so much. It was those years from 2000-2004, remember? We shared so many beers, had some great laughs - I even had my going-away party with you. You were a little mad at me for having so many people there without telling you, but you forgave me. It's so cute when you get mad. You had the best fish and chips, such a lovely patio, and such a hip and dumpy vibe all at the same time. The things that just made me love you like I've never loved another.

But the second time is never the same. Whatever happened to your fish and chips? They used to be the best around! Now there is so much breading on there, and they got soggy so fast. Then I wanted to watch some football the other night, but the TV had a big black line though it - which made the game very difficult to follow. And it's just too cold outside for me right now (where there's a much better TV). Plus, there is table service? When did that happen? While I do actually like it, there is just something so odd about it. Like having a goatee... it's kinda nice to feel that tickle on your neck - but you kinda look like a douche. And the service isn't really all that good... so if you just kept it like it was where I had to go get my own, there wouldn't be anyone to get mad at for the crappy service.

I still love you... there is no way that that love is not there to stay. But I'd really like it if you could improve the TV inside, fix those fish and chips, and perhaps improve the service if you're so intent on having it. You don't have to change anything else... but for the love to return to full capacity, I need you to compromise.

If you're from somewhere with actual Mexican food, this place is so-so at best.  If you've never lived in a state bordering Mexico, then you'll probably think it's pretty good.  Portions are big, food is cheap, not sure how "quality" it is, but seems fresh enough.  Perfect for the college crowd that wants a cheap, fun place to go.  Atmosphere is kitchy in that there are bright funny decorations everywhere.

As a native Texan I was leery to take the advice of my Yankee coworker from Long Island. However, I was pleased with my visit to Border Cafe. My wife and I got the beef fajitas ($11) and the cheese enchiladas with jambalaya ($7!) instead of rice and beans which was actually a nice diversion.  

While this place was not up to par with some of the places back home it was definitely well worth a visit and I'm sure I'll be back. I do recommend the beef fajitas if you enjoy mesquite favoring and  my wife, who is a big fan of cheese enchiladas, enjoyed them very much. 

The wait staff was attentive and you could tell that the restaurant was well managed. We went on a Friday night and the place was packed, however, our wait time was only about 15 minutes and the food came in a very reasonable amount of time.
The food has been good - burgers and salads. The drink specials are decent and the staff has been friendly.

It's weird how I haven't reviewed Halo until now.  

Anyway, it's in the neighborhood and I end up here very late at night occasionally.  I like it here.  The bartenders are nice, the design is cool and I usually like the weekend dance music they play.  I like to dance here.

I also hate paying the cover but I can usually avoid it.  If I have to pay, I'll just go to Cypress.

I came here for dinner the other night because I was craving sushi.

The restaurant is tiny. Mostly bar seating with a table that squeezed a party of 6 like a can of sardines. It was entertaining listening to their conversation. It looked like a girl with her parents and the bf/spouse with his parents. Apparently the girl and her parents knew the owners because they were talking to each other (in Chinese) and the girl's father was giving the female owner a neck/shoulder massage. Kind of awkward.

I ordered salmon sashimi, tiger maki and red and white maki. The salmon sashimi only came in 2 pieces and were tiny. It wasn't bad but not worth the $5-6. The makis were just okay. They were falling apart and there was just a lack of flavor. I also got some bones in the eel which was very surprising.

I enjoy mom-and-pop type of restaurants, but unfortunately I won't be back for the sushi.
Great for MIT stuff of course and useful in a pinch for some random school supply needs.

Wow, I am glad all the reviews say the food blows -- now I know I didn't miss anything.  Went there with a group of 6 people, in the middle of the day on a weekday, well after lunch time but well before dinner, and the host said he couldn't seat us. The place was empty, but he told us he couldn't accommodate us for at least 45 minutes.  No one else had to wait, just us, standing there staring at all the empty tables while he gave us a dirty look and had a nasty attitude that basically suggested we go somewhere else.  So we did.

at this location i had the bbq steak burrito and it was different in a good way.  The bbq sauce sweet not overpowering.  The employees here also seem nice.  This place is better to sit and eat at with more room.  They had the tv on and music playing I would like just one or the other...I get easily confused and I was really curious about the river monster they were hunting on tv.  This place is clean, sauces great, good stuff.

For one of my supervisor's birthday, we ordered a cake here. It was a chocolate oreo mousse cake.  It was suuper rich in flavor and very sweet. I'm not much of a chocolate cake fan, but I feel like this had a very good portion of chocolate. The edges had oreo crumbs and the interior had chocolate cake topped with mousse.

Not bad, I think they have a bigger variety of cakes too since I heard from my other supervisor that we always order cakes from here.

my search continues for good pizza in cambridge......
 Me and the gf saw pinnochio reviews on yelp. After experincing   oggis  the disaster we tried it.
 we arrived inthe pouring rain..... order a slice of cheese first. vs  a large pie( we wanted the option to cut our losses after 1 pie)
 
 result is... a

 You people out here dont know good pizza... really. 
you know chowder, you know boston accents, you know bad driving ... but you  dont know pizza!!!!
Crust was crunchy , like dry crunchy as in no flavor and kind of sort of burnt.
Sauce.. no taste needs more oregano and sugar...
Cheese was ehh.  The entire thing had no "soul"

 it was meh....  I am honestly thinking that bertuccis might be the best pizza out there. .. next stop is armando's and   village kitchen..... let s see

Being a bit of a foodie - I've eaten at every Austin Thai restaurant a few dozen times (one of my favorite cuisines - and I like eating out 8 days a week). I've been eating at Madam Mam's for the last 8 years - even before it was called Madam Mam's (it was just known as Noodles and More then). 
This is the best thai place in Austin - with only one other place coming close (Titaya - see my yelp on that - if you have nothing better to do...). The only other Thai restaurant that I CRAVE apart from Madam Mam's is on 3rd Avenue (and 28th Street) in NYC - called Jaiya Thai. That's THE best thai  food outside of Thailand (I've been fortunate enough to pig out on Thai food in Thailand - Phuket was my favorite).
So - to summarize - if you TRULY love thai food - fly to Phuket. If Phuket is not for you - fly to NYC - catch a cab to Jaiya Thai (3rd and 28th). If NYC is not for you - drive over to UT (spend about 30 mins looking for free parking - or pay to park in the covered tower garage a few steps away from Madam Mam's). Walk over to Madam Mam's for the best Thai food west of New York! ALL THE CURRIES ARE FANTASTIC (this is the only place that can truly do green curry right). If 3 stars spiciness (default for most curries) just doesn't do it for you - try the Jungle curry or the green fish ball curry (5 star chillies). That should open up your nostrils (and your neighbour's as well). 
 
 For some kicking noodles - try the Pad Spaghetti Kee Mao (I think F5). For a thick masala type sauce - try the slow cooked beef curry (P44). The entire 'special menu' (P41 through P50) is a treat for your taste buds. Order anything from that list - and you will not be disappointed.

The chu-chee salmon will make you see salmon in a whole new light. Just a big chunk of fresh salmon in a great tasting red coconut curry. 

I can write an individual note on each entree in the menu - but I'll just get hungry in the process...

 That's it - I've downloaded ALL my hard-earned Thai cuisine knowledge - for YOUR TASTE-BUDS ONLY!

Slight addendum to the story: while it was really cool that they patched my tire and didn't charge me, I now kind of wish they had, because then I would have some leg to stand on in asking for them to cover the costs I later incurred.  You see, when they put the tire back on, they cinched the lug nuts on with the air wrench, which is much faster than a regular old wrench-with-a-handle, but which torques it to three hundred pounds.  Three hundred pounds of torque is a Very Bad Idea.  In the best case, if you get a flat tire, and all you have is the dinky little 12-inch wrench to put the spare on, you're completely fucked unless you weigh 300 pounds and like jumping on wrench handles.  In the WORST case, you are me.  I drive a VW, which has those finicky little locking bolts that require a key to open.  When you apply three hundred pounds of force to that key six months later, it shears in half, leaving you with a bolt that has to drilled out at some expense, and leaving you with three out of four snow tires on your car, which you can barely limp over to the dealership in.  Not a good scene.

Sounds like a really cool bunch of guys, but make sure you ask them not to use the air wrench to put your tires back on...

Seeing as how it's a nondescript bar that doesn't really have great drink specials or good live music, I think the thing that makes me love the Dead Mule so much is the ambience. The Christmas lights strung throughout the trees overlooking the deck stay up year-round and give the area a nice glow on balmy summer nights, while the fireplace inside is a good place to warm up during the more chilly months. It's a small bar, but because it's in a renovated house there are a few different rooms and you don't feel crammed into one tiny space. The service has always been friendly, and even though they are a members & guests only bar, it's not really enforced. Maybe it's because it's sandwiched between the Franklin Hotel and Chipotle Grill, but the Dead Mule doesn't attract the young East Franklin St. crowd. Something tells me the patrons prefer it that way.

Shin's is Great!    Really great prices (Cheap), good portions, great Sushi (yes, better that some other places at a cheaper price), they have beer on tap and it's always a fun place to eat; loud and fun and everyone is always enjoying the dinning experience there.    Birthdays there are a fun event that gets everyone involved - something the birthday guest and you will remember.    They are open late, which is really great for us late diners.  We were introduced to Shin's by our two boys (now in College) and we are now regular mid-week, late diners and will continue!
The Middle East is a good venue to see bands where you knew the drummer before he got the tattoos.  Its a very relaxed, beer by the can, kind of atmosphere great for intimate shows.

this place rocks! I'm a student at a nearby graduate school whose campus is so lackluster and the coffee shop there closes at 4. They are cash only, and charge $1 extra for drinks in paper/to-go cups (no way to force people to be eco-friendly than to hit their wallets). Drinks are super inexpensive ad they have all sorts of baked goods that seem to run out in the afternoon/evening. They also have fancy chips, Annie's mac and cheese, kombucha, etc. 

Lots of tables to study at, plus power outlets and free wifi. It does get noisy here though and can get crowded. It's also a little hard to find.

Great lunch specials - the portions are quite large and filling. I had my fill on a Japanese vegetable curry and their 99-cent unagi nigiri (which was really pretty!) for $10 flat, including tax and a generous tip. 

One of my friends got a crunch roll and it wasn't what you usually expect of a crunch roll, but it tasted pretty good still. She also got a spicy roll and it was quite spicy. ;) Speaking of rolls, it always amuses me to read what kind of names sushi restaurants give their rolls. Here, there are Shattuck Rolls, Durant Rolls, Sexy Sexy Rolls (or something like that)...

The restaurant is really big (it's rare to see such a large restaurant in Berkeley!) and looks really nice. I think there's a special banquet/meeting/group room too in the back. It's not really busy so it seems empty at lunch when there's only a few people. I hope they hold up under this economy...I'd hate to see this place go!

Pretty good deal for lunch at a sit-down restaurant. It's owned by Koreans, so there's a bit of a Korean feel to the place, but it seems like the owner speaks Japanese too. Anyways, I'd come back again! [in fact, my friends and I are coming next week for sushi and KARAOKE!!]

I've been going to this dentist for a long time and I've always tried to change my dentist but can't find anyone i can trust..
They have good dentist but VERY expensive.
They try to sell extra staff as much as possible.
The first time when I went there, I spent $500 extra for something that I didn't need..
The receptionist are awful.. I asked them to check if my HMO would cover my teeth cleaning and they said they would pull out my file and find out. 4 days later with 3 phone call, still they haven't find out yet.
I made an appointment and I showed up on time, they said they didn't have my appointment.
I made another appointment and showed up, I had to wait for over an hour.

I am so tired of this place..

Went there in a quite big group of people, probably about 15 and they did a very good job at seating and serving us. I was actually surprised by how efficient they were!

I had the garlic pepper pork which was really really good! I also tasted some of the dishes from other people and they seemed all right.

Not sure I love this place, but I definitely like it a lot!!

Probably my favorite place to eat in the Asian ghetto (come on, have you ever heard anyone call it the "Durant food court"?). I went here about once a month during my four years at Cal. Although I've heard rumors about the owner being a jerk/racist/baby-eater, all the guys who there have always been really nice to me.

While the hummus, baba ganoush and "potato salad" are all mediocre, the yogurt sauce (which goes equally well with salad and meat) is worth a star by itself. Some of the plates are kind of overpriced, but the student special is a terrific deal.

When I encountered the Slice Truck:
1. I was at work & my company was giving us free tickets to try the truck.
2. I was extremely hungry.

And usually, Free Food + Famished Asian Girl = (orgasmic food experience)^12

Unfortunately, it didn't perform.  I had the Grandma (appropriately named) and pepperoni.   It was greasy, flavorless and the crust was way too thick. Frigid pizza.  Disappointing food truck experience.  Never again.

Great Italian food!

I came here for my second anniversary during lunch hour. The place is cozy and the service is excellent. That being said, I would imagine that it can get really loud when it gets busy.

We had the Calamari for an appetizer which was served with a garlic lemon sauce. Great calamari, and I've had my fair share at other places. A salmon bisque came with my meal and also bread (which looked, smelled, AND tasted amazing I ordered the Stucca ravioli and my lady had the shrimp capallini. They must of gave her 10 huge shrimp with her order--it looked so good. My food tasted like ravioli had a baby with pumpkin pie and then bathed in awesome sauce--it really was something else.

One of my favorite Italian places that I have ever been to. Puts Olive Garden to shame.
Their sourdough cheddar chive loaf is amazing.
Hoagie Haven is great. They are cash only, so don't forget. Prices are reasonable and food is delicious. I've been going here since I was a kid, love it.

When I first started working in the area, I ate at Zankou for about six months straight. Then I got sick of it and didn't eat here for a year-and-a-half or so. I've started again! The quarter chicken plate is my favorite. Also the kabob plate. I hate waiting for the kabob, so if you can remember to call in an order for it, it's worth it. Smother on the garlic, too!

I'm saving money these days for a trip, but I still come here in the afternoon to pick up my tabbouleh salad at least. Sooo yummy. The people who work here probably think I'm anorexic because it's the only thing I order these days, but I get it to supplement my homemade lunch or to make me feel better about eating a microwavable lunch. This isn't an expensive restaurant, but even getting the cheap things add up. 

The staff is VERY friendly. And the second register is now allowed to take credit cards (only regulars will know why this is so great). When in doubt, order ahead. It gets busy here, and if you're like me and don't want to watch your lunch vaporize while you read the articles about the restaurant on the wall for the hundredth time, make the damn call.

Walking into this building and you are in for problems. The elevators are out of order. You get to the seventh floor and there are stains from the vent penetrating the entire hallway floor. Gross. There is recycling and trash in the hallway. You get into the office and there is no receptionist. You fill out the same paperwork as on the internet application only to learn there are more demands than previously stated. You'll have to go in every week and donate from what i think the Russian lady said, donate blood once a month, and if you break your commitment before 6 months, you'll owe them $7500. You also can't touch drugs, so forget that doobie at the concert this summer. Maybe if you are having trouble finding a job, this might be a good fill in.

I've been here three or four times, and each time I've been impressed. It's located in a place notorious for going out of business (before Moti's it was Rolando's, and before Rolando's it was Fatzo's, etc.) and I'm hoping that the same thing doesn't happen to this one. 

Anyway, they've got the best lamb and beef gyro I've ever had- the kind that they actually cut off the spit before they make the sandwich, not the pre-formed kind. Their chicken curry is really good. I've heard mixed reviews about the falafels- I'm not a fan of them to begin with, so I couldn't judge how they are here.

My only problem is I'm hoping they incorporate some sort of double-doored entryway so that the tables sitting right next to the entrance don't have to suffer the cold air as it comes in each time the door is opened. The last time I went we were seated right next to the door, although there were only two or three others eating at the time. They've recently expanded into Bucci's old location, though, and it looks beautiful! This makes it much more accessible for larger parties.

All in all I'd highly recommend this place. It's relatively cheap, the food is really good, the wait staff is friendly in my experience, and I'd love to see this place stick around.

This was the one place in Providence I had bookmarked before my trip because it got such great reviews, and I'm glad we stopped.  Located along a great little street in the heart of Providence (close to Brown), it's surrounded by shops, nightlife, everything.  I really wanted to hang around, but I had only gotten 1 hr of sleep the night before on the plane, so we took our order to go.
My only complaint is I wish the pita bread had been grilled either before or after making my gyro.  I really hate tortillas and pitas that break when you eat them.  I want my tortillas steamed and my pitas grilled, though I'm sure they would throw it on the grill if you asked.
I love the variety of things you can get on your gyro (or whatever you're getting)-hummus, tahini, tabouli, siracha, tzaziki (say that 10 times fast), all for no extra charge.  I wanted to get everything, but figured my pita would be way too weighed down by the end.
Their pita chips are really good, topped with some sort of spice, and really good with a side of hummus.
Also, the staff was great.  I loved the way the guy wrapped up my gyro in foil and then twisted it around, threw it back and forth between his hands, like a little show.  I love when people have fun at their jobs.
Best of all East Side Pocket is cheap!
Great Food. Good staff. Cool bartenders. Best beer.

I know someone who's not going to be too pleased with me when they see this review, but Middlesex only gets an "A-OK" from me. The DJing is usually solid, as many other reviewers have mentioned, but overall the place doesn't inspire me. I will say, though, that the service at the bar is excellent, especially when you're there with someone who's a regular.

In the end, I'm not sure what Middlesex is trying to be -- but maybe that's the point.

This is such a cool little bar- my friend's and I have come here often, we love their specialty cocktails and there's never a problem finding a place for all of us to sit.  Parking is tight and we usually have to park on another street or elsewhere, but what else is new?  It has a great laid back vibe and feels very private inspite of the fact that its in the Village.  My only complaint is that it can sometimes take a long time to get a drink.

Dudes, really? Every time I have been here it has either been closed or insanely busy. EVERY TIME. Also, every sandwich or burger is mediocre when I finally do get in there. It's pricey. What am I missing? Do I need to try a frappe or something?!

If you think this is the best burger in Boston/Cambridge you either have not been to very many burger places or you have no taste buds. And I'm very sorry for you if you were born without a palate, but I can recommend some other places that will knock your socks off. R.F. O'Sullivans, anyone? Hell, UBurger beats this place hands down.

I like the place for the history but they need to take out some of the tables. I feel like I have to invite the strangers next to me to rest their elbows in my ketchup just so they can get to their meal. The last time I was there I got elbowed in the head, twice, by our server.

when i heard about this place i was super excited to hear there were bahn mi sandwiches central, but man bite mi needs to take some lessons from tam deli and lulu b's. these sandwiches are haphazardly put together. the carrots are too shredded, the cilantro still had stems and there was way too much pepper.  not to mention that it could of used double what was on there.  the great thing is that it is only $3 and some change, and some potential flavor there.  I would pay 4.50 for something a lil more hearty like lulu b's.  fresh ingredients and better prepped veggies. sorry bite mi, but you can bite me. i'll take the trip down lamar next time.

Almost a home away from home.  We stayed at the Penthouse for a couple of nights and had fairly high expectations.  

Parking wasn't always ideal but there was always a space.  Biggest problem is most people drive SUV's and can't park.  

Front desk - 5 stars

Cleanliness - pretty good

Property condition - 3 stars, it needs some handyman touches

Our room was 2 bedroom / 2 bath loft with 20 foot ceilings!  Full kitchen, fireplace, and overall one of the best rooms I've rented away from home.  

Free breakfast..... hmmmmm.... well, do you like kids?  What about unruly kids?  What about parents that can't control their kids?  Whiny kids, messy kids, messy parents, crowded buffet lines?  I'd rather pay!  The breakfast is fine for the price (free) but the company sucks.  Now if you have kids and need to minimize expenses while on vacation, then this is the place to be.

I've heard a lot about this place and finally got a chance to find this obscurely-placed burger joint in the depths of some alley in Pasadena.  Parking is in a small structure (don't forget to validate before you leave the restaurant!).  The surrounding area was quaint and consisted of a few fancier restaurants and a cheese store (which was closed when I got there).

We didn't get an appetizers.  I ordered a 1/3 lb veggie burger on an English muffin, and the boyfriend got a 1 lb beef burger.  Due to his order, we had to wait half an hour for our orders to come out to allow for cooking to medium.  I wished then that we had ordered an appetizer....

The service was only somewhat attentive even though we were sitting at the bar (long waits that night).

My burger was good... one of the better veggie patties I've ever had because you could see the grains, corn, and beans that make it.
