The English muffin was toasted perfectly, and the sprouts I had on them were fresh.  I wish they gave more cheese (I ordered cheddar).  Additionally, I got grilled onions, which I ended up scraping off because they were oily/soggy with too much pepper.  They nearly ruined my burger, ugh.

I had also ordered BBQ sauce, which I found overpowered the burger.  Next time, I'd probably get mayo because the burger didn't come with any on its own.  The boyfriend and I agreed that the sauces they gave on the side were pretty stingy, and we weren't sure if they charged for extra since the menu indicated that additional sauces were an additional $.50 at the time you place your order.

Overall, the fact that my veggie burger cost $8.95 is enough to make me believe I can produce similar results at home for much cheaper.

A few weeks ago, the zipper on my purse broke so I had to get a new one pronto.  I scoured all of the shops in Harvard Square for a new handbag, but I was not getting much luck.  I wanted a simple, small, neutral-toned purse, and most of the bags around the neighborhood were too busy in design, too bulky, or not the right color.  Monella had the closest bag to what I wanted.  I bought a small Shiraleah purse in the sand color.  It was a bit pricey, but I plan on using it a lot so I don't mind TOO much.  

About a week later, I shopped around Harvard Square for a pair of nude-colored heels for my graduation.  This is no easy feat for me because my shoe size is 5.5.  Monella, like most stores, did not have a size 5.5 in these patent leather Steve Madden pumps that I wanted.  When the saleslady saw that I really liked them, she offered to call other Monella stores to see if they had the pair in stock.  One location had the shoes and was able to have them sent to the Cambridge shop.  I always appreciate that kind of customer service since my busy schedule does not always allow me to stop by every store in the city for a shoe size that is seldom readily available.

definitely not a four star place. The food was excellent along with presentation but the service was horrible! 
I had the rib eye steak which has an excellent sauce with cooked garlic cloves. the spinach wasn't very tasty that came with it but the potatoes were great! slightly crispy on the outside with rosemary and pepper . 
My boyfriend had the pasta with clams, muscles, calamari, scallops and a light red sauce. He said that his food was very good, once again presentation was nice. 
I tried the malbec wine the $9.50 one per glass. It was full bodied and as it breathed it got spicier. not bad. good place but not a repeat.

If I'm feeling a burger I generally go to buns... BUT if I want a burger, a beer, and to sit outside, then PT's couldn't be more Awesome. Its a good vibe, great deal, and tasty fries. (they're pretty salty, and I think its lime salt)  I remember them having PBR by the can at a $1 each. Good place and easily doable during a lunch break.

I am struggling between 3 and 4 stars.  I've been twice since it opened but probably won't go again for a while.  The food was delicious, excellent meals both times, however the menu was too small and it offered nothing at a reasonable enough price to make this place my go-to.  I hope they add some simple dishes with matching prices to up the take out and local crowd.  This neighborhood needs a restaurant where people who don't want to cook can pop down and get a bite.  Lido is more of a destination because of its price and small menu.   

The staff were pleasant but not representative of the neighborhood, I'd love to see some diversity among the staff.

Firstly: $10 cash minimum. Come prepared. 

Fantastic coffee.  Fantastic!  Their well-pulled espresso drinks are some of the best I've had in Cambridge. I once indulged in some sort of flavored latte frippery, which, as a black coffee drinker, I admit was a mistake, but it was disappointing all the same (and expensive, to boot). While drinks are surprisingly well-priced, beware: a small is an 8-oz espresso size cup. I don't mind terribly, as I am generally of the opinion that portions are bigger than they need to be, but it was surprising the first time around. 

One thing I've never been disappointed by: the food. The salads are always fresh, have more upscale options (berry/feta is delicious), and are a filling size. The pastries are routinely fan-freaking-tastic and not to be missed. Plus, the place is beautiful. Crema's exposed-brick decor with its second-floor loft seating is beautiful and welcoming. Friends and guests I bring along always coo at its cuteness upon passing the threshold. 

Given its quality and charming decor, I have grudgingly accepted that I only ever stand a one-in-four chance of finding a seat.  This is fine in the summer, but awkward during the winter if I wanted to sit and talk with my companion. Truly sad, however, was my discovery that there is no WiFi in Crema. But I guess then seats would be even harder to find, so I'll take the trade-off.

Luscious, healthy salads and sandwiches, oh my!

I used to walk by this place on my excursions to Telegraph. I would see these huge bowls full of salad and fresh toppings, with a big slice of bread and these thick, amazing sandwiches...I had to try it. 

I'm not sorry I did. I waited patiently in line with Babe and we got a huge salad and each a sandwich...we barely made a dent in the salad. It was so good, so fresh. My sandwich made my mouth water, the servers were so generous with their ingredients. They made it right in front of us and I couldn't stop staring at all their amazing food. 

Watch out though, because this place is very popular. Therefore, seating can require some waiting, as with the line. Cafe Intermezzo is amazing!

Another vote for the sweet potato sandwich! I should hate this sandwich because it's got so many ingredients that I don't prefer (sprouts, sweet potato, wheat bread), but the whole really is a lot more than the sum of its parts here at Crema Cafe! And even for this omnivore, the vegetarian sweet potato sandwich really satisfied! The creaminess of the avocado, the tang of the apple, the out-of-worldness of the dressing/sauce...it's a recipe for :P***** Seriously. 

There were about 4 people in line ahead of me, but I had to wait about 15 minutes for my sandwich. If I were seated with a cup of water and bread basket to hold me over, it would be alright. But standing there by the pick-up counter, dodging people going in and out of the bathroom, stymied the experience a bit. 

But I love the price (sandwich + cookie + bottled water [less than sign] $10!), love the atmosphere and love that sandwich!

Tip: Credit card minimum $10.

I've come to find out my largest regret in life is not applying to UW.

If only i had known this magnificent place would be within walking distance, open till 2am, and serve the best damn falafel, gyro, and chicken shawarma!

Disclaimer, I've worked here for years. But ask yourself - how many restaurants retain a good bit of their employee base for years? Not that many! The Carolina Brewery has a special place in my heart, and stomach, and for good reason.

I'd say about 95% of their brews are brilliant, taking into account my personal brew tastes - so keep that in mind when you're ordering, and let your server know what beer you typically drink! Also, if you're not sure what beer to get, I know the servers are happy to offer a little sample taste. Or, you can purchase the sample paddle, which is a paddle of small pours of each beer on tap at the time, so you can try everything.

I've always loved the food - the chicken bites done buffalo style were my MOD for years until I sort of stopped eating meat, and every time I work I swear I'm going to have a heart attack if I don't order french fries after the shift. And there's a regularly changing seasonal menu with all sorts of new things to try. The layout of the restaurant is also cool, with full views of the brewing equipment (and if you dine during the day you can watch the brewers at work). And the place can accommodate large parties regularly, a definite plus.

Great service, great beer, great fellow employees!

We were brought to Olive House as prospective students for grad school.  I had their lentil soup and chicken briyani, and both were excellent.  Everyone was very happy with their food, and the portions were pretty large-- no one finished their food.  They were a little confused what to do with a group our size (8 people).  The service wasn't the greatest (lack of water refills, etc) but the food was good.

How often have I come here and yet not realized that "Deep End" was actually a part of East End?  I thought it was just a clever nickname born from the location.  Well I'll be darned.

I can't speak to upstairs, but here's what I do know.  East End (the street level) is a small dance club type bar that's kind of like Players only with a more healthy acknowledgment that the outside world exists.  The music is much better and the clientele takes a step down on the dodgy meter.  Generally people here are higher class, though still extremely Greek.

The real attraction here is Deep End, the basement.  It's grim and dark and loud and furious and sleazy... but in a good way.  You come down here to pound back terrible, cheap beer with your other cheap friends (chances are I'll be one of them) and play beer pong on some excellent tables.  It's a dive bar's dive bar.  You'll love i.t

I really wanted to like this store... because it was my numero uno reason for coming to Berkeley, the reviews here, and the website was pretty impressive.

It's not on Telegraph, so I had difficulty finding the place (because once again I suck at directions given to me by the friendly folks over at Filthy Dripped, AND I've passed by this joint a couple of times prior-I'm PATHETIC). Finally I gave up and called them up. Super friendly. I had good feelings.

It's really small. Eyeballing (ROUGHLY OKAY???) 20-30ft by 12ft. I'm only assuming they have other sizes in the back, because space seems sooo limited that they really have NO CHOICE to just have one size out. 

Because it's so out there, this should be your go-to if you just can't find that 10 Deep plaid button upl you've been feenin' fo, but TRUE and all your nearby urban boutiques were SOS (Sold Out Sucka!)

They have some stuff for the ladies, and they had some pretty cute and cool hats. The shoes weren't nothing out of the ordinary.

The people that work here seem to love working here, because my bf and I got a warm reception from them even if we didn't look too interested to buy anything. But in a nutshell...don't come looking here unless it's for something specific or you're just in town. If you do, don't expect to get dissed because they don't play that here.

Ever since Amoeba usurped Rasputins hold on the "coolest record store in the Bay Area" throne, Rasputins has been sliding down a sad and pathetic trajectory. Up through 1990, Rasputins was THE primary destination for music obsessives who like the cheaper prices of 2nd hand LPs/CDs and an eclectic collection of a wide variety of music that you just can't find in most other places. Rasputins was simply unrivaled, and its great reputation and high standing in the pantheon of great Bay Area record shops seemed cemented. But when Amoeba opened shop down the street, that all began to shift, as Amoeba offered better prices, friendlier and more knowledgeable staff, and slightly more generous amounts of $$$ given to people who sell them their records. Soon enough, Amoeba's increasingly fabulous used selection had the lead  in cool, interesting, sought after vinyl. Within a year of its opening, Amoeba became the record store on Telegraph you'd go to *first*. 

Nowadays Rasputins is a sad joke. The vinyl selection, in particular, has become a heinously absurd situation. Whoever prices their LPs is either highly delusional or simply on crack. LPs that are grossly overpriced increasingly look as if they've been subjected to a disk sander. I'm sorry, but $17 for a not-that-rare Cocteau Twins or Smiths record that's so badly scratched it's totally unplayable? Who the hell are they trying to fool? (Similar records in crappy condition wouldn't go for more than a few bucks at Amoeba). Hell, it seems anything that Rasputins sells for $5 or less has been used as a cat-scratching post before going out on the shelves. I mean, they've just completely lost touch with reality in this department. 

The used CD selection is also kind of sad. True, the average used CD price seems to have fallen below that of Amoeba's, but the selection has become comparatively thin and uninteresting. 

Furthermore, one really gets the sense that Amoeba's staff tends to care more about what they're doing, so that not only are they friendlier, but much more with it in general. Rasputins, by contrast, now seems only to hire jaded, aloof, unknowledgeable college kids to augment the staff of ancient burn-outs who've been there since the 70s. 

Basically, Amoeba surpasses Rasputins in every way, and has continued to do so for over 15 years. Throughout this time, Rasputins has made no attempt to catch up, improve its shortcomings, or even acknowledge Amoeba's existence. Blinded by self-importance and a deeply faded legacy, Rasputins stubbornly forges ahead down its sad path of overt mediocrity. 

That said, I do still pop in there now and then and very occasionally find an LP or two sold at a fair price that reflects a connection with reality. But walking out empty-handed has become much more the norm.

I had lunch there recently with a friend and I have to say I was pleased with the food and service. I ordered the Paragon Burger topped with aged Vermont cheddar cheese which was prepared quite will and I recommend you try it.  Their Sangria, though a little stronger then I'm used to for a Sangria, was good as well.

Atmosphere-  Welcoming when you arrive.  Wait to be seated.  University Environment. Loud

Food-  Wings are perfectly prepared and fried to crispy golden brown.  Quite a few flavors to choose from.  Sweet Tea is delicious!  Nom Nom Nom

Service -  Meh,  its a typical scene where college kids need a part-time job to help pay for books, food, etc  slow and steady but im used to it.

Pinocchio's is awesome!

I have been a long-time fan of their delicious, desirable Sicilian pizza! They also have that great deal where you can get two slices of your favorite Sicilian slice for $4.25 +tax, which is great for students (like me) and people struggling in this economy for great food at a favorable price.

I highly recommend everyone to drop by Harvard Square and give Pinocchio's a try.

Apollo has the reputation for selling cheap and MSG-filled food, but I think it really depends on which food you order. Some dishes like pork and dark egg(pidan) congee are pretty good and healthy, but other dishes can be really greasy. But overall I think the food is good and cheap.

They don't have a contact number, they also have terrible management. I went with a friend to sell a phone at a certain price but apparently they didn't have enough cash to buy the equipment so they checked it into their system and went ahead and did whatever testing was necessary and let us know they would call by Saturday because they "should" have enough by then.. mind you we were there on Wednesday. Well the weekend rolls by with no contact and then finally on Monday they let us know they've got enough cash to buy the phone. We drive from the south bay to pick up the money and now they won't honor the price of the purchase from the day we dropped of the phone! It was enough of a drop in price to make a difference. The "manager" did nothing to help and tried to tell us that he was already skipping other customers would had brought equipment in to be purchased to "help" us out. Bottom line is this place pulled a bait and switch, it's not like it was around the corner that we could just pop in and ask or even just say we'll come back another time when the prices change again. Don't do business with these guys if you value any sort of customer service. They lack professionalism (using profanity while there were multiple customers in the store.) and the manager lacks integrity. Sell your stuff on eBay or craigslist, not only will you probably get more $$, you'll probably deal with much nicer people.

Also you can find better deals on every product they sell in their stores second hand on eBay and craigslist. Sometimes you'll even find better deals on the same items new online.

Oh my, I had the best chicken pot pie, corn bread and iced tea here!  It's a good thing I don't live nearby ... I would surely become an addict.

I didn't stay at the inn, but enjoyed the grounds and gift shop.  It's a totally cute place to stop if you're on a road trip.

The best thing about this place in my opinion is the pizza and calzones.  The rest is pretty average Italian fare.  They have some things that are on the pricey side but the calzones and pizza are at a fair price.  The service can be a bit slow but overall it's not bad. Their lunch buffet is good if you don't mind not having too much variety.  They usually put out a few pizzas with a few options for dessert.  The quality is great but the variety not so much.  I'd go here again but only for their pizza or calzones.

Here's how to eat properly at Chipotle if you want to get around 1/3 of your calories from protein:

1. Get the burrito bol (no tortilla).  At first you feel bad that you're paying the same price for them to not give you a tortilla.  Eventually you stop caring.  I still get rice, as even though it has very little protein, I'm not really interested in starving to death.

2. Get beans.  It doesn't really matter which kind, though I personally prefer black beans.

3. Don't get the fajita vegetables.  Yes, that is correct, do not get the vegetables.  They contain tons of salt and fat.  Get lettuce instead.

4. Don't get sour cream or guacamole.  Neither has much protein and they actually charge you extra for guacamole, in violation of several U.N. resolutions.

5. Get meat.  I like the chicken.

6. Get whatever salsa you want.  I prefer the green salsa.

7. Drink water instead of soda or juice.

8. Don't even think about getting chips.

Use this nutritional guide to help you:

http://www.chipotlefan.com/index.php?id=nutrition_calculator

This meal will cost you less than $6, which is not bad for a healthy protein-rich meal with around 600 calories.

Some simple words to describe:

Yummy.

Cheap.

HUGE!

If you have a sweettooth this is SOO the right place-

Example:  Fresh cookies baked daily- throughout the day.  They are always soft and moist.  Icecream sandwiches custom made for $1.50?  its HUUUGE!  and SO good- the quality of ice cream is good too.

Shaved ice... to die for.

$1 for three big cookies and even brownies are cheap- and always fresh.  I take these for my cousinsand they are always so ohappy to have them.  This is the perfect dessert place.  

BTW they have hot dogs and drinks too for cheap combos as well!  So you can probably get a cheap lunch and dessert here!  The  line tends to be long esp at night, but its quick moving. The crowd alone tells you just HOW good this place is!

Oh and do try their strawberry cheesecake ice cream.  OMG toooo good!

(My fave:  White Choc Macademia, Double Choc with Nuts and Choc w/white choclate chips)... TOO GOOD!!!

I'm rating this place mainly just for Sornam's power yoga class. She's a great instructor and the class is really challenging. She manages to keep it peaceful even through the gym is packed to the gills (with giggling freshman). 

This is a great gym for students: $10/semester! Not worth the crowds and the beat up equipment if you are paying full price.

Update: 5/31/07
If you want to sweat to great tunes, Amanda's spin class rocks!

I bet everyone has that one restaurant where they order the exact same thing   every time, and this is mine.  Hai Ky has been the model of consistency with my #44 (vermicelli with grilled pork and egg roll)  hold the cucumbers and  fish sauce please!  I would venture to say that the bun at Hai Ky is among the best in Austin,  and it has finally dethroned Kim Phung on Lamar as my personal favorite in Austin.  

Staff is super nice, there's not a dish over 8 dollars on the menu, and they give you enough for two servings if you feel so inclined.

Some of you may have noticed the "214 food poisonings and counting" caption below my reviews. Note: by the time you read this, it may be bigger. This scorecard is a result of, but not limited to, experimentation with restaurants, ingredients, Asian markets, Costa Rican car wheel grills, Foogoo and my mother's cooking which I no longer eat - mother's cooking that is. 

Naan and Curry has the supreme honor of having 4 notches in my stomach's lining. I am reminded of president Bush's famous "Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice... Won't get fooled again." That being said, I am not president material, and for me 4 times is a lesson learning score. 

Let me begin by saying that if anybody could engineer a method by which I could inject Naan and Curry Tikka Masala into my veins, as well as produce a toothpaste with the flavor and fill all public pools with this liquid gold buttery goodness - well to that person I would be greatly indebted. 

This place makes a solid, buttery rich Tikka Masala. Forget the chicken in there, I'll order just the sauce, Ill order it with Paneer, I'll order it with green eggs and ham and eat them I will!. Like a good Pavlovian dog I will drool a Saint Bernard under the table if I had access to just one of the dubiously-hygienic 5 gallon buckets of Masala sauce I see the cooks lugging around time to time. This stuff is that good. 

The Lamb is great, the Chana Masala is great, the Aloo Gobi keeps me asking for more. The Tandoor chicken is moist and spicy sweet. Even the free chai tea doesn't taste like crap. 

Man I really love this place. But guess what? I've been folded over in half one too many times to give these guys any more of my money, dignity and gastro-intestinal fortitude. No more I say. Unless I see a yellow-orange IV, I say no thank you to Mr. Naan and his wife Mrs. Curry. No thank you sir and ma'am, though tempted I am for your liquid heroin of delicious golden joy, I will not falter. 

To put a nail in the Naan and Curry coffin let me just say that right across the street on Durant, you can find a joint called House of Curries. And guess what? They use the same recipes and you get to keep the food in you for more than 2 hours. I can almost guarantee it. 

Exact same recipes except for one: the mouth watering, crispy/fluffy, buttery garlicky or oniony, Naan. Yes boys and girls the naan at Naan and Curry is not only unbeatable but unrepeatable even by the wonderful House of Curries. 

So I do bid you all farewell - as it must have been written in the stars, that a wretch of my moral ineptitude and self loathing could not resist another visit, another hit from the golden heroin you call Tikka Masala folded into the perfect naan. So raise your glasses high you fellow experience junkies because I am 215 food poisonings and counting.

This website is great and their services are superb. The manager is really helpful. Not to mention the website is heavily staff so there sees to be always some people on there telling others about the latest low down on Berkeley. Woot. Go B-Live!

The food is just bad. The soups are all warmed up straight from the Sysco can, their "famous" bread is thick, doughy, and like eating stone, their Hollandaise sauce is gross and tastes like it has been sitting in a vat all week, the list goes on and on... I just don't know why people continue to open their wallets to go to this overpriced place. Even the service leaves a bad taste in your mouth - there is one really nice waitress, and everyone else is just crabby because they're cramped and pushing customers around in this tiny space all day.

The sandwiches are crummy and overpriced, they pinch pennies in ways that make you feel bad about your food (when they say "avocado" it means a small dollop of guacamole), the omelettes are huge greasy overly salted messes, their fruit is under-ripe and crunchy...the only thing I like is their waffles.

In every way it's obvious that they just run a business, that they don't take any pride in their food. I just can't say enough about the food - yet I keep eating there because it's so close to the medical school and they're basically the only game in town when I'm in a rush. Which is why I'm baffled by the enormous lines that form on the weekends. People, it's not worth the wait! There are plenty of other brunch spots that taste far better and are priced more reasonably.

I'm bumping this bad boy down based on plain rudeness ..
around 9:30 on a t.n.o we were looking for some food.    
We walked over here because I remembered it was open late.   
Due to a snowstorm I'm sure they had been pretty dead so the dining room was dark.   The sign stated they were open until 11 and there were 2 youngish girls sitting at a table playing with a laptop.    
The doors were open so we walked in and I politely asked if they were still open. I was impolitely notified that they were.  One of them got up and went behind the counter looking annoyed.  Since the lights were out I asked if it was only for takeout or if we could sit down.   The reply?  "Uh you could if you want"     I have never witnessed so much eye rolling in one conversation.  I turned around to look at my companion  "ruck cheese fries?"   It was agreed.   I said Nevermind and we were off.  I'm sure the girls were delighted that they could go back to stalking their crushes on Facebook.

I finally made it to Amherst to check out Moti - the dinning area is beautifully decorated, clean, cozy & warm...very tasteful Middle Eastern decor. The service was excellent. The food was not excellent but it was very good and beautifully served. I look foreword to going back and would highly recommend it.

This is my absolute favorite independent bookstore.  I haven't shopped at a chain since moving to Boston, and the only reason I can say that is because of the Harvard Book Store.  I've done special orders with them, and it's incredibly convenient and easy.  The staff is so helpful and friendly, but they don't linger too much - it's a bookstore, after all, and sometimes you just want to be left alone!  

Tons of free readings, too, and a fantastic used/remaindered section downstairs.  I've had so many great finds for cheap.  The only downside is for serious book geeks like myself, it's almost impossible to leave without buying something - you'll definitely find something you can't live without!
Totally gross. I generally love the roach coaches there but the indian food from here was almost inedible. I never had indian food this bad.

I went here awhile ago as someone gave me a gift certificate to the place, but I wasn't too impressed. The selection of dishes was not too impressive, and out of the couple of items that we ordered in our group - none of them were exceptionally delicious or inventive. I wouldn't go here again unless I got another gift certificate for a free meal...

I had dinner at Cafe Japengo with a group from work and enjoyed the food, the service, and the convenience of the location.

Wow, I'm starting to sound like an old person who doesn't like loud restaurants or crowds! :oP I met some coworkers for a late dinner though so convenience in getting in and out of the restaurant is key. The restaurant is located in the same round about as Melting Pot and its right off the freeway which is a plus.

Food: Nice selection of standards with a few creative options.

Ambiance: A bit of a warehouse-dressed-up feel inside, but overall nice

Service: Good

We ordered several sushi rolls which were all devoured, my seaweed salad was great (mixed in with some shredded field greens and served with a sesame dressing on the side), the duck potstickers were great, and we ordered several desserts to share and those were all devoured as well.

In the mornings when I walk by, it's all I can do from banging the door down.  The smell wafting out of the locked doors is like gramma's kitchen.  It envelopes you with positive images.  In the afternoons and evenings when I walk by I sometimes pray there is a long line so that I won't be tempted to get three cookies for $1 or even better, an ice cream sandwich - the perfect combination of any two cookies and ice cream in between.   When I am really craving something sweet though I really hate the 30 min long wait.

OH MY GOD.  I am goign to knock Krispy Kreme and Dunkin, because as a food service person who has lived in Boston and Chicago I am used to having local places that make good homemade doughnuts and don't have them shipped in from a center and then fry them up at a store location.  So yes, VERY flavorfull.  The Apple fritter and cinnamon roll ones are SO good.  Don't be afraid to try the out of the ordinary ones though too, like the mango.

Had a Jasmine milk tea w/ pearls.  Pearls were really good.

under $1.50 CHEAP.

I love american apparel clothing, but I have to say, the clerks at this store tend to be plain rude! I tried on a pair of shorts once, and put them back because I didn't like the way they fit, only to be harassed by one of the women working at the store about why I wasn't buying them. Another time, a different clerk was convinced I was shop lifting from the store, merely because I was carrying an over sized canvas bag. She even had the nerve to ask if she could look through it. I was down right insulted.
However, I have had better experiences at the men's store 4 doors down when buying my boyfriend a shirt; I was helped when I couldn't find what I was looking for, then complimented when I went back later to buy the shirt.

For those of us who have record players....and not just to have, but to use.....this is nirvana. Not the band, you tool, the place.

The "back room," which late into my residency in San Luis I realized has its own door, contains a plethora of classics, new stuff, 7 inches, this, that, lots of fun things. I usually never go looking for something specific. I feel that my luckiest record-shopping moments have been "look and see" adventures, yielding some of my most prized vinyl possessions.

Boo Boo is also a decent place to purchase CDs, of the used and new variety. Most of the time, there is some sort of bonus giveaway with the purchase of newly released albums. Some examples might include, but are not limited to, 7" records and limited release posters. If I can pay the same dollar amount and get more than I would somewhere else, I get really excited.
It's good food, but you are paying for the pretty presentation.

$1.50 for a huge ice cream sandwich in L.A.! My prayers have been answered!

Ice Cream Sandwich (5/5) - I usually get the snickerdoodle cookies with cookie dough ice cream. Though I do like to change it up and get the peanut butter cookies with peanut butter cup ice cream as well.

In brief:
- Hands down, 100%, 5 stars, no question about it - this has the BEST indian food in the bay area. Nay, in the world (except, most likely, India). 
- I may not be that exotic in my choices, but I've tried a variety of their dishes. Every single one is full of flavor, heat and spice. The winner, though, is their Chicken Tikka Masala. 
- The Durant location is randomly placed at the front of a hotel, but don't be dissuaded from going in - you will not be disappointed! Go in and order at the counter, grab some utensils, plates and water and you're good to go. 

In depth:

- I went to House of Curries several times a week through most of college and never ever ever got tired of it. The service is personable and quick, their selection is diverse and the food is just absolutely perfect. 

- I usually get Chicken Tikka Masala because it's just too good not to. I know it's a bit boring, but their chicken is flavored to a T and the masala sauce has a slight kick that just makes my mouth water. I seriously have never had a better dish than this anywhere in the U.S.

- The people behind the counter are all very sweet and patient. They even remembered me after 2 years of being out of college - I'm telling you they are fantastic people. 

- Overall, I am giving House of Curries my highest recommendation of 5 stars. I would travel across the country to get my hands on their food. In fact, I have.

I ordered the Sienna. As promised: mozzarella, parmesan, garlic, rosemary, red onion and mushroom. No sauce. A pizza -has- sauce unless specified, not vice versa. This was not a pizza, this was a personal thin-crust cheesy bread.

That said, the toppings were decent quality. Service was also fast and friendly, even though the employee appeared as though she would rather have been somewhere else.

It's certainly not bad by any means, but it's apparently not a pizza unless specified by the customer.

As far as value, the price is about right.

Movie selection is great; inside atmosphere is great; bathroom was clean; staff was nice; seats were NOT comfortable (they leaned way too far back); sound system was HORRIBLE (we came to see The Soloist, where sound does matter); and the projector was bad (the center was out of focus).  I hope that management upgrades the place because it looks inviting, until you actually see a movie.

I've been to three different Scotty's Brewhouses now and the Lafayette location is the best one yet. The layout is more open and spacious than the others and there are plenty of TV's within view -- perfect for watching the game or just relaxing with family and friends. 

The beer selection here is one of the most impressive in town... and they have daily drink specials as well, which is very nice. Lots of variety and pretty good prices to boot. But while you might come to enjoy a nice cocktail or a cold beer, the food is really the draw for me on most occasions. 

Right off the bat, I just need to say this: Scotty's is home to my favorite order of wings on the planet. I've had several different flavors and they're all superb. I typically go for the traditional BBQ and always leave satisfied. They've got a slight crunch which really makes the perfect wing I think. And for a guy who often complains about the lack of quality in the bleu cheese dipping sauce -- this place does not fail. BIG chunks in there... and I like that. 

But the rest of the menu has been great as well. My brother in law has a higher heat tolerance than I do and just adores anything smothered in their Mo' Fo' sauce. As for me, I typically stick with the wings or one of the sandwiches and top things off with an order of waffle fries (sometimes w/ cajun season, sometimes not). 

For starters, the dill chips and spinach/artichoke dip are the real winners -- but if you like cheese and bacon, you certainly won't be disappointed by the loaded fries. 

From there, let's skip to the burgers -- the Shewman Special is daunting, but it's as delicious as the idea is ridiculous. Just try it sometime. Takes the best that the XXX has to offer and ups the ante with bacon and jalapenos. 

If you can't do it though, the backyard bar-b-q or blues burger are sure to satisfy. 

And if you can handle a little heat, go for the Atomic Mo'Fo' -- I hear it's one of the best spicy burgers around. 

My wife has enjoyed a number of the salads and wraps as well, but perhaps prefers the fish tacos most. Beware of the Mo'Fo' mustard though... it's got a surprising amount of kick. 

And if you're not feeling beer or a drink, definitely try a tall glass of their root beer or a chocolate shake -- both come highly recommended.

When I crave greasy, inexpensive chinese food, I come to Star Wok. It is pretty convenient, right next to Vons. I am also really indecisive, so I end up getting the 2-combination plate (2 dishes + fried rice), which can feed me for 2 days. The orange chicken is not as good as Panda Express, but the other dishes are pretty good (more authentic than Panda's). 
the servers are as nice as chinese servers can get. And they pack the styrofoam containers with food to the point where its almost exploding. 
There are a few tables for customers to eat at, but I always take my food to go. It looks clean enough though.
The yogurt is great, if you don't mind waiting in line while a vapid pothead/fratboy/sorority girl asks to sample "vanilla."  Who doesn't know what vanilla tastes like?  It tastes like vanilla!!!

Boudreaux's is good when it's good and awful when it's not.  The service is pretty much always lacking, sometimes ridiculously so.  The drop biscuits and sausage gravy is good, but kind of expensive especially for a college town.  The brunch is a la carte for the most part, which can get annoying, but the drinks tend to be good.  Had a bad experience with the oyster po'boy, so I wouldn't recommend getting that.  The seafood gumbo is generally good.  Honestly not going to miss it like some of the other places on main street after I move away from Blacksburg.

A breakfast stop on my way to work for those days where I need a rich breakfast biscuit sandwich to guarantee fullness for the rest of the day. The cheapest hot breakfast option I can find is the egg, cheese sandwich ($2.99) which they happily toast for me. Also am a fan of the coffee here. It comes out of one of those self-serve thermos, but it's hot, fresh and something unique from the Starbucks and Peet's on the same block.

My boyfriend and I actually take the long way to San Francisco just so we can stop by this place for tri tip sandwiches. It does get crowded, but I prefer the outside seating area anyways. I sometimes can't finish a whole sandwich, but it makes for a great drunk snack later on.

YUCK.

Call me a coffee snob, but I come from the land of coffee. Good, strong coffee. 

I tried Coffee Bean because I was under the assumption that they were local, and I try to patronize local biz. But the atmosphere was very "corporate coffee" and the actual product was alarmingly bad. 

Undrinkable. 

I ended up at Starbucks just so I didn't go into withdrawal. Never again.

Oh hello tasty food!

I have past this place for years and never really acknowledged it's existence. Which is probably both good and bad. Good for my wallet, bad cause I've missed out on some good eats!

I decided it was time to stop reading the menu on line compulsively and go here for Restaurant Week this year. It was open late, so it was an option to go with co-workers after we closed, and it was a short walk into the square from work. Easy as pie. 

I made reservations online, and we strolled in a few minutes late, were seated without a problem once they found the reservation. The waitstaff was really nice, and once we had chosen our cocktails and three courses, we basked under the halogen lamp (which is REALLY F'ING close to the table top, a bit of a glare if you are 5'6" and sitting, like I was...) relaxed sipping away at our drinks. I got the mango martini, which was really really good.

My friend got some kind of asparagus soup for starters, I got the salad that was on the menu - arugula?  So good. There are no words. My friend got the steak dish and I got the fish. It was unreal how good his steak was. It was like butter. In fact I think I proclaimed it (loudly, several times) to "be just like buttah!" upon tasting it. Mmmm. We were in a happy food coma by the time dessert rolled around. I got an espresso, and got a strange look when I asked for lemon, but they brought it anyways. 

The place is a bit dark, but the seating, at least in the booths is nice enough. No frills really. The bathrooms are very clean, from what I saw that night. I was, all in all, very happy with this experience. I will try to go back.

wow, shocked to see so many poor reviews for thailand cafe!! 

i used to get takeout from TC ~all the time when i was an undergrad at MIT. i judge dumplings from other places based on the TC dumplings, because they are just oh so good. particularly love the sauces that they include. i was recently in central square around dinner time, and picked up some TC and it was just as good as i remembered...and a short wait!!

i've always been more of an appetizer person, so i can attest to the meat steamed dumplings, spring rolls, and scallion pancakes all being quite excellent. i've also tried their eggplant with garlic sauce, and i believe their chicken with green beans, and very much enjoyed both of them. lo mein noodles are probably only so-so, but the dumplings more than make up for that!!

definitely coming back here whenever i'm in central and craving dumplings....in fact, i think i'm going to order from the arlington location (same owners) tonight!

DINER FROM HELL. NIGHTMARE. STAY AWAY. Apparently 4 years was enough time for me to forget how unholy this sick, sad place is. Dammit dammit dammit! Happy I had time to heal, but sad that the wounds are gaping open again. I guess in another 4 years, I might be ok. Went here like a dummy without even checking yelp first ::sigh:: disgusting food, stupid service, had the food redone, still disgusting, 100% waste of money. This is what I get for trying not to spend $$ at a national chain, right? Ihop would have been a MUCH better bet.

I have only been to TT's once, my freshman year of college, circa fall 2003.  It was one of those nights that started out great, went awry part way through, then righted itself again.  

I was going there to seeing Sondre Lerche, my favorite Norwegian singer/songwriter, so I was totally pumped.  Combine that feeling with my freshman excitement over never having been to Central Square before (such a mysterious/foreign land to me at the time, now I live there) mixed in with some cheap vodka,(all I had available to me as a pathetic frosh) and you get an idea of my mood on the way to TT's.

Upon arriving, I was immediately rebuffed by the bouncer as apparently it was a 21+ show and I was a mere 18.  (It had never occurred to me that this would be an issue...I'm an idiot)  After 10+ minutes of crying and pleading my case to the bouncer, however, he finally let me in, but only after I swore to him that I wouldn't get people to buy me drinks.  I'm sure he didn't end up checking, but I was dying to see the show so I didn't push my luck.
  
The show turned out to be awesome and I had a rockin good time.  Since it was SL's first time headlining in the US, there was tons of energy in the place and everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves thoroughly.  Because of the small size, the energy of the crowd is infectious, which was perfect for this show since everyone was loving it.

I agree with previous reviews that the sound there is substandard.  I do think that the small/intimate size and convenient location somewhat make up for the sound problem though.

Overall, TT's will always remind me of the innocence/idiocy of my freshman year, and I will inevitably be back at some point.
Topless Seafood - the one and only. We have never seen it elsewhere. Get one for each diner!

i think ive spent thousands at this place

must eats:
-their happy hour appetizers and drinks!!!!! from chicken wings, to boneless strips, to pot stickers, and spinach dip! 
-my favorite was the ultimate salad that they took off the menu but they can make it for you if you request for it

decor: like any other tgif. red and white

room: large area, with a bar, and a outside seating area

service: its always hit and miss at this place... i wanna say... for the hundreds of times i've come here it averages out to a 3 star place... no one is extremely wonderful when it comes to service, but what can you expect? haha... but anywho... i've had some bad bad service here also! the bar has been the most hit and miss... more the miss side... 

price: happy hour 1/2 off appetizers are hard to beat. other than that they have salads that are $7-$10, and entress from $8-$20 for steaks and ribs. 

overall: as a ucsd student... i think ive keep this facility open for at least one month on my spendings here. haha. good times...

This place has great giant burgers, yummy, crispy criss cross fries, and one of the best butternut squash soups I've had.  Its the kind of place that you go to when you know you'll also be going to the gym later that day.  Even when I've gone and had the grilled salmon and veggies with fresh herbs over greens, I can't help but get the fries also because they're sooo good.  My husband always gets the fried fish tacos, which he really likes, and a pretty good side salad, which is an upcharge from the side of fries, potato, or sweet potato chips.

this place has great food for veggies, vegans and meat eaters... it's all very good, and cheap.  a great place for a first date, when it's warm, so you can go outside and relax with a little less bustle than inside.  i've never had any issues with the people working there, they've been nothing but nice.  perhaps some of the other reviewers hadn't thought to be so themselves? who knows... i have and will continue to go back.

I stopped in Emma's on the way back from an interesting venture into the world of the Garment District (wow was that an experience btw). I didn't know anything about Emmas, I just knew that I was hungry and wanted a slice of 'za. 

The inside was pretty cozy. There was space for traditional dining as well as bar type seating in front of the window for a more "grab, stuff your face like a chipmunk and run" type of meal. I was more inclined to the latter of the two options so I ordered a slice of plain cheese and plopped down the wait. Tick tock. I was hungry so the maybe five minutes that it took for my slice seemed like AGES but at long last the server approached with my slice. 

My first thought was, "$2 for this?!" I guess I'm just used to jumbo sized slices and the slice that I got at Emmas looked like a slice from a small or medium sized pizza. 

My second thought, "Ugh. Thin crust pizza. Damn it!" I am a creature of habit and have never really dilly dallied in the land of crispy crust. I like my dough soft and warm.

With much disappointment I had my first bite and it was surprisingly better than I was expecting. By the time I finished the bite with much gusto, I was sold. It was YUMMY. I considered getting another slice but I didn't want to wait plus I still kind of felt that $2 for such a small slice was a slight rip off.

To make a long story short, I would probably come back here to sit down and order a whole pie. But I am not sure if I would order individual slices here again.

EDC2010 was my first large scale concert/festival and converted me into a fan of trance music. 

I really love the atmosphere, everyone was there to just have a good time and listen to good beats. It really is the best outdoor club experience one can have. Friday is suppose to less crowded than Saturday but the main field was closed pretty early on (before darkness) but there was still plenty of seating in the coliseum to enjoy the music. 

The usual quibbles have more to do with logistic stuff: expensive food/drinks, zero cell phone reception at all, pricey lockers (going with a group? coordinate & split the locker price). Don't forget to wear comfy shoes because there is a bit of walking between the fields and you want to be able to get your dance on. 

There's always something interesting to look at, occasionally a friendly unexpected hug from a stranger and eargasms to last throughout the night.

I can't believe I've been here 4 times and neglected to post a review!  

I've been 3 times for dinner and once or twice solely for drinks...Dinner was once with a group of 4, twice with the Fiance for some sexy date time.

I LOVE this place.  Sure it's got that theatrical 1920's flapper/grandma's attic feel...but that's one of the things that makes it so fun.  I love having an excuse to put something sexy on (glamorous sexy, not trashy club sexy) and go for a vintage cocktail and delicious food.

DRINKS-  A lot of posters have complained about the $10-11 vintage cocktails.  PS.  This is a restaurant that carries GOOD liquor, not that no-name crap you find in a plastic bottle. They now carry Absinthe...the real stuff (FYI).  I've never had a bad cocktail here.  Mojitos are amazing, the corpse reviver and ANY of their champagne cocktails are amazing.  They carry a number of fantastic after dinner ports, single malts, cordials...etc.  If you appreciate the quality of a well made drink, please stop by.

FOOD- I've had nothing short of awesome when it comes to their food.  We went last week and ordered 6 or 8 dishes.  They have an amazing scallop ceviche shot that was cold, spicy, citrusy, and the scallop was so creamy and good.  The duck a l'orange crepes and potato croquettes were a delicious standard.  We also had some amazingly tender braised short ribs and a mixed meat tangine with very yummy figgy sauce.  We ordered a side of bread, but really only ate one of the hunks.  it was 2.50 or so, but whatever. we know for next time.  

SERVICE-  We have never had any problems with service.  We've eaten when it has been packed full, we've been during Valentine's Day, as well as when the restaurant was nearly 1/2 empty on a week night.  The ladies that work there are as attentive as we'd like.  They bring our food, ask us if we need drinks when we're nearly done with our current ones, clear our plates when they're empty, and refilled our waters.  

Go here if you are looking for a sexy time with awesome drinks, awesome food, and GREAT people watching.  If you're a d-bag...stay on the red line...transfer at Park St to the green line and get off at Kenmore and go to Tequila Rain.....

Hmm...where shall I start? Oh yeah, I know! This is BY FAR the WORSE dining experience I've EVER had!! With all the poor reviews, I'm surprised they make enough to pay the rent each month. Pay close attention to the bad reviews because they are all VERY accurate. Very poor service and management all around. I'm honestly disappointed because I was really looking forward to trying this place.

There are so many things that went wrong with our dinner that I hardly know where to begin. First of all, not only did they get our order almost completely wrong, we got something we didn't even order.

Instead of getting the Calamari appetizer that we asked for, we got a Calamari salad, which cost more.

Instead of getting just a burger, I got one with an extra side that I also did not order, which cost more as well.

Instead of getting a MEDIUM steak, my bf got a VERY RARE piece of beef that was lightly seared at most. I should not neglect to mention, however, that they did fix our raw meat problem...they magically turned it into rubber! I didn't know that could be done--amazing!

You would think that at a place called "Bubble House" you could at least get some decent bubble tea. Boy, was I mistaken. Also the worse bubble tea I've every had...& that's saying a lot. Instead of getting the frosted (blended) bubble tea that we anticipated, we got some severely watered-down concoction...and surprisingly enough, the tapioca balls were entirely undercooked. As a matter of fact, the calamari seemed to be the only thing that wasn't undercooked...it was nice and chewy!

Did I mention the chicken wings that we did NOT order and had to pay for anyway?! Ironically, that was probably the best dish we got.

And to top it off, they wouldn't allow us to use the Restaurant.com certificate that we had, even though we ordered well more than the $50 min spend ("Valid for food only. Excludes alcohol.") specified in the certificate. Who knew bubble tea was not considered food. Oh wait, I forgot, that's right, the bubbles were made from an inedible, gummy substance not qualified to be called food! So after already getting the check, wrapping up my food & giving the waitress my credit card, I was forced to order something else and wait another 20 mins because I was short a WHOLE $2! Of course, they couldn't just apply the cert as a courtesy after all the mistakes that were already made. That was way too much to ask. What WASN'T too much to ask, apparently, was a full 20% tip automatically applied to our check (which was NOT specified in their cert btw, or anywhere else for that matter).  While they did adjust our check for the two earlier mistakes, we still ended up paying a lot more than we had hoped.

Needless to say, I did not love this place. Take my advice...If you ever find yourself walking over to the Bubble House, just keep on walking...over to the White Dog Cafe next door.

I got horribly sick after eating a chicken sandwich there. I won't go into graphic details but let's just say it had to run its course for 48 hours, despite OTC Rx. It was a painful way to lose weight. I know it was their sandwich because it was the only thing I ate that weekend, but the store and the corporate office were dismissive saying no one else got sick "that day." I didn't want anything from them. I just wanted them to look into cleaning up their act so no one else (eps. someone with compromised health) get sick. Their defensive brush off made me mad so I asked for a refund. They refuse to do so unless I sign a 2-pg legal doc that basically say I won't sue. It's kind of funny but does make me wonder how many other complaints like this they get. They had that doc readily available. I won't sign it. They can keep my money to cover their liability insurance. But PLEASE don't eat their prepared food. I assume the baked goods are safe enough, but please please don't eat any perishable food there.

Best value for money in town! The food is AMAZING with great portions and good quality! No wonder its been open so many years! Try their charbroiled chicken, breakfast burrito, carne asada and in general, whatever i have had at this place was awesome and filling!!! Got to try it!!!!!

Went here for a girls night out / semi bachelorette party. I call it "semi" because there were 5 of us, and we wanted an intimate and relaxing, club-free scene for our girls-only special night out. 

What a perfect pick!! Highly recommended if you are looking for a great place for a similar event - or just a fun dining or drinking environment.

Food was great, the ambiance was strange and yet very welcoming, the staff was kind, light-hearted and educated on their food and drinks.

The staff dress as 1920's flappers and you will find the decor to match. With a bit of creativity, you could allow yourself to feel like you've stepped back in time into a speakeasy of sorts - even when you are seated by the window :)

The HIGHLIGHT of this restaurant's offerings are the cocktails. The list is exciting and creative (even foreign to me - so I had to ask for recommendations). Drinks with fresh cilantro, mint, lemongrass, basil, berries and other fruits  - you name it. They seem to use only the best alcohols too. 

These cocktails run about $10-11 but are better than any others that you will find in this price range or higher in the city. Needless to say, our party was on a weeknight - and I was shocked that I woke up with no hangover!! I say its because of the fresh ingredients and quality of the booze - but whatever it was - could not have had a better night! Thank you, Cuchi Cuchi!

Aw these ladies are just wonderful. They are running a goodhearted family business and genuinely seem to care if you're happy. I had the crawfish po boy and itwuz oh so DELICIOUS.

I will definitely be back to try all of their other offerings.

I should give them a 5*, but I'm in a wierd mood.

I went in and asked which cheeses would go with a dry rose with white pepper overtones.  The cheeselady helped me.  I tried at least 6 cheeses.  Chose 3.  It's helpful when you know the wine and its undertones, and my goodness these people are helpful.  They seriously go backwards to make you happy.  And if I said I wanted 1/2 inch of cheese instead of 1", they would have done it.

Ok.  I'm giving them a 5. 

The meat recs were good too.

They also have ends of meat for 1/2 price. I will use these instead of fatback for my collards.  Yes--I have to make things good.

Why I went here today?  Witherspoon Grill for 2 glasses of mediocre wine or our porch for great wines from Coolvines and a plate gathered from Bon Appetit.  $25-70 either way, but with one choice, you get leftovers. 

Nothing says romance like a picnic.  Try it.  If they don't like it, they're not worth it.  Trust me.

Community is an asset to Morningisde Heights. Perhaps my opinion is skewed since there are almost no good places to eat in the 'hood, but I really do enjoy Community. The inside is very chic and clean--long tables, light colors, huge windows, open kitchen, etc. 

The prices are a bit high but the food is really good (especially breakfast and lunch). Very fresh and beautifully presented. The sign is quite inconspicuous, but Community is worth a trip and a few passes in order to find the door.

Usually helpful service, I came here to develop film at a reasonable rate and get their very nice "white" border look that CVS at the time didn't have until later.  Their technicians are very helpful, usually.

Now, it's a place to get digital cameras fixed and regular point-and-shoot SLRs with extra accessories line the walls, and a few telescopes now and then.  Some film left that's sold here.  And they have transfer (from VHS to DVD, etc.) services, too.
Very convinient location for USC - park campus. Its minutes walk from campus and students can grab lunch or snacks here. It also has a theater, a bike shop, cafes, ice cream store, etc.

Love, love, love this place!  I was previously a fan of Lush products, but Naked is so much better.  The bath bombs/fizzies are unbelievable - after 30 minutes of soaking in the bath, your skin will be incredibly soft and you will smell great for hours.  I was previously having problems with dry, itchy skin, but after switching to their soap and using their body butter, my problems have remarkably disappeared.  Highly recommend.

Great tapas restaurant.  Get there early on the weekends, as this place gets crazy busy.  Tiny place with a great spanish decor. You will not be disappointed.  Oh yeah and get the sangria and bacon wrapped dates.

The lunch buffet was extensive, but did lack in spiciness. I have yet to order a la carte, but have no doubt my ordered spice level will be met. The flavor of the food is definitely there. The extensive chutney selection is nice, and the naan and paneer are up to par. The only downside was the odd/rude service by the middle aged, indian, male, waiter. While I was too full for desert, my girlfriend said the kheer was very good (and she's picky).

Andreas has to be one of the most consistant restaurants in the country. The food is not gourmet just good and well represented on the menu - no suprises.  brunch, lunch and dinner - good portions, cooked to your specifications, decent drinks, nice staff that greets and remembers you. The owner makes the rounds every so often and runs a clean ship. If you are familiar with greek food they have all your favorites. This is another restaurant where i like to sit at the bar

It must be stated from the beginning- no, I'm not Korean.

With this in mind, I enjoyed my meal.  It was huge (with all of the complementary, mini dishes they provide you with during each meal).  And my food was tasty.  Kimchee, broccoli, some egg stuff, squid in a spicy/oily paste, steamed dumplings, and soup.

All for a bit over $20.

Considering the sort of lackluster reviews of this place, I was pleasantly surprised!

Went there once on a Tuesday. Karaoke night.

Small patio outdoors, small inside with table. 

A bit expensive for Mac and Cheese. 

Drinks are high end average.

Wasn't crowded till about 11, then everyone got their singing on. Next!

I've been there a few times on Wednesday evenings. I love the EPR parties but the venue is a little random. 3 stories. Bar/restaurant the level u walk into. Dungeon basement. The upstairs sometimes feel like it'll drop to the first floor when you dance.

I bought a pair of great shoes here the other day. The staff was very helpful. I basically went in, told the man working that I want comfortable shoes and he brought me the perfect pair. I love this place!

What CAN'T you do here? Dinner, Dance nights, Watch the game. This place has everything I've ever wanted in a bar. The staff is amazing and the music is always great. Be warned however, this is not a very "Jersey Shore" friendly venue. MIT and Harvard patrons mixed with hardcore music enthusiasts keeps the "pick-up bar" attitude at a minimum. I've been coming here for 5 years and don't plan on stopping as long as I'm in Boston!

We went to Legal on Christmas Eve. The place was packed, as to be expected. No biggie. Except we were seated in literally the darkest, most ignored corner of the restaurant. This must have been newb-land because our server had the four tables that exist back there and he was terrible. He took forever, forgot stuff, we had to remind him about our order several times, and still our food was screwed up.

The dinner was good but left something to be desired. Especially for the price. Lately I just feel like Legal has lost of their attention to detail. Kind of a bummer.

I am kind of astonished that I've never written a review for Big Time.  Maybe I just took for granted that this is the best bar in the universe, and therefore thought no review was necessary.  This bar is my home bar.  From the time I turned 21 five years ago, this place has been my bar.  Over the years I've gotten to know multiple bartenders, had pretty much every beer they brew, spent hours and hours with friends eating baked potatoes and playing games.  

I've recently moved to Olympia, but my relationship with Big Time is still going strong.  Every time I'm back, I'm in and saying hi to Rick and playing dominoes at the bar and eating their new addition of Belgian Frites (complete with dipping sauce!).  This place is an oasis in the midst of frat-bars, and I hope I'm still visiting twenty, thirty, forty years from now.

I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!  I always get the tri-tip sandwich with seasoned fries and BBQ sauce... nom nom nom... I don't eat here all the time but every once in a while, it's a treat.  Sometimes orders can get backed up if it's packed but worth the wait.  I love how you can see the kitchen staff cooking the tri-tip... smells so good!

I literally compare all the tri-tip at other restaurants to this place and so far, they're number 1 on my list.

I'm going to miss this place once I move out of SLO.  =(

I desperately needed a Rocio Durcal CD for my 5 hour drive back up to the Bay. Best Buy of Westwood is the last place I'd think to find it but I did. Big ups to whoever put her in stock for me. 

Also found El Cantante for $9.99...I'd been searching high and low to no avail and bam just when I stop looking, there it is. Kind of like a boyfriend.

I'm taking off one star for the dim-witted cashier who said "like duh we don't sell books" and then forgot to give me my change. I'm pretty sure she's a UCLA student which is annoying because I am a much sharper tool in this shed we call Planet Earth and I barely got into SJSU. 

Also, parking is a bit of a pain but they let me through without paying even though I forgot to validate so whatevs.

A Blockbuster is a Blockbuster is a Blockbuster.  Well not really, they all have slight differences and this particular store is certainly a highlight in the chain.

This store has a generous parking lot and it is located in a good neighborhood, which some stores can't claim.  The staff here is incredibly polite and helpful and will help you locate your favorite film or even order whatever it is you might need.  

The always have a great selection of previously viewed films here on sale for dirt cheap and the staff is very cool about exchanging any you have problems with.  This and the Brodie location and probably my two favorite locations in town.  

Great staff, great selection, great location.

The best pho in town!  For just under $5, you get a steaming bowl of happiness.  Fresh add-ons of basil, bean sprouts, and lime wedges are brought just before the food, and there is always plenty of Sriracha and other sauces available to liven up your dish to a hearty 4+ stars.

CHEAP price, excellent quality, and quick service, which are only enhanced by the added bonus of a sweet, tasty cream puff.

My days at UT were filled with either stopping by Plucker's on Rio Grande at 2 am, or calling to have it delivered around the same time.  Usually, the deciding factor was not if I had been drinking and couldn't drive there, only where I had been drinking.  If we were in West Campus, we were going to Pluckers.  If I was at my house on 12th and Lamar, we were ordering Pluckers. 

In the last couple of months, they tore down the old University Gardens Apartment building that housed Pluckers (and use to have Gumby's too) and built a monstrosity of a garage behind it to house a leasing office and some retail/office space.  Well, Pluckers is now a tenant in the building.  Even though i miss the memories that I have from the old location, the new one is much more comfortable and a much better place to watch a game.  Plus, they have a new patio.  And, wait for it,.....................wait for it....................a FULL BAR.  Of course, this isn't as big of news as it would have been when I was 21 and bars were noticeably absent from the West Campus area, but, it's still a welcome addition (my office is close).  But the new building is like the S Lamar, Round Rock, and Lakeline locations and has a ton of plasmas playing every sport you can imagine and the chairs and tables are much nicer, new, and comfortable.  So, if you need a place to hang out before or after taking in a UT game, you should definitely give the new Plucker's a try.

Bub O'Malley's is entertaining as hell on Thursday nights.  You walk up some dingy stairs in a building next to a dingy parking lot and you walk into a dingy place.  A dingy place that will be some of the best entertainment you can have.  The bartenders are amazing, super nice and entertaining.  The karaoke DJ is fantastic.  The best is when the DJ and the bartender sing, you're sure to be amused :) (And impressed!!)

You get to embarrass yourself in front of many people and watch them embarrass themselves as well.  The singing is fun because the whole bar gets into it.  You can sign up for the 100 beer club and start working on your card.  Play darts or pool? They have that too! Hah, whatever you like to drink, Bub's has it, beer? liquor? Water? Ok only bottled water... but still, they have a good drink selection for beer drinkers for sure. 

They now also have geektastic trivia on Tuesday nights! You should all come out and try it! It's fantastic and will put your geeky knowledge to the test!

Bub's is a ton of fun on Thursday nights for the karaoke and on other nights for just a nice chill bar.  I recommend that you try it out and see if it's your kind of place.

Got a fabulous facial from Lena & will absolutely be back! Her demeanor was very soothing and I fell asleep several times I was so relaxed. She explained everything & asked the right questions while taking wonderful care of my skin. She did a great job with the extractions & when I left my face wasn't all red & splotchy like it usually is post-facial...I could actually go out in public!

The price for the regular facial is $70 and with the student discount I get (yay grad school!) it was well, well worth it. I'm sure i'll be back again soon & tag a fifth star onto this review. Lena was fan-freaking-tastic!

Nice, inexpensive sushi option in cp.  I like the little salad that comes with meals (always seems fresh & I just love ginger dressing :)

Also like the bubble tea smoothies. Staff is friendly too.

Love this place!  I always get their pad see ew dish because it's really superb, but pretty much everything i've had here is tasty.  My friends always went to Bangkok Balcony in Squirrel Hill over this place probably because I went to CMU and this place is slightly more difficult to get to.  Also, I'm a big fan of booth seating, which is lacking at the other place.

Boom boom boom! Sh'zam! Words that describe how fast things work at the Mediterranean Cafe. When my buddy first told me about the place, the conversation went like this:

Him: Watch this, you'll get your food in 30 secs or less
Me: Cool - I'm down for short waits
Him: Naw man, you literally get it when you order it - you might even get it before you even get your change back
Me: Uhh.. sure.. better be good though
Him: Trust me - it's goooood

So I order the Lamb Kabobs - and sure enough, my buddy was right:
1. I got my order as I was giving my money to the cashier
2. It was gooooooooooooooooooooooooood

So you think - how do they do it so quickly? Sure, they have mountain stacks of their food pre-packaged - but they pre-package it 3-5 minutes before you order it, so you know it's fresh.

Pros: Super fast, and relatively affordable. Tasty and satisfying.

Cons: The parking could be devastating as it shares the lot with a bazillion other businesses. The facility is small, so seating, both in and out, are limited.

Overall: LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! If only I were in the area during lunch more often... *sigh*

As I'm writing this, Buns has a perfect overall rating, which I feel is pretty uncommon. After stopping by for take-out last night, I definitely think it deserves a perfect score. 

In fact, the only remotely negative thing I could say is that maybe the burger was too big, as I could only finish about 3/4 of a single. It was delicious, though, and less than $4. The fries reminded me a lot of those at PT's Grille, but they're tasty nonetheless. 

The staff was very friendly, and the food was ready in under 10 minutes. I can't comment much on the dining room since I didn't eat there, but it did look pretty clean. I'm sure it's a litte messier at 2:30 am, but I love that they're open late.

Normally, I would never make the trek out to Berkeley, since I live in San Francisco and BART is quite expensive. When when I found Top Dog on Yelp, I just had to make a visit. The trip cost 6.80 on BART just for a $3 hot dog, but it was all worth it to support my people: Libertarians. Liberty never tasted so good!

The episode of How I Met Your Mother in which Marshall embarks on a quest to find the hole-in-the-wall burger joint that had the best burger he's ever had only to try a bunch of different places & be pretty disappointed at all of them is similar to my story. My Boston burger mecca has always been Tim's Tavern (RIP), home of the best burgers in & around Boston. Since its closing, I've tried to find a place to replace it. So far, no one has been able to. Miracle of Science was recommended to me as a place that makes a burger that (potentially) rivals Tim's (RIP). So one Friday night, a friend & I decided to see for ourselves.

Fabulous space, inside & out. Big windows that open to the street (it's on a corner, so two sides can be almost entirely open), a menu written in a periodic table on the wall (nerdy! yes!), nice lighting, great atmosphere (very open, & very loud). It was crowded when we got there, so grabbing beers & standing around to wait for a table was a little awkward (all the tables & the bar were occupied), but once we sniped a table (downside: you have to totally hover over a group that is getting up to leave if you want to get it, lest someone grab the table out from under your watch - hence the 100% appropriate term 'snipe'.) If you want to sit down anywhere, be prepared to wait. The place seems to cater more to the folks who want to have a few drinks, which would have been fabulous had we not been waiting to eat, too.

Got a burger along with chicken & veggie kebabs. The burger, unfortunately - while good in its own right - could hold no candle to Tim's. But it was a satisfying "neighborhood burger," flavorful & cooked well. The kebabs were delicious.

I wouldn't recommend this place for a legit dinner, but I think it's a great place to have a few drinks & maybe a small plate on a nice evening!

Star for ambiance, another star for the location and mediocre food.
Overpriced for the quality. The lamb seemed fine. The lobster risotto- oh dear. It tasted a bit too salty/bitter for some reason, and a ton of pieces of green onion... and not to mention, I'm getting some sort of stomachache afterwards. Blah.
French? Not really.

Delicious, piping hot, greasy, stuffed full of awesomeness pupusas. Larger than expected, which is nice as I'm often disappointed by the size of pupusas. Had the revuelta, which was stuffed with cheese, shredded pork, and beans. Yom. 

About 2.50 each, comes with a side of pretty tasty slaw so you can get your ruffage on. One was good for a snack, two are probably good for a meal. Worth checking out if you're in the area for sure.

It serves its purpose. I would be wary about having my prescription being botched up by one of the interns who work there, but that can happen at any pharmacy. Prescription pick-up lines are always really long, but the retail lines are always very short.

ice cream sandwiched between two freshly made cookies for $1. 

this is my top place to bring out-of-towners for a quick snack. they can't believe that in a city like LA that something this fantastic can be bought for a single bill.

pick your cookie type, or mix it up with two different flavors, then select your ice cream flavor and eat. it's that simple. 

the line can be long, but it moves fast. parking can be a chore, but once you're found a spot, there is tons to do in the area. an ice cream sandwich is only the beginning. 

diddy riese is luckily way too far away from my house for me to be a frequent customer, but i can imagine having a serious ice cream sandwich addition if it weren't.

if you've never been here, i highly recommend it.

Harry's is rockin'. Aside from the impossible-to-miss cast iron cow on the sidewalk at the entrance, everything about Harry's is utterly non-pretentious and comfortable. We sat upstairs in a room with two glass walls. The music was great. Our waitress was super friendly. The beer selection was impressive. The fries were perfect. 

How else to describe Harry's? I don't know. While still in the downtown, Harry's is just a stone's throw from all the downtown action. Which is probably why we always missed it before. Good thing there's a big cow out front, because we probably would have walked on past.

Honk if you love burgers.

I don't know why the Loft isn't higher rated; one would think that a pretty intimate, well maintained venue in the middle of UCSD would garner a little more praise. Of course the Loft is absent any of the city flavor one will find at other venues in downtown areas--but instead it is complete with University charm and a casual and relaxed atmosphere. The venue itself is comfortable with plenty of space for small shows. Plush seats, tables, and an adequate center for pits or zombie crowds--whichever fits. The only problem that I personally had, which may or may not be attributable to the bands which played, was that the sound technicians were somewhat amateur and my left ear drum took a pretty gnarly beating. But it's all worth it in the end, and I won't hold it against the venue. Keep the Loft alive!

Cold Buster... mmmm my stable jamba order. 

Staff was courteous and helpful. 

Nice quick and easy beverage joint.

Food was great. No need for me to go into detail about that. We had the papadum, garlic naan, and curry chicken: all were fantastic.  

I can't in good conscience give Mint five stars even though I loved the food, had a great time there, and look forward to returning. My reason? Well, the short version is that Mint ran out of "mint."

No joke. 

The longer version of our experience is below surrounded by lines so you can move on if you don't want to read it. 
=====================================
My girlfriend ordered a mojito at the bar. The bartender met us at our table with her "mojito" and then apologized for running out of mint. Seriously?! Sir, your establishment is called "Mint." But for the smell of curry or the sign outside that said "Indian Restaurant," I would have assumed that you had Chapel Hill's largest stockpile of mint leaves. Clearly that was a far-fetched assumption. 

As a general rule of thumb, restaurants of this quality (good ones that charge a premium for what they offer in terms of location, food quality, service, and overall experience) ought not run out of anything, especially at the bar, where the bartenders themselves are traditionally responsible for making sure that the restaurant has all of the supplies he/she needs to keep his customers happy. 

This would have ordinarily been an ironic mistake, which the bartender could have remedied by simply saying "this is really embarassing, but we rant out of mint. Can I offer you another drink instead?" Rather than doing the obvious, the bartender chose to thread the perilous needle of handing a customer a drink she never ordered. Anyone who knows anything about bartending knows that this is almost always socially inappropriate, and rarely leaves the customer satisfied. 

More specifically, the bartender brought her a "mojito" without the mint, and asked if it was "okay." I described this (see above) as socially inappropriate because it puts us on the spot in a most uncomfortable way: (1) it forces us to either refuse the drink, which, in addition to making us feel guilty about a problem we did not cause, requires the bartender to make something else without making more money (he wouldn't rationally expect his tip to go up for doing what we asked for in the first place simply because he is working twice has hard for it), which means we have no reason to believe that he will do the second drink any better, or (2) accept and pay for a drink that we would have never ordered. Making us choose between these options was improper. 

The bartender should have either (1) never offered the not-mojito to her, and should have asked her if she would have liked something else (why would you start mixing a drink that you don't have all of the supplies for anyway), or (2) should have given her the drink, and asked if she wanted something else instead, telling her that he was going to throw it out but figured he should at least give her the option to drink it before he does. In both cases, he should have comp'd the drink, which he didn't. Even if he comp'd the drink, he still failed to ask if he could get her something else in addition to that. It was the equivalent of him saying "here is something you didn't order. Please pay for it. Would you like anything else (that you will have to pay for)?" 

Worst of all, my girlfriend told me that the drink tasted like vodka. Last time I checked (and maybe I'm wrong here), Mojitos are made with rum. 
=========================================

I look forward to and would happily go back to Mint. I was, however, disappointed (and admittedly, amused) by Mint's lack of mint.

Top of the Hill is an icon for Chapel Hill, but I find it overrated. They have outdoor seating, which is nice to sit out on and enjoy a meal overlooking downtown Chapel Hill. The service here is also exceptional, but that's where the good points stop.
