The food tends to be overpriced for the quantity and the beer here is also overpriced as they only sell their own micro brews.  While I think one visit is necessary just to check it out, there are other local spots that are better to visit.

Get: EVery single donut, seriously, try them all
My favs: bacon maple bar, french maple, old fashioned maple (can you tell i like maple??) apple fritter

Pass: well, the avocado cream cheese was definitely interesting, but I probably wouldn't try it again. 

All donuts are made equally right? I thought so until I tried this place. These donuts are super light and fluffy, with amazing dough. The glazes, yes all of them, are extremely tasty and have just the right amount of sweetness. One of the best things about this place is the sheer diversity of donuts - they have your usual maple and glaze and chocolate highlights (old fashioned, bars, twists, french, etc), but then they have their outrageous donuts - the avocado cream cheese, the peanut butter and jelly, the MAPLE AND BACON OMG I DIED ITS SO GOOD, the raspberry, orange, java maple,the cereal donuts,  mint, devils food cake, etc. I know a lot of the donuts have been done before ( voodoo donuts up in portland for one), but slodoco just does it better. The service is always great too - friendly staff and owners, always willing and eager to talk or make recommendations. The atmosphere is great for this town too, since they have free wifi, coffee, ample drinks, other foods - muffins and such, the decorations are unique and they always have local art hanging on the walls. But wait, there's more. They have contests almost nightly to win free donuts for people in the store, they have live music/open mic nights, they really cater to this city, especially the always hungry student population. Plus, they are open 24 hours - what more can you ask for? Quite possibly the best donut store in the world. 

*only only only thing that is bad - the seating is uncomfortable if you are trying to study there for more than 3 hours - all wood = all sore.

Good prices. Tasty tacos. Much better alternative to Chipotle. Make the walk down Telegraph! It's worth it!

Now, if I only they would validate my parking. Oh well, Cream across the street does, so head over for some ice cream sandwich desserts and validate your parking that way.

OK.  It not that the food is bad.  It's actually pretty decent.  It's just when I order delivery, I would like the food delivered to my door.  Not to the curb outside my door.  I know, stairs suck.  Why do you think I ordered delivery?  Because I don't want to go anywhere to eat.  I want to stay inside and not have to put any effort into getting it.  Hunter/gatherer? Screw that. 
Beauty's, please.  Don't make me walk the stairs.

i wish my favorite artist (joseph arthur) would find somewhere else to play.  yes, the one thing this venue has going for it is some excellent sound - IF you stand in the right place.  best place to witness this is from halfway back (i'm talking about the downstairs here) near the soundboard.  any further back, and unfortunately you'll get more bar noise than guitar noise.  other good points... the ticket guy at the counter is nice.  and the positives end there for me. 

anyway, so if you're in the right spot, the sound is glorious.  last week i saw joseph arthur thrice (one show at wcl, one in nyc at the bowery and once in hoboken at maxwell's).  the wcl show trumped the others in terms of sound, but was the worst of the three shows.  i blame the wcl.  OK, so the bad parts: the setup is HORRIBLE.  i mean, tables in the front for a rock show?  granted he usually plays with a backing band and this time he is touring solo, but he wanted the crowd to stand up and move and get into it, obviously.  but there was no room because people were packed like sardines amongst chairs and tables.  the crowd did their best to work with a bad setup.  it was unnecessarily crowded up front compared to totally empty at the back.  weird.  anyway, rock show  = general admission.  so unhappy about tables in my way of enjoying the concert.  which brings me to my next complaint, i would have reserved one of said tables to get right up front, but i couldn't because i find their food inedible.  i mean, i don't know how you can go wrong with nachos, but they do.  terribly, terribly wrong.  i was smart and ate a small dinner elsewhere first, but even the smells of the food coming from the kitchen was unappetizing to me.  come on, that never happens!   and though it didn't affect me much personally, i thought our bartender was a bit of a dick.  this place needs an entirely new kitchen and bar staff IMO.  i hate being back by the bar, where the speakers don't reach all that well, and hearing more of the bartenders bantering back and forth and glasses clinking than the music itself.  come on, it's not a social lounge, it's a music venue!     

i've been to probably somewhere in the neighborhood of 15 shows downstairs, and 4 upstairs, and i could echo pretty much the same sentiments for the upstairs.  they get two stars for the crystal-clear sound system.  but every time i go there wish to myself that the artist had picked another joint.  favorites on my list: johnny brenda's, and the troc.  honorable mention to TLA, and surprisingly enough, the tweeter center over in camden (preferably in winter, when the curtains are down - good sound system, super-friendly staff).

I've had excellent support and service here. Sometimes there is a longish wait--no fun, particularly when they have almost no place to sit, and the three or four "seats" they do have are very low and have no arms. In case you hadn't noticed, guys, at least 50% of your customers are on the far side of 40 and might like a comfortable chair or bench while they wait. Same goes for the background music...techno-rock, I guess you'd call it. Either skip the music entirely, or choose something a little less age-specific.

Overall, I'm happy, but do think a bit about your demographic. All cell phone users are not 20, hip, and  techno-savvy.

I like going here. It has a viking longhouse kinda feel. Lots of wood decor. It's on Mass ave within a short walking distance of the redline's Central square stop. On tuesdays they have a fun trivia night that starts at 9pm, which is what I usually go for. Show up early to get a good table for that.

Drinks are good and they have a variety of options, although I've found the mixed drinks to be a bit overpriced for the amount of alcohol in them. I generally stick to beer or wine. They have a pretty large dinner menu. You probably won't eat anything mind blowing, but the food is great in terms of bar food. I've had a quesadilla (adequate), spinach artichoke dip (warm cheesy goodness), steak salad (yummy) and pulled pork burger (super yummy and filling).

Nope, never going back. 

Both my husband and I felt sick after eating at Havana Central. The Nacho appetizers were seriously embarrassing. Stale chips, with a few shreds of cheese and a couple of olives. The entrees were....edible.

The only reason I give 2 stars is because of the free refills and our server was extremely pleasant.

Dr. Bromberg & Dr. Joel are great doctors. 

I had been having a constant dull pain in my hip for months, and within a day after my first visit, the pain disappeared completely. I now have regular appointments at Bromberg Chiropractic to address long-standing back pain and postural imbalances. Dr. Bromberg had me take x-rays at the beginning of my care plan, so he could develop a medically sound & highly personalized plan. 

While the regular adjustments are immediately gratifying, it is the education in exercise & ergonomic issues that I find most unique about Dr. Bromberg's approach. He provides supportive equipment & exercise plans to help align the spine and strengthen appropriate muscles. 
With Dr. Bromberg & Dr. Joel, you really feel like your particular case is being thoroughly studied and your postural needs cared for. 

Also, they have great personalities & it is just a day-brightener to visit their clinic. Highly recommended to anyone curious about the chiropractic method!

So, let's get one thing straight.  This is not Ny Style pizza.  As a one-time resident of Manhattan I can tell you that there is no such thing as true Ny-style pizza that costs $2.75.  Yes, you heard right, an abysmal $2.75. To make matters worse, this restaurant insists on charging $.35 to use a credit card.  How sleazy is this? It's like 'okay, they already ordered, now we can probably get them with this charge.'  

Now all of this would be somewhat acceptable  if the the pizza was NY-Style.  It isn't.  Still it would also be acceptable if it is good.  AND IT IS NOT.  My pizza was completely burnt, the cheese sort of pasty and it was crunchy like a pretzel.  It was just disgusting.

Austin does not have the best pizza, but there are plenty of better options than Home-Slice.  Big Bite or Mellow mushroom for example, have MUCH BETTER PIZZA and are also MUCH cheaper.  

Stay far away from Hot-Slice.

Mac's selection isn't anything out of the ordinary but the prices are the lowest I've found. The best thing at Mac's is the "build your own six pack" area. When a bottle breaks in a six pack during shipping, they put the remaining soldiers on a rack for people to pick and choose. Normally there is a fine selection of stuff. It's a cheap way to try a bunch of new beers. I think you get the best price by paying in cash, btw.

The cookies here are amazing. Especially the White Chocolate Pecan. They are so rich and delectable. I also had the South Western Fiesta Turkey and Corn Salad and the daily special- which was Chicken Gumbo. It all cost about $11 which is more than I was expecting to pay but I was very full. 

The Salad was great. And I NEVER like salads. I generally go out of my way to pay extra for an alternative but I noticed that the salad today looked pretty good and I was glad I made that choice. It was chock full of fresh vegetables, juicy chicken, and great taste! The salads here are wayy bigger than the entrees. 

I was not impressed with the Gumbo. I can't put a finger on it but I have to say that the overall flavor was not appealing...

This is HONESTLY one of the WORST schools out there.  Their academic counselors literally offer you NO HELP.  They can't even outline the classes that you will need to take to prepare for the national exams.  It's ridiculous.  The school's only interested in earning your money.  After they get the money, you're on your own.  This is DESPICABLE.  I have tried to communicate with the school for WEEKS.  So far, NOT a single person has been able to provide me a complete list of the classes that I will need to take.  I am looking into other colleges that offer the similar coding certificate. This school can go screw itself.

I'll K.I.S.S. - 

*Tri-tip sandwich - ask for extra BBQ sauce 
*Cajun Sausage sandwich - request the onions grilled, if possible
*Long line goes by quick - checked-in today, Labor Day, at 1pm. Found seats, ate, and done by 1:40pm

This place is HIGHLY recommended if you're visiting SLO. Thank you come again.

This place is an okay place to pick up an okay meal.  You will not be impressed or depressed by whatever you get, but you'll be able to eat it and then you'll be able to leave.  I generally get salads here and they are not worth saying anything more about.  Bread and soup are also very edible.  It has this weird convention of switching from deli style around lunch to restaurant style in the evenings.  I would never eat at Cosi if I lived in a city with options, but considering the smattering of crap that Ann Arbor has to offer this place is on par with the other eateries in the area.

So if you are looking for a place to escape the hot weather, and are planning to sit out on a patio and take advantage of Happy Hour, then you have to go to Six Feet Under. We had just finished touring the Georgia Aquarium, (i know how touristy that sounds) and were ready to be refueled with food and since we happened to find happy hour priced drinks well we couldn't refuse. First off if you come here head upstairs for some of the best views of Atlanta in the city. The view is amazing and the patio is well decorated with wooden drink rails and and landscaped with tall grasses. For our drinks we started off with a peach Bellini and pomegranate margarita. The Bellini was the best that i have ever had, the peach puree was balanced with the perfect amount of champagne. I had the pomegranate margarita, and i have never had one made with this type of fruit juice before, and it worked well with the tequila. 
For food we started with a gorgeous plate of oysters with lemon, seafood sauce and horseradish. The oysters were super fresh, i just wish that they were served with a mignonette. With that we also had the spicy seafood gazpacho with shrimp, squid and scallops. This was one of the most memorable dishes that i had in Atlanta. It is was so satisfying because it was so flavorful, the heat was there but not overwhelming, and there was such a bounty of seafood. 
Overall, if you want a place that serves up great food and drinks, provides a great vibe, and as a bonus has on of the best patios in the city, then you must head over to Six Feet Under.

I dig this place. I love the design, I am ok with the laid back service, great for breakfast, wonderful pancakes....they even have a bar. I keep wondering what it's like in there at night!

But if you need a good hangover breakfast in that area of Cambridge....go for ti!

My wife took me one night when we could not think of any other place for dinner.  It is a small quaint little place that strives to look like a bistro in France. It sort of accomplishes the task.  However, the first thing I noticed upon entering is the wine.  At that point I feared dinner would be abhorrently expensive because the whole place is really one large wine cellar.  They have so much that  almost every table abuts several cases of wine.  This results in a huge intimidating wine list. So large, that I had to ask for help making a choice.  The wine steward (actually stewardess) guided me to an excellent red from the loire valley in the $65 range (this may seem high, but we drink so its usually economical for us to buy a bottle).  We both loved it and have been looking for it at Specs since.

As for the food, this place met one of my rules for affordable dining:  the menu was on the wall.  From there on, I got over the fear of sticker shock.  Almost all of the handwritten selections looked appealing and the prices were quite reasonable.  I know it is cliche, but we started with the escargot which came out smelling incredible.  The butter and garlic leaped from the dish; very simple but very good.

For dinner, I settled on the bouillabaisse (about $20) that I would have licked from the bowl if my wife was not there and she loved the mussels (about $20 as well) that she devoured plus we shared a yummy dessert.  All in all, it was well worth the trip and a great bargain at something less than $150 considering the wine, dessert, appetizer and dessert.  I recommend this place to everyone.

OK, As a Chicagoan who has been in the area for a few years I have tried all the local places looking for a great Chicago style hot dog.  Let me just say I have been disappointed by all.  This place has been my most recent disappointment. 
 First lets all remember you are a hot dog stand there are hundreds of options for people in the area.  So you better be pretty awesome.
They should go to Chicago and do some research. I suggest Fat Johnny's or Hot Doug's or even Portillo's to see what makes these places institutions.
Now onto the hot dogs,  When I went and ordered the bun was not fully steamed through any great Chicago hot dog place is going to have a super soft poppy seed bun at its base.  Turn up the steamer boys.  
Next the superior hot dog places I know use  the Vienna beef hot dogs with natural casings. They are bit more expensive but nothing beats the snap of the hot dog when you bite into it and the flavor of a natural casing dog is second to none.  I suggest they make the switch from artificial casings to natural.
I order my dogs with everything except sport peppers.  When I got the dog with the cold bun it also had icy relish, tomatoes, and pickle wedges watch your cooler. Also, rather than putting mustard on the dog first it was put on last which I have never seen before.
There are hundreds of successful hot dog places in Chicago.  They are successful because they pay attention to the details and present quality ingredients.  This place does neither at this point so I'd say stay away.

Samir, the man behind the name, is so incredibly nice and completely made my day!  I came in and was greeted right away and told to take my time looking over the menu.  I placed an order for a falafel sandwich and a lamb shish kebab sandwich.  He proceeds to cook them himself and everything is freshly made to order on the grill.  I had one of the nicest chats with him too when I was waiting for my food.  He said he's been at this restaurant since he was 17 years old.  

And the food was delicious!  The lamb was perfectly seasoned and so juicy.  The veggies were fresh, the lettuce crisp and the pita warm and chewy.  The falafel was crispy on the outside but I wished it was more tender inside.  Still, so satisfying and such a great deal.  I think it was a total of $9 for both.  Awesome neighborhood spot for Lebanese food.
i dont eat indian food much. this was really solid though. could be 5 stars. great option for lunch or dinner.

I want to love this place, I have a long standing rule: No chain restaurants at all cost.  And, I love a good dive.

Decor wise, this place fits into the dive category; same furniture for the past god knows how many years, etc. and they claim to be the oldest restaurant in Troy.

But the food is, bleh.  Wa and I went here for the required Sunday morning hangover brunch and it has to be pretty bad when the food isn't even good enough or bad enough for that.  Wa liked his, but we know Wa will eat anything; ask me about the time he ate the 3-week old sandwich out of my fridge. :)

I went back today out of convenience sake and was equally unimpressed, plus, the place is filthy.  I was the only person in there with three staff all discussing their sexual exploits.  I think they should probably vacuum and discuss sex after hours or at least tell better stories.

Swirl is good stuff.  It is a frequent destination for the Super Secret Tuesday Night Happy Fun Time Crew, especially if we are converging for dinner in the Rice Village and we want a nice dessert.

Some people aren't crazy about the tartness, but I like it.  I typically get the pomegrante with almonds and fruit... Staul Wall usually opts for the fruity Pebbles on hers...

There is another location in the River Oaks area that I will definitely have to try as well.

EDIT: Check out the review for the River Oaks location... it is really cool!  They have 16 self serve machines with 16 different yogurt flavors and a self serve buffet of toppings... and you pay by the ounce...  which in my opinion is a better deal than the West U pay by the served serving size... It is almost worth the extra drive for me to go to the River Oaks location!

Let me start by saying I've never had alterations done here, just dry cleaning, so can't comment on the alternation issues that some people have mentioned.  

What I can tell you is that I've been bringing my clothes here for almost 2 years, and have never had a problem with damage, lost items, anything like that.  The staff is always helpful and courteous, and the turnaround time is pretty standard for the industry.  Prices are reasonable, haven't found anywhere that can match the quality at that price.  

So yeah, I love having a dry cleaner that I never have to worry about - one less stressful thing in my life!

i really, really wanted to like this place. Especially since while i was walking in, there was a group of students raving about their bubble teas. unfortunately, i did not have their experience. i ordered the chai bubble tea and my bf ordered the taro bubble tea. Both the chai and taro tasted really watered down. So watered down, in fact, that we could not taste the taro flavor at all. The bubbles were severely undercooked. 

it's sad that this is the only real bubble tea option in university city. there are so many better places in chinatown. Do yourself a favor and hop on the train to chinatown if you want bubble tea.

This is my favorite place to eat on campus. 
I love coming here because their food always hit the spot for me! So far i've tried their sandwiches, pad thai and their BBQ pork noodle. Mmmm how i love the Bbq Pork noodle! I can never get enough of it!

the prices are $5 to $7 depending on what you get, the sandwiches are $4 though. They also give you a lot of food for how much it is worth!  Occasionally i get the young coconut juice... it comes in a cracked open coconut just like how i like it! It's always a treat for me when i get it :) I love it when my TA have their office hours there because thats just an excuse for me to have another delicious meal on campus!  

The only thing that i don't like about this place is that the bread for the sandwich is too hard/dry. But i've only had the sandwich once so i can't say for sure if it is always like that. Nevertheless, everything taste great !!

haha, first time i had a falafel, and it's pretty darn amazing! 
the owner here is quite proud of her business because she personally said, "we make the best falafels around here and no one can beat us". 

since it was my first time getting a falafel, the lady even offered me a sample. i got the super falafel, thanks to all of the yelpers who have recommended it, and i can definitely swear by it that they're really good. it felt fresh, with right amount of consistency and flavor, and it felt a lot healthier than eating a burrito. 

this place is nice because it's right across from campus. i've walked past here so many times when i used to live in unit 3 back in freshman year. i'm glad i walked in here today and gave it a shot. 

my friend ordered the lamb shawarma and it was alright. i'd recommend the super falafel for first timers :D

Where to begin with this place? I've never thought a burrito place could be pretentious, but this place managed to defy my expectations. First things first, the burritos are just sub-par, being neither authentic or interestingly different from a standard burrito. The staff has the snark of a really good coffee shop, but without the quality or decor to back it up. Oh and the employees don't wear gloves when preparing your burritos. I would almost never recommend a chain, but in this case, you're much better off at a Chipolte.

So this is what Papa's became.  I am amazed that with Pinnochio's, Crazy Dough's, Cambridge 1, Oggi, and the other pizza joints spitting distance from this place, that another pizza place is warranted.

then again, it's right in Harvard Sq, so I guess there is a demand.

Ordered only a slice - and it was a weird looking one.  Pepperoni was very old school - like the size of a small drink coaster.  Cheese sprinkled on and melted.  And then a thin crust

Beware Barney B - thin crusts in this town disappoint.

But for $2.50, I won't feel guilty if I toss it if it lives up to normal standards.

The slice didn't disappoint.  It was greasy, but not too.  It was crispy, but not too.  It was tasty, but not too (so I deduct a single star).  But overall I am happy I tried it - and I welcome it to the neighborhood.

And like any good pizza shop - open until 2:30 on the weekends.  Not sure the last time I made it out that late, but it's nice to know it's there

I wish them luck

Their coffee is a little pricey but worth it. Try the walnut brownies with a cappuccino -- so delicious on an autumn day! I grew up near Princeton and I always make it a point to stop by Small World every time I'm in town.

Ok first off I have a hate-on for them for replacing Hartnett's. While I'm not huge into naturopathy or anything, I liked having the option to go in there and pick up some probiotics or lip balm or whatever. I'm not sold on homeopathy or naturopathy, but I thought it was great that there was a store with a staff that seemed invested with which whom I could discuss natural remedies that were potentially a waste of money.

Now I can spend that potential waste of money on a plain t-shirt. I honestly don't get the appeal of American Apparel. I love getting their stuff when other artists have done cool screen printings on them (I like to shop on Etsy) but in general I really rarely need a $20+ T-shirt. Maybe it's a sign that I'm getting older, or maybe it's because I'm not as hip as I think.

Their sizes piss me off too. I'm a small in some shirts, a medium in others, sometimes a large in tanktops, sometimes not..if this were a department store where one was dealing with different designers it would be one thing, but it all comes from the same place!

All that said, sometimes you need a nice plain cotton shirt, and they do have them, in an array of colors ranging from neutral to neon. They do one thing, and they do it well and I can't begrudge them that.

 I dunno. I grew up in the eighties, I didn't love them then, I don't love them now (and that seems to be their aesthetic) , and their print ads used to sketch me out big time (and before y'all call me prude go check out some of the other places I've reviewed!)

Really good deli with salads, sandwiches, and other foods. The soup is fantastic. The overnight deli Guy is awesome.
The place however is super expensive. 3 bucks for some of the bottle drinks is awful. The market area is also way overpriced.  The counter help isn't that great either.

Exactly what I've always wanted! A restaurant with an equal amount of vegan and meat options. Since I'm a carnivore and my girlfriend is a vegan this is our little gem since we both have options. This place is also great because they actually have avocados. As a native Californian I like to put avocados on my sandwiches and this has been a rarity in Pittsburgh. The avocado & turkey panini I had was heavenly. I was not as impressed with the salad dressings but I will definitely be returning. 

As for the ambiance, I got the feeling this is a restaurant started by a group of late 20 or early 30 somethings. Decor is cute but there was one waitress. While the place is small it's best to have an experienced waitress to handle multiple tables at once. We only saw her twice in the whole restaurant and it seemed every table wanted her attention when she came by. I don't fault her but sometimes it's best to hire a professional rather than a friend or family member (just taking a guess here). 

My only complaint is the hours. It'd be nice if this place was open a little later. It seems you can only eat here if you work in the area and can visit during your lunch break.

Its been 15+ years since I've eaten falafal or baba ganoush, but getting reacquainted at East Side Pocket has been a delicious experience.  This is my new favorite take-out place on the East Side, based entirely on the falafal pocket (with "everything").  Yum!

It's busy during lunch, but the line moves quickly and the staff is very friendly.  Street parking only and there are rarely spaces available on Thayer Street itself - try Brook or one of the side streets.
This is a nice place to have a drink and share a tiramisu. That's about all I've come here to do, and it's nice knowing that a quiet bar area and a well-made dessert are mere feet away from my home.

I've tried three freshly-made sandwiches at Crema: the roast beef, the chicken, and the turkey. My favorite was the turkey because I'm a huge pickle fan, and they put a ton of really good ones on the sandwich along with a tasty Jarlsberg spread. They were all very good, though.

I really liked the homemade chips you can get as an add on.
I also really like the chocolate-chip cookie. 

As mentioned by others, the atmosphere is really nice. It's so much better than what it used to be and really hit a niche that needed to be filled in H-Square.

When you compare prices, these sandwiches are less expensive than both Darwin's and Hi-Rise.
A new and growing woman-owned pilates and yoga studio.  Excellent, highly trained staff and an ever-expanding class offering.
Delicious and affordable, with delivery thrown in there as well. What more could a college student ask for?

Maybe I'm just expecting too much with this place. I've been here 3 times and each time I'm disappointed. I came in yesterday and picked up a scone and a croissant. The scone was just okay. The croissant was awful. Way overcooked, to the point that it was actually chewy. I probably shouldn't have bought it cause it looked a little dark, but why was it even being sold ? The owner seems kinda crabby too. I'll stick to Witherspoons.

I come to fruizen at least 3 times a week. Their milk green tea boba is sooo addicting. It did take some getting used to though. Both the tea and the boba are very sweet. You may be able to ask for the milk tea without syrup (I was there about closing time one night and she didn't have any pre-made milk tea left). The shave ice is very Taiwanese. At Fruizen it is standard to put condensed milk and brown sugar syrup on the shave ice. They also have about 20 different toppings you can put on it. Definitely don't order shave ice to-go. I think you get a lot less. You can share a shave ice between like 3 people, they're so big

I've been going to Mr. Caluti at Rizzo for 13 years (1-2 times a year, most recently just a few months ago), and I have never had a problem with him or his service. He has never given me attitude, and his tailoring is immaculate. Having once had an irreparably botched job by a dry cleaner offering alteration service, I have been more than happy to pay a little extra for competence and professionalism. It's too bad to hear about others' negative experiences, but I will say that the last time I was in, I was amazed at the attitudes of the three other customers I encountered while I was waiting. Their sense of entitlement and self-importance was astonishing. If I were Mr. Caluti, I'd probably more than bristle.

Here in Seattle, it is more accepted to wear comfortable shoes with various fashion styles.  Finding hip, high functioning shoes is the trick and Sole Food  is one of my sources.  What makes this a great place is the ability for the whole family to shop here.  They also have some great men's shoes for  those guys that are confident enough to wear something besides athletic shoes, (boring!) 

 I'm all about options, and this is a great one  for  finishing  my individual look I like to have.

Really cute place to eat! I had never known about it before. I got the bulgogi sandwich - it was really delicious but I'm not sure if it was worth the money? I think this is one of the only places that's super close to campus that has REALLY GOOD shaved ice :)

The food here is good, but the portions aren't as great as at the Villa La Jolla location.  The service here is okay, maybe not as friendly as the other location though.

I like the seating arrangements in the back of the restaurant, makes it a little bit more intimate.

The Palm has been delivering terrific movies for decades. They continue to find good movies and always have something for us. We continue to support this theatre and love it. If you love film festival winners ant the IFC (independent film channel) then this place is for you! It sure is for us! www.thepalmtheater.com for details

This italian restaurant is different from one I have ever been to. First off it smells like Cheese the moment you enter. Kinda sickening and kinda not. I like cheese, but when it's too cheesy I feel like I want to barf. Don't worry I didn't barf. 

Anyway this italian restaurant is like fast food, but the quality is plated restaurant style. You order, take your number, wait for them to call your number, and then you EAT! I had the Pollo Con Pesto Pasta and my boyfriend had the Gypsy's Chicken Pasta. Big portions! If I had known that from the beginning, I probably would have shared a dish instead of getting my own. The bread that came with the pasta wasn't that great, but the pasta itself was so damn good! The only thing that was making me hesitant about eating the pasta, was that it was so filling! I felt so heavy with every bite I was taking. After eating half of my meal I felt like a ginormous whale!!! The pesto pasta I had was very cheesy and had lots of pesto sauce (i think it was dripping in oil too). The pasta noodle was yums! The Gypsy's Chicken Pasta looked too creamy. I don't really like creamy stuff. Overall this place serves really heavy food!! Be ready to get food coma after!

I paid $15 for both of us, so like $7.50 per dish? SUPER CHEAP! Especially for Italian food. Open late and a great place for college students on a low budget.

Great place to eat in Westwood with one or two other people. The reason why it's only "a-okay" is because of the tiny space for seating and long lines during rush hours (for food, that is). 
If you are hungry, feel free to have one order all to yourself. The teriyaki chicken, gushi, bulgogi, etc. are all delicious. Even the rice seems to be especially savory.
If you're not too hungry, sharing an order with someone else would be your best bet. The combo bowl/plate is the way to go.
UCLA students - you are not a true Bruin if you have not had Gushi. Just putting it out there!

I get it.  Tapas are trendy right now.  I had a restaurants.com gift card here which allowed me to order about 5 different menu items (at least 3 of which were house recommendations).  Nothing was all that great.  Most of it was bland.  Had it not been for the gift card, I would have felt ripped off.  Went once, never need to go again.

I did the certificate of accounting program long time ago, it was just ok.  
Most of the instructors were pretty good, but there was a professor named Boutari who I really objected to; besides being a bit unpleasant at times, he also charged $100 for his class notes.  The notes consisted of a cheaply bound folder that summarized his lectures, not all that well done and certainly not worth $100.  And while they weren't absolutely essential, w/out it, if you spaced out at anytime during the lecture, or weren't able to write as fast as he spoke, you were in trouble for the exams.  It really was pretty sleazy of him to charge that much for it, and his excuse was not much better.  His reasoning was that $100 was what he charged private and govt entities, which implied that since he overcharged everyone else, we should be ok w/ it.  It wasn't the least bit convincing, it still felt like we were bent over the couch w/ our pants around our ankles.  I still can't believe admin allowed him to pull that s--t..
Also, I took a taxation class last year, and it wasn't too in depth, esp in comparison to the classes I'm taking now at csun for the ms taxation.
However, I took a class on the old testament long time ago, it actually was excellent.

The spring roles here are amazing. The entrees are good but sadly, not as amazing as the spring rolls.

I come to Madam Mams quite often.  At first I did a fair bit of experimenting with various dishes and their spice rankings.  I have now on a couple favorite dishes that I always order. My favorite of which is the garlicly delightful F11 (its real name is rather intimidating).  

I found their spice rankings to be a little inconsistent. 2 pepper and the dish wasn't too bad.  Next time I was brave so I tried an item with 3 peppers and before I was halfway through my body was doing all kinds of things, all of which are not appropriate when in such an cramped restaurant. I was crying, my nose was running like crazy and I had sweat all over my face. Next time I tried another dish with only 2 peppers, and it was nearly as hot as the one with 3 peppers. I enjoy spicy food more than most people, but I guess not enough to hang with the folks that order spicy at Madam Mam's.

Don't plan on driving here and finding a convenient parking place. Though I think it is probably worth dealing with the parking because its a great place to eat.

This is not Austin cuisine!?

But my friends insisted it's the best Pho even compared to what's available in SF so I had to meet the challenge.

I have to say it was better than expected but I still prefer Tu Lan my friends.

Although the quirky gentleman with the dry sense of humor that took care of us was definitely a preferable alternative to the bitter curt service I am accustomed to at Tu Lan.

I noticed this place was hit or miss with meals. I came here with friends, first time to the U district, ordered a variety of dishes family style. Some of them were 4 star status, others 2, but all of them were cheap as hell. Obviously, if I went to school at U Dub I'd be eating here on the regs. Go with the Basil Basil and ignore Seattle grunge bums for a good time.

MMM good.  I stopped by today for lunch with a friends who had been here before. We both order the lunch combo with fries and I got the greek fries.  The gyro came to the table fast and full! The fries were covered in a yogurt sauce and feta which looked weird but the taste was really good!  It was a totally filling lunch and for $7 with a soda.
I gotta venture out to the ave more often.

I consider this more of a weekday lunch spot due to it's small size. The lunch specials are good sized and good value. The Tofu Delight is very interesting - almost better as a dessert.  I go by myself and the service is attentive - which is not always the case at some places. You can park in the back and come in through their little patio.

When I went to Columbia, I used to come here and get takeout to eat while I slaved away in the studio.  Brown rice, chicken satay appetizer.  Enough for a decent meal.  Give it a shot if you're at Columbia.  It's right across the street.

My favorite bar in Austin, a great dive bar. Amazing jukebox selection, fantastic live music every night of the week, usually it's free. The bartenders & staff are also my favorites, they are good people. Drinks are reasonably prices, they have a back patio for enjoying the outside. If you want a casual place to have drinks in this neighborhood, I don't know why you would go anywhere else, really.
It's 2 floors and mostly kids of Columbia. Drinks are very strong and the music is top 40s. Pretty much a regular college bar.
A TV in each booth. Bad pizza. Corporate robotic dolls delivering it all with a somewhat disingenuous smile. I can't imagine they will last long all things considered.

I literally have nothing bad to say about crema cafe.

my one request would be that they add a few more pastries to the selection such as a blueberry scone or coffee cake. i feel like sometimes i don't want such sophisticated desserts and pastries and would love some more classics!

i work right near crema and go there basically every day, whether it is to have lunch or just an iced tea. their ready made tarragon chicken, brie, pear and pecan sandwich is awesome and their turkey and jicama slaw sandwich is the best sandwich i've ever had. add some homemade sweet potato chips!

i've never had a rude barista before, but i understand if they can get a little irritated. come on! it's hard to work with people sometimes and it gets insanely busy there. i'm sure each person makes at least 150 drinks a day.

anyway, if you're in harvard square or even if you just want a delicious lunch or coffee date, crema is definitely the place to visit.

2100 reviews, you can just add me to the stack. Simply the best value cookies in the country, with the best taste-to-cost ratio i've ever seen. a dollar gets you 3 of some of the best, freshest cookies in LA. add 50 cents and you get a perfect ice cream sandwich in a cup. 

There are no negatives, they do 3 very specific things (cookies, ice cream sandwiches, and Hawaiian ice). They do it ridiculously cheaply, and they do it consistent and delicious. Every single time I'm even around westwood I make it a mission to come here. 

There's nothing more to say.

This review is only for the gourmet deli "spicy special" sandwich.

It is the best sandwich for 4 dollars in the Columbia area.  The deli itself is a tiny, sketchy convenience store frequented by lottery addicts, smokers, drunkards and Columbia students - or drunk Columbia students.  In any case, the cajun turkey, pepper jack, lettuce tomato and spicy sauce make for a delicious sandwich.  When inebriated, the sandwich only tastes better.  The sandwich also goes well with Campells chicken soup.

Eddie & Son! This little hole in the wall saved me from the scary breakfast's offered at my dining hall in college. It is so cheap, $3-4 per breakfast entree! The food always came up fast and tasty, from pleasurable waitstaff. I really enjoyed meeting up with friends before class as this little place. As a bonus, the "down city" locals always provide a little entertainment during your meal.

Is the son of Eddie's in Son the older man who always runs the cash register?

This Grinder has a fun retro vibe with colorful sports decor. I've eaten there several times and I always feel comfortable even when it's crowded and I don't feel rushed. It's cozy for late night and winding down.The extensive menu of  comfort food brings a coffee shop to a new level and is tasty and reasonable. Be hungry, the portions are a  hearty size. Breakfasts are any time of day which must make it great for L.A. and it's many activities. The tropical tea, I heard is blended from tea leaves selected in Europe by the owner himself and is fabulous. I love the breakfasts and loved the Chinese Chicken Salad for lunch last time I was there.

Alright price.
I only like their plain tart.  Great consistency.  Very creamy!
the other stuff..the flavored ones..more on the icy side.  Weird texture..not about it.

They didnt have fresh fruit so I got it plain. 
2.50 for a small.  But it was just the perfect amount!

They have other smoothies and milkshakes there too!

If i ever go back, which probably will because I live close by..I think id only get the tart yogurt again!
My power Mango-A-Go-Go came out to about one inch below the rim. Other people in my group had smoothies that were about half an inch below. I like this chain, but what a rip-off at this location.

Tosca has been closed, out of business, gone since September 2009. The owner/chef has flied for bankruptcy, moved on to work at another restaurant, the equipment has been sold, and the space is offered for rent on Craigslist as we speak.

Here are some related articles about the closing:

http://blog.timesunion.com/business/tosca-grille-owner-files-for-bankruptcy/18653/

http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=844517&category=BUSINESS

http://www.examiner.com/examiner/x-2256-Upstate-NY-Restaurant-Examiner~y2009m9d21-Taxman-shutters-Tosca-other-Troy-spots

After kayaking out in Morro Bay, my friends and I headed to Firestone to try their famous Tri Tip Steak Sandwich that my friend was raving about the entire weekend before our 4 hour trek home to the bay.  Famous to all the SLO college kids...even after they've graduated they come back for it.  I'm not sure if it was because of the sun and we were starving but we all ravished our food.  The sandwich had the perfect amount of meat (loaded) and just a good spooning of BBQ sauce on top.  The bun was buttered and toasted...nice.  I'm always disappointed when the bun gets soggy and you can't pick up your sandwich, Firestone's held up nicely.  The onion rings were humongous...you can share a basket with 4 people.  Most of the group ordered the Tri-Tip Steak sandwich,one person ordered ribs, a couple pulled pork sandwiches and one person ordered the bacon burger.  We all agreed, the Tri-Tip is the way to go.

Be prepared for a grease-coma after!  yummmmm

Masala Bay has good Indian food. The two times I've gone, I have been with a group of people and we have shared dishes, family style. So, I'm not always sure what I ate. But, it was all good. 

Some of the things that stood out to me were: the garlic naan and the vindaloo (it is VERY spicy even to this southern so watch out). 

As the previous reviewer pointed out, it is a small restaurant with what can be difficult parking (the second time we parked in a free parking lot just past the restaurant which was nice) and they can be understaffed. But, the food is good, the beer is good and the atmosphere is nice. I will certainly go back if I find myself in W-town!

Don't pick this place for the middle-o-road decent cheap pizza.  Was craving lasagna and gave Rosati's a shot.

OM Gobz super yum.  Takes them up another star just for that alone!  The bread stick and box of iceberg with one slice of cuke were kinda lame sauce.  But enough lasagna for 2 meals at my appetite level.

Their delivery has been always quick and reliable.

The restaurant is oddly decorated with random Buddhas. And it smells of garbage (the scent isn't strong though and you get used to it). 

There didn't seem to be any order on what food came out of the kitchen first, so I got my food before the 5 people who ordered in front of me. The silverware we got was plastic forks and knives and a small napkin all in a plastic bag (classic cafeteria silverware).

The food wasn't good for the price I paid ($7 for a lo mein?). I wouldn't be that mad about it, but I'm pretty sure I found a bone in my food. A piece of beef I bit into was very hard, so I spat it out and found something in the beef that looked like a bone. I enjoy going to restaurants that look bad but have good food for a cheap price. Not a cheap price and after that hard piece of whatever, I probably won't come back. 

Worse of all: No Chopsticks!!!

I was tempted to put a 1 star...no cucumbers, no olives, and the chef salad comes with four things on it.  It sucked.....Olives weren't on the menu but cucumbers are and they said that they don't even stock them. Everything tasted like onions. Why can't they have good toppings here?  I won't be back.

I just tried Cinderella's last night for the first time. It was a good italian restaurant but I'm unfamiliar with what to compare it to in the area.

They have a wide variety of pizzas with lots of toppings. Extra toppings were a little pricey, about $1.69 but maybe that's average. I just stuck with a pepperoni pizza and was more than pleased.

Friendly waitresses, and close to the T to get back to Boston. A nice, quiet italian restaurant.

Food was sooooo yummy! Got the M.O.A.B. its has everything. Thanks to this place I don't miss Shake Shack in NY anymore!!!   They also have a hugge beer selection.  Will be back for sure! The only reason that I don't give them 5 stars is because the burgers are a bit greasy.

Three trips to Tiny and I'm a fan! 

This place is so delicious--the sandwich topping combinations are unexpected and fun.  They sandwiches tend to be pretty large, so I order a half unless I want to take half home for dinner!

Everything is fresh and the staff is very friend and accommodating.  Great place for a work lunch.

Cool atmosphere during the summer and it has super inexpensive drinks making this the spot to be at! Bartenders are really cool. Best thing is that after the bar you can walk right accross the street to gourmet deli and get a cheap samewhich.

The person responsible for scheduling the #1 bus appears to have mental capacities equivalent to an infected pustule resected from Sarah Palin's anus. 

There is no other explanation for the fact that one can walk along Mass Ave, during peak hours, from Harrison Ave in the South End clear across the Charles River (over 1.5 miles) without being passed by one single measly bus. But you'll probably see over a dozen buses passing in the opposite direction. In fact, it's not uncommon to see caravans of 3-4 buses at a time. They must be going to some bus drivers rally.

I get brunch here as often as possible. They don't open til 11 so I frequently take a walk through Morningside Park before arriving. I've never had to wait for a table. It's very cute inside with a strawberry/watermelon theme going on.

My first visit I ordered the chicken and waffles as part of a personal search for the best chicken and waffles in Harlem. My findings: Amy Ruth's has really great waffles. They are lovely brown Belgian style crispy. Their fried chicken, however is not so great. Miss Mamie's Spoonbread Too has amazingly tasty fried chicken through and through, but the waffles are soft and quickly turn to mush. Ask yourself: Do I want crispy waffles with merely decent fried chicken, or soft waffles with amazing fried chicken? As for me, I just go to Spoonbread and order the chicken with cheese grits instead followed of course by the peach cobbler.

Service could be better. For example: if you want coffee you might have to remind the wait person a couple of times to get it, but then the coffee is really good.

I get Diddy Riese ALL THE TIME! My favorite is the chocolate white chocolate chip cookies! YUM!! 3 cookies for $1- can't beat that. I love that UCLA athletic socials have Diddy Riese cookies all the time, so free cookies for me! Their ice cream sandwich cookies are amazing diabetes in a cup! They upped their prices to $1.50. Parking is tough unless you have a UCLA parking permit, or you can park in the Broxton lot. Frist 2hrs are free before 6pm, and its $3 flat after 6pm. CASH ONLY. They no longer serve hot dogs. Don't let the crowd discourage you from getting cookies, it moves pretty fast.

My daughter and I went on a Saturday afternoon and the line was out the door.  We probably waited for about 45 minutes or so before we ordered but I have to say it was worth it.  I ordered the Dallas burger with sweet potato fries and a coconut milkshake, she ordered the Philadelphia burger with onion rings and a black and white milkshake.  We split the burgers in half and swapped so one could sample the other.  Both burgers were phenomenal.  I loved the way the beef was not bland but seasoned lightly with salt.  The sweet potato fries were the best that I've eaten so far with their thin cut and perfect crispness.  The onion rings were huge and fried perfectly.  My coconut milkshake was off the chain!  About an hour after I left I was craving a second coconut milkshake.  All in all, we had a great experience at BBP.  I'll definitely be returning soon.

Eat Here! You really can't go wrong... it's clean, organized, friendly, well-lit, and you get a ton of food for your money.

Oh yea, Cal students who show their ID get a free drink!

The people are super nice and friendly, even though they're being over-worked. It's hard for me to imagine working as hard as they do... I mean there is usually a pretty constant stream of people coming through the door and these guys / gals just keep on slinging burritos. They really take the time to make sure that whatever you order is the way that you want it. I also often see them cleaning up the tables / floor / drink area / bathrooms to make what little space they have as friendly and hospitable as possible.

This place really gives you the option of making your food as healthy as you want it to be. I've ordered burritos, soft tacos (off menu), quesadillas (off menu), salads, and burrito bowls. All of the ingredients are fresh and freshly made!!! I usually get a Chicken burrito with black beans, grilled veggies / fajitas, corn, mild / tomato salsa, guac, and lettuce. The burrito does wind up being huge... probably 3-5 pounds. 

If you're really trying to get the most bang for your buck, this is the place to go. A burrito can easily last you 2-3 meals and, at $6-$7, is cheaper then most of the other places in the area.

what you order is not what you get. You want french toast with blueberries, strawberries and seasonal fruit like the menu lists? Order that and you will receive a few blueberries and a ton of gross , lardy filler in between 2 pieces of greasy bread for $15. Mention to the rude waitress that it is uh, different from the menu and you will hear "too rich for you?" huh? coffee is NASTY. But enjoy it because it wil never get refilled and yes you pay for that. Over and over people write this place is out of ingredients and it is true. But they dont have the decency to tell you that, their new method is making something else gross and giving it to you. You can go up to Tom's and have $6 french toast . You can go to many places on the UWS and get great french toast. Avoid this place at all costs. I left $25 lighter and hungry. They charge downtown Manhattan prices but give you something Bubba from Arkansas made from the left over swine fat. Avoid.

The worst thing I can say about this place is that I no longer live close enough to get a chance to go here very often.  Some Kind of Place is a small but good Korean barbeque restaurant, which mostly caters to the take-out crowd, although there's some tables setup outside and maybe one inside (as I said, it's small).  I'd recommend the hot pepper chicken, and the baked fish is also usually really good, but the real treat, especially if you live for spicy food, is the great hot sauce they have which you can put on whatever you order.  I haven't found it anywhere else, even at Asian/Korean stores.

The Crunkleton is plain and simply a great bar.  The inside looks the way a bar is supposed to: dark wood everywhere, a few tvs, and a decent pool table.  You won't find Ed Hardy here either, the patrons are all decent members of society, and there's no Memphis rap being blasted out of the sound system or girls with back tattoos.  This place isn't cheap because you're drinking real beer instead of watered down Miller Lite, I don't know why people are complaining about the prices.  I wish I had gone here the first time I visited Chapel Hill as this place changed my whole perception of the town.  I will definitely be back when I visit again in May.

Tazza's new renovation make puts it in another category of "upscale". This isn't bad, just.... different. 

Good ambiance, decent food, medium/high prices, and good service. 

They offer "Movies on the Block" on thursday evenings during the summer across the street at the park.

this is where my dad buys all his wine. 
great selection of beer & wine for blacksburg.

fun tastings as well!!!

i liked this place.  it had a different feel than most bars/clubs.  and the only way i can possibly describe it... is... i felt like i was at a party rather than a bar/club.  social... people tended to talk to each other a lot more than in normal bars where guys and gals just kinda wait for eye contact.  there was a sense of familiarity with one another that you just don't get in boston or cambridge bars.

zucchini bread is good. 
but its like a muffin more than bread.  

i had breakfast food there which was decent.
whenever i have eggs and home fries i think the home fries are the decision makers. since you can't really mess up on eggs... good home fries (aka potatoes) = i will go back. 

i had:
2 eggs scrambled (undercooked, kinda runny,  just the way I like) flavorless potatoes, and chewy, not crispy bacon.  i like crispy bacon so that was a disappointment.

Fresh squeezed OJ. 

Cute outdoor patio area.  

Average.

I stopped in to Urban Optics on a whim- my glasses have been broken for awhile and I haven't had the chance to get them fixed, so when I happened to stop in SLO for lunch on a road trip, it was the perfect time. I asked for some help, and Susan gave me great advice, as well as a screwdriver for my glasses. I didn't spend a penny here, so they didn't HAVE to help me. Susan treated me like a paying customer and truly cared. If I lived up in SLO, there's no way I'd ever go to another optometrist. They had an incredible selection of frames. I might have to just go back up there when it's time for new specs!

I went on a date here and had heard so much about their crazy good pizza rolls.  The pizza rolls were gross.  So greasy and bland.  I had to dump ranch sauce all over those things just to keep on chewing.

So sad--the owner has decided to only serve out of Ivy Garden in West Warwick, and has closed this location!  We went last night only to find that she's gone.  Frankly, it's hard to blame her after cooking for crowds on a hot plate for 6 or 7 years, without a real kitchen.  She had mentioned that moving to Thayer St. was her dream, but maybe the right place wasn't available.  I hope she moves back to Providence at some point.  The food is great!

There are not a lot of gyms in the area. I'll start off by saying that I used to live in Boston and San Francisco, so granted I am a bit spoiled when it comes to training facilities- the gyms I have been a member of in the past were stellar, well equipped, clean and attractive to go to.

But even given all that, the experience I have had with this gym (now called The Edge) is inexcusable.  First of all, I joined for three main reasons 1) It is close to where I live so I can zip there and back easily. 2) It was a member of the Gold's Gym chain, and since I travel, it would allow me to go to other Gold's locations nationally 3) Although their equipment was not that great, I was PROMISED that they would be getting new cardio and other updates soon.

Well, guess what. Two months later they dropped the franchise. So when I had to travel all last month, I shelled out $60 to go to other gyms. No new cardio equipment, and in fact, half of the cardio they have is broken. I complain daily, and have put in suggestions for specific models and types of machines I want to see. I report that their one stairmill is broken daily. I could go on. When I told the manager how disappointed I was, she basically said tough luck.

Now, I really don't have that many other options (plus I signed a year contract, although it was a contract under the chain when they were still part of the franchise) so I realize that I am not in a place of power. But I do feel lied and misled. I also feel that when I have expressed disappointment at other gyms in the past, they have been more than attentive and accommodating, trying to make their customer feel better about the situation, offering incentives for compensation, etc. I know many other members that feel as I do- dissatisfied. 

That said, the staff there is nice and sympathetic, although they don't seem able to do anything to alleviate the situation.
luv the burritos. you get free chips and salsa. I choose this over chipotle most of the time. it's tastier, and is cheaper.

I liked this place. It was kind of what an out of town noob like myself pictures when they picture an NYC diner: slightly better than average diner food, better than average style for a diner, a lot of beautiful college students who don't want to talk to you.

Service was shockingly attentive.

PLEASE CLOSE DOWN!!!!!! THIS WAS THE WORST YOGURT, NOT JUST FROZEN YOGURT BUT THE WORST YOGURT OF ANY KIND I'VE HAD IN MY LIFE INCLUDING ONES FROM GROCERY STORES.

I got the Plain Tart Yogurt without toppings. I was pretty much done after the first bite, but it was this incredibly nasty indescribable taste that led me to another sample and I finally knew what it was - a blend of fresh vomit mixed with ice cream and tartness from spoiled milk with a side of now I want to vomit because it was sooooo disgusting.

Came here last night for dinner with my husband and son, The food was great!!!! the service was above average, since we are semi-new to this area, we are trying all different places out to get some spots that we can know we can get get good eats and service! we will definately come back here frequently.

I am giving this place 5 stars because both the food and service was nearly impeccable.

Went there today and cashier and server were both very friendly without being annoying at all. 

I really like the decor, the chalkboard menu is clever and the artwork lining the walls ties in with the whole feel and theme of this Korean bistro.

Got the California Bibimbap with the bulgolgi and brown rice.  The rice got nice and crunchy on the bottom and the meat was still tender and not overcooked.  

My favorite of the day was the Spicy Vegetarian Topokki (Rice Cakes)! It was the perfect spicyness and nice crunchy textrue on outside of rice cake but still chewy on the inside.  It was actually the first time I ever had this dish and I'm definitely headed back for more.
Great Salads and frozen bars!

OKAY.

I'm not gonna lie, I go here nearly every day since it's on campus. The drinks here may sometimes be less than perfect due to the inexperienced staff but it still provides that great boba fix (unless it's almost midnight where they routinely run out of boba T_T). Passionfruit snow bubble + crispy chicken snack so good.

More like 3.5 stars.  The prices seem to have skyrocketed from the time I got my restaurant.com coupon some months ago to the time I finally ate here this past weekend.

I tasted some of some basic starter salad with some sort of tangy cream dressing.  Clearly I wasn't paying much attention. But I do remember that it was ok, pretty basic.
I didn't bother to taste the spinach empanada, it just didn't look that great.

I got the ravioli (Sorrentino) made with some sort of Italian ham--this is "traditional Argentinean"?  Maybe, I don't know.  Anyway, it was really delicious.  Must have been that Italian ham that really made it tasty.  It comes with a pink sauce, which I'd normally shun, but this one was very nicely flavored, I couldn't quite figure out what made it special.

One of my friends got the pasta special that came with a whole small lobster.  I tried some of that lobster--it was perfect!  Perfectly pan roasted, very nicely seasoned.
My other friend got a steak, rare.  But it looked kind of well done.

I got the pear poached in malbec for dessert.  The pear halves looked kind of shrivelled, but it tasted great.  My friends got the quince and something else in pastry.  The pastry looked just like what was used on the empanadas, and apparently tasted exactly the same.  The quince and something else filling was very good.

There wasn't enough on the menu that interested me, and it was kind of sticker shock because I remember the prices were lower when I last looked at their online menu.  But what I had was very good.

Yeah, it's Blue C Sushi.  Yeah, it's not the best quality sushi in the world.  But:
a) The sushi, for the most part, isn't Bad.  I'm not concerned about my hygiene when I go there.  There might be some weird sushi or something in particular that doesn't look good... so you just choose something else from your many options.
b) The prices are pretty great.  It is very clear how much you are getting for what you are paying, so you're able to have just as much as you would want and pay just as much as you would want.
c) For me to want to pay more for "Good" sushi, it's going to need to be pretty freaking awesome to justify a higher price than what my budget can appreciate.
d)  The conveyor belt.  Need I say more?

Also, the staff at the University Village location have always been polite and professional, and did not try to rush my group out even though we sat at our booth long after we had finished eating.

So, Blue C Sushi.  Not where I would go to try and impress someone.  But it is a fun, comfortable place where you can go to get sushi that is good enough for very reasonable prices.

Tios, if you want to charge $15 for run-of-the-mill fajitas and $8.50 for a small(!) guacamole, at least bring me some chips.  Your food is pretty good, but it's not good enough to charge those prices.
Decent food.  Crappy service.

Located in the basement of Drexel's Korman Center, this non-university-affiliated business is there with an open-hand when some dumb college student (me) spilled a bottle of water into his laptop.

As much as doctors must hate giving bad news, the people here must love it. Every "I'm sorry, sir/ma'am" is money in the bank. Almost two years ago, when said incident happened, the Computer Fixer kept me waiting two weeks and 300 dollars later to find that my computer was dead. In addition to the 300, they asked for 80 more to salvage the hard drive.

This experience really hurt me, as did the outage of not having my computer as a working writer. For some reason, I thought this would be better than Apple. The staff is friendly and somewhat compassionate, but as they hire Drexel students, I get a bit skeptical. As I move into my next laptop, I much prefer warranties than being left to the whims of places like these.

Pizza is one of my favorite foods and I was quite curious to try out this new wood fired pizza spot in Troy, after hearing some good things about it.  The decor seems very cavernous, with dim lighting and many tables hidden in nooks and crannies.  The beer and wine list offers selections I was surprised to see at a small pizza place, and the menu offers a variety of pizza and pasta dishes.  We settled on a pair of salads, some drinks and the margherita pizza to split.  The food was pretty good, though I wouldn't say the salad or the pizza were overly noteworthy.   I'd probably try the pasta if I went there again, or maybe a pizza with a little more pizazz.

There are a whole bunch of reasons this place only gets 2 stars.

#1 Be forewarned they don't accept returns other than for store credit or exchange!!!  I even walked back after 5 minutes of realizing the size was too big and NO RETURNS.

#2  They weren't very nice about it either.  I will caveat the service is usually pretty good.

#3  Way too pricy...

#4 limited selection.  They only seem to carry a few main brands.  I'm always wishing for more options.

#5 always oversizing my kids, choosing one size too large every freaking time I go there, which obviously needs to stop.
 
#6 no prices anywhere, but I've learned they're pretty much the same:  $$$$$ for kids shoes they'll only wear for 3 months.

Now you have to wonder why I go there at all... I work full time, have 2 insanely active kids, and have to cram as many errands into one trip as I can so one trip to stanford mall beats driving all over the peninsula.  And some of the shoes are cute.

Great frozen yogurt store that is always bustling with locals and students. There are several places that make Franklin street unique. Most people would agree Yogurt pump is one of those institutions. On, first blush, this place feels like Loco Pops - local run and low profile. It is exactly this atmosphere that Yogurt pump has that is adored by its loyal patrons.
Healthy, and hip. Definitely worth a trip.

Gonna have to add my voice to the others here. I have NO IDEA what the people rating 5 and 4 stars were smoking. SERIOUSLY. This place is the epitome of starving college student lowest grade sushi. Transplanting this restaurant anywhere else with a decent sushi appreciating crowd would probably make it implode from the gravitational pull of its own suckiness. Srsly.

I remember coming here when I was a wee freshman loooooong ago. I was the only one who ordered sushi out of my friends. I figured why visit a sushi restaurant and order something like a terikaki bento? Made no sense to me. It was too bad for me that the logic that usually served me well backfired on me and helped my friends whom I thought made a dumb choice. The sushi was terrible.

I made the mistake of visiting a couple of more times during my undergrad years. I guess I am a sucker for pain. 3 stars for their OK non-sushi dishes and 2 stars (pushing it even at that) for their bad sushi. Even Tako Sushi doesn't deserve a 1 star bad buffet sushi rating. At least they have humans making it here (albeit badly).

This place has friendly staff and really good strawberry milk tea! I love bubble tea and I also love being treated like my business is apreciated! The food is also really yummy. I only give this place 4 stars because it is kind of cramped in there and there is a 5$ minimum when using a credit card.

I agree with Carla - these cookies are way to buttery. Now, I love me some cookies, and I love me some buttery cookies, but these left grease all over my hands and made the box as greasy as a KFC bucket.  I'd still eat 'em though.  Oh yeah, I'd still eat 'em. But they're still too buttery.  But i'd still eat 'em.  Do you have any on you?

I like Mary Chung. But I don't love it.

I'm Chinese and grew up with a bowl cut. Mary Chung reminds me of a Chinese restaurant in Saskatoon where the White family down the street took me when they wanted to impress me with their chopstick skills in the 80s.

Any place that you can get two entrees for under $20 is perfectly fine by me.

Border Cafe is more than fine, however. The fresh tortilla chips and homemade salsa that comes with every meal are addictive (I'm pretty sure I saw them sprinkling crack on the chips).

I've tried a couple of the things on the menu, but I always come back to the Chicken Burro. Chicken and cheese, stuffed in a tortilla and smothered in...MORE CHEESE. 

You really can't go wrong. Unless you get the frozen sangria. Minus one star for that yucky drink.

The wait can be brutal, especially on a Friday or Saturday night (plus it always smells so good in there - but I always leave smelling like I rolled around in a tub of smokey ground beef). Totally worth it.

Surprised to read the reviews below, I've found this store to have far too many attentive sales people (When they think you're about to break the bank, that is). This place is A-OK because of their amazing winter sales. In February, a good portion of the over priced merchandise can be found 50% off!. Ended up getting boots at a deep discount to what I found on Zappos, and that made me happy. This place is awesome, when there is a sale!

The Apache was the highlight of my visit when i went to its open mic on Saturday.

Sucks I couldn't find a seat but thats on me for not coming way earlier.

I can't rate the drinks cause all I had was a bottled beer so I guess I'll give a true rating when I return. But the host of the event was great, and funny as hell. I forgot his name but I give it up to him, he shot jokes off the fly.

The sound quality was the best I've ever heard in any establishment I went to so a big thumbs up for that.

I'll definitely be coming here again and will perform something as well... this is a must

I placed an order for delivery online. I received food and the items that I substituted were not substituted. I called and explained the mistake. They apologized for the error and offered to send the delivery person out asap with corrected order. Great food, great customer service. My fav chinese restaurant by far in RI.

New menu just appeared and is way less expensive.  Drinks are overpriced, but amazing.  Specifically Mango Margarita special.  Decor is worth a visit.  Check out the art on the wall in the back room area by the bar.

You just learn to miss Emma's. How could you not miss Emma's? Emma's is my choice for go OUT for pizza to converse and keep intimate restaurant. Emma's has a sweet tone with their full on but still simple pizza & wine menu. I say stick to their already planted mixtures of toppings instead of ordering your own... but if you have special dietary needs.. go for it.

Artichoke hearts on thin crust. Mmm. Be ready to wait a little. Enjoy close neighbor seating and plastic everything.

Hummus is a good place to get a snack, especially if you like...hummus.

The decor is decent, but most people take it to go.  While I dined in, it was a little difficult to maneuver around the lines to get more sauce or water.  

The falafel was pretty good, and the hummus smooth.  The beet salad was good, even though I usually stay away from that type of dish.  The wholewheat pitas, however, I could eat all day.  Call me crazy, but the hummus and bread would have been enough for me.

Although a bit on the pricey side for what you get, it is far better than going to the McDonald's on the corner.  :op

For a quick snack (except during peak times), Hummus is a good change of pace from the usual fare.

Man alive, this place was amazing. If you've got a chunk of change to throw  around definitely get the tasting menu! Pricey but worth it. There were  internal organs involved, but you know what? They were good, damn good. The only draw back for me was they didn't have wine parings with the tasting menu but the chef made some great recommendations so problem solved.

The famous "Andre's" Cafes of Houston just opened up their 3rd restaurant, this time in Rice Village where the short lived Mission Burrito used to sit (next to Baker Street Pub and across from Brian O'Neill's).  Great new location, same amazing food!  Wow I love this place!  I'm more familiar with their lunch items but today I went there for breakfast and their crepes were out of this WORLD!!!

Is Andre's French or Swiss? I don't know? I'm not sure I really care.  All I know is they serve top notch breakfast and lunch and their pastries are legendary in Houston.  At my old office I used to bring boxes of their pastries from the River Oaks location and I was like a GOD in that company (for a couple of weeks anyways).

Thierry Andre Tellier Cafe also recently won Best Pastry Chef in Houston by My Table, so obvioulsy they're doing something right.

Check out this new location, not too many people know about it so it's nice and serene for the moment.

I noticed they built a great private party area in this new location so it's the perfect spot for private outings.  I'm thinking of throwing a small company Christmas party here actually.  But my friend told me their location in Uptown has become THE place for throwing baby showers so I can definitely see that happening in this location as well.

Was shocked to randomly run into an Isaac Toast in the US - I literally ate here about 3-4 times a week during a summer I spent in Seoul. I guess LA is an appropriate place for their one and only US location. They have this delicious sweet sauce that they brush their toast with that I wish they would sell, but the guy refused to sell me the sauce. :(

If they used higher quality lettuce this place would get a solid Yay! in my book.  Yes, their salads are massive, but who wants to eat that much nasty bulk, Costco iceberg crap?

Also, for me, those salads are just too big and it ends up being sort of wasteful (who likes day-old soggy salad?), but maybe that's just me.

Price is good, selection of toppers is good, sandwiches are good, I love how you get pineapple or watermelon or something with the salad, and that honey wheat bread is AMAZING......But.....A nice baby field greens mix here would do worlds of good for Intermezzo's salad.  Candied walnuts would class it up a bit too, but that may be asking too much.  

Also beware: they put a sickening amount of dressing on if you don't ask them not to.  Probably about a cup.  Blegh.

It is a truth universally known that a spa day is not to be shared with just any kind of girlfriend. 

Spa-Level Girlfriends are few and far between. These are the girls with whom you can carry a conversation about everything from the weather to current celebrity events. They are not Chatty Cathys or Debbie Downers (and especially not Unhygienic Ursulas! Ew!) They are fabulous, fun, and know the value of a good pedicure. SLG's are the upper echelon of lovely girlfriends a girl has who embrace their femininity and rights to spa days. 

Luckily, my bestie thinks I'm a spa-level girlfriend, which is how I found myself soaking in hot milk and almond oil one sunny afternoon in December. The staff was nice enough, but (for an SLG like me who hasn't been to a spa for just a pedicure before) I would have appreciated a tour of bliss spa and its amenities. I felt a bit abandoned once they showed me into the waiting room. A tour, or at least a little rundown of where everything is, would certainly have added a "wow" factor.  

As for the the hot milk and almond oil, I got a very standard pedicure with massage, and though I enjoyed it, there wasn't anything above and beyond about it. For a $65 service - pedicure only- I was hoping for a mind-blowing pedicure, pampering, and whatever else a Westwood spa would allow me. They did bring me a cup of tea, but it felt like an after thought. 

The polish job lasted a very long time, which was great but mostly because they used OPI nail polish. For a spa, however, the experience was pretty much no-frills.

This is some decent pizza. Not serious NYC-style and not authentic Italian, but a sort of cross between that sweet dough/ Mellow Mushroom/ southern pizza thing and the classic toppings of some place with a Little (or normal-sized) Italy. So take a sweet dough pizza, flatten out the middle but leave the puffy crust, then randomly scatter ricotta, red chilies, and some extremely tasty sausage, and get a couple of those char marks on the bottom. That's the deal, and it is very good.

My crust was chewy & a bit soggy, but I blame this on the drive my gracious personal delivery man made on my behalf.

I needed a spot to have a quick business meeting and found Mariposa Bakery!  Glad I did!

You walk into the store and you are greeted with a very warehouse-themed coffee shop with cute chairs and art deco.    The baristas were very friendly and the prices were very reasonable.  Seating is available with a lot of windows so it is bright and fun to hang out.

I ordered the iced coffee and was glad that I did.  It was made very strong, and they offer several types of milks for you to doctor your drinks up!   I also ordered the cookies, which were home made and fun to eat!

The best thing about this place is that it is very peaceful and relaxing.  People here are cool and kicked back.   Nice change in a bustling town!
My favorite wi-fi spot. No one bugs you there.

as far as cheap eats goes, gypsy's is definitely a dependable, to-go place. most items are generally quite good, though tomato based sauces tend to be a tiny bit bland. drown your pity in the fake parmesan cheese and red pepper flakes, provided on every table. 

extremely cheap pizza and calzones as well, all freshly baked, and good enough to make you think twice about eating at blondies or fat slice. 

i myself make frutti di mare a regular meal whenever here, the chicken dishes tend to use dry chicken meat, but the pesto and cream sauces are very rich and very good indeed. 

i'm on a diet though, i miss it all ;*[
The campus is beautiful campus and I love taking the 3 mile run around the campus. I know many people whonare students or alumni and this university is the best in Houston!

I used to work at Walter's and here's my two cents.  While the food isn't comparable to Pasadena or LA, it is better than anything of equal or lesser prices in the area.  

I'd like to clear up a few points people made that were entirely inaccurate:

1.) Walter's does carry chai.  The best chai around for sure.
2.) When Walter's was a burger joint (about 40 years ago) it was under completely different ownership...don't confuse bad burgers then with the completely different restaurant that shares only a name...
3.) It is not the intent of the restaurant to be classified as "Afghan".  They are a continental restaurant.
4.) If the bread isn't up to par, ask for better bread.  It's not a problem and the bread comes out of the oven every half an hour.  It's the best bread for miles.
