5.) Walter's has more vegetarian options than most restaurants.  And yes, salads do count.  Even without the salads, you're looking at 5 or 6 vegetarian options which is way more than most restaurants.
6.) Really?  Did you say good food at the Press and Pizza N Such?  I'd say Walter's is better than both and at Walter's you get ambiance.
7.) Walter's historically uses a runner/server system.  Who cares who is filling your drink as long as its full.  And know there is a generous tip out system.


People, prices are based on ambiance and setting and food...you don't sit down at a restaurant only for food..that's what Chipotle is for.  

And to clarify, maybe 2 of all the restaurants in Claremont have an actual Chef.  Don't confuse cooks with chefs.

Allow me to give you a little insight into my personal set of priorities.  Ready?  BEER.

What TJ's Beverage & Tobacco really means is, "Come here for gourmet beers.  Please."  Yes, there are other things here, sure.  Cigarettes and snacks and, I don't know, wild snakes (probably).  But you come here for the beer.

TJ's fills the market niche for excellent microbrews from all over.  If you have a favorite independent brewery, chances are they'll have something from it.  If you want a cash of Coors Lite for beer pong, Harris Teeter is right down the road.  If you want to treat yourself with some Flying Dog or Bell's, this is the place to come.  Do you hear me?  Come here for all your microbrewed beer needs!

Still love Le Pain!  It's so hard ordering something different because I love the Mozzarella & Proscuitto tartine with the sundried tomatoes and pesto (mmmmmm) ... but I swear next time I will MAKE myself order differently.

LOVED this place! I travel quite a bit for work and am far too familiar with your average Courtyard Marriott. I stayed here while on a trip to Houston and found it to be a very enjoyable experience. Hotel had a really funky cool atmosphere - kind of dark swanky and loungy with artistic touches everywhere. Visually really pleasing. My room was also very nice - very cushy comfortable bed, clean, and unique. We also had a dinner event in a private room off Monach and the food was also excellent. I would definitely reccomend this place and would absolutely stay here again!!

As a new Asian place on campus, I planned on trying Spoon House as soon as I had the chance. The menu was quite original, a spin of western and Korean fare, offering tacos and burritos made with korean style meats as well as Bul gogi  trays and some other random offerings.

We ordered a few tacos and a Chicken bulgogi tray. Then problems started, our food took a HALF HOUR to come, and that was after I asked the manager where our food was. This is unacceptable at a place where they don't even serve you.

Once our food arrived, it was fairly decent. The tacos had a very interesting taste to them. The bulgogi tray was a bit boring. The salad was bland, but the sweet potato fries were pretty good. 

Overall, the food is not worth the rather long wait and I likely wouldn't go back.

Went to the new restaurant for a Sunday Brunch. We were literally the first poeple in there at 11AM. Guess it will take a little while before they pickup a crowd. The restaurant is located in the space that used to ENO's. 

The space has been renovated and there is much more light in the room now. Very nice. Great space layout and they also have outdoor seating. Not sure I am too crazy about sitting in Peachtree St exchaust fumes for dinner/brunch, but we all have different preferences. 

The place has been changed to be more of a bistro with a European flavor to it. The place is both a bakery (opens 8AM in the morning) and a Bistro. The bakery has some very appetizing things, you have to stop by if you happen to go there ot get a sense of the kind of baked goods they do. 

We have only tried the Sunday brunch. As the number of people there were limited we had a lot of attention from the staff (thank you!). The juices are not freshly squezzed. The coffee is really good if served in smaller European styled cups. 

We had quiche and eggs with bacon. The quiche was very good and served with a side salad. The scrambled eggs were served with bacon and fried potatoes. The scrambled eggs were very fluffy and tasty. Overall the experience is that they have a high quality chef that makes great food. 

We had a great experience and are certainly coming back to test their dinner. I am sure we will also return for more brunches. Very nice addition to the neighborhood.

If you have not been to Mary Chung's and tried the Suan La Chow Show you owe it to yourself to make a visit. Go now. Don't hesitate. Truely extraordinary.  Basically it is a simple dish of pork dumplings on a bed of crisp bean sprouts in a delicious spicy sauce.Suan La Chow Show is one of those dishes that once you have it you can't stop thinking about it, it's that good.  You will be happy and grateful.  The spicy dun dun noodles and the stuffed fried eggplant are also pretty tasty.

I'm sorry to pooh-pooh this place, after all, plenty of people rave about it to me. But the buffet is so mediocre and it's not especially cheap, either. I get kabobs here usually, which are okay but not the divine experience I crave from Afghani kabobs. Compared with the downward spiral of the train-wreck Prince Cafe next door however, this is definitely the better option.

Love.

Yes, I love hot dogs.  I refuse to be hidden about this passion any longer.  For $2.75 I can get a scrumptious, flavorful, and filling dog that is handmade and beyond delish!!!!

I have been dying to try Hewtin's for quite some time, but refuse to join Twitter, as I can not be limited to 120 characters.  InDowncity Facebook posted that they were coming to Grants Block for Food Truck Tuesday - I have no idea if this is a weekly thing or not (but it should be - scratch that, it should be DAILY!) - and I headed over for a quick bite before a 11:30 meeting that would run until 3.  

Not only was I able to enjoy this lovingly prepared pair of perfectly grilled extra-long buns encasing a 'casing worth tasting' - but it held me through my marathon meetings without getting a case of the stomach rumbles!  2 dogs has never before done that for me!

Thank you, Hewtin's.

Bartenders here are the best!

I can only speak for the nightlife side of things but it is very fun on the weekends and 80s night on Thursday!

to me this is my favorite grocery store in pittsburgh. plus shopping there gets ya discounts on fuel which helps alot nowadays. from flowers to fresh sushi it has it all. a good meat selection with a ton of variety in the case. olive bar. fresh fish .a ton of vegetables .huge selections of cheeses and prepared foods as well.not to many people there at night time makes it easier to shop quickly but also means all of the departments with cases are closed. free samples most days as well and a chef that cooks up something and has the recipe next to the food and you get to sample it.

all and all i love this giant eagle!

Fugaboutit!  Enzo's Pizzeria is heaven for a New Yorker who craves NY pizza.  Dinner plate special is HUGE just like in Brooklyn!  Come hungry for the combo meal.  Luv the 'Godfather' photos on the wall reminds me of Vito Corleone first kill in Godfather II ... morbid I know I like to roll like that.

Fun place to go if you're in UCLA area... Diddy Riese is SLIGHTLY overhyped, but I give 'em four stars for not raising their prices despite their popularity.

They serve quality ice cream in their cookie ice cream sandwiches, and I definitely appreciate that. :) Their cookies are good, not AMAZING, but are worth it.

I liked their snickerdoodle and white chocolate mac.

Thai Toms NEVER lets me down.  I get take out about once a week and its phenomenal every time.  While there may be a couple health code violations here or there, the food is amazing!! Prices are cheap and they are always quick- especially with take out.  I highly recommend deep fried spring rolls and spicy broccoli with chicken :)

order your food at the bar, grab a drink from the fridge, and then go find a seat outside.  the portions here are really good, and they have yummy bread.  i had the poached eggs over toast w/ celery and olives today.  it came w/ a side of the home fries w/ pancetta, and it was delicious.  the eggs were super gooey when poked and ran all over the buttery toast.  yummy!  my friend got the breakfast panino, which was gigantic and came w/ a side of the home fries AND salad.  the panino had pancetta, spinach, and TWO over easy eggs.  i am getting that next time!

After craving some top dog after the college football season opener and then being disappointed by the ridiculously long line in front of this Cal institution, we dropped by Blondie's for a bit of nostalgic college grub.  The line was luckily not as long and moved much faster since the slices were grab and go.  Not as good as I remember in college but still good for what it is: large slice of pizza that will fill the tummy.

I have to agree with matthew w. on this one. get the saki for a psuedo japanese experience, and load on the wasabi. Incredibly convenient and healthier than almost any other restaurant on walnut street, but nothing to write home about.

I have only been here once, but I had a great experience. I actually came here on a first date and it could not have gone better. Although, I don't think I didn't really fell for the girl, I did fall in love with Border Cafe. 

Holy Lord was that cheesy, I may just change my Yelp name to Cheese Boy after that bad boy.

One star for the horrible, horrible vegetarian options. The main problem with the vegetarian fare is that in order to cater to vegans, most of the vegetarian fare is vegan. This is obviously disappointing if you are vegetarian but not vegan. The other bad thing, is that this place has a really, really bad nutritionist on the vegetarian side of things. Seriously -- if you were to exclusively eat from the vegetarian options here, you would be in a lot of trouble, especially if you didn't eat the pizza (which, as far as I can tell, is how they expect you to get all of your vegetarian protein).

Sometimes Crossroads as good vegetarian dishes -- especially in the "Fire & Ice" Asian section of the dining commons -- but on the whole, the selection is simply far from adequate. Not only is the food inadequate, there simply isn't a lot of variety. There's a dozen or so dishes in the vegetarian area, period. The Mexican food station always has the same options, and the Asian section has two or three vegetarian dishes that are served only occasionally. If you are a vegetarian eating here, you will eat all of the new food you are going to eat here in the first month or so. Towards the end of my second and last year in the dormitories they conducted a survey and focus group due to the overwhelming number of complaints by vegetarians, so things may have changed, but when I ate here a few times during the following fall things seemed the same here.

I have never had better wings.  

Also, if you order 14 wings, you usually get at least 18.  If you order 21, you get damn near 30.  That might have changed, though.  

Lastly, this place used to be owned by the Menendez brothers.  That is cool as hell.

Never met the driver, so I can't vouch for them, but the operator was a complete moron! He didn't even say the name of the company when he answered, just "What town...?". I thought I'd dialed directory assistance by accident! Then he was impatient, even as he continued to mumble commands at me (which I had to constantly ask him to repeat.) Just unnecessary, really.

If you are lucky to find a parking spot in downtown SLO, but want some BBQ, this is the place to go. Tri-tip sandwich is pretty good, and their fries are tasty. Too bad it can't be ordered as a combo meal, but then again the portions are reasonable, if not large. Unfortunately, the line is quite long here most days, and finding a place to sit can be a challenge. It is a college hangout, after all...

This is another run of the mill fro-yo establishment. The yogurt flavors are nothing to be super-excited about, but you might find a few that you like. I honestly don't like their original. It somehow reminds me of cheese sticks/string cheese. Their chocolate is pretty fake tasting, as is their vanilla. I didn't mind the cake batter though, it was a better alternative than their vanilla. There was a fruit punch flavor that wasn't too bad, but it got sickening after a few spoonfuls.

The selection of toppings is large, but not everything was fresh. I got a waffle cone and it was stale. I'm sure lots of stuff they reuse if their waffle cones are stale.. I didn't want to try the fruits, so I just added some mochi, andes mints, and caramel cup chocolate pieces. Oh, and their cheesecake topping was really mushy..

I will say that the place is clean, and bigger than most fro-yo places. They also have a mini drinks bar(which seems pretty empty whenever I stop by), but you can order coffee and other things.

My tip for you: Grab some sample cups and make sure you like the fro-yo flavor that you're getting. Then splash on the toppings.

Okay, so their beer selection basically blows, but Happy Hour is everyday and you can get a supermug (33oz.) for $7, so I'm not really complaining that much.  The Happy Hour, however, is really for the $5 burger.  It's amazing.  Good patty with a buttered bun, some fixin's, and an onion ring.  The sauce/ketchup is groovy and I have no idea what it is.  The whole thing is stacked much taller than your mouth can handle and typically becomes a disaster, but who cares?  If you're not feeling the burger and you feel like ordering an entree, I highly recommend the Ahi Tuna Salad.

I haven't seen this kind of food since NYC!

Very satisfying, if unhealthy haha

A bucket of great pickles sits on each table. 
Old school mustard
Yummy big sandwhiches 
Delicious blintzes
Yummy knish, if a bit too fried
Wholesome french bread challah

and gotta love the Russian music from the adjacent banquet room

this is where all the too-cool bike kids hang out.  My visits in there leave me feeling uncomfortable and judged and like my presence is a hassle to the employees.  They have a decent selection of stuff so I'll go there if Broadway Bicycle School doesn't have what I'm looking for and it's something I can't wait to order.
My experiences:  Don't trust them to do anything  more difficult than putting on a new tire.

The waitress obviously had a problem with my group the moment we sat down. We ordered our drinks, and the waitress took forever to bring them to our table. We asked for napkins, and she brings back 2 napkins to a group of 4 people. When I took a sip of my tequila sunrise, I realized it wasn't a tequila sunrise, but a cup of orange juice with a little tequila in it. No grenadine. With the rest of the table having a similar experience, we didn't bother to order any food, and got up to leave.

Ok, I like hot dogs here, but

Let me ask you,

Does any of you get disgusted when they take cash with bare hand and touch your hot dog and bun with that same bare hand?

Please, use GLOVES.

This restaurant is a huge hit in Chapel Hill and is even moving to the old Patio Loco location next to McDonald's and CD Alley. From the sandwichs that I've been able to try, the food does not warrant the insanely high price.   The food is great, but not 12.95 for a tuna salad sandwich with chips. There is a palpable pompous air to the establishment that bodes well with the high prices. There are many more local and tastier food selections available throughout town.
Best Thai place in town!! I love Thai Palace.  Their curries are great.  Pineapple fried rice and pad-see-ew are also really good.  Servers are really friendly.  My #1 choice always for Thai

Though this was a recommendation to me by a friend, I was pretty disappointed. I had a buzz going but I was able to order my food like a sober person. 

Food:
SOGGY NACHOS with questionable urine colored cheese..Can I say los problemas de saneamiento? 

a FALL APART CHICKEN BURRITO. Freebirds, go get some burrito making lessons from Taco Bell because right now ya'll fail miserably! 

Service: 
Could be better. 

Atmosphere:

Dude..I'm not coming here again.

-4 stars for Food and Service
+1 star for me attempting to give a damn because my friend recommended me.

It's not the seediest Subway's I've been to. I've gone in the middle of the night for something decent to eat in the wee hours of the morning since it's literally across the street from where I live. I've also gone for my fourth/fifth etc. cup of coffee when I didn't feel like making it for myself. The breakfast sandwiches are surprisingly good. As is the Teriyaki Chicken, but I wouldn't want to look too closely at that! They will add extra lettuce etc. if you ask for it. The guys who were in there at four in the morning when I stumbled in as though I were drunk (I wasn't, I'd just been awake for 36 hours) were very congenial and dealt with me as though I were a rational human being at the time. (Even though I made up an imaginary boyfriend so I could get two sandwiches, one for now and one for later, without seeming like a pig.)

Claremont's new additions never cease to amaze me. I love this theater. It shows a nice mix of popular as well as indie films. It's never too crowded and its nice, new and clean with comfy seats. It's a nice addition to the village area.

this is a good place to go to scope out some of the higher end brands of shoes and trendy clothing.  I don't like spending my money here, however.  I have found items here, maybe even tried some on, and left the store to order them on zappos or shopbop.  why would I do that?  why would I avoid giving my money to a local business?  because the service here is horrible.

I find many of the male employees a bit creepy.  they just have a lurking, leering quality about them much of the time.  they kind of follow and watch you without offering any actual help.  the women tend to be better, though I've still had to ask to be helped (new flash, when a customer is holding a sample shoe and looking around, they want to be helped!).  I have bought an item or two when the salesperson was friendly.

it's too bad the service puts such a damper on the store.  they have an interesting selection of clothing and shoes, though in limited sizes.  it's rather expensive even though most of those brands are made in china, but their pricing is pretty consistent with other stores.

and btw, nobody believes you when you say every shoe is 'the last pair' so stop trying to use this as a pressure tactic.

After 91 years in business, Princeton's "five star" restaurant closed on Friday, November 19th.

Three generations have managed this illustrious restaurant, which has feted stars and sweet-sixteen parties alike.  However, the world moves on, and after the building was sold to an investment firm, ML Seven, owner Joe Christen decided it was time for him to move on as well, leaving this location empty for the foreseeable future.

Mr. Siegel, as president of ML Seven, do you think you have enriched the community?

meh. i came all the way up here one day because i kept hearing about how amazing it was. maybe it was an off day. the girl working was kind of standoffish. the selection wasn't great and the prices were pretty much the same as every other store in new york. don't think i'll be back.

As far as balancing food quality, convenience, price, and atmosphere, this may be the best Asian food that Harvard Square has to offer. The atmosphere is (to me) remarkably better than 9 Tastes and Aiyara, and the service is efficient but never obtrusive. I think the portions are bigger than at 9 Tastes, too, but the prices are essentially equivalent. I've never had problems with seating, either, even though there are always at least several tables' worth of people.
Super delicious with tasty microbrew soda. Stopped giving free chips in exchange for dropping the price. Still pricey though, but fills you up.

Good donuts.

Bad coffee.

Hearing Stan yell at his employees for not properly cleaning the floor the night before.

Price is right.

Seeing Stan chat up customers as he leaves.

(and I haven't yet had the peanut butter banana donut, so I can't comment on it)

Yep, call that just about right.

We LOVE Monahan's!  We typically  make a weekly pilgrimage to Ann Arbor from Lansing on Saturdays so as to go to the Farmers Market  - and Monahan's.  Bought some red snapper today that we just finished off an hour ago and it was absolutely fantastic.  So, so fresh.  Like many midwesterners, I grew up thinking fish was Mrs. Pauls so I absolutely hated it for many years.  Then, in the early 1990's, I took a trip to the eastern Canadian provinces, including Newfoundland, and after having what fish is supposed to taste like, definitely prefer it now to beef, pork, etc.  Monahan's is fresh with just that slight, ocean smell to it.  YUM.  Already thinking about what we'll get for next week's treat!  Won't even consider 'grocery store' fish as it smells, well, like fish.  Monahan's is a little on the pricey side, but I simply don't care as long as I get fish this fresh.

Went here on a Friday night and had no problem getting a table. The bar area was really packed, so we decided to get a table and order some appetizers along with our beer.

The Portobello Fries were awesome -- nicely breaded and not too greasy. The wings appetizer was larger than expected and the chicken wings were nice and meaty. 

Oh and the beer. We each got the 8 beer sampler. It was a bit confusing at first because we wanted the 8 beer sampler but we didn't know if there were even 8 beers on tap. It took the waiter a little while to get things straight; actually, he never was able to figure out what they had available so we just said screw it and told him to get us 8 random beers.

I'm normally not a fruity beer guy but their Cherry Raspberry Ale was my favorite.

Your typical Urban Outfitters, except this one is crowded with students.  Well, what I did expect on Harvard Square.  So be prepared for higher than usual crowds, especially downstairs in the bargain basement.  The lines to try on clothes can be unusually long - especially with everyone trying on stuff then coming out to parade in front of their friends, then trying out something else in the pile of 20 items they have.

This little gallery, located in the back of Harvard Square's Leavitt & Peirce, is one of the neatest things in Harvard Square.  There's an incredible selection of unusual and asymmetrical pieces, including a large collection of amber, all of it unique, elegant and reasonably priced.  This store is one of the reasons I became interested in wearing jewelry, and I've always had a stellar customer service interaction with the owner.

The reason I finally got around to remembering my password on Yelp is that I wanted to write specifically about my experience last week.  My fiance and I were taking our lunch break to measure my finger to get our engagement ring resized - we initially went to Zinnia, just down the street, thinking Zipa was so small she might not have the tools.  We had a pretty nasty interaction with the woman there, and it left us both feeling a little unenthusiastic.  After eating, I asked if we could just try Zipa, knowing the owner to be really nice, before going back to work.  Not only did she have the tools, she was pleasant and informative even though we weren't buying anything and provided us with plenty of advice and her congratulations.  I don't see why I would go anywhere else!

Irene's pupasas are fabulous!  Granted, my only experience with pupusas is from Irene's, but still.  

Irene's must have recently (within the last few years?) upgraded from selling pupusas out an RV to having a real restaurant, because I only remembered the RV w/ the pupusas sign when my coworker suggested we try it for lunch one day.  Boy was I surprised to find a nice, clean restaurant!

The pupusas are fresh, quick, and yummy.  I've only ordered veggie dishes, but the best I've tried so far is the carrot pupusa.  The zucchini one is kind of bland, but the bean one is decent.

Went here today for the first time, even though I've lived and worked in the area for about four years now.  Was happily surprised with the food and environment, along with my co-workers!  Lunch was reasonably priced ($8 burgers to the $24 filet mignon...but most prices around the low teens).  Everyone was happy with their dishes but we weren't blown away, thus only the four stars.  The desserts (creme brulee and this molten chocolate cake) were the best.  The ambiance is calm and quiet (trying to do upscale French provincial like Henrietta's Table, minus the noise), and the service was quick and dependable.

I don't really read comic books.  I just never got into it.  I always loved the artwork but ended up spending most of my money on new electronics and music.

I sought out Zanadu on a mission.  I was there to get a copy of Johnny the Homicidal Maniac and the first book of The Sandman series.  I love me some JTHM.  And I realized I didn't have a copy.  And I really started to like Gaiman's books, so I figured I would give his Sandman series a go.

The store was a tad small but large enough to navigate a small stroller. (awesome)  I was completely lost on where to look.  But the wonderful staff here was very accommodating and grabbed what I was looking for.  Too bad they were out of JTHM, I'll be back for that though.

The food is ok. However, their meat patties are so thin you have to get at least a double-double or a triple-triple to get something that actually resembles a cheeseburger. And buy the time you do that, the cost ends up going way above what you should pay for a fast food burger. Their fries are absolutely mediocre, I have had better fries at a million places, including lots of other fast food restaurants. The one delicious thing they do have = milkshakes. And the staff is always very friendly.

The restaurant itself was nice, with a good amount of seating, and the people working there were nice. The food itself wasn't that great. I had a chicken burrito, and it was just bland tasting. I was only given rice, black beans, chicken, and barely any pico de gallo. I mean, I understand that I'm only paying like $4 for this burrito, but I really expected it to be more tasty.

I love having Shagga "in my backyard."  The service is graceful and the food always fresh and delicious.  The vegetarian combo is very good.  Kids fit in very well here unlike some of the places in Shaw and Adams Morgan.   Spices can be a bit "off" at times but over all this place is great for the location.

It had been a while since I had gone to Trata and I had forgotten what a cool little place it is. Warm, welcoming hues everywhere you look.  Vintage movie posters.  Window tables overlooking the street and overflowing flower-boxes.  Very modern and mellow.

It was too late to get anything from the kitchen so we went next door and got a big bag of SmartFood popcorn that I shared with the bartender and the few people that were there.  When the kitchen's open, the food's been pretty good and the staff is always friendly.

Note to self:  Don't be a stranger, Ali.  You like Trata. :)

Back when I was a student at Columbia I heard Amir's mentioned a lot as cheap digs for your chickpea dosage. Years after college, I'm back in the neighborhood and in need of a quick bite. I was quite disappointed!  Though I'm not Lebanese, I'm Greek, so I do have SOME idea what good falafel and hommus tastes like. This was awfully runny cheap tahini and the pita pockets were slapped together. A mess to eat and a bit overpriced considering it was hommus in a store-bought pita pocket with iceberg lettuce and styrofoam-esque tomatoes. Come on now.

I'd never been here for a concert until last night (Florence + the Machine). Up until then, I had only been here for Broadway shows. 
The place is a really great venue because it's so historic and takes you back to a different time before multiplexes were the thing. Great atmosphere. 
I waited a bit long to buy tickets to the show and there were not many seats left, when I say not many seats left, I mean literally, according to the seating chart, there were about 20. We were up in the gallery in the very last row so I can say with confidence that there isn't really a bad seat in the house. Even though we were far away, we still had a good view. My only complaint is the sound up there. You're so high up (and I'm not sure there are any speakers anywhere up at the top) that when Florence was talking, I couldn't hear anything she was saying except for about every third word. But when she was singing it was fine. Next time there is someone I want to see, I just need to buy tickets earlier.

The first time I went to Mister Sister, I was with my prudish gay boyfriend and my sweet.  So, the first impression was already dampened.  

This time, however, it was just me and the sweetie.  As a lover of a good toy, I went to this place with armed with great expectations, a ton of knowledge, and a smile on my face as I was giddy with anticipation.

Needless to say, I was not disappointed... The staff is super-friendly (loves the Ducky!) and there is a great selection of vibes and dildos. I found the prices to be similar to the prices I found online.  In some cases, Mister Sister's were lower.  Just another reason to go to the uber-friendly neighborhood toy store! 

All in all, I am a true fan.  I am a tough grader, which is the reason why I didn't give a five.  Plus, I couldn't buy all the toys I wanted and no one asked me be a toy tester... But, I will definitely be stopping in this store many more times!

Came here on a Saturday afternoon with 3 friends. I had only been here once before and it was to have a burger and a beer after a day of intense, pre-Phd examinations. The burger was delicious (it was the first thing I had eaten that day at around 5pm) and the beer (again, on an empty stomach) got the job done.

Fast forward to 9-10 months later on a Saturday in February:
My friends and I decide we NEED to have calamari and beer. We visit city tap house and they're not serving it until 6pm. It's now 2:30pm. We see that New Deck has calamari on its menu so we decide to go there. We arrive, wait forever to get a table, an additional forever to order, the calamari comes out. There are two tiny plates of small, golden balls of fried batter with a tablespoon of canned (maybe jarred?) tomato sauce on the side. We ask for lemons. The waitress brings 3 slivers of lemon (the kind that sit on the rim of a glass). These slivers are so thin that it is impossible to squeeze the lemon onto the "calamari" without first mushing it in between your fingers. We order a few burgers, a salad and the "char grilled" chicken quesadilla. The meat in the quesadilla was not grilled, it was soggy, ground, dark meat chicken. The fries that game with the burgers tasted like funk.. sorta like what a wet dishrag would taste like. The salad was somewhere between room temperature and noticeably warm.

Now, if I had visited New Deck at, say, 11:30pm on a Saturday night I wouldn't be surprised that the bathroom was in the state that it was in but 3pm on a Saturday? Piss, toilet paper and what looked like spit was everywhere. They also have these weird faucets that only work if you hold them on.. I was so disgusted and confused. 

I'm absolutely positive that I won't be back. I don't care that the quesadilla was $3.00. That's because they used what looked (and tasted) like discarded chicken parts. No thanks.

So, while not quite tex-mex, they don't have a Brazilian option for categorizing food.  Let me tell you though, this place was FANTASTIC.  I went in there at about 6pm, the service was very prompt and efficient, and...  Yes, they provide love in the form of a ($2.99 during happy hour 2-7 7 days a week - what a steal) passion fruit margarita.  So tasty.  Their happy hour also had great-looking appetizers, though I enjoyed just a heart-of-palm and cheese...  dish.  I'm not sure how else to describe it other than fantastic.  Came served with banana-tots which are exactly what you'd picture when you think "banana-tot" and a light mustard sauce that I dipped them in and...  Heaven.  I'll certainly be back.

Great work guys, way to take care of us up in north campus.

I wasn't impressed.  I was bored, and not ready to go home yet, so I popped into Mudo.  Some of the shoes seemed to be on sale, and I'm going to be honest, some of them were really cute, but they had them in like 2 sizes! And half the shoes didn't even have the prices on them.  When I asked the girl, she didn't even give me a price, she gave me a range of prices....and all of them were way more than they should have been.

The Sale's rack was alright.  There were some cute jersey knit dresses, but I wasn't sure if they were worth $50.00.  Some of the tops were cute, but sadly, I still wasn't impressed.  The girls seemed to know who was interested and who wasn't, so I was ignored in favor of the annoying 50 year old woman that probably shouldn't even be shopping there.  She had such an annoying husband too....ack but that's another story.

I didn't really take a look at the rest of the store, because frankly I wasn't into the place.  Maybe it was because it was pouring out, but I left.  I might come back, but not anytime soon...

Strokos is a staple for late winter nights at the library when you realize it's 9pm, you haven't had dinner, you're braving the 30 degree weather and 20mph gusts, and you don't want to deviate more than 10 ft. from your walk home.

The salads and sandwiches here are great.  The hot prepared foods, not so much.  Don't let the looks fool you; that baked ziti looks delicious, but once you bite down, you'll be magically transported back to your high school cafeteria and the flavorless mush from unknown sources.  Not to imply the quality of food is subpar, just sayin' a little salt & pepper (or olive oil, oregano, basil, garlic...) wouldn't hurt.

Stick with the salads and paninis and you should be good.  Many times has the pesto queso grilled sandwich saved this starving grad student.

I am addicted to Ike's Place! Every single item on their menu is loaded with flavor and they've created all best combinations possible. I'm a sandwich lover so I've brought a bunch of my friends out. My meat lovers and vegans have all been super happy with their food because there are so many options! 
I always have a hard time actually choosing one over the other, so I'll definitely be going back to try the other ones & the boys behind the counter were so sweet!

I did not know who Lee was, but all things considering, this replacement was worthy.  The sandwiches are not cheap.  It's 6-7 bucks for a very simple, diner style sub or sandwich with non-fussy breads (no foccacia or artisan for you) and non-fussy ingredients (pickles, tomatoes, nothing soaked in aged balsamic vinegar, etc).  
My boyfriend and I sat at the diner style counter.  He ordered a corn beef club and I ordered chicken salad.  It looked glum -- what with the regular square bread and the generic looking ingredients.  I bit into my sandwich and I almost died of goodness.  This is the best effing chicken salad I had EVER tasted.  My boyfriend liked his sandwich as well.  And the guy behind the counter was very friendly, very nice, and very genuine and helpful.  Got a return customer in me and my boyfriend.

I've been getting my hair cut by Claire at Orbit for a few years now and have nary a complaint.  Claire is great, I always look forward to getting to sit and chat with her as she snips away, and she definitely knows what she's doing.  I like that I can either come in with a very specific idea in mind or just a general concept and let her be creative with it, and either way I'm always satisfied with the results.  Orbit itself is a nice environment with a lot of open space and everyone I've encountered there is very friendly.

Bring a Sweater, parka, arctic survival suit... because you'll be C*O*L*D!

Beautiful new facility.  I wasn't a guest at the hotel, but rather sat through three days of meetings in the actual conference center in June 2009.  So this review is about the conference center. The conference area is connected to the hotel.  The conference center is large and comfortable.  There are balconies on the outside of the building where you can warm up fro the freezing inside temperatures.  In the conference rooms there is a little natural light (which is unusual) so that's nice.  We were in one room and the lights kept going on and off.  Our presenter couldn't determine why.  They it was determined that the lights in our room and another room were connected.  Crazy! 

We were served lunch by the conference staff and kitchen on three days in a row.  I was impressed with the food.  We had wraps one day and they were very good.  The flavored iced Tea was overly flavored for me.  

The place could use a small room with vending machines.  What about those of us who don't drink coffee? soda please?  The parking under the building is expensive.  You can park across the street for as low as $5 a day.  Don't waste your money. 

I spoke to many people who did stay in the hotel and they were all really impressed.

Froyo by the ounce!  Visited with the wife and kids after dinner.  The boys loved it.  One loved plain choc/vanilla twist and the other loved the myriad of toppings.  I enjoyed it more than I thought would.  The coconut and red velvet froyo was very good and the fact that you can control how much of whichever toppings you want, where you want them was really cool.  Example... I could put almonds and hot fudge all over my coconut froyo while keeping only choc chips and coconut flakes on the red velvet.

Now, I'm not exactly what you would call "health conscious" but if I was id be happy here too.  Lots of low fat froyo choices and toppings like flax seeds, blueberries, other fresh fruit, graham cracker crumbs... even kashi cereal.

Kids want to go back, so we will.  (I want to go too.)

I really like how efficient this place is... don't worry if the line is long it won't take long. Their pita chips are delicious and so are their grape leaves. Yum! There is a reason why it's busy... and has lasted on Thayer St. IT IS GOOD. 

Street parking only. A couple seats outside,  does have inside seating.

If you like a lil hummus in your life this is your kinda place.

Good burrito, but for the $6.75 I payed it should have been bigger. I can't give it any more stars then 3 for that reason, I just hate beeing jipped, when I'm done with a meal I like to be full, whether that be the finest French restaurant in California or the local taco truck.

This is my go-to food market. Can get pretty crowded but never so packed I want to scream. They have a we're trying to be whole foods but falling much much shorter prepared and semi-prepared section. Skip those, they suck, especially the cooked food, it looks and is, awful. lots of oil and grease. Cheese section is pretty nice though, and they offer just about anything else you'd want. Food and produce is one cut above a normal supermarket, but not as nice as whole foods or garden of eden. I don't think prices are expensive here, rather quite reasonable. Open 24 hours, not sure why though. I like how they have a nice selection of natural body products (shampoo, conditioner, soap, etc) by the registers. Probably the best beer selection in this general area too, you can always find something nice and new to bring home there. Make your own salads are pretty good too.

Stop hatin' on the Pu Pu, people.

Their lunch specials are practically free!  A big mac or a big serving of spicy beef with rice?  No brainer.

They also have these dumplings in peanut sauce that I looove and this is the only place in the area that makes 'em almost as well as my old love, Tai Ho, which went down in flames.

MSG TASTES GOOD!
It's "The Kong." PBR's are $2.50, Scorpion bowls are $16 and stronger than you think. The scallion pancakes are made crispy and fresh to order (seriously try them).

My 5 reasons (although I have more) for the 5 stars.
1.  Great staff 
2.  Good food (they have gelato too!)
3.  Amazing drinks (LOVE their chai latte)
4.  Live music on the weekends
5.  Free wifi

I had read all the rave reviews on Yelp and decided to check out Cafe Luna myself.  Upon entering, I had a 3 minute chat with some of the servers and by the end of our conversation I knew I was going to love this place.

The place IS small and the layout is narrow, but I love the cozy feel of it.  I went on a Sunday right before brunch time so I was able to grab a table for myself and my friend.  

We ordered from the weekend brunch menu and both our meals were fantastic (Greek omelet and Belgian waffle).  We ate our plates clean.  They even gave us free cinnamon buns (which were AMAZING).  
For drinks I ordered a tea and then the infamous chai latte.  I loved both.  My friend ordered a regular cafe latte and she loved it too. 

My friend and I then proceeded to whip out our laptops/books to study.  Even though it was crazy busy, the staff was extremely accommodating and did not rush us to leave.  

I love the vibe the place and the live jazz music playing in the background was a plus.  We were sitting towards the back so the music was not too loud while we studied.  (Perfect for casual studying - NOT a place if you need absolute silence aka library studying).  The place is perfect if you love to study with a constant busy (but non-intrusive) buzz around you.  But beware! Tables are relatively small so don't expect to sprawl all your books out.  I'll definitely be back...OFTEN!
The place for unique kicks in Seattle.

Easter dinner and we decided to have Rock Bottom. Why you ask? Well somehow we were both super tired and I wanted to cook some dinner but the boy just wanted to be lazy and go out. 

It was between Flame Broiler or Rock Bottom. We should have gone to Flame Broiler! doh!!

We were seated in the a corner table while everyone else was seated in a booth. My bf whispered to me "racial discrimination?" haha. Who knows but it's not a big deal if we don't get to sit in a booth

I ordered the chicken panini sandwich. The chicken was grilled a little too long and was very dry. It came on thick bread that was lacking in pesto sauce. The mozzarella cheese was ok and there was only one slice of tomato. The argula was pretty standard. 

They are currently have a special of prime rib Fri-Sunday for $12.50 with mashed potatoes. OH DEAR! We should have known that ordering prime rib from a place that specializes in beer is a huge no go!!!

Prime rib: dry and pretty flavorless. The mashed potatoes..get this we never ever add salt to any of our restaurant food but we had to with these potatoes. They tasted from a box and apparently never made it to the seasoning station haha. 

Service: eh..our waitress seemed more attentive to the other customers than us. 

Total price: $30.00 with tax and tip. Eh.. I should have used that money for something else like clothes or shoes 

Probably only come back for the beer and not the food

I have to say that I come here often. I always get my hair cut here. Now why would I continue to go to a 2-star location, you ask? Because my hair is really short and not very hard to deal with, and it's sort of easy to hide slight mess-ups and the like since I always use product. And it's really cheap! In fact, right now it's only 10 bucks with a student ID.

BUT, sometimes they really mess up here and it takes a lot of effort to make it look right in the week that my hair grows a little longer and starts to even out after getting it cut here. I've even had to take scissors to it a few times myself to fix outstanding problems a few times.

I have had far worse hair experiences than those I've had at FAMA, so it's not all that bad. The best hair stylist I've EVER had I found through FAMA, but when i went to get my hair cut again he had apparently left for China and never came back. It's been over a year now so yeah, he's gone for good. Anyway, moral of the story: if you care about your hair, you will NOT be coming here, I promise you that.

NO THANKS! 

In case you were wondering whether or not customer service is a luxury, try Radio Perfecto. Answer: yes.

My friend and I walked in last night after not seeing each other for quite some time. We sit down, and wait a bit for service. A moderately friendly bartender comes over, takes our order, and serves us up. 

We were there before 7, and it wasn't too full. Around 6:45, people started coming in individually every other minute. How do I know? Because the door stayed open for a good 30 seconds after each person came in, bringing in the crisp December air.

That was uncomfortable.

Don't worry, discomfort continues. A man in a khaki suit eating dinner on his own next to us is watching "the" game. We continue to carry on our conversation and he decides to interject and buy us drinks. I said sure, but my friend wasn't so up for it. Eventually she gave in, and the guy tells us to "never say no".

Hmmm, that's not what my feminist theory teacher at Columbia taught me, but OK, moving on.

It was a sweet gesture, yes. He continues to watch the game, and (as I said in the beginning) since I have not seen my friend in a while we kept chatting it up. No qualms, we exchanged thank you's and your weclome's. 

SUDDENLY...
This one short, hipster-esque bartender kept giving my friend and I an attitude for the remainder of our stay, and I have no idea why. And he was deliberately being friendly with everyone else at the bar!

Could it have been that I asked for an extra dirty martini and he gave me a simple martini and I called him out? I just wanted my drink... Maybe he thought we were using the guy? Except that my friend tried turning down the drink and the guy wasn't trying to talk to us... Was it my hair?

I, like other Yelpers (and techinically everyone else) do not like wasting money, and especially not giving it to a jerk! I felt completely disrespected and offended by Mr. Randy Grinchy Scrooge. 

NO MORE RADIO PERFECTO!

Although we've been going to Le Monde off and on for many years, recently we've had two awful experiences.  On one occasion several months ago my husband became very ill after eating an omelette with eggplant.  We've known for years that their  lunch/brunch is not terribly good and have returned several times since then for dinner.

This past Sunday we went for dinner and it was a nightmare.  First of all, our very sarcastic waitress served our drinks (there were 4 of us) across the length of the table rather than  walking around.  At one point I was sure that should would spill the drink on me.  My husband ordered a la carte from the prix fixe menu and although he asked the waitress what the entree' was like, she reassured him that it was very good, neglecting to tell him that it is smaller than an average appetizer.  The entree' consisted of a small dollop of mashed potatoes, two thinly sliced pieces of salami and two thinly sliced pieces of port tenderloin.  That's it!! Furthermore, the prix fixe dinner is $31 for three courses.  If ordered a la  carte the same 3 courses add up to $33!!  Some deal.  I ordered the lam shank which was 90% bone and very tough.  It came with parmesan polenta which was like gravel.  As we were entertaining others, we did not make a fuss so as not to embarrass them.  This time, we will definitely not return.  EVER.

The two stars are for the decor and for about half of the wait staff who are actually very professional.

Even though its RIGHT there from campus, I've only came here once a few years ago and recently for their free burrito through TAGGSTR.

I dont know if its because it was free and that was why the quality of the burrito was so poor but I didnt order a bean burrito thank you very much. I did appreciate and enjoyed the salsa bar and free chips though. Its also another plus that its open late and actually has a few tables inside. 

But eh, I probably wont be back unless I'm really desperate. Campus cred this week is $5 for $10 though :)
Great neighborhood place. The food is delicious at a great price, the staff is friendly and helpful, the room is comfortable but sophisticated. Love the catfish!

i love this place!!!!
first of all, I am a vegetarian, and this place is definetly vegetarian and vegan friendly. they always have a vegan soup, and their salads and sanwiches are amazing!!!
now that said, this place also has a lot of good stuff for meet eaters, they have all kinds of meat sandwiches (blts, roast beef sandwhiches, and lots of other stuff) that would make my mouth water if i ate meat (actually they do make my mouth water even though i don't eat meat)

the portion are HUGE though, which isn't a bad thing, but i suggest ordering the half sandwhich and salad, or half sandwhich and soup combo, because a half sanwhich in intermezzo language is as big as a normal sandwhich

their fresh baked honey bread is sooo good

oh and here a tip: if you really like the bread, all you have to do is ask for some of the bread ends (which in my opinion are the best part) put 25 cents in the tip jar, and the cashier will normally give you as many pieces as you like


also the marinated tofu is to die for, whether or not you eat meat, you should try it at least once!

My boss has been talking this place up for a long time, and I finally made the trip over the find out what all the noise was for. Trouble is, I DON"T KNOW WHAT WE'RE YELLING ABOUT.

The place was ultra tiny. Not an issue, really but it should be noted. We were sat at a table along the wall, and there were bits and chunks of food freshly smeared on the wall. Yummy.  

We asked for the fresh spring rolls with no shrimp, and there were shrimps nestled comfortably in my supposedly animal free appetizer.  We also ordered the mango curry with tofu and and pad thai with tofu and no egg. The mango curry was not bad, but boasted only two pieces of mango in a sea of sauce. The pad thai was served as requested without the egg, but the noodles were grossly overcooked into a giant gelatinous mass topped with some sad little bean sprouts. I could barely pull it apart. Not. Pleased. 

The service was genuinely friendly, so stars for that, but the search continues for five star Thai.

This is a famous subs place. Get the cheese steak with onions. There can be horrible lines at lunchtime. Years ago we used to go there from work during lunch - we'd call and place our order across the street on the pay phone, so we could cut in line and get our pick-up order.

This place reminds me of the Seinfeld episode about the non-fat yogurt. To quote Jerry: "This is so f'n good!"

No claims of non-fat here. If I still lived in my old house, pretty much across the street, I would be even more obese than I already am. I would be able to put slices of pizza in orbit around me to eat at will thanks to my gravitational pull.

I cannot even count how many times I have been back. Well I can, but I am still in a pizza coma from tonight. Did the Margherita go up in price from $15 to $17? Still worth it! Tried the San Gennero a couple times now and love it. Sausage is awesome. Tried the Pomodorini too. I am making myself get the Gigiotto Calzoni next. I am going to try and eat that by hand too, no utensils for me. Who eats pizza with a fork? Can you say cram the wad?

I am thinking I should bring them some bacon and see if they will throw some on for me. Mmm. Not like I am anyone to say their pizzas need improvement, because they do not. I just like bacon.

No loss in quality from the massively increased foot traffic. We still get treated like family. Giovanni still takes time to talk to us when we are there and still is able to make delicious pies.

Like Arnold said in Terminator 2: "GO...NOW." It also reminds me of Speed. If your pizza is not cooked in under 55 seconds it will explode. Explode in your mouth that is.

And for those of you complaining about lack of tables, they have one now. They always had a couple counters set up by the windows for you to eat at anyway. Is pizza a sit down food now? I like the atmosphere here. You and other patrons are all standing around one big table enjoying and sharing the experience. Much better than just sitting at a little table. There are also plans to extend the eating areas into the parking lot and the parking lot behind the place. It is amazing how much they listen to their customers. They know most people want to eat it right out of the 1000 degree oven. Sitting is for suckers. Ivan and Kit's moms sit on me all the time and believe me, they are suckers.

Time to roll myself home and plop into bed to dream of going back tomorrow. Stick a fork in me I am done, since you will not be needing it to eat pizza with anyway;)

I used to live down the street from this restaurant and would walk down all the time for huge margaritas, possibly accompanied by greasy Mexican food, and hobble in a drunken state back to my apartment. The margaritas here are great (free one on your birthday), whereas the food, outside of the tasty nacho appetizer, is more mediocre. The service is ok, though, and it was nice to be able to walk there and pick up takeout sometimes. In retrospect this was actually kind of a lousy restaurant, but it earns a 2nd star for being so close to my apartment and all the drunken memories.

NnnnOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!

I want this place to stay hidden. Screw y'all, stay in your cubicles!

I used to have the greatest dentist at UCLA. But going to the Cafeteria  there is like eating food from the day before.
I mean, why not having a little better food and stimulate the taste buds. USC after all has a much better food cafeteria. As for the dentist, I changed to a private practice in Beverly Hills. At USC or UCLA you are just a number with no name.

Its hard to believe I had never set foot in a Trader Joe's until a couple weeks ago, since this place has already become a part of my regular weekly shopping.  For some reason, I had the incorrect assumption that Trader Joe's and Whole Foods were the same over-priced place.  Since I despise Whole Foods after a summer spent living in Palo Alto without a car and nowhere else to shop, I never bothered to check out Trader Joe's.  I've found that the prices are actually very reasonable, and although some items do tend to run a little bit more than they do at Safeway, they are nowhere near as overpriced as Whole Foods.   Moreover, they offer a lot of really unique items at reasonable prices that I would have never gotten to try if I stuck to just shopping at Safeway.  For example last night, I picked up their Trader Joe's brand lemon-pepper pappardelle after failing to find pappardelle at Safeway.   At $1.99 for 8 oz, it was about twice the price of Safeway's pasta, but was incredibly delicious and made a lovely meal with just a splash of cream, a sprinkling of Parmesan cheese and a head of broccoli.    I've also found frozen chocolate croissants here that are excellent, and although a bit pricey (about $3.50 for 4) they are still much less than buying a chocolate croissant at a bakery.  They also have sporadic staples that are much cheaper than Safeway - for example, I've seen butter here for $2 as opposed to $4 for the cheapest option at Safeway.  

So this review ended up being as much for the chain as for this store, but I will say that I have never had a bad experience at this store - it is organized, not too crowded, has friendly staff, and I've always found parking.  The traffic on Embarcadero Rd can be annoying after work, but so far it hasn't been too ridiculous.

it's a fun place to go with kids!!!!  this time, i went for the dino exhibit, and it was pretty good and informative!  i don't think it's the best natural history museum i've been to, but it's close and convenient!

and if you have kids, discovery room on second floor is fun!  used to be on the ground level, but moved to upstairs!

It IS an interesting mix of folks but if you aren't a stuck up ass and like different varieties of people then you'll be fine with the crowd.  We had a good time.  I was expecting more from the music but I was up on stage dancing at one point so I guess that means it wasn't bad!  I'll return as soon as I get my next urge to shake mah bootah.

I joined the USC Credit Union when I bought my car a couple years ago, so this review is for their auto loan services. Parking, hours, or deposit services have never been an issue for me because I've never stepped foot inside the business - my experience has been online or over the phone. Also, you don't have to be a Trojan or family member to be a customer here. (https://www.usccreditunion.org/usccu/en/about_who_can_join.php)

Getting set up was incredibly easy. After a ten-minute phone call I knew what kind of rate I qualified for and what loan options I had. Their rates easily beat the quotes I got from the dealerships, and I realized it was a waste to let those car guys run my credit at all. Additionally, USCCU offers lunch-n-learn series on topics ranging from home ownership, car buying, investing & retirement to their members. It's a great service that I would utilize if I worked closer. 

The only reason that they have 4-stars is because they, like many other credit unions and community banks, don't quite have the resources to keep up with their multinational conglomerate competitors (Chase, BofA) in terms of online services. Direct debit still needs to be set up via a faxed letter, and other changes (account transfers/payment adjustments) cannot be done online either. But when you need to reach a person, it's pretty easy to do.

On a separate note, but unrelated to this review: I wish that their home loan services were more expanded because I would have loved to do my home loan with them because their rates are also fantastic. They have a loan officer in a couple times a week, but that is just not enough support for someone going through the home buying process.

Being the lover of frozen yogurt that I am (despite being mildly lactose intolerant) i cannot help but LOVE this place. Ever since my freshman year of college, when i lived literally ACROSS THE STREET from yogurt park, I've looked forward to grabbing a (huge) mini cup of some of the delicious flavors they serve. Some of the best are black forest cake, irish mint, any berry flavor, pumpkin, snickerdoodle . . . basically every flavor i've tasted I like. Also, if you like toppings, they are EXTREMELY GENEROUS with the amount given. Order any size, and i'd say about 30% of your cup will be filled with the topping(s) of your choice. Avoid this place late at night especially thurs-sunday, when the drunken or pre-drunken crowd of berkeley-ites barrage the place, but other than that . . . AMAZING!

I love the Java Roaster. It's a family run business, and they have great salads and sandwiches that are prepared fast. Great for businesses in downtown Lafayette. Fridays are my favorite because they have coconut coffee. It's a shame David doesn't work there anymore, he was a ray of sunshine.

They're up to speed  with the full menu now and I must say they have the Masala Dosa working.  Although it not the best dosa I've had it's still quite good and one of the best lunch options in U district.  For less than six bucks you get the spicy potato filling, the sambar lentil soup, and coconut and tomato chutneys!

The food here only gets 3 stars, but overall I'm giving it four stars because it's so fun to come here!  My husband and I always miss Japan and Taiwan, respectively, so coming here is like watching Lost in Translation.  I love the random videos of Japanese people going about the day.  I love the cheesy subway-line theme.  I love the conveyor belt.  I love the blue lighting and glass stones outside.

The best thing on the belt is probably the fried chicken.  The sesame noodles are also pretty decent.  The sushi is just decent enough not to make you sick, especially with plenty of wasabi and soysauce to drown out the slightly rubbery texture of being on the belt for too long, but the fun factor keeps us coming back in spite of the lower quality sushi.

Er... if you're going to rate a University on its parking, shouldn't they all get one star?

I received my degree from UCSD and I now work for UCSD, so obviously I love it here. 

It's a great location- walking distance to the beach, right off the freeway, central to everything. It's beautiful, and I love getting my exercise walking across campus every day. 

The education is second to none and continues to rival the best universities in the country, even the uber-costly private ones.  

The students here are awesome- smart and fun. I see plenty of students having a great time and yes, partying. And 40% of the students here live on campus, how is that a commuter school?

I've been here for a few times and it hasn't disappoint. I've tried the 1/2 burger, fish and chips, and Dave's madness burger. My current favorite is the garlic fries! They are battered but not a lot of garlic taste :/ But the way they prepared it taste unique. I also tried the beer battered fries, but go for the garlic fries.

The place has a sporty atmosphere, and there's a giant tv with a sport game on. They also provide free peanuts that you can munch on while you wait for your meal!

They usually have some sort of deal for beer. It's pretty cheap.

Go give it a try if you're in a mood for burgers or some delicious fries!

Normally I wouldn't bother reviewing this, but since I have been on the hunt for a pharmacy without pharmacists who are rude, unprofessional jerks and I have finally found one, I thought I would post. The young woman pharmacist with brown hair and glasses is especially nice, and they seem a lot faster at filling prescriptions than any other CVS I have been to in this city (or in the suburbs), and are also really good at straightening out various SNAFUs I have had with canceled prescriptions/refills needed without seeming too annoyed with it.

Also, this place was recently remodeled, as I discovered when I walked in and was confronted, bewildered, with ready made sandwiches and salads (in a CVS???) They seemed a bit overpriced, but it was still interesting. Also, now that they have self checkout lines, things at the front of the store go MUCH faster.

This is the only CVS in the area I will bother with.

I was super excited to see they were open for breakfast after playing tennis one morning. I victory danced over to the counter, and ordered a breakfast burrito with potato, egg, cheese, and oh no bacon? (minus one star)? Ok, sausage then. And extra hot sauce please!

So I'm not sure if it was because I was starving, or because it had been forever, but the burrito disappeared fast into my belly. Well half of it of course, because I couldn't finish the whole thing. It was delish! I heart you Anna's! See you soon...I may even play tennis more often just so I have an excuse to stop by!

Wayyy over hyped. It's pretty expensive considering about 60% of it is just frosting. The cupcakes were okay, and the flavor is good, but it's not worth waiting in line for about 1+ hour for it (that's why I pre-ordered!)

Tip: Pre-order the cupcakes so you can skip the line. Beware though, some people might think you are cutting them and start yelling at you, like they did to me. I had my cupcakes and left the store within 5 minutes. Hah! 

The place is really small and cramped, people start to push (especially if they think you are cutting them)... Not a good experience with the frustrated customers who were waiting in line.

Okay. So I was debating if I should post a review or not, because it IS a little personal! But anyway, I will without hesitation validate the reviews that Dr. Smoot has on here, because he works absolute wonders.

Dr. Smoot and his staff treated me with the utmost respect and made me feel comfortable with every visit I had here, including my surgery.  He has a high level of professionalism that is hard to find with a lot of cosmetic surgeons.  His nurses, including Carmen, Denise, and Julie are amazing nurses and help you feel taken care of every step of the way!  

In the end, my recovery was so much easier than expected! I respect Dr. Smoot for his honesty and straightforwardness.  Something that is really hard to find in this area of expertise.

I'm really happy about my results, and even referred some friends and family to Dr. Smoot.  If you're thinking of any cosmetic procedure, including facials and med-spa, come to Dr. Smoot and his team!

Pretty average sushi, nothing to write home about. It's a bit pricey, but depending on the roll you may get enough to satisfy your sushi craving. Avoid the wraps as they're pricey for what is just 2 pieces of raw fish wrapped in a piece of seaweed. 

Staff is kind of just there but they get the job done.

This place isn't too bad.  Gave it a shot because it's in walking distance from our place, and figured it being right next to Diddy Riese, it could be the start of an interesting dinner combo.  

The food wasn't too bad.  Most of the dishes tended to be on the pretty sweet side.  Otherwise decent portions for the price considering you're in Westwood.  Otherwise, people lie.  The portions are NOT HUGE.  I had the majority of an order of chicken pad see ew, and the Thai BBQ chicken.  That and a bit of my wife's string beans and garlic with tofu dish.  

The tables are way too close to your neighbors.... you hear everything, including the older lady at the next table who asks you what you're eating, is it good, and why did you order so much food?  By the way, she waited until I finished to actually check if I would finish it, or would waste it.  I finished it... I just told her I'm a growing boy, instead of explaining that I'm training for a triathlon.  I'm sure she would have had 30 other annoying questions at that too...

Anyway, a maybe spot for a fall back, but otherwise at this point, I'm still thinking Thai Boom is a better option. We could always stop by Diddy Riese afterwards too....

I LOVE World Cafe Live as an event space, so I'm keeping my rating at a four... but if I was rating the food I had the other night at an event, I'd probably go with a three- or even two-star rating.  

Sweet potato fries were limp and had some sort of sugary coating that I thought made them way too sweet. The spicy dipping sauce was pretty nice, but not enough to counter the sweetness of the fries. 

I ordered a sesame-crusted ahi tuna salad with wonton strips, cashews and sesame ginger vinaigrette. I expected a lush, healthy-looking salad. Sadly, I missed the part that said the romaine would be grilled. My salad looked pretty lame with a couple shrunken stalks of lettuce and two hunks of tuna, plus a smattering of toppings rolling around the plate. The taste was on par with the appearance. A little soy on the side to dip the tuna or some kind of wasabi sauce could have made it better, but I was definitely disappointed. 

I'm going back for another event this weekend, and I probably won't be going in hungry.

I really love Newbury Comics--the used cd and dvd collection is pretty impressive and decently priced. Otherwise, it's a little expensive for my tastes, but I like the vibe of the store. The Harvard Square locale surprised me b/c of the amount of New England sports paraphenalia--I feel like this branch has way more than any of the other spots, good to keep in mind when shopping for game day.  This is my favorite place to buy birthday gifts for people--you never know what you're going to find, but you can always guarantee no one else will pick the same gift.
Delicious food, very good service and a mix of Ithacans rarely seen in other places. Today an anniversary and a newcomer were announced to be celebrated by everyone in the diner.

Heard about this place just in time for finals! Nothing ease the stressed mind than a cookie ice cream treat. 

Cream:Berkeley
Diddy Riese: UCLA 

The concept is the same, cookie, ice cream, $1.50. No offense but Cream is a lot better than Diddy Riese when it comes to quality of cookie. It's a lot chewier which has its pros and cons. Pros: taste better! Cons: you might have a collapsing dessert if you eat your dessert at a leisurely pace. 

 Went with my favorite flavors: cookie and cream ice cream with chocolate chip and a double chocolate chip cookie. I mean, the combinations are nearly endless and luckily it doesn't put a dent in your pocket. 

Opens decently late. great for those late night cravings/munchies

The only thing I've ever had here is the tri-tip sandwich and I love it.  Simple but very good, if I'm passing through SLO on a road trip I make it a point to stop by here and grab two or three.  Has that college town feel to it and everyone wears flip flops there.  I've heard the other food there is pretty good but I go straight for the tri-tip and a side of fries.  It's a good thing I don't have it very often.

This hole in the wall makes me feel like I'm on the streets of Bangkok.  I only tried the pad thai.  O.M.G.  So good!  I've read about people complaining about the burnt noodles - au contraire - I love that the pad thai has that smoky charred flavor - that's what makes it so good!  I did wait 20 minutes to get a seat.  The place is tiny and is not good for groups or kids.  Service is perfunctory.  It is basically street food but indoors.  You will come out smelling like pad thai and your shirt will still reek 24 hours later.  Is it worth it?  Hell yes!  Oh and bring cash as they don't take credit cards - like I said - it's like an indoor street food stall.  Smell ya later.

Really good crab rangoons.  Lots of choices of bubble tea.
I almost always get the Signapore rice noodles or the Pad Thai.

Since it's in Oakland, you're going to see quite a few students.  Sometimes it can be noisy during busy hours.

im cornfused as to why so many people drool over this place. it was good enough, and it was a very cute little joint in an otherwise odd venue, but the food is really not that good. and i LOVE peruvian! the plating is cute, but the little lady is like... not super hospitable. but i guess that's how all asian women are. anywho, it was just whatevs. i like los balcones better. no wait- i LOVE los balcones. go there.

This place is not overhyped at all! Went here with the boyfriend last night and was surprised to see how long the line was. We decided to wait through the 45 minute line to see what the big commotion was about. And to our surprise, the wait was so worth it. 

- 2 warm moist cookies with a big scoop of ice cream only for $1.50??! YES PLEASE. Turtle &Chocolate Chip Cookie + Chocolate Chip Ice Cream = HEAVEN ON EARTH. The cookies were warm and moist and the ice cream just made everything so much better. Nothing can beat cookies that have just come out of the oven. I'd be willing to drive here from Davis again. Everyone must try whenever you're the in area. It's the perfect place to go especially when you're on an inexpensive date with your boyfriend.

This is a fantastic restaurant. They have an original selection, the only sticky rice in town (and seriously good!). Plus, the food is flavorful, not greasy, actually something I could imagine being prepared by someone at home. The only thing I would advise against is the "Laotian sausage"... seems like some Spam variant. Also, I love super spicy food, but do not order more than medium here. Seriously. Here's a list of things I've tried: 

Sticky rice with Papaya - This one is great!!!! My favorite. 
Sticky rice with Mango - Orgasmic. 
Curry Puff - very good
Summer roll - standard, good. 
Fish Tamarind soup - good, but seriously, order medium.
Mok-Plaa - Haven't seen it elsewhere, quite delicious. 
Pad Thai - standard, above average
Pad See Ew - standard, above average

This is the only good Thai delivery in town. I have tried them all several times. I never give up after one bad dish. This is truly the best one here.

Not the nicest Marriott I've stayed in, but not bad.  My room was comfortable, with a great view of downtown Boston.  The Starbucks in the lobby was a convenient option for breakfast (much cheaper than the hotel buffet), and the proximity to MIT was nice.  The price for internet access was pretty steep, and I could hear my neighbor whistling to his 6:30 alarm (possibly the most unique rendition of OMD's 'How Bizarre' I've heard).  But, I slept well, and got to work quickly in the morning--can't complain!

A solid place for an after work casual dinner with your sweetheart. 

Pluses:
All the entrees are around 10 bucks, give or take a couple of bucks.
Service is basic but friendly and perfectly OK.
They have cocktails.
They have lots of outdoor seating.

Minuses:
Don't sit in the non-bar area unless you want to be surrounded by dozens of children. Loud children. Loud. Children. Never again!! But good news: the best outdoor seating is in the bar area, and the inside of the bar has plenty of seating too.

Remember that scene in Serendipity where John Cusack's character has the Macy's (?) clerk digging thru receipts so that he can track down Kate Beckinsale's character?

Well, that's what I was imagining what Whitney was doing while I was praying that she could brighten my day and help me with my Tom Ford predicament.

I bought my beloved sunglasses back in February and carelessly threw away the receipt AND the little bar code sticky they tell you to NEVER throw away knowing that I would never in a million years return my shades.

It never dawned on me that my shades would break.

Whitney came through, found my original transaction and replaced my sunglasses!

4 stars only because their stock doesn't compare to SF Centre store.

God bless the Nordstrom return policy!

Played here last summer, sometime.  Good venue.  A 5 minute walk from Central Station on the Red Line.  

The stage is only maybe 8 inches higher than the rest of the floor so you're right at the level of the crowd pretty much and there's maybe 6 feet from the end of the stage to the bar, a little weird when playing... but you get shots pretty fast!

Didn't have any of the food here, but I did get a White Russian which was the largest one I've ever had at a bar.  This thing came in a HUGE mug and the bartender didn't skimp on the vodka at all.  That was pretty much all I needed for the night.  The people working are also really nice.

There's plenty of space to sit and a coin-op pool table as well.  Thinking back, I had a really good time there... I wonder why we haven't played again yet, time to get on that!

grading it 5 stars on the basis of:
- hangover cure burito
- location
- decor
- good place to study
- freakin' hangover cure! i remember when they introduced it and they only served it on sundays... then they went to 7 days of hangover cure goodness. it is so good i want one right now.

the secret is to keep kiva han's number in your phone, and call them when you're walking or busing down there, and then you won't have to wait so long.

I used to frequent the Am-Caf as it was called (and still by me, anyway). It was a run of the mill columbia bar/eatery. I had stopped going for some time as I switched up my friday night hang-out to the now defunct West End Bar.  Anyway, my brother and I used to be good friends with one of the bartenders and bouncers from West End. We heard one of them was having his birthday celebration there. Plus, the bouncer was now workin at Am-Caf. My brother and I headed there after stoppin by Moca. The entire West End crew was there. I hadn't been there since before they made the renovations. The place looked hot! The lounge downstairs was pumping. The DJ, which we also knew from West End, never disappointed on the tracks. The bar area is sexy and the bartender there was a real nice guy. Me and my brother have a tradition of just tipping real heavy from the get go and seeing what happens ala "you start with an A grade, all you got to do is keep it". My man never disappointed. It was awesome to see familiar faces from West End. That's what hooked me in. I'm only 15 minutes from the place so you won't be hardpressed to find me there on a Friday/Saturday night. Definitely take advantage of their happy hours Monday through Friday from 4pm to 7pm, plus Thursday night from 10pm to 12am. 

I have yet to try the food. But a lot of my friends have told me that the food is top notch with great Tapas selections and worthy of the price. I'll update my review upon sampling. But as a night spot, AmCaf gets a thumbs up.

taste: totally full of sodium!! if you want to be bloated check out pick up stix!! the only good thing if you like cream cheese is their cream cheese wontons so they get one star. but other than that... i dont know how you call that chinese food... but go figure. the food is crap. so much soy sauce... pick up stix has gone down the drain from the past couple years.

decor: nothing much to it. its simple. not much color to the place.

room: the place is small its annoying. they might've just called it a to-go place.

service:  THE WAIT IT TOO LONG!!

overall: the only reason why this place is alive is the cream cheese wontons... everything else is drenched with soysauce or whatever sauce you want. if your a big salt eater... then this place is for you.

panada express would demolish this place.
Horrible service & bland food; I left unsatisfied an annoyed at the staff..

this is one of those hidden gems i want to give 4.5 stars because 5 is too much, and 4 doesn't do it justice.

pinocchios is a treat every time i'm in harvard square. the pizza is very tastey, but its a bit claustrophobic getting in there, or sitting down. its best to get a slice to go.

I guess I had too high expectations after all of the hype I have heard about this place.  The food was okay.  The drinks were far better than the food in my opinion.  Jesse and I started off with the fried goat cheese and the piqullo peppers.  We both agreed the peppers were better.  The fried cheese was good, just very rich.  Next, I  had the chili-braised pork with garlic and pappardelle and Jesse had the duck pinchos with shallot confit and sherry.  The pasta dish was liked by both of us.  The duck was good but nothing "wow" about it.  We split the eggplant dish as a side.  It was served cold and had an unique curry flavor.  It was tasty, but took us by surprise.  The drinks were delicious.  I had the Gi-Gi Says and Jesse tried the Castro Monk and the Wicked turned innocent.  He enjoyed both. 
Our waiter was very informative and the service was excellent.  I will return for cocktails at the bar.

This is a 'looking back' review as I'm new to Yelp.  I found Bacaro when I was looking for a special place that Mary and I hadn't been to for celebrating our then 1 year anniversary of being together.  I also wanted something convenient to the Providence Waterfire event which was also happening that night.  Honestly, we could have ended after leaving Bacaro and felt the night was great.

To begin, Bacaro is situated right on the Providence River which actually is very nice at sunset and even better once the torches are lit for Waterfire.  We were able to get a window seat, all the better as our meal overlapped both.  The waiter was incredible- aside from his enthusiasm he was very versed in all of the dishes and wine pairings.
