We started with a wonderful cheese and olive board and pinot grigio that was perfectly chilled.  Mary is a big risotto fan so that was her order, and she was more than satisfied with how it was prepared.  I had the pork chop and mixed vegetables which was equally terrific.  

For anyone thinking of heading there before Waterfire, try a 5:30 or 6:00 booking to give yourself an hour and half or so.  You'll want it to truly enjoy all that they offer. Parking at that time and in that area on the street is usually available, another plus.

Disclaimer: I have never actually eaten at this place unless I was well beyond drunk, so understand my view of how "good" the food is could be a little off.

Now with that said, my first thought in my drunken head was Buck Fiddys? huh? Understand my confusion being new to Westwood and being taken to a place everyone is cheering and saying Buck Fiddys, now I may have been drunk but I can still count and my burrito did  not cost $1.50 more around $3.50, regardless, still cheap (I guess things used to costs $1.50 here, not so much anymore...)

Anyways I digress, as for my burrito, at 2:00am so drunk I could hardly stand on my own it was the greatest thing I've ever tasted.  Now I would honestly like to believe this burrito has the potential to be that good at anytime during the day and *gasp* even sober.

note to self: now that you're remembering to get a bottle of wine while searching for a place to eat, also carry a corkscrew

It was a crappy day for many reasons, so we decided to see "Burn After Reading".  We had an hour to spare, so headed to streets with food.

Chuck's smelled great this afternoon, and not wanting anything chi-chi, we stopped in.  Ribs and crabcakes.  Can we open a bottle?  Sure!  Had to run out for a corkscrew while waiting for the food, humoured by the terrible effects of the new Knight Rider on the TV.

Ribs: Incredible.  Fell off the bone--so tender that even some of the bones were probably edible.  One of the few ketchup-based sauces I liked--not too sweet, almost tamarind-like without the harsh nose effect.  

Crabcakes: good.  Crispy.  A little mushy for my tastes, but good none-the-less.  Served with shredded lettuce, tomato slices, and tartar sauce.

Order, pay, then sit.  Food delivered when it's ready.  

5 ribs and 2 crabcakes: $15 with tax, +$3 for the tip jar.  Friendly people, incredible food.

YUM

The movie was good too, although we probably laughed louder than anyone else.

UPDATE: awesome wings.  We had them to go (less than $9 for 14 wings).  Love this place.

I like this Urban Outfitters best because of the bargain basement. Even though I ususally don't find anything I love to dig around down there. 

It's really close to the Harvard Square stop so I can't resist making a pit stop every time I visit the area.

Co-workers took me to Sharky's and they were telling me how GREAT the place is.  I didn't realize Sharky's is of the Rubios, Baja Fresh, La Salsa genre.  Given that I think La Salsa and Rubios are pretty good, I don't really understand why Sharky's is in business.  They were pretty busy at lunch time but nothing stood out to distinguish them from any other Mexican grill.  The Taco salad I got was more expensive than Taco Bell or Del Taco who prolly do a better job.   Oh well....

I came here for HARD Haunted Mansion 2010. I went both days.

The event was the most dangerous event I've ever been to. I'm not going to kick off any stars because of how the event was held though, this is a review on THE SHRINE - which is what a lot of other reviewers here need to realize.

It's huge! There's a balcony that was used as a bar. I wouldn't know how good it was because I'm not 21+ but it seemed like everyone was enjoying it. There was tons of room for people to sit down while being gone off Ecstasy or high out of their minds.

The stage that they set up inside was pretty big. It was pretty decent, and it's LOUD. It gets really hot inside, which was gross - but it was fine with me.

The outside stage was huge as well. If anybody ever wants to go to a HARD here, avoid the outdoor section as much as you can! It's hell. And you'll never be able to get back inside.

Other than that, this is a good place to hold events like this. They just need to work out HOW they hold the event because I almost died of dehydration.

The falafels at Sunshine Deli are perfect - golden brown, good-sized and well-done. Mmmmm...I used to buy 3 or 4 and eat them out of the paper bag.  The falafel plate, which comes with hummus, tabbouli, dolmas, and picked radishes, is also delicious or if you need something more portable, the wraps are great. I don't eat meat, so I've never tried the shawarmas, but meat-eating companions have attested to their tastiness.  

This is an ideal lunch place, centrally located on Bancroft, right across Eschelman Hall. Get your falafel plate, wrap, or paper sack to go, sit on the benches in Lower Sproul, and watch people practice the Soulja Boy dance. Good times.

I haven't been back to this place in a while, but by god, I hope it still stands. Before Sunshine Deli, this used to be a boba spot. Oh, the fickle palates of the Cal populace.

I love that they're always changing the flavors, so it's like an adventure each time you come!  Don't be shy about asking to sample the flavors  :)  They recently added "Sex on the Rooftop" as a tribute to the sex-capades at the USC campus this past week.  Love a place with a sense of humor!

I always go for the tres small -- super small -- size, and it's just the right amount to satisfy a sweet tooth without over-doing it.

Service is friendly, prices are super low, place is always really clean.

I'd give this place 5 stars plus a heart if I could because it reminds me of Yogurt Park in Berkeley  :)  It's like having a little piece of Cal here in LA!

*Note: may be a biased review since I was an employee

*Note 2: Christina B. mentioned the free drinks deal with the deli order. That was our beginning promotion because we had a lot, and I do mean A LOT, of cases of the plastic Arizona bottles. We pretty much just wanted to get rid of them, so that's why they came with the drinks. It's a nice promotion, but until we get a lot of cases for a really cheap price, I don't know when the next free drink will be.

*Note 3: We've had some people ask about all the deli charges. Basically it comes down to this: If it's a cold sandwich, it's just $4.99, no tax. If you order anything hot, we gotta tax it. The cheese, for 75 cents more, is not taxed. (They've been meaning to get a new deli sign and I keep telling them to make the cheese charge a little more prominent)

Pros:
- A great deli. If you get anything on a roll, it will definitely fill you very quickly. The chicken sandwich is a must. They even sell roasted chicken either by the whole or half and those are delicious too.
- An eclectic mix of drinks. I love the Looza nectar and the very random soda bottles.
- It sells produce that gets delivered M-F.
- It's very convenient for those who don't want to go far to Safeway and don't want to spend tons of money at Whole Foods, Andronico's, or Berkeley Bowl.
- One banana will not cost you 75 cents on your way to school or work in the morning.
- They are in the process of fixing the shawarma machine.
- There is a really cute cashier who works there and is very friendly. If you're short a penny or two, she will let you go. (I think this is where the biased part comes in. *ahem*)

Cons:
- Some of the items sell at retail price, not at a nice discounted price that you can find at the big companies like Walgreens or Safeway. The cereal boxes are at least $4.00 and as high at $6.00.
- Sandwich prices? Sure, $6.00 for a hot sandwich (not including tax) and the extra 75 cents for cheese may be a lot to some people, but take my word for it: order it on a roll (since the bread fills you up quickly) and you will see how much you can eat of that whole sandwich.
- No seating. For now anyway.

We're getting good business; people like our deli and they like our convenient location. We may be getting the liquor license at some point and I hear from those who shop at Fred's on University, they stock really fun and an eccentric mix of alcohol.

P.S. They are going to keep the Rexall sign as a part of history. The place that was there before Sam's actually wasn't even Rexall; it was called Blue Heaven. At and some point before that, there was a soda pop diner called Foley's... thus the name of the deli.

Why do I keep coming back here?  It's really not bad, but it's really not too awesome, either.

Pros:  
Really great service.
Dolcetto Salad - Love this!
Lobster Ravioli - decent
Spaghetti meatball - bland sauce, meatballs decent
Mama's meat sauce - decent
Super fast italian comfort food.

Cons:
Super fast italian food = packaged sauces
Satisfying, but not great.
Pricey for 'fast food' at 10 bucks a plate of pasta
Lots of kids in this location ALL the time.  Love kids, but for some reason it's always super rowdy in here.  Ok for a quick pit stop due to lack of choices in U-Village

Well, I hate to downgrade a restaurant but Raven Grill, you disappoint me with your Sunday Brunch.  You do get props for touting your bloody Mary as "Houston's Best Bloody Mary."  A bold statement and your drink is good.  Too bad the rest of the limited brunch fare was not.

I had the chicken enchiladas with the fried egg.  I knew it was a risk and being true to form, I lost on the bet.  The presentation of the dish was like a prison slop tray of food versus what should have been something unique.  Covered with sauce, cheese and a goopy fried egg, this dish disappointed me.  What was worse is that I kept thinking about it and 24 hours later, I have come to the conclusion that it was just plain nasty.

The eggs benedict is institutional too.  Store bought English muffins, lunchmeat and poorly poached eggs with the addition of ancho grits and fresh fruit???  What is the chef thinking?  

I heard from the waiter -- who looked like he had quite a long night BTW -- that the quiche and the French toast are the best choices for brunch....Too bad for us they were out of both.  

Try another spot for brunch or order off the non-brunch menu if you find yourself there on a Sunday.
Like eating a homemade quilt made of biscuits.

I don't know much about the selection, but they have a good assortment of used bikes for sales and the staff is helpful, knowledgeable and friendly.  Overall, the best homely feeling bike shop I've been to in Boston.

Hm... Oh right I had the burnt caramel with banana cookie and chocolate bits. 

The ice cream was nice but came out a little soft. Perhaps the heaters that were running that day wanted to heat up the freezer too!

It's nice that there's wifi and a place for students to study but it was kinda awkward to stand in the store licking my ice cream while some folks were sitting at the table with empty cups and such. Sharing is caring!

PS This place very much reminded me of Bi-Rite and Humphry Slocombe in SF.

Great movie theater, beautifully designed and restored. The screen is one of the best in the city and the digital project and sound are crystal clear. 

**Warning - the staff are pretty much jerks. There is no coffee in the theater and a Starbucks next door. They forced tons of people to dump their coffee after they bought tickets. Second thing was that they let people in with bottled water even though they sold bottled water inside but not with coffee. 

***Warning to students - make sure you and your friends bring your student ID. Even if you friend looks 17 they won't give you the student rate without it. I saw them do this to the couple behind us. It was clear that the other girl was a college student but the woman in the booth just wanted to be a bitch.

Flour will be the death of my weight watchers success!!

I love everything here- the soup, the delicious fresh sandwiches, the cookies, the sticky buns, the homemade oreos.. I mean, the list goes on. Completely worth the occasional points splurge! It's a welcome addition to the kendall lunch scene.

Honestly I prefer to call it the Hyatt Sport Club, not because it makes it sounds more prestigious, but because it exactly explains the location and quality of execution. 
I enjoy working out there every single time, especially in classes: professionals trainers, clean and new equipment and fresh air inside the building. The gorgeous Pool with cabanas and three different sounas is literally a state of art. I can stay in the club for hours.
The whole Club is dedicated for a healthy dynamic living style: Isn't that awesome?

In the years since I've graduated, I've only been back on campus a handful of times, mostly to do with figuring out a career (career counseling and meeting with my college advisor--and he thought he was rid of me after I'd graduated, ha!). The most recent time I was at Brochstein Pavilion was for the Zadie Smith reading, which almost inspired another crisis, as I contemplated becoming a writer. Never mind that the last time I wrote any non-Yelp-related items was for a writing class I took in New York, which taught me that I'm not in touch with my emotions enough to be a writer (write about past experiences under the guise of fiction? erk). 

People kept telling me about how the campus has changed, pointing to the Brochstein Pavilion. It's most often spoken of in a positive light. I can understand it. It's an all-glass building, with tables outside on the perimeter. The tables inside include normal-dining-height levels, though the chairs are of the sort you might see at an outdoor wedding (horizontal strips of wood for the backing), as well as those at knee-level with blue-winged chairs, which call to mind a Jetsons-era airport lounge. The food is from Salento, which closes earlier than the Pavilion, with paninis, empanadas, coffee, and the like. Again, the setup of the Salento as a circular free-standing white (as with the rest of the interior)...thing is futuristic airport-esque, though we're probably not calling them airports in the future--hoverports, anyone?

The positives are also what makes Brochstein Pavilion three stars. Technically, it's in the middle of campus, if you consider the Greenbriar lot/guest parking ($1/day) at one end and the North colleges at the other end. It'd really be more central if it was stuck on top of the statue of Willie, which I imagine would be super futuresque--a rotating glass building on top of a statue. And, I need to reiterate this: Brochstein Pavilion is a GLASS BUILDING. Rice students are not hothouse flowers. They don't flourish in the sun. How are they supposed to maintain a ghostly pallor if they study in a glass building? Not that the hoverport chairs and wedding tables are conducive to studying. And, if students are exposed to the sun, they can't lose track of the passage of time. "Oh, look, the sun's gone down. Time to head home." Study FAIL. Literally. 

Okay, so maybe a building that promotes discussion and socialization isn't all that bad, but I still take umbrage with how at odds it is with most of campus. Damn you, change! And, kids, get off my lawn!

On one of my many excursions to destroy my liver I once overheard a woman talking about her love life with one of  her girl friends. She told her friend that her current lover was " Not the best, but certainly the biggest" she had ever had.  
    Those words are my sentiments about Koronet's pizza. It is your run of the mill New York slice in terms of flavor and cheese distribution but it compensates for that by being friggin HUGE!!. Easily bigger than your head you will be able to eat one slice but any attempts at slice number two should be avoided unless you are planning on passing out somewhere real soon. At only 3.25 a slice Koronet's will fill your fatten your belly with minimal damage to you wallet.

Kams is a great bar to get fine beer and have a quiet discussion with another person. The atmosphere is a mixture of quiet pub and modern cocktail bar. The beer and spirits list does not leave much to be desired. One of the best brews I tried was actually named after the last stone placed in arches during their construction. This name and beer took me on an intellectual ride to the sixteenth century as I imagined elaborate arches and the people of those times. Another beer that I tried had the word natural right in the name! 
And should it be that you desire more than fine beer and atmosphere, the women that frequent KAMS are a mixture of beauty, novelty and sophistication. My first visit I was overwhelmed with the avant-garde way the women dressed. It seems that the newest styles are all about minimalism, an art movement I very much appreciate. 

Overall, my experiences at KAMS have always been memorable, and I suggest anyone who can go to KAMS should.

For me personally, this is the definitive cheesesteak.  Make sure to get the mustard blend.

I've been to this location a few times and never had problems finding a seat, but then again I only go on weekdays.  The one on Westheimer is larger, and gets very crazy when the Longhorns make it to the NCAA playoffs.

*sigh* What to say... You're "A-OK" but definitely not great. 

Pizza is pretty damn good. I like their Maui Zaui in particular. But dear god is that stuff expensive for what you're getting. I recently did pizza at a student org event and it cost like $62 for 3 pizzas, and that was *with* $9 worth of coupons. Oy! I'm a student! I'm broke, don't do that to me! Think of how much alcohol that could have bought me at a bar! lol. Seriously though, spending approx. 20$ a pizza is too much. 

Also, they no longer serve Smirnoff ice. I know I suck for liking that stuff, but I do! So I miss it. They also no longer serve a hard cider. So you're stuck with beer or beer. And I think they have wine still, but I honestly didn't check. Try the beer with the Orange Slice dude that looks like a deformed Raisenette on top of it...It's pretty light and "fruity" hehe, the "breakfast beer" as the guy called it. 

They do deliver on campus so that is pretty cool. And they definitely have alcohol and us students appreciate that. It's usually pretty quiet and empty even though it's in Price Center (I mean at the lunch rush there's a line, but once that disperses you're good). So you could actually study and drink in peace here.

BROOKLINE LUNCH ROCKS BREAKFAST!! (been a few times now)

I finally decided to give this dinky dive a try for breakfast. My wife had mentioned it a few times, but we never took the time to go check it out. I wonder why they don't call it Brookline Breakfast, since they seem to be more known for their breakfast than lunch.

As it turns out, today was a rainy Friday morning at about 9:30am. Walked right in, picked a seat, nice young man came and took my order, and I kid you not in 7 minutes was back with my food.  It was delicious and CHEAP! 2 eggs and bacon, with home fries for $3.75???! Yup!  Home fries were good and greasy, bacon wasn't all crunchy (I like soft bacon), and the eggs were perfect.

The place was clean, and had kinda weird paint on the walls (designs), and the enormous a/c unit hanging above the entrance looked like it was a lawsuit getting ready to happen at any moment.

I don't know if I'd be so impressed if I had to wait outside in a line, or if I had experienced slow service, both of which other Yelpers have mentioned. I guess I'll only go on weekday mornings, and avoid weekends.

Oh, I did meet the owner lady and her baby who was providing us with screeching and yelling child-made background music. Owner was very nice to me.

Warning: Home Plate does not serve pitchers of beer. If they did, I'd give em the full five stars.

Hearty, quality burger on campus? At last. Somewhere to dine where you don't feel like you're on campus is always a good thing. I'm all for the quality factor in which Home Plate is quite presentable. Flat screens everywhere, seating upstairs, patio, good place to hang. Almost there... now if they could get their liquor license to serve pitchers of beer, it's a sports bar on campus we've waited for all along.

I am not from Chi-town and I have never heard to this place. But my friends who are from the south side were commenting on their delicious fried chicken. So, I decided to give it a try. 

Their chickens are made to order, so it takes about 15 minutes for the food to be ready. If you are on a hurry, this is not a place to go. It tastes pretty good and not as greasy as I thought it would be. But I still don't get why they have a slice of sandwich bread under the chicken. I wish they have rustic rolls or corn bread instead. Since I didn't know what to do with it (I don't eat sandwich bread), I used it as a paper towel to soak up all the excess oil. It turned out to be very handy.

Overall, I would say Berkeley Thai House is good, but not great.

The night we visited the service was excellent - glasses never went empty and dirty dishes did not languish on the table.

The food was acceptable although a bit more pedestrian than is my taste.  To someone who does not consume Thai food regularly, I am sure their preparation would be considered to be quite flavorful, however to me, most of it tasted bland.

We ordered chicken satay, green papaya salad, beef salad, yellow chicken curry and organic pumpkin curry with tofu.

The satay was unlike any that I had ever had - this isn't to say it wasn't good - it was just different.  The standard peanut sauce was replaced by a sweet sauce reminiscent of jam.

Both salads were quite good, although the beef salad lacked any cucumber which is normally part of this dish.

The curries were the major disappointment of the meal.  In Thailand, pumpkin curry is generally too spicy for foreign tastes.  At Berkeley Thai house, it was quite flavorful but had no heat whatsoever.  It tasted more of coconut milk than of curry.  The same can be said of the yellow curry - although this is generally a fairly mild dish.

For pudding we had sticky rice with mango and fried banana with coconut ice cream.  Both were quite good.

I would return here to eat if I were in the area, but I would not make a special trip.  Although I don't know much about the restaurants in Berkeley outside of the "Gourmet Ghetto," I am quite certain I could find better Thai.

Kimchee Fried Rice with spam and Kimchee Ramen. 
A cheap kimchee fix you can't argue with.

I get that the name is a pun. I get that this seems to be a sandwich place and that the coffee is, at best, incidental.

But shouldn't a name stand for anything anymore?

Because my coffee was really weak this morning. TWO STARS!

I finally had the opportunity to check this place out with my friend, George and it did not disappoint.  

The first thing I will say is that it wasn't so much a "beergarden" than a spacious bar with lots of outdoor seating under umbrellas.  But no matter.  This place was exactly what the doctor ordered after an hour's bike ride through Central Park's loop.

Harlem Brewery had an extensive beer selection including few of my favorites, Delirium Tremens and Ommegang Hennepin, all in it's proper glasses.  A very nice touch that you don't find very often in Manhattan!  They also had a wide array of selections on the food menu including chicken schneitzel but I opted for the turkey burger and sweet potato fries.  They were both delicious.

Now for ambiance... What a fun and vibrant place!  Harlem Tavern is a great thing to have happened to revive the neighborhood.  I will definitely revisit with or without my bike and try the schneitzel next!

Top Dog has the best selection of hot dogs in the Bay Area, and their prices are quite good. I'd check them out if I was going to cater an event.

I have bought uncooked hot dogs from their stores to grill at home. $7.50 gets you 6 dogs and buns, and the per-dog price goes down if you buy in 25-30 dog packs.

Went to Eddie's for breakfast and was very satisfied with the deal.  Asked for 3 blueberry pancakes.  I can't remember the last time I had pancake that large... each was as big as a plate it was served on, and thick in height!  And these were very sweet cakes which came with real fresh made butter spread (churned, not out of a frozen stick).  The sausage was decent too.  The place had a sign up about 65+ years in business.  They follow the routine.  Unlimited coffee refills?  I got next! Only drawback: cash only.

I first checked out Melba's when it had just opened. The food was OK, but not great. The staff however was so gracious and friendly that I grabbed a few friends and we returned a few weeks later. This time, I was pleasantly surprised. Have you ever even heard of barbecued meatloaf? I hadn't, but I'm happy that I tried it. Delish! The restaurant has a nice vibe, friendly, but still a little exclusive. Just the way I like it!

On Friday night, I wanted something cheap and good, so we hunted down the Calbi truck.  

We had to make the comparisons to Kogi, so we ordered:
-kimchi quesadillas 
-veggie burrito 
-beef and chicken taco

The food was pretty tasty, but Kogi is still better and the portion sizes are bigger. I'd give Calbi 3.5 stars and I would try it again, but nothing makes me do the happy dance like Kogi.

I am not Chinese, but I have been fortunate to have eaten good Chinese food in San Francisco, Chicago and China. Mary Chung's food to me is very authentic and so good. They make their own raviolis and wontons and they are super. I never had anything there I did not like. The food can be hot, but we love hot. The only problem I have with Mary Chung is that we ALWAYS go there. One day we went to Tu y Yo Mexican restaurant in Somerville and that was a nice change, but of course we are back to Mary. The Shrimp Wonton Soup is exquisite. I made some myself. Lots of work. Very good, but I still think Mary's is better. We like the wait staff too, especially Alice, who will help you choose food. If Alice says it's "spicy" - beware. If you order anyways, she'll bring you lots of napkins. One of our friends swears by the Sunday Dim Sum. I'm going to try that soon. We always go evenings, about every 2 weeks so we are among the regulars.

We went to a pool birthday party here and drank until the wee hours and almost crashed if it weren't for a reservation at another hotel.  The courtyard here is immaculate, with almost all native California plants.  The pool area has a big screen playing a children's movies while it has a soft salted water without clorine.  The rooms are spacious, beautifully appointed in that Mexican Spanish Southwest decor and the vibe is like a spruced up modern Spanish ranch.  We had a terrific time, but don't expect to get out of here without emptying your pockets.  What I didn't like was the nickel and diming of your pocketbook:  $9 amenities charge?  $17 for parking?  You can park across the street at UCSD for free on the weekends.

Best curry I have ever had! Today was my first visit and I had the Green Jungle Curry with Beef on the lunch special....it was soooooo good! It had big chunks of eggplant, red peppers, crispy green beans and tender slices of beef. It came with a choice of rice (white/brown) and a nice crispy salad with a yummy sesame ginger dressing all for $6.95! This is def a new favorite place for me and its super cute as well. Pretty chandaliers, bird cages and empty frames on the wall. Daisy Mint I love you...

I have heard about this place and finally checked it out yesterday (Friday evening). This place was pretty kick ass.

Located under some stairs is a small bar run by graduate students and alumni volunteers. Beer was pretty cheap, 95 cents for a lone star.

Now I'm not sure what size the beers on tap come in. I went to a BCM function so I think they made the cups smaller, since BCM people could drink for free. No matter what, cheap beer is cheap beer.

I just think the main reason I liked this place was because my college didn't have anything like this. I'm sure other schools have their own bars as well and it's probably not a huge deal to people but since this was my first experience I thought it was great. Looking over the website they also have soda, water, and chips all for cheap.They stay open til 2am during the week and Sundays 7pm-2am. Nice way to start off the week.

I could see myself swing by for a quick couple. There was a nice mix of college/alumni so I didn't feel out of place not being an Owl. Although I do own a Rice hat so maybe next time I'll wear it.

The Local is a good place to go when you want to watch a game, hang out without dressing up, and drinking a reasonably-priced pitcher of local beer. The bathrooms are astoundingly clean, and the pin-ups are much appreciated (my favorite is Brad Pitt). The outdoors area is really nice, and the taco truck out back serves delicious drunk food. The bartenders are relatively friendly, even if you're not a beloved regular. Great specials too.

One caveat--the reason why this review is 3 stars instead of 4. Upon a recent visit to The Local, I happened to glance over my tab before I tipped and paid. There were multiple drinks on it that I hadn't purchased. When I brought it up to the bartender, she seemed unsurprised but took them off quickly. I just checked my debit card, and realized that she did herself a favor by adding a few dollars onto my tip. If I had tipped her poorly, I might understand, but a 20% tip seems reasonable to me when all you're doing is filling up pitchers. Regardless, make sure your check is accurate. End rant.

I was uber excited to shop here and made a friend meet me after work so that we could get our cardio on.  I'd heard through some trusted folks that I was getting my hopes up too high but I'm an optimist and I did what I do best, looked forward to my highly anticipated trip.

It may be that I checked out the website too much, or maybe just envisioned the pieces available differently but I will say that the concepts and selection were not to my liking.  I saw a thing here or there that was OK but nothing really jumped out at me.  After about an hour, I fell in love with a simple dark coat with faux fur lining.  Cute little toggles, with a zip up and button overlay.  My gigantic bewbies make it hard to find a coat that looks good, does the job of keeping me warm and not looking like a top heavy wale.  Yeah for my new coat.

I didn't find the staff to be impressive in any way.  There were no rude glances or remarks but there wasn't even a single "do you need help finding anything".  At some point, I reached for something off of a rack and the entire rack fell down.  I went to let a group of staff know who were standing by the fitting rooms and they said they would fix it.  As I was walking away, one of the girls said "oh, thanks for letting us know".  If it wasn't for that one thank you, I would have been a little perturbed.  Good save girlie, good save!

My gal pal went to the Southcenter location and came back locked, stocked and loaded with oodles of goodies.  She's shopped now at both locations and said the selection was different.  I've witnessed some of her purchases form the SC H&M and they've def. got some cute stuff so it looks like I'm going to have to fly south on my next venture for fashion.

I love the atmosphere here! They also have really good lunch/brunch choices. The regular menu also has a wide variety of choices - I had a hard time choosing what to order! I ended up going with a mediterranean wrap, which was excellent and just the right amount for lunch. I've also been here for dinner once and ordered one of their pastas - it was perfectly flavored and I had enough for leftovers the next day!

I've been here a few times and have not been disappointed. Recommended!

AVOID AT ALL COSTS! YOU WILL BE RIPPED OFF!

Absolutely, positively DO NOT go to this shop. You will be completely and totally ripped off. Somehow they inflate a $200 fix into a $1100 job. Unreal. 

AVOID!

Gosh... such high marks for poor and rude service.  They've got a prime location considering they are in the middle of the center.  Location is probably why they get so much business.  If they had an outskirt-of-the-center location they wouldn't be so packed.  The food is acceptable, but the service isn't.  That is why I give them 3 stars for just "A-OK".  

The service, mind you, even though they weren't busy, was really offensive.  Employee was holding back the urge to roll her eyes at me.  I wasn't overly pushy, slow, or rude to warrant such a reaction.  

Their saving grace from being given 1-star... their European-style baguettes, palmiers, and mango-flavored cake which are very good.

I went here for the first time last week upon recommendations from two of my good friends, and couldn't have been more pleased! It's a cute little Aveda salon in Pasadena, and everyone that worked there was super friendly. 

I have naturally curly hair (as does one of my recommending friends), so I felt pretty good about having one of their stylists with curly hair working on me. And she did a great job! She gave me a partial highlight, and the color turned out gorgeous (if I do say so myself). She also gave me a cut and blow-dry, both of which were fabulous...it's probably the best cut I've had in years, and when she styled it, it actually looked GOOD (which can be hit-or-miss at salons...)! This place is SO my new salon!

As for the parking situation, I really must say it was frightfully easy...it's just street parking! Seriously, don't get your panties in too much of a bind over this one...it's not that bad. I'm not sure what "lot next door" is that Nicole B. is referring to, but I'd say don't mess with it.
CLOSED! What a shame. Soon to be a "What the Pho" vietnamese restaurant.

awesome chicken and waffles! the restaurant has a beautiful decor and has a wonderful atmosphere.  the fried chicken is crispy, has a light batter that is seasoned to perfection - the waffles were crispy and fluffy, served with a yummy strawberry butter.  you must try this place if you haven't been there yet!

Way more convenient than trying to find the always-moving Ike's in the City! Followed the detailed directions of yelper Megan L. (thanks, Megan!) and found the cafeteria without a hitch. I called our order in thinking that it would be busy at  close to noon on a Saturday morning. Walked in around 11:20 to pick up the order I called in 10 minutes prior and was instantly handed my sandwiches. No lines, no fuss, no nothing! Now that is an experience in itself as I have waited over an hour for Ike's in the city.

Now...on to the sandwiches! Love Triangle-a vegetarian's dream come true! Honey mustard, bbq sauce, different kinds of cheeses...nom nom nom!! I will be back for more! Also had  a sandwich with red pesto (can't remember the name) which was also heaven-in-my-mouth.

Ike's just never fails to please me and I like the fact that I can now have Ike's without a) having to travel all the way to the city b) having to wait in an insane long line c) having to go on a wild goose chase to find out what kitchen in The Castro Ike's cooking at. : )

p.s. always order your sandwiches on Dutch Crunch-you won't regret it. Promise!

The food is cheap here, although the portions are relatively small so I feel like I have to order more and thus end up spending more.  The rolls and entrees are just OK - the main pull for Tako Sushi is the location right near campus & relatively cheap prices (especially the student lunch special).  I used to come here sometimes in between classes, but rarely went out of my way to eat here for dinner, unless someone was visiting me and wanted cheap sushi.  Overall, Tako Sushi is not bad...2 1/2 stars for food quality, plus that extra 1/2 star for cost effectiveness.  And it's a heck of a lot better than the sushi at GBC...

Bears Lair is definitely a Berkeley experience.  It's probably the best place to watch sports.  It has a lot of TV's for a Berkeley bar, and every TV usually is a different game or sport event.  

On busy days, like Cal football games or March Madness, things can get hectic.  Room is spare, and it can be a hassle to get from point a to point b with a pint in hand.  Just use your reflexes, and you can do it.

The people provide the atmosphere though. It can get REALLY fun during a close game or during March Madness.  People cheering, fans screaming, high fives and tipsy people, what else do you want?

I've had the food a few times, and it's pretty decent to.  Sometimes you get so lost in the beer, that you forget how good bar food compliments it perfectly.

I've had so many great college and post college memories here that I can't give it anything lower than a 5 star.  The people are usually friendly, and its a nice break from the busy hub bub and stress that Cal can bring.  Just chill, relax, and drink a beer.  Good times.

Went to the Volcano to meet up with some birthday girls on our 2nd night out in Houston.  I can't remember much about it (since we went to the Marquis first) except that it seemed to be a reasonably good bar.  There were friendly people to chat with and the bartender was quick and made a good drink.  It got a little packed as the night went on though, making it more difficult to stand around and drink in comfort.

#USC (neighborhood) pride. When I worked around there, this was the place for key copies, storage containers, etc. Always friendly--well, as friendly as you'd expect from a hardware store. Receives my ringing endorsement.

Not wanting to squander a rare lunch break in West Philly, Dan and I ventured in search of the best bar in the area. We ended up at City Tap House. This huge new space is beautiful, if weird. Located in the heart of University City, it has the potential to attract an annoying crowd. But we didn't deal with any of that on our visit. The staff here is great, and our bartender was knowledgeable about his beer. He was willing to pour samples and offered carefully thought suggestions.

The space is beautiful. The bar is probably the largest in the city, and City Tap house also boasts a sizable dining room with an open kitchen. To top it off, there's an great outdoor area complete with faux fire pits. Overall, the space is impressive and well used. even the bathrooms leave a good impression. 

Let's move on to the important part: Beer. The first time I visited City Tap House I was part of a record setting night: Most taps by a brewery in a single place at once. Ever. The brewery was Bell's and there were some great beers available. Still, on a normal day, the Tap House boast a quite respectable list. With the sixty taps available, they offer something for everyone and are simultaneously able to have more than a few rare and impressive drinks on tap. I had a black IPA, Hop in the Dark, from Deschutes Brewery, and, at the moment, City Tap House is the only place in the state that has beer from Deschutes. I cannot imagine the person (other than those who do not like beer at all) that is unable to find something enjoyable.

The menu here is impressive. While ordering, I was wrestling between several different choices, and there is a dinner menu available that I didn't even see. Because I believe the cheeseburger is the standard to which all other food at an establishment can be benchmarked, I ordered one medium rare with mushrooms and bleu. It came out quickly and well cooked. It was a huge burger, and in reality, I should have only ate half of it. Everything on the burger was high quality, with the bleu cheese as an incredible standout. While not my favorite burger I've ever had, I have no hesitation putting this on the highest echelon of burgers in the city. The thin, crispy fries perfectly round out the dish.

Dan ordered a pizza, and it came out perfectly cooked. The pizza is cooked in a brick oven, and the result is a crispy, thin pizza that, like the burger, is excellently crafted. Also like the burger, one pizza is more than enough food for one person. City Tap House offers several mouth watering combinations of toppings for the pies.

Bottom Line: Prices are on par with everything else in this area. The space is beautiful and huge, just like the tap list. The food rounds out this contender for the best bar in West Philadelphia.

Good addition to the neighborhood! Tried falafel plate and beef shawarma.  Both were very tasty although portions were small. Skip the spinach pastry/pie--it was dry with little spinach and overpriced.

Apple Tree is a big deal. When I meet people who used to live in my neighborhood and I want to explain my current location, it's the siren I reference first. Not "near Columbia," but "around the corner from Apple Tree." They've got everything and then some; it's the only place in the neighborhood that reliably stocks Morningstar crumbles (the Met supermarket down the street, meanwhile, is the only place that reliably stocks Morningstar bacon). You can take care of your staples here and dress it up with some of the pretty extras; they also take care of anyone shopping Kosher. The produce selection is uneven but the hummus, spice rack, & fancy cheese selection is a strong. They also have all sorts of odd household goods tucked around, so if you're in need of a paring knife you can get that. 

Prices are no worse than Morton Williams, actually they can be slightly better. If you're bargain-hunting, though, walk over to Met. 

Apple Tree recently knocked out a wall (the one that used to divide them from the dry cleaner that moved up the block a couple years ago) and they've expanded the deli area. There's now a huge amount of space to stand while you wait for your veggie burger (or: a huge amount of space to maneuver around people waiting for their veggie burgers) and today I noticed they've even added stools and a shelf-like counter. Apple Tree has been growing steadily for years (remember when it wasn't 24-hours? me either! but it wasn't!) and I'd go so far as to call them a neighborhood fixture. In a neighborhood defined by waves of temporary residents, that's a big deal.

I am a soup fanatic and for $6 I can satisfy my cravings with some of the best soups I've ever had! 

I also love how efficient this hole-in-the-wall is. It is a model for what it takes to be a  successful business. There is always a line at lunch, but the two workers inside the small red box keep waiting to a minimum. 

My only complaint is the hours. They are only open week days for lunch. If you share a similar love for soup, you are extremely limited to this experience if you can't try it out between 11:30am-2pm.

Cat's Cradle is a well known music and performance space for many independent bands from around the country, as well as, well known acts in the music world.

I've gone here to see some great local bands perform, like "The High and Mighties", in which case it's a big deal to perform here-- you're making a name for yourself when you've played at the Cradle on this level.

They've also hosted parties for eighties night which is so much retro legging-- jelly shoe wearing & skin tight stretch jean fun!  As you're walking down part of Franklin Street and into Carrboro on Main Street it's as if we've warped back into time.  I love eighties music, it evokes feelings of the greatness of life and being on top of the world!

True love as represented by flour, water, yeast, salt: the pita at Bella Pita. I don't know that I have ever experienced a more delicious pocket of bread, handcrafted while I waited.

I chose to enjoy my bella, nay, bellissima, pita in chicken wowshi form and topped it with cucumbers, onions, tomatoes, and cabbage. One half I topped with hommus and the very hot sauce; the other, with tahini and white sauce. I'd be hard pressed to pick a favorite, though the garlicky white sauce paired rapturously with the chicken and pita.

My dining companions swooned over their lamb pita, falafel pita, and fried cauliflower. Indeed, we were so sated by our true love pitas, we managed to steer clear of the DSW down the street.


A note on the wowshi and pita difference: the wowshi is almost calzone-like, cut in half with the fillings baked in. It allows you to construct two separate creations with the salad bar. The pita is your classic pita sandwich, and allows you the opportunity to fill one large pocket. Both are marriage material. 

A note on seating: 3 stools and a counter facing the street. You'd be wise to consider where you want to eat your magnificent concoction before venturing to Bella Pita.
My all time favorite spot in town for delicious, cheap, NY pizza. YUM!!!!
Tasty thin crust pizza. Near Stanford campus. Liked the pepperoni.

Thursday Night- wanted to go out with a friend.
I never tried Hookah before and we decided to search for
a place nearby my work (Santa Monica). At first, we saw 
'the Gypsy Cafe' which was across the street; i was treated
pretty rudely and the atmosphere wasn't what i wanted my 
first hookah experience to be; so i said "lets go across the street
it looks a hell more fun!" We checked Yelp for reviews, and it seemed
better or much-less the same as where we were.

The reason why i am giving this place 2 stars instead of 1 star
is because 1) i got the 'tuna melt' & it was amazing! 
Why i am taking 2 stars away is because:
1) Worst service in the WORLD! (took 20 min to leave!)
2) Bill was too high, i had to call a waiter to explain it to us
3) Hookah was cheap (my friend said) hurt our throat
4) Creepy old Arab men standing by counter in a line, just
'people watching'
5) Music was annoying, and nothing on TV's
6) Worst of all: I heard a worker tell the man who cleans the
tables & hookahs to "come here" and the man did not hear
the waiter, and so he said "hey, that table over there needs you"
and he made a face (prob. because the music was so loud!) 
& he said "THE BLACK GUYS" I was beside myself. I am mixed
but even if i wasn't that was so rude! & he was so loud, and said
it with the straightest face! My friend was like "did he really
just say that" WOW! 

Needless to say, we will find another hookah lounge! thanks
p.s.) we didn't tip at all! haha :)

This is the restaurant that singlehandedly opened my eyes to Asian food, back in 2000-2001 (hey, I was a freshman in college and I grew up in Eastern Washington). Phad thai and other staples are well executed -- but their curries leave something to be desired compared to other venues like Phuket. Any dish with peanut sauce comes overloaded with said -- and the sauce itself resembles peanut butter too closely...

If you're in the U-District and craving Thai food, go here. Otherwise, it's worth your while to drive to Phuket in Lower Queen Anne.

I was coming back from the airport after an exhausting business trip wherein I had had little time or inclination to eat (super stressful).  I was starved, and have been wanting to try this place after having seen a promising menu on-line.  Dehydrated and expecting a long workday (today), I chose against imbibing, deciding instead to gorge myself on nachos Garcia, broccoli and mushroom pizza, a cubano sandwich, molten lava cake, and pale ale bread pudding (the bf ate exactly 2/3 of all this).  The place was pretty empty and pretty, well, boring.  It was rather devoid of character or anything resembling charm.

The nachos were supposed to have veggie chili on them.  I saw maybe 1.5 teaspoons of that; it was mostly sour cream.  The pizza was mediocre, with approx. 1 tablespoon of toppings for an entire $12 pizza.  I ordered this arugula asparagus salad with it for like $9 that was wilted and had exactly 2 measly asparagus spears.  The cubano was pretty good.  I love pretty much any bread pudding, but this pale ale bread pudding was drenched in this savory rather disgusting sauce which killed it for me.  Nothing was presented with any sort of pride.

The service was distracted, but very sweet.  We ordered dessert from him and about a half hour later someone else brought it out just as he was about to hand us the bill (i.e. he forgot that we had ordered).    

Between the unreasonable prices, slow service, lack of ambiance, and dull food, I will not return and will not recommend it.

After 3 days of backpacking we were thrilled to head to the Euro Cafe.  The food, particularly the vegetable panini, was wonderful and the latte beats any of those chain coffee stores (you know the ones, I'm sure).  The service has been exceptional every time we've stopped by, including being given samples of superb Portuguese dishes, wine and port!  I'd recommend this restaurant to anyone who is hiking in the area as the best choice to be found!

So great! I love the vibe and the food! I really enjoyed the spicy fried potatoes and the bacon wrapped dates!!! Bacon can be wrapped in pretty much anything and taste good. There was a lot of tapas on hand. 

But warning: be prepared to wait for your dinner! But it's worth it!

I can only speak of my experience with the owner, Stephanie.  She was very unprofessional, finished my two sessions I had with her early.  This place is very expensive, and she should give me the entire half hour i pay for, not end it early.  The machine also was still wet from the other person who used it before me, DISGUSTING!

Java-Fi here!

Grab your books, study gear and study buddies and head over here for coffee and wifi (Java-fi). Great way to take a break from studying and to get caffeinated. The cafe is inside the Honnold Library on the ground floor!
Couches, cafe tables and regular tables... a very nice alternative to the library and even Starbucks.

A good place to get Vegetarian and Vegan food.  A+ for their pizzas.  OMG, the caramelized onion pizza is sooooo good.  They miss getting 5-stars for not serving alcohol and for being closed when they have shows at the club.  But on the other hand, if you're in the mood for a folk music concert, it's pretty cool that you can sit down for dinner there.  I've seen a good band or two.

I stayed there in 1998... Graduate students, post-doc, exchange scholars, a lot of foreign exchange students.  There are people stayed there for long long time, simply because it is cheap with all the essentials.  There are also people treat it as a temporary place to stay while they are familiarizing the area and know their options.  I would say, yeah, this is a place that people should at least try to stay a quarter or so, experience the dynamics, and then plan the move out.  When preparing to come to co-op, also prepare to have an open mind.

my favorite. soft, creamy, rich. perfection. they have new flavors every now and again and i believe pumpkin is now out!! 

they have tangomonium, pom, green tea, and original tart typically. All of them are fantastic and the quality is outstanding.

the fruit is fresher here than any other yogurt shop in my opinon!!

I take it all back. They dropped the only thing I could really eat from the menu, and even though it's made entirely from just a few ingredients that they have around for other items (and would really just involve dropping an ingredient from something they still make) the wouldn't make it for me.

I decided to avoid a "Five Easy Pieces" moment and left.

Synopsis: Yummy pizza & fresh veggies make it worth your while

This is the best pizza I've found in Cambridge!

The New Orleans Cajun can't be beat!  Fresh veggies, slightly spicy/salty sausage.... I'm drooling just thinking about it!  The sandwiches are great too!

Tip: Definitely use their online ordering system, or a site like foodler.com or order in person as the people who answer the phone are sometimes hard to understand...

Conclusion: Order the New Orleans Cajun online, you won't regret it!

Back in 1976 when I was first dined here, my baby sister and I had the best Steak Diana and i had my first cappucin,  The establishment was Butlers Terrace.  Cuisine was predominately french back then.  I recall the total bill set back  my late mom a weeks pay but that is how much she loved us and taught us fine dining. It was nice to see the array of celebs of the time some who still lived in the neighborhood.
Although it doesnt cost me a weeks pay to take 4 people out it is certainly not the same quality and if youre going to require proper dress code, at least provide the formal waiting service and find another distributor for your meat. The panoramic view  was never a big deal as other skyline restaurants have nicer views.  Stay downtown.

My cousins introduced me to this place when I was visiting LA once.  Best deal I've ever gotten for ice cream.

It's cheap, but delicious!  You can build your own ice cream sandwiches.  Pick the cookies and the ice cream for $2.  

I went classic the first time.  Chocolate chip cookies and vanilla ice cream.  The cookies are still warm and gooey on the inside but firm enough to keep from mushing up in your hands when you eat it.  The ice cream is soft enough to just bite into, unlike when you get an It's It from the ice cream man and the ice cream is super hard and you have to wait for it to thaw out.  Really good!
Great food, very efficient and friendly service.
This is truly the BEST ice cream in Boston. The list rotates daily, but if you can get there on a day when they've got burnt caramel, all will be right with the world. Great hot fudge too.

Hands down my favorite bar on campus.  Another 'older' crowd bar since it's no cover for 21+.  Though TWICE my underaged friend went and got the overage wristband.  Hmm.

Love this place, the bartenders were super cute, drinks were cheap if you went on the right night. Wed nights were always crowded b/c of 10cent wings (which I thought were pretty awful).  You can dance anywhere if you wanted, they always had really good cheesy dancable music.  Pool tables on the first level.  Photo hunt games on the upstairs bar area.  

Our favorite place to sit was on the 2nd floor front balcony - we'd sit right where we could see the entry door, but people's heads were cut off. We'd play this game if we thought guys had receding hairlines or not based on what their bodies looked like, it was awesome.  

Watch the stairs though!  There's a long stair case on the way up to the bar, then inside there's a couple of staircases to get up to the 2nd balcony level.  My friends and I have fallen many a time on our way down the stairs.  Oops!

It was raining and I hadn't eaten the whole day. I looked through the window and started salivating at warm, scintillating miso soup that seemed to say, "come in, come in." 

So I went in. I got my miso soup and ordered a ginger chicken dish with rice. The waiter forgot to get my tea, until towards the end, when I had already finished my meal. Since I used to host and wait at restaurants myself, I don't get peeved about such a minor mistake.

I really liked the decor. Its clean-cut lines and Zen arrangement was especially comforting on a rainy day. Otherwise, the food was okay. The ginger chicken could have used some soy sauce. What can I say? I love sodium! The tables were too close to each other. I sat next to a couple that fought the entire time. Talk about awkard!

It's convenient. It's relatively reasonably priced, depending on what you get. The food is mediocre. 

Overall, A-Okay.

Food was good, you get to make it yourself.  The first time I went to this place, I really liked it because of the novelty.  However, once I went to this place another time--for a creative night out--it really didn't get me going.  Despite all of he 'choices,' they all seem to be limited to either an asian or a north american style of eating.  I wound up being unimpressed the second time.  Also, the service could be better, and the menu could be more accurately priced--it's structured somewhat oddly.

I wish I could give a 3.5 rating. I am normally really placed with all Corner Bakery locations, but the last time I went to this location, I was really underwhelmed.

I went on a weekday morning, it wasn't incredibly busy. There was one person ahead of me in line, and pretty much everyone I looked at who was seated already had their food.

I ordered a bowl of oatmeal. And then I waited....and waited...and waited. After waiting 20 minutes,  (Yes, 20 minutes for a bowl of oatmeal), I walked back inside with my reciept and said "excuse me, I ordered 20 minutes ago" "you were order number 20?"  "um....no, I ordered over 20 minutes ago. I ordered oatmeal...I'm still waiting. Number XXX" and then the cashier and some other guy started scrambling around as if my oatmeal was going to materialize near the muffins. I walked back outside, sat down, and waited some more.

Ten minutes later, I had my oatmeal. And the bananas seemed a little...old.  No one apologized for completely overlooking my order. No one said a word.  I suppose if I was the kind of person who complained, I potentially would have gotten my meal comped, but that's just not me.

It's likely I will return, but the experience did leave a bad taste in my mouth. I just can't resist that oatmeal....

This could be an all time favorite. I had been several times for lunch but recently went for dinner. It was phenomenal. Everybody, all 8 of us, ordered something different and all of us had to share because we could not stop raving about the food. I had a tenderloin that was the most perfect.veggies great and some real tasty apps - try the Asian Dumplings - incredible! It is listed as pricey - but actually for the amount of food they serve it is very reasonable. The wait staff was very knowledgable and pleasant. Drinks were a very decent pour! Be prepared to settle in - this is not an experience you want to rush!

My dining experiences at the Blue Room have included a company holiday party, a romantic dinner, Sunday brunch with friends, and the weekday lunch grill on the patio.   The setting is nice whether it's daytime or evening and the food and service have always been very good.  

My only complaint is that when we arrived about 10 minutes early one time, they sent us away (the servers were all eating at the bar before the place opened) and weren't too nice about it.  I would expect that 10 minutes before a reservation, they would at least be ready to receive diners at the bar.  Oh yeah, the bar was occupied...

Being from Ithaca but living on the left coast hasn't reduced the power of Moosewood. I bought one of their cookbooks at a local bookstore and the check-out person started asking me all these questions about the restaurant. This has happened at least three times here. With good reason.

Moosewood is not 'fine' dining. It isn't fancy or fusion. It doesn't put on any pretensions of being something it isn't. It isn't going to satisfy your hunger for morels, truffles, fine wines, or foie gras. What it is is very well done vegetarian food in a remarkable atmosphere that makes you feel like you're having dinner with your family. It's warm and welcoming and, oh yeah, the food is really yummy. 

If you're staying away just because vegetarians can be annoying and preachy, well you're right, but they aren't at Moosewood! Being (mostly) a vegetarian restaurant is totally secondary to Moosewood being just a really wonderful place.

The menu is changed daily so I can't tell you what to get, but I think I've only been dissapointed once. Get the house dressing for your salad. Get whatever looks good fod dinner and desert.

Also check out their cookbooks. Once again, not fancy! This is food you can actually cook, without blowing your account, and will satisfy your soul.

I haven't been here in a while but it deserves a good rating just for the guy who looked like Tupac serving me wings.I guess from the previous comment Tupac has left, but he was a great guy. I'm also a fan of the nuclear or 911 wings. You know they are good wings when you start choking just by inhaling the aroma of the wings.
As I am fairly new to Austin, I only got to hit up the Dobie once.  And once was not enough!!!  The Dobie was exactly what Austin is all about, and it's return must happen soon.

Peter's Pub is a decent college bar, but without the "charm" of nearby Hemingways. Drink prices are low, but not the lowest in town, and the same generally annoying college crowd is there.  It's actually a nice place to be during the day, but at night it transforms into a not-particularly likeable crowded smokefest where you'll wait forever for a drink.

The drinks here are good, but the prices could be better.  You'll find pretty standard college fare.  The food is decent as well, it's pretty standard bar food.  Upstairs there is an area where live bands sometimes play or it can be rented out, with its own bar.  My experience is you'll get much better service up there.

BOTTOM LINE:  There are better places.  It's a pretty standard college bar, without all the charm.  Expect crowds, with loud loud music and lots of smoke.

This place is great!  They serve sushi that is excellently prepared and cheaply priced.  I've been many times.  Plus it's BYOB, so you can drink and eat cheaply.  We brought in a box of Franzia once and ended up doing "Boxed-Wine-Stands".  Anyway, the service is good.  It's definitely not 'friendly' in the "Welcome to Chili's, my name's Debby and I'll be taking care you tonight!" way, but it's very fast and responsive.  

I've started off many nights in Providence here, because it's a cheap way to go out, eat good food, and pre-game all at the same time.    

Also, the dragon rolls are awesome!

Orange King is a convenient and relatively cheap place to grab a burger by the U-District.  So many burger joints I leave feeling like I just ate a pound of grease, but at Orange King this isn't the case.  Also the fries always come out warm, crispy and just slightly salted.  I haven't had the teriyaki here, but my friends who have ordered it, were not so thrilled with the result, so I recommend sticking to the burgers.

Really not impressed, especially since this was where I had my first meal in Seattle.  Service was slow and then they got my order wrong on top of it.  I also think that $13 for the tiny salmon combo they gave me is a little pricey for the U-dist.

Ah I'm a little biased since I've only had their drinks and crispy chicken (no horror stories on the other food), which haven't really failed me. Okay here goes:

For the chicken, the difference between medium spicy and spicy-spicy is really big. Medium spicy doesn't even taste spicy, while spicy is really spicy (which I prefer). I don't order the chicken too much though since I don't crave it as much and can't finish it by myself unless I'm reallllly hungry.

For the drinks - pretty standard, however the drinks a sweeter than the Convoy version, which can sometimes take away from the tea flavor in milk teas. I mistook this location's ownership as the same as the convoy one, but it's not. It's owned by the people who own the regents location. Anyhow, the drinks are still pretty good. I definitely would recommend the taro milk tea and almond milk tea if you really want something sweet.

Service: IDK what it is, but I feel like this place is ONLY efficient if males are working. For some reason whenever there's only girls working, the service is pretty slow. I went here yesterday on my break and it was pretty backed up in terms of drinks, so I was actually LATE back to work! The girl who was working was pretty slow. I watched her and I couldn't believe it! Even when the was backed up before, when there were guys working -- even just a single guy -- the service was pretty quick. When it's mixed guys and girls, it moves pretty fast too.

The owner (I'm assuming it's the slightly older lady that I see there from time to time and was there on the first day it opened) is really sweet. She really cares about her customers, and that's really important. Whenever the wait is long, she apologizes, and she even makes the drinks really fast too! I swear she makes the drinks faster than probably the two girls working one time while a guy rang up the orders. I guess I'm also a little more biased in terms of reviews/ratings because of the owner, lol.

my favorite smoke shop. the staff is super friendly and super knowledgeable about all sorts of vessels. simply provide them with your criteria and they'll show you a bunch of options. I've purchased 3 pieces from them and each one has been great! they have a wide range of prices and a wide range of styles.

one guy even gave me some free wraps and a lighter. NICEST dudes. 

and, in case you're wondering, my pieces do have names.

Duke Long Bong McBighole (brother of Sir Swirly McBighole, who was born in the Haight)

Bubbly the Smoketopus

and

Kermit the Bong

Despite the fact that I live in New York, and should therefore be used to somewhat snobbish boutique sales staff, I was awed by the treatment I received at Clover. Here, perhaps finally, is the best example of Worst Sales Strategy I have yet encountered. For anyone interested in replicating:

My friend and I approached the store, as the sales associate watched. We proceeded to open the door (unlocked) and entered. As we did so, the sales person's small dog approached. My friend exclaimed over the cuteness of said dog and asked of what type it was. Sales person then retorted (with arms crossed and steely stare): "We don't open until eleven. You're going to have to come back later". I check my watch: it is 10:53. So, we leave. And have no intention of ever going back.

love the taste, texture and frosting of the cupcakes, although they're pricey for their size in comparison to sprinkles - but i prefer kara's "cake" over sprinkles...i'll definitely be coming back here, plus their CS is great :D

Yeah, "Steve's Mexican BBQ"...that's what she said. KIDDING.

ANYWAY, the portions are monstrous. I could raise a baby tiger with Steve's BBQ if I wanted to. I always order the beef or chicken bibimbap to-go, eat 1/3 of it before I go up two pant sizes, and then dump the leftovers in a pan to make kimchi fried rice that'll easily last me another two meals.

Don't get the barbecue chicken or beef, just get the bibimbap. They're essentially the same thing, same $7ish, but the bibimbap comes with more sides+a fried egg.

p.s. Since the bibimbap's $7.06, if you hand them $10 or $20 dollar bills, they'll give you exact change (including the 94 cents); if you hand them $8, they'll just take $7 :)

Gypsy's makes for great comfort food, especially since it is open so late. My current goal here is to try every pasta dish they have. The price is average (around 7 dollars) and the portions are very large. They are equivalent to two meals for me. The workers are very efficient and friendly.

I go to Gypsy's quite often, averaging about once a week, and have only been disappointed a couple. Some good pasta dishes I'd recommend are Frutti Di Mare, Tortellini Georgio, Penne Gorgonzola, and Capricciosa. The parmigiano cheese sauce is very good. 

I was disappointed by Chicken and Broccoli because the broccoli was just tasteless and in huge chunks. I also don't like their gnocchi, but that was the first time I ever had gnocchi, so maybe I just don't like gnocchi in general. I don't eat the garlic bread because it is chewy, plain white bread with a piece of garlic (I hate pure garlic) without butter.

So much better than going to Panera.  The turkey reuben is probably my favorite sandwich, and it is usually big enough to last me for lunch and dinner if I also get a bowl of the famous crab bisque.  Prices are great (~$6-8/sandwich) and portions are generous.  Definitely recommend of you're looking for a sandwich for lunch.

As someone who reflexively cites Seinfeld way too much, I knew it was about time I made the pilgrimage (of one block) to Tom's. And even though I know the Suzanne Vega song fairly well, for whatever reason the words from the Nick at Nite version about I Dream of Jeannie come to mind more readily than the actual lyrics.  ("Major Nelson works at NASA with suspicious Dr. Bellows...")

Anyway. I like this place! I should preface that (a) I love diners great and small and (b) I usually order from a standard repertoire of hard-to-mess-up diner foods that make me a difficult patron to disappoint. Ninety percent of the time I stick to the following: scrambled eggs, toast, bagels, fries, onion rings, cole slaw, grilled cheese, milkshakes. My arteries and I are on non-speaking terms.

The Broadway shake (chocolate and coffee ice cream) is really, really thick and good. They give you like a liter of it, too. My usual items are reasonably priced, but I can see how deviating to the entrees can get expensive. Other than the shakes, they're not doing anything revolutionary. Good stuff, but I suppose my standards aren't terribly high.

I am from Missouri, and you have got to Show Me... or something like that.

It's my understanding that the pit smoker used by Rack and Soul is from Cape Girardeau, Missouri. The chicken that has been smoked first, and then slathered with sauce and BBQ'd is the way I remember it from home. 

The sweet tea is nice, and so are the prices. Come with a friend, and the combo platter is a fantastic deal. I like the biscuits with honey. The asparagus is cooked nicely (just the right balance between tender and crisp).

Rack and Soul ain't perfect, but I like it better than any other BBQ place in Manhattan (for example, the bloomin' onion at one unnamed place on 23rd Street was so greasy that I puked, and this is ridiculous because I grew up eating stuff like that for BREAKFAST).

EAT EARLY (menu items dwindle as the day wears on) and EAT OFTEN (prices are fair enough to consider becoming a Rack and Soul 'regular').

It's not my local, but I've been making the trip when I've wanted BBQ over the past 2 years or so.

So......I don't usually venture past UWS but a friend who lives in Harlem suggested we try this place late Sat night for drinks. A neighborhood place, not many spots like this in the area, it was nice. Casual, yet cozy ambiance, decent wine section and cheese/meat choices, reasonably priced. The only problem was the service, it was a bit slow, our waitress who was also the bar tender was sweet but in general it seemed they were a bit understaffed. Other than that, it was fine.

Since my first review 18 months ago, I have been returning to Dr. Sherman for necessary work as well as cleanings. Dr. Sherman and his staff continue to give me outstanding professional care on every visit. And they are very caring people as well. As I said in my original review, Dr. Sherman and his staff are in a league above any other dentists who have ever treated me. Dentists don't get any better than this!

This is an indoor/outdoor restaurant & bar.  This place gets very busy and it's always full because the indoor section is very small, almost tight.  It's a first-come-first-first-served basis and it's not a server's job to be on the look-out for a table for you.  For what's on their menu, I can wait while drinking a Belgian beer while standing and I don't care how long as long as I'm not too hungry.

This is a beer place.  The beer menu is longer than the food menu.  Watch what you order on draft because two glasses can cost you $25. Good but pricey!:)

I always order the Back Abbey Burger (Turkey instead of Beef) that comes with a small portion of good salad.  Their fries are very similar to In-n-Out's, which is my favorite, so I always order the large one.  The fries come with several dipping sauces and I love all of them.

My friends and I always eat here.  It always helps when upon arrival, I do a short walk from front to back while checking out and picking two tables that I think are almost done.  I stand on one end of the room and one of my friends on the other end. We each order a beer and we watch those two tables like hawks.  It never fails.  That, plus the fact that we always eat there and tip well, so we always get served well:) That's just how it goes...

Check!

This is one of my favorite teriyaki on the ave.

The combo plates chicken/beef is a good deal at $6.00.
Yakisoba is greasy. Great for after drinking.
The servings are large and is good for two meals.
You order at the counter and they bring your plate to your table.

This place is never crowded. It's a hole in the wall but worth the trip.

If your in the area and need a good deal. This is a place to try.

The beer selection is amazing, the pretzels are delicious, and the fries are the best fries I've ever had. The service is very good; the servers always keep track of my table even when I move several times throughout the night. My only complaint is the price, which is a bit steep for beer.

Place is frikin awesome.  Come in around 11 p.m. if you are in the area cuz thats when the hot donuts are ready.  My favorite are the donut holes.  Those things are seriously addictive.  The smell just wafts right out of the place.  Once you take bite from that lil pocket of heaven you get this crispy coating from the freshly fried dough and then the inside just melts in your mouth.  Once in awhile tho you get a donut that is really greasy.  That still doesn't stop me from getting a donut because the good ones are just too good.

Focusing on bringing art to Seattle that will inspire discussion about contemporary culture, politics and art, the Henry is sure to offer interesting and experimental art (without purely going for shock value). The beautiful and architecturally interesting museum is a piece of work itself, and free on Thursdays.

Can I just tell you that the owner makes me want to eat ice cream. She is always super happy and seems to be on a permanent sugar-high. This is exactly who I want making my ice cream and then handing it through the little glass window. Aside from the awesome service the flavors and texture are heavenly. The varied flavors range from vanilla bean to Mexican chocolate (sweet and oh-so spicey) and the ice cream is so silky with no traces of ice. A beautiful hybrid of traditional ice cream and Italian Gelato. This is definitely exotic for the capital region. 

And even though I'm not 7 years old, I still love Blue Moon in a cone... :)

Cheers.  Moes.  The Drunkin Clam.  MacLaren's Bar.  All legendary bars in their own right, but fail in that none of them are in the Greater Lafayette Area.  Kirby's is our Cheers or Moes.  The perfect hole in the wall pub, with great drinks, and amazing food.  The portions are large, the fries & chips are homemade and AMAZING.  The best is that D makes it point to talk and get to know each of his customers that come in.  

Kirby's is a gem in the area, and my absolute favorite place to go.  Plus, if you are a cubs fan, this is the place to go.

Wow, like the other reviews state, get the fried goat cheese!! It was delicious! Just serve me up a whole plate of those, and I would be one happy woman. For my entree I ordered a pasta dish ( which I can't even remember which one) which was less than memorable. I appreciated the saving grace of freshly made pasta. Service was a little less than attentive and my lady friends and I waited impatiently and starving while we waited to place our orders.  I'm definitely up for giving them another try. Oh yes, make sure you try some of the homemade truffles, one word: decadent!

The BLAT is AMAZING!!! A-MAZING!!

The service has been great every time I've gone. It's not fast food, so give it a little time!

Just order a BLAT and thank me later. :o)

Came here for lunch on a weekday with my significant other and had the bibimbap with kalbi and brown rice with a side of dumplings. The bibimbap was delicious, highly recommended, the crunchiness of the rice suited well with everything else. A nice spin. The dumplings were a slight disappointment. Decent prices, total with tip and tax for 2 with a drink was about $25.

Nice setting, a bit different (modern) than your typical Korean restaurant. You order first at the register, sit down at one of the benches and they bring the food over to you. Overall a good experience.

Don't worry about looking for parking. There is underground parking (entrance located next door on Cordova) It is free if you get it validated.

OMG, this show was so beyond amazing, I don't even know where to begin! Even the little annoyances and hassles were well worth it to experience the bands and and immense energy and talent that is Rage Against the Machine. The Reeducation Camps were very informative and I hope that all the head-banging kids stopped there and learned something on the way to the mosh pits!

Yes, traffic was a byatch all along Exposition and Figueroa Streets but there were over 60,000 people packed into the L.A. Coliseum. Lots of security everywhere, which I found unusually reassuring only because so many people were in the pits-all three sections set aside on the field-and there were going crazy moshing.

Good vendor selections of all different kinds of foods and drinks and I even grabbed a bacon-wrapped hot dog inside the Coliseum, and after the show, on the streets. Yummy! But it was hot there and lots of people were obviously drunk. Still, once the first three acts were done (El Gran Silenco, Immortal Technique and Lauryn Hill), the melting of faces began in earnest! Rise Against was really impressive and I liked how Tim-the lead singer- talked about veterans and then sang a song about them. Muse was-as usual-grandiose but wonderful. They really have a great light show full of strobes and all kinds of special effects that is showy but their music is awesome too. Some people think Muse might have stole the show from Rage?

But then Rage Against the Machine hit the stage and it was MIND-BLOWING! Intense, powerful, life-changing rock that was played so perfectly. The mosh pits were going crazy! A fire was even started but quickly put out. I was so transfixed by the show that I had a hard time walking back to my hotel. Then I had to take a knock-out pill to get to sleep, I was so revved up from the show! Now that's 5 YELP STARS all the way!

Papa Del's is great! Senior year I lived across the street from here, so obviously I frequented it! They have a great area inside to sit down and eat the pizza, watch TV and drink some good beer! The pizza is pretty big and tastes great!
I've had a bunch of piercings done at Stiehl's when I was in college at IC. Dawn and Ron are fantastic body art educators and make you feel comfortable, whether it's your first piercing or your 50th.

I don't get why everyone is so obsessed with this place. The service is slow and not particularly outstanding in any other way and the food is like an overpriced Bertucci's. The popovers are tasty, but honestly they are overrated and everything else is just uninspired.

MM the burger i got was delicious. Avocado, bacon, cheese, the works. It was a huge burger too i couldn't finish it and took it home. The fries were beer battered, always which is always good. 

I didn't get to get any of the cheap beer for dinner cause it was finals week, but for sure next time!

I wish I could love Kerbey, but I can't. It seems they always burn my sausage or I just ending up having a sub-par breakfast experience.

It's super when they have their pumpkin pancakes and you can have a nice hot coffee, especially during the winter months (or winter-ish months), but other than that, I just keep on trying, perhaps its futile.

Wish I could dig.
