I love USC Credit before I graduated I was trying to get all my friends to join Jenni O i'm amazed by your comment Im currently dealing with a fraud situation because of Starving Student Movers who took unauthorized money from my account im dealing with the same ladies you dealt with i hope it doesnt go as bad as yours did or these 5stars will quickly go to none.

i came here for dessert and got a chocolate truffle. it was perfect..not too sweet. I probably would have tasted it more if I didn't eat this while drinking coffee from salento..This place is always crowded! Maybe I will try some "real food" next time..though the food looks like your typical american food..nothing special.

what a disappointment. I remember it when it was pho pasteur and the food was much cleaner and better tasting.

The basil and bean sprouts were NOT FRESH.

it's still cheap though but then again, I could get the same thing in LA for even cheaper and I wouldn't have buyer's remorse nor gas afterwards.

fart.

I like Dog&Duck because one of my favorite people has his annual birthday thing here, and it's just like him- laid-back, casual, and down with outdoor seating.  Also, I heart cider on draft, and Dog&Duck has it: Wood Chuck Pear and Granny Smith.  It's got ample parking, lots of indoor and outdoor seating, and it's never been too crowded for me to walk around.

Update: I ate dinner there for the first time yesterday.  The veggie burger was delicious, with American cheese and a wheat bun, and came with fries.  The fries are the fish-and-chips kind of fries, and were seriously delicious.  My mama would refer to them as "jam-up" fries, in fact.

With frozen yogurt so much the rage, it leaves me craving full fat, full flavor ice cream. 

At Toscanini's, the Hydrox cookie felt positively indulgent - creamy and rich and full of big chunks of cookie. A lovely respite, indeed, from the fro-yo lunacy.

This place is really a misnomer.  While it's called Vietnam Village Restaurant, it's staffed by Chinese people and serves mostly Cantonese-style/Americanized-Chinese food with a meager dose of pho and grilled meats over rice.  Not that this is a particularly bad thing, one should just have an understanding of this when walking in.  If you're looking for a fuller set of Vietnamese food, I would head down to Shattuck to the pho place beside the public library or better yet to Oakland.

As with most of the clientele in the Asian ghetto, most customers are students, and the prices reflect this.  The food is decent and served in fairly large portions - try the chicken and broccoli over rice as well as the minced beef with raw egg over rice.  Both are pretty solid, though the latter has a tendency to be a little too salty.  A good option in the Asian ghetto and generally better than the Mandarin House place on the other side.

It's pretty safe to assume that when you stay at the W, you'll be well taken care of. 

This is my favorite W. 

Tucked away on Hilgard, it's a little inconspicuous yet incredibly central. The staff is beyond friendly from the bar to the front desk to the pool to the Bliss Spa. 

I'd walk here from UCLA often for drinks or spa services and am always excited to return whenever I'm in town. 

Lots of times there are private parties, red rope and all. Swanky.

I love this salon because I have been Jenna's client almost 10 years.  I always look great when I leave her salon.  Her service is professional yet creative.  I never really have to tell her what to do.  Instead, she usually suggests cool hairstyles or colors that I've never thought of!  Besides, the salon's using an organic hair color line which is very nice.  It doesn't smell or stain my head.  The color is very vibrant and there are a lot of choices!  The prices are also fair.  I think they deserve every penny they ask for.  I highly recommend this salon because they know what they are doing!

Berkeley is where I discovered baked air fries.  I love fries.  I could be a fry-a-holic.  The salads were huge... I love fiber!  The burgers organic.  This is just the kind of food I like:  fresh, healthy, organic and a good deal.

Man, this place is good!! Literally just got done eating the Spinach and bacon burger, which had a very mild herbed goat-cheese and some caramelized onions on it. It's also served on some crusty, toasted sourdough bread. That was a seriously good burger!! The boyfriend had what I guess was their special burger of the day, which was the Chipotle BBQ Pork burger, and although I'm not a fan of blue-cheese I took a bite anyway and it was super-delicious!!! 

We also decided to be fat kids and got dessert. I got their Cranberry-Walnut chocolate chip pie and OH MY GOD!!!! You realllllly need to try that. Randy got the Bourbon Pecan Pie, which was good..... buuuuuut.... mine was better. They make their own desserts and I really hope they make their pie crusts too because it was amazingly buttery, flaky and delicious. If they don't make their crusts I don't want to know. Just let me keep thinking they do.

While we were ordering our food (to go) we looked over their extensive beer and wine lists (but mostly the beer) and they have a great selection! Lagunita's, Bell's, and other craft beers! 

The service was good, too, I have to add! (Mostly because I'm a server)

The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because all the toppings of the burger were on the bottom and I felt that it made the foundation (bun/bread, etc) kind of soggy. But definitely give this place a go!!! I highly recommend it!!
My fav place!! All u can drink free refills on iced coffee. The nicest people ever!

Parkside is one of the more popular dining halls on USC's campus. When I first got to USC, I loved being able to spend my "dining dollars" there. Over time, the food started to really disgust me and I realized how unhealthy everything actually is.

I love Parkside for it's diversity. They always have bagels, cereal, yogurt, (average) fruit, a salad bar, an omelette station, burgers (including veggie burgers), and pizza. Then they try to spice things up by switching around the main dishes. Sometimes you go in and there's tuna, sometimes it's pork, sometimes it's turkey.. you get the idea.

The thing that bothers me about Parkside now is how everything seems like mystery food. I always stick with cereal or yogurt because I know what it is. The sauce-covered dish that looks like meat? I'm not so sure.

It's convenient and takes dining dollars. So that earns it points. But the food is not so amazing. Doesn't look healthy and not exactly conducive to helping out vegetarians/vegans.

the cookies here are crack!!

amazing cookies!!

also the ice cream sandwiches are where its at....even though they are not a dollar like a few yrs back....its still a steal.

If you havent been to this joint do yourself a favor and go....you wont be dissapointed

Look, you know what you're getting into here - you know this is a boutique and that the clothes are ridiculously expensive. On the other hand, they have excellent customer service (I'm talking exclusive attention for 30 minutes), a fantastic selection of clothes, and best yet, a goddess by the name of Sabrina who basically dresses you. This is maybe not the place to buy your everyday stuff (although I've bought all of my last 3 pairs of jeans here), but if you need a special dress, really want some expert advice, and are willing to drop between $150 and $500 (remember I said it was expensive) this is the way to go.

The best body piercing joint I've found yet. If you don't live in Providence its definitely worth a commute. I went a few years ago and was impressed on all levels. Their studio was impeccably clean, (you could have eaten off the floor )friendly and well experienced staff- who definitely knew their stuff, prices were standard. I have only the best things to say about Rockstar, check them out.

Are the Burritos great? Cheap? Big? Yes yes yes! The dudes running it seem clean enough and I'll  eat from their roach coach.

You could get a burrito that's 1/2 as good, a dollar more, yet without a long line from Chipotle, Qdoba, or Mexi-Cali (or one of the food trucks around the corner).  

I guess I wouldn't mind waiting if there were some cute penn co-eds in sundresses crowding the sidewalk, but otherwise I just keep walking.

There was some confusion with a previous review of mine, which I *swear* I posted for the Cedars on Brooklyn, but then it ended up on this place's page... It was weird, whatever, but I fixed it, and then decided I ought to give this place a shot, because, hey, why not. 

And, it was okay. Not the best falafel I've ever had (though, granted, the best I've ever had was in Amsterdam, and I feel like there might have been something in the air there that affected my food-related judgement... Heh, heh), but not the worst, for sure. The sauce was a little boring (and there wasn't that much of it, at least at the top) and I'm not a huge iceberg lettuce fan, but the falafel itself was pretty fine. 

The service was fast and very friendly. 

I'll probably go back to try something different--maybe the eggplant sandwich, or something.

I'm still trying out the baked goods here. But the thing that's won me over to Sugarland is the gelato.  It's fresh tasting and light, different from any standard ice cream places around.  I recommend the pear flavor, but it seems like they rotate a few different gelatos in and out.  

The atmosphere is fun and bright too. Have tried the chocolate truffle, croissant, and cupcakes.  The croissant was light and not greasy, as well as very tasty. The chocolate truffle was very chocolaty.  

The only thing is in the evening the pastries seem to be running a bit low, even though they're open very late. I'm figuring the place is still working out how customer demand, since it hasn't been open very long.

It's local. It's good. Try it!

$10 minimum on credit cards, but they accept debit cards with no minimum.

P.S. On a more recent visit, I discovered the mini cone sampler. If you go with family/friends, you might consider getting this. 8 mini cones of gelato for $7.50. It makes for fun taste testing.
Yummy! Its pretty good considering there aren't many peruvian places nearby. It tastes more authentic than other "peruvian" places up the road near Ikea.

I wish I could get MARRIED to one of those little Brazilian cheesy bread balls (pao de queijo) they have at Sao Paulo's! Over the years I've been such a loyal Sao Paulo's patron that, really, I may as well put a ring on it.

Seriously every meal I've had here is pretty damn delicious. So much so that once a waiter was actually visibly taken aback by how quickly a girlfriend and I had "demolished" (his word, not ours) two gigantic dishes. Here are my reviews for some oft-demolished favorites:

Pollo Magdalena - easily my favorite dinner here - the red tortilla-encrusted rolls of chicken breast stuffed with crabmeat, spinach, and cream cheese are mildly crispy on the outside and succulent, saucy, and meaty on the inside. They rest on a sufficiently generous bed of rice and veggies, and the mild ancho sauce adds some needed moisture to the mix. 

Bobo de Camarao -  this is the Austin Chronicle award-winning dish, and deservedly so! A really nice amount of shrimp and yucca served in a GREAT tomato and coconut cream sauce + bell peppers/onions + rice. I'm usually sort of skittish about yucca since I think it can so often be rendered bland, but the nutty and creamy blend of flavors balances well with it in this case.

Enchiladas de Chipotle - finger-licking good satisfaction! I mean, I know that with the monterey jack cheese and mild chipotle sauce this pretty much meets your usual enchilada standards + the typical rice and beans fare. But Sao Paulo's really does it well - hot, delicious cheesiness!

Galinhada (Brazilian paella) - meat + jasmine rice suffused with a tasty amount of herbs and veggies - saffron, cilantro, tomatoes, and onions. Definitely hits the spot when you're hunting for some non-Spanish, but equally satisfying paella.

Outside of the food, the atmosphere's great, too. Kooky modern art with romantic undertones adorns the walls, the lighting's dim, and the candles make it a very cute datey scene. The live Latin bands are pretty fab as well and really set the mood for the South American cuisine. But a tip - sit in the back if you're hoping for a conversation since it's quite loud up front. Parking can be a bit obnoxious on a busy night, so if you're near/on campus I might recommend walking it.

Go! Soon! Tonight!!

Sadly I have to agree with many others: Bartley's is overrated.  I wish I didn't have to write that, because I want to love this place, but the burgers are overrated.

You can get a million different burgers here (OK maybe like 50), and many of them have AWESOME toppings.  But it doesn't change the fact that the actual burger patty is pretty average.

If you go, definitely order the onion rings (they're worth going for) and the raspberry lime rickeys are great to wash down your burger.

Be prepared to wait though... the legend of this place lives on despite the mediocre reviews.  If you are visiting Harvard, everyone will tell you to visit Bartley's.  Just don't say I didn't warn you about its mediocrity.

I used to come into Ajia regularly four or five years ago, and at that time it would have gotten at least three stars.  The all you can eat sushi special being my soft spot.  But my recent Tuesday night meal had suggested otherwise.  Ajia exhibits signs of a dying restaurant and here are my reasons why:

1.  We brought a bottle of Riesling to be enjoyed with our food..  A corkscrew was slammed on the table for us.  Seriously?  I've never ever been to a BYO where I have to cork my own wine.

2.  The wine glasses were VISIBLY dirty, gross.

3.  The prices have gone up a lot in recent years.  I understand what inflation is, but the fact is you're paying more money for less food.  Rolls used to be larger and not so hurriedly constructed.  And the pork katsudon bowl was very small for $10.  You get almost 25% more at Yakitori Boys--same price, and a lot tastier.

4.  Everyone complains about the service of the one waitress.  I think she is the owner or part owner.  In addition to the wine corking incident, we also weren't asked if we wanted soup or salad with our food.  We were just given soup as a default I guess?

All in all this place has an atmosphere like it just doesn't care anymore.  The all you can eat special isn't even advertised on the menu anymore, but from what I hear, it's now $24.  If you're really in the mood for sushi or Japanese food, I would advise you to broaden your search radius outside of University City.  Definitely think twice about coming here for dinner though.


P.S. - the music playlist here is archaic.  I don't think I've heard an Evanescence song since high school.

Persuaded to go by Mexican-cuisine enthusiasts, I decided to give Mexi Cali a try. I was sorely disappointed. First, atmosphere is very important to me and Mexi Cali did not have any. The plain tables and chairs with minimal decoration was just not working for me. 

Because I was wary about this place to begin with, I cautiously ordered the nachos. Big mistake. The tortillas were stale and none of the flavors melded. The cheese wasn't even all the way melted. I didn't know it was possible to have bad nachos until now. There are plenty of places to get good Mexican food in Philly... MexiCali is just not one of them.

You know what makes the Asgard a stand up Irish style joint? Nothing. In a neighborhood riddled with bars and lounges and crack heads and MIT geeks, this joint operates as the Friday's or Appleby's in a land where the chain restaurant has not managed to sink it's claws in on the local business. Don't get me wrong, this is a perfectly fine place to get a Corona or to use the bathroom but don't order that beer that you would like to try because they will be out of it. Or you could get the almost passable honey bbq wings, if you like warm carrots and soggy celery on the side. Nuffsaid.

Service was slow, but the Carne Estufada was excellent. Well worth the wait, although would have been even better accompanied by some fresh baked bread with butter. Salad was a bit skimpy. Business seems to be good as the time we sat there was a constant flow of people. Had a nice out of the ordinary selection of food.

Hands down best affordable sushi restaurant in Austin. I usually go for their happy hour from 4-6pm daily, but it's not too pricey compared to other sushi places if you don't go during happy hour.

The Blue Moonlight is a must. It's a 10-piece roll with tuna, shrimp, salmon and tempura flakes on top, and drizzled with Japanese mayo. I also really like the Volcano roll. It's similar to the Blue Moonlight, but it has jalapenos so it has more of a crunchy texture. Other rolls that are good: shrimp tempura, sake, and ginza (unagi) roll. Salmon nigiri here is really fresh! As for drinks, they have pretty good sake and selection of beer.

The sushi chefs and servers are all really friendly. If you decide to sit by the sushi bar, the chefs usually talk to you as they're making your sushi. They also do cute little designs such as shaping the wasabi into a leaf or drawing some hearts with mayo.

There is limited parking, especially during happy hour, and you will be double parking. Sometimes you have to move for the person in front of you to pull out, so be prepared for that. If you don't live too far, it would be best to walk there.
Best standalone theater in the city, along with the main Chinese auditorium. Let's just hope it doesn't go the way of the National.

Northside Grill is perhaps my favorite breakfast joint in Ann Arbor, and that's saying something.

The food is spectacular - definitely a cut above standard breakfast fare. It's also very unassuming, which I like - there is very little air of Afternoon Delight-esque pretension. The Morning Eggdition and Northsider breakfast sandwiches are two of my favorite menu items in the entire city. I also like that they'll substitute fries for hash browns at no additional charge - makes them great lunch choices.

I also love the staff. Every server I've ever had was just incredibly friendly and welcoming, in addition to being very competent. It just makes for an enjoyable meal.

If you go on a Saturday or Sunday, be prepared to wait for 20-30 minutes. But it's worth it, and they put out free coffee for you. During the week it's much less busy and makes for a great lunch spot - I try to hit it once or twice a month.

Highly recommended.
Ss now has bar snacks like fries and charcuterie.  Better yet, fries covered in charcuterie. Yum...

Literatea?  They should really rename this USC cafe "Shannon's Favorite Things."  A decent tea latte really gets my engine going, and they have a wide assortment of grab-and-go vegan entrees.  WHAT!  So many times, when I forget to pack food, I'm stuck buying an expensive avocado roll at Seed, and it just makes me sad.  Literatea = happiness.

Not to say it's perfect.  There are no vegan desserts to tempt me, and they make their tea lattes like Starbucks, with the teabag stuck inside, which I deplore.  Please, brew the tea first, then make the latte!!  Annoying as that is, however, the Sassy Chai latte is the real deal.  Spicy, not overly sweet (even with soy milk!), and made with real looseleaf tea as opposed to Oregon Chai.  And, a small is only $2.99!!!  Be still my heart.

Service is fast and friendly, and it's a little oasis tucked behind Doheny library, which just happens to be my favorite building on campus.

Say you wake up at 10:45 on a Sunday morning in your apartment on the UM campus. You have nothing in your house but stale granola and no milk. You know you need breakfast food, but there's no way you're waiting for Angelo's, and the chef at the Brown Jug decided not to open the place on time so you can't go there, either. 

Mr. Greek's to the rescue! This affordable and quick little establishment will pump you full of french toast, eggs, breakfast meats, several preparations of potatoes, and whatever else you need to make waking up and facing the fact that the weekend's almost over bearable. And you won't have to wait too long to get a table.

Very cool place...everyone in there is a student working on their laptop with their cup of joe.  I really like the white chocolate mocha.  Also groovy how they have all the flyers and cards for upcoming events to check out.

EW this place is disgusting if you ACTUALLY know Mexican food.
YUCK YUCK YUCK.
The only decent mexican in the area is a little restaurant in Los Osos called La Casita. 
Don't waste your time..taco bell tastes better.

Where else can you find a place that specializes in Breakfast, American food, and Mexican food?  Cafe Durant of course!  I love sitting on the balcony on a sunny day with just a view of the buildings and not the dirty streets below haha.  

I tried the steak and eggs here and it was NOT good.  The steak was cooked with onions, as it said on the menu, but the menu did not say there would be some weird red sauce that it is smothered in.  It was gross and kind of hard to eat, but if you like that kind of sauce, it's actually a really good deal because it comes with rice and beans and corn tortillas.  My friend and I gave the guacamole and chips a try, since it was so cheap, but the guacamole tasted like there was too much lime in it.  Not good.  My friends both got breakfast dishes (I don't believe in eating breakfast foods until it is dark) and kept on raving about the good ass pancakes.  They said they were light and fluffy and amazing and then talked about them all day; I guess I should try them when school starts again.  There is a salsa bar, which was nice because it salvaged the chips we got with the disgusting guacamole.  

The menu is very extensive and everything is really cheap, so I will definitely come back to try more items.
Everything on the menu is delicious. good for breakfast lunch and dinner

Philly Diner is amazing.... if you are WASTED. 

That's about all there is to say. They have a 10 page menu with every item imaginable. The thing thing that is most odd to me about Philly Diner is that the quality of the food actually varies based on the time of day. If you go in for breakfast, you get a decent meal. Any time after midnight and your eggs come out looking like roadkill.

A little while ago we dropped by Tom Collichio's Sandwhich shop in NYC called Wichcraft. For a chef of his caliber, you would expect perfection...but what i received was slightly above average, at best. I was taken aback a little because it seems like the people that were working at his place did not care that much, so that explains a lot. 

 After reading the reviews about SandWhich in CH, I was expecting a really good meal, but not a near life-changing experience. Am I talking this place up... I don't think so. The owner is right there in the kitchen, she cares about the food she makes and even admitted about being a little OCD about making everything herself...And, I can relate. I make as much food homemade as I can too....from soup, to bread, to yogurt...you get the idea. 

 I won't talk about the food TOO much b/c I'm confident that anything you get, will be great. We tried the Tuna, OBLT, Chicken Salad and the Turkey....(TUNA is Dynamite!) IT's sad to see there are not more places like this...places that make you feeling satiated not only physically after your meal, but also mentally knowing the amount of time and energy that went into this food. 

Great jobs guys....keep doing what you're doing. 

Thank you.

So after two years of basically living a couple blocks away from SIP, I decided to give it a try and was totally disappointed.

First, I tried ordering two things on the menu (both were associated with the happy hour) and they were "out" of both of them. Really? you are out of the two random things I pick that are the cheapest on the menu? Of course, a more expensive item was recommended to replace what I had asked for.

Second, We also had to repeatedly ask for our free tapas that went along with happy hour, that came out really late afterward. Although I did enjoy my beverage (third choice was a charm) my experience was disrupted by constantly trying to get the waiter's attention.

Third, The AUTOMATIC SURCHARGE of 18%, sealed the deal for me that this place was a one-timer. Honestly, we just had two drinks and had an 18% charge on our bill. The bill also gives you advice on what more you can tip below (different percentages with different prices). If I didn't look close enough I would not have realized I was already charged for the tip. I have never been to a restaurant that does this anywhere else ever (there was only 2 of us and we just had drinks). NICE TRY SIP--never again. Full stop.

I like that they serve pizza by the slice but it severely diminishes the magic of Round Table pizza.  As a former college student, this was the most I could afford on most days.  Even still, Round Table pizza is a treat.  I firmly believe it's the pizza sauce that puts Round Table ahead of other chain pizzerias.  It's bold, spicy (not hot spicy but spices) and got some kick.  So when they stiff me on sauce, I get really upset.  This particular location seems to go easy on the sauce but I really shouldn't expect much from pizza by the slice.  Order a complete pizza, however, and things look good again.  It's a good place to watch sports since they serve beer and it doesn't get TOO crowded and it's also cool that they deliver pizza on campus.

The best way to enjoy a Round Table Pizza at UCSD is as follows:

1. Get some buddies together and order a few small/medium sizes
2. Put the boxes and some napkins in your backpacks
3. Sneak them in to Geisel and claim one of the private group meeting rooms on the 4th or 5th floors (I forgot where they are)
4. Scarf down pizza with you friends while pretending to study
5. Throw your trash away outside the library so as not to encourage more rats to gather in the library.

No matter the Round Table Pizza, and I will always hold their pizza in high regard.

I can't, in good conscience, give them 5 stars because I did not have my computer repaired here. 

One of the fine gentleman did, however, take a look at my laptop and confirm my darkest suspicions...that "Ol' Bessy" had most likely moved on to the great Laptop dock in the sky. I was told that my data was secure, but the motherboard would be pointless to replace for the cost. As much as I loved my laptop, I gotta say that dropping several hundred dollars on it's aging bones wasn't what I was planning on.

The tech was honest, straightforward with what they offered and why, and gave me a detailed account of possible options for replacement if I wished. There was no push whatsoever, and the guy knew his stuff.

I will hopefully never return...only because that would mean I need to have something repaired again. But if I do need to...this is where I will go.

I had Tako sushi for the first time today and I was quite pleased with the roll and the price. I ordered the Godzilla, which was basically an unagi roll deep fried. I got 10 pieces (even though the menu says 8) for 5.40 before tax and tip. The price definitely made my roll more delicious, but even objectively, I would have enjoyed my sushi roll. I definitely recommend the Godzilla, which is what I had.

However, my friend had a less satisfactory order. his don katsu donburri had some really gross egg thing on top of it that looked gray and just not appetizing. also, his don katsu was soggy and not crisp and the meat was very chewy. stay away from the donburri.. but his salmon popcorn (appetizer) was pretty good! you can't really go wrong with deep fry 

i was happy with the price, variety, and overall quality of the food. i can definitely see myself coming here more often

Food + Price + Ambiance +  Service -
Thai basil is like other restaurants in the Durant Food Court (aka Asian Ghetto) the food is cheap, oily, over spiced, and fast (well faster than sit down restaurants). And like all food we have to take into consideration the price and convenience so in that respect Thai basil is great for the empty wallets of poor college students. The food portion alone is worth the trip and what a short trip it is from most of the Southside dorm residents, and the food is always consistent in flavor and texture. The only complaint is that the restaurant seems to be in possession of only five sauces, many of the dishes taste similar to each other as the spices totally over power anything. Dishes that are staples of the place: Basil Eggplant, Pineapple Curry, Chicken Pad Se Ew, and Garlic Pepper Chicken. 
The service is sometimes lost in translation but with proper pointage and lots of patience while trying to convey what you want, you can get what you actually ordered most of the time. The ambiance of the place is slightly better than others in the court, there are tables for instance and an attempt at keeping them clean is very much appreciated.

Came here for breakfast on a Saturday morning and was pleasantly surprised with the decor of the place.  The walls are decorated with quirky signs and I was amused by this faux hamburgler-statue with a mustache.

Onto the dining experience, I ordered the Mexican Mashed Meal with the cayenne-cheddar toast.  Remember the cheesy bread from Sizzlers?  The cayenne-cheddar toast was like that, but 132445842x better.  The mash was loaded was chorizo and topped with a fried egg, it was delicous.  I was about to ask the waitress for some tapatio until I tried the chipotle sauce the mash came with and that was plenty spicy for me.  My friends ordered the Almond Joy cakes and the Orange French Toast (no complaints from either of them).  The waitress warned us that those were both HUGE portions, and she wasn't kidding.  Both were GINORMOUS...and when the waitress returned and saw that we had all clean off our plates, she was truly impressed.

Seriously, some days the only thing that gets me out of bed and moving is the thought of a caramel apple fritter from Sublime. 99% of the time I get out of bed and then don't make it there, but hey, whatever works right? Well, this morning I DID get there. And it was amazing as always. Thank you Sublime, for being my alarm clock.

Ummm...I hate to be the dissenting voice, but I think it's important that folks looking for a church in the Bay Area have as much info as possible.  

I am appalled at how activist this place is.  

At least 2-3 times each service some sort of political commentary is made.  Completely inappropriate.

For Example:
Last weekend, a guest speaker was brought in to talk about some of the work he does with immigrants in the Bay Area.  Instead, for 30 minutes, I was subjected to a lecture about how illegal immigrants are being discriminated against.  Again, I do have compassion for those trying to seek a better life and become US citizens, but I DO NOT want to be lectured in CHURCH about a particular special interest group. That type of talk would be appropriate for an AFTER church voluntary discussion, NOT being forced upon those who have come to worship.

Let me be clear, I am definitely on the left as far as my political leanings, but I really don't want to hear about folks opinions on the war, the presidency, etc. Even if I happen to agree with them.

If you want a place to express your particular political viewpoints with a dash of  "religious ceremony", you'll love it there.

If you are looking for a place strong in ministry, worship, and learning about Jesus Christ,  this may not be the place for you.

I usually go to Anna's, but I got a free burrito certificate to this place so I decided to try it out. I brought a friend. First of all, as soon as I walked in the feel of the place really put me off. It's so sterile and unfriendly; reminded me of an airport. As we approached the counter (and this took a while b/c there was a slow line even though it wasn't lunchtime), it turned out that you can't pick anything except what kind of meat (or non-meat) you want. What happened to the small whole wheat burritos? Anyway, I got my FREE burrito, a drink and my friend's burrito as well......for $11?!?!  Whatever, I was thinking, they should be really good. As we sat down and started eating, I was immediately hit by how spicy it was, and how separate all of the ingredients were from each other (first the rice, then chicken, the guacamole, salsa, etc.) Then it started to come apart b/c there was too much stuff inside. I was really full about half way through it (I usually go for a small elsewhere). 
I guess it's an okay place if you're really really hungry, or if you want to split one with a friend. Overall though I wasn't impressed, I like choices and a friendly atmosphere (not a concrete/metal jungle with a line). I think I'll stick to Anna's.

This place is awesome. It is a book-lover's dream. I'm sure there is something similar to this in every city and I appreciate the one we have in Houston. 

Recent purchases have included Willa Cather's A Lost Lady ($2.95) and an Anton Chekhov short story anthology ($3.00)... You can't get a magazine at these prices at Barnes or Borders. 

I subtracted a star because they are all business and from my experience, selling books is tough. I once cleaned out my room and mini-library and showed up toting no less than 15 hardcover popular titles in mint condition from authors like John Grisham, James Patterson, Dan Brown, etc.. The guy looked me dead in the eye and offered me $5 for all of them. I donated them to the library.

I have been to the aledged "Atlanta's Premier Barbarshop" for my last 2 haircuts and was less than excited either time.  

I am real picky about my hair and just moved to the area did not know where to go.  I walked in to American Haircuts based on my research on Yelp and instantly felt comfortable right away. I was greeted by a man at the desk.  He was polite and led me back to my stylist, Derek. He was very nice and we made some small talk and asked "how long since my lash haircut". It told him how long and then I  told him how I wanted my cut this time. The conversation was very comfortable as if I had know him a long time.  (my wife says I can talk to anybody) 

My haircut was great and the atmosphere was laid back and while I did not have a drink because it was 11:00am (the bar was very welcoming) I will go next time in the PM and will have one. 

I have found a new spot to get my haircut!!  I will be back!!

Oh, how I miss Peet's.  

It had been six months since I left the Bay Area.  And I almost forgot what a good Cappuccino could taste like.  

But the richness and depth of flavor of the espresso, the tiny bubbles and creaminess of the foam, are unknown in all of the cafe's I have visited in upstate NY (my new home).

Damn you Peet's.  Now that I remember how good Cappuccino can be, I am even more dissatisfied with what passes for espresso in Albany.  

Damn you Peet's.  
Damn you Cambridge.
It is so unfair that you get Peet's and Trader Joe's.
What gives?

Yeah, the staff are big jerks.  Seriously, it's like they hate their job.  I wonder why... serving pizza to snotty college kids...  but it's no excuse.  Lots of businesses in Westwood, and they all have to serve the snotty college kids.  
Anyway, I'm a fan of their lunch special #1 for like, $5.95.  One topping slice, salad & a soda.  I go with the basil on my pizza, & the caesar.  And yeah, it's not worth writing home about, but i like that they toss it fresh.  And it's not some tiny side salad.
Also, the last time I was there, two Italians sitting at the table across from me were devouring their pizza.  They hardly spoke, they were so eager to eat their pizza, so it took a lot of eavesdropping to determine that the language they were speaking was in fact, Italian.  But I did it for you. So, that's validation.  A pizza joint Italians eat at.  
I don't spend much time in Westwood anymore, but I'd gladly go back.  Even if it's run by a bunch of jerks.

I remember when these types of stores started popping up 5-10 years ago - everything in them was super-unique, hard-to-find, and guaranteed to be an awesome gift. Once they became more common, the contents became less unique, and now they're everywhere. Black Ink is a fine example of this type of store. I particularly liked the postcards for $1 each and various greeting cards.

As if campus wasn't already a site to behold the views atop Hoover are amazing.  Make sure you go up here a few times during you Stanford career.  And if you are visiting you definitely need to check it out.

This place can really be hit or miss, just as any thrift/vintage/consignment store can be. But I feel like if you've got enough time on your hands and the strength to haul your finds away, there are definitely treasures to be had.

The Garment District is memorable for two specific occasions- Halloween, and the 50% off everything in-store sale, which happens twice a year. Halloween is a madhouse but the Garment District really does have anything and everything you could possibly need for a costume. Is it worth paying that much for a pre-made outfit when you could scavenge the clothes needed from the thrift section upstairs? But the real winner is the biannual sale, in which I took home a wool peacoat, a silk kimono, some cardigans, and two button-downs for the BF for about $30. Other times I've found Cole Haan suede boots in exactly my size, and amazing funky t-shirts and jackets. Sometimes all you end up with are slightly inflamed sinuses from all the dust and disinfectant. But hey, it's worth it.

Coming from a predominantly Hispanic hometown, I find it hard to swallow the blandness of Berkeley's Mexican food choices, but at least for the price, location, and speed, it's hard to find much better near campus without traveling far far away.

It's not totally unusual to walk right in and pay for your food (with credit card as a bonus!) and then be out and scarfing down a generously sized burrito in under 5 minutes here, but you can tell that most of the ingredients have been sitting out and mellowing for a while, especially the meats. Nothing here tastes particularly fresh or authentically Mexican. 

The one highlight of La Burrita is their unlimited salsa bar, which actually introduces some much-needed flavor, especially if you like the spicier salsas. The free chips that come with their burritos are nothing to rave about, but I like it because most of my friends give me their chips and that's just more food for me! As a corollary to that, skip the nachos here. They microwave them and the chips are just not durable enough to stand up to the heat and the soggy toppings they put on top.

Tip: if you want your meat grilled, order something with fajitas and it comes with some tasty grilled meat that hasn't been sitting premade in a pan. The only downfall is this is a bit pricier and takes a LOT longer to cook.

Quick and tasty conveyer belt delivered sushi and sashimi (the best tamago in town!). Menu items also include a fantastic beef bowl. A great place to go for lunch if you have limited time and limited budget. Sushi chefs and waitstaff are very attentive.

okay, so im not sure if its called intermezzo or mattina these days but here is what i know...

-gigantic salads (although the gigantic-ness varies on the day/time that you go); id recommend eating here (as opposed to getting it to go) b/c the portions are bigger and you can easily share it with another person (cheap meal!)

-fresh produce (again, it depends on the day/time that you go, though, because ive gotten brown lettuce and smooshy tomatoes before)

-cash only; $6.75 for a salad or $7 for half salad/half sandwich

-vegetarian delight salad comes with 1 hard boiled egg, croutons, 1/2 avocado, carrots, cabbage, tomatoes, a few cucumber slices and a hunk of honey wheat bread on the side. sometimes you get a slice of fruit, sometimes you dont

-most importantly, and this is a big negative for me, the employees do NOT change their gloves after handling meat

I thought I already yelped this one but,

Mixed reviews on this one....

let me think...they have decent:
books
(sometimes) housewares and clothes.

It is crowded. guaranteed!!!

(in my experience) Clothes are so-so

But I am addicted to second-hand stores and since this is in my radius...you know you'll see me in there sometime and Ill probably be in line with something cool I found...

B/c we are in cambridge/somerville, there are sometimes lots of good things at the second-hand stores as many students come and go. we more premanent residents can benefit!
You can't beat the french press Counter Culture coffee at octane... smooth and fully bodied.
Watching the employees singing that shitty song in their shitty paper hats for minimum wage makes me want to cry.
Tell me where there is a better burger and I will call you a liar.

i loveeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee toscininis. its pricey, yes, but the flavors are wonderful. once, on a particularly bad day, i went in and bought a small chocolate marshmellow pudding...........heavenly. plus its a good place to read/study if not too crowded. ive never tried their weekend brunches but he menu looks tasty. i had an almond croissant there and it was also good.. as are the steamers and coffees and the staff are friendly and cool.

Everytime I go to Westwood I HAVE to stop by here. The smell carries from across the street and you follow it to end up here. I always buy a dozen little donuts for only $3 and share them with my sister. They are beyond delicious and what I wish I could wake up and eat every morning!! While they are fattening, they are totally worth it.

this is one of those places that even if it were $1000/donut, youd still pay it just to keep places like stan open. but stan is beyond that--hes loyal to his customers and in todays day and age, keeps taste a priority. stan admits they suffered a 10% loss in recent years to the health craze, but they arent budging on making low cal donuts (thank gooddess).

i love the old-fashioned choc. donuts with choc chips. they use really good chocolate. also--you can jack free wi-fi from boba loca next door while munching on your donut breakfast.

A this hotel, your reservations mean nothing!!!  

My girlfriend and I recently made reservations to stay Friday and Saturday night.  When we arrived on that Friday, the manager told us that all of the rooms were already sold out and that he only had us down for reservations on Saturday night.  He then proceeded to call us liars and told us that we didn't have any proof that we had reserved both nights (the confirmation number they had given over the phone apparently didn't serve as proof).  I stay in hotels fairly often and have seen this situation before in small-town hotels ... the hotel promises a really good deal because they think the hotel will be empty and then it turns out to be a popular night and they rent your room for a higher rate.

Anyways, I sort of understand that situation and would not have even been all that upset if the manager would've politely said something like  "let me phone a hotel down the street and see if we can get you a room, and we'll knock a few bucks off of tomorrow night's rate here with us."

But instead, the manager just stood there looking at us meanly with his arms crossed.  Eventually, I broke the silence by saying "well, can we do something to make this right?  As of right now, this is the worst customer service I've ever had at a hotel."  He then got really mean and repeated that we didn't have proof that we had reserved both nights, and that he was going to do nothing.  It got a little heated after that, and when I asked him to cancel my reservation for Saturday night.  He told me that it was too late to cancel that reservation.  After some heated words and a threat to call the Ramada corporate office (which I will make good on), he eventually told me that he was going to do me a "favor" and cancel my Saturday night reservation.

We ended up staying at the Le Quesenta up the street, which was very nice.

I can't say anything about the hotel itself, as I did not actually stay there.  However, I want to warn people that you cannot rely on reservations at this hotel to ensure that you have a place to stay when you get to SLO. They will rent to the highest bidder (they seemed really greedy). If you do make reservations, be sure they e-mail you the reservation, or you may get hosed with only your confirmation number.

If I could, I would givw this place zero stars.
always safe bet for my sugar crunch. strawberry shortcake, and amazing romanoff.

This is my neighborhood Publix, and despite its relative small size, I love it. While they can't stock absolutely everything in the space, they've done a great job of catering to their local demographic: a large frozen food and go-to meal section, decent natural/organic selection (not a ton of produce), eliminating the large bakery and pharmacy departments. In this location, it all makes sense.

Plus, the employees at this store are just about the friendliest folks ever. It's hard for me to make a trip to Publix and *not* get a fresh made sub, and the people in the deli are always super sweet. I don't grocery shop often (I eat maybe 1 or 2 meals at home... a week), but when I do this Publix certainly does the trick, whether you can walk from nearby or need to drive and use their super easy (and free!) parking garage.

I see Kitty, and she has hands down given me the most consistently great haircuts of my life. I have fine hair that I dye at home (because it's cheaper) and she makes it look polished with a little bit of flair. I can also grow it out for at least 12 weeks without it getting messy. 

I also have very long "bangs" and they're willing to trim them as fit. 

The environment at Pyara is wonderful: it smells good, you get tea, and there's a complimentary massage.

Uncle Dougie's makes italian heroes, a soul food that is native to New York. I live in the apartments right next door, and saw it when I was walking to Top Dog, and decided to give it a try instead. They make only four sandwiches meatloaf, Italian sausage, chicken parmesan, and eggplant parmesan. The employee in the from offered me a sample of meatloaf and eggplant. The meatloaf is delicious, so I decided to try a whole sandwich. The sandwich tasted like a home cooked meal, that is deceptively filling. I wouldn't recommend this place if you were vegan or on a diet, but otherwise if you're a student who is homesick and is looking for a good solid sandwich It's a good change from the standard telegraph fare.

First off, for convenience, this place can't be beat. I mean... It's literally in the library building. But would I come here otherwise? No. The coffee's alright, but nothing special. 

I'm writing this review, though, because I have started a personal tour of places to buy baked goods on/near campus (to start, anyway). They really don't focus on this, but since they're offered, I had to try it. I got a blueberry scone, and if my rating was just for the scone, it would be a 1 star. More muffin texture than scone, and almost no flavor. After about half of it (and it took me a while) I questioned whether I should finish it. Cheaper than a lot of places, but I'd rather pay more.

Okay.......Top dog at Durrant is not just about the dogs. It is the Top Dog experience. Lets face it There are better Dogs to be had(casper's in the Dimond).

What could be more fun at 1.30 am in sleepy Berkeley town than hitting up a crowded, drunken, rocking Top Dog. The African American front man Repeating 10-15 orders and always adding to it...(an amazing feat not easily accomplished).....His side kick the grill master extraordinaire railing through orders with just as much proficiency as the ringleader. Never have I received the wrong order and I always leave satisfied and ready for bed......Is there a better Dog...yes. Is there a better late night experience in Berkeley...Hells no.

The closing of Buffalo Wild Wings on Franklin St. left a serious dearth of decent chicken wings in Chapel Hill. Ba-Da Wings is definitely the best of what's left, even though they are a little more expensive (like $6 for 4 wings). They also have really good wraps - I especially like the Cajun variety. Their delivery radius isn't as large as I'd like, but it doesn't take them long to prepare a to-go order. Service is usually pretty friendly and efficient, but I've been there a few times when it was definitely lacking. Also, there's plenty of parking (yay!), which is something that Buffalo Wild Wings never had.

What's not to love? This is the campus bar that plays all the televised Cal games and serves great beers at great prices. I don't know of a student who has been to the Bear's Lair and didn't love it.

Beat the Clock is a tradition at Berkeley that's almost as vital to its roots as free speech - okay maybe not THAT vital but it's pretty damn entertaining. You have to love an hour during which every minute you must down a shot of beer. Good times... Go Bears!
It's been a solid year and a half since my trip to Boston, but I still drool over the slice of pizza that I had at Pinocchio's. It was so fricken good. And cheap! And delicious. I want more.

Lost: dark blue blazer, with gold buttons

Food and microbrews aren't too bad tho' - plus it's pretty much the only place in Princeton you're going to get any food after 10 pm.

My favorite lunch place.  A little expensive if you get a drink, too, but the discount punch card helps a bit if you go a lot like I do.  Tons of drink variety, though I've only tried the matcha, original, and taro bubble milk teas, which are all good. I love their crepes--they are a perfect size for lunch, and are a well-balanced meal (I usually add extra lettuce or corn for added nutrition.). Nice magazine selection for reading, and free Wifi. Decor is fun and modern--bright orange and white with natural wood.  The only downside is no exterior windows due to mall location.

There's nothing missing from here. It's all wonderful. 

Even at it's busiest, the staff was great, the food was delicious and you can't beat the price with a stick. Bim-bop is so good it makes my liver quiver. And even if you can eat the whole bowl, you feel good about yourself for doing so. It's not processed or flavored or MSGed. And the sesame chili sauce on the tables brings my future children's children to tears of joy. 

Did I mention the sweet robot face? Well, then, you're just going to have to go check it out for yourself. 

Oh and try the pickled daikon. It's brilliant.

I really enjoyed Corner Bakery.  It's like a glorified Paradise Bakery!  It's a great place for breakfast & lunch.  Decent prices & decent yum food!  
I got the  Anaheim Scrambler  - Eggs scrambled with crisp applewood smoked bacon, tomatoes, green onions, and cheddar cheese, topped with avocado.  Served with oven-roasted breakfast potatoes and harvest toast. 

You only get one sliver of avocado, but overall it WAS good!!!

Dr Lipson is without a doubt the best ENT (and amongst the best doctors) I have been to. I went to Dr Lipson ten years ago when I had completely lost my voice and could barely speak. I had been to several doctors before this and they had prescribed steroids and all other manner of medications.  Dr Lipson took plenty of time to talk to me, understand my full medical history, and within three weeks my voice was back.  He really understands singers voices as well as ordinary people's voices.  He is extremely thorough, gentle and a gem of a human being.  He does not rush you.  Fair warning, he does tend to get backed up because this thoughtful, non-rushed approach means that appointments later on in the day can get delayed.

This Chipotle marked one of the first real strides towards the "Westwoodization" of the USC Area - the twenty year long plan to force out the locals and remake the neighborhood into someplace safe and expensive. Naturally, USC students were very excited.

This place offers decent, american variety burritos and tacos (and - secret item! - quesadillas; just ask) at a-little-higher-than-reasonable prices. I went there a bunch before a health conscious friend broke down exactly how many calories are in one of those burritos, so now I only rarely go (also, they stopped giving out free drinks to students). Supposedly they're going to get a liquor license, which would allow them to serve margaritas like the other locations, so maybe I'll go back when that happens. Till then, La Taquiza is a better bet.

I went for the happy hour and enjoyed a dirty martini and a salad. 

The sweet potato fries and very gouda grits were a hit. My partner had a burger and a few beers.

We enjoyed the good service, the bar atmosphere, and the food.

I will be returning!

It's a cute movie theatre inside a mall, what more can you expect?

I walked into the movie theater with a cookie that I just bought from subway and they didn't say anything (bless their hearts).

The seats weren't that comfortable.

I came here with my friends to watch Resident Evil in 3D.

I'm happy that they had 3D glasses in kid sizes because my nose isn't that big and the bridge won't hold up the glasses.

If you're looking to do something on a Friday or Saturday night and want to avoid the drunk people, come here!
Yes, I know it's smack dab in the middle of a college campus, so can't expect much for atmosphere. But this seriously may be the most cramped and unorganized venue I've ever seen a concert at.
Bad service. Subpar food. Will not go again.
Great place to see a show... too bad it sounds like it doesn't make any money and might close because of that....

This is a tale of a two restaurants in one:

The good City Tap House:
The beaten copper bar, high ceilings, and decor coupled with the rest of the decorations all come together to generate some good ambience(Not to mention the view from the outside seating/window tables). The mussels and Tap House burger are both solid. The fries are good. The beer list is excellent and no beer is ever skunked/off. The service, while not stellar, is decent and the food comes out of the kitchen within a reasonable time frame if you are watching a game and not in a hurry.

The bad City Tap House(as typified by my last two visits):
What precipitates a bad City Tap House experience you ask? Any type of crowd.

People mill around everywhere and bump into you while you are seated at the bar. If you sit at the back of the bar farthest away from the entrance and towards the back you are in what one bartender called "The Dead Zone". She used this as an excuse to cover up the fact that she screwed up, forgetting about my beer order for at least 10 minutes after I placed it with her. Mind you this was the 2nd screw up, the first being that she never placed our order for a pizza, which we only discovered after waiting an hour. That's why you got a small tip. Own up to your mistakes instead of bullshitting me.

If you sit in the non Dead Zone you might have to still grab a bartender by the chest or use a flare gun in order to get a 2nd beer, even if your pint glass was long empty and you had politely indicated that you needed service.

The food is less than stellar in the bad City Tap House. My Cubano had the worst pulled pork I've ever had on it.  How does someone consciously serve dried ass pork that literally crunched when I bit into it? The chicken press sandwich I had was a hot mushy mess that had no discernable flavor. Someone isn't checking the dishes before they leave the kitchen, or their standards are abysmally low. 

This place has the potential to kick every other bar's ass in the area. Unfortunately the crappy service and less than stellar food whenever CTH is crowded makes it a must pass unless its a snowy Sunday afternoon or school is out.

Another restaurant that I was introduced to through work.  This past year we had our office holiday dinner there and it was great.  The menu had good, diverse options (especially considering several of my coworkers have various food restrictions) and everyone was able to find something they liked.  Our server was very attentive and the meal moved at a good pace.  Its dark and basked in red hues which makes it feel cozy, especially on the rainy night we were there.  We were seated upstairs near the green house like ceiling area and I enjoyed the pitter pat of the rain on the glass.

A quaint Italian place in the beginning of Harlem that serves incredible and simple dishes. Very reasonably priced. Dinner for two $25 including tip. Top notch service and very fresh ingredients. Great place for dinner. I myself look forward to trying lunch soon

The food is very good and they are a bit pricey. We had the 10 course tasting menu. The dishes were a bit small but it does give you a sampling of their menu . It does get crowded and the next time I think we will do the bar.  I definitely recommend reservations in advance. They have a different menu at the bar then they do on the dining room. The specials are what I recommend if you are in the dining room and try the burgers at the bar...

Found a good deal on Hotels.com for this place ($180/night) and the Yelp reviews were pretty positive for the most part, so I tried it out for a couple of nights when I was in the area for business. To echo some of the other Yelpers' sentiments, this is a really cozy, quaint  hotel. The hotel is also steps away from the Kendall T stop on the red line and it's easy to get to/from the airport from this stop.

Other than that, I didn't find anything at the Kendall Hotel to be extraordinary. A few Yelpers praised it for the customer service, but it didn't seem exceptional to me. In fact, when I first go there and was checking in at the front desk (around 9 pm when it was hardly busy), the front desk clerk answered the phone just as I had stepped up to the counter and proceeded to chat it up with someone (who I'm guessing also worked there ) to tell him/her about her not-so-busy day. I stood there waiting for at least 5 minutes listening to a clearly non-important conversation. 

The hotel also doesn't offer room service (and the kitchen at their in-house restaurant closes at 9:45 pm). I don't usually order room service, but I got in late and hadn't had dinner yet and it was on my company's tab anyway. There's a Legal Seafoods bar/restaurant across the street, which seemed to be the only dining option, at that time of night, within walking distance.

I had to catch a cab to the office one morning and unfortunately they don't have a taxi stand outside. You either have to ask the front desk to call a cab for you, or walk around the block to the Marriott's taxi stand.

I've had three experiences at Stanford and they are all similar.  Exceptional talent on the physician staff, mediocre talent elsewhere, and complete disregard for timetables with respect to the patient, or information sharing.  There was general chaos with respect to who knew what when and how to contact the right individual to get the appropriate information. I would never recommend going here unless it is for a speciality that is unique.  Most peninsula hospitals are better, and PAMF is much much better.

ATTENTION COLLEGE STUDENTS (Or broke people): Only come with a parental unit or after tricking your favorite professor! 
This place is preeettty expensive but REALLY good. 

On Sundays (at least this one) they have a 3 course prix fix menu that is 40 dollars and 50 for the fillet mignon. It included one small appetizer and one normal one of your choice, a main dish - all of which looked great -and a dessert. I had a fillet mignon wrapped in chorizo that looked like it should be framed and tasted amazing. 

Everything at this place was great - it had an upscale but not stuffy atmosphere, really attentive and not snobbish service and - again - great food.

Classiest and probably the most expensive place in the village but definitely worth it (if you're not paying or have money).
There is a time and a place for everything, and it's called Kips.
It's a cute store, but small and busy enough that it's a better to-go place.  They have an amazing variety of choices and it's great for buying bulk loose tea and accessories.

Being from California, the land of In-N-Out, I am quite picky about my burgers.  And I thought that there wasn't a good burger in all of Boston.  That is, until I ate at Mr. Bartley's.  I have been by myself every time I have gone, and have never had to wait.  However, even if I had to wait, it would be worth it.  Their burgers are of substantial size, and cooked to perfection.  The menu selection is incredible.  Also, be sure to try their frappes, as they are satisfying even on a cold day.  Mr. Bartley's may not be In-N-Out, but it is the best I've encountered on the East Coast.

Went there for lunch the other day. It was great. Good atmosphere and friendly staff. Ordered the Black and Blue burger, delicious as were the garlic fries that came with. Friend ordered Mac and Cheese, it was amazing! I will be coming back!

Typical Papa John's. Not much in the way of seating, but somehow monopolized the Penn campus events circuit for pizza.

I always like the hot peppers, and the butter/oil solution is a great way to swallow their crust (thicker than the average New York style). Totally unhealthy, and light on the toppings at times, but overall not bad.

It's the kind of place where the $10 pitchers of beer come in scratched up RubberMaid plastic juice jugs with disposable cups on the side. Want food? Order a pizza with the bar phone. Cheapest beer in Cambridge, with a great view of the Boston skyline.

This BK tacks up the prices on the menu for some odd reason. Aside from the IN N OUT takin away business not many students come here. My old pal Ryan has been here with me. One more of our confrontations happened here. If he wanted to eat here he had to counterbalance his diet with some weird salad he brought along. That act got me so curious as to what was in that tupperware he had with him. 

So one time I decided to take it from and eat it. It tasted so nasty.  Then there was the time Sammy came with us. I fronted on him like it was some gourmet some I was having so in the middle of my meal he stole it from me too. Was he in for a suprise! Funny stuff to Ryan. I really thought eating that salad would be one of the successful steps to become wealthy or a successful person but I guess it had nothing to do with that. However I do enjoy having a flame broiled Whopper once in a while so that brings me to this location. Downside is that this place closes early like 11 I think.

This is a very average donut shop.

They sell the usual variety of donuts and donut-derivations, coffee, and espresso-based coffees as well. I have tried most everything here (jelly-filled, regular, toppinged, etc.), and I honestly only like their donut holes, and only if they are fresh. I have had this fortuitous timing of buying donut holes right out of the oven, and they are an amazing antidote for your sugar cravings.

They also sell bags of day-old donuts at a discount. I don't recommend it.

A major plus is that this is the ONLY shop that is regularly open past 2 a.m. in this area. They close anywhere from 3 to 4 a.m. (yes, I have been here at that time). This means if you're up studying late and need a coffee and sugar pick-me-up, this is the place to go. Check it out during dead week.

Close to campus.

Unbelievably friendly staff

Very good breakfast in the morning ... cereal, milk, juice, toast, bagel, eggs, bacon, fries, fruit ... more and more

very well appointed rooms

good TV (not LCD, CRT) and 60 channels including HBO

very comfortable beds

very clean, good shower, very good water pressure (unlike the other persons experience)

overall, a comfortable stay .. highly recommended for both business and leisure

This is one of at least 5 bubbletea places on the ave, but it's one of the top 2, along with pochies all the way up the ave. It used to be called gossip, but with the new name change a few years back came better food along with their great selection of bubble tea flavors. I especially love the japanese milk tea here, which I rarely, if ever find at other bubble tea places. Although the seating is limited, the atmosphere is very cool and calm (complete with AC and heating). It is definitely a place to go to if you are a poor college student wanting quick and yummy food/non-alcoholic drinks. The only downside is that they mess your drink up more often than the other places, I have gone there probably over 50 times when I was at the UW and they messed mine up probably almost 10 times total.

Strengths:
  -77 with fish filet (creamy corn fish)
  -74 with chicken (pan fried noodles)

Development areas:
  -All other dishes, especially their pho

How to get 5 stars:
  -Move out of the asian ghetto and stop serving pho
Good lunchboxes and pretty reasonable prices. There's seating upstairs so there's almost never a wait. My only complaint is parking options - but Oakland is always tough.

I must say this place puts both of the conservatories in Chicago as well as the domes in Milwaukee to shame.   It is old, classy, large, varied and their spring flower show -- we caught the last weekend -- was not only beautiful but original and clever.  Should be considered one of the highlights of Pittsburgh.

Deluxe.
Dutch Crunch.
Turkey.
Provolone.
Avocado.
Can't go wrong. Affordable. Perfect for college students!

Hi!

I'm over 40 and not a size 4 anymore, so clearly I am invisible to anyone who works at H&M. Oh wait, never mind, even if you are 16 with daddy's charge card and you are the only one in the store the 18 sales assistants will totally ignore you, so don't lose sleep over it.

Cheap, cheerful and expect it to last one season. 

Once you have those lowered expectations you will be fine.

Good solid burger joint. I'm so glad they opened shop in Pasadena. Since it's a Build-Your-Own burger concept, I think your experience can vary depending on what you get on your burger. 

The garlic aioli sauce is really good, but the russian dressing just tasted mostly like mayo and lacked the usual zing. The bun is too greasy for my taste and not heavy duty enough to hold the burger all together. My bun had pretty much broken up into several crumbly pieces halfway through eating it. The sweet potato fries as well as regular fries were great and come in huge portions (enough for 2).

This place was spectacular and extremely cheap.I have heard this place is a Westwood institution and it lived up to and exceeded all of my expectations.

My family and I came around 3:00 on a weekday. We just walked right up and ordered. Eating an ice cream sandwich here was a religious experience. The cookies were still warm and just the right texture to make for the best ice cream sandwich....EVER! Did I mention it was only $1.50.

I found this place via a yelp search, and went in looking for a drink and some food and a cool place to kill some time.  

The iced chai is good - it tastes like the those I might make myself out of a carton, not a bad thing.

Feeling veggie, I ordered the sweet potato sandwich.  Comes quickly, but looks rather small.  The size is totally made up for by the taste, however, as this tops any sandwich I've had recently.  The combination of soft sweet potato slices, onion, apple, and cheese is killer.

Wifi exists, but doesn't work on my mac for some reason.  Ample outlets upstairs in the nice loft, and ample seating, even on a Saturday lunch hour.  Bare brick interior with local art; spotless restrooms.  There are a couple of big communal tables, which is a good touch, and someone just came by to put flowers on the tables.  Music first sounded sortof like Ben Folds, then some old Coldplay came on, then Elliott Smith.  As others have noted, the staff seems really sweet.  Hope this place does well.

My low star # is primarily due to portion size, cost, & the long line around the corner for just OK food.  For an $8 sandwich I expect it to be bigger, come w/cheese, & be the way I ordered it--it came w/a mystery sauce on it which was not in the sandwich description.  I was hoping for chicken salad, but it was not on the menu the day I was there.  I've heard great things about their cakes...but skipped it when I saw that they were charging almost $4 per cupcake.  Food was fine, but nothing special.

Located outside Franklin Field, this colorful food truck stopped me in my tracks on the way to Potbelly.  Looking at the menu, I saw Korean Tacos, Pork Buns, and Banh Mi sandwiches.  How could I go wrong?  Despite a limited menu, Tyson Bees does not disappoint, and their tacos give crosstown rival Tacos Don Memo (TDM) a run for their money.

The window guy was really nice and they organize all the orders with playing cards, so as soon as you hear your card, your food is ready.  The price for a triplet of tacos is one dollar steeper than TDM, but they are worth every penny and prepared in a similar manner.  Your choice of filling: sweet Korean BBQ short rib, Thai basil chicken, or minced Edamame served on two soft corn tortillas with minimal additional toppings and fresh lime.  While I didn't initially think the Edamame taco would be that good (I'm usually not one for vegetarian cuisine), it was surprisingly flavorful.  The Thai basil chicken taco was exceptional, with a good balance of savory flavors and a hint of heat.  The Korean BBQ taco was a tad too sweet, but still tender and tasty.

Next time I go back, I'm definitely hitting up the Pork Buns.  If they're as good as everyone says they are, this could end up being a new weekly lunch spot.

I don't understand, all this talk about poor service and bad attitude. I have been in so many times to browse their wares and have never felt anything as described here. 
A friend and I started up our summer tennis matches a while back and we both needed to have our strings redone. He went one way & I went here. He payed $65.00 somewhere in Newton and I payed around $40. Jon? did the work for me and recommended a great set of hybrids, based on the strings I had set before. 
Bottom line, we play about six hours a week & not two weeks after the strings were redone, his strings shift all over the racquet & mine have stayed in perfect placement and tension. Awesome work and will return for anything else.

I came here a while ago with some of my friends (back when pho was relatively new on the menu) and I have yet to go back! I was having a major pho craving and since this place looked so crowded, we assumed it was good. (In social psych, this is called social validation.) However, we later found out that this place was always crowded because the service was so slow! We had to ask for the check and a box 3-4 times before they finally brought it to us. =[ 

PHO: I ordered their pho, even though it was over $8! x__x Back at home, I could have gotten 2 orders of pho with that! And it would've tasted 1000x better! My order came out and I found that the noodles they used weren't even pho noodles, the beef came in chunks, the broth tasted off, and the plate of lime/herbs/bean sprout add-ons had carrots on it! CARROTS!! Who puts carrots in pho?? Now I'm not Vietnamese, but I do know that in all my experience with pho, not once have I ever gotten carrots! I was VERY disappointed and my pho craving was not satiated in the least. =[ I would've been better off getting pho from Noodle Planet a few blocks down, but even there, it isn't the greatest and is still overpriced. Ahh, Westwood... what do we need to do to get good Viet food here? *sighz* I was hoping that since our trip, they improved their pho or got a cook who knew how to make it, but judging from the other reviews, it still leaves something to be desired. (At least no one else appears to have gotten carrots! Haha!) So my quest for good pho in the Westwood area continues...

PAD THAI: I'm not really a fan of pad thai, but I tried some of my friend's order. The noodles were nice and chewy and it had good flavor. I was surprised I enjoyed it. If I were to ever go back to Mr. Noodle, I'd probably order the pad thai.

Meh. This place usually has a cover, which to pay means its good inside right?? Nah.. :P it's just okay. Loud bands don't = good bands. Sure there is a slue of fawning women over the bands, just probably standard entourage. Enough about the bands. This place is large enough. When it's packed it's pretty great. Most of the times I've gone it has been around 10 percent capacity (Dead). Wait staff is friendly. Pretty Casual Dress. Good for meeting people, but there's better places.

Pros:

Large Groups
Medium Groups
Small Groups
Good place on a Bar Hopping list
Night-Time 1on1 Dates ( good for a last stop, or on a bar hop list )
Social Atmosphere
indoor and outdoor seating
Cheap Drinks
Good location
Friendly Staff

Cons:

Not my kind of crowd.

Wow, this place has everything you need. It also employes people who know exactly what almost all the beers taste like and how they are made. I have no idea what half the words they say mean, but they usually can pick out a great beer. They have lots of good beers to try, and all of the usual and classic favorites for a good price.

This has to be my most favorite beer store in the world.

i like it! the hummus is creamy and the chicken is tasty. i like the chicken kebobs better than the scharma chicken. the hot sauce is garlicky, which i love! 

BUT, fries are ehhhhhhhhh here. and the eggplants are too greasy! and i wish they had a fountain soda machine, because fountain soda is much better than bottled. but overall tasty stuff!!

I went here with my mom and brother. The best thing I can say about this place is that the service was fantastic. The hostess was gracious, and any waitress that will customize a salad order for a fussy ten year old boy is a saint. 

I had mixed feelings about what I ate. The appetizer of veggie potato wedges was pretty good but a little light on cilantro in my opinion. (The tomatoes weren't perfect either.) My entree was, for me, nearly inedible. I ordered the crispy risotto with portobello mushrooms and tomato sauce. It was the sauce that really tanked this dish. Maybe if I liked Campbell's tomato soup I'd have enjoyed it more.

The place is also famous for its popovers, but I am not crazy about popovers. Once the expansion is finished it'll probably be better for groups.

I love Thanh Vi.  I love that they are so so cheap.  I love their beef pho.  I love their chicken pho even more.  I love the bun.  I love that the servers here remember you after just a few visits even though they obviously have about a million different customers.

I am not crazy about their appetizers.  But everything else is delish.

I was never much of a fan of the pizza here, but they do make a decent burger, and I don't mind their fries.  They're definitely close to campus, so they're convenient for Freshmen, but it's much cheaper to go a few blocks North or West to Cal Pizza, Village Pizza, Ed's, or Mad Greek's.

They sell a few misc. bottles or six-packs of beer, and they of course have a soda fountain for sit-down dining.  Up until the Drexel cafeteria renovation they had the exact same kind of chairs that Drexel's caf did.  I'm not exactly sure what that says about Drexel Pizza, but I think it's generally worth it to walk the extra few blocks to eat elsewhere.

I always try to stop by Time After TIme whenever I'm shopping on West Franklin. I'll agree with William that it seems to be more thrift than vintage to me. The selection turns over pretty regularly, so it's wise to drop in often. I can never really find cute dresses that fit me well, but if the price is reasonable you can always go get it tailored. The real reason I stop by is for the accessories. I found a great bakelite ring there once and I've also picked up several scarves. I usually spend at least an hour in here, so I'd say make sure you have enough time to search.

My aspiring epicure of a little brother called dinner here the "best meal" he'd ever had.  My only problem was that of  indecision: a drink  from the exotic cocktail menu or the encyclopedia of wines?  classic roast chicken (a specialty) or a nicely accessorized piece of fish?  rhubarb tart or a taste of cognac?  This is less of an issue if a parent or  boss is footing the bill, but regardless, it's hard to make a bad choice here.

Okay... wait until after 5:30 then it's HAPPY HOUR! it's like 2.50 for a hot dog...

but one time I went there and got a turkey dog... those beautiful people gave me two dogs in one bun... they are so naughty in a GOOD way!

grilled onions and peppers... on the HOUSE! all kinds sauce, all kinds FRIES! all kinds chips and drinks!

It's right on Sproul... it's so limpia and sabroso wtf amazing! if you go there, say hi to the ugly alien weird creature lady painted on the truck for me
I have discovered the omelette making station, the salad making station, the sandwich making station!!!!! Awesomeness in a grocery store.  :)  I'm in love!!
Owner is super friendly! Knows a lot about cloth diapering!

This place cracks me up! There are all kinds of crazy objects all over the walls and ceilings and I'm sure they haven't changed any of the decor in forever. The service is very matter of fact and so is the food.
Everything is tasty, but my favorite thing is their pancakes! They are sooo good and I'm a total pancake snob. Definitely nothing fancy so don't go in with any lofty expectations. Just take in the scene and enjoy some good and very inexpensive diner food! There is nothing else like it.

I heard really good things about this place from staff. I went in to seriously buy a used bike at the end of the school year and the staff basically ignored me.

I hear they do a great job with service and repair, and they do buy tons of used bikes from students. They just didn't seem that interested in educating or assisting a customer. Still, I would take the bike I got somewhere else here if I needed help with a flat or something.

I used to frequent this place a lot back when I was living in Austin. Back then, it was called Mojos and it was an eclectic late night coffee junkie hangout with a side of crazy. It was truly unique and it remains so. The hookah is good (I tried blue mist) and service is friendly and fair. BYOB if you want to cool off your smoke.

Love. Love. Love. That's right I, "Jess N." enjoyed the outdoors! For a city girl or a nature enthuisiast this can be the most amazing view you'll ever get of Boston. 

If you do not resemble the Hulk or Ronnie from the Jersey Shore, try paddling out on a less windy day. It will save you some aches and pains the next day. Also,  a double kayak can make a kayaking adventure romantic or fun with friends. Just remember it's a kayak, not a UHaul. Do not bring everything but the kitchen sink. 

Parking in this area was a breeze! There were plenty of meters in the area so bring quarters. There's also a parking garage and a public restroom where the ice skating rink is in the winter. 

Want to know a secret? If you check in on Facebook you can occasionally get a discounted rate! We rented a double kayak for around $15!

The buns alone are worth the five stars here!  Spike's has all sorts of awesome topping combinations, great fries and veggie dogs.
