The food is cheap, the staff is nice and the cookies are as big as your head.  The Thayer St. frat boy scene is indeed annoying, but these dogs make it well worth the trip.

Best blueberry pancakes in town, hands down. Everything is home-grown and organic. One of my favorite breakfast places, although dinner isn't bad.  This Guadalupe location is where all the students go, and it's where I lived when I was at UT, but now I go to the one on Research.  The wait there is just as long on the weekends.

I live around the corner from this place and I love Indian food, so when I first moved in I was excited.

It looked like a real Indian restaurant like the kinds that are all over San Francisco.  You know, like Shalimar, Pakwan, Naan n' Curry and friends.  Old decor, cheap prices, great food.

Except, scratch the great food part.  In fact it's not just not great, it's absolutely terrible.  No joke, worst food I've ever been served in a restaurant, ever.

I tried, oh I tried.  It's so convenient, and the prices are so right.  I went back three times.  Meats, no go.  Veggies, worse.

I really wish this place would close so that a real restaurant could move in.  I really don't understand how it stays in business in the first place.

If you like undercooked pancake batter naan, rubbery meat and watery curries with little to no spice, this is your place.  Otherwise, run!

Papamingo's definitely my place to go on Monday when I'm craving frozen yogurt.  Why?  Because it's ONLY 25 cents per ounce on Mondays.  

Here's the scoop about their quality: people are saying that it's icier compared to other places.  Well, since it's relatively warm or hot most days in Berkeley, I don't have a problem with that.  In fact, I think their plain frozen yogurt is a good balance between creamy and tart.  

Currently, the two flavors I have been getting are plain and mango.  I usually top it with one kind of fruit and mochi.  I'm pretty sure all the frozen yogurt places get their mochi from the same vendor because one time Papamingo and Yogurtland both had rainbow mochi instead of white mochi.  Sometimes if you're lucky, there will be green apple or melon flavored mochi!  It was there two weeks ago I think.  

GOOD: Self serve, 25 cents/oz on Monday, super nice Korean owner, four different cup sizes to choose from
BAD: Only six flavors to choose from, and it's been like that for almost 4 months.

It's a shame that Papamingo isn't frequented more by Cal students.  If all the people who went to Yogurtland during the day and night tried Papamingo, they'd know better.

I suppose I should review this place... but don't expect anything spectacular.  It's off to the side of the Shell station in a little shack house with a picnic table setting on the side.  After having tacos al pastor in mexico for $0.60, I am a bit hesitant to pay $2.10 for some carne asada ones... but we are in SLO.

The tacos were pretty good, but for the price I paid, I probably won't go back to get them.  They said there would be guacamole.. BUT NO GUACAMOLE!  The meat was pretty good, not piping hot.. but still good.  The horchata at $2.50 for a Large is the same as El Nabor, but there is some nasty aftertaste (like soap?) I prefer El Nabor's, it's got some distinct creamy taste I like.  Maybe if the sign is true and this place was open 24/7 I'd prolly drop by at like 2am before going to Chili Peppers.  Oh yeah, and they take credito/debito!

Yawn, boring review!!! teehee..

This is not the best I ever had but its cheap and better than most; emphasis on cheap but there is always a line (damn UCLA).

If in LA, this is a must try place like some of the classics and its easy on your pockets and brownies are great too

If you are going to eat  here, order the unlimited coffee mug. You can get refills of all the different flavors.

I had eggs, corned beef hash, with toast and home fries.

The place is cute, but unfortunately nothing worth writing home about.

So there was a booth with at this past weekend's Big Apple BBQ Event and it was Rack & Soul's. It was hidden behind the massive line that was for Salt Lick (I don't know what the wait was for because it wasn't that good). Rack & Soul - now there's some ribs that were worth it. There wasn't much of a line and we were able to get a tasting of their ribs really easily. Out of all the rib places that we tried this past weekend, I'd have to say Rack & Soul came out the winner for us. It definitely makes me want to try out the actual restaurant itself if I'm ever around the area.
I've been a customer of Dave's since he first opened on Holly St. just west of Fair Oaks.  Very customer centric.  I've enjoyed shopping and working there.

Avoid if possible - Asian Legend is just around the corner and is infinitely better. If for some reason you have mo choice but to eat at TK Wu, stick with the beef noodles. That is the only dish remotely edible. My condolences.

This is a place I stopped in because it looked inviting, and it was.  There's enormous selection in paninis, all made with high quality ingredients, and the soup I had was prepared well with freshly shredded parmesan and toasted bread on the side.  I'd love this place more if it had a little more space (it can get pretty crowded, especially at lunchtime) and perhaps was a little less expensive.  That being said, it's still worth getting a large hot nutella on a cold day - beats many SBUX choices!

LOVE UCLA! 

goooooooo bruins! 

F*ck  $C!

Yes, you get to DRINK ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES inside the museum....that and that alone should be worth the 5 stars.... I have been here both for first fridays and just as a little outing and i love it.

Theres just something about this museum that takes me back to my childhood fieldtrip days and eating ham sandwiches out on the huge lawn while playing tag and waiting for the busses to pick us up in front, definetly nostalgic for any kid who grew up in L.A. 

and now being able to spend an evening with friends chit chatting over prehistoric mammals, oggling rare gems and sitting in front of huge hippo habitat diorama with beer in hand, makes for awesome new memories... I love it. Its a must both on first fridays and during regular hours.
All it's got going for it is that its better than Fat Slice...That's about it. I hate these thick pizzas!

Of the two cafes in Berkeley that I can actually productively study at, this is one of them.  I'm not a coffee person but their food items aren't spectacular, but not bad either.  The focaccia they serve with their soup is delish.  

The big thing for me here is the atmosphere.  The music is non invasive and the upper level is pretty peaceful and a good place to stay focused on reading.  It's a nice place to get a little respite from Berkeley.

This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Their brunch is amazing. I had the french toast with caramelized bananas and pecans, and it comes with this amazing maple butter that Clinton St Baking Co also has... which is just simply HEAVEN. SOOOOO good. 
For dinner, you can never go wrong with the rice bowl. Also had the burger, which was deelish. I can't give this place enough stars. They rock my world. 
They had a kitchen fire about 6 weeks ago and still haven't re-opened, sadly. Cant wait until they're open again!

Went here for some quick drink and the bartender was nice and quick.  They have many beers on tap from Bass Ale to Widmers Pear Cider.

They check ID's to cover their ass folks, not to bother you.  

And LOL to the mice party behind the dart board!

Grading the burgers here cause I haven't tried anything else. 

Simply put, I probably will never try anything else except the burgers cause it's that amazing! The meat is thick and juicy and just right. Fries are real nice too. I like to order them on the crispy side. Who cares about decor? It's a blast to the past with some amazing food. Enough said. Let's eat! 

FYI: Cash or local checks, no credit cards please.

After experiencing several Chinese restaurants in Upland this one is by far the best.  From the staff (most of which have been there for years and years) to the decor and most importantly the food (great sized portions and very flavorful) you will NOT be disappointed.

Went at 7:45 pm on a Sat PM and they had already sold out of three items on the menu.  When the menu only has about 10 items on it - I call that pretty poor planning.  Salads were fine.  Entrees were good but fish portions were so tiny we wondered if they were running out of the ingredients and cutting portions in half.  Our entrees were the size of small plate portions.  We are used to eating contemporary cuisine and don't expect Big Boy portions, but it was truly shameful to charge $24 for this portion of fish.  It should have been a $15 small plate.  Decor is nice and simple.  Love the size of the restaurant.  Love that the place is not pretentious.  Still I would not go back.

My wife and I often have to visit the Univ of Penn Hospital. I have found this to be the excellent restaurant within walking distance. Most of the food is good. Excellent pub atmosphere. Some tables outside. I recommend the fajitas (ask for a couple extra tortillas).

I think it's a great place to go get some Mexican without too much grain.  Their powerplate comes with a lot of meat and great grilled onions, but I kinda wish there were more than just squash for grilled vegetables.  That is pretty typical for most places though.  The beans are very tasty with a little spice to them.  The service is friendly and its quick which is good for a place that serves organic.

Texas Fight! UT Austin is one of the best schools in the nation..  We are located in one of the best towns, while having great academics and great looking coeds. UT Football, Basketball, & Baseball.. just icing on the cake. For all you Ohio St fags..  Go Blue.. I hope Michigan crushes you this year.

Hookem Horns!

Nice outdoor seating in the summer months, with a neighborhoody feel. Not cheap, but reasonable for delicious Italian. Candle-lit and cozy at night. I very much enjoyed the lighter-than-air gnocchi, fennel and arugula salad, and tiramisu!

In the words of Tina Turner, 

"You're simply the best, better than all the rest..."
As a Korean family, we are 100% disappointed. Korean foods there are too salty and spicy as well as expensive. Service was slow and unresponsive.

Cafe Fresh, you are almost everything my heart desires.  Organic coffee, nice atmosphere, free wifi, nice seating.

Why the heck are you so far out of the way, then!?  Sheesh.

This place is great for those who live near it or go to Columbia.  But it's far more of a trek from the subway than I'd like.  Too bad, for it is lovely!  But I'd only come here for writing if someone desperately wanted to be here.
Good coffee, close to UC. Parking is almost non- existant in this busy place, expect to park 3-4 blocks away. Nice outdoor heat lamps

Okay, three things:
1) The main draw to Pie 'n Burger is the atmosphere.  Genuine oldschool lunch counter atmosphere.
2) The burgers are amazing, the pie is even better
3) I am STILL burning off the calories from my first visit three years ago.  

Go.  And get an angioplasty on the side.

Love the Coliseum!!! Practically cause the Trojans wreaks shop here. Concession stands have a variety of foods from different cultures. Been there twice, heckled some sun devil and beaver fans. Go USC! Fight On!!!

In the beginning I didn't like this place, but I finally found 1 dish that i like.  I always came back for it, but that's all.  The service is ok and the dining area is a bit dirty/sticky.  But just take it to-go and you won't have an issue.

Yay for Angkor!  Yay for their Nam-yaa soup!  Yay for their street noodles!  Yay for their homemade Thai Chili paste...which is like a nuclear bomb exploding in your mouth.  Yay for their Chive Pancakes with a mixutre of hot/peanut sace to coat them with.  

Yay for Angkor!  You have to try this place...Since being back in Providence I have eaten there at least twice a week.  

Don't try their desserts.  Drinks are overpriced so I stick with water while there.  

And yeah...the nam yaa soup...oh yeah!

Ordered a lot of things on the menu. The Nachos Libres Encarnacion are nachos on steroids. The nachos are topped with cheese, beef, refried beans, and cilantro. Can you ask for more? We did. The atun ceviche was good but not spectacular. The tacos were great - I would go with mahi mahi and pork. The pato huaraches were good as was the queso fundido but the tamales were fantastic. The main issue I had was that we ordered way too much and the waiter didn't stop us, not that it was such a big deal. Food was good and the place was decked out with Lucho Libre masks so it had a cool vibe to it.

I LOVED China Gate Restaurant!

I had the Pho Bac and the Pork Fried Rice and it was the best I've had outside of New York City and California. The service was fast and efficient and the food was delicious and a lot for the price. I am going to be back to try the Dan Dan Noodles (which you rarely find outside of big cities) and the Beef Chow Fun and the dumplings. Superb!

I was strolling through West Lafayette looking for a non chain place to get my grub on and found Parthenon. Seeing I just left Chicago without having Greek food, I was stoked because this would be my fix. Like Lauren said, it was has a chain feel to it and I was the only person there on a Friday afternoon. I blame the emptiness on being in a college town during the summer time. Staff was friendly and prompt. I ordered a gyro, fries and soda and it chapped my butt a bit to pay $9.995 but oh well, I need a gyro stat. 

Food came out and everything was fresh and I could barely fold the gyro over because there was so much meat. Maybe paying an extra buck or two wasn't such a bad thing? I got a to go box for my pup to put some of the meat in and went on my way with wolfing down the sandwich. The meat wasn't seasoned too much but it was cooked just right. The tzatziki lacked flavor as well so that was a bit of a let down. It looked like they had some veggie options as well which is always nice, of course if I were to go back, I would want to bring a veggie friend just so I could say "What do you mean you don't eat no meat??"

Papa Del, you are one overrated sonofabitch.  Your pizza is edible, but just not the real deal, and your service blows.  You're a staid Chambana eatery, and I respect that, but I just don't think we can be friends.

They double booked our couples massage room on Valentine's Day and canceled our appointment.  We rescheduled the appointment for another day. In my two encounters with receptionist, I couldn't help but notice her attitude. If it wasn't for the amazing massage by Eve, this would've been a 1 star review. It was the best massage I have ever had. 5 stars for the massage.

A decent option near school.
Wowshi and falafels, yum!
Cheap eats, I'd go back.

Probably one of the better boba shops around campus.

The drinks are good, the boba is chewy, the food is yummy (and cheap!), and the service is really friendly-- what more could you want?

The service is pretty speedy considering there is usually just one employee. THEY ACTUALLY SPEAK ENGLISH HERE, AND YOU CAN UNDERSTAND THEM, unlike other shops where I feel like I only understand what is being chirped at me because I'm from an Asian family (Quicklys, Sweetheart, I'm looking at you).

One of the most impressive things about this shop is that their straws are individually wrapped! No longer will I have to reach into a communal bucket of straws after Lord knows who has stuck their grubby, disease infested hands into the bucket and thereby infecting all the straws with some new pestilence.

As someone that frequents this shop way more than I should, I can in very good faith call out all the low rating people as dipshits. I eat here on a weekly basis and have never once gotten sick from the food. Maybe they've been shoveling so much garbage food down their gullets that the moment something that wasn't processed entered their stomach it felt it had to purge it from the system? Just a thought.

My female namesake's ROTD today piqued my pop-interest.

Super nice people, great story (hanging on the wall)... basically the owner's two girls graduated from UT and decided to stay in Austin (didn't we all).  So mom and dad sold their donut business, moved to Austin, and started a mom and pop pop shop.

Taste whatever you want (very nice perk).  I bought a small bag of their most popular, the dill.  And now I'm sharing it with everyone (even strangers) in the coffee shop.  Everyone loves it.

====================================

UPDATE:  No lie... I go 3 times a week.  The owner (Mark) and his daughters (Courtney and Chelsea) know me by name.  I've taken close to a dozen people and all of them are now raving fans.  Trust me, I was skeptical at first... "popcorn... come on, how good can it be."  But I am not only a convert but an evangelist.  Ask to try the Dill Pickle and the Zebra (or if they are out the Cinnamon Roll). 

And tell them Don sent you.

I must say, this is quite an interesting treasure shop.  It's PACKED with: pipes, smoking accessories, bongs, adult items, candles, incense, stuff on the ceiling, tapestries, buddhas, and just a ton of crap everywhere.  In a good, but dusty, way, though.  Especially the incense and candles--the dust is starting to build cities and highways.

But!  This place, ironically enough, has one of the better buddha collections that I have run across.  They have a few of the small, one inch tall ones and even more large figures, around six inches, but the joy here is sifting through all of the medium priced buddhas, around $10 or $15.  Yes, most of them are ancient, but that's how they're supposed to be, right? For weeks, I have been searching for a figure that I finally found here, that oh so special one that calls me without speaking, moves me without effort, teaches me without knowing.

Or at least that was my experience here.

The Friendly Toast was amazing when it was only in New Hampshire, and now it's brought the amazingness to Kendall Square.

The staff is friendly, the decor is vintage, and the restaurant itself is a pleasure to be in. Few other restaurants offer such a delightful experience even before you order your food.

As for the food itself - prepare yourself. The portions are generous and everything is packed full of flavor. Whether you're headed for breakfast, lunch, or dinner, you'll leave full. The appetizers are delicious, especially the nacho platter. If you are feeling adventurous, order a "Hello Silo". It's a local specialty you can't get at their Portsmouth location, but alone makes the visit worth it.

Go with friends, share each other's company and enjoy the decor, and leave happy and full!
This is now called Artistry Chocolate, I suspect a buy out.
Their last day open is tomorrow. We are sorry you had to close :(

Bear Basics is the place to go if you are in need of cheap, knockoff Cal paraphernalia. The CAL merchandise is not the best quality, but it will last you through a football season. This huge store keeps changing its name, so it is sometimes confusing. Just look for the big glass windows on Telegraph.
This is not the primary reason I am an avid Bear Basic shopper. I go for the local Bay Area t-shirts and sweatshirts. I buy all my "Am I not cool in my East Bay cranes shirt?" gifts for non-locals at this shop.
Today, however, I discovered the basement, and I am now in love with the dirty little secret. They call it  The T-shirt orgy, and they are so right. We were on the hunt for a communist party shirt, a very specific one. Did you know these are hard to find?
I walked into the basement and heard a choir singing! I could shop here for hours, and find novelty t-shirts for all of my friends.
Comic book shirts, movie slogans, political satire, religious icons, fighting dolphins, crude humor, nostalgic 80's images. You name it, they got it. My husband finally had to drag me out  before I spent our entire Christmas budget on t-shirts!

Expensive, decadent, old-school steakhouse done right.  Tucked away between the Melting Pot and Cafe Japengo, you walk in and immediately feel like busting out a cigar.

Saturday night and the lights are low... and we walk in with no reservations, party of 5.  No problemo, they seat us in a big fat booth and the waiter is seriously just the nicest.  I think they really know how to train them there, because I was blown away by how down-to-earth he was.  Most waiters sorta just list off whatever is popular/expensive when you ask them what's good in THEIR opinion, but this guy just made me feel like, "Hey, it's alright that you're a noob here. I'll take care of ya even if you're not ordering any wine."

We scarfed down the celery/crisps with their signature wine-infused cheeses, seconds were gladly distributed.  The Mahi-Mahi had a divine mushroom sauce, Rib-Eye w/o Bone was excellent, but I have to say that the Fleming's Potatoes was a huge letdown, ick.  Also, its a bit boring to see absolutely NOTHING on a plate except a slab of meat and a few sprinkles of parsley.

Anyway, big portions, big price.  Next time I'm going in on a Sunday so I can get me a prime rib.  And try a cocktail or two.  And watch the waiters balance ten hot dinner plates on one arm (no trays ma!).  And steal more chocolate mints.

PS.  If you're a poor college kid like me, free parking in the Hyatt!  Just get validation.

Carolina Brewery is one of the first places I think of going when I'm looking for somewhere casual to meet people on Franklin Street. The bar serves brews made by the Carolina Brewery (duh) and has a pretty decent menu full of your typical bar food.

The place is pretty big, making it a great place to meet a large group (our dinners usually end up being 8-10 of us). They have televisions all over the place if you need to catch the Carolina game going on, and the wait staff is typically pretty attentive, even when they're exceptionally busy.

LOVE LOVE LOVEEEEEEEEEEEEEE the donuts here.  By far the best in the area.  I had no idea it even existed though until I moved to the great city of 'Vliet.  It's a local legend and for great reason.  The glazed are heavenly, other donuts in the area can NOT even compare.  Def a great place to check out for the donuts and many many other baked goods as well.

Overall I've been to better carwashes but i did have them touch up some spots they missed and jerry was awesome! He apologized like three times and got every last spot! He was really awesome and genuinely wanted to make my experience as pleasant as possible! So will I return? Because of Jerrys customer service yes!

I never really had a problem with Einstein Bros Bagels until today.  I usually go because it's a convenient location before I have to go to work.  However, their customer service is absolutely horrible.  

Surprisingly, they were not busy during lunch hour and so I was checked out faster than I expected.  Yet, as I waited for my order I slowly started to notice that people who had ordered after me were getting their order before me.  At that point of time, I had already waited 20 minutes for my order which was just a turkey tornado with a side of potato salad.  When I pointed this out to the cashier, patiently waiting for him to check out the last person, before informing him.  He went to the other 4 workers to ask them when my order would be made.  

They told informed him that it would be soon but proceeded to make 3 more orders that were not mine.  Unapologetically, they finally gave me my order...but by then my patience was gone.  Bagels are decent enough but seriously?  NOT EVEN WORTH IT.  I'm going somewhere else on the drag for lunch.

I agree with Saenam and Minou... the service is terrible.

I can see the appeal of this cafe to people who'd like to be left alone with their studies, but the staff can at least say hello, or acknowledge your existence once seated. I settled down at the cafe yesterday late afternoon and after what seemed like eternity of trying to make eye contact with the waitress, she plopped the menus on the table and walked away. It then took her another eternity (as if it were possible) to come back and say "what do you want?" 

After ordering a glass of wine (which according to the menu was half price due to happy hour from 5-7pm) and antipasto max, I didnt hear or see anyone until I packed my bags and went up to the register to pay. 

It was only til then when the waitress notified me that happy hour is now only wednesday and friday. thanks a lot. 

this really wouldn't have bothered me and would have probably still ordered the same thing had the staff been more welcoming.

Fabulous espresso.  But every few months the dishwasher breaks down for a month.  They go "all paper cups"  even though most other serious places in same situation will still give their espresso drinkers porcelain.  They don't seem to want to employ a dish washer, even though the markup on coffee is great.  Not very green strategy.  And why do I continue to tip if the staff are unwilling to wash dishes every few hours?  Well, the espresso is still fabulous.

mi luna is definitely a fun place to visit if you're wanting tapas or would like to mingle for salsa dancing.  they also serve good drinks.  

here is my take on dishes I remember trying:

1)  Paella: not the best I've had, but it wasn't too bad.  
2)  Beef Empanadas: these were actually quite scrumptious
3)  B'Stilla: the phyllo dough is quite great
4)  Lengue con Nueces: this was alright, but there's room for improvement

mi luna is also a great place for happy hour, as they serve $5 margaritas $3 Sangria & beers, as well as $3 selected tapas and tostas.

the service isn't the greatest, but it's a nice place to people watch if you're able to grab a seat out in the patio.

this is one of the best chinese (mandarin and szechuan cuisine) restaurants in Massachusetts. The Dun Dun noodles is great! It's spicy, peanut-y noodles. We also tried the chicken velvet - ok (i'm not a big fan of egg) and the spicy bean curd with chicken - yummy! Today we tried the mini pork steamed bun with vegetables. They are awesome!

A straightforward no frills kind of place but the food is pretty good. Simple menu with some soul food classics plus you get the 2 sides options which is always a treat for the foodies that need to nibble on a few different things! I had the pulled pork once and then tried the catfish my second time there. The catfish was fresh and was still quite flaky and not dry. The batter was also not too oily.

Huge portions which definitely put you into a food coma. Overall, a great addition to the Morningside Heights area. Go hungry!

Do I like The Blue Room?
Well, I do and I don't.
I really liked the food.  Everything was thoughtfully prepared with fresh, inventive ingredients.  My favorites were the "perfect cheese", Gruyere that night with raspberries, pistachios and apple slices (that were on the mushy side) and the chicken liver ravioli.
I didn't like the options on their menu, however.  It seemed like there was always one ingredient too much pushing me to a point where I dismissed an entire dish simply b/c one ingredient made it sound less palatable.
Also, they only have one chicken dish, one beef dish, one pork dish, one veggie dish.  I could have had more options in that area, which is why I went with an appetizer instead.
Lots of cool kitschy things make this place look pretty hip: the menu is attached to a clipboard with rubber bands; the chairs are plastic; very open room contrasts the low ceilings and makes it seem like a bigger space.
Service was very friendly.
Everything was pleasant, although I was not impressed enough to make it a place I automatically think of whenever I wanna throw down some dough in Kendall Square.

I refer to this restaurant as the "bong-bong" place bc you walk in and they bong the drums to announce to other patrons that you've arrived! Better not have a bad hair day. Agedashi tofu is great. Salmon skin hand roll is okay. I wasn't crazy about their Spicy tuna though someone posted a pic of their spicy tuna and mine didn't look like the one in the pic. Might of been an off night.  Chicken balls were okay. Vegetable croquettes were good.Yes, I am one of those that orders the classic beef teriyaki. What can I say, I love my beef!! I felt it was pretty good in comparison to other places. Tempura is fantastic. I definitely will be coming back and will try other dishes. Hopefully next time the spicy tuna will be better. This place is several notches up from Ichima.

Great venue, very convenient, good acoustics. This is a local treasure, not just a concert hall but a comprehensive school with half-a-dozen performance spaces. Parking was an issue when I was last there, but that may only be because there was a big lacrosse match at the same time.

I used a giftcard to have my color touched up at Element. They have a very nice, well-decorated space - very upscale. The staff, on the other hand, was a bit under-trained for their surroundings. When I pay $100+ for a root touch-up, I expect to have first class service. Unfortunately, the receptionist was young and unprofessional, my stylist was wearing a tee with jeans, and they were all chomping gum and giggling together in a side room the whole time I was there. Talk about alienating higher-end clients... I watch Tabatha's Salon Takeover, I know how these things should be done people!

Anyway, my stylist was very nice but just a bit unprofessional in regards to her banter with me. I also ended up walking out with WET hair... she gave me a deep conditioning treatment after the color, neglected to tell me she would send me home without washing it out or doing a blowout for me. Seriously... it was a bit ridiculous. I couldn't figure out what was going on. She did a nice job on the color though, which I only found out AFTER I went home, rinsed my hair and dried it myself. Seriously, I paid over 100 dollars for the service. Should have been much better, in my opinion.

Opening Day was this morning!!!!

How amazing that in our neighborhood, we have both Silver Moon and Levain to choose from. 

Limited but phenomenal selection included various cookies, banana bread, muffin, scone..  I was particularly touched by the blueberry muffin.  I am not a muffin person, as I tend to find them either too bready, dense, or gummy.  But this was just the way I dream of it from childhood - moist, light, wonderful blueberry flavor plus a crispy and large "muffin top" (thank you Seinfeld).  I could eat one every day.  And the cookies are very thick, moist, rich but not obscenely so.  Seriously great.

This Levain's selection is much more limited than Silver Moon, which has options from bread to cakes.

for some reason i like la burrita better than fancier mexican restaurants. i get the enchilada taco plate which is my favorite. i like how they dont smother the enchilada in the sauce and they fill up the entire box. this is the food to  eat when you are starving but are too busy to walk to the swankier northside gourmet ghetto b/c of finals. la burrita really fills me up.

the things that i don't like is that they dont give you that much tortilla chips,  and if you order to-go w/ a friend they will combine ur chips in one bag so they dont have to give you as much. also, the stupid little containers for salsa are annoying since i have to get at least 6 of them for my meal, which really annoys the lady w/ the freckles.

The food use to be good, but this place is falling apart! The walls have holes, they are always out of stuff on their menu, their furniture is runned down and dirty, and the staff is poorly trained and offers horrible service. The table and menus were even sticky and not cleaned! When we asked to see the manager or owner we've been told that she is never there which makes me really skeptical about how well this business is being run... Even worse, the restaurant and bathrooms are a mess and dirty which raises a huge concern about the cleanliness of the kitchen... EW. I'll never return or go to any other business ran by this owner ever again.
Damn huge burritos that won't break the bank, but will delight your taste buds. This place is almost always pretty packed, and there's a good reason for it!

I love Universe City Yoga. I especially love the founder Richelle. Her classes are fun, challenging and she is SO MUCH FUN! 

For me yoga is incredibly relaxing, but after recently taking some yoga classes with some yogis who take themselves way to seriously taking a class with Richelle was so refreshing! She is funny and engaging, incredibly knowledgeable and best of all she knows that the main reason we are doing yoga is to let ourselves go. 

Because Universe City Yoga is just starting up the classes I've taken have been super small (myself, my friend(s) and one additional person). This has made it easier to get personal instruction and have more fun. 

I hope this studio gets the attention it deserves. Richelle has a big heart and passion for yoga that is refreshing and inviting.
My big fat Greek disappointment. Food is bland, service is slow, baklava is soggy and there was standing water at the bottom of my Greek salad.

Quite the disappointment. Being from California, you always hear stories/tales/legends about philly cheesesteaks from Philadelphia. I half expected that even the fast food philly steak would be at least a smidgen better than what we out on the west coast. Boy, was I wrong. 

First off, what a rip off. We paid 9 dollars for the smallest cheese steak in the world. Second, everything was tasteless inside :( The cheese was not impressive (stringy, hot, melt-y) like I hoped for. The steak was not anything special. My advice is to "not come here", but I understand the feeling that "you must". It's true... eventhough this place sucked.. I can say forever that I had a philly cheese steak in Philadelphia.

My sister and I were very disappointed with both our manicures and our pedicures.  We both agreed they were the worst we've ever paid for.  We both have natural nails.  My sister's nails were still very jagged and uneven at the tips.  So were mine, but not as bad.  The polish is uneven and messy on both our fingers and toes.  Ugh.  We got gel manicures and regular pedicures.  The worst part about the manicure being so bad is that because it's gel, it's going to be really hard to get off.  The whole attitude and process was kind of rude and inattentive.  What a waste of 60 dollars.  ($50 +$10 tip)  Yeah, we still tipped.  We just won't go back.  I don't know why the other reviews are so good...  I used yelp to choose this place, and I was so sad all day looking at my hands.  :-(

This was the first place I ordered off of when I got my food through collegebite.com.  I must have misread that their delivery is free, but it was $1 with a minimum order of $10.  Delivery took an hour, but I gave them the benefit of the doubt that something came up.

After having fallen in love with lomo saltado over summer back in LA (at the much cheaper price of 5.99 that also included a cup of soup), I ordered the Lomo Saltado here for 11 bucks.  Granted it is a tad expensive for the ingredients that go into a lomo saltado, i was still CRAVING it. I also ordered an extra serving of Aji, the peruvian green-colored sauce.  Even with both servings of Aji, it was far from enough for me.  But regardless! The beef was slightly overcooked, but the dish definitely did satisfy my craving for what I wanted. They also did not provide enough rice for my liking, so I simply heated and added a bit of leftover rice I had in my fridge.  On the positive side, I was happy with the portions; it definitely filled me up for the rest of the night!

Next time, I'm going to try to go to the restaurants itself to see if they offer unlimited Aji through a squeeze bottle or something.  Rotisserie chicken isn't my thing, but I will definitely be ordering this dish from them again, given that other peruvian places near my apartment don't offer lomo saltado (e.g. La Feria).

This is a must stop 4 every visitor of Atlanta! Take some Tums & make sure your doctor clears you for this heartburn and greasy spoon experience.  I had the chili dog, chili burger, onion rings, 'Frozen Orange' (AKA: FO) and of course a hot fried peach pie.  I got one more pie to go and had it with breakfast 2 days later and it was delicious with a fresh cup of coffee.  

Going downtown to this location is a must, I heard the food is better at this location.  I am not sure why, but the locals told me so!
So I went back and was not disappointed.  Staff was very pleasant (Thanks Kitty!) and the food was good.  Sushi was excellent.  I will be back!

For $1 an hour, you can spend an entire day exploring Telegraph Ave the the Cal campus for super cheap. My friends & I wanted to get some shopping & eating in before heading over to the Ashby Stage not too far away & this was the cheapest, most convenient parking location. The lot is not too big, but it wasn't busy yesterday so we had no trouble finding an open spot. You put your dollar bills into the machine, pick the number of hours you will be staying & out pops a ticket that you put on your windshield. Cash only, they do not take coins & they do not give change.

A big thumbs up for their creative, health conscious and extremely yummy menu.  I feel the need to warn readers who haven't been there - this isn't typical pizza.  The first time I had it I thought the dough was prepared in a dehydrator, not an oven (this is not a bad thing, just different) because it's thin and unusual and a bit chewy.  The toppings are awesome, and the salads and soups are great as well.  Tofu croutons, hooray!  Friends of mine have raved about the mac and cheese but I have never tried it.  Any "pizza" you want can be prepared on their bread or over a bowl of rice.  Very yummy and very unique.

This review is strictly for their wedding cakes.  I attended my friend's wedding reception on 6/17/11 which was at the Lindley Scott House.  Overall presentation of the cake was nice and neat.  But the taste well that is a different story.

I had the opportunity to try their black and white cake with mocha buttercream and their banana cake with banana cream.  Both cakes were pretty disappointing as they were dry and not very flavorful.  The buttercream icing was not very tasty either and had an unappealing consistency.   I think....no I know that I have tasted better cakes from Vons or Albertsons or maybe even Costco or Sams!  

If you are looking for someone to make your wedding cake, try somewhere else.   My husband and I had our wedding cake done by Rossmoor in Signal Hill and had a far better outcome. :)  Or even better, try Scrumptious Wedding Cakes in the city of Orange. They have  fabulous and unique cake flavors and fillings.

I can only speak to the ice cream, as it is all I have had at Fran's, but wow it's good. You won't need a lot, as the portions are respectable and the ice cream is rich and flavorful. For ice cream, this is my favorite spot in Seattle.

Disclaimer: I worked here all through college as a work-study student. I loved it. The job was easy and fun, I worked with some of the best people I've ever had the luck of working with and being around art day in and day out was wonderful. 

Contemporary art isn't really my cup of tea (I'm more of a traditionalist at heart) but I've seen some incredible exhibits pass through the Henry. Lichtenstein, Kim Jones, Maya Lin, so many wonderful and inspiring works of art that inspire creativity and consideration. The Henry's build crew tailors the downstairs space to each exhibit, which is amazing work and dedication. The annual UW MFA show is always fun and worth a visit. The James Turrell Skyspace is also a great place to sit on a sunny day and quietly reflect. If you like modern/contemporary art and want to expand your horizons, the Henry will challenge you.

Errr... not great. I've definitely had better. It was justa  convenient place to go because of CP. But I defintiely try not to go when possible-which I had been successful at not going.

Chips were stale... Maybe that's suppose to be authentic. But whatever it was, I would not go again.

What a great addition to The Ave! The decor is open, airy and clean; you forget that this place was once a dirty, cramped Chinese restaurant.

This place has all the regular standby Thai noodle dishes available at every other Thai restaurant in the area, but also has amazing unique dishes. My first time I got the Wonton soup with egg noodles. The broth is flavorful and slightly spicy from white pepper (which I think they really love here), with nice additions of bok choy. The wontons themselves were pretty good considering this is a Thai restaurant. The noodles also seem very fresh. 

Recently, I tried the spinach noodle dish with duck. This dish is AMAZING. A little pricy for The Ave at 10 bucks, but for duck and well prepared noodles I don't mind. The spinach noodles seem very fresh and are a nice refreshing alternative to egg and rice noodles, especially when served with such a rich protein as duck. You will not be sorry for ordering this dish. Can't wait to order this again!

Well, since I frequent this cafe almost everyday, I figured I should finally review it.  The croissants and coffee here are definitely above the quality present at Starbucks, so as a morning wake-up cafe - it succeeds.

However, the service is always somehow antagonistic yet simultaneously bewildered at their role within the cafe.  They are a whirling pattern of employees behind the cash register, but they seem unable to get beyond a slow trickle of orders coming out.

Most importantly, don't ever ask to alter something on the menu, b/c it either won't come out or the request will simply be ignored.  I'm not referring to some complex vegan order here - I asked them to put an egg on a bagel (something mysteriously missing from their menu), but somehow the bagel arrived nicely toasted sans egg...

Great location, lots of potential, a bit of a let down

Probably one of my favorite restaurants in the city of Atlanta. My brother took me here late one Sunday night and I fell in love. When I go I order the spicy garlic chicken.  Delicious!!! The portions are big and the price is exceptional.  I always have food to bring home when I eat there.
Not a place for a woman that is over a size 8- and it is a little overpriced. better luck and finds at the Ballard Goodwill. But if you're a teen or a very thinowman than have fun!

This is by far one of the best cosmetic medical offices I've ever been to!! The staff, Dr. Gupta and Dr. Mehta are wonderful!! Angela and staff offer great customer service, they're extremely friendly and have always been very attentive to the needs of clients. Dr. Gupta and Dr. Mehta make you feel at ease and very comfortable with any procedures you plan on doing. The office is also very clean and professional. Definitely come here and you won't be disappointed! Get ready for this office to Beautify you in SD!! ;)

Panda is decent, fairly-priced Chinese and good sushi.  Their sushi really is very good (a lot of reviewers say that they haven't tried it; I'd rather get sushi from here than from Arigato, for instance, because I think it tastes better and it is significantly cheaper).  Also, their food is tasty and generally isn't very greasy.  Service is quick and the people who work there are nice.

Proprietor/Chef: Tony Maws

STELLAR!! one of the rare reviews i've seen that merits all 5 stars and actually spot on.  i give it my high five.  

a gf and i originally was planning on going to cuchi cuchi instead.  the hostess with her fancy red lipstick and avant garde look, much like the rest of the restaurant and its decor.  its presence is to be seen and to be remembered.  something unforgettable that's for sure.  as much as i was looking forward to eating here, 45-60 minute wait was unacceptable.  especially considering my last real meal was 7 hours ago.  glucose levels decreasing by the minute.  NO CAN DO!!!

we rolled through next door to craigie (not an easy name to remember btw)...without reservations at the main table (next time slot avail. @ 10pm) we gladly seated ourselves at the bar.  what the hell, i have more fun sitting at the bar anyways, as past references will tell.  

the one thing i didn't like about sitting at the bar was my view away from the open, visible kitchen.  I was in love with the set up.  everything prepped, cleaned, cook right in front of your very eyes.  Transparent as day & night.  Clearly, my level of trust on the food here was in their hands now...

i decided to go with the mussels when a couple adjacent to the corner of us, had their monstrosity of a burger come out.... the husband saw my dimly light eyes bright up... and said "she's been thinking about this burger all day...since 2pm".  better than sex i thought?  i so desperately wanted to find out. i quickly chased down the bartender who kindly enough was able to change my order just in the nick of time. 

Local Grass-Fed Burger - stuffed with cheese, house made sesame bun, mace ketchup, home made celery root slaw and pickles and the thinnest shoe string fries ever made on earth.  tasted straight like potato stix from the can, plus the chives, garlic and cayenne pepper that it was topped with.  amazing crack substance, i mean...additive.  it was the perfect complement to the over-sized juiced burger.  safely medium please.  i put my money on eating "half" the burger before giving up.  the fries, the burger... gracious gluttony.  i'd be a complete fatty (and quite the feat) if i were able to finish it.  gluttony knows boundaries too...and i still had a "night" to get through.  the comatose would just have to wait a few more hours.   

ladies and gentleman, i have to say for the first time in about 10 years, i forgo seafood for RED MEAT...and it felt wonderful.  my friend highly enjoyed her sturgeon... she offered, but i happily declined.  i was much content stuffing my face with the burger & fries instead.  that's what she said!

it's important to note that this place is not your typical, traditional french fare.  rather modern american, nuances of french infused.  this place is brilliant- for upscale foodies, saavy'nites, masochists, modernists... forgo the well mannered, prim & proper tables and get your ass to the bar and enjoy the food there...(unless you obviously want to try the tasting menu...which i definitely do for next time...)  it's one hell of an experience wherever you end up.  or be smart and call to make reservations ahead of time.  that's what she said...

The prices are low, but it's not worth it.  This place constantly spews a cloud of greasy smoke over the Ave and if that's not a fair warning, let this be. 

The service and burgers are mediocre. The atmosphere is non-existent.   The seating seems cramped.  No reason to go here when you can go to A Burger Place for a dollar more.

i thought i was special discovering this place, its not that people dont come here an there isnt a line all the time....its that it's easy to walk by. and it seems most people do because they are headed for strada up the hill.

i don't feel special anymore bc now everyone's talking about milano.  oh well, its hard to be "unique" at berkeley anyway....

rant on cal later....milano now...but this is good, you're waiting for my review....waiting....see this is what you do in milano anyway.....there is always a line, and it curves too....38!!!!  still waiting.....41!!!! (those are orders being shouted into your ear while you wait by the way...has anyone else noticed they always call 38?) 

anyway....the wait is actually not bad, they are well staffed and everyone knows what they are doing. organization like this is refreshing. gooooooddddd espresso drinks, cheap (relatively) salads and they have a lot of seating.  not as many options for seating if you are looking to plug in your laptop, but airbears stretches here just fine...(no i won't tell you where to plug in your laptop, i dont want any more competition for that spot..nothing personal...). ooooooo skylight is a plus and the balcony area too..cute and cozy...

One of my Boston favorites. Excellent specials (including scallops when i was there) plus delicious (but sometimes overly rich) desserts. Parking is tough and while valet is nice, it isn't cheap - use the garage option for sure. The bar is a nice option for a more casual meal.

Because the portions are so huge, I get a half sandwich and salad.  I get the sandwich to go and eat the salad there, then I have leftovers for another meal.

Everything that I have eaten there tastes very fresh.  The price is reasonable, considering that I am able to split my meal into two.  Definitely a Berkeley staple.

If any place in Ann Arbor deserves 5 stars it is Zingerman's deli. 

It's expensive (for a deli) and can be a bit hassle when busy, despite the great customer service, but all negatives considered it is still the place where I would want to eat when I come back to AA. 

During my few years in Ann Arbor I felt the food of Ann Arbor did not live up to its reputation however Zingerman's did not disappoint. 

Tip: Order the large size sandwich. Considering everything at Zingerman's is pricey the upgrade to a large sandwich is reasonable.

Not taking rooftop reservations = lame. I'd rather have them use some sort of strict policy (see Muqueca). Grant.. we did get seating for our party of 7 just after we had all arrived, but waiting around for seating would have been annoying slash we all had somewhere to be after dinner! 

First off, if you're sitting by the edge of the roof, don't freak out or scream when you drop your stuff because there is a bit of ledge for you to rely on. So chillax. 

The menu is small but I definitely couldn't choose so I went in on a few dishes. Calamari, crab cakes, and the portobello mushroom salad.. on top of getting both desserts offered. Unlike my dining partner, I enjoyed a lot of the food we had. The calamari was good, not the best I've had, but good. The crab cake was fantastic and I really loved the portobello mushroom salad. I could probably eat that on the regular. The desserts were smallish and I wasn't a fan of the apple, but the chocolate was goood (rich.. so the smaller portion is good for 1 or 2.. not great when sharing with 7 people). 

Prices were okay but I felt like I was kicking in some moola for the view. I do love me a good breeze though. But.. service was slooowwwwww. Waiting was definitely the name of the game. I don't know if they assigned the waiters to tables on both floors or if they were short handed, but the place wasn't full, so I really didn't understand. This was my first time dining in though, so I'll have to report back. I have had drinks at the downstairs bar on a few occasions and the bartender has always been friendly. I'd definitely come back for drinks.. but I'd only come back for dinner if I had a little extra money to burn and enough time to laze about.

I was going to write a review almost exactly to the effect of Marie H's. Their food is outstanding, authentic Northern Italian, as in, Silvio moved here from Italy some time in the '90s or 2000s. Unfortunately, the service is "authentic Italian" too. I've had the exact same thing where they're using every single person working front of house to partially do a single task. It takes forever, it is funny in a Marx brothers kind of way, but it can also be extremely annoying. Also, they don't post what their pizzas of the day are anywhere, so they waste time telling every single person what each and every pizza is. 

Also, I tried to order delivery on a Saturday night, and they said they couldn't because their delivery driver (singular) had the night off or something--on a Saturday night. Then they pleaded with me to come pick up a pizza, but I drunk too much to drive and parking around there is a nightmare anyway.

The food is amazing, though, so it's worth the aggravation when you're (1) not in a hurry and/or (2) not going during lunch rush. Check out their little noticed desserts too! Excellent!

If you're getting something besides slices or soup, you can order online and just pick it up. You'd think this would reduce your wait time. It does, but only slightly.
pretty good fusion tacos and a bit expensive for truck food.

Yats is good. If you like cajun/creole, come here.
Their menu is limited but it's also a daily rotating menu.

I'd recommend bringing many friends, ordering everything and then sharing.
Delicious! Hit the spot... Beef ramen soup (3 alarm!!!)
i'm sure it's delicious based on the theme park lines, i'll revisit my stars when i actually have enough time (and a crossword puzzle in tote) to wait in line.  i'm sure it's worth it.
surly owner/manager really ruins the experience. Guy acts like he's paying you to eat his ice cream. If you have an extra ten minutes, go to the monrovia location; they are always cool and friendly!
Overpriced stuff with a great location...what can you do...you pretty much HAVE to buy stuff from here.  It's directly in the student center and close to almost everything in central campus.

After all the positive reviews I was very disappointed. The Civeche looked unappetizing. Tasted the same. We also had a crab app that had the texture of baby food and was just boring. We all had the Marisco and rice. It was just OK. Not worth the stop unless you have to be around the area.

Not many places do peanut butter ice cream well... JP Licks has cracked the code though!  And the peanut butter hard yogurt is incredible (especially considering it's much better for you).

The problem is that everything here is good... Oreo cake batter! Chocolate chip cookie dough! And their monthly special flavors are to die for!

It's not as gourmet as Christina's (Inman Square), but this place is consistently SOLID.

TIP: Get an ice cream cake from JP Licks for your next birthday.  They are indescribably good!

I am super upset. I had my friends from USC over and wanted to take them to what I thought would be a nice brunch in the village. I was sooooo embarrassed.

Here's the story: 
Sara S., "Where should we go eat before I have to drive back to LA?"
Me, "I really like this one place in the village!!" :D
Sara S., immediately on her phone, reading my yelp review: "SOUNDS GREAT! LETS GO!"

We walk in and wait to be seated.
Host: "Uhhhhh you can seat yourself (motioning to 2 open tables that havent been  cleared), or you can seat yourself somewhere else"
We wait. Should have known then that it was not gonna be a good experience. 

I ordered what I always end up getting here.... smoked salmon tartine and a glass of OJ. YUMUM. I also begged the bf to let me order a side of baguette, thinking i can ALSO eat baguette and white chocolate spread. 
We kinda finish up eating, but I haven't touched the baguette and I'm pretty stuffed (the bf knows me too well). I offer the bread to my friends, raving about the white chocolate spread. We wait 10 minutes to flag down a waiter to get us some spread. NO waiter wants to help us :( we finally get the attention of the manager. "Uhhhh, I don't have any open now sooooo......" and she walks off. UHHHHH, okay. I am now depressed. All I ant is white chocolate spread. I mention maybe buying a jar, just so they can try.

We must have looked pretty sad, because our waitress came by and asked if we needed anything. I mumble something about white chocolate spread...."I'll go get you one!" WHATTTT?! my eyes light up and i jump around in my chair. But deep down inside, I know she's teasing me.....the manager said there were none open.....

She comes back with an opened, HALF-USED bottle of white chocolate spread. WTF.

WTF.

Food: 3.5 stars
Service: 1 star

This is my first time to Bertucci, the food was great (exceeded my expectation), the price was very reasonable, but the service we experienced was horrible. The waitress was not rude, but was too busy to provide our needs. We were very glad to be seated right away on a Friday evening, but had to wait a long time to be greeted by our server. The server finally came after we told 2 other servers that we had been there for a while and would like to order. When the server finally came, she didn't apologize for the delay and seemed to be very busy and in a rush to take our order. 5 minutes after she took our order, she brought us rolls, but we had no utensils or plate. We asked for them, but before we can completed our sentence, she was already gone. Similar experience happened when we wanted to pay our bill. Last but not least, our drinks were never refilled the whole night, until after we paid the bill. 
The food was great at its price, but the service was too slow. They really need to hire more help for their servers!!
If the service was average, I would definitely visit frequently, but now I would have to think 3 times before I step into your restaurant.  

Oh yeah, as far as the food goes, I had the Ultimate Bertucchi Pizza, it's pretty good.
Price: The website has menu with prices.
Love It! The long lines are worth the wait for the simplest, yet most wonderful dessert: your very own customized ice cream cookie sandwich!

Place is awesome... The salsa bar
Is also great and awesome ... Nothing is expensive and goes over the price of 5.95 and the nachos are awesome . Chorizo and spicy ckn is especially good .. Though deducting one star for paying for refills on soda not cool

Cool little middle-eastern place. Just stopped in for a drink in the early evening (7) before a play at Central Square Theatre. Reminded me a little of Abu Zom Zom in the Haight. Food looked and smelled great but we didn't eat. Drinks a little weak.

I was once asked what I thought of Claremont... I could only come up with the answer of   "I don't" 

Why would anyone think of all two blocks of this hidden bourgeois wonderland made up of a several colleges with fancy old libraries? And it's probably for a good reason. I mean, it's technically in the 909, right? 

More puzzling is that it sits between Pomona and Rancho. Like a little gem surrounded by.. well, the rest of the I.E. But maybe that's a good thing. Maybe that's why when I drive into the area I feel like I was just transported to some place different... almost welcoming.. 

A small tucked away town with one gas station that could easily be mistaken for a Santa Barbara style city. Best of all is that next to the local art house, which prominently proclaims that none of its theaters are in 3D you have the Back Abbey. 

The Back Abbey is a place I heard about a while back and sort of just forgot. Again it's Claremont. But thanks to Matthew P. I decided that I was finally going to try them out and boy am I glad that I braved stepping foot into the 909 for it. 

I have to say, it's really a nice little area and I just feel bad that it's stuck at the gates of the I.E. Talk about bad luck. The city must have been in the bathroom when god was passing out town positions. But in an effort to make it up to this wonderfully quaint little village, he bestowed upon them a burger establishment that is worthy of saying "God Damn!" 

I mean, seriously, God damn, that is one tasty burger! 

It's almost as if you took Father's office and instead of being your literal father, you made it some spiritual one (hence the monk made brew and monastery appearance) Because this burger is heavenly with every bite you'll think you're getting closer to god. 

In theory I guess you are, considering the amount of calories one could expect to be had from such decadence. But yeah, this burger was a clear sign that yes, there is a higher being up above and yes, he loves hamburgers. 

All this coming from an atheist, so you know that's saying something. 

But yeah, the place has a very missionary look to it. I guess it doesn't hurt that it has a vast amount of Belgian beers for the offering. I mean, it's really a great beer selection. And even though I favor local craft beers a bit more, mainly because I can actually pronounce the beer's names, I have to say I don't have any problem making a fool out of myself in saying the beers here. 

Now I was eating alone and to some of you, eating alone, let alone drinking alone would be a sign of just being sad. No sir. How can anyone be sad with a good beer and a lot more fries that you need not share? 

I got myself a half order of fritas and even that seemed like way too many. Though I felt compelled to finish them all. How could you leave fries that have been double fried. Once in duck fat and once in soybean oil? It would truly be a sin and I already spent far too much time confessing for my sins eating that burger. No way do I want to confess anymore. 

Your gut instinct may be telling you to fight tooth and nail for a seat inside. I mean, it is cold (Well.. for SoCal, I guess), but I have to say that the outside patio seats were so much better than eating inside. A lot more chill. It also helped that they had heat lamps going so you really weren't feeling any of the cold anyway. 

And if you were, well there's always more beer to warm you up. And again, there's a lot of it. I mean, the main problem I have with Belgian beers is I always feel like a fool ordering the first two or three beers. Then after that I just blame the inability of pronouncing the name correctly on already tossing back a few. 

If there's one reason to go to Claremont it's for this burger.. and I guess to see how the 909 isn't all a complete wasteland you'd expect to see in some Mad Max movie. 

I mean, there's not even a single meth lab or RV in any part of town! But what there is, is some heroin level addiction in the form of their burger.
I have been here several times and have never left disappointed. Everything from the service to the food and wine is excellent!

Geoff's is definitely a Providence staple; it's just one of those "go-to" eateries that have been local favorites, thanks in part to starving college students who take classes right across from here.

The first thing that hits you when enter Geoff's is how monstrously BIG their menu is. Seriously, they have so many things to choose from, and after you've chosen a sandwich, you can customize it any way you want. But because there are just so many to choose from, I feel like some of their sandwiches are really good while others are just ok. 

My friend loved her Kevorkian (hot pastrami, bacon, cheddar cheese, lettuce, tomato, hot sauce) while I thought my Dead Head (sprouts, carrots, cold provolone, tomato, onion, oil & vinegar) wrap was ehh. I feel like at Geoff's, you should get a hot sandwich; they have these cool steamer things that they use to heat the meat and melt the cheese to utter perfection. So next time I'm back in Rhode Island, I'll definitely be getting a hot vegetarian sandwich.
 
I was also a little confused when I got my Dead Head wrap because it was different than what was on the menu. There weren't any carrots; instead, they were replaced by raw mushrooms. I also asked for a whole wheat wrap, but it came out in a green spinach wrap. And I don't think that the greens in my wrap was spinach; it tasted like romaine lettuce to me. So there might have been some misunderstanding when I placed my order, but these guys get crazy busy and they make all these sandwiches from memory, so I can't really blame them for mixing up a few ingredients. 

However, one of the best things about Geoff's is the people who work there; they're so cool! The guys making the sandwich always joke around with their customers, making the atmosphere very chill and casual and I immediately felt welcome there (even with a giant DSLR around my neck). The workers here are more than willing to recommend a sandwich for you, as well as tell you what's good that day.

This place definitely has a lot of character, and a must-visit if you're ever in Providence. i know I'll definitely be back next time I'm in the area, just to try another one of their sandwiches and say hi to the workers :)

A little word of advice to the management here:  Style and cleanliness do not begin and end in the hotel lobby.

This is the first Holiday Inn that I've ever stayed at that I was thoroughly disappointed in.  My boyfriend is a Preferred Club member, so we thought we would get great service during our recent stay here.  We booked a room for an entire week to vacation around the Finger Lakes and attend the Finger Lakes Wine Festival.  You would think that if a hotel has room availability and a preferred club member books a stay for an entire week, they would be given one of the best rooms for the money.  Not here.  We were given one of the worst rooms in what resembled "the welfare wing" of the hotel.  

Top 5 things that were so NOT right with our room and / or the overall hotel atmosphere / appearance:

1) Parking lot was too small for the size of the hotel:  almost every night when we got back from our day trips, the parking lot was jam packed and there were no spots available.  Instead of offering complimentary parking at the public garage directly across the street, the staff at the front desk pretty much just shrugged their shoulders and told us we were on our own to find parking (except for on the weekend, when parking in the garage across the way was free).  REALLY?  That's how you show your preferred club members appreciation for being loyal?

2) No refrigerator in our room (this is the only hotel I've ever stayed at where the room didn't have at least some sort of mini fridge)

3) Plumbing issues:  our sink kept backing up from the first time we used it and the faucet was installed incorrectly (you had to turn the handle to the "hot" side to get cold water and vice versa).

4) Overall cleanliness:  Rugs and floors throughout the building's public areas were dirty.  The rugs looked like they hadn't been properly vacuumed in weeks and there were a lot of cobwebs in the corners of the hallways and stairs.  The rug in our room was only vacuumed ONCE the entire week we stayed there.  There were cobwebs inside all of the lampshades in our room. Gross.

5) Overall, the amenities were severely lacking.  No complimentary continental breakfast for preferred members, ice / vending machines not conveniently located (especially considering that there was no mini fridge provided in the room), pillows and comforter were stained.

Another thing that bothered me about this place was the way they treat their staff.  The staff had an outdoor eating table / break area that consisted of a picnic table tucked away behind a high fence...DIRECTLY next to the garbage dumpster!  REALLY?!  That's how you treat your staff that works hard all day to keep this hotel afloat?  No wonder they can't be bothered doing a thorough cleaning job around the hotel if they are being treated that way!

Needless to say, we won't be staying here on our next visit to Ithica.  We'll be staying at the Hilton across the street or at a B&B and get better service for pretty much the same price!

I used to go here every once and awhile when I worked at the bookstore.  I normally would get their vegetarian chili, which is by far my favorite chili ever.  This is where I learned to put cinnamon in chili, yup, I would've never figured that out.  I don't remember trying anything else, because I would always be in chili mood.  The lines are sometimes ridiculous, and when you are hungry and have time constraints like I was most of the time, I would opt for the fruit salad truck, which would leave that empty chili-less void in my stomach for hours later.

Really this is more like a 2.5, but I'm going to round down.  For me, this El Mercado has a convenient location.  It's only a 2 block walk from my office.  So, since I failed to pack a lunch today, I decided to try this place out.  

I found the decor and atmosphere pleasant--lots of bright colors on the walls.  The center of the dining area featured a nice skylight and a fountain (no water in it).  The tables and booths were far enough apart that I didn't feel cramped.

Service was polite, and we got what we ordered, but the timing was a little off.  We got chips, but salsa didn't come for another 2 or 3 minutes.  Water refills were lagging.  It took a long time to get the check; then the server took a long time to come back and run our credit card, too.  They advertised "Express Lunch" and I didn't think they lived up to that at all.

The food wasn't bad though.  It wasn't particularly good, but with fajita chicken tacos for $5.75 (lunch menu) I thought I got my money's worth.    The lunch special, a carne asada burrito ($6.50), was sort of nasty though.  The sauce sort of tasted like gravy to me, and the meat was a weird texture.  I guess I was expecting the meat to be something like Chipotle's barbacoa, but it wasn't.  

It looked like they had some good happy hour deals, so I might check that out some time, but I probably wouldn't make and effort to go here for food again.

The Archives are an amazing place. You can truly get in touch with our nation's history by visiting here. Remember to have your research topic well planned out. The staff will be glad to help you, but they will need more than guesses and hunches.

If you are looking for someone who is strong enough to reach the furthest depths of you pain but aware enough not to hurt you than Dennis is you man.

I have seen Dennis several times now and I have to say my experiences only get better. I also love New Seattle Massage, the co-op in the University District where Dennis practices. The facilities are spotless, fresh clean towels always available for use and for a small extra fee you can use the steam room and sauna. 

My first visit with Dennis was a last minute call looking for coinciding appointments for my partner and I. Normally I wouldn't chose to see a male practitioner but I have to say I am very happy that I opened my mind and pushed my own boundaries to give Dennis a chance.

Dennis is a soft spoken man who very quietly and gently asks you about why you are there and what you are looking for. Actually his demeanor is so gentle that when I laid on his table I was quite shocked but the significance of his touch. Dennis has strong hands but is keenly aware of my reactions to his touch and always seems to adjust his pressure intuitively. 

Dennis has a routine. My massages are almost always the same with him but they are different than with any other massage therapist I have ever seen. Dennis uses the usual techniques but he also has some unusal moves that one might prefer to be prepared for. This is not a lay down and go to sleep for an hour kind of massage. Dennis requries some passive participation. The first time he asked me to grip his hand and pulled me to the top of the table leaving my head and arms hanging I was a little leery but as I hung there for a moment I felt the stretch relieving tension in places I never expected to be relieved. 

The biggest difference between Dennis and other LMP's I have worked with is that he is there to relieve your aching body not just through rubbing but stretching also. He has a way of making me feel relaxed and comfortable, to trust him when it is against my instinct. 

I have just made another appointment to see Dennis tommorow. I think this will be my 5th or 6th visit with him and I am so looking forward to it!

Steve is the best. Other staff members rock as well-- fun, happy, nice, and hip. Frames are the best selection ANYWHERE and believe me, I have been looking for years for just the right frames. I like classic with humorous twists, well-made and unique-looking frames and this place was a treasure trove for me. Even though it looks small inside, they have a ton of great sizes, colors, and shapes. Great customer service. Have already purchased 2 pr of progressive bifocals there and will def be back.

I miss this place like crazy.  I used to go here all the time when I was in school. Now that I'm home, I crave it all the time.  :[  The naan is still the best that I've had yet, although the guy who used to make it would stalker stare at me and my friends.  The vindaloo is very spicy and yummy, and the mango lassi is great.  The price is great too.  Indian food is usually expensive and small portioned, but this place is a good buy for the money.  I love it!
Excellent place to sit and have a beer, or 20.  There are even heaters in the backyard in case the beer isn't working.  Dogs also welcome.

Coupons were not honored as written. It is clearly written on my coupons "Limit one per customer" but when I arrived at the place, I was told that only one coupon is allowed per table, not per customer.

The other yelpers are right: Golden Wok has THE best pad thai around (and it's not even a thai restaurant, it's "chinese/thai," a combination I usually stay far far away from).  Correction: Golden Wok has the best pad thai EVER.  And yes, this is comparing it against not only the local places, but also every thai restaurant I've ever been to, and I've been to plenty.  The reason why their pad thai is so good is because of the flavoring: A lot of other Thai places either don't have enough of it, or they have so much that it's overly sweet and/or salty and it becomes so cloying I can't ever bear to finish it.  Golden Wok's pad thai, on the other hand, is done so well I finished it very quickly in one sitting...and as others have said, their portions are VERY generous.  Besides the flavor, the noodles are also done well, not mushy and stuck together, and not undercooked, and overall the dish isn't too oily either.  Four stars for the delicious pad thai all on its own; I haven't tried anything else there but we'll see how that goes...like I said, I usually stay away from "chinese/thai" places, but I feel like Golden Wok has earned my respect, if nothing else for their pad thai.
They have their own lot, so parking isn't as bad as it is on campus.  Look out for the small yellowish standalone building; it's easy to drive past it.

Amazing menus!  There is just about any kind of sandwich you can think of in here, with about 10 vegetarian options.  When you walk in, they have a big vat of free pickles, which is an easy way into my heart.  The employees are warm and friendly, and it has the great feel of a hole-in-the-wall sandwich shop.  I got the monster lisa, which wasn't quite as good as I thought it would be, but everything else made it a very pleasant experience.

Reasonably priced food in Westwood that also happens to be In-N-Out. Probably explains why the wait for food is always, always long at this location. Alas, a victim of their own success.

Still, it's In-N-Out. Hard to argue with the food.

My favorite uncle hates me. He doesn't really hate me. It's more of an indifference towards me that borderlines hate which is exactly why I adore him. He's sarcastic, funny, has great taste, has a killer apartment that I would give my left eye for, his partner is one of my favorite family members, and he is very devoted to my grandparents while managing to avoid all other family drama. I respect the man more than I could ever say even though we've never really connected on any level. Buona Tavola changed all this. 

My grandparents are true blue meat and potato republicans. After going to Tahoe Joe's one too many times I finally conned them into trying something different the last time I visited. My uncle usually avoids all family functions but he jumped at the chance to eat here as it was one of his favorite restaurants. Once I knew my uncle wanted to eat here I knew it would be a five star experience.

The food is AMAZING. The salads were light enough to not ruin the pasta overload I was about to experience. The gnocchi wasn't swimming in an overly heavy sauce (this is a good thing). The Linguine fradiavolo was one of the greatest things I've ever put in my mouth. They made my grandparents a fettuccine alfredo, since they wouldn't eat anything on the menu,  that was to die for. 

If you are coming here for dinner keep the party under 6 if you are going to sit inside as the place is very intimate. The wedding I was in town for coincidentally was having the rehearsal dinner (20+ people) here in the outside section the same night and the bride said everything was amazing. 

4 star experience bumped up to a 5 star now that my uncle sees me as more of a grown up. ....he really does hate kids.

The beautiful campus is worth walking around, even for folks who haven't heard of it or don't care.

Here's my recommended tour for the time pressed:
Approach the university from University Ave, driving down Palm Drive. Park in the Oval, check out the folks sunbathing/playing frisbee/picnicking/etc. in the Oval, and then walk through the main quad to Memorial Church. Check out the Rodin sculptures on your way, and then check out the church, including all the cool inscriptions in and around it. Then walk to White Plaza, the bookstore, and the student union. After milling around and buying some Stanford paraphernalia, head to Hoover Tower. Pay $2 to go up to the top floor and take in the beautiful view of the campus and the surrounding Bay Area. Then head back to the Oval, and stop by the Cantor Arts museum before you leave. It's got great rotating exhibits, plus a nice permanent exhibit on the history of the school. If you've still got time, go play a round of golf on the world class golf course (at a world-class golf course price :( ), or go for a hike up the dish.

Five stars because it's my alma mater and the school color is the most beautiful shade of red on earth. Plus, the students, faculty, and staff are generally friendly, kind, inspirational, brilliant, fun, and all around wonderful.

Having finally received my $25 for $12.50 gift card from the Sunday Paper, I dragged a buddy down to Spoon to give 'em a try. The place was easy enough to get to on a Tuesday night, and parking was easy. As we walked to the restaurant, their neighbor had some folks standing on the sidewalk giving out samples of what appeared to be some sort of Slush Puppy, but neither of us tried it; we decided that would be our dessert.

We were seated quickly, but when our server showed up barely a minute later with water, he didn't offer to take our drink orders, but wanted to know if we were ready to order. Huh? We'd barely had time to figure out what we wanted to drink. We told him we weren't ready to order our entrees yet, and he said ok and walked off. Hmmm... restaurants usually push the $10 drinks and $5 beers, and I even made the comment "no drinks for us, I suppose."

Our server did come back a few minutes later and took our drink, appetizer and entrée orders. Our spring rolls and chicken satay came out first. While the spring rolls were very light and airy, they lacked taste in addition to weight. Had they had any flavor at all, they would have been the best spring rolls I've ever had. The chicken satay was good, but not noteworthy.

For our entrees, I went with the Cashew Nut Stir-Fry, and my buddy went with the Golden Red Snapper. My stir fry was ok, but nothing to write home about. It didn't really taste like there was very much seasoning on it, but it was satisfying with its small bowl of jasmine rice. My buddy's snapper came out on a sizzling griddle like fajitas at a Mexican restaurant. I didn't taste it, but there wasn't anything left on his plate when he was done. Perhaps there's a reason the menu refers to it as "our house favorite".
