All in all, the food wasn't spectacular, but it wasn't bad either... just mediocre. I won't make a special trip to Spoon, but if I'm in the area I'd go back. As for our free dessert from the place next door (something about Chicago in the name), they weren't there when we left so I had to go to bed with no dessert. Perhaps I should have followed Eric's lead and stopped at Dairy Queen!

Not impressed. The food seemed sloppily prepared--the sauces were just poured straight out of the bottle or can--canned/frozen vegetables (and even those in short supply). Not coming back again, ever.

The first thing you have to say about Laughing Turtle is that this store knows its market really really well. They have those cute Buzz and Berly UNC logo dresses and skirts and Carolina bags and wallets - even jewelry made with Carolina blue beads and freshwater pearls. And if you're a Carolina student, you'll probably go nuts over this stuff - I would. 

However, there's plenty here for a non-UNC person to like as well. They have lots of fun casual and dressy clothes, many by this brand "joyous and free" which has cute stuff at very reasonable prices. Downstairs is more casual, upstairs has lots of dressier, cocktail-type dresses in brands like London Times and Adrianna Papell. There's also lots of non-Carolina blue jewelry to pick from, books, gifts (ice cream soap!) and a good selection of Hobo International bags. 

One of the coolest things about this store is that they feature the work of Elaine O'Neil, who creates these colorful Chapel Hill landscapes in pieces of fabric. At Laughing Turtle, you can buy her pictures as prints, on notecards or on decorative pillows.

Alexander's is an extraordinary family-owned old fashioned Italian restaurant.

Highlights: Homemade rice pudding, tiramisu. Sorry, desserts first.

The bread is fresh and is served with oil, vinegar, and parmesan cheese.

Traditional antipasto is delicious and made to suit the size of your party. For appetizers, the fried ravioli and calamari fritti are to die for. Entrees: the cream sauces, red sauces, and the pesto are all delicious but my favorite is the Marfredo Sauce, a mix of marinara and alfredo. The Marfredo goes really well with sliced spicy Italian sausage.

PS. The service cannot be beat. It's one of the friendliest restaurants I have eaten in. I used to go there often when I was a student living in Bloomfield.

i love this place simply because I can get hot cooked after you order chinese food with soup, rice, and an eggroll for under $6!

I recommend the meat/veggies dishes with black bean sauce and not so much for the sweet and sour pork/fried meats.  

really...all i get is mushroom chicken. everytime.

BLECH! The first time I went there about a year ago, my boyfriend woke up with the stomach flu - no way to tell where he picked it up so we gave them the benefit of the doubt. 

I went back this weekend for dinner on Friday night and before I was even walking out of the restaurant I felt nauseous. I was miserably ill all through the company party we went to afterward and when I got home my body finally rejected the Mexican Melt and the blueberry beer I got. As soon as that happened I was back to my old self! 

BLECH.

Yes, the incredible number of choices can be daunting- but oh the fun you will have trying things out!  Food comes out straight from the stove (be careful with that first bite) and is well worth the wait.

One of the reviewers mentioned a review in the Champaign Taste blog that might give you ideas of what to order. Another blogger has been posting pictures and descriptions at http://goldenharborchineserestaurant.blogspot.com/. 

I was inspired by one the pictures to order #896 (Snow pea leaves with King Mushrooms) - which included the greens and two kinds of thinly sliced mushrooms in a savory brown sauce (with lots of whole garlic cloves). Wow. In Hawaii, we would say "broke da mouth"!

A warning - we arrived at 5:30 PM on a Saturday, and a lot of the tables were already reserved (which meant not a lot of tables left for walk-ins). If you have a party of more than 2-4 you might want to call ahead on a weekend.  Even if you have to wait, it will be well worth it!

I thought it said OK Noodle on the front, but apparently this place goes under a different name...

I loved the old vinyl record cover menu, food art (dry noodles!) on the wall, and friendly staff. Although my visit to this restaurant was well after the normal dinner rush hour, the service was a bit slow (because the waitstaff was super friendly and willing to explain each dish in detail helping other customers pick dishes...)

A lot of the dishes on the menu have a bit silly names. I think mine was called something like Yum Yum Noodles (noodle soup + 5 star spiciness), and my boyfriend had Crazy Noodles (stir-fried flat rice noodles + 5 star spiciness). They were both flavourful (sweet, salty, sour, chewy, crunchy all at the same time), delicious, and not obnoxiously spicy. The only bummer about the food was the deep-fried tofu. I was hoping for fresh kind. Also, the tofu was deep-fried for a bit too long and exploded (super crunchy on the outside and nothing left on the inside).

Their shortcomings can be easily overlooked; I'll probably go back there and try something different!

I really don't understand the hype of this place. I've been here twice, and each time I'm left unsatisfied. I distinctly remember ordering a pastrami sandwich once, and walked out with a roast beef sandwich. How the hell could they screw that up? It's a simple sandwich, and they should know what kind of meat pastrami looks like. Their salads look incredibly huge, and I probably will never be able to finish it, so I'd rather stick with the salads at GBC. 

All in all, I've experienced better places.

Good and cheap Chinese food right at MIT's backyard. 
The lunch specials are simply amazing.  If it weren't such a walk from campus, I would totally be coming here all the time!
This salad and sandwich joint is a Berkeley staple.  The portions are nice and big, and often so is the line.

I hate working out.  It's boring, and there's all these strangers around sweating and grunting.  It's nasty, it hurts, it's expensive, and I don't want to do it.  But I finally got to thinking this year, it's time to commit to this.  I did the free week membership at one of those large basement gyms where there's, like, 236 people in a row on all these machines and a used band-aid on the bathroom floor.  No thanks.  I need somewhere quiet and clean.  Something small scale where no one has to witness my paltry feats of strength.

Vim Fitness is new, small, and somewhat undiscovered.  It's tastefully furnished with all new equipment, located above the Karma Yoga Studio with a view of Mass Ave below, and the founder/personal trainer, Pierre, is a nice guy.  Fortunately, my company made a discount deal, because otherwise I'd never be able to afford this place, so be warned.  Being so new, it has its share of growing pains (I joined in June and was just given a membership card today), but it's relatively uncrowded.  Usually it's just me and a few others.  Sometimes I'm completely alone.

There are about 3 treadmills, 5 ellipticals, 2 bikes, 3 spinning bikes, and ample free weights and machines.  Because the space is so limited, there is the potential for feeling like you're in someone's way when they're having their personal training session (tonight I almost got hit by a dropped medicine ball).   The thing is, so far, even on the busiest day, there was never a problem adjusting my schedule to work around people so I could use the machine or flat bench I wanted, which is exactly what a whiney fitness-hating prole like myself needs.

MODsquad employees create a warm courteous experience form bikers of all levels. I'm amazed by how they attentive and patient thy can be whether working with a triathlete or a 10 year old trying to his chain put back on. I've been riding for over a year now consistently and while I consider this my local bike shop (LBS) I have made visits to other shops for comparison sake. I'm amazed at how some sales poeple eith aggressively ipsell your or pay you know mind unless your wallet is out. The is never my experience at MODsquad. It is definitely a bike shop I would travel to if it weren't in my neighborhood. If you can't settle on a LBS that you where you can find reliable service and knowledgeable technicians come by.
Awesome food, great service and a wonderful atmosphere! Our whole family loves Flemings!!

I like exploring the Town and Country Plaza and Hobee's was our next place to try for breakfast / brunch.

Like what the stars say "Meh, I've experienced better."

They offer complimentary coffee out front.

First, our server acted like he hated life and that we were a road bump in it. I was a little confused with the wording on their menu regarding the combination of a breakfast item, he did not try to explain it to me, but gave attitude as if I was the dumbest customer of the day.

Second, food was mediocre and presentation was average.

GOOD:
* BLUEBERRY COFFEECAKE - nice BIG slice, not too sweet.

OKAY:
* THE EYE OPENERS - 2 farm fresh eggs, served with "Country-style" hashbrowns, and your choice of Blueberry Coffeecake or toast and one choice: ham / chicken apple sausage / pork sausage / steamed veggie / turkey bacon / chorizo
- everything was average, the turkey bacon was dried out almost jerky like

* WAFFLE WITH FRESH FRUIT - the waffle was limp and chewy (like the frozen ones I buy from the supermarket and nuke in the microwave.) BUT, the fruit was sweet.

I was very sad with my first experience at a Hobee's, I'm not inclined to visit their other locations.

Surprisingly good food.  We had the calamari appetizer which crispy and not too chewy, tomato based dipping sauce had nice flavor.  We shared a family size chicken parm, it was one of the best chicken parms that I've had at a restaurant, tender chicken, crispy coating,...very well done.   Atmosphere is nice.

OMG fries, double down short rib meat... legitt
short rib tacos are good too and the kimchi quesadillas but before all else, you gotta get the fries.. its my guilty pleasure when im trying to pig out for a day lol

Great dogs, but Top Dog fanatics will be saddened to hear that their dogs have been replicated by several places across the bay in San Francisco. I must say that they were a main stay of my early years in Berkeley before I expanded my tastes and you can't really go wrong with any hot dog here.

I miss the days when they were cheaper though. It's usually a last resort to go to Top Dog now in my post-student days, but for the new students, it's a must-have experience.

Dr. Allendorf has terrible bedside manner, he is not only insulting in his comments, but makes you feel like an inadequate parent. He is insensitive and gave advice contradicting most advice I read about (getting your baby to sleep, setting a routine), example, advising to leave your 1 month old to cry it out in the crib. As if a 1 month old knows how to manipulate?! I am a first time mother, and Dr.Allendorf has done something to upset me at each and every appointment. He is sarcastic and frankly I feel like my daughter would be afraid of him by the time she was old enough to discriminate people's personalities. The staff is kind, and I'm not sure how they put up with him and this busy practice. This place is like a baby mill, there are at least 20 kids cycling through at any given moment, so you feel very rushed. He also makes you feel like your questions are dumb. I highly recommend you find ANOTHER pediatrician for your child, for you and your child's overall good.
Get yo Greek on! Awesome place!

Im a regular customer here. The manager knows me and some of the workers do. Its a cool store, I get most of my clothes here. Its easy and cool clothes to wear. The flex-fleece hoodies are the best and the tri-blend cardigan.

Perfect.  From the moment we pulled up I was blown away.  The families hanging outside, the neighborhood feel, the smell coming from the kitchen...love at first site/smell.  The experience for me was right on.  Nothing lacked.  Bravo.  AND I never looked at the menu.  I'll be back.  Mike

I expected a much more rigorous curriculum but the social work program, although top rated, didn't live up to that. I had some great professors and one terrible one. There was lots of reading on top of the field work and a few papers. I made some great friends here but, in hindsight, I might have looked at more affordable schools. I know having Columbia on my resume has opened doors but I'm not sure if it was worth the money. I spent my first year in the old building and the new building is much better. There's a nice little selection of restaurants nearby for lunch and happy hour.

Just a half block from my office, it's a place I drifted into like a masterless samurai in a stupor when I was desperately looking for a place to get lunch in 20 minutes.

The food here is very good, but I appreciate it because it tastes like similar food does in Japan.  Others may have a preference for certain ways in which Japanese food has been Americanized, but if you're interested in Japanese food that tastes the way it does in Japan, this is a great little place.

For example, I'm often startled (yes, startled) to be served tempura that has been sitting around for a few minutes.  Like radioactive elements, hot food (especially things like tempura) have a half-life, only instead of losing half of its radioactive particles, hot food loses half of its deliciousness.  In the case of tempura, it's very hard for any food to be better than just-cooked tempura.  After about five minutes, you'd take it over eggplant.  After ten minutes, you'd eat it rather than starve.  Probably.

At Matsuri, the tempura is served immediately, which of course is how it's done in Japan.  My years in Japan made me a bit of a fanatic for hot food, western convention of serving all food at once be damned.

The sushi is also good, although any place that uses fresh fish, actual sushi chefs, japanese rice and the right kind of vinegar in the rice should produce sushi that is good enough for the great majority of flavor dullards, including me.  When you taste that the fish has been frozen or when the rice is al dente, you know you've made a wrong turn at Albuquerque, but that's definitely not the case at Matsuri.

Tar Heel Taxi is great when it comes to scheduling a pick up to or from the airport because they always arrive on time and get you there quickly. Without an appointment in advance, though, it is difficult to get them to come pick you up. I forgot to call well in advance last time I was going to RDU, and they said it wouldn't be a problem and someone would arrive with in 15 minutes. Much to my disappointment, no one ever showed up, and I had to beg a friend to take me. Just remember to call ahead and you will be fine, otherwise try someone else.

I am IN LOVE with this place. I worked two events here this past week. Utopia has SO much character!!!! It's split into three sections: The Ice Ultralounge, Shangri-La and Utopia. Each section has its own personality and somehow everything works without being too gaudy. Seriously, I would just come here to stare at the wall. 

Didn't really get a chance to partake in the food since I was working, but the calamari and chicken were pretty good.

Ice is the dance section of the Utopia, and, you guessed it...it's blue and gray/silver. Nice, spacious dance floor with plenty of mirrors to assure you that you are looking your best!

Utopia is the "main" room, of course...this is where the sushi bar is and food is served. This room has SO much going on but somehow it works. I love it. There are several flat screen TVs around so you can catch up on the latest game. Waterfall wall that is hot!...Ample seating with a very sexy section of about 4 or 5 booths in the back. 

Shangri-La is downstairs. Bright green walls and modern furniture decorate this cutesy area...it reminds me of a beautifully furnished basement. There is also a small bar down here. 

We should have a Yelp event here!!!
